site_title: New fund gets S$1m committed capital to help migrant workers in Singapore
summary: A Singapore-based venture philanthropy organisation, LEAP201, has received S$1 million in committed capital to support migrant workers during and beyond the Covid-19 pandemic. The fund, in collaboration with migrant worker organisations, will provide assistance in areas like emergency financial relief, mental health support, and legal aid. Anchor donors include Kewalram Chanrai Group and United Overseas Bank, with grants of S$30,000 to S$50,000 to be disbursed over the next six quarters. The fund aims to address structural challenges faced by migrant workers, including potential retrenchment due to outstanding loans.

site_title: We can change - if we truly want to
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic has shown that societies and individuals can rapidly respond to immediate threats, leading to unprecedented measures to flatten the curve and mitigate its impact. This crisis has also highlighted the potential for a more sustainable world, with a significant decrease in greenhouse gas emissions globally. The sudden and drastic measures, such as lockdowns, have resulted in a decrease of pollution in countries like China, India, Europe, and the US. The crisis has also led to the development of new technologies and business models, with companies adapting to meet the needs of the pandemic. As the crisis subsides, it is likely that some of these changes will persist, including a shift towards remote work, freelancing, and sustainable practices.

images.alt_text: Seaweed floats in Venice's canals as the water turned clear when motorboat traffic was stopped as the country went into a lockdown. With more than half the world's population in lockdown, one of the most obvious consequences has been the sudden and tremendous decrease in pollution.

site_title: Japan bread maker fails to rise with people stuck baking at home
summary: Japan's largest baker, Yamazaki Baking Co., reported disappointing first-quarter results, with its "sweet buns" segment experiencing a 1% decline in sales compared to the previous year. The company's shares plummeted 18% due to the drop in sales, the largest in 33 years. Analysts attribute the decline to the impact of the pandemic on consumer behavior, with a boost to bread sales but a drag on pastries. The company's revenue is expected to be affected in the second quarter, with sales of bakery products likely to be weak in April.

site_title: India's Bollywood star Rishi Kapoor, 67, dies of leukemia
summary: Indian actor Rishi Kapoor, 67, died Thursday after a two-year battle with leukemia. Kapoor, a celebrated Bollywood star and scion of a famed film industry family, was diagnosed with cancer in 2018 and treated in New York before returning to Mumbai last September. His death follows that of fellow actor Irrfan Khan, 54, who also suffered from cancer. Kapoor's family urged fans to follow social distancing rules due to the novel coronavirus pandemic, and Prime Minister Narendra Modi praised Kapoor's "multifaceted, endearing and lively" talent.

site_title: Euro zone economy shrinks at record rate, worse to come
summary: The eurozone economy contracted at a record rate of 3.8% in the first quarter of 2020, with economists expecting even worse numbers for the second quarter due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Inflation slowed sharply to 0.3% month-on-month in April, but core inflation measures showed prices growing 0.7% on the month. Unemployment ticked up to 7.4% in March, and economists predict it will increase in the coming months. The European Commission has proposed a recovery plan to help finance an economic recovery in the bloc.

images.alt_text: The eurozone economy contracted at a record rate in the first three months of the year and inflation slowed sharply as much economic activity in March came to a halt because of the Covid-19 pandemic, data showed on Thursday.

site_title: Virgin Australia has 20 potential buyers, deal seen by June: administrators
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings has 20 potential buyers for its sale, with negotiations underway for a June deadline. Administrators from Deloitte Australia have given eight buyers access to a data room and are in talks with another 12. Private equity firms Apollo Global Management and Oaktree Capital Management, as well as US-based Indigo Partners, are among the interested parties. The airline owes nearly A$7 billion to creditors, and administrators are seeking to restructure and sell the airline by the end of June.

site_title: GCCP gains approval to resume operations in Malaysia
summary: GCCP Resources, a quarrying firm, has received approval from Malaysian authorities to resume operations in full capacity, subject to precautions such as temperature checks, mask-wearing, and safe distancing. The company had halted operations in March due to the movement control order and had applied for permits to resume with a minimum workforce. GCCP's operations in Perak will resume on May 12, after the end of the current movement control order. The company's shares rose 0.1% to close at S$0.007.

site_title: Banks to follow standard deferment of more consumer loans: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced that banks will follow a standard deferment of consumer loans, including industrial and commercial property, renovation, education, and car loans, from May 6. Borrowers can defer principal payments for industrial and commercial property loans until the end of this year, while mortgage equity withdrawal loan borrowers can defer either principal or both principal and interest payments. Other measures include extending loan tenures, refinancing investment property loans, and waiving fees for failed deductions. The MAS aims to provide further support to affected individuals amid the challenging economic outlook.

site_title: Shell cuts dividend for first time since 1940s as oil demand collapses
summary: Royal Dutch Shell cut its quarterly dividend to 16 US cents per share, the first time since the 1940s, due to the collapse in global oil demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The company also suspended its share buyback program. CEO Ben van Beurden stated that the move is to bolster Shell's resilience and support long-term value creation. The decision reflects the significant uncertainty in the macroeconomic outlook.

site_title: Europe: Stocks jump at open on virus treatment hope
summary: Europe's major equity indices rose at the open on Thursday, driven by news of a possible breakthrough in testing for a coronavirus treatment. London's FTSE 100 advanced 0.6%, Frankfurt's DAX gained 1.1%, and Paris's CAC 40 rose 1.0%. The positive sentiment was attributed to the potential development in virus treatment, boosting global investor confidence.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on optimism over virus drug
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 2.1% to 20,193.69, following positive news of a coronavirus drug trial. The broader Topix index added 1.0% to 1,464.03. The rally is seen as a boost to investor optimism, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS' oil-and-gas portfolio is its largest loan exposure to industries hit by Covid-19, totaling S$23 billion. Singapore manufacturing and services firms are pessimistic about the next six months due to the pandemic. Deliveroo laid off 25% of its Singapore staff. Grab extended financial assistance for its drivers, but warned it may not extend past June 1. SIA shareholders voted in favor of a S$15 billion cash call. The STI recorded a 4.2% gain this week, while Vietnam was surprised by a US tariff announcement and the Asian garment industry braced for higher US tariffs.

site_title: Thailand to reopen some businesses as new coronavirus cases slow
summary: Thailand is set to reopen some businesses on Sunday, including outdoor markets, barber shops, and pet groomers, as the number of new coronavirus infections drops to single digits. The country reported 7 new cases, bringing the total to 2,954 cases, with 54 deaths. Reopened businesses will include small retailers, street food stalls, and restaurants outside shopping malls, but department stores, movie theaters, and most indoor sports venues will remain closed. The government will continue to monitor the situation for 14 days before deciding to ease restrictions further.

site_title: SocGen posts loss as equities traders are wiped out in rout
summary: Societe Generale (SocGen) posted a surprise first-quarter loss of 326 million euros due to significant losses in equities trading, with revenue from equities trading and hedge funds declining 99% to 9 million euros. The bank set aside 820 million euros to cover bad loans and incurred losses of 200 million euros on cancelled dividend payments. Despite a 32% gain in fixed-income trading, SocGen's trading business declined 40% and the bank plans additional cost reductions of 600-700 million euros this year.

site_title: Google 'task force' fights bad Covid-19 ads
summary: Google's task force has blocked tens of millions of coronavirus-related ads for policy violations, including price-gouging and misleading claims. The task force, led by ads vice-president Scott Spencer, is building new detection technology and improving enforcement systems to stop bad actors. Since recent months, Google has removed and blocked marketing pitches for bogus cures, illegitimate unemployment benefits, and overpriced medical supplies. This effort aims to protect users from misinformation and maintain a safe online environment.

site_title: UOB, SPH, Singtel to provide 250 laptops, digital resources to disadvantaged students in Singapore
summary: UOB, Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), and Singtel are partnering to provide 250 laptops and digital resources to disadvantaged students in Singapore, supporting remote learning amid the coronavirus outbreak. The UOB My Digital Space programme aims to bridge the digital gap for children from disadvantaged backgrounds. The initiative includes a new laptop, Wi-Fi dongle, and online learning resources, such as newspaper subscriptions. The programme will be available for a year, with optional extension and technical support.

site_title: Africa health startup gets investment from Dubai venture firm, Tencent
summary: Dubai-based Global Ventures has co-led a $7 million investment in Helium Health, West Africa's largest electronic medical records provider, alongside AAIC Japan and China's Tencent. This investment aims to address the significant gap in recorded hospital visits across Africa, where only 30% of visits are documented. Global Ventures sees health tech as a promising sector, similar to fintech's success over the past five years. The investment follows a surge in demand for life sciences and digital health technology amid the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares rise at Thursday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 11 points or 0.8% to 1,391.32 on Thursday, with 337 gains outweighing 69 losses. Trading volume reached 380.9 million lots worth RM150.6 million.

site_title: Japan's factory output, retail sales slump as virus hits economy
summary: Japan's factory output declined 3.7% in March, the largest drop in five months, due to the coronavirus pandemic. Retail sales also dropped as businesses struggled with reduced overseas and domestic demand. The global economy may suffer its worst downturn since the Great Depression, with Japan's economy facing stagnation due to its export dependence and soft domestic consumption. This slowdown is attributed to the virus-driven collapse of activity, affecting both overseas and domestic markets.

site_title: Malaysia's Sapura sees delay in energy projects as pandemic hits demand
summary: Malaysia's Sapura Energy expects delays in energy projects due to the pandemic's impact on oil demand and prices. The company's CEO, Shahril Shamsuddin, cited a 10% increase in Brent crude to $24.90 a barrel, but noted it's still near a 20-year low. Sapura aims to lower operating costs by 500 million ringgit per year and is budgeting for a long-term oil price of $40-$45 per barrel. The company posted a loss of 4.23 billion ringgit in the fourth quarter, with revenue down 25% due to the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore's manufacturing, services firms pessimistic about next six months amid pandemic
summary: Singapore's manufacturing and services sectors are pessimistic about the next six months due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. Manufacturing firms' business sentiment turned sharply negative, with a net weighted balance of 56% expecting worse conditions ahead, while services firms' sentiment deepened to -58%, with 55% expecting operating receipts to fall. The sectors expect a decline in business activity, particularly in accommodation, food and beverage services, and retail trade, with employment forecasts also gloomy, especially in the accommodation sector.

site_title: SIA shareholders vote in favour of S$15b cash call
summary: Singapore Airlines' (SIA) shareholders voted 99.79% in favour of raising up to S$15 billion through a S$8.8 billion rights issue and convertible bond issue to address the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on the airline industry. The airline will use the funds to cover operating costs, aircraft purchases, and debt servicing. SIA has made sweeping capacity cuts, grounding 96% of its fleet, and has stored aircraft at Alice Springs in Australia. The decision comes as the airline industry faces an unprecedented crisis.

site_title: Coronavirus plunges French economy into worst post-war slump
summary: France's economy contracted by 5.8% in the first quarter of 2020, marking the sharpest decline since World War II. The contraction was attributed to a lockdown that left shops shuttered and consumers at home. This is the second consecutive quarter of economic contraction, technically placing France in recession. The decline is a significant blow to the French economy, which is struggling to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: France saw its sharpest economic contraction since World War II in the first quarter as a lockdown from mid-March left shops shuttered and consumers hunkered down at home, official data showed on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong stock market closed April 30, May 1 for public holidays
summary: Hong Kong's stock market closed on April 30 and May 1 for public holidays, resuming trading on May 4. This is unrelated to the article's content which discusses various market trends and news from other regions, including a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, a mandatory offer for PSC shares, and the US market reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: HDB launches EC site in Yishun, extends tender period to 6 months due to Covid-19
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched an executive condominium (EC) site in Yishun, extending the tender period to six months due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The 99-year leasehold land parcel spans 21,514 square meters, potentially yielding 600 residential units. The tender will close on October 29, and the sale is part of the government's land sales program for the first half of 2020. The move aims to provide developers with additional time to assess the current market situation.

site_title: China says has prepared pool of transport projects worth 800b yuan
summary: China's transport ministry has prepared a pool of transport projects worth 800 billion yuan, which can start as soon as funding is guaranteed, to boost the sputtering economy. The projects are expected to kickstart economic growth. However, Chinese people are unlikely to travel during the upcoming May Day holiday due to caution following the novel coronavirus outbreak, with short-range trips by car within provinces being the preferred option. This suggests the impact of the pandemic on consumer behavior remains a concern for policymakers.

site_title: Boeing to shrink workforce, raise cash as coronavirus slams jet industry
summary: Boeing plans to cut 16,000 jobs, or about 10%, and reduce 787 Dreamliner production to seven per month by 2022, as the company prepares for a years-long industry recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. Boeing expects to resume 737 MAX deliveries in the third quarter and boost liquidity by ramping up production of the grounded aircraft. The company aims to have positive cash flow next year and is working on a potential bond deal worth at least $10 billion. Boeing's adjusted loss for the first quarter was $1.70 billion, and the company's cash reserves stood at $15.5 billion.

site_title: China factory data shows global slump undercut nascent recovery
summary: China's April manufacturing data shows a split economy, with domestic rebounding and weak overseas demand. The manufacturing PMI fell to 50.8, while services and construction rose, taking the non-manufacturing PMI to 53.2. The data suggests an uneven recovery, with the global slump undercutting China's nascent recovery. Export orders plummeted, and job markets slowed, with some companies cutting back employment. The government may need to step up policy support to help enterprises and households survive the pandemic.

site_title: South Korea: no new domestic coronavirus cases, no transmission from election
summary: South Korea reported no new domestic coronavirus cases, marking the first time since February, according to the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The national tally stands at 10,765 cases, with 247 deaths and 9,059 discharges. The country also found no local transmission from a parliamentary election, where safety measures were taken. A clinical expert panel concluded that some recovered patients testing positive again were false positives due to PCR testing limitations.

images.alt_text: South Korea on Thursday reported no new domestic coronavirus cases for the first time since February, the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (KCDC) said.

site_title: Germany's new coronavirus cases increase the most in 4 days
summary: Germany reported a 1,627 increase in new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 161,539, and 153 fatalities, with a death rate of 4% as of Thursday morning. The country's reproduction factor, R0, declined to 0.75 from 0.9 the previous day, indicating a slowing spread of the virus. Chancellor Angela Merkel is set to consult with state premiers on easing restrictions, but regional leaders have expressed caution, citing it's too early for significant changes.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust's Q1 DPU down 70.5% on income retention
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) has reported a 70.5% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.85 cents for Q1, due to income retention amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Gross revenue rose 6% to S$204.3 million, but net property income fell 5.9% due to rental rebates granted to affected tenants. The company has retained S$69.6 million of taxable income and will defer non-essential expenses. CMT expects the impact of Covid-19 to deepen in Q2 and urges unitholders for support.

site_title: Australian retailer Woolworths' supermarket sales jump on panic buying
summary: Woolworths Group reported an 11.3% rise in third-quarter supermarket sales due to panic buying amid the coronavirus outbreak. Sales at its supermarket division increased to A$11.17 billion, with comparable sales growing 10.3%. The surge in demand for groceries and household goods led to the increase in sales.

site_title: Tesla's Elon Musk calling US coronavirus lockdowns 'fascist' overshadows profitable quarter
summary: Tesla's CEO Elon Musk criticized US coronavirus lockdowns as "fascist" in a call, overshadowing the company's third consecutive profitable quarter. Despite the shutdown of its Fremont factory in California, Tesla reported a 8.8% stock price increase and a net income of $1.24 per share. The company expects to ramp up production gradually in the second quarter and may announce a new US factory location within one to three months. Musk's comments and the company's strong earnings overshadowed rival Ford's $2 billion loss and General Motors' suspension of dividend payments.

site_title: SoftBank sees 900b yen net loss on WeWork writedown
summary: SoftBank Group Corp expects a net loss of around 900 billion yen (US$6.6 billion) in the year ending March due to a writedown on its WeWork investment, extending the group's expected net loss to 1.35 trillion yen. SoftBank is also launching a 2.5 trillion yen buyback to support its shares, which CEO Masayoshi Son uses as collateral for loans. The company's shares rose 2.4% in early trading despite the expected loss, and SoftBank is under pressure from debt and declining portfolio company valuations amid the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Singapore bank lending down 0.1% in March: MAS preliminary data
summary: Singapore's bank lending declined 0.1% in March from the previous month, largely due to a 1.4% drop in consumer loans, which fell amid the COVID-19 fallout. Business loans, however, rose 0.8% to S$434.2 billion. Compared to last year, total lending increased 2.4%.

site_title: Value emerges for retail S-Reits: Morningstar
summary: Singapore retail real estate investment trusts (Reits) have seen value emerge due to attractive dividend yields. Morningstar Equity Research reports that three retail-exposed Reits, CapitaLand Mall Trust, Suntec Reit, and Frasers Centrepoint Trust, have attractive yields following a 30% decline in unit prices. Morningstar expects long-term distribution growth to be driven by population growth, consumer sentiment, and favourable supply-demand dynamics. However, uncertainties remain due to the coronavirus outbreak, and Reits may delay distribution to conserve cash. Morningstar favours CMT and Suntec Reit for their diversified nature and resilience through market cycles.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rally on treatment hopes, currencies await ECB
summary: Asian stocks rose to a seven-week high on Thursday, driven by positive early results from a Covid-19 treatment trial and encouraging news from South Korea. The US dollar and US futures remained steady, while bonds held cautious ranges ahead of a European Central Bank meeting. The ECB is expected to expand its bond buying program, putting pressure on European leaders to agree on a rescue package. Despite market optimism, analysts caution that it's too early for a sustained rally in risk appetite, and a pullback is likely.

site_title: US dollar nurses losses after Fed, jump in risk appetite
summary: The US dollar experienced losses on Thursday, with the euro holding steady, as the US Federal Reserve hinted at further monetary easing to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The Fed kept interest rates near zero and promised to expand emergency programs, dampening expectations for a quick recovery. Positive trial results of an experimental Covid-19 treatment and signs of the pandemic receding in other countries also boosted risk appetite for currencies like the euro and Australian dollar, which rose to six-week highs. The dollar traded at a six-week low against the yen and declined against the pound.

site_title: Grab staff urged to take no-pay leave; driver financial support may not extend past June 1
summary: Grab staff are urged to take no-pay leave as the company faces financial strain due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. The ride-hailing firm may not provide further financial support if Singapore's partial lockdown measures extend past June 1. Grab has already halved its commission rate for drivers and waived commissions for those renting cars from its vehicle rental arm. The company's income support program will be extended till May 31, but its financial resources are dwindling.

images.alt_text: Grab is urging its staff to take no-pay leave voluntarily as the novel coronavirus outbreak continues to batter its business.

site_title: Amid an economic catastrophe, a few billionaires are still winning
summary: Billionaires are still winning despite an economic catastrophe, as the Vision Fund, a $100 billion venture capital fund, expects to lose $16.7 billion on its portfolio for the year. SoftBank's losses are due to bad bets on startups like WeWork, Opendoor, and Zume. The US Federal Reserve has intervened in the capital markets, providing $6 trillion in loans and buying junk bonds, which has warped the financial markets and created a "moral hazard" for investors. Billionaire investors are profiting from the crisis, while companies that made poor economic decisions are being rescued by the Fed.

site_title: Deliveroo lays off 25% of Singapore staff amid Covid-19 economic downturn
summary: Deliveroo is laying off 25% of its employees in Singapore, affecting 20 out of 80 staff members, as part of a global cut that will impact over 300 workers. The move comes amid the ongoing Covid-19 economic downturn. The departure of top executive Siddharth Shanker in Singapore was unrelated to the pandemic. Some employees will be put on furlough, while others will lose their jobs. The company is also scaling back operations in several countries.

site_title: No kissing, no extras: How to make TV in the age of the virus
summary: TV producers are adapting to filming soap operas during the pandemic with restrictions in place, including no kissing and limited extras. Australia's Neighbours continued filming despite the global industry halt, with actors now wearing protective gear and temperature checks. The show's demanding five-day-a-week schedule is being maintained, with producers closely watching the situation. This approach is seen as a model for other TV productions worldwide.

site_title: Gilead says over 50,000 experimental Covid-19 drugs ready to ship
summary: Gilead Sciences CEO Daniel O'Day announced that over 50,000 courses of the company's experimental Covid-19 treatment, remdesivir, are ready to ship once authorized by US regulators. This comes after a US-run trial showed the drug helped patients recover faster, with NIAID director Anthony Fauci confirming the results. The news sent stock markets soaring, with the potential for an effective coronavirus treatment. Gilead has been in close communication with the FDA and has intensified discussions as trial results roll in.

site_title: Singapore's pump prices fall by up to S$0.05 a litre, a week after oil plunge
summary: Pump prices in Singapore have fallen by up to 5 cents a liter, a week after crude oil plummeted to record lows. The price of 95-octane petrol has dropped to S$2.04 per liter at Esso, Shell, SPC, and Sinopec, while 92-octane petrol is now S$2 at Esso and SPC. 98-octane petrol is cheapest at S$2.38 per liter at SPC, followed by Esso and Sinopec. Diesel prices have also decreased, with SPC selling it at S$1.64 per liter. The price reductions are attributed to the recent drop in oil prices.

site_title: Microsoft sees digital reboot from pandemic, profits up
summary: Microsoft reported a 22% increase in profits to $10.8 billion in its fiscal third quarter, driven by a surge in digital adoption during the COVID-19 pandemic. Revenue rose 15% to $35 billion, with gains in Office commercial and cloud revenues of 13% and a 27% jump in Azure platform revenue to $12.3 billion. The company's business services focus has insulated it from the pandemic's impact, with CEO Satya Nadella noting a "two years' worth of digital transformation in two months."

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher, tracking US market gains; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.8% to 2,595.42, tracking US market gains. The gains were driven by telco Singtel, which rose after being awarded a 5G operating licence. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also rose after reporting Q1 net profit falls. US markets closed sharply higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 2.2% and the S&P 500 up 2.7%.

site_title: Gold soars in April as top central banks fight pandemic's damage
summary: Gold prices surged in April, reaching their highest since 2012, as top central banks implemented stimulus measures to combat the pandemic's economic damage. The Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell expressed concern over the crisis' potential long-term impact, while the European Central Bank prepares to decide on further action. Gold futures rose 1.1% to $1,732 an ounce, with worldwide exchange-traded fund holdings reaching a record high. This month's gain marks the metal's largest since 2016, as investors seek value amid the economic downturn.

images.alt_text: Gold is heading for the biggest monthly gain since 2016 as top central banks ramp up stimulus to repair the economic damage inflicted by the coronavirus pandemic, boosting the metal's allure as a store of value.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Oyo to offload more loss-making hotels amid pandemic: sources
summary: Oyo Hotels and Homes, backed by SoftBank Group, plans to offload more loss-making hotels globally amid the pandemic, prioritizing business in India, South-east Asia, Europe, China, and the US. The company aims to reduce monthly expenses to $25 million by June from $40 million. Oyo had already cut 5,000 jobs and ended contracts with hotels not generating $100,000 in annual revenue. The retreat comes after the hospitality sector was severely affected by the pandemic, resulting in a 50-60% drop in revenues and occupancy levels.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS downgrades AEM Holdings to 'hold' on limited upside, economic uncertainty
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded its call on AEM Holdings to "hold" from "buy" due to limited upside on its higher target price. The company's first-quarter results showed a significant increase in net profit to S$36.1 million, driven by higher sales from Intel and higher margins. Despite positive industry developments, the research team is cautious on the outlook due to economic uncertainty surrounding the Covid-19 pandemic. AEM's share price has risen 73% from its trough, but the downgrade reflects a more cautious approach to the stock's potential.

site_title: Facebook surges after revenue holds up in midst of pandemic
summary: Facebook reported a 18% increase in first-quarter revenue to $17.7 billion, beating Wall Street estimates, despite warning of advertising weakness in March due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue guidance was not provided, but Facebook said sales in the first three weeks of April were in line with the same period a year earlier. The company's daily users averaged 2.36 billion in March, up from 2.26 billion in December, and its core social network now has 1.73 billion daily users. Facebook shares jumped 10% in extended trading.

site_title: Decade of US growth ends as Fed warns of more virus hardship ahead
summary: The US economic expansion, which lasted for a decade, has ended due to the coronavirus pandemic, with the Fed warning of more virus-related hardship ahead. The economy contracted by 4.8% in the first quarter, and private-sector economists predict a 40% decline in growth in the second quarter. The Fed has pledged to use every tool to support the economy, slashing interest rates to zero and committing to buying US Treasury debt and other corporate debt. Unemployment is expected to take time to recover, with Fed Chairman Jerome Powell warning that it will take "some time" to return to pre-crisis levels.

site_title: Australia: Upbeat virus treatment view, oil jump lift shares
summary: Australian shares rose 1.1% to 5,451.5, driven by encouraging trial results of an experimental Covid-19 treatment, a rally in crude oil prices, and US Federal Reserve assurances to support the battered economy. A top US health official stated that Gilead Sciences' antiviral drug remdesivir may become the standard of care for Covid-19, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Singtel, StarHub, Keppel, SIA, CCT, Yangzijiang, Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a 29% fall in first-quarter profit, its lowest in 2.5 years, while Singtel and StarHub secured licenses to build nationwide 5G networks. Keppel Corp posted a 20.9% drop in Q1 net profit, and Singapore Airlines (SIA) plans to use rights issue proceeds to purchase aircraft. CCT's DPU fell 25%, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's net profit tumbled 51%. Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust's DPU rose 4.4%, and UMS Holdings resumed normal operations after the Malaysian government's green light.

site_title: US recession begins with economy shrinking annualised 4.8% in Q1
summary: The US economy has officially entered a recession, with the largest contraction since 2008, shrinking 4.8% in Q1. This marks the end of a record-long expansion of almost 11 years. The downturn is attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic forcing businesses to close and consumers to stay home. Analysts predict a worse quarter, with a 37% annualised contraction, and the economy is expected to take time to recover. The recession's impact is being felt globally, with China and the euro-area also reporting declines in output.

site_title: US: Optimism over Covid-19 drug, Fed stimulus boosts Dow 2.2%
summary: US stocks rose 2.2% on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 reaching new highs, driven by optimism over a potential Covid-19 treatment and continued Federal Reserve stimulus. The Nasdaq Composite Index surged 3.6% to a record high. The gains followed positive news about a coronavirus treatment under development, which boosted investor confidence.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 1.6% or 319.23 points to 20,090.42, following positive global stock rallies due to news of positive trial results for a COVID-19 treatment drug.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, tracking rallies on global stocks after news of positive trial results for a drug used in treating the new coronavirus.

site_title: Oil posts double-digit gains after US crude storage build slows
summary: Oil prices surged over 10% on Wednesday as US crude stockpiles grew less than expected and gasoline posted a surprise draw, sparking optimism about fuel consumption recovery. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 22% to $15.06 a barrel, while Brent crude futures jumped 10.2% to $22.54 a barrel. The slower build in US crude inventories delayed storage from filling to capacity, pushing prices up. A modest pickup in fuel demand offset a rebound in refinery output, suggesting consumption declines may be leveling off.

site_title: DBS Q1 profit falls to 2.5-year low on coronavirus loan loss provisions
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Singapore's largest lender, reported a 29% fall in first-quarter profit to S$1.16 billion, the lowest in 2.5 years, due to coronavirus loan loss provisions. The bank set aside S$1.09 billion to cover the impact of the pandemic, exceeding average estimates. Despite this, DBS retained its proposed dividend of 33 cents per share. The lender joins international banks in setting aside provisions for bad debts as the pandemic cripples the global economy.

site_title: What Covid-19's second wave could look like
summary: The world is likely to experience secondary outbreaks of Covid-19 as countries reopen, but the severity and frequency of these outbreaks are uncertain. Seasonal tendencies may limit the size of post-lockdown rebounds, but could also lead to rapid spread in the Southern Hemisphere. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention warns of a potential winter outbreak, and a flu vaccine could help mitigate this. Scientific breakthroughs, such as effective treatments and lab-grown antibodies, could steer the trajectory of Covid-19, but significant mutations could undermine progress.

site_title: Yangzijiang Q1 profit tumbles 51% following China lockdown
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's first-quarter net profit plummeted 51% to 403.8 million yuan due to China's temporary lockdown to contain the Covid-19 outbreak, which slowed production and revenue fell 44% to 3.50 billion yuan. The company secured new contracts worth US$360 million and maintained a healthy outstanding order book of US$2.9 billion. CEO Ren Letian reported that almost 100% of workers had resumed work by the end of March, and production is now in good progress with deliveries on track.

site_title: Biggest mall operator in US plans to reopen 49 of them from Friday
summary: Simon Property Group, the largest US mall operator, plans to reopen 49 shopping centers across 10 states starting Friday. To ensure a safe shopping experience, security officers and employees will remind shoppers to maintain social distancing and refrain from shopping in groups. This move provides insight into the American shopping landscape post-pandemic, with a focus on individualized and controlled environments.

site_title: Exxon freezes dividend for first time in 13 years amid crash
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp froze its dividend for the first time in 13 years amid the lowest oil prices in a generation, due to the impact of Covid-19 lockdowns on energy demand. The company will pay 87 US cents a share in June, unchanged from March. Exxon had previously maintained an uninterrupted streak of quarterly increases since 2007. The move is a sign of the times and expected given the price environment, with the annual payout of US$3.48 a share representing a 1.5% increase above 2019.

site_title: The elephant in the room: natural disasters
summary: Natural disasters pose a significant threat, claiming thousands of lives, rendering millions homeless, and causing economic recovery challenges. The World Economic Forum ranks climate change as the biggest global threat for the next decade. As countries battle Covid-19, they must also prepare for and respond to natural disasters, including typhoons, earthquakes, and monsoon seasons. The article highlights the need for preparedness and readiness, emphasizing that it is not a question of if, but when, these events will occur.

site_title: China parliament sets key meeting for May as Covid-19 outbreak ebbs
summary: China's parliament will convene on May 22, signaling the country's return to normal after the Covid-19 epidemic. Delegates will ratify major legislation, set economic targets, and make personnel changes. The session, initially postponed due to the pandemic, comes as the epidemic has subsided and economic life has gradually returned to normal. Analysts expect China to roll out additional fiscal stimulus to cushion the economic blow from the pandemic.

site_title: Oil prices gain as US storage fills less rapidly than feared
summary: US oil prices rose 12.6% on Wednesday, trimming losses from the week, after US stockpiles rose less than expected and demand is expected to improve as lockdowns ease in Europe and US cities. US crude inventories rose to 510 million barrels, and production cuts by US shale producers are expected to slow flows into tanks. Regulators in Texas and other states are considering output curtailments, which could add to global production cuts. This could put a floor under oil prices, with demand recovery hopes supporting prices.

site_title: Goldman Sachs puts premium on sustainable investing with new global markets council
summary: Goldman Sachs has established a 20-member council, the Global Markets Division Sustainable Solutions Council, to share expertise on sustainable finance and investing. The council aims to help clients achieve climate change investment commitments despite the COVID-19 pandemic and oil price slump. Members will meet every few weeks to share strategies and best practices across the Americas, Europe, and Asia. This move highlights Goldman Sachs' commitment to sustainable investing, which is increasingly in demand from clients.

site_title: Tapping the SDR to help contain Covid-19 economic fallout
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) estimates that the global economy will suffer a cumulative loss of over $9 trillion between now and 2021 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. To mitigate this economic fallout, the IMF is considering the issuance of Special Drawing Rights (SDRs), a reserve asset that could provide $1.37 trillion to support countries severely affected by the pandemic. Italy, France, and Spain are expected to experience significant spikes in their debt-to-GDP ratios, while developing countries will struggle with constrained access to international capital markets.

site_title: Data on Gilead drug raises hopes in pandemic fight, Fauci calls it 'highly significant'
summary: US infectious disease official Dr. Anthony Fauci hailed preliminary results from a key clinical trial of Gilead's experimental antiviral drug remdesivir as "highly significant," showing patients given the drug recovered 31% faster from Covid-19. The US FDA has been in discussions with Gilead about making the drug available to patients quickly, with President Trump calling for fast approvals. Full results from the trial are expected by mid-May, and Gilead is preparing to donate existing doses to hospitals, with the potential for commercial sales pending regulatory approval.

site_title: NTUC, government and employer federation pledge to safeguard lives and jobs
summary: Singapore's labour movement, government, and employers have pledged to safeguard lives and jobs in the face of the Covid-19 pandemic. In a joint May Day message, they expressed solidarity and commitment to protecting livelihoods, with over $63.7 billion allocated for jobs and wage support. They also encouraged workers to improve skills and employers to retain workers using the Jobs Support Scheme. The partners aim to create opportunities in the difficult job market through initiatives such as the SGUnited Jobs Initiative and reskilling efforts.

site_title: US dollar hovers above 2-week low before Fed meeting
summary: The US dollar hovered above a two-week low against its rivals on Wednesday, edging down 0.2% to 99.73, ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting. Investors are betting on central bank easing despite partial lockdown lifts. The greenback has weakened 3.5% since March, driven by aggressive stimulus measures to combat the pandemic. Analysts expect the Fed to continue supporting the US economy, with some predicting a 3.8% expansion in 2021.

site_title: IAG to cut up to 12,000 jobs at BA in survival fight
summary: IAG, the parent company of British Airways, plans to cut up to 12,000 jobs at BA, approximately 30% of its workforce, as part of a painful restructuring aimed at shrinking the airline group due to a potential downturn lasting several years. The move comes after a 1.3 billion-euro charge from fuel and currency hedges, and operating results are expected to be "significantly worse" in the current period due to the coronavirus pandemic. The airline group has avoided government-supported fundraising plans and expects passenger demand to recover to 2019 levels for "several years".

images.alt_text: British Airways, which has already placed 22,626 workers on the furlough plan, will now start discussions with labour groups on permanent reductions.

site_title: STI overcomes negative data to register third straight day of gains
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose for the third consecutive day, closing 11.78 points or 0.46% at 2,574.73 points. Despite dismal employment numbers and an 85% year-on-year drop in visitor arrivals, the index was boosted by gains from CapitaLand Commercial Trust and Singapore Press Holdings. Shares of Jardine Cycle & Carriage declined due to revised earnings forecasts.

site_title: Deutsche Bank warns of lower revenue
summary: Deutsche Bank warns of lower revenue this year due to a fading trading boost and the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, which is expected to significantly increase provisions for credit losses. The bank's chief financial officer notes that profitability will be tougher than initially assumed. This prediction joins other banks, including UBS, in warning of pain to come as lockdowns drive up defaults. The warning comes as a turnaround plan for Deutsche Bank, announced last year, is gaining traction.

site_title: Lockdown forces Spain's old-fashioned property market to modernise
summary: Spain's lockdown has forced the country's old-fashioned property market to modernize, with estate agents offering virtual visits and notaries lobbying for e-signatures to offset a near-total halt of business. 99% of transactions have stopped, with only a few exceptions certified by notaries with gloves and social distancing measures. The sector, which accounted for 10.5% of GDP in 2019, is now embracing digital solutions to survive the crisis, with some agents already providing virtual viewing for most listed properties.

site_title: Government initiatives may dovetail with companies' sustainability reporting
summary: Singapore's government initiatives may align with companies' sustainability reporting, particularly in water management. Research shows that companies with strong sustainability reporting have higher market valuations, but the impact is limited. PUB, Singapore's national water agency, has implemented successful standards and best practices, such as the Water Efficient Building certification programme and Mandatory Water Efficiency Management Practices. These efforts have driven lower water consumption and improved water sustainability measures. PUB's approach could serve as a model for companies to improve their water disclosure and performance, potentially dovetailing with the Singapore Stock Exchange's (SGX) sustainability reporting standards.

site_title: DBS' O&G portfolio makes up largest chunk of loans to industries hit by Covid-19
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, reported a 29% decline in Q1 net profit to S$1.165 billion, with a 29% fall in overall earnings since 2017. The bank's oil-and-gas (O&G) lending portfolio makes up the largest chunk of loans to industries hit by the Covid-19 pandemic, totaling S$23 billion. DBS has set aside S$1.086 billion in provisions, with S$383 million specifically for an oil trader, and expects credit costs to rise between S$3 billion and S$5 billion over two years. The bank maintained its quarterly dividend payout and expects its full-year profit to be around 2019 levels after factoring in declines for the rest of the year.

images.alt_text: DBS on Thursday guided that its oil-and-gas lending portfolio at S$23 billion makes up its single-largest loan exposure to impacted industries made vulnerable by the Covid-19 pandemic, and that it expects further allowances set aside specifically for O&G support services.

site_title: Tesla's profit streak not derailed by coronavirus as auto industry braces for losses
summary: Tesla reported its third consecutive quarterly profit, despite the coronavirus pandemic affecting deliveries. The company's shares rose 8% to $870. In contrast, rival Ford Motor Co reported a $2 billion loss and forecast another $5 billion loss for the current quarter. Tesla's CEO, Elon Musk, expressed uncertainty about the full year due to lockdown restrictions. The auto industry is bracing for losses due to the pandemic, while Tesla's focus on electric vehicles appears to be helping the company weather the crisis.

images.alt_text: Tesla Inc on Wednesday posted its third quarterly profit in a row but said the novel coronavirus was hurting deliveries and lockdown restrictions made it impossible for the electric carmaker to provide guidance for the full year.

site_title: Singapore Q1 unemployment rate up to 2.4%; Q2 numbers to worsen as virus hits
summary: Singapore's total employment contracted by 19,000 in Q1 2020, with an overall unemployment rate of 2.4%, the sharpest quarterly decline in 17 years. Retrenchments rose to 3,000, with the service sector bearing the brunt, while the construction and manufacturing sectors also saw job cuts. Economists predict Q2 data will worsen, with employment expected to contract by 80,000-100,000, driven by the circuit breaker measures.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust posts Q2 DPU of 1.9 Australian cents
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) reported a 4.4% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.9 Australian cents in Q2, driven by contributions from European and Australian acquisitions, but partially offset by divestment activities in Australia. Revenue rose 12.8% to A$67.3 million, while distributable income increased 16.7% to A$43.1 million. FLCT's total distribution for the period will be paid out on June 26.

site_title: 'Business as usual' is being transformed by pandemic
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to unprecedented economic and social changes, with many previously unthinkable outcomes. The US economy is expected to suffer its worst contraction since the Great Depression, with a potential 30% fall in the second quarter. Governments are reevaluating their strategies, considering semi-continuous restrictions rather than a single lockdown, and the potential for a wave of coronavirus outbreaks this winter. Amidst the crisis, there is growing optimism about the potential for transformation in areas such as working patterns, supply chains, and corporate responsibility, which could drive a new wave of growth.

site_title: Singapore building sector seen shrinking 10.3% in 2020
summary: Singapore's construction sector is expected to contract 10.3% in 2020 due to the COVID-19 outbreak, according to Fitch Solutions. The sector was previously forecast to contract 3.2%. The contraction is attributed to the government's decision to suspend construction work and restrict residents from leaving dormitories, where many construction workers reside. The sector is expected to recover gradually in the second half of the year, but not return to 2019 levels. The buildings sector is expected to shrink by 11.5% year-on-year, while the infrastructure sector is expected to contract less.

site_title: BIS arm calls for global hackathon to solve compliance problems
summary: The Bank of International Settlements (BIS) has launched a global hackathon, the G20 TechSprint initiative, to address regulatory compliance and supervisory processes. Hosted on the API Exchange (APIX) platform, the event aims to bring together financial institutions, regulators, and fintechs to solve pressing problems. Private firms are invited to participate in the remote hackathon, which is part of the BIS's efforts to promote innovation and cooperation in the financial sector. The initiative is expected to tackle urgent issues in compliance and supervision, with the goal of improving financial stability and promoting economic growth.

site_title: ECB action to save eurozone now only delays future dilemma
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has calmed markets by ramping up bond-buying to vulnerable nations, effectively mutualising debt via the central bank. However, this strategy assumes euro-area inflation doesn't accelerate, which few economists see happening soon. If inflation does rise, the ECB may be forced to withdraw stimulus, potentially sparking another crisis. Economists predict the central bank will need to boost its 750 billion-euro pandemic bond-buying programme by 500 billion euros later this year, and consider raising its inflation goal or using a tool to buy unlimited amounts of individual countries' bonds.

site_title: Jobs-for-a-fee site for law students under probe by LawSoc
summary: The Law Society of Singapore is investigating lawmentors.sg, a coaching platform that promised to help law students and graduates land plum training contracts for a fee. The platform claimed to have a "mentor network" with elite law firms in the UK and US, but its claims were deemed "speculative" and "unsubstantiated" by the Law Society. The platform's creators took down the site after receiving feedback that it was unreasonable to charge students for job placement assistance during the economic crisis. The Law Society has warned prospective lawyers to be cautious of "hungry wolves in sheep's clothing" who seek to exploit vulnerable students.

site_title: ComfortDelGro, SMRT undertake initiatives to help their cabbies take on food delivery jobs
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp and SMRT have launched initiatives to help their taxi drivers, who have been impacted by dwindling passenger numbers, by offering food delivery services. ComfortDelGro's ComfortDelivery service allows food establishments to book taxis for delivery runs, with cabbies earning a distance-based rate starting from S$6.50 per trip. The service is available daily from 9 am to 10 pm, and ComfortDelGro will not charge any fees to cabbies or F&B outlets during the 'circuit-breaker' period.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) has been renamed Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) following a $1.58 billion merger. The trust's trading name will be Frasers L&C Tr, with its stock code remaining unchanged. Frasers Commercial Trust has been delisted from the Singapore Exchange. UMS Holdings has resumed normal operations at its Penang factory after Malaysia's government gave the green light.

site_title: Temasek Trust launches S$10m fund for initiatives that support virus-hit communities
summary: Temasek Trust has launched an S$10 million fund, oscar@sg, to support community initiatives affected by the COVID-19 outbreak in Singapore. The fund will provide up to S$5,000 in direct sponsorship and match third-party funding sources up to S$50,000. Donations have been made by corporate partners and individual philanthropists, including Temasek Holdings subsidiary Pavilion Capital. The fund will support projects that embody the values of ownership, sustainability, care, assurance, and resilience. Individuals and non-profit organizations can apply for the grant, with a requirement to submit a workable implementation plan.

site_title: Nearly half of global workforce risk losing livelihoods: ILO
summary: Nearly half of the global workforce, approximately 1.6 billion informal workers, are at risk of losing their livelihoods due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The International Labour Organization (ILO) forecasts a "massive" poverty impact, with wages plummeting by an estimated 60% in the first month of the crisis. Prolonged lockdowns and closures are expected to lead to a 10.5% decline in total working hours worldwide, equivalent to 305 million full-time jobs. The ILO urges governments to speed up procedures for unemployment benefits and support for independent workers to mitigate the devastating impact.

site_title: Money FM podcast: What does the future hold for regional airlines?
summary: A Money FM podcast discussed the future of regional airlines, but the article does not provide information on this topic. The article instead covers various financial and business news, including NTT DC Reit's public offer being oversubscribed, Creative Technology's revenue warning, and Indonesia detaining an employee in a graft case.

site_title: Singtel, StarHub-M1 bag 5G licences; some see pandemic hobbling roll-out
summary: Singapore's Singtel and a consortium of StarHub and M1 bagged 5G operating licences, marking a significant step forward for the country's wireless technology. The move was seen as a boost for telcos, but analysts warned that the COVID-19 pandemic could hinder deployment due to financial challenges. The decision to issue only two licences is expected to have a positive impact on the competitive landscape, with analysts praising the move as a shot in the arm for the industry.

site_title: SIA defends planned aircraft purchases, expects 'substantial' hedging losses in fuel
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is defending its plan to use proceeds from an upcoming S$8.8 billion rights issue to purchase aircraft, citing the need to maintain its leading industry position and reduce emissions. The airline expects "substantial losses" on its fuel hedges due to low fuel prices, but plans to monitor developments before entering additional hedges. SIA is also negotiating with aircraft manufacturers to adjust delivery streams to balance its fleet-renewal program with long-term sustainability.

site_title: Biden wins Hillary Clinton's endorsement in bid to woo women voters
summary: Joe Biden won the endorsement of Hillary Clinton, a former US presidential candidate, at a critical moment to boost his profile with female voters ahead of the November 3 election. Clinton, who lost to Donald Trump in 2016, expressed her support for Biden's campaign, highlighting issues such as abortion and domestic violence. The endorsement comes as Biden aims to pick a woman as his running mate and follows previous endorsements from other Democratic establishment figures.

site_title: Uber, Tripadvisor axe staff as pandemic dries up business
summary: Uber and Tripadvisor are cutting staff due to the pandemic's impact on their businesses. Uber plans to axe 20% of its global staff, affecting over 5,400 employees, while Tripadvisor will impact around 900 employees, about a quarter of its workforce. Both companies will offer transition packages, including severance pay and outplacement support, to affected staff. The pandemic's effects are being felt across the travel and retail sectors, with other companies also implementing staff cuts and furloughs.

site_title: March visitor number to Singapore hits 17-year low amid pandemic
summary: Singapore saw its March visitor number plummet 85% to 240,000, the lowest since the Sars outbreak in 2003, due to travel restrictions and the COVID-19 pandemic. China accounted for 20% of total tourist arrivals, with 1,500 visitors in March. The Singapore Tourism Board expects a 25-30% drop in visitor numbers for the full year, with revenues forecast to fall "roughly in line." The government has allocated a S$22 million fund to support the tourism sector's recovery, but Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for harmonized health and hygiene standards, connectivity, and technological capabilities among Asean countries to recover from the pandemic.

images.alt_text: With movements worldwide severely restricted and the Covid-19 pandemic far from tamed, the downtrend in visitors which started in January is tipped to continue.

site_title: How the coronavirus crisis differs from other global downturns
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic-induced global shutdown differs from other economic downturns in its rapid and deep impact on the global economy. Unlike previous slowdowns, which were triggered by financial market fluctuations, this shutdown was driven by government intervention to slow the spread of the virus. The shutdown has accelerated changes such as a shift towards local markets, increased focus on technology, and a consolidation of economic power into giant corporations. While the shutdown shares similarities with other economic cycles, its sudden and voluntary nature sets it apart, making it a unique event in modern economic history.

site_title: Better a dividend cut than a cash call
summary: HSBC investors are urging the bank to pay a final dividend despite the company's weakened financial position due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The bank has already cut its dividend, but investors are seeking alternative solutions, such as reducing senior management pay or paying out dividends in scrip. However, experts warn that preserving dividend payments at all costs may not be in the long-term interests of the company, and companies should prioritize cash flow management during this economic downturn.

site_title: PE deal value in Singapore falls as investors look to higher growth markets
summary: Private equity deal value in Singapore dropped 26.9% to US$4.9 billion in 2019 due to increased attractiveness of deal opportunities in hinterland markets such as Vietnam and Indonesia. This led to a US$2 billion year-on-year drop in total PE deal value in South-east Asia. Despite this, deal volume in the region edged up to 116 deals in 2019, driven by strong gains in the Internet and technology sectors. The COVID-19 pandemic is expected to have a sustained impact on the PE industry in the region.

site_title: CIMB Singapore delays mortgage floor rate hike, but customers unmoved
summary: CIMB Singapore has delayed the implementation of a higher minimum mortgage rate, initially set to take effect on May 18, 2020, due to customer backlash. The new start date is January 1, 2021, for mortgages pegged to Sibor and Sor. The move aims to address customer concerns over the rate hike, which would have increased borrowing costs for certain mortgage products.

images.alt_text: Following a pushback from irate customers, CIMB Bank Singapore will delay the start date - to Jan 1, 2021 - of its higher minimum rate for certain mortgages pegged to the Singapore inter-bank offered rate (Sibor) and Swap offer rate (Sor).

site_title: Companies band together to supply meals to vulnerable groups
summary: A collaborative effort by companies and non-profit organizations is supplying 1,000 bento meals daily to vulnerable groups in Singapore amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The "Eat for Good" initiative, launched by the National Volunteer & Philanthropy Centre (NVPC), brings together funds, resources, and expertise to support those struggling with food insecurity. Key partners include Maybank Singapore, Samsui Supplies & Services, and Food Bank Singapore, which are leveraging their strengths to deliver meals to beneficiaries such as nursing homes and non-profit organizations. The initiative aims to increase its scale and reach, with the goal of providing sustainable food support to those in need.

site_title: Hello, social distancing. Goodbye, handshakes?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a reevaluation of the handshake as a symbol of social etiquette, with many experts recommending against it due to the risk of transmission. Scientists have found that hands can carry hundreds of species of bacteria and viruses, and a single handshake can spread pathogens to up to 50% of the surfaces it touches. As a result, alternatives such as fist bumps, elbow bumps, and traditional greetings like bows or doffs are being considered as replacements for handshakes.

site_title: UK extends deadline for Libor loan switch till end March, 2021
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority has extended the deadline for ending the use of the Libor interest rate benchmark in new loans until the end of March 2021 due to the coronavirus pandemic. This decision was made as part of a transition to the Bank of England's overnight Sonia rate, a Libor replacement.

site_title: 690 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, taking total to 15,641
summary: Singapore reported 690 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 15,641. Foreign workers made up the majority, with 660 cases in dormitories and 19 outside. The new cases include six Singaporeans and permanent residents, and a 23-year-old nurse at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases. 1,188 patients have recovered and 14 have died from Covid-19 complications, with no imported cases. Globally, the outbreak has infected over 3.13 million and 217,000 have died, with the US being the worst affected country.

site_title: Mentoring platform under investigation for 'speculative' claims, 'opportunistic' operations: LawSoc
summary: The Law Society of Singapore is investigating a coaching platform, lawmentors.sg, for making "speculative" and "unsubstantiated" claims about its ability to secure training contracts for students and graduates in the legal industry. The platform, which was taken down after just over a week, promised to equip participants with a "decisive advantage" to "outshine" their peers and secure a training contract. The Law Society has cautioned parents and law graduates to be discerning about the platform, which was accused of being "exploitative" and "unethical".

site_title: MPA unveils S$27m support package for maritime sector
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has announced a S$27 million support package to aid the maritime sector amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The package includes a 30% port dues concession for cargo vessels and harbourcraft until the end of 2020, increased rebates for regional ferry operators, and flexible credit management measures. Additionally, MPA will introduce new manpower schemes and increase co-funding for upskilling and digital transformation efforts, providing financial assistance to eligible seafarers and Certificate of Competency holders.

site_title: UMS' Penang factory resumes operations amid Covid-19
summary: UMS Holdings' factory in Penang, Malaysia, has resumed normal operations after receiving the green light from the Malaysian government. The factory, which had been operating at a limited level since early April, is now allowed to operate at full capacity. UMS' factory in California also resumed normal operations, while its Singapore production will continue with a lower headcount. The company does not expect the temporary halt to have a significant financial impact.

site_title: World's deepest gold mines on a 'cliff' as virus curbs output
summary: South Africa's gold industry, which once employed over 500,000 workers, has dwindled to a fifth of its 1970s peak due to high costs and the COVID-19 pandemic. The industry is now operating at 50% capacity, with some mines achieving only 30% of their previous output. The nation's five-week lockdown and strict conditions attached to reopening gold mines pose a significant threat to the industry's viability, with analysts warning that producers may struggle to cover costs. The industry's future is uncertain, but restarting mines may allow producers to cover salaries and electricity costs.

site_title: Mastercard sees spending return as economies open after coronavirus gloom
summary: Mastercard reported better-than-expected first-quarter earnings, driven by a gradual return to consumer spending as countries ease lockdown measures. The company expects spending to stabilize and then normalize, with sectors like home improvement and healthcare likely to recover faster than mass entertainment and long-haul travel. Mastercard also saw a 40% growth in contactless transactions worldwide and plans to temporarily suspend its 2020 share repurchase, citing caution.

site_title: Hunker down at home with some mindfulness tips
summary: During the ongoing pandemic, people are turning to their homes for comfort and mindfulness. A recent article offers tips on how to stay at home mindfully, including retail therapy, DIY projects, and self-care advice from a psychologist. Meanwhile, billionaire Kim Lim shares her efforts to support frontline healthcare workers with weekly food drops. The article also highlights the creative ways people are coping with stress, such as fashion designers expressing themselves through photography and product design.

site_title: Barclays Q1 profit drops 42% on pandemic
summary: Barclays' net profit dropped 42% in Q1 due to the economic shock from the COVID-19 pandemic, reaching £605 million. The bank will take a £2.1-billion impairment charge, primarily linked to the pandemic's impact on the UK retail bank and international investment arm. Despite the downturn, Barclays' CEO Jes Staley reassured the bank's "robust" position, citing its diversified business model and commitment to supporting customers, clients, and the UK economy through the crisis.

site_title: An ironic retreat: United States MIA in global response to Covid-19
summary: The US has largely retreated from its leadership role in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic, with President Donald Trump instead focusing on domestic politics and blaming other countries for the outbreak. This has allowed China to fill the vacuum, providing medical aid to hard-hit countries and positioning itself as a potential new global leader. The US has also launched a diplomatic campaign against the World Health Organization, threatening to cut financial support, which is seen as an act of utmost irresponsibility.

site_title: DBS rolls out its investment analytics to the mass market
summary: DBS Bank has launched a new digital advisory tool, NAV Planner, to help customers consolidate and analyze their finances, providing personalized financial information tailored to their life stage. The tool includes investment analytics, previously reserved for private banking clients, and aims to "equalize everyone from an information perspective." With over 300,000 users accessing the tool in its first month, DBS hopes to encourage more customers to begin financial planning, particularly university students and new workforce entrants.

site_title: LHN expects hit to rent collection, renovation delays amid Covid-19
summary: LHN Group expects rental collections for its Space Optimisation Business to be impacted due to the Covid-19 outbreak, particularly for sub-leases of commercial and industrial properties. The company also anticipates renovation delays for its projects in Singapore and overseas. LHN has closed its headquarters and implemented work-from-home arrangements to comply with circuit-breaker measures, while continuing essential services. The company is assessing the economic and financial impacts of the pandemic, but has not provided a full assessment of its business.

site_title: Samsung warns of profit slide after virus slams tech sector
summary: Samsung Electronics warned of a potential decline in profits due to the ongoing impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak on demand for smartphones and gadgets. The company reported a 4% slide in net income to 4.9 trillion won (S$5.69 billion) in the first quarter of 2020. Despite earlier expectations, Samsung attributed the decline to continued market disruption across various regions.

site_title: Trump orders meat plants to stay open in move slammed by union
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order requiring meat processing plants to remain open despite the COVID-19 pandemic, sparking opposition from unions. The decision aims to maintain the national meat supply chain but is seen as a "potential death sentence" for workers. Meat plants have already shut down due to the virus, and the order sets up a confrontation between Trump and the unions.

site_title: GE warns of more pain ahead as pandemic deals US$1b cash hit
summary: General Electric Co warned that the coronavirus pandemic has dealt a US$1 billion blow to its industrial business cash flow in the first quarter, with total revenue falling almost 8%. The company has cut 700 workers, reduced capital spending by 25% and is bracing for repossession of some aircraft. CEO Larry Culp declined to predict when cash flow might recover, stating that some cost-cutting measures would be permanent. The company's total revenue is expected to worsen in the next three months.

site_title: NTUC, govt and employer federation pledge to safeguard lives and jobs in May Day message
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC), government, and employer federation have issued a joint May Day message pledging to safeguard lives and jobs in the face of the Covid-19 pandemic. The tripartite partners, including NTUC president Mary Liew and Manpower Minister Josephine Teo, expressed their commitment to protecting livelihoods and ensuring business sustainability. This is the first time the partners have released a joint message.

site_title: SGX RegCo to review No Signboard report for possible listing breaches
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) is reviewing an independent report on No Signboard Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, for possible breaches of listing rules due to non-compliance with Financial Reporting Standards (FRS). The report found that No Signboard had not followed merger accounting principles, resulting in non-comparable financial statements and "double-counting" in two consecutive periods. SGX RegCo expects listed issuers to exercise caution when changing accounting principles and to clearly justify such changes.

site_title: Volkswagen joins other automakers in warning of severe hit from pandemic
summary: Volkswagen, the world's largest automaker, has warned of a severe hit to its operating profit due to the coronavirus pandemic. Supply and demand disruptions caused by government measures will lead to a significant drop in deliveries and sales this year. The company expects to remain profitable for the full year despite an anticipated second-quarter loss. Volkswagen's warning follows similar announcements from other automakers, including Ford, which forecast a Q2 operating loss of over $5 billion.

site_title: Google makes its video meeting service free to all
summary: Google has made its video meeting service, Google Meet, free to all users worldwide, aiming to compete with Zoom as people increasingly use video calls and conferencing due to the pandemic. The service was previously only available to subscribers of the premium G Suite software tools for businesses. Google emphasized the security and reliability features of Meet, which will be rolled out gradually in coming weeks, with a 60-minute time cap starting in September. This move follows Alphabet's report of higher revenues and profits, and comes after Facebook unveiled a new video chat service with virtual "rooms."

site_title: SIA defends aircraft purchases, expects 'substantial' hedging losses
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has defended its plan to use proceeds from an S$8.8 billion rights issue to purchase new aircraft, citing the need for a modern fleet to maintain its leading industry position and reduce emissions. The airline expects "substantial losses" on its fuel hedges, but plans to adjust its delivery stream and negotiate with manufacturers to mitigate these losses. SIA has also deferred non-essential expenditures and tightened discretionary spending to ensure long-term sustainability.

site_title: Coronavirus hammered US economy in first quarter
summary: The US economy contracted at its sharpest pace since the Great Recession in the first quarter, with a 4.8% annualized decline in gross domestic product. This was largely due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which led to widespread lockdowns, factory shutdowns, and a decline in consumer spending. Economists predict the economy was already in a deep recession, with some warning of potential bankruptcies for small and medium-sized businesses. The decline was the steepest pace of contraction in GDP since 2009.

site_title: Singapore's graft rate stays low as fight continues despite Covid-19
summary: Singapore's graft rate remains low, with the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) receiving 350 corruption-related reports in 2020, a 2% decrease from 2018. The CPIB has concluded investigations into 85% of the number of subjects investigated, with a conviction rate above 97% over the past five years. Notably, Keppel Offshore & Marine accepted a conditional warning from CPIB due to substantial cooperation and remedial measures taken, while the government's response to high-level corruption cases was commended by Political & Economic Risk Consultancy.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust Q1 DPU down 25% to 1.65¢
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 25% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.65 Singapore cents for the first quarter ended March 31, due to retained taxable income and withholding tax-exempt income. Gross revenue inched up 3.8% to S$103.6 million, driven by gains from Main Airport Center and 21 Collyer Quay. Net property income rose 0.7% to S$80.3 million, with aggregate leverage increasing to 35.5%. CCT's committed occupancy fell to 95.2% due to lower occupancy at Six Battery Road.

site_title: SPH Reit secures refinancing of S$280m in 5-year loan
summary: SPH Reit secured a refinancing of S$280 million in a 5-year loan from OCBC, replacing a loan due in July 2020. The new loan maintains a healthy balance sheet and reduces gearing to 29.3%. The refinancing will also increase the weighted average debt term to maturity to 3 years. This move is seen as a prudent capital management strategy to safeguard the interests of investors amid the prolonged COVID-19 situation.

site_title: US: Wall St jumps on hopes of potential coronavirus drug
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.61% to 24,490.37, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gaining 2.08% and 2.27%, respectively. This followed an encouraging update from Gilead Sciences on a potential COVID-19 treatment, as well as upbeat earnings reports from Boeing and Alphabet.

site_title: GSK surpasses profit expectations on pain medication stockpiling
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) exceeded quarterly profit expectations, driven by strong sales of its shingles vaccine, Shingrix, and pain and respiratory medicines during the coronavirus pandemic. The company's turnover rose 19% to 9.09 billion pounds in the first quarter, with sales from its over-the-counter products business jumping 44% to 2.86 billion pounds. Despite challenges in manufacturing and clinical trials, GSK maintains its full-year profit forecast, expecting a 1-4% fall in profit, lower than analysts' prediction of a 7.2% drop.

site_title: Debate over coronavirus 'immunity passports'
summary: Global health authorities and experts warn against the use of "immunity passports" due to concerns over antibody test accuracy and individual privacy. These passports aim to identify people with reduced risk of spreading the coronavirus, allowing them to resume activities and return to work. However, experts caution that the accuracy of these tests is uncertain and that such passports could lead to unequal access to essential services and further exacerbate health disparities. Governments and organizations are still considering the use of immunity passports, sparking debate over their potential impact on public health and social cohesion.

site_title: Boeing to cut workforce and production as it braces for years-long industry recovery
summary: Boeing plans to cut its workforce by 10% and reduce production of its 787 Dreamliner and 737 MAX aircraft as it prepares for a years-long industry recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. The company aims to boost liquidity and has drawn down its credit line. Despite burning through $4.7 billion in cash in the first quarter, Boeing is confident of getting sufficient liquidity to fund its operations. The company's adjusted loss stood at $1.70 billion, or $1.70 per share, in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: Boeing said on Wednesday it would cut its workforce by about 10 per cent, further reduce 787 Dreamliner production and try to boost liquidity as it prepares for a years-long industry recovery from the coronavirus pandemic that drove the planemaker to a net loss for the second straight quarter.

site_title: Europe's virus lockdowns send confidence plunging at record pace
summary: Europe's virus lockdowns have led to a record plunge in confidence, with the European Commission's monthly sentiment index dropping to 67 from 94.2 in March. This is near the lows recorded during the 2009 financial crisis. Companies are worried about demand and employment, while consumers are less likely to make major purchases. The lockdowns have also hit industries such as airlines, hotels, and restaurants, with some companies, like British Airways, planning to slash workforce by nearly 30%.
