The economic damage is expected to be irreversible if governments do not formulate plans to reopen businesses.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on Covid-19 drug hopes, upbeat outlook from corporates
summary: European stocks rose 1.8% on Wednesday, boosted by positive developments on a potential Covid-19 treatment and upbeat earnings from corporates. US drugmaker Gilead Sciences' experimental antiviral drug remdesivir showed improved symptoms for Covid-19 patients. Shares in banks, oil giants, and automakers surged, with Barclays and Standard Chartered driving the rally. European shares have recouped nearly half of their losses since the February rout as countries restart their economies. However, analysts predict a sharper slump in second-quarter earnings, with healthcare stocks falling 1.6%.

site_title: DBS names Olivier Lim new lead independent director
summary: DBS Group Holdings announced that Olivier Lim Tse Ghow has taken over as the new lead independent director, replacing Ho Tian Yee. Lim will succeed Ho on the Nominating Committee, which has been reconstituted with Tham Sai Choy. DBS clarified that it has a majority independent board, following recent changes that include the appointment of two new independent directors, Anthony Lim and Punita Lal. The bank's board now has 11 members, with six independent directors, following Lim's appointment.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.10 points to 1,380.30, closing higher on Wednesday. The index saw 4.826 billion lots worth RM2.465 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 629 to 249.

site_title: Fewer corruption-related reports in Singapore last year: CPIB
summary: Singapore's Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) received 350 corruption-related reports in 2020, a 2% decrease from 2018. Despite fewer reports, more cases were investigated due to improved information quality. Private sector cases made up 90% of the total, with 147 individuals prosecuted in court, including 142 private sector individuals. The CPIB achieved an 85% clearance rate, an improvement from the previous year. Director Denis Tang emphasized the need to maintain vigilance in combating corruption, as Singapore's reputation for fairness and incorruptibility must be protected.

site_title: DBS aims to bring investment analytics to the masses
summary: DBS has launched a digital advisory tool, NAV Planner, to help customers consolidate and analyze their finances, providing personalized financial information tailored to their life stage. The tool, accessible on mobile and internet banking platforms, offers investment analytics previously reserved for private banking clients. With over 300,000 users, the NAV Planner aims to equalize access to financial information, encouraging better personal finance habits and promoting digital financial planning.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose at the open on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.2%, Frankfurt's DAX 0.3%, and Paris's CAC 40 0.2%. The gains were driven by a further easing of coronavirus lockdown measures, boosting global sentiment. The rally also extended to Asia, where Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and the US stock market edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Keppel's Q1 profit falls 21% on absence of divestment gain
summary: Keppel Corp posted a 20.9% drop in Q1 net profit to S$160.5 million, mainly due to the absence of a Vietnam township project gain. Revenue rose 21.3% to S$1.86 billion, driven by higher revenues from offshore & marine, property trading, and power & gas projects. Key business units remain profitable, and the company has a strong balance sheet and credit lines to finance operations. Despite the Covid-19 pandemic's impact, the company expects to stay busy for the next two years with a net order book of S$4 billion.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corp posted a 20.9 per cent drop in quarterly net profit to S$160.5 million from a year earlier, mainly due to the absence of gain from the partial divestment of a Vietnam township project that had boosted profit previously.

site_title: STI rises for third straight day despite negative data
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose for the third consecutive day, ending up 11.78 points or 0.46% to 2,574.73 points despite negative macro data, including a 17-year low in quarterly employment numbers and a 85% decline in visitor arrivals. CapitaLand Commercial Trust and CapitaLand Mall Trust were the top performers, while Jardine Cycle & Carriage saw its shares decline due to revised earnings forecasts. The STI's gain was largely driven by investor positivity and a lack of concern over negative data.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust's Q1 DPU down 25% to 1.65 cents
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 25% decline in Distribution Per Unit (DPU) to 1.65 cents for the first quarter ended March, due to retained taxable income and withholding tax-exempt income amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Gross revenue rose 3.8% to S$103.6 million, driven by Main Airport Center and Frankfurt properties, but was partially offset by lower income from Asia Square Tower 2. Net property income increased 0.7% to S$80.3 million, with a committed occupancy rate of 95.2%. CCT's aggregate leverage increased to 35.5% and has renewed about two-thirds of expiring leases.

site_title: 5 new Covid-19 clusters identified; 660 of 690 new cases are workers in dormitories
summary: Singapore reports 690 new Covid-19 cases, with 660 involving foreign workers in dormitories, bringing the total cases to 15,641. The new cases include six Singaporeans and permanent residents, and five work pass holders. A 23-year-old nurse is among the new cases, who reported onset of symptoms last Thursday. Fourteen have died from Covid-19 complications in Singapore, with no imported cases.

site_title: Singtel and StarHub-M1 tie-up win 5G operating licences in provisional awards
summary: Singapore's first nationwide 5G operating licences have been provisionally awarded to Singtel and a joint venture between StarHub and M1. The winners must meet terms and complete the regulatory process by May, after which their provisional awards will be converted into final 5G licences. The joint venture will lease its 5G network to the individual partners, who will operate separately to offer retail services to end-users. The IMDA has also announced plans to build infocomm technology talent for new 5G-related roles.

site_title: Three commercial shophouses in Bugis, CBD up for sale
summary: Three commercial shophouses in Bugis and the central business district are up for sale, with guide prices ranging from S$7 million to S$17 million. The properties, located on 534 North Bridge Road, 60 South Bridge Road, and 96 Amoy Street, are zoned for commercial use under the Urban Redevelopment Authority's Master Plan 2014. The shophouses offer opportunities for investment or own usage, and both locals and foreigners can purchase the properties. The tenders for 534 North Bridge Road and 60 South Bridge Road will close on June 3, while the expression of interest exercise for 96 Amoy Street will close on July 1.

site_title: Britain's PM announces birth of son with partner Carrie Symonds
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his partner Carrie Symonds announced the birth of a healthy baby boy at a London hospital on April 29, 2020. The couple had announced their engagement in February and were expecting a baby in early summer. The baby's birth is the first child for Johnson, 55, and Symonds, 32. Both mother and baby are reportedly doing well.

site_title: Local firms develop cross-border food-procurement platform in response to supply-chain uncertainties
summary: Local firms Singapore E-Business and Alliance 21 develop a cross-border food-procurement platform in response to supply-chain uncertainties triggered by the novel coronavirus outbreak. The platform, launching in June, will enable Singaporean food manufacturers and suppliers to source and trade goods internationally, with accredited overseas suppliers and a multi-currency e-payment gateway. The initiative is expected to benefit around 2,000 small and medium-sized enterprises, reducing logistics costs and providing a seamless cross-border trade solution.

site_title: BIS innovation hub in Singapore calls for global hackathon to solve compliance pain
summary: The Bank of International Settlements (BIS) Singapore innovation hub is launching a global "remote hackathon" to solve regulatory compliance problems. The G20 TechSprint initiative, funded by the Saudi G20 Presidency, will challenge private firms to develop innovative solutions to issues in regulatory reporting, analytics, and monitoring. Selected participants will compete for cash prizes of US$50,000 and present their proposals at the Singapore Fintech Festival in November. The initiative aims to showcase collaboration between the public and private sectors using digital means, despite the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: 'Life of Pi' actor Irrfan Khan dies at 53
summary: Indian actor Irrfan Khan, known for films like "Slumdog Millionaire" and "Life of Pi", has died at 53 due to complications from a colon infection. Diagnosed with a neuroendocrine tumour in 2018, Khan had been open about his struggles with cancer. Despite facing rejection in the Hindi film industry, he went on to achieve international success in Hollywood. Tributes have poured in from his colleagues, including Amitabh Bachchan and Karan Johar, praising his talent and dedication to his craft.

images.alt_text: Acclaimed Indian actor Irrfan Khan, whose international movie career included hits such as "Slumdog Millionaire", "Life of Pi" and "The Amazing Spider-Man", has died aged 53, his publicist said Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore's construction sector to take hard hit in 2020 amid Covid-19: Fitch Solutions
summary: Singapore's construction sector is expected to contract 10.3% in real terms this year due to the COVID-19 outbreak, making it the worst-hit market in the Asia-Pacific region. The sector was brought to a "virtual standstill" after the government suspended construction work and issued stay-home notices to construction workers. Fitch Solutions forecasts a 11.5% year-on-year decline in the buildings sector, with the industrial buildings sector expected to underperform. The infrastructure sector is expected to contract less, with high-value contracts still being awarded due to government plans to enhance the transport system.

images.alt_text: Singapore's construction sector is poised to take a hard hit from the Covid-19 outbreak in the short-term, and is now expected to contract sharply by 10.3 per cent this year in real terms, according to Fitch Solutions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish higher for third day
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a third consecutive day, driven by optimism as countries begin lifting lockdown measures and the coronavirus shows signs of easing. The Hang Seng Index gained 0.28%, closing at 24,643.59. This follows Asia-wide advances, with China's Shanghai Composite Index rising 0.44%. The global market sentiment is boosted by easing lockdowns and improving economic prospects, despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: EC World Reit manager donates 500,000 masks and medical supplies to Singapore
summary: EC World Reit's manager, Zhang Guobiao, donated 500,000 face masks and medical supplies to Singapore in response to the Covid-19 outbreak. The donation includes 5,000 protective coveralls and 5,000 overalls. Chairman Zhang stated that EC World REIT and its fund management company in Singapore want to support the government and people during this time. The donation was made in light of the global impact of the virus and EC World REIT's presence in Singapore.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: CIMB has delayed raising its mortgage floor rate to January 1, 2021, amid customer backlash. The bank, believed to be the first to increase its floor rate, initially planned to increase it to a non-zero rate amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Meanwhile, Vietnam reacted to a US tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate, while the Asian garment industry prepares for increased US tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Citigroup forecasts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index.

site_title: Billionaire activist investor calls on Wirecard to remove CEO Markus Braun
summary: Billionaire activist investor Christopher Hohn has called for Wirecard CEO Markus Braun's removal following an independent audit that criticized the company for internal "shortcomings" and unable to verify one billion euros in transactions. The probe, led by KPMG, was hired to investigate Wirecard's third-party partner business and operations in India and Singapore. Shares in Wirecard fell 37% in early trading.

images.alt_text: Billionaire activist investor Christopher Hohn has called on Wirecard to remove chief executive officer (CEO) Markus Braun after an independent audit of past revenues criticised the German payments processor for internal "shortcomings".

site_title: Singapore visitor arrivals in March lowest since Sars outbreak in 2003
summary: Singapore's visitor arrivals plummeted to 240,000 in March, the lowest since the Sars outbreak in 2003, with a 85% year-on-year drop. The tourism industry has been severely impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, with travel restrictions and closures of attractions and entertainment venues. The Singapore Tourism Board expects the decline to continue due to the global pandemic. Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for collective action among Asean countries to tackle the pandemic and promote regional connectivity for post-pandemic recovery.

site_title: Gig workers get help as fiscal stimulus catches up with times
summary: Governments worldwide are providing unprecedented fiscal stimulus to support the gig economy, with countries like the US, UK, France, Singapore, and Australia offering financial assistance to part-time and freelance workers. The support is aimed at addressing the lack of a safety net for self-employed individuals, who make up a significant portion of the global workforce. The initiatives, which include cash payments and subsidies, are expected to help mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic on this vulnerable group.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher as virus restrictions ease
summary: Australian shares rose 1.51% to 5,393.4 points, driven by strong domestic inflation data and easing coronavirus restrictions globally. The country's headline consumer price index rose 2.2% in the first quarter, its highest reading in five and a half years. However, the long-desired pick-up in inflation is likely fleeting due to a coronavirus lockdown and collapsing energy prices. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.9% due to losses in the healthcare and consumer sectors.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end higher on surprise factory output data
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.70% to close at 1,947.56 on April 29, ending the month with the sharpest monthly gain in 11 years. Factory output unexpectedly rose, and higher oil prices also contributed to the gains. The KOSPI index rose 10.99% in April, its sharpest monthly gain since July 2009. However, investors remained cautious ahead of public holidays, limiting further gains.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares rose on Wednesday, ending the month with the sharpest monthly gain in 11 years, as its factory output unexpectedly rose, while higher oil prices also aided sentiment.

site_title: StanChart eyes quick recovery as profit falls 12% on coronavirus crisis
summary: Standard Chartered reported a 12% profit decline in the first quarter due to the coronavirus crisis, with credit impairment rising to $956 million. Despite this, the bank expects a gradual recovery from the pandemic, with markets in its footprint likely to recover before the global economy moves out of recession in the latter part of 2020. The bank's shares rose 8% in afternoon trade, while its CEO Bill Winters said the bank delivered good underlying income growth and maintained strong cost discipline.

site_title: Keppel's net profit down 20.9% to S$160.5m on absence of divestment gain
summary: Keppel Corp's net profit fell 20.9% to S$160.5m in Q1, mainly due to the absence of divestment gains from Dong Nai Waterfront City. Revenue rose 21.3% to S$1.86 billion, driven by offshore and marine projects, property trading in Singapore, and the consolidation of telco M1. The company's offshore and marine segment posted a net loss, while its infrastructure division saw a significant increase in net profit. Keppel's chief executive Loh Chin Hua noted that the company is watching its cash flow and gearing closely amid the COVID-19 pandemic and oil price shock.

site_title: State inequality, energy trends among Malaysia's challenges: report
summary: Malaysia faces challenges in maintaining its growth trajectory, including state inequality and changing energy trends. A Moody's Analytics report highlights the income gap between states, with the East Malaysian states receiving only 5% of oil revenue, despite producing a majority of the country's oil. The report also notes that Malaysia is heavily dependent on volatile commodity prices and changing global demand, with plans to diversify its energy sources. To address these challenges, the country needs to develop strategies to reduce income inequality and adapt to global energy trends.

site_title: Ngee Ann Poly offers job support to graduating students amid Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Ngee Ann Polytechnic has launched a graduation support package, Career Jumpstart, to aid its class of 2020 graduates amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The package includes employment and learning opportunities, campus job placements, and free continuing education and training programs. Over 80 campus job placements and 150 work-study program placements have been secured for graduates. The polytechnic also offers education and career guidance counseling and has launched a GoSchool programming language academy with job placement opportunities.

site_title: US virus cases hit a million as Germans wear masks in shops
summary: The US reported its one millionth coronavirus case, as European countries, including Germany, began to lift lockdowns. Masks became mandatory in all German shops starting Wednesday. Despite tentative steps towards normality, experts warn of the risk of new outbreaks and growing economic devastation. The pandemic has left tens of millions unemployed globally, with forecasts predicting the worst global recession in a century.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's Q1 budget slips into deficit as oil revenue slides
summary: Saudi Arabia reported a 1Q budget deficit of 34.107 billion Saudi riyals (S$12.9 billion) due to sliding oil prices, demand, and a supply glut amid the coronavirus crisis. This reverses a 1Q surplus of around US$7.4 billion in 2019. The kingdom projects a deficit of 187 billion riyals, or 6.4% of GDP, this year. Oil revenues dropped 24% to 128.771 billion riyals, mainly driven by slumping global crude demand and prices. The government plans to finance the deficit through local and international borrowing.

site_title: Airbus burns through US$8.7b as aviation crisis deepens
summary: Airbus reported a record quarterly cash burn of $8.7 billion due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with 3.6 billion euros spent on a bribery case settlement. CEO Guillaume Faury warned of the "gravest crisis" in the aerospace industry, citing reduced demand for new aircraft and existing orders. The company has reduced capital spending, extended credit lines, and furloughed over 6,000 jobs. Airbus now expects to deliver around 600 planes this year, down from 863 in 2019, and faces tough decisions on jobs amid the crisis.

site_title: Barclays profit falls sharply as coronavirus hurts borrowers
summary: Barclays reported a 38% drop in first-quarter profits to £923 million, lower than analyst forecasts. The bank set aside £2.1 billion to cover potential loan losses due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite this, group income rose 20% to £6.3 billion, driven by a surge in its transatlantic investment bank. Barclays maintained its return on tangible equity target of greater than 10% and delivered a group ROTE of 5.1%. The bank expects 2020 to be challenging due to the economic downturn and low interest rate environment.

site_title: Huan Hsin's chairman and MD make exit offer at 1.6 cents a share
summary: Huan Hsin, an electronics contract manufacturer, has received an exit offer from its chairman and managing director Hsu Hung Chun and Hsu Cheng Chien, valued at S$0.016 per share, a 14.3% premium to the last-traded price. The offeror, Pacific Moment Holdings, now owns 38.17% of the company, and the offer price represents a significant premium to the company's recent performance, which recorded a loss per share of S$0.0062 in FY2018.

site_title: City of Beijing may ease quarantine rules as early as Thursday: sources
summary: Beijing may ease quarantine rules for domestic travelers from low-risk areas as early as Thursday, according to sources. People arriving from low-risk areas will no longer be required to quarantine for two weeks, except for high-risk areas like Heilongjiang and parts of Guangdong. The decision comes ahead of a major political gathering in the city. The municipal government has not commented on the move.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain amid easing virus curbs; Crown Resorts jumps
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 5,333.1 points, driven by improved risk sentiment amid phased easing of coronavirus lockdowns. Crown Resorts surged 12% after Blackstone acquired a stake. Financial stocks and energy stocks also gained, with heavyweight stocks adding 2.1% and energy stocks rising 2.5%.

site_title: Shopee offers SMEs financial, educational support
summary: Shopee, a leading e-commerce platform, is offering a tailored support package to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore and its seven neighboring markets, aiming to accelerate digitalization and promote long-term sustainability. The package includes financial relief, educational support, and logistics assistance to ease operational costs and help SMEs refine their e-commerce strategies. This move is seen as crucial to support SMEs, which account for a majority of the region's employment and gross domestic product, and are particularly vulnerable to macroeconomic headwinds.

site_title: Indonesian startup Stoqo becomes latest casualty of coronavirus
summary: Indonesian startup Stoqo, which delivered fresh ingredients to food outlets, is shutting down due to the coronavirus pandemic's drastic reduction in income. Founded in 2017, Stoqo employed around 250 people before ceasing operations. The company's collapse is part of a growing trend of tech startups in the region struggling to cope with the pandemic's economic impact. Other startups, such as Traveloka, have also taken cost-cutting measures to deal with the cash crunch. Stoqo's shutdown highlights the heavy toll of the pandemic on Indonesia's tech industry.

site_title: Singapore's Q1 total employment sees sharpest contraction since Sars
summary: Singapore's total employment contracted by 19,000 in Q1 2020, the sharpest quarterly decline in 17 years, mainly due to a significant decline in foreign employment amid the COVID-19 outbreak. The overall unemployment rate rose to 2.4%, with resident unemployment at 3.3% and citizen unemployment at 3.5%. Despite these numbers, they remain lower than those seen during the Sars outbreak and the 2009 global financial crisis.

site_title: SMRT Taxis extends full rental waiver, expands food delivery tie-ups
summary: SMRT Taxis has extended its full rental waiver for its cabbies until June 1, 2020, as part of efforts to cushion the financial impact of "circuit-breaker" measures. The waiver, which costs SMRT an additional S$6 million, brings the total support to around S$20 million. This move aims to support taxi drivers during the difficult period, with SMRT continuing to explore other ways to support its taxi partners.

site_title: Copying rich world's virus plan is big risk for emerging markets
summary: Developing economies are adopting a playbook used in rich countries since 2008 to fight the coronavirus, buying government debt to stabilize financial markets and support fiscal deficits. However, this policy carries a risk of scaring off short-term foreign capital, reviving inflation, and triggering a financial meltdown. Already, emerging markets have seen outflows surpass the 2008 global financial crisis, with some currencies plunging over 20%. Policymakers are weighing the risks of monetizing fiscal deficits, with some countries considering unconventional measures like yield-curve control.

site_title: SK Innovation to start building second electric-vehicle battery plant in US
summary: SK Innovation plans to build its second electric-vehicle battery plant in the US, worth $727 million, with an annual capacity of 11.7 gigawatt-hours, starting construction in July 2020. The plant will join its first factory, also in the US, which is expected to begin production in 2022 and cost $1.5 billion. The investment is part of the company's rapid expansion into EV batteries, with factories in South Korea, China, and Hungary.

site_title: More than 2,200 US coronavirus deaths in 24 hours: tracker
summary: The US reported 2,207 additional coronavirus deaths in a 24-hour period, bringing the total to 58,351, surpassing the number of US fatalities in the Vietnam War. This surpasses the previous record held by the National Archives. The US also reached 1 million cases of new coronavirus infections, accounting for about one-third of the world's total cases.

site_title: Boeing eyes major bond issue to raise funds: sources
summary: Boeing is working with investment banks on a multibillion-dollar bond-fueled financing package to strengthen its balance sheet amid a travel downturn from the pandemic. The company aims to raise up to $10 billion, despite considering government aid under a $17 billion program. Boeing's CEO, David Calhoun, has been wary of government aid, citing potential equity stakes. The company is also exploring funding support from the Federal Reserve, and its funding needs are estimated to be around $30 billion in 2020.

images.alt_text: Boeing is working with investment banks on a multibillion-dollar bond-fueled financing package, aiming to shore up its balance sheet amid a sharp travel downturn from the pandemic, three people familiar with the matter said on Tuesday

site_title: Uber, Tripadvisor hit with massive layoffs as virus outbreak dries up business
summary: Uber and Tripadvisor are implementing massive layoffs due to the coronavirus outbreak. Uber plans to cut 20% of its global staff, affecting over 5,400 employees, while Tripadvisor will lay off over 900 employees, about a quarter of its workforce. The companies are offering severance pay and outplacement support to affected staff. The layoffs are part of a broader trend of businesses in the travel and retail sectors cutting costs to conserve cash amid the pandemic's economic impact.

site_title: China's Pinduoduo alerts police to suspected bribery involving Cue manager: sources
summary: Chinese e-commerce firm Pinduoduo Inc has referred a case of suspected bribery involving a Cue Holdings manager to the Shanghai police. A Cue sales manager allegedly bribed a Pinduoduo manager to win a four billion yuan (S$799.9 million) advertising budget last year, totaling over two million yuan. Senior executives at KKR, which controls Cue, are aware of the issue and are investigating. Both Pinduoduo and Cue have declined to comment further due to the ongoing investigation.

site_title: JD said to file for US$2b Hong Kong second listing
summary: JD.com Inc., a Chinese e-commerce giant, has filed confidentially for a second listing in Hong Kong, aiming to raise at least US$2 billion. The Beijing-based company currently trades on Nasdaq with a market value of US$64 billion. This move follows Alibaba's US$13 billion Hong Kong share sale last year, which marked a homecoming for Chinese companies on the Hong Kong stock market. The deal is seen as a win for Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing, which relaxed dual-class share voting rules in 2018.

site_title: Deutsche Bank swings to Q1 loss amid restructuring, coronavirus outbreak
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a Q1 loss of 43 million euros, swinging to a loss from a 97 million euro profit a year ago, amid a costly overhaul and revenue pressure amid the coronavirus crisis. The bank's earnings results showed a revenue lift from a surge in trading, exceeding analyst expectations. The bank's restructuring efforts are ongoing, with the goal of improving its financial performance and competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank swung to a loss in the first quarter as the bank undergoes a costly overhaul and battles pressure on revenue amid the coronavirus crisis, the German lender said on Wednesday.

site_title: Australia says Covid-19 inquiry is "reasonable", not targeted at any country
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison has defended the country's call for an independent inquiry into the origins of Covid-19, stating it's "reasonable" and not targeted at China. The call came after Morrison's comments on Australia-China relations, but he clarified that the inquiry is aimed at understanding the global impact of the virus. Morrison emphasized that the inquiry is necessary given the virus's extraordinary implications, including over 200,000 deaths worldwide and the global economic shutdown.

site_title: SkillsFuture Singapore suspends Wong Fong unit from funding schemes for a year
summary: SKILLSFUTURE Singapore suspended Ascer, a subsidiary of Wong Fong Industries, from funding schemes for 12 months after finding breaches of the SkillsConnect general terms and conditions. Ascer made restitution payments of S$101,000. Wong Fong Industries noted that the audit committee has directed management to rectify lapses and review internal controls. The company believes these measures will prevent similar lapses in the future.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks build on gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.85% on Wednesday, extending a rally as the government prepares to open up parts of the city after a day of no new infections. The Hang Seng Index reached 24,786.02, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.31%. The gains come as investors await the government's plan to reopen the city.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares opened with further gains on Wednesday morning, extending a rally as the government prepares to open up parts of the city after recording another day of no new infections.

site_title: Hot stock: iX Biopharma shares surge after Xativa supply pact in Australia
summary: iX Biopharma's shares surged 22.4% after the company formalized a supply agreement with Cannatrek Medical Pty Ltd to supply its medicinal cannabis product Xativa in Australia. The agreement allows iX Biopharma to start supplying Xativa to pharmacies across Australia, and it will also be prescribed by medical practitioners through the Special Access Scheme. As a result, the company's shares rose to 30 cents, up from a Tuesday closing price of 24.5 cents.

site_title: Temasek Trust launches S$10m fund for initiatives that support virus-hit communities
summary: Temasek Trust has launched an S$10 million fund, oscar@sg, to support ground-up initiatives aiding communities affected by the COVID-19 outbreak. The fund, anchored by a S$10 million sum from Temasek Holdings, provides up to S$5,000 in direct sponsorship and matches third-party funding up to S$50,000. The fund aims to support community needs exacerbated by the crisis, with applicants required to submit a workable implementation plan. The initiative, led by Cheo Hock Kuan, CEO of Temasek Trust, encourages participation from individuals, groups, and non-profit organizations.

site_title: Singapore shares pare previous day's gains; STI down 0.2% at open
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 2,557.35 at open on Wednesday, reversing its previous uptrend. The decline was attributed to overnight losses in the US and the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) half-year report, which predicted a more sharp contraction in GDP in the second quarter due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Layoffs and unemployment are also expected to rise this year despite a massive fiscal stimulus.

site_title: Blackstone buys A$552m stake in Australia's Crown Resorts; shares soar
summary: US private equity firm Blackstone Group has acquired a majority stake in Australia's Crown Resorts for approximately A$552 million, buying 67.7 million shares from Melco Resorts & Entertainment. The deal comes after Melco shelved a bid to raise its stake in Crown due to declining traveler numbers. The transaction value represents a 5.2% discount to Crown's last closing price, with shares soaring following the announcement.

site_title: Asia: Equities build on gains as more nations ease lockdowns
summary: Asian equities rose on Wednesday, driven by further easing of lockdown measures in countries such as France, Germany, and parts of the US. Markets have rebounded over 20% from March lows, boosted by government stimulus and central bank support. However, concerns about a second wave of infections and the impact on the global economy remain. The US economy is expected to show a contraction in the first quarter, and the Federal Reserve will end its policy meeting, with traders awaiting guidance on future bond purchases.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed on Wednesday for holiday
summary: Financial markets in Japan closed on Wednesday for a public holiday, with trading resuming on Thursday, April 30. In other news, Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, while Asia markets were boosted by mining and healthcare shares and US-EU trade talks. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S$T Index up 0.4% on Thursday. Meanwhile, eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: China's legislature to meet in May after virus delay
summary: China's top legislature, the National People's Congress, will hold its annual session on May 22, rescheduling it for the first time in decades due to the COVID-19 outbreak. The decision, made by the NPC Standing Committee, signals the country's confidence in bringing the outbreak under control. The session, which typically rubber-stamps bills and personnel moves, will be attended by top Communist Party leaders, including President Xi Jinping, and nearly 3,000 delegates. The gathering, originally scheduled for March 5, will be a significant event in China's political and economic policy priorities for the coming year.

site_title: CIMB to delay raising mortgage floor rate to Jan 1, 2021 after customer furore
summary: CIMB Singapore has delayed the effective date of its minimum mortgage floor rate from May 18, 2020, to January 1, 2021, due to customer feedback and the COVID-19 circuit breaker in Singapore. The bank will waive penalty and administrative fees for customers who wish to refinance. The move follows criticism from customers who felt the rate increase was "highly unethical" and intended to challenge the bank. The decision is believed to be the first by a bank to increase its floor rate for floating-rate mortgages amid the pandemic.

site_title: US government reveals details of sunlight study on coronavirus
summary: The US Department of Homeland Security has revealed details of a study on how ultraviolet radiation destroys the coronavirus, stating that its experiment accurately mimicked natural sunlight. The study found that the amount of virus on a non-porous surface shrunk by half in two minutes when sunlight was present, and by half in 1.5 minutes at room temperature and 20% humidity. However, experts have expressed caution, citing previous research that showed the SARS-CoV virus did not respond to UVA light, and suggesting that the results may be "straining credulity."

site_title: ComfortDelGro Taxi starts food delivery service
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp has launched its dedicated food and beverage delivery service, ComfortDelivery, to support taxi drivers during the COVID-19 pandemic. The service, available daily from 9am to 10pm, uses a fleet of 10,000 taxis and charges a distance-based rate starting from S$6.50 per trip. F&B outlets pay directly to the taxi drivers through PayNow or cash, with no fee imposed during the "circuit-breaker" period. The service aims to provide a fast and affordable delivery option for consumers while helping taxi drivers earn extra income.

site_title: US coronavirus deaths top Vietnam War toll: tracker
summary: The US coronavirus death toll has surpassed the Vietnam War toll, with 58,365 reported deaths, according to the Johns Hopkins University tracker. This surpasses the 58,220 US casualties in the war. The US death toll and number of cases (over one million) far exceed that of any other country, including communist Vietnam, which has recorded 270 cases and no deaths.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust appoints financial adviser; 5 hotel managers exit
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust has appointed financial adviser Moelis & Company to assist in the restructuring process, following the departure of five hotel managers. The managers had previously sent termination notices to their master lessees, leading to the closure of five US hotels. Temporary caretaker services are now being provided by GF Hotels & Resorts to preserve asset values and minimize losses during the Covid-19 pandemic. The trust's special committee and trustee will continue to assess the master lease agreements and explore options for achieving the best possible outcomes for stapled security holders.

site_title: Oil rebounds, but gains capped by virus worries
summary: Oil prices rebounded 8.35% to $13.37 a barrel after a US exchange-traded fund started selling its short-term contracts, but gains were capped due to concerns about a coronavirus-induced demand collapse and low storage capacity.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rebounded on Wednesday but gains were capped due to concerns about a collapse in demand due to the coronavirus pandemic and storage capacity running low.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 0.27 points or 0.02% to 1,372.47. Volume was 102.32 million lots worth RM27.08 million, with gainers beating losers 186 to 41.

site_title: YouTube expands fact-check panels in move against misinformation
summary: YouTube began adding fact-check panels to search results in the US for videos on hot-topic claims deemed false, expanding a feature launched last year in Brazil and India. The panels, developed in partnership with over a dozen US organizations, aim to reduce misinformation and promote credible sources. The feature, initially tested two years ago, will be shown when users search for false claims, such as Covid-19 being a bioweapon. YouTube plans to expand the feature to more countries as the system's accuracy improves.

site_title: Singapore's 'Beng Who Cooks' offers free meals for needy during Covid-19 lockdown
summary: A 28-year-old Singaporean cook, Jason Chua, has been offering free meals to those in need since the city-state's lockdown in April due to the Covid-19 pandemic. As food stalls around him have closed, Chua's "Beng Who Cooks" has been serving up dozens of free meals daily through a foundation, Beng Who Cares, co-run by his friend Sean Hung. The foundation refuses donations, instead relying on cash and donations from others, with Chua motivated by positive feedback from those who enjoy his food, aiming to sustain himself and others throughout the economic hardship.

site_title: Samsung Electronics reports 3% drop in Q1 net profit
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 3% drop in Q1 net profits to 4.88 trillion won (S$5.67 billion), primarily due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on consumer demand. The company attributed the decline to store and plant closures globally, affecting sales and profits of set products, including smartphones and TVs. Operating profit rose 3.5% year-on-year to 6.5 trillion won, while sales in the first quarter stood at 55.3 trillion won. The company expects uncertainties from Covid-19 to persist in the latter half of 2020.

images.alt_text: The world's biggest smartphone maker, Samsung Electronics, reported a three-percent drop in first-quarter net profits on Wednesday, as the coronavirus pandemic dampened consumer demand.

site_title: British expat pays S$10k a month to swim in Sentosa Cove bungalow's pool
summary: A British expat in Singapore is paying S$10,000 per month to use the private pool of a luxury Sentosa Cove bungalow due to his own condominium pool being closed during the Covid-19 circuit breaker measures. The deal was arranged by a real estate agent, who agreed to lease out the pool and garden on a short-term basis. The man's family has access to the bungalow through a side gate, and the arrangement is seen as a first for the agent, who has typically rented out entire properties or amenities.

site_title: British Airways set to cut up to 12,000 jobs
summary: British Airways is set to cut up to 12,000 jobs as part of a restructuring plan due to the novel coronavirus fallout. The airline's parent company, IAG, has announced the plans, which are expected to affect most employees and result in redundancy. Passenger demand is unlikely to return to 2019 levels for several years, with IAG reporting a 13% decline in first-quarter revenue and an operating loss of 535 million euros. The airline has reduced passenger capacity by 94% for April and May.

site_title: Aviation industry warns of cargo capacity shortfall
summary: The global aviation industry is warning of a severe cargo capacity shortage due to the coronavirus crisis. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) reported a 15% drop in cargo volumes and a 22.7% decline in capacity, citing a doubling of demand for pharmaceutical shipments. Airlines are slashing jobs and suffering plunges in profits, with IATA chief Alexandre de Juniac urging governments to cut red tape to ensure the safe operation of special flights. The industry faces years of financial difficulty, with IATA rescheduling its annual general meeting to address the damage and plot recovery.

site_title: US: Stocks end down after volatile session, weak data
summary: US stocks ended lower on Tuesday after a volatile session, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing 0.1%, the S&P 500 dipping 0.5%, and the Nasdaq Composite tumbling 1.4%. Mixed earnings reports and weak consumer data, including a plunge in April's consumer confidence to 86.9, underscored economic challenges. Despite optimism about future improvements, investors expressed skepticism about the market's buoyancy throughout April.

site_title: Brokers impose higher margins, restrictions on oil futures trading
summary: Several brokerages have increased margin requirements or imposed restrictions on oil futures trading to safeguard clients amid unprecedented volatility. Despite these restrictions, trading interest remains unchanged.

site_title: Fitch cuts Italy's credit rating to 'BBB-minus' with stable outlook
summary: Fitch has cut Italy's credit rating to 'BBB-minus' with a stable outlook, reflecting the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on the euro zone's third largest economy. The downgrade, one notch above junk, comes despite a stable outlook, citing the European Central Bank's net asset purchases as a supportive factor for Italy's fiscal response to the pandemic. The move is another blow to a country with the world's second highest death toll from the virus and a chronically sluggish economy heading into recession.

site_title: Olam obtains US$176m term loans to buy agri-commodities from smallholder farmers
summary: Olam International has secured US$176 million in term loans from the International Finance Corporation and Japan International Cooperation Agency to purchase agri-commodities from smallholder farmers in five countries, including Indonesia. The loans will support the expansion of its Indonesia cocoa processing facility and help smallholder farmers access global markets, boosting their incomes. The move is part of Olam's efforts to build a sustainable agri-business, tackling environmental and social issues. The loans consist of a five-year and seven-year term loan, providing stability and reliable access to smallholder farmers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sheng Siong, DBS, UOB, OCBC, SIA, Ascendas Reit, Dairy Farm
summary: Sheng Siong Group posted a 49.9% increase in net profit to S$29 million for its first quarter, with shares rising 0.7% to S$1.46. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC are expected to face higher provisions due to oil and gas exposure and the recession, with their shares rising 0.4%, 0.4%, and 0.9% respectively.

site_title: Top US theatre chain pulls Universal films over streaming row
summary: The leading US movie theatre chain has stopped playing Universal Pictures movies on its screens due to a row over the direct release of "Trolls World Tour" on streaming platforms. The decision comes after Universal released the film directly to on-demand platforms last month, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The move is seen as a response to the theatre chain's concerns over the impact of streaming on the film industry.

images.alt_text: The leading US movie theatre chain said on Tuesday it will no longer play any Universal Pictures movies on its screens as a row over the record-breaking release of Trolls World Tour on streaming platforms sharply escalated.

site_title: FLT renamed Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust after merger
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) has been renamed Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) following a S$1.58 billion merger. The new trust's trading name will be Frasers L&C Tr. and its manager has been renamed Frasers Logistics & Commercial Asset Management. As of Dec 31, 2019, FLCT has a portfolio of assets worth about S$5.9 billion across the Asia-Pacific, Europe, and the UK. The trust's stock code remains unchanged at BUOU. The merger took effect on May 4, 2020.

site_title: Ford says 2nd-quarter loss due to coronavirus to exceed US$5b
summary: Ford Motor Co reported a $2 billion first-quarter loss due to the coronavirus pandemic, citing a shutdown of its North American plants. The company expects its second-quarter loss to exceed $5 billion and has slashed costs, including cutting salaries of executives and white-collar employees. Ford plans to restart most of its European manufacturing on May 4 and has sufficient cash to last until the end of the year, despite a downgrade to "junk" credit rating.

site_title: Hillary Clinton endorses Biden's White House bid
summary: Former US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has endorsed Joe Biden's White House bid, calling him the country's "real president" and criticizing incumbent Donald Trump. Clinton, who lost the 2016 presidential election to Trump, expressed her support for Biden during a live video linkup, citing his experience and ability to lead the nation through the COVID-19 pandemic. Biden has been endorsed by several prominent Democrats, including former President Barack Obama, and faces Trump in the November 3 election.

images.alt_text: Hillary Clinton endorsed Joe Biden's White House bid on Tuesday, saying the United States needs a "real president" and not just "somebody who plays one on TV."

site_title: 'Decisive' fall in local community cases key to circuit breaker rollback
summary: Singapore's daily coronavirus cases have started to ease, but authorities are waiting for a "decisive reduction" in local community transmission before relaxing enhanced circuit breaker measures. National Development Minister Lawrence Wong stated that the trend is improving, but caution is needed before making any moves. The goal is to ensure a significant decrease in local transmission before considering a rollback.

site_title: California plans to reopen some retail, manufacturing within weeks
summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom announced plans to reopen some retail and manufacturing businesses within weeks as coronavirus testing and tracing improves. Non-essential businesses, such as offices and childcare facilities, will be in the first phase of reopening, along with some parks. Schools may resume in July to make up for lost learning time. To meet safety benchmarks, the state must achieve statewide contact tracing and a stabilization in hospitalizations. Higher-risk businesses, such as nail salons and concerts, will take months to restart.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise on bank rally; Wirecard shares crash
summary: European stocks rose 1.7% to seven-week highs, driven by a rally in banking shares. UBS and Santander reported strong profits, lifting the sector to its highest point in two weeks. Despite HSBC's warning of earnings pain ahead, the sector's gains were broad-based. The healthcare sector declined 0.1%, while Novartis reported growth in quarterly sales. European stocks have recovered over 25% from mid-March lows, with optimism fueled by easing lockdowns and central bank support.

site_title: Brent settles higher on hopes of easing lockdowns, US crude falls amid storage shortage
summary: US crude prices fell 3.4% to $12.34 a barrel on Tuesday, while global benchmark Brent crude rose 2.3% to $20.46 a barrel. Despite a 10 million barrel increase in domestic stockpiles, markets were supported by hopes for easing lockdowns and a recovery in demand. Oil traders are resorting to expensive storage measures due to low storage levels, and Opec oil supply in April reached its highest since December 2018. Production cuts are expected to take effect from May 1, with global demand forecast to drop 15 million barrels per day in the second quarter.

site_title: Pence flouts US hospital's mask policy during visit
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence visited the Mayo Clinic without wearing a face mask, violating the hospital's policy and CDC guidelines. The clinic had shared the masking policy with Pence's office, but he claimed he didn't wear a mask because he wasn't infected and masks only prevent transmission by those who are infected. Pence's actions have sparked speculation of a coordinated decision to downplay the severity of the COVID-19 crisis, with other senior White House officials also ignoring CDC guidelines.

site_title: IMF approves US$3.4b for Nigeria to address coronavirus
summary: The IMF has approved a US$3.4 billion loan for Nigeria to address the economic damage caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The loan aims to support the Nigerian government's efforts to address the severe economic impact of the pandemic and the sharp fall in oil prices. This is part of the IMF's Rapid Financing Instrument, which has received over 100 requests for aid from its members, totaling approximately US$2.5 trillion. The loan will help Nigeria mitigate the effects of the pandemic, which has been exacerbated by the global demand for oil products.

site_title: Kazakhstan close to deal with Big Oil to cut output 22%: sources
summary: Kazakhstan is close to a deal with major oil companies operating at its Tengiz and Kashagan fields to cut output by 22% from May, aiming to meet a global supply pact. The country plans to reduce its overall oil output by 22-23% from the first quarter's average, with Tengizchevroil and the Kashagan field set to participate. The cuts will impact CPC Blend exports, with traders expecting a revised May loading plan at 5.73 million tonnes, down from the initial 5.73 million tonnes.

site_title: Alphabet-Google profit up despite pandemic-linked ad slump
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, reported a profit of $6.8 billion in the first quarter, a 3% increase from last year, despite a pandemic-induced economic slump that hit advertising revenue. Revenue grew 13% to $41 billion, driven by search, cloud computing, and YouTube ads. Alphabet's ad revenue rose 10% for the quarter, with YouTube's ad revenue increasing by 33% to $4 billion. The company's focus on efficiency and long-term opportunities is expected to help it navigate the pandemic's impact on the digital ad market.

site_title: Toilet paper trophy hunters on a roll as US shortages start easing
summary: US consumers are spotting rare Quilted Northern and Charmin toilet paper rolls on store shelves, as stocks start easing after weeks of severe shortages. According to data from NCSolutions, about 48% of US grocery stores were out of stock of toilet paper on April 19, down from 73% the previous week. Demand remains high, up 27% from pre-Covid-19 levels, with the average US household using about 409 rolls per year. Companies like Procter & Gamble and Georgia Pacific are boosting production to meet demand, with some plants running 24/7 to meet record production months.

site_title: 3M earnings rise on demand for medical masks
summary: 3M reported a 45% jump in first-quarter profits to $1.3 billion, driven by a 21% surge in sales in its healthcare business. The company ramped up production of N95 masks, with global output doubled to 1.1 billion per year, to combat the coronavirus outbreak. Despite this, global demand for respirators far outpaces supply, with 3M prioritizing critical needs. The company cut spending by $350-400 million and withdrew its full-year profit forecast due to uncertainty. Executives also announced measures to combat price-gouging and fraud, including a toll-free hotline and publishing prices for N95 respirators.

site_title: Riksbank: Rate cut may yet come, but not needed now
summary: The Riksbank, Sweden's central bank, has left its main interest rate at zero, as expected, but may consider cutting it to negative rates in the future if needed to stimulate demand and support inflation during the recovery phase. The bank will continue to purchase government and mortgage bonds until the end of September 2020. Despite a possible rate cut, the bank's governor has downplayed the need to return to negative rates, citing the need for monetary policy stimulus in the form of low interest rates and liquidity.

site_title: Trump expected to order US meat plants to stay open amid food supply fears
summary: US President Donald Trump is expected to sign an emergency order compelling meat packing plants to stay open despite high coronavirus cases, to secure the country's food supply. The order will invoke the Defence Production Act, but the nation's largest meatpacking union, UFCW, urges more safety precautions for workers. At least 20 meatpacking workers have died from coronavirus, and over 5,000 have been hospitalized or showing symptoms. Trump's move aims to prevent food shortages, but the UFCW prioritizes worker safety.

site_title: APB donates S$75,000 to support migrant workers affected by Covid-19
summary: APB Foundation, the philanthropic arm of Asia Pacific Breweries (APB), announced a S$75,000 donation to support migrant workers affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The donation will be used to provide daily necessities, food, and accommodation for migrant workers in isolation, as well as financial support for those unable to work due to the "circuit-breaker" measures. Migrant workers, who make up over 70% of Singapore's total Covid-19 infections, are among the most vulnerable groups hit by the outbreak.

site_title: Some bubble tea and other F&B players find ways around circuit breaker
summary: During Singapore's circuit breaker period, some food and beverage outlets temporarily closed, but others found ways to continue operations by partnering with third-party brands. Establishments such as bubble tea shops offered their items as part of a set, bypassing the restrictions. Meanwhile, other businesses, including Teochew City and Rookery restaurants, started to fold due to the tighter restrictions.

site_title: The big tilt away from China
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated a trend of decoupling from China, driven by rising labor costs and the US-China trade war. China's economy remains a significant player, but the shift towards lower-wage economies like Vietnam, India, and Indonesia is underway. As the world becomes less dependent on China, countries like Vietnam, India, and Indonesia are poised to emerge as new economic powers. Indonesia has the potential to become a major agribusiness player, but its manufacturing sector needs to adapt to attract investments. The pandemic has exposed the vulnerabilities of global supply chains, and the West and Indo-Pacific must act to reduce dependence on China.

site_title: Stack launches 'institutional grade' Bitcoin tracker fund
summary: Stack, a Singapore-based digital asset investment platform, has launched its flagship product, the BTCX100 Bitcoin Fund, offering 100% long-only exposure to Bitcoin. The fund is designed to boost confidence among institutional and private investors, with a minimum investment of US$100,000 and an annual management fee of 2.25%. The fund has attracted institutional commitments of around US$160 million, with a focus on diversification benefits and a perceived "safe haven" asset. The fund's success is attributed to the heavily anticipated Bitcoin "halving" in May and the potential for significant price rises.

site_title: Fiscal policy remains key as disinflationary pressures rise: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) expects disinflationary pressures to rise as the Covid-19 pandemic's demand shock reverberates, but fiscal policy will be the main response. MAS forecasts core and headline inflation to turn negative this year, with all major components declining, except for food prices. Monetary policy is seen as a blunt instrument, less effective than fiscal policy in tackling the crisis. MAS maintains its forecasts for growth and inflation, but notes a risk of growth falling below the forecast range. The MAS keeps its exchange rate policy unchanged, with a zero per cent per annum rate of appreciation starting at the prevailing level of the S$NEER band.

site_title: New York AG raises concerns about Amazon's pandemic safety practices
summary: New York Attorney General Letitia James has raised concerns about Amazon's pandemic safety practices, stating that the company may have violated labor laws by firing a warehouse protest leader, Christian Smalls. Amazon terminated Smalls after he joined a demonstration at a Staten Island warehouse, citing a paid quarantine violation. The AG's office claims Amazon's health measures are inadequate and may have been used to silence employee complaints. The company has taken "extreme measures" to keep employees safe, but the AG's letter calls for adequate sanitization and disinfection of warehouses.

site_title: Street artists stay home to recount the lockdown
summary: Street artists in Paris have adapted to the COVID-19 lockdown by staying home and working online, rather than creating public art on city walls. Despite previously operating in a legal grey area, most urban artists have taken social distancing measures seriously, revisiting old work with confinement-inspired twists. This shift highlights the creative ways artists are finding to continue their craft during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: An artwork from street artist Angel Crow on a wall in Paris. Isolation has had the opposite effect on Angel Crow. In his Paris apartment, work is piling up - some of which is related to the virus.

site_title: Singapore consumer satisfaction at record high
summary: Singapore's consumer satisfaction has reached a record high of 74.3 points in the 2019 Customer Satisfaction Index of Singapore (CSISG), up 1.2% from the previous year. The improvement was driven by local consumers across various industries, with the food and beverage sector leading the way. The CSISG study surveyed nearly 30,000 questionnaires across eight industry sectors, showing significant increases in customer satisfaction levels. Experts suggest that businesses must focus on continuous measurement, customer expectations, and preferences to maintain high customer satisfaction.

site_title: Should SIA review its fuel hedging policy?
summary: Singapore Airlines' (SIA) fuel hedging policy may have exposed shareholders to unnecessary losses due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The airline has hedged 79% of its fuel requirements for the next two months at US$76 per barrel, but spot market prices have fallen below this rate. This results in the airline losing out on payments to counterparties, such as banks. The article suggests reviewing SIA's fuel hedging policy to minimize potential losses.

site_title: Thriving in a digital economy
summary: The digital economy is expected to add $10 billion to Singapore's GDP by 2021, with Asia Pacific (APJ) region witnessing significant growth in digital transformation initiatives. Businesses in APJ need to build infrastructure that supports scalable applications, agility, and customer experience. Key trends include leveraging unique digital ecosystems, adopting emerging technologies, and transforming industries such as manufacturing and healthcare. Companies must adopt a holistic view, modernize processes, and cultivate a culture of innovation to succeed in digital transformation, which is critical for competitiveness.

site_title: Asian Pay TV proposes 1-for-4 rights issue; declares unchanged 0.3 cent Q1 DPU
summary: Asian Pay TV Trust has proposed a 1-for-4 rights issue to raise S$46.2 million, mainly to reduce offshore debt. The proposal, if approved, will result in the issuance of 361.3 million rights units at 12.8 Singapore cents each. The trust's financial results for Q1 2020 showed a 18.5% decline in net profit to S$6 million and a 0.3 cent unchanged ordinary interim distribution per unit (DPU). The rights issue is subject to approval from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Ascendas Reit reports 'healthy' Q1 operational performance
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a "healthy" operational performance for Q1, with a 91.7% overall portfolio occupancy rate. Occupancies remained stable in overseas portfolios, with a 8% positive rental reversion in multi-tenant buildings. Aggregate leverage was 36.2% and debt-maturity profile was "well-spread". The Reit will pass on fully any reduction in property tax granted by the government to its tenants, and retail and F&B tenants will have their rents waived for April and May. The Reit's units rose 4 cents to S$2.86 following the update.

site_title: Infrastructure financing platform Bayfront inks deals with 15 banks
summary: Bayfront Infrastructure Management, a Singapore-based infrastructure financing platform, has partnered with 15 global banks, including DBS, OCBC, and Citi, to acquire loans and redistribute them to institutional investors. The platform aims to raise US$600 million annually to build a portfolio of loans, addressing the infrastructure financing gap in Asia-Pacific. The move is backed by the Singapore government and aims to recycle bank loans, freeing up balance sheets and providing institutional investors with a diversified portfolio.

site_title: Singapore banks in spotlight over upcoming Q1 provisions, dividends
summary: Singapore banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB are expected to report higher bad loan provisions and lower earnings in Q1 2020 due to the global pandemic's impact on the economy. The banks' oil and gas exposure will also weigh on earnings. Analysts expect earnings to decline by 13-18% and dividends to be cut, with provisions potentially reaching up to 6-8% of net profit. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) guidance on provisioning will be crucial in determining the level of credit costs.

site_title: Germany taps SAP, Deutsche Telekom for contact tracing app
summary: Germany has partnered with SAP and Deutsche Telekom to develop a contact tracing app to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The decentralized solution will collect anonymous data about nearby mobile phones using Bluetooth technology and alert users if they've been in proximity to an infected individual. This approach is expected to create more trust among users, according to Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman, Steffen Seibert. The decision aligns with European governments' efforts to utilize national champions to build solutions to the pandemic, with other countries like the UK and Australia also developing their own apps.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Cache Logistics Trust has been renamed ARA Logos Logistics Trust (ALog) with a new trading name and stock code, while maintaining its existing stock code. ALog announced a distribution of 0.997 Singapore cent for the first quarter. Dairy Farm International reported a "serious" impact from the Covid-19 pandemic on its first-quarter performance, with grocery retail benefiting but health and beauty and convenience businesses declining. AEM Holdings posted a net profit of S$36.1 million for the first quarter, up from S$6.6 million last year, with revenue more than doubling to S$146.8 million.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Courage Fund
summary: The Money FM podcast "The Courage Fund" discussed various financial and business topics. The podcast covered the Singapore public offer of NTT DC Reit, which was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Additionally, the podcast touched on the upcoming retirement of OCBC CEO Helen Wong and the appointment of Tan Teck Long as her successor. The episode also explored the concept of corporate purpose and the importance of financial literacy, particularly for women.

site_title: UBS posts 40% rise in Q1 profit as wealth shows resilience
summary: UBS, the world's largest wealth manager, reported a 40% rise in Q1 profit to US$1.6 billion, its best quarter since 2008. Strong operating performance across all business divisions, despite increased credit loss expenses, drove the results. The bank's wealth management business showed resilience, with a 41% pre-tax profit growth and US$12 billion in fresh client inflows. The firm attributed its success to a revamped vision and conservative risk management.

site_title: HK hotels on the brink amid protests, pandemic pain
summary: Hong Kong's hotel industry is on the brink of financial ruin due to a year of political unrest and the coronavirus crisis. Hotel occupancy rates plummeted to 29% in February, down from 91% a year earlier, with many hotels shutting down or taking time out to renovate. Smaller hotels, such as three- and four-star hotels, have closed down, while five-star international hotels with more cash reserves are trying to stay afloat. Industry experts say boutique and budget hotels need to reinvent themselves to survive, and potential buyers are mostly local private equity firms and co-living operators.

site_title: HSBC sees mounting credit losses after pandemic halves Q1 profit to US$3.2b
summary: HSBC reported a 48% decline in profit to $3.2 billion in Q1 due to the pandemic, with $3 billion in bad loan provisions. The bank expects total provisions for the year to range from $7 billion to $11 billion. Credit losses are expected to be "potentially significant" due to increased fraudulent activity and corporate borrowers in crisis. The bank's new CEO, Noel Quinn, faces challenges in implementing cost-cutting plans, which have been put on hold due to the pandemic.

images.alt_text: CEO Noel Quinn: "It's most important for us to be prepared for all scenarios - the optimistic and the less optimistic. Only time will tell where in that range we will fall."

site_title: STI's uptrend continues for second day amid lower virus case numbers
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 13.55 points or 0.53% to 2,562.95 points for a second day, driven by lower Covid-19 case numbers. ComfortDelGro Corporation was the top performer, with shares rising 6.16% to S$1.55, while Keppel Corporation also gained 3.79%. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was the most heavily traded stock, despite a 3% loss. The government's jobs support schemes are expected to cushion the labor market, but layoffs and unemployment are likely to rise.

site_title: Online channels and self-ordering kiosks becoming popular
summary: Consumers in Singapore are increasingly using online channels and self-ordering kiosks, resulting in higher customer satisfaction levels. A study by the CSISG found that customers who used self-checkout at supermarkets and self-ordering kiosks at fast-food restaurants had higher satisfaction scores compared to those who used traditional methods. The use of these technologies is expected to accelerate consumer acceptance, particularly in the post-Covid-19 era. Companies are now focusing on upskilling staff to provide higher-value-added services, while leveraging AI-powered solutions to enhance customer experiences and improve business profitability.

site_title: BP hikes debt, keeps dividend as coronavirus hammers profits
summary: BP's first-quarter profit plummeted by two-thirds to US$800 million due to the coronavirus crisis, which has severely impacted oil demand. Despite the decline, BP maintained its dividend of 10.5 US cents per share and reported a net debt of US$51.4 billion, its highest in at least five years. The company expects lower refining margins in Q2 as global travel restrictions reach their peak, and its debt-to-capital ratio rose to 36%, significantly higher than its target.

site_title: Record-long US expansion to see its end in Q1 GDP
summary: The US economic expansion, which began in 2020, is set to end in Q1 GDP, with the Commerce Department expected to show a 3.8% annualized decline from January to March due to the Covid-19 pandemic. This would be the steepest decline since the 2009 recession. The end of the expansion marks a significant shift in the economic landscape, with policymakers facing increased pressure to address the slowdown in growth.

site_title: India, China need dose of cricket spirit, not hostile takeovers
summary: The Indian government has introduced new restrictions on foreign direct investments (FDI) from neighboring countries, including China, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The rules aim to curb "opportunistic takeovers" of Indian companies, but have raised concerns among Chinese-funded startups. China has invested around $4 billion in Indian startups, and the new restrictions may deter Chinese capital inflows. Both India and China need to adopt a spirit of sportsmanship and cooperation, drawing inspiration from their existing collaboration on the cricket field, where Chinese companies sponsor Indian cricket tournaments. The Indian government intends to examine Chinese investments on a case-by-case basis and ease the curbs over the longer term.

site_title: Singapore adapts to electronics trade shifts by focusing on high value-added activities
summary: Singapore adapts to shifting electronics trade by focusing on high-value-added activities, solidifying its position as a trade hub. Despite increased US-China trade barriers and technological restrictions, the Asian supply chain remains mature, accounting for a dominant share of global electronics production. This adaptation enables Singapore to capitalize on its existing strengths and maintain its competitive edge in the global market.

site_title: CDL to give most retail tenants additional rebates for June, July
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) will provide additional rental rebates to most of its 400 retail tenants in Singapore for June and July, with a 50% rebate in June and 30% in July. The rebates, totaling S$23 million, are in addition to earlier announced rebates for April and May. The move aims to support the government's measures to curb the spread of Covid-19, which has affected businesses, particularly in the food and beverage sector.

site_title: Transforming Asia's financial services through open banking
summary: Singapore's PayNow, an open banking platform, has successfully integrated over three million individual users and 129,000 merchants since its introduction in 2017. The platform is seen as a model for Asia's financial services, with the potential to foster innovation and competition across the region. The Emerging Payments Association Asia report found that open banking, when implemented securely and with consumer benefits in mind, can modernize the region's payments ecosystem and address financial inclusion.

site_title: Johnson likely to exercise caution in relaxing UK lockdown
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is expected to announce steps towards relaxing the UK lockdown, but is likely to take a cautious approach due to his recent Covid-19 experience. The government will follow top medical advice and consult with business leaders and opposition parties before making decisions. Key changes may include reopening garden centres, recycling centres, and DIY shops, with shoppers and commuters required to wear masks and maintain social distancing. The lockdown's economic impact is significant, with corporate and household debt extensive and numerous firms at risk of failure, according to a CBI survey showing a 55% decline in sales in April.

site_title: Australia, China tensions escalate over Covid-19 inquiry call
summary: Australia has asked China's ambassador to explain comments threatening economic boycotts if an international inquiry into the COVID-19 pandemic is pursued. China, Australia's largest trading partner, claims the inquiry is an attempt at "economic coercion." Trade Minister Simon Birmingham stated Australia will not change its policy position on major public health issues due to economic threats. China accounts for 26% of Australia's total trade, and Australia is a crucial supplier to the Chinese economy. Australia aims to maintain a positive relationship with China while exploring opportunities with other countries like India and the European Union.

site_title: Sheng Siong rings in 49.9% rise in Q1 profit
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket operator, reported a 49.9% increase in Q1 profit to S$29 million, driven by stronger revenue, better gross margin, and higher other income. Revenue rose 30.7% to S$328.7 million, largely due to the impact of COVID-19 and better-than-expected Chinese New Year sales. The company also announced staff rewards and plans to continue expanding its retail space despite potential supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Developing a free, effective Covid-19 vaccine for all
summary: Researchers are racing to develop a free, effective Covid-19 vaccine. 73 vaccine candidates are being explored, with five in clinical trials. To succeed, a mission-oriented approach is needed, focusing on public and private investments on achieving a clearly defined common goal. This requires clear rules on intellectual property, pricing, and manufacturing, prioritizing international collaboration and solidarity. Collective intelligence and steering are also crucial to accelerate advances. Countries must lead in building manufacturing capabilities, particularly in the developing world, and ensure global, equitable, and affordable access to the vaccine.

site_title: How a robust investment portfolio can protect your wealth and help you retire
summary: A well-constructed investment portfolio can protect wealth and support a comfortable retirement. Creating a portfolio requires time, patience, and experience, as it's a dynamic process that needs constant review and adjustments. Effective capital allocation is crucial for long-term success, and it can't be solely learned from books or articles. A diversified portfolio is key to navigating market fluctuations and achieving financial stability. By focusing on productivity gains and adapting to changing market conditions, investors can increase their chances of achieving their financial goals. A well-planned portfolio is essential for a secure financial future.

site_title: SGX announces two separate tie-ups for markets collaboration, Reit portfolio
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has announced two separate tie-ups for markets collaboration and Reit portfolio. The first partnership is with Citic Securities, covering multiple areas including fixed income, currencies, and commodities, as well as equity and debt capital markets. The second partnership is with digital wealth management company Syfe, launching a Reit portfolio that gives retail and accredited investors access to SGX's iEdge S-Reit 20 Index. The partnerships aim to promote SGX's Reits and large-cap stocks in the mainland China and Hong Kong markets, and to deepen collaboration in areas such as bond issuance and capital market development.

site_title: Chinese bank ICBC posts 3% profit rise despite pandemic
summary: ICBC, the world's largest commercial lender, reported a 3.04% net profit rise in the first quarter despite the COVID-19 pandemic, reaching 84.49 billion yuan. This marks a year-over-year increase from 82.01 billion yuan. The bank's profit growth was driven by cost management and a stable economic environment.

site_title: Customers keen to try out new digital banks
summary: Almost half of current banking customers, 43.3%, are willing to try out new digital banks operating entirely online. This willingness to switch is driven by younger, middle-income customers who are already familiar with internet and mobile banking. The most willing segments are those with higher loyalty to incumbent banks, particularly for credit cards (99.7%) and loan products (48.2%). Incumbent banks are advised to focus on improving service reliability, availability, and customer experience, while digital banks should target younger customers and focus on loan and credit card products. The entry of digital banks is expected to drive up customer satisfaction and push incumbent banks to improve their services.

site_title: Pentagon releases 'UFO' videos taken by US Navy pilots
summary: The Pentagon has released three videos taken by US Navy pilots showing mid-air encounters with unidentified aerial phenomena (UAPs), also referred to as UFOs. The grainy black and white footage, shot in 2004 and 2015, appears to show objects moving erratically and accelerating away from view. The Pentagon stated that the videos do not reveal any sensitive capabilities or systems and do not impinge on ongoing investigations. The release aims to clear up misconceptions about the authenticity of the footage, which had previously been leaked.

site_title: DBS Trustee will uphold its legal, regulatory obligations
summary: DBS Trustee, the trustee of Eagle Hospitality Real Estate Investment Trust (EH-Reit), has responded to criticisms of its handling of the situation. The trustee clarified its duties, stating it upholds its legal and regulatory obligations and acts in the best interests of unitholders. DBS Trustee is working towards an orderly resolution, appointing FTI Consulting Inc as Chief Restructuring Officer and obtaining temporary forbearance from lenders.
