Additional work is underway to restructure EH-Reit and appoint a financial adviser. The trustee vowed to take action if it discovers any wrongdoing or inappropriate conduct.

site_title: Moutai's Q1 profit up 16.7% despite virus lockdowns
summary: China liquor giant Kweichow Moutai Co reported a 16.7% increase in Q1 profit to 13.1 billion yuan, despite virus lockdowns, as demand for luxury goods remained resilient. The company's solid earnings signal a rebound in China's demand for luxury goods, with sales in mainland China turning positive in April. This growth is expected to mitigate the sales hit in global markets, particularly in the US and Europe, as the pandemic continues.

site_title: Krona climbs after central bank holds rates steady
summary: The Swedish krona rose 1.2% against the US dollar to 9.911, a two-week high, after the central bank held interest rates steady and maintained stimulus measures to support the economy. The Riksbank left its benchmark rate at zero per cent, citing that a rate cut wouldn't solve Sweden's economic problems. The decision was seen as hawkish, with some analysts expecting rates to remain steady this year and next. The move was seen as a positive for the krona, which also rose 0.6% against the euro.

site_title: GDP contraction to worsen in Q2 on Covid-19 impact: MAS
summary: Singapore's GDP is likely to contract more sharply in Q2 than in Q1 due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact, with full-year growth possibly coming in below the official forecast range of -4 to -1%. The MAS downgraded its forecast, citing risks from stricter containment measures, prolonged pandemic, and uncertainty. If downside risks materialize, Singapore's economy could experience its deepest recession since independence, with some industries like manufacturing and services expected to suffer. The government has pledged to support businesses and households with necessary measures.

images.alt_text: Apart from the external blow to electronics and oil-related manufacturing, modern services is likely to suffer, as will private consumption, according to MAS's Macroeconomic Review.

site_title: US: Stocks open up amid deluge of mixed earnings reports
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, extending April's upward trend, after mixed earnings reports from large companies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.3%, the S&P 500 gained 1.2%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.9%. The gains come despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and mixed economic data, with investors seemingly optimistic about the market's outlook. The US stock market continues its upward trend, with major indexes reaching fresh records.

site_title: Mnuchin says relief loans over US$2m will be audited
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin announced that loans over $2 million in the Paycheck Protection Programme will be audited to ensure they were justified. The loans, intended for small businesses, were criticized for being taken by large public companies and big chains. Mnuchin stated that borrowers who made false certification claims have "criminal liability" and will be held accountable. The US Small Business Administration will verify the need for the loans due to the coronavirus outbreak.

images.alt_text: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said all loans of more than US$2 million in a government relief programme for small businesses will be audited to ensure they were justified after large public companies and big chains sparked outrage by taking funds.

site_title: Wirecard says KPMG could not review all data for audit
summary: Wirecard AG reported that its independent audit by KPMG, conducted in response to Financial Times allegations of accounting fraud, was unable to review all data due to unavailability of information from third-party vendors, specifically 1 billion euros. Despite this, the audit found no evidence of questionable accounting methods. The audit's delays were attributed to complications from the Covid-19 pandemic and Wirecard's inability to provide requested documents on time. The company's shares dropped 22% following the report's release.

site_title: Oil prices sink as world runs low on storage capacity amid frail demand
summary: Oil prices plummeted on Tuesday, with US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures falling to $10.64 a barrel, a 12.8% drop, and Brent crude futures falling to $18.85 a barrel, a 4.3% decline. The decline is attributed to concerns about dwindling storage capacity worldwide and fears that fuel demand may remain slow due to the novel coronavirus pandemic. Strategists expect inventory numbers to be a key focus, with the risk of full capacity at Cushing, a WTI delivery hub, maintaining bearish pressure on the market.

site_title: Bunkering set to weather challenging times
summary: The shipping industry, particularly bunkering, is weathering the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic and the implementation of the International Maritime Organization's (IMO) 0.50% maximum sulphur in fuel regulation. Despite initial concerns, the industry has shown resilience, with a high degree of compliance reported in Singapore, where 96% of ships arriving at the Port of Singapore used compliant fuel. However, the sector faces long-term challenges, including the transition to a zero-carbon shipping industry and the impact of the pandemic on global economic systems.

site_title: HC Surgical: None of Julian Ong's patients switched doctors after learning of complaint
summary: HC Surgical Specialists (HCSS) announced that none of its patients have switched doctors after being informed by Dr. Julian Ong of a Singapore Medical Council (SMC) complaint alleging collusion with another specialist to have sex with vulnerable female patients. Dr. Ong had lost a defamation lawsuit against the complainant earlier this month. HCSS stated that Dr. Ong will now inform all patients of the complaint before consultations and obtain consent to act as physician, except in emergency cases. The company emphasized its commitment to upholding professional standards and allowing due process to run its course.

site_title: Facebook's Reliance deal is a big bet on India's Internet future
summary: Facebook invests $5.7 billion in Jio Platforms, a 9.99% stake in the telecom and digital business of India's Reliance Industries Ltd, valued at $66 billion. The deal is the largest foreign direct investment in India's tech sector and gives Facebook access to India's e-commerce market. The collaboration will focus on JioMart, an online retail business, and WhatsApp will allow neighbourhood shops to take orders and digital payments. The move is seen as a strategic bet on India's internet future, amid concerns about Chinese investments in the country.

site_title: OCBC Bank and staff donate another S$1.225m to the needy
summary: OCBC Bank and its staff have donated an additional S$1.225 million to support Singaporean families and migrant workers affected by the coronavirus outbreak. This is the bank's fourth tranche of donations, following previous contributions to those in need. The funds will be used to help families and migrant workers under enhanced circuit-breaker measures.

site_title: Greater inclusion will boost resilience to disasters
summary: Investing in the capabilities of low-income groups and promoting inclusive growth can help build stronger resilience to disasters, according to a lesson from the COVID-19 pandemic. Countries with high income inequality, such as the US, India, and Singapore, have seen disproportionate impacts on low-income communities. Investing in education, health, and skills training can help reduce inequality and promote economic growth, making countries better prepared for future shocks. Governments should prioritize inclusive growth in their recovery plans, including strengthening social safety nets and directing resources to increase economic opportunities for lower-income strata.

site_title: SPH Reit to pay management fee by way of issue of units in SPH Reit
summary: SPH Reit's manager has decided to receive the base fee component of the management fee for the period from Dec 1, 2019 to Feb 29, 2020 in the form of units in SPH Reit. A total of 2.5 million units were issued at S$1.0438 per unit to settle the base fee. This payment method was chosen to reduce the cash outflow for the company.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit confirms three Covid-19 cases in Japan nursing home
summary: Parkway Life Reit confirmed three Covid-19 cases at its nursing home in Kobe City, Japan, including one resident who has died. Two staff members have been quarantined, and additional measures have been taken to minimize contact between residents and staff. The property remains operational, and the Reit manager reports no material financial impact. Parkway Life Reit is following relevant guidelines and providing support to the asset manager and operator.

site_title: US consumer confidence nosedives but optimism for future rises
summary: US consumer confidence plummeted to 86.9 in April, its lowest level since 2014, amid concerns over jobs and incomes due to the coronavirus pandemic. The Conference Board's index dropped 31.9 points, the largest decline since 1973. However, a subindex of expectations rose to 93.8, indicating consumers see the pandemic's impact as temporary. A record 40% of respondents expect better business conditions and 41% more jobs in six months.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with more gains
summary: Hong Kong shares posted gains for the second consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.22% to 24,575.96. The move is attributed to investors' optimism about the slowing rate of coronavirus infections and deaths globally. In contrast, China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes declined 0.19% and 0.32% respectively.

site_title: LionGold's group CEO Raymond Tan resigns
summary: LionGold's group CEO Raymond Tan Soo Khoon has resigned, effective April 30, to facilitate board renewal. He will remain as a consultant. Sun Shu has been appointed lead independent director, taking over from April 30. The change is aimed at addressing concerns and ensuring transparency. Tan's resignation follows his 8-year tenure as CEO, during which the company was involved in the 2013 penny stock crash. No information is available on his successor.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit's Q3 revenue down 8.9%
summary: Starhill Global Reit's Q3 revenue fell 8.9% to S$46.7 million, with net property income down 11.1% to S$35.2 million. The decrease was attributed to lower contributions from Starhill Gallery and rental assistance extended to tenants due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The Reit's income available for distribution fell 4.1% to S$24 million, with no proposed distribution to unitholders for the quarter. The Reit manager plans to delay non-essential capital expenditures and reduce management fees to maintain financial flexibility.

site_title: Merck sees US$2.1b coronavirus hit to 2020 sales
summary: Merck & Co expects a US$2.1 billion reduction in 2020 sales due to the coronavirus pandemic, citing a drop in doctors' office visits. The company lowered its full-year adjusted profit forecast to US$5.17-US$5.37 per share. Many of Merck's top-selling products, including Keytruda, are physician-administered, making it vulnerable to the pandemic. The company suspended its share buyback program and expects a potential recovery in the second half of the year as restrictions ease.

site_title: PepsiCo scraps forecast due to coronavirus crisis
summary: PepsiCo reported a 7.7% increase in first-quarter revenue to US$13.9 billion, but scrapped its full-year forecast due to uncertainty caused by the novel coronavirus pandemic. The company's net income fell to US$1.34 billion, or 96 cents per share. The pandemic's impact led to a significant decline in forecasted organic revenue growth and core earnings per share, prompting PepsiCo to reevaluate its financial projections.

site_title: Moody's slashes economic and oil forecasts again
summary: Moody's has slashed its global economic and oil forecasts again, predicting a 4% contraction in the G20 group of major economies this year due to ongoing coronavirus lockdowns, before bouncing back 4.8% in 2021. Individual country forecasts include a -5.7% slump in the US, -6.5% in Japan and the euro zone, and -7% in Britain and Italy. The agency warns of significant downside risks, including a structurally high unemployment rate and persistent malaise in consumption and investment.

site_title: How alternative data can help chart path for a Covid-19 recovery
summary: Alternative data platform AlphaWise, developed by Morgan Stanley Research, is helping investors navigate the COVID-19 recovery by providing insights on consumer behavior, economic trends, and company sentiment. AlphaWise's data, including weekly surveys of 2,000 Chinese consumers and analysis of online job advertisement data, suggests a gradual economic recovery in China, with consumers returning to work and spending on essential goods. However, consumer habits have permanently changed, and demand for luxury goods and electronics has declined. The platform's Global MNCs China Sentiment Index also shows a weakening trend in sentiment among major companies, foreshadowing the disruption caused by the pandemic.

site_title: More expected to be jobless, especially in retail, F&B, recreation sectors
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) warns of rising layoffs and unemployment, particularly in retail, food and beverage, and recreation sectors, despite a fiscal stimulus. Labour market conditions were already soft in 2019 before the Covid-19 pandemic. The MAS cautions that these sectors are "most vulnerable to being laid off."

site_title: 23,000 beds to be added to isolation and care facilities for Covid-19 patients by end-June
summary: Singapore plans to nearly double its facilities for housing Covid-19 patients by the end of June, adding 23,000 beds to its current 18,000 beds. The new facilities will cater to patients with mild cases, those waiting for test results, and those who have recovered. Four types of facilities will be established: Swab Isolation, Dorm Isolation, Community Care, and Community Recovery. The government also launched the SG Healthcare Corps, with 3,000 healthcare professionals volunteering to support the response.

site_title: STI's uptrend continues for second day
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) continued its uptrend for a second day, ending up 13.55 points or 0.53% at 2,562.95 points, as the Covid-19 situation improves. ComfortDelgro was the best performer, with shares rising 6.16% to S$1.55. Keppel Corporation also rose 3.79% to S$6.03 after selling a stake in its Reit. Jardine Cycle & Carriage lost 5.85% to S$19.80 due to challenging trading conditions.

site_title: Dairy Farm Intl's Q1 business 'seriously affected' despite grocery retail uplift
summary: Dairy Farm International, a Pan-Asian supermarket and convenience-store operator, reported a "seriously affected" Q1 business due to the Covid-19 pandemic and deteriorating consumer sentiment. While grocery retail benefited, the health and beauty businesses in North Asia and convenience stores were significantly impacted. The group recorded strong profit growth in grocery retail, but warned of an adverse impact on trading in the second quarter in Malaysia and Indonesia due to government policies enforcing social distancing. Dairy Farm remains confident in its overall financial position, with secured new committed banking facilities and a cash reserve of US$248 million.

site_title: Surf's up: Sydney reopens its famous Bondi Beach
summary: Sydney's famous Bondi Beach reopened on Tuesday after being sealed off for five weeks due to large crowds ignoring social distancing orders. Hundreds of surfers and swimmers flocked to the beach, with many adhering to distancing guidelines. The reopening is part of Australia's easing of coronavirus restrictions, with several states allowing increased gatherings and travel. The move comes as confirmed cases of COVID-19 slow in the country, with fewer than 20 new cases per day reported over the past week.

site_title: Prime US Reit's Q1 net property income exceeds IPO projections by 6.7%
summary: Prime US Reit reported Q1 net property income of US$23.5 million, exceeding IPO projections by 6.7%. The company's gross revenue and distributable income also surpassed projections. The outperformance was driven by the accretive acquisition of Park Tower and lower finance expenses. Prime US Reit maintains a conservative debt profile and is reviewing options to reduce interest costs. The company's CEO emphasized the diversified portfolio and strong balance sheet, which will provide stability in uncertain times, and remains focused on delivering stable performance and managing capital prudently.

site_title: India's Reliance Industries to consider first rights issue in three decades
summary: Reliance Industries, an Indian conglomerate, is considering its first rights issue in nearly 30 years as it seeks to slash its debt of around $22 billion by March 2021. The move comes after Facebook's plan to invest $5.7 billion in Reliance's digital arm, raising questions about the need for additional capital. Analysts see the rights issue as a positive sign, reflecting management's confidence in the company's long-term prospects and commitment to eliminating debt.

images.alt_text: India's Reliance Industries said it will consider its first rights issue in almost 30 years when its board meets on Thursday, in another attempt to slash its debt.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: European stock markets remained steady at the start of trading on Tuesday, following weeks of volatility caused by the coronavirus outbreak. London and Paris dipped 0.1%, while Frankfurt and Milan made slight gains. As nations ease lockdowns, shares in mining and healthcare sectors rose. Meanwhile, US stocks continued to edge towards fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.04 points to 1,372.20 on Tuesday, driven by higher volumes. Losers outnumbered gainers 548 to 305.

site_title: Mysterious blood clots are Covid-19's latest lethal surprise
summary: A growing number of COVID-19 patients are experiencing mysterious blood clots, leading to severe complications such as amputations. Studies have found that 31% of patients in the Netherlands suffered thrombotic complications, with some experiencing microclots in their lungs, heart, and brain. Experts attribute the risk to underlying medical conditions, prolonged periods of inactivity, and an abnormal immune reaction called "cytokine storm." Researchers are working to understand the underlying mechanisms and develop preventative measures, such as blood thinners, to mitigate the risks.

site_title: Sterling rises as investor risk sentiment improves
summary: The pound strengthened 0.4% to US$1.2468 on Tuesday as investors anticipated central bank meetings to provide stimulus for the economy amid the coronavirus crisis. Sterling's rise is linked to increased risk appetite, with officials from the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank expected to announce further stimulus measures. The pound also rose against the euro, with traders expecting the Bank of Japan to follow suit. The news comes as the UK reported a lower daily death toll from COVID-19, with 360 new deaths bringing the total to 21,092.

site_title: Sheng Siong's Q1 profit up 49.9%; staff to get additional month of salary
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket operator, reported a 49.9% increase in Q1 profit to S$29 million, driven by a 30.7% revenue jump and better gross margin. The company attributed the growth to the impact of COVID-19 and better-than-expected Chinese New Year sales. Staff will receive an additional month of salary for their hard work during the elevated demand period. Despite strong Q1 results, the group expects revenue to taper off when the pandemic normalizes, and will maintain a higher-than-normal inventory level to hedge against potential supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Harley-Davidson cuts dividend, halts buybacks to preserve cash
summary: Harley-Davidson cut its quarterly dividend to 2 cents and suspended share buybacks due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on motorcycle sales. The company has US$1.47 billion in cash and is in talks to secure an additional US$1.30 billion in loans. Harley's net income fell to US$69.7 million, and it temporarily laid off most global production employees and cut leadership salaries to lower costs. The company aims to boost sales in the US and expand its lineup of profitable motorcycles to improve profitability and long-term growth.

site_title: Temasek-backed Tikehau Capital hires banking veteran Neil Parekh as head of Asia, Australia and NZ
summary: French asset manager Tikehau Capital has appointed Neil Parekh as head of Asia, Australia, and New Zealand, effective later this year. Parekh, a Singapore citizen, joins from National Australia Bank (NAB), where he was general manager of Asia. Tikehau Capital, backed by Temasek Holdings, aims to deepen investment capabilities and grow its business in the region, focusing on speeding up investments, partnerships, and diversifying its investor base. Parekh brings over three decades of experience in the financial services industry in the Asia-Pacific, US, and Europe.

site_title: AEM Holdings' Q1 net profit surges to S$36.1m on increased orders
summary: AEM Holdings reported a net profit of S$36.1 million for its first quarter, up from S$6.6 million a year ago, due to increased orders for tools, consumables, and services. Revenue more than doubled to S$146.8 million. The group expects revenue to be between S$360 million and S$380 million for FY2020. It has been working with potential customers on its AMPS platform and has gained traction on its collaboration efforts with customers to develop the platform. The shift to telecommuting has created increased demand for semiconductor chips.

site_title: Covid-19 may bring CLMV growth to new lows: report
summary: The Covid-19 pandemic is putting severe growth pressure on CLMV economies, with forecasted growth rates of 3% in 2020, down from 6.9% in 2019, and 6.5% in 2021. Vietnam is expected to do better with 3.6% growth, while Cambodia is expected to be worst hit with 0.5% growth due to its high reliance on tourism. Myanmar is forecasted to see 2% growth, and Laos is predicted at 2.4%. The pandemic's impact is expected to cause the region's growth to slow to a historical low.

site_title: BP announces US$4.4b Q1 loss as oil prices crash
summary: BP announced a US$4.4 billion net loss in the first quarter due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on oil demand, resulting in a price crash. Crude prices plummeted from around US$70 per barrel to under US$20. The company plans to reduce cash costs by US$2.5 billion by 2021, with underlying replacement cost profit at US$800 million. BP also reported a 2.8% drop in oil production to 3.7 million barrels per day.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end firmer as countries ease lockdown curbs
summary: South Korean shares rose 11.32 points, or 0.59%, to close at 1,934.09, as optimism over easing lockdown curbs offset a slump in oil prices. Foreigners sold US$102 million worth of shares, while domestic investors advanced 484 shares out of 897 traded. The country's exports contracted at the sharpest pace in nearly 11 years in April due to the pandemic. South Korea's President Moon Jae-in expressed concern over massive job losses, while North Korea's leader may have missed a key holiday due to coronavirus concerns, not illness.

site_title: Hong Kong preparing to reopen public facilities, says Carrie Lam
summary: Hong Kong is preparing to reopen government offices and public facilities starting May 4, with chief executive Carrie Lam taking cautious steps to ease social distancing measures amid a decrease in coronavirus cases. The city has contained the spread of the virus through early measures and contact tracing, with zero daily new cases for four of the last eight days. However, activists have begun organizing new pro-democracy protests, defying the measures, raising concerns that the government may be suppressing political unrest.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong announced plans to reopen government offices and some public facilities, as chief executive Carrie Lam took cautious steps to get the city back to work amid the threat of further coronavirus outbreaks and fresh political protests.

site_title: HSBC warns credit losses may swell to US$11b this year
summary: HSBC Holdings warns that credit losses may reach $11 billion this year, the highest since the last financial crisis, due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the economy. Adjusted profit slumped 51% in the first three months, with $3 billion in expected credit losses driven by a Singaporean client exposure. The bank has also delayed parts of its restructuring program until the end of 2020, curbing CEO Noel Quinn's plan to boost profitability.

images.alt_text: HSBC Holdings cautioned bad loan charges may climb to as much as US$11 billion this year, the highest since the last financial crisis as the coronavirus pandemic halts economic activity around the world.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei inches down ahead of holidays, earnings
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index dropped 0.06% to 19,771.19 on Tuesday ahead of Golden Week holidays and corporate earnings announcements, with investors in a wait-and-see mode. The broader Topix index rose 0.13% to 1,449.15.

site_title: Marks & Spencer strengthens liquidity to cope with coronavirus impact
summary: Marks & Spencer is strengthening its liquidity to cope with the coronavirus impact, planning for a slow return to shopping. The retailer scrapped its next year's dividend and accessed the UK government's coronavirus corporate finance scheme. It has significant undrawn credit available for 18 months and relaxed covenant conditions with its banks. This move is expected to save the company 210 million pounds of cash. The firm's financial planning includes resources for both a recovery and a faster transformation of its clothing unit in 2021.

site_title: Singapore's focus on high value-added activities cements position as trade hub
summary: Singapore has maintained its position as a trade hub despite shifts in the electronics trade flows, primarily due to its focus on high-value-added activities. The country has adapted to the emergence of China as a global electronics production center by diversifying its trade relationships. Singapore remains a significant source of integrated components for Malaysia and Indonesia, while also importing components for its own production. This strategic approach has helped Singapore maintain its competitive edge in the global supply chain.

site_title: Ascendas Reit announces 'healthy' operational performance in Q1 update
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a "healthy" operational performance in its Q1 update, with an overall portfolio occupancy rate of 91.7% and a positive rental reversion of 8%. The Reit's manager stated that aggregate leverage was at 36.2% and debt-maturity profile was well-spread. The company will pass on any government-granted property tax reduction to tenants and provide additional rental assistance to retail and food and beverage tenants. No properties were shut down due to COVID-19, and the Reit is proactively marketing vacant spaces and engaging customers digitally.

site_title: Malls face catastrophic hit in Canada with unpaid rent surging
summary: Canada's malls face a catastrophic hit due to unpaid rent surging, with 20-25% of tenants paying rent in April. The retail sector was already under pressure from weak sales, property taxes, and the shift to e-commerce. Vacancy rates are expected to triple by year-end, reaching 6-8%, with smaller property owners at risk of tenant closures. The Canadian government has introduced a rent relief program, but its effectiveness remains uncertain, and some experts predict a "reckoning" for the retail industry.

site_title: In Seoul, the art world gets back to business
summary: Seoul's art world is slowly returning to normal after the COVID-19 pandemic, with galleries and museums in other parts of the world remaining closed. South Korea's low number of coronavirus deaths, just two, has allowed for a steady stream of art events, including the opening of Billy Childish's paintings at the Lehmann Maupin gallery. The city's dense population and strict health measures have enabled a safe return to business, with art enthusiasts and fashion-forward individuals attending events without social distancing measures. This offers a possible answer to how the art world will look in the post-pandemic era.

site_title: Major US cinema chains waiting for summer to reopen
summary: Major US cinema chains, including Cinemark, AMC, and Regal, plan to reopen in the summer, with Cinemark aiming for late July, pending the release of big-budget films like "Tenet" and "Mulan." Georgia has authorized cinemas to resume screenings with social distancing measures, while Texas plans to follow suit with a 25% capacity limit. The chains aim to ensure COVID-19 safety measures are in place while encouraging public return with highly anticipated releases.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MAS warns that retrenchments will rise, especially in retail and food services, despite job support measures. The central bank says fiscal policy will be the main contributor to the economy's expansion this year. Retail tenants can expect rental rebates in June and July from CDL. The Straits Times Index (STI) continues its uptrend, ending up 0.53% at 2,562.95 points. Meanwhile, global economic concerns include Vietnam's reaction to US tariffs, China's slowing GDP growth, and the UK's shrinking economy.

images.alt_text: MAS warned in its latest half-yearly report that retrenchments will rise with retail trade, food and beverage and recreation services staff "most vulnerable to being laid off" - especially as overall and industry labour market conditions were already soft in end-2019.

site_title: SAS airline slashes 5,000 jobs over corona crisis
summary: Scandinavian airline SAS announced it will lay off up to 5,000 employees, about 40% of its workforce, due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on air travel demand. The company expects limited activity in the summer season and believes demand will not return to pre-pandemic levels until 2022. SAS is cutting 1,900 full-time positions in Sweden, 1,300 in Norway, and 1,700 in Denmark, with support from credit guarantees from Sweden and Denmark's largest shareholders.

site_title: Japan's ANA net profit dives 75% as virus hits air travel
summary: Japan's ANA Holdings reported a 75% drop in annual net profit to 27.6 billion yen due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on air travel. Operating profit fell 63.2% to 60.8 billion yen, with sales declining 4.1% to 1,974 billion yen. The airline reduced scheduled flights by 90% on international routes and 70% on domestic routes. ANA cited uncertainty over the pandemic, not releasing earnings forecasts for the current financial year. The airline had previously expected strong sales ahead of the 2020 Olympics, now delayed due to the pandemic.

site_title: Game on: Japan group offers retro consoles to cooped-up kids
summary: A Japanese non-profit group, Japan Retro Game Association, is offering 100 classic Nintendo consoles to children under 16 due to lockdown-induced boredom caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The consoles, including Super Nintendo Entertainment System (Super NES) models, will be sent complete with games and accessories. The group aims to introduce children to retro games that were popular in the 1990s. The consoles are secondhand but have been restored and disinfected.

site_title: Wirecard says KPMG could not review all data for audit
summary: Wirecard hired KPMG to conduct an independent audit of its third-party partner business and business activities in India and Singapore. The audit found no need to restate earnings, but all data needed to confirm past revenues from 2016-2018 is "primarily in the control of third parties". Wirecard's 2019 accounts will not be released on April 30 due to the Covid-19 virus and the KPMG report, which Wirecard has stated will be published "as soon as possible". The company has faced repeated allegations of accounting fraud and has denied all allegations.

site_title: 528 new Covid-19 cases take Singapore tally to 14,951
summary: Singapore reported 528 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 14,951. Foreign workers accounted for 511 cases, mostly in dormitories, while 10 cases were in the community. No new imported cases were reported. The country has 1,889 patients in hospital, with 1,128 fully recovered and 11,920 isolated with mild symptoms. Globally, over 3.06 million people have been infected, with 211,000 deaths, and the US remains the worst-affected country with over 980,000 cases and 55,000 deaths.

site_title: HSBC profits halved as virus batters global economy
summary: HSBC reported a 48% drop in first quarter pre-tax profits to US$3.2 billion, citing credit losses from clients affected by the global coronavirus pandemic. The banking giant is embarking on a major restructuring, including cost-cutting measures, to address multiple uncertainties caused by the pandemic, trade war, and Brexit. The lender had previously announced plans to slash 35,000 jobs, but has put many of these redundancies on hold to reduce employee uncertainty. CEO Noel Quinn aims to transform the international bank, focusing on Asia, where the business has historically performed well.

site_title: ComfortDelGro's rental waiver extension to cabbies matched by only 1 taxi firm
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore taxi giant, has extended its rental waiver to cabbies for a second month until June 1, matching the government's stay-home measures to combat the coronavirus outbreak. However, only one taxi firm, SMRT, has matched this move. Other major taxi operators, such as Trans-Cab, will charge drivers a daily fee of S$21.40 from May 6 to June 1, causing a stir among drivers. The decision highlights the varying approaches among taxi companies during the crisis.

site_title: SGX, CITIC Securities in Singapore-China markets tie-up
summary: SGX and CITIC Securities Company have signed a strategic cooperation agreement to collaborate on multiple areas, including fixed income, Reits, and equity markets. The tie-up aims to promote SGX's Reits and large-capitalisation stocks in mainland China and Hong Kong, and engage Greater China companies on raising funds in Singapore's capital markets. CITIC Securities will contribute expertise in Chinese government bonds, while SGX will provide its debt securities platform. The agreement seeks to develop new bond and risk management products for international investors and build out the Reit platform.

site_title: Expat rents pool for S$10,000 a month to swim amid Singapore's lockdown
summary: A British expat rented a Sentosa Cove bungalow's pool and garden for S$10,000 a month to swim during Singapore's lockdown, as his condominium pool was closed. The deal was brokered by a real estate agent, who agreed to a short-term lease of three months. This unusual request is part of a trend of individuals seeking to rent private pool and garden facilities in upscale areas, as public facilities are closed due to the lockdown.

images.alt_text: Not helping any with Singapore's image as home to a bunch of crazy-rich Asians comes the almost too-ridiculous-to-be-true story of a man who rented a swimming pool for S$10,000 a month.

site_title: Gold drops towards US$1,700 as economies show signs of restarting
summary: Gold prices dropped to US$1,703.94 an ounce, falling 0.6% as economies show signs of restarting and stocks rose to their highest in almost seven weeks. The decline comes ahead of policy announcements from the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank. Despite being near the highest in over seven years, investors question the scope for further gains due to reopenings. Other precious metals, such as silver and platinum, also declined, while palladium advanced.

site_title: Microsoft wins five-year deal with Coca-Cola to supply business software
summary: Microsoft has won a five-year deal with Coca-Cola to supply business software, including Teams chat app and customer service tools. The deal includes Dynamics 365, a suite of Microsoft tools competing with Salesforce.com. This win marks Microsoft's efforts to expand its customer service and sales software offerings. Details of the deal's size were not disclosed.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed leaders eye lockdown easing but oil sinks
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Tuesday as lockdown easing efforts were offset by profit-taking and concerns about a possible second wave of coronavirus infections. Oil prices plummeted below $11 a barrel, while some markets, such as Tokyo and Wellington, rose due to optimism over economic reopenings. The Federal Reserve and European Central Bank are set to make policy decisions this week, which may influence market trends.

site_title: Virus prompts Japan to rethink stamping documents by hand
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has urged a review of traditional office practices, including stamping documents by hand, to promote remote work and contain the coronavirus. This practice hinders efforts to reduce public contacts by 70%. Abe called for changes to the "system and custom of seals and submitting paperwork" to support the shift towards remote work.

site_title: Autodesk gives some clients free software access during downturn
summary: Autodesk is offering free software access to clients struggling financially due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company, which projected $4 billion in revenue this fiscal year, will provide 90-day free access to its software through various programs. CEO Andrew Anagnost believes this will benefit the company in the long-term, as clients are using cloud-based tools and collaborating on 3D designs. Autodesk has also provided financing and upfront payments to partners and resellers to mitigate the effects of reduced sales activity.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS says Mapletree Industrial Trust becoming 'alternative data centre play'
summary: DBS Group Research has maintained its "buy" call on Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) with a target price of S$2.70. The trust is seen as an alternative data centre play with ample capacity for strategic acquisitions in the US. MIT's asset diversity and contributions from its US data centres should push distributions higher, and the trust's low gearing allows for opportunistic acquisitions and developments. The analysts expect better-than-expected rental reversions and/or acquisitions to boost MIT's earnings and share price, but potential rising interest rates are a key risk.

site_title: Trump was warned about coronavirus repeatedly in Jan and Feb: report
summary: US President Donald Trump was repeatedly warned about the coronavirus in January and February intelligence briefings, despite downplaying the threat. More than a dozen classified briefings, known as the President's Daily Brief, contained warnings about the dangers of Covid-19. The warnings were contained in daily classified summaries of global issues and security threats. This contradicts Trump's public statements at the time, sparking questions about the administration's handling of the crisis.

site_title: Virus likely to keep coming back each year, say Chinese scientists
summary: Chinese scientists believe the novel coronavirus will not be eradicated, instead becoming a seasonal, sustained epidemic that co-exists with humans. Unlike SARS, which caused severe illness and stopped spreading once infected individuals were quarantined, the coronavirus infects some people without symptoms, making it difficult to contain transmission. This "asymptomatic carrier" group poses a significant challenge in controlling the virus. Experts predict the virus will likely return in waves, similar to the flu, and will continue to be a persistent health concern.

site_title: Australian dollar near 6-week high, New Zealand dollar lags on easing talk
summary: The Australian dollar has reached a six-week high, trading at US$0.6472, as countries around the world ease lockdown restrictions and contain the coronavirus. New Zealand's kiwi dollar lags behind, at $0.6028, due to speculation about further policy easing and record-low bond yields. Both currencies are seen as barometers of risk, with Australia's economy expected to begin recovering as more restrictions are lifted and 400,000 workers return to work.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on dashed hopes for fresh stimulus; New Zealand gains
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to close at 5313.1, despite a decline in coronavirus cases, as the Treasury announced no new stimulus packages. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.5% on Monday. Energy stocks lost 1.4%, while healthcare stocks fell 1.6% and gold stocks dropped 2%. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 3.3% to its highest close in over a week. The disappointing news came as measures of Australian business and consumer sentiment hit record lows.

site_title: Digital wealth management firm Syfe partners SGX to launch Reit portfolio
summary: Syfe, a digital wealth management firm, partnered with the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to launch a Reit portfolio, allowing investors to access the iEdge S-Reit 20 Index, which tracks the largest and most tradeable Reits in Singapore. The portfolio offers two options: a pure Reit portfolio for maximum real estate exposure or a risk-managed portfolio balancing Reits with government bonds to mitigate volatility. This move aims to provide investors with more accessible and diversified Reit investment options.

site_title: Singapore firms nudged to boost staff mental wellness amid Covid-19 crisis
summary: Singaporean banks DBS and UOB are introducing initiatives to boost staff mental wellness amid the Covid-19 crisis, including mindfulness applications and well-being challenges. DBS employees will have free access to a mindfulness app, while UOB is providing online learning programs and a dedicated mental health hotline. The move comes as companies adapt to new work-from-home arrangements and the Ministry of Manpower issued an advisory asking employers to consider taking practical steps to support staff mental well-being.

site_title: Nokia clinches 924m euro deal with India's Airtel
summary: Nokia has secured a 924m euro deal with India's Airtel, a multi-year contract to boost network capacity and prepare for 5G. The deal, valued at 1.42 billion euros, will deploy 300,000 new radio units across the country by 2022. This agreement solidifies Nokia's position in India's large telecoms market, which is expected to grow to 920 million unique mobile customers within five years. The deal comes after Nokia's earnings forecast downgrade last October, but marks a positive turn for the Finnish network equipment maker.

images.alt_text: Finnish network equipment maker Nokia has secured a multi-year contract to boost the capacity of one of India's largest mobile operators, the firm announced on Tuesday.

site_title: Most retail tenants to get rental rebates in June, July as CDL ups Covid-19 relief kitty to S$23m
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) is increasing its rental relief kitty to S$23 million to support retail tenants affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. Most tenants will receive a 50% rental rebate in June and 30% in July, with an average of 2.8 months of gross rental rebates. About 80% of CDL's retail tenants have temporarily halted operations due to Singapore's partial lockdown. The company is also giving tenants relief on cash flow and passing on government property tax rebates.

site_title: US oil falls below US$11 as fund sells off holdings
summary: US oil prices plummeted below $11 a barrel on Tuesday as the United States Oil Fund sold its short-term contracts, amid concerns about storage capacity and demand due to the coronavirus. West Texas Intermediate dropped 14.8% to $10.88 a barrel, while Brent crude fell 4.4% to $19.10 a barrel. The price collapse follows recent weeks of declining demand, with top producers agreeing to reduce output by 10 million barrels a day to shore up markets. The storage concerns overshadow signs of production cuts, leaving oil prices at their lowest levels for years.

site_title: Disinflationary pressures to broaden, but fiscal policy plays main role in Covid-19 crisis: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) expects disinflationary pressures to broaden in the economy due to the Covid-19 pandemic, but fiscal policy will play a main role in mitigating the crisis. Both core and headline inflation are expected to turn negative in 2020, ranging from -1% to 0%. Fiscal policy is seen as providing the main response to the crisis, with monetary policy complementing government moves to ease the economic cost of the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Disinflationary pressures will broaden in the economy as the demand shock from the Covid-19 pandemic reverberates, but fiscal policy will play the main role in mitigating the crisis, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said in its half-yearly Macroeconomic Review on Tuesday.

site_title: US airlines announce new policies to slow coronavirus spread
summary: Major US airlines, including Delta, American, and United, have announced new health and safety measures to slow the spread of coronavirus in-flight. Starting May 1, airline personnel will be required to wear masks, and masks will be made available to passengers. Airlines will also offer protective gear and increase cleaning and disinfection procedures. The measures come as states begin lifting restrictions and there is a risk of increased air passenger traffic.

site_title: China Everbright's proposed 3b yuan note issue gets regulatory nod
summary: China Everbright Water has received regulatory approval for its proposed 3 billion yuan (S$600.9 million) issuance of medium-term notes. The notes, which will be valid for two years, will be issued in single or multiple tranches to institutional investors in mainland China. The company plans to use the proceeds to replenish working capital and optimize its financing structure. The issuance remains subject to prevailing market conditions and the company may proceed or not, depending on market conditions.

site_title: Jobs support cushions blow but layoffs, unemployment will still rise: MAS
summary: Singapore's Jobs Support Scheme is expected to cushion the blow of layoffs and rising unemployment, but unemployment is still projected to rise this year due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the global economy. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) warned that retail, food and beverage, and recreation-services staff are most vulnerable to job losses, while wages are expected to decline, particularly in the transport and storage industry. The scheme provides an effective annual wage subsidy of 16.7%, larger than previous measures, but labor force growth is expected to be limited to a handful of industries.

site_title: Vickers Venture leads US$34m round for X-ray systems firm Lumitron
summary: US-based X-ray and laser tech firm Lumitron Technologies has closed a US$34 million funding round led by Vickers Venture Partners. The funding will support the development of the company's HyperVIEW X-ray platform, which can be used in research, industrial, medical, and therapeutic applications. Lumitron aims to build its first commercial X-ray systems by the end of 2020, with strong interest from university research facilities and government institutions worldwide. The investment is expected to benefit millions of patients, healthtech firms, and industrial fields globally.

site_title: White House media briefings hit turbulence as Trump attacks 'enemy'
summary: The White House abruptly canceled and then reinstated a coronavirus media briefing after President Donald Trump attacked "enemy" journalists, following his previous suggestion to inject patients with disinfectants. Trump's press secretary, Kayleigh McEnany, announced the briefing would focus on safely reopening the US economy, while White House strategic communications director Alyssa Farah tweeted that reporters are kept on their toes. The move comes as Trump faces pressure to demonstrate his leadership amid the pandemic.

site_title: South Korea has run out of commercial storage space for oil
summary: South Korea has exhausted its commercial oil storage space, according to people with knowledge of the matter. The country's state-run Korea National Oil Corp and Oilhub Korea Yeosu Co have all rented out their onshore capacity, leaving strategic or logistical needs to be addressed. This shortage intensifies a global scramble for tankers to store crude and fuels, driven by low prices and long-term supply agreements.

images.alt_text: South Korea has run out of commercial storage space for oil, according to people with knowledge of the matter, a development that's likely to intensify a global scramble for tankers to store crude and fuels.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 0.21% and the Topix index down 0.34%. The decline follows sharp rallies in the previous session due to cautious trade ahead of holidays.

site_title: UBS posts 40% Q1 profit rise on higher trading activity amid market turmoil
summary: UBS reported a 40% increase in Q1 net profit to $1.595 billion, driven by higher trading activity amid market turmoil caused by the coronavirus outbreak. The bank extended more loans to its wealthy clients and maintained a strong operating performance despite the risk of higher defaults. UBS warned that the economic recovery's timing and shape remain uncertain, and its strategic plans will help mitigate the risks. The bank's Q1 profit was in line with its previous forecast of $1.5 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong hotels on cliff edge from protest, pandemic pain
summary: Hong Kong's hotel industry is facing financial ruin due to a year of political unrest and the coronavirus crisis. Hotel occupancy rates have plummeted to 29% in February, down 98% from the same period last year. Many hotels, especially three and four-star establishments, have closed or are shutting down for renovations. Boutique and budget hotels are struggling to survive, with some considering conversions into offices or offering long-term stays. Local private equity firms, developers, and co-living operators are potential buyers, offering yields of 4-5% for co-living investments.

site_title: UAE wages war on tiny scourge threatening date palms
summary: The United Arab Emirates is waging war against the red weevil, a destructive insect threatening date palms in the Middle East and North Africa. For 24 years, date farmer Said Al-Ajani had to spray his six-hectare plantation five to six times a year to control the infestation. The UAE is taking measures to combat the problem, and Al-Ajani's plantation recently survived the plague. The issue highlights the significant impact of the weevil on the region's agricultural industry and the efforts being made to protect date palms.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.83 points, or 0.35%, to 1,374.99, driven by a higher volume of 208.25 million lots. Gainers beat losers 208 to 44. The increase follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and comes as US-EU trade talks are in focus. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the US dollar remaining stable.

site_title: US records 1,303 coronavirus deaths in 24 hours: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US recorded 1,303 coronavirus deaths in the past 24 hours, bringing the overall death toll to 56,144, with 987,022 confirmed infections. At least 111,109 people have recovered from the virus. The country's confirmed cases are nearing one million.

images.alt_text: The United States recorded 1,303 more novel coronavirus deaths in the past 24 hours, according to figures reported late Monday by the Johns Hopkins University, with confirmed US cases nearing one million.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Jardine C&C, MIT, Ascendas India Trust, SPH
summary: Keppel Corp agreed to sell 38 million Keppel DC Reit units for S$92 million. Jardine Cycle & Carriage reported challenging trading conditions in the first quarter. Mapletree Industrial Trust's distribution per unit fell 7.5% in the fourth quarter. Ascendas India Trust's trustee manager expects adverse impact from India's lockdown extension. Singapore Press Holdings will divest its subsidiary Buzz Shop to Thai-Pore Enterprise.

site_title: HC Surgical says none of Julian Ong's patients switched doctors after knowing of complaint
summary: HC Surgical Specialists (HCSS) says none of Julian Ong's patients have switched doctors after being informed of a Singapore Medical Council complaint. The complaint, filed in 2018, alleged Ong and another specialist had sex with vulnerable female patients. HCSS announced that Ong must inform patients of the allegations and obtain consent before consulting. The company also disclosed that Ong was called up by the Ministry of Defence to assist with the COVID-19 outbreak.

site_title: Thailand to extend Covid-19 emergency measures till end-May
summary: Thailand will extend its COVID-19 emergency measures until the end of May, with no new local cases reported in Bangkok for the first time since January. The country has 2,931 cases and 52 fatalities, with 2,609 patients recovered. The government plans to consider easing some restrictions on businesses and public activities as the number of new cases has eased, but a Cabinet decision on the matter is pending.

site_title: American Airlines mandates masks for flight attendants
summary: American Airlines has mandated its flight attendants to wear masks starting May 1 in response to the Covid-19 pandemic. The airline also announced enhanced cleaning procedures, including the use of EPA-approved disinfectants, and will provide sanitizing wipes or gels and face masks to customers. This move follows United Airlines' similar requirement for its flight attendants.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on stimulus hopes, partial easing of global curbs
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to a three-day gain, driven by hopes of stimulus from central banks and partial easing of global coronavirus restrictions. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,357, while New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index surged 2.5% to a one-week high. Despite a 4.5% gain for Westpac Banking, the lender announced a A$1.6 billion charge due to the pandemic. Crude oil prices plummeted, and gold stocks fell 2.6% as risk sentiment improved.

site_title: Trump says he never considered delaying election
summary: US President Donald Trump denied allegations by Joe Biden that he would try to delay the November election, stating he never considered changing the date. Trump also claimed Biden's comments were "made-up propaganda." The president cannot unilaterally change the election date, which is set for November 3.

site_title: Q&M dentists, staff volunteer to administer Covid-19 swab tests
summary: More than 90 dentists and staff from Q&M Dental Group have volunteered to administer COVID-19 swab tests at factory-converted dormitories and quarantine facilities in Singapore. The team, led by doctors, began testing on April 23 and works in daily shifts with protective gear. Q&M believes its role in assisting the country during the pandemic is crucial, and its CEO stated that the company is well-positioned to provide resources and capabilities to combat COVID-19.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.03%
summary: Singapore shares edged higher on Tuesday, advancing 0.03% to 2,550.16, following overnight US market gains driven by optimism about reopening the US economy. Gainers outnumbered losers 107 to 39, with 73.6 million securities worth S$110.7 million changing hands.

site_title: Rich Asian families tighten belts, while others seek bargains
summary: Asian family offices, managing over $5.9 trillion, are adopting a cautious approach amid the coronavirus pandemic, with many opting to hoard cash and manage their portfolios conservatively. Unlike Western family offices, Asian wealth tends to be newer and more closely tied to the real economy, suggesting forecasts of a rapid rebound may be overly optimistic. Many are worried about the impact of global unemployment and its effect on consumer spending, and are raising cash and dry powder to prepare for worse. While some are still keen to invest, especially in China, others are deferring deals and focusing on building cash buffers.

site_title: Fintech startup Helicap raises US$10m led by Saison Capital
summary: Fintech startup Helicap has raised US$10 million in a Series A funding round led by Saison Capital, with existing investor East Ventures and new investors also participating. The fresh capital will be used to enhance Helicap's credit-scoring technology and explore opportunities in private debt, particularly in the wake of the Covid-19 pandemic. This brings Helicap's total fundraise to US$18 million, solidifying its position to weather the current economic storm.

site_title: APTT declares 0.3 S cent DPU for Q1, proposes 1-for-4 rights issue to pare debt
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT) has declared a 0.30 Singapore cent ordinary interim distribution per unit (DPU) for Q1 2020, unchanged from the previous year. Revenue rose 8.3% to S$79.3 million and Ebitda increased 9.5% to S$48.3 million. APTT proposes a renounceable non-underwritten rights issue to raise S$46.2 million, with S$45 million to pare offshore debt and S$0.1 million for working capital. The issue price is at a 3.8% discount to the last traded price.

site_title: More than 2,200 Indonesians have died with coronavirus symptoms, data shows
summary: More than 2,200 Indonesians have died from coronavirus symptoms, but were not officially recorded as Covid-19 victims, according to a Reuters review of data from 16 provinces. This suggests the national death toll is likely higher than the official figure of 765. Indonesia's low testing rate has contributed to the inaccuracies, making it difficult to gauge the extent of infections in the country.

site_title: APB donates S$75,000 to support migrant workers affected by Covid-19
summary: APB Foundation, the philanthropic arm of Asia Pacific Breweries, has donated S$75,000 to support migrant workers affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The donation will be used to provide daily necessities, food, and accommodation for migrant workers in isolation, as well as financial support for those unable to work due to the "circuit-breaker" measures. The donation aims to provide relief to the most vulnerable group of people hit hardest by the outbreak.

site_title: Japan's March jobless rate rises to one-year high as coronavirus hits economy
summary: Japan's jobless rate rose to 2.5% in March, its highest in a year, due to the coronavirus outbreak and containment measures. The jobs-to-applicants ratio fell to 1.39, its lowest since September 2016, and economists expect further deterioration. The government and Bank of Japan are under pressure to stimulate the economy, with the central bank unveiling steps to ease corporate funding strains and the government increasing its spending package to $1.1 trillion yen.

site_title: France daily coronavirus deaths rise to 437: official
summary: France reported 437 new coronavirus deaths, bringing the total to 23,293. The number of patients in intensive care fell by 74 to 4,608, while hospital patients decreased by 162 to 28,055. The country is set to emerge from its lockdown on May 11, with schools expected to reopen gradually, but cafes and restaurants will remain shut.

site_title: Fintech startup Oriente bags additional US$50m for ongoing Series B round
summary: Oriente, a fintech startup, has secured US$50 million in its ongoing Series B funding round led by Peter Lee, co-chairman of Henderson Land, and Wix.com. The new capital will be used to drive growth in existing markets and expand into new markets, such as Vietnam. The funding will also enhance technology infrastructure, product suite, and big-data capabilities. Oriente has seen significant growth, recording a 700% year-on-year growth in transactions in 2019 and serving over five million users across the Philippines and Indonesia.

site_title: US judge rules talc lawsuits against J&J can proceed, testimony limited
summary: A US judge has ruled that thousands of talc lawsuits against Johnson & Johnson can proceed, but with limits on expert testimony. The lawsuits claim J&J's talc products contain asbestos and cause ovarian cancer. The ruling allows plaintiffs to present epidemiological studies on the link between talc and cancer, but restricts testimony on the talc's direct impact on the ovaries. J&J denies the talc causes cancer and says its products are safe and asbestos-free. The decision will allow plaintiffs to present their cases, potentially leading to a settlement or trial verdict.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust changes name to ARA Logos Logistics Trust; posts Q1 DPU of 0.997 S cent
summary: CACHE Logistics Trust has changed its name to ARA Logos Logistics Trust (ALog) with effect from April 30. The trust posted a Q1 DPU of 0.997 S cents, down from 1.513 S cents a year ago, due to retained earnings. The decline in DPU is to conserve capital amid a challenging period, with lower gross revenue and net property income. The trust's manager, previously known as ARA Trust Management (Cache), has also been renamed ARA Logos Logistics Trust Management.

site_title: Amazon defends virus safety efforts amid fresh protests
summary: Amazon has faced renewed protests from warehouse workers amid concerns over its coronavirus safety efforts. Over 50 employees walked out of an Amazon warehouse in Minnesota, and 2,000 signed a petition demanding extended paid leave. Activists claim Amazon has not taken sufficient measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19, despite 130 workers testing positive in US facilities. Amazon defends its safety efforts, stating it has implemented deep cleaning, safety supplies, and flexible leave options, including extended paid leave for those diagnosed with Covid-19.

site_title: California governor admonishes crowds who flocked to beaches
summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom admonished crowds who flocked to beaches over the weekend, warning that their behavior could reverse progress in combating the coronavirus pandemic. Despite beaches being closed due to the pandemic, thousands of people packed beaches in southern California, prompting a backlash. Newsom stated that such behavior could push back the state's gradual lifting of stay-at-home orders, and he plans to reassess enforcement measures to avoid a repeat of the weekend scenes.

site_title: Trump appears to confirm that North Korea's Kim is alive
summary: US President Donald Trump confirmed that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is alive, despite days of speculation about his whereabouts. Trump expressed a desire for Kim's well-being, saying he had a "very good idea" about his health but declined to elaborate. This comes after Kim's absence from public appearances since April 11, sparking media reports of his illness or death. A top South Korean security adviser had previously stated Kim was "alive and well."

site_title: Defining interface between IP rights and climate change
summary: Singapore has adopted measures to combat climate change, including a National Climate Change Strategy, a Paris Climate Agreement, and a Carbon Pricing Act. The country aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 36% by 2030. Intellectual property rights can incentivize the creation and dissemination of environmentally sound technologies, but there is a need to calibrate IP rights to control access to these technologies. Patent pools and certification trade marks can promote access to green technologies. Singapore's Climate Action Plan seeks to improve energy and carbon efficiency, and the country has submitted an enhanced Nationally Determined Contribution to the UNFCCC.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Tuesday with fresh gains
summary: Hong Kong shares began the week with gains, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.50%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. The positive market trend is attributed to easing coronavirus outbreaks in several countries.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares opened higher on Tuesday following a positive lead from Wall Street, with traders taking heart from further signs that the coronavirus outbreak is easing in several countries.

site_title: White House adviser Navarro lashes out at China over 'fake' test kits
summary: White House trade adviser Peter Navarro accused China of sending low-quality and counterfeit coronavirus antibody testing kits to the US, claiming it "profiteers" from the pandemic. China has rejected US accusations, with Foreign Ministry spokesperson Hua Chunying saying President Trump should "stop playing the political game." The US is heavily reliant on China for equipment and drugs, and the two countries have traded accusations over the outbreak.

site_title: Businesses push to delay minimum wage hikes in US states
summary: Business groups in several US states, including Virginia, California, Illinois, Michigan, and Massachusetts, are pushing to delay planned minimum wage hikes due to the economic crisis caused by the coronavirus pandemic. They argue that embattled businesses cannot afford to give workers a raise, citing the need to survive the economic downturn. Some states have already approved delays, including Virginia, which postponed the increase to May 2021, while others, such as California, are weighing similar measures.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Opportunities in tech? China cutting LPR, Hin Leong and Singapore banks, S-REITs
summary: A recent Money FM podcast discussed market opportunities, including China's potential to cut the LPR (lending prime rate), Hin Leong's financial struggles, and Singapore banks. Naveen Kumar, founder of Nityo Infotech Services, shared his insights on market trends and the impact of dollar asset diversification on Asia. He also touched on the rise of stablecoins and the potential for retail investors to drive ETF growth in Asia and Europe. The conversation highlighted the importance of productivity gains and de-dollarisation in unlocking wealth creation.

site_title: Investors to challenge Neiman Marcus bankruptcy loan: sources
summary: An investor group, comprising Mudrick Capital Management LP and Third Point LLC, plans to challenge a $600 million financing package for Neiman Marcus' impending bankruptcy. The group will push for the department store operator to sell itself. Neiman Marcus is preparing to file for bankruptcy protection in a Dallas federal court as soon as Monday. The company's sales have significantly decreased due to the coronavirus outbreak, forcing temporary store closures.

site_title: Avocados are in, pork bellies out as pandemic changes consumer eating
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly altered consumer eating habits, with people seeking comfort and healthier options. Avocados have seen a 60% price surge due to high demand, while butter prices have plummeted due to reduced restaurant demand. Other produce items, such as citrus, are also in high demand. Packaged foods, including frozen pizzas and instant noodles, are selling out, and snack consumption is on the rise. Experts believe these trends may persist even after lockdowns end, as people continue to cook at home and prioritize convenience.

site_title: Insurtech startup Qoala bags US$13.5m in Series A round
summary: Southeast Asian insurtech startup Qoala has secured US$13.5 million in its Series A funding round, led by Centauri Fund. New investors include Sequoia India, Flourish Ventures, and Mirae Asset Venture Investment. The funding will be used to invest in technology, people, and brand, with plans to double its staff to 300 over the next year. Qoala aims to digitize insurers and improve customer experience, partnering with large-scale platform partners to increase insurance awareness in Indonesia, which has low insurance penetration.

site_title: First Sponsor Q1 profit rises 4.8% to S$24.9m
summary: First Sponsor Group, a Mainboard-listed property developer, reported a 4.8% rise in net profit to S$24.9 million for its first quarter ended March 31, 2020. Revenue rose 1.1% to S$45.8 million, driven by property financing revenue. The company successfully issued S$100 million medium-term notes and completed refinancing of its committed revolving credit facilities. Operations were suspended for 13 out of 16 hotels due to the Covid-19 pandemic, but the group is "cautiously optimistic" about new deal opportunities arising from the crisis.

site_title: Federal Reserve expands lending programme to smaller US cities
summary: The US Federal Reserve has expanded its Municipal Lending Facility (MLF) to include smaller US cities and counties, lowering population thresholds to 250,000 residents for cities and 500,000 for counties. This move aims to provide more entities with access to funds to mitigate the economic damage caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The program, which offers up to $500 billion in lending, will also support the Paycheck Protection Programme and other economic measures. The Fed has rapidly rolled out new lending vehicles to pump cash into the US economy.

site_title: Amazon extends closure of French warehouses to May 5
summary: Amazon has extended the closure of its French warehouses until May 5, following an appeals court's confirmation of a ruling restricting deliveries during the coronavirus pandemic. The US online retail giant initially shut its warehouses on April 16 after a court allowed only food, hygiene, or medical products to be delivered. Amazon will pay its employees full pay while the warehouses are closed and will be allowed to deliver a range of non-essential goods, including digital products and groceries.

images.alt_text: US online retail giant Amazon said Monday it will keep its French warehouses closed until May 5, after an appeals court confirmed a ruling restricting its deliveries during the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: StanChart's troubled loans may top US$600m on corporate woes
summary: Standard Chartered Plc may face loan losses exceeding $600 million due to corporate scandals and the COVID-19 pandemic. Nearly $500 million of lending to NMC Health Plc and Hin Leong Trading (Pte) could result in only 18 cents recovery per dollar lent. The bank's exposure to problem companies, including energy producers hit by the oil crash, may lead to significant write-offs. Standard Chartered's assets are largely based in Asia, Africa, and the Middle East, where the pandemic's impact is significant.

site_title: As Covid-19 eases, China faces huge unemployment challenge
summary: China is facing a huge unemployment challenge as the Covid-19 pandemic eases, with millions out of work and the number set to continue rising this year due to slowing annual growth. The country's official unemployment rate stands at 5.9%, but estimates suggest tens of millions of people are actually unemployed, particularly migrant workers and those in the services sector. The government is struggling to provide financial relief to small private companies, which are largely responsible for the layoffs, and many business owners have little choice but to shut down.

site_title: Catastrophe bonds raise Singapore's profile as hub for alternative risk
summary: Singapore's efforts to become a global capital for alternative risk transfer are gaining momentum, particularly in catastrophe bonds. Since 2019, six cat bond issuances worth US$488 million have been domiciled in Singapore, with investor interest in alternative asset classes growing amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's grant scheme to fund up to 100% of ILS issuance costs has been successful, with the market expected to continue growing, driven by demand for diversification and yield. However, Singapore needs to grow its ecosystem of service providers to encourage more issuers, with Mr. Goh calling for incentives and subsidies to encourage overseas-based arrangers to set up an office in Singapore.

site_title: HC Surgical should immediately exercise put option on Julian Ong's practice
summary: HC Surgical Specialists faces financial risks due to its association with Dr. Julian Ong, who has been accused of colluding with a psychiatrist to take advantage of vulnerable female patients. The company's board was unaware of the scandal until recently, and it is now considering exercising a put option to sever ties with Dr. Ong and recover its investment in his practice. The put option, which was introduced in September last year, requires Dr. Ong to buy back the company's 70% stake in Julian Ong Endoscopy & Surgery (JOES) if he is found guilty of misconduct.

site_title: Oil back below US$15 on glut, producers start cuts
summary: Oil prices dropped below US$15 a barrel as global crude stockpiles surged, making it difficult for producers to balance the market. US drilling declined, with Saudi Arabia reducing output ahead of Opec+ supply cuts. The glut is expected to test storage capacity limits in three weeks, raising fears of another price crash. Despite Opec's efforts to curb output, demand remains weak, with the coronavirus pandemic weighing on gasoline consumption.

site_title: Sembcorp Cogen obtains court order to secure gasoil stored at Hin Leong's terminal
summary: Sembcorp Cogen has secured a court order in Singapore to prevent Universal Terminal from moving or disposing of gasoil reserves designated for the subsidiary. The order requires the terminal to store the reserves separately from other gasoil. The move comes after Sembcorp Cogen scrapped a decade-old gasoil supply and storage deal with Hin Leong Trading, which is grappling with a debt pile of US$4 billion. The court order may protect Sembcorp Cogen's interests in the reserves, valued at S$94 million as of 2019.

site_title: Over a million Australians download virus tracker app
summary: Over 1.1 million Australians have downloaded a government smartphone app designed for Covid-19 contact tracing, despite concerns over data use. The Health Minister, Greg Hunt, hailed the take-up as "extraordinary". The app aims to make contact tracing easier, but its use of personal data has raised concerns. The app's success highlights the growing demand for digital health solutions during the pandemic.

site_title: Changing hands
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

US stocks opened lower due to President Trump's tariff salvo on Canada. Companies like Creative Technology warned of lower-than-expected revenue and similar operating losses. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO is Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. Singapore stocks rallied for the 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data. CGSI downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to expected slowing earnings growth in H2. MAS and PBOC also announced deeper cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: India offers funds 500b-rupee credit facility after Franklin Templeton stress
summary: India's Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has launched a 500 billion rupee (S$9.3 billion) credit facility to support the country's mutual fund industry, which is facing a crisis due to the shutdown of six funds by Franklin Templeton last week. The facility will provide liquidity to mutual funds through banks, and the RBI has announced a 90-day repo operation at a fixed repo rate. The move aims to calm investor concerns and prevent a distress sale of assets.

site_title: Old Chang Kee warns of decline in sales and profits; explores e-commerce tie-ups to expand sale of food
summary: Old Chang Kee, a Singaporean food and beverage operator, has warned of a decline in sales and operating profits due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company has temporarily closed 22 of its 89 operating stores in Singapore, with 67 remaining open for takeaway and delivery. To offset the decline, Old Chang Kee is exploring e-commerce tie-ups and has received corporate catering orders, including dormitory orders for bento meals. The company is also assessing the impact of potential impairment to its assets in overseas markets.

site_title: Prudential pays over S$800,000 from Covid-19 package; launches new app
summary: Prudential Singapore has disbursed over S$800,000 from its S$1.5 million Covid-19 relief package, primarily as quarantine benefits to over 1,000 people. The company has also launched a new digital health app, Pulse, which offers a symptom checker, tele-consultation platform, and daily hospitalisation allowance for Covid-19 cases. The app is available in Singapore and other countries, and users can pay a flat fee of S$15 for consultations. Prudential aims to integrate wealth and business management services into the app and protect user data.

site_title: Michelle Obama book tour documentary hits Netflix
summary: Michelle Obama will star in a documentary about her global book tour for her memoir "Becoming," set to release on Netflix next week. The film follows the former first lady as she shares stories of the people she met after the memoir's release. This is the Obamas' latest collaboration with Netflix, following their Oscar-winning documentary "American Factory" in February.

site_title: Why some fear a coronabond as much as the coronavirus
summary: The European Union is facing a deep economic downturn, with the International Monetary Fund forecasting a 7% drop in real GDP this year and only partial recovery in 2021. Europe has been slow to contribute to the economic costs of the COVID-19 crisis, with member states engaging in a scramble for medical supplies and failing to make progress on fiscal aid. The European Central Bank has taken steps to calm financial markets, but the EU's lack of action has left many countries fiscally stretched. The economic fallout from the "Great Lockdown" is expected to be severe.

site_title: Government reviewing housing arrangements for foreign workers
summary: Singapore's government is reviewing housing arrangements for foreign workers, with plans to find new sites and spaces for migrant workers who have recovered from Covid-19. Minister Lawrence Wong said the goal is to have "longer-term housing arrangements" ready in a year or two. Meanwhile, the government is scaling up testing efforts for Covid-19, with a focus on migrant workers and essential workers. Testing capacity has increased to over 8,000 tests per day, and targeted testing will be expanded to more groups. The government aims to gradually reopen the economy while minimizing the risk of new infections.
