Health Canada emphasizes that these drugs should only be used under a physician's supervision due to their potential to cause serious health issues.

site_title: All eyes on ECB for further virus-fighting moves
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has launched unprecedented measures to combat the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic, including a 1.1 trillion-euro bond-buying program and cheap lending to banks. The ECB may consider further actions, such as buying "junk"-rated debt, to restore confidence and address debt sustainability concerns. ECB President Christine Lagarde will make a public appeal for EU leaders to overcome their differences on rescue funds, as the ECB may be forced to take more drastic measures to support the eurozone economy.

site_title: Oil falls on storage woes in virus-hit market
summary: Oil prices fell 5.5% to $16.00 a barrel and 1.4% to $21.14 a barrel, as storage concerns and reduced demand due to the coronavirus pandemic weighed on the market. Despite some producers cutting output to boost markets, storage facilities in the US are struggling to cope with oversupply. Analysts say the continued virus fight and positive signs in the market kept prices from falling too heavily. A major agreement to reduce output by 10 million barrels a day from May aims to shore up markets and end a price war between Russia and Saudi Arabia.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell on Monday on renewed concerns over storage capacity, as the coronavirus throttles demand, even as producers start slashing output to boost markets.

site_title: China Everbright Water bags 213m yuan public-private partnership project in Shandong
summary: China Everbright Water has secured a 213 million yuan public-private partnership project in Shandong province, China, for a wastewater treatment plant. The project, valued at S$42.8 million, has a concession period of 30 years and a daily treatment capacity of 50,000 cubic meters. This is the company's seventh water project in Jinan's Zhangqiu District, solidifying its local market position. China Everbright Water will hold a 99% stake in the project, which is expected to leverage the company's long-term trust and support from local government authorities and the public.

site_title: StanChart's troubled loans top US$600m on corporate woes
summary: Standard Chartered's problem loans have reached over $600 million due to corporate scandals and the COVID-19 pandemic. The bank's exposures to NMC Health, Hin Leong Trading, and a South African farm bank have contributed to the increase. While loan losses are manageable, the bank's exposure to Hin Leong may result in only 18 cents on every dollar lent being recovered. The pandemic's impact on the financial system is rippling through the industry, with analysts predicting further bad loans to energy producers.

site_title: New York may partially reopen May 15: Cuomo
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo announced that the state may partially reopen manufacturing and construction after May 15, with easing of measures first occurring in upstate regions. A lockdown is set to expire on May 15, and any reopening of New York City would need to be coordinated with authorities in New Jersey and Connecticut. The state will require businesses to present plans for sanitation to reduce virus transmission. Cuomo emphasized the need for a downturn in Covid-19 hospitalizations and a full return to normalcy won't occur until schools reopen.

site_title: Egypt seeks aid from IMF amid virus-inflicted downturn
summary: Egypt is seeking a one-year aid package from the International Monetary Fund to mitigate the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The loan, expected to be negotiated within days, aims to support the domestic economy and affected people and businesses. The aid package comes amid a severe downturn, with foreign reserves dropping from $45.5 billion to $40.1 billion at the end of March. Egypt's tourism sector, which earned $12.6 billion in 2019, has been severely impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: UK reports lowest virus toll in weeks as Johnson returns
summary: Britain reported its lowest daily rise in coronavirus deaths in nearly four weeks with 413 new deaths, bringing the total to 20,732. This is the lowest daily increase since March 31. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has recovered from the virus and returned to Downing Street. The UK's economic contraction for the second month in a row adds to pressure on Labour leader Keir Starmer.

images.alt_text: Britain on Sunday reported its lowest daily rise in coronavirus deaths in nearly four weeks as officials confirmed Prime Minister Boris Johnson had returned to Downing Street after recovering from the virus.

site_title: Train likely belonging to North Korea's Kim seen at resort town: US monitor
summary: A train likely belonging to North Korean leader Kim Jong Un was spotted at a resort town in the country's east, according to satellite photos reviewed by a US-based think tank. The train was parked at a station reserved for the Kim family in Wonsan on April 21 and April 23. The US think tank cautioned that the train's presence does not prove Kim's whereabouts or health, but it lends weight to reports that Kim is staying at an elite area on the eastern coast. Kim has been absent from public appearances since April 11.

site_title: Taiwan sommelier takes wine tasting online
summary: A young Taiwanese sommelier, Peter Petrus, is taking wine tasting classes online due to social distancing rules caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. He teaches students across the island, live streaming from his studio in Taipei, and couriering wine samples to students. Despite constraints, Petrus keeps students engaged, with one student describing the experience as "quite special." This move aims to keep his business afloat during the pandemic.

site_title: Virus death tolls ease off in hard-hit parts of Europe
summary: Europe's hardest-hit countries, including Italy, Spain, France, and Britain, reported drops in daily fatality rates, a sign the peak of the crisis may have passed. Lockdown measures are being eased, with children in Spain allowed outside for the first time in six weeks and hairdressers and shops reopening in Switzerland. However, the World Health Organization warns that recovered people may not be immune to reinfection, and cases and deaths continue to plateau.

images.alt_text: Europe's hardest-hit countries reported promising drops in coronavirus daily death tolls on Sunday, as governments around the world started peeling back lockdown measures in a bid to restore normal life and resuscitate crippled economies.

site_title: Giving back with compassion and a social heart for the community
summary: A Singapore-based technology startup, FINDJOBS, has been working to provide job opportunities to non-executive workers, including low-income and illiterate individuals, since its launch in 2017. The company has seen over 100,000 downloads of its app and partnered with the Employment and Employability Institute and Ministry of Social and Family Development to set up smart job kiosks. This initiative aims to bring job searching offline to better serve the technology-savvy but lower-income workforce.

site_title: Deflation stalks the world after expansive policies of coronavirus era
summary: Deflation is emerging as a global economic concern following the coronavirus pandemic, with collapsing oil markets and weaker demand contributing to the issue. Despite large stimulus packages, concerns about rising prices are being overlooked, and inflation targets are no longer seen as a reliable measure of economic health. Historically, inflation was the preferred indicator, but alternatives have not been proposed, leaving policymakers without a clear guidepost for assessing economic conditions.

site_title: China says all coronavirus patients in Wuhan are discharged
summary: China reports that all coronavirus patients in Wuhan have been discharged, according to a health official. The city, where the pandemic began, had 46,452 cases and 3,869 fatalities. Wuhan was placed under lockdown in January and is still conducting regular testing despite restrictions being lifted. The city's efforts are seen as a success, with the number of new patients at zero.

site_title: The bike is back as Europe looks to exit lockdowns safely
summary: European nations are using bicycles to help city dwellers move safely as lockdowns are lifted. Authorities in Paris, Milan, and Berlin are creating temporary cycling paths to encourage social distancing. This approach is seen as a way to get people back to work without increasing the risk of spreading COVID-19 on crowded public transport. Cycling is also considered a more eco-friendly option. France plans to make masks mandatory on public transport, and Germany is doubling its funding for bike and walking lanes to 58 million euros.

site_title: Embraer hits out after Boeing scraps US$4.2b tie-up
summary: Boeing scrapped a $4.2 billion deal to buy Embraer's commercial jets division, citing Embraer's failure to meet conditions, but Embraer claims Boeing was the one that torpedoed the deal due to financial woes. The collapse halts a potential US-Brazil alliance and breaks a previously close relationship between the two planemakers. Embraer is poised to sue Boeing for significantly more than the $100 million breakup fee, and the deal's collapse will likely impact Embraer's finances and future plans.

site_title: Speculators' bearish bets on US dollar at a near 2-year high: CFTC
summary: Speculators' net bearish bets on the US dollar reached a near 2-year high, totaling $11.51 billion for the week ended April 21, according to the CFTC. This represents a significant increase from the previous week's net short position of $11.39 billion. The US dollar positioning was driven by a bearish bias in currencies such as the Japanese yen, euro, and British pound. The dollar's decline is attributed to investors' renewed appetite for risky assets and the Federal Reserve's aggressive policy actions.

site_title: Private placement investors stepping up to address cash crunch
summary: Private placement investors have stepped up to address cash crunch concerns in the Singapore dollar bond market, which has been seized up by extreme volatility since March. Six out of seven Singapore dollar bond issues have been done on a private placement basis, including deals by PSA International, SATS, and Keppel Corporation. These investors, including insurance firms and banks, are attracted to the wider spreads offered in private placements. The move has helped issuers raise funds and refinance existing borrowings, with PSA issuing a S$500 million 1.63% 10-year fixed rate note through a private placement.

site_title: Google's real estate pause shows cracks in tech office demand
summary: Google's recent pause on real estate deals in Silicon Valley, San Francisco, and Seattle signals a slowdown in tech office demand, prompting concerns from landlords and brokers. The tech industry, which accounted for over a fifth of US office leasing, is rethinking its office needs amid the coronavirus pandemic. Executives are deciding to wait before making lease commitments, with some advising clients to wait a few months to negotiate better deals. This pause may lead to a broader retreat by technology companies in the US office market.

site_title: Dark clouds shroud outlook for AUD/USD
summary: The Australian dollar (AUD) is facing a downward outlook for the AUD/USD pair due to declining manufacturing and service PMI numbers amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The recent widening gap between short-term and long-term moving averages and strong resistance at the 50 EMA levels indicate bearish momentum. Additionally, a downtrend line since 2020 is holding strong, and Fibonacci retracement levels suggest a 4.04% downside potential if prices dip further. This suggests that the AUD/USD pair may experience further weakness.

site_title: Bank of China clients said to have 7b yuan losses on oil bet
summary: Bank of China Ltd estimates retail investors have suffered losses of over 7 billion yuan (S$1.4 billion) due to the collapse of a product linked to US crude oil futures. The losses stem from the bank settling May contracts at minus US$37.63 a barrel, leaving customers with losses of up to 4.2 billion yuan. The bank has suspended trading in the product, and hundreds have protested online, demanding the lender take responsibility for the losses. The lender has not commented on the matter.

site_title: 931 new cases in Singapore, on Sunday, of which 15 are Singaporeans and PRs
summary: Singapore reported 931 new COVID-19 cases on April 26, 2020, with 15 cases being Singaporeans and permanent residents. The total number of confirmed cases has reached 13,624, mostly among work permit holders in foreign worker dormitories. Experts warn that a sustained decline in local community cases is needed before Singapore can turn the corner, and caution that recent dips in migrant worker cases may be due to reduced testing. The country's COVID-19 curve remains a challenge.

site_title: Military spending saw biggest increase in a decade in 2019: study
summary: Global military expenditure reached its highest point since the end of the Cold War in 2019, with nations spending a combined $1.9 trillion, a 3.6% annual growth from 2018. The US was the largest spender, accounting for 38% of global spending, with China and India joining the top three for the first time. The increase in military spending is attributed to the US and Asia's growing ambitions, with China seeking to become a military superpower. However, the new coronavirus pandemic and economic fallout may lead to a decline in military spending, with experts predicting a potential reversal in spending trends.

site_title: Covid-19 setback a reminder for investors to tread carefully
summary: The Covid-19 crisis is far from over, with Singapore extending its "circuit breaker" measures to June 1 and imposing additional restrictions. Despite a strong rebound in stocks, investors should exercise caution due to the risk of companies needing to tap investors and controlling shareholders seeking to access their companies' funds. This could lead to a surge in capital-raising exercises, including rights issues and follow-on share issuances. Investors should focus on companies with liquid balance sheets and be prepared for bad news as the crisis drags on.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sim Leisure Group, a theme park operator, will hold a remote extraordinary general meeting on May 11 to vote on a plan to place over 13.4 million shares to a new investor, Tropika Kiara. Mirach Energy and Nam Cheong, listed shipbuilders, have received extensions for their annual reports and meetings due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Serial System is selling a stake in an inactive subsidiary for a net loss of US$2,000, while Sarine Technologies expects its second-quarter results to be severely impaired by the pandemic.

site_title: PM Lee's May Day Rally to be aired on TV, social media
summary: Singapore's National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) will hold a virtual May Day Rally on May 1 due to the ongoing "circuit breaker" measures to combat the novel coronavirus. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will deliver his May Day Message on TV and social media instead of attending the in-person rally. The NTUC has also cancelled its May Day Fiesta and May Day Awards ceremony, and will instead hold alternative online events to honor migrant and domestic workers.

site_title: LHT stays chipper on higher demand for its pallets made of recycled wood
summary: LHT Holdings, a Singapore-based company, has seen a surge in demand for its pallets made of recycled wood, with rental demand for its wooden pallets increasing by 40% compared to pre-Covid-19 times. The company's CEO, May Yap, attributes this to retailers seeking to build their own stockpiles of fast-moving consumer goods. LHT has been able to capitalize on this trend, despite intense competition from regional pallet makers. The company's focus on sustainability and green products has also led to plans to create even more eco-friendly solutions, with a goal to become a "one-stop shop" for logistics services.

site_title: China eases restrictions on exports of some coronavirus equipment
summary: China has eased restrictions on exports of some coronavirus equipment, allowing products such as test kits, masks, and ventilators to be exported as long as they are approved in the importing countries. The move comes after previous restrictions hindered the supply of these products to countries fighting the pandemic. The new rule applies to products with overseas approval or registration, which will undergo verification by a trade group authorized by the commerce ministry. This change is seen as a revision to a previous one-size-fits-all policy, allowing for greater flexibility in meeting the requirements of importing countries.

site_title: Director filings subside as earnings come into focus
summary: The Straits Times Index declined 2.7% over the five trading sessions from April 17 to 23, with the Nikkei 225 Index, Hang Seng Index, and S&P/ASX 200 Index averaging a 0.9% decline. There were 13 primary-listed stocks conducting share buybacks, with Hong Fok Corporation leading the consideration tally. Director and substantial shareholder transactions saw 42 changes, including 14 acquisitions and three disposals. Filings have declined significantly as earnings season takes focus, with Sasseur Reit and GSS Energy seeing notable transactions.

site_title: Game on: Secretlab goes from startup to global brand in 5 years
summary: Secretlab, a Singapore-based gaming chair manufacturer, has rapidly grown into a global brand in just five years. Co-founded by former professional gamers Ian Alexander Ang and Alaric Choo in 2014, the company turned a profit in its first year and now manufactures over 300,000 chairs annually, sold in over 60 countries. With a valuation of over S$200 million, Secretlab has become a recognized global brand, with North America accounting for over 50% of its sales. The company's success is attributed to its focus on building a solid business foundation, rather than seeking investors, and its commitment to supporting its employees and the community during the coronavirus pandemic.

images.alt_text: Mr Ang says the growing e-sports sector offers opportunities for Secretlab to develop better and more advanced versions of its gaming chairs.

site_title: Nearly half of firms in Singapore to review their business continuity plans: survey
summary: Nearly half of companies in Singapore plan to review their business continuity plans following the Covid-19 pandemic. A survey by CBRE found that 44% of firms will review their BCPs, while 40% are considering splitting operations across multiple office locations. Experts believe the pandemic has been a testing ground for BCPs, and companies are adapting to a "hub and spoke" model or "core and flex" model to cope with the new reality. The survey also revealed that 96% of companies plan to boost technology to support remote working and nearly 70% expect to ramp up flexible working.

site_title: M&C hotels join fight against pandemic
summary: MILLENNIUM & Copthorne Hotels (M&C), a subsidiary of City Developments Ltd, has converted its Singapore properties into isolation facilities for returning Singaporeans and long-term residents to serve a 14-day stay-home notice. The company has also donated rooms to support medical staff, government employees, and key workers, including Chelsea Football Club. In addition, M&C's hotels globally have offered discounted accommodation to affected staff and medical personnel, utilizing its 145 hotels across 80 locations with 43,000 rooms.

site_title: Australia launches Covid-19 tracking app
summary: Australia launched a coronavirus tracing app based on Singapore's TraceTogether software, using Bluetooth signals to track close contacts. The app has been criticized for its potential invasion of privacy, but the government claims it's safe and will legislate privacy protections. The app's stored data will enable health officials to trace people potentially exposed to infections. The government aims for at least 40% of the population to sign up, with a legislative directive proposed in May to ensure data protection.

site_title: Many of China's Belt & Road Initiative projects put on hold due to Covid-19
summary: China's Belt & Road Initiative projects face a significant slowdown due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with many projects put on hold or delayed. International pressure has mounted for China to write off debt repayments to developing countries, and analysts predict a shift towards more sustainable and transparent projects. China may also focus on a "health belt and road" strategy, promoting healthcare infrastructure and services between BRI countries, as a cheaper and more viable option.

site_title: Clearbridge's 'build, borrow, buy' approach
summary: Singapore-based healthcare entrepreneur Jeremy Yee, CEO of Clearbridge Health, aims to nurture talent and unlock human potential through his 'build, borrow, buy' approach. Clearbridge Health, a precision medicine services firm, has expanded its network in Singapore and across South-east Asia, offering affordable products and services. The company has a growing network of owned and operated primary healthcare touchpoints and healthcare systems across Asia. Despite challenges, Yee believes his vision will bring high-quality healthcare to the masses through a Public-Private Partnership model, and the company is moving towards profitability.

images.alt_text: Mr Yee says: "Healthcare is pretty much an under-served market here, given Asean's population base of more than 655 million. With a feasible business model, you can easily capture a multitude of opportunities."

site_title: Factory doors finally start reopening in Europe
summary: Europe's factory doors are reopening after coronavirus shutdowns, with nations easing restrictions on public life. The restart is crucial to revive the region's economy, which has been in its worst slump since records began. Companies will implement social distancing and hygiene measures to keep workers safe, and ramping up production is more complicated due to supply chain disruptions. The European car industry, which accounts for 14 million jobs, is eager to get back to work, but it's unclear whether buyers will return to showrooms once lockdowns are lifted.

site_title: Anti-viral drug and oil hold the key to market's recovery
summary: The US stock market may continue its recovery, but faces challenges from the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, the oil crash, and the Federal Reserve's ability to support the economy. A positive update on Gilead Sciences' remdesivir trial could boost consumer spending and demand, but leaked data from previous trials has caused market swings. The oil crash has led to a global surplus, with prices near zero and some producers on the verge of bankruptcy. The Fed's policy statement on Wednesday may address concerns about its ability to support the economy, but a "spike" in cases in Georgia could send shockwaves through markets.

site_title: Germany flips on smartphone contact tracing, backs Apple, Google
summary: Germany has changed its approach to smartphone contact tracing for COVID-19, backing a decentralized method supported by Apple and Google. The new approach will store contacts on devices only, rather than on a central server, to prioritize trust. This shift follows criticism from hundreds of scientists regarding the centralized approach, which could lead to state surveillance. Germany's decision aligns with Apple's and Google's plans to develop tools for decentralized contact tracing, which will work by assessing closeness and length of contact between people and notifying recent contacts if infected.

images.alt_text: Germany's change of tack would bring its approach in line with that taken by Apple and Alphabet's Google, which said this month they would develop new tools to support decentralised contact tracing.

site_title: Biolidics unlikely to be affected by allegations against coronavirus test kit distributor: Board
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has questioned Catalist-listed Biolidics over its agreement with Nasdaq-listed Aytu Bioscience, a scandal-hit company, as an exclusive distributor for rapid Covid-19 antibody test kits. Biolidics' board stated that it does not expect a material impact on its business from the agreement, despite ongoing probes into Aytu's distribution of unapproved Chinese test kits. Biolidics has not verified the claims or sought legal advice, but believes it would not be impacted by the investigation.

site_title: Richard Branson seeking buyer for Virgin Atlantic: report
summary: Richard Branson is seeking a buyer for Virgin Atlantic Airways Ltd due to struggling to secure a £500 million government bailout. The airline has set an end-of-May deadline to save itself from collapse, focusing on securing new private investment from over 100 financial institutions. Discussions with stakeholders are ongoing, but the application for government aid has been effectively shelved, with negotiations potentially reviving if investment can't be found elsewhere. Several investors, including Centerbridge Partners and Temasek, are in the running to acquire the airline.

site_title: Next stage of oil crisis: from the great crash to the great shutdown
summary: The global oil industry is facing a severe crisis, with the specter of production shutdowns becoming a reality. Negative oil prices, surging shipping costs, and traders seeking creative storage solutions have led to a surge in shutdowns. The US shale patch is leading the way, with over 40% of oil rigs stopped, and other countries including Saudi Arabia, Russia, and Chad also cutting production. The world is running out of storage capacity, with 50 million barrels of crude going into storage each week, and oil refiners are also shutting down, with some processing just 12.45 million barrels a day.

site_title: Bosses may not get wage subsidies for some contract workers
summary: Employers hiring contract workers through third-party staffing agencies in Singapore may not receive wage subsidy benefits from the Jobs Support Scheme, despite industry urges to pass them on to customers. Authorities have not obligated agencies to do so, but they are encouraged to do so. This decision may impact employers and customers, who may not receive the full benefits of the subsidy.

site_title: OKP sees hit from lower construction demand
summary: Construction group OKP Holdings expects a hit from lower construction demand amid the novel coronavirus outbreak in Singapore, with projects delayed and supply-chain disruptions to materials. The company plans to launch a second project, Phoenix Heights, in the second half of 2020, "depending on prevailing market conditions." OKP will exercise prudence in share buybacks and monitor its share price performance closely.

site_title: 400 daily limit for Malaysian workers who will need entry permit to return from Singapore
summary: Malaysia has set a daily limit of 400 workers who can return from Singapore, requiring an entry permit prior to re-entry. This measure is aimed at controlling the influx of workers amid the ongoing pandemic. The limit will be enforced starting Monday, according to Senior Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob and Johor health committee chairman R Vidyananthan.

site_title: May Day Rally to go virtual amid Covid-19 circuit breaker
summary: Singapore's May Day Rally will be held virtually due to the ongoing COVID-19 circuit breaker. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will deliver his message on national television and social media channels. The event typically draws over 1,500 unionists, but about 500 representatives will participate in a closed-door virtual dialogue session. The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has cancelled its May Day Fiesta activities and scrapped the May Day Awards ceremony, instead planning online celebrations for migrant and domestic workers. The virtual May Day event will take place on Thursday evening.

site_title: World's biggest central banks to meet as pressure mounts to do more
summary: Global central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, Bank of Japan, and European Central Bank, will meet this week to discuss economic support amid the coronavirus recession. Despite record-low interest rates and trillions of dollars in asset purchases, pressure mounts for further action. The US Federal Reserve, Bank of Japan, and European Central Bank, which cover nearly half of global output, will convene meetings of policymakers to address the pandemic-driven economic turmoil and financial market instability.

site_title: China reports 12 new coronavirus cases, no new deaths
summary: China reported 12 new coronavirus cases on April 24, with 11 being imported, and 29 new asymptomatic cases, including 4 imports. The total confirmed cases in China are now 82,816, with a death toll of 4,632 remaining unchanged.

site_title: Mindset change needed towards migrant workers - and manual work
summary: Singapore should mandate that employers house foreign workers in a manner promoting good public health and human dignity, and provide food at all times, according to Victor Mills. This will increase the true cost of treating foreign workers with respect, forcing employers to reduce their dependence on foreign workers and encourage collaboration and innovation in the construction sector. Employers will have to factor in the costs, potentially leading to a reduction in reliance on foreign workers. This change is long overdue to improve the living conditions of migrant workers.

site_title: Sarine Technologies warns of 'severely impaired' Q2 results as pandemic hits gem trade
summary: Sarine Technologies, a gem production industry company, warns of "severely impaired" Q2 results due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The Israel-based firm expects limited revenues from its inclusion mapping service centers in Israel and Moscow, and a lockdown in India's rough diamond polishing hub, which contributes to 75% of its revenue. The company aims to reduce its cash burn rate by one-third and is monitoring the overall economic conditions and consumer sentiment for future growth.

site_title: Singapore reports 931 new coronavirus cases; experts say too early to say country has turned corner
summary: Singapore reported 931 new COVID-19 cases on April 26, reversing the downward trend over the past few days, with the total number of confirmed cases reaching 13,624. The majority of new cases, 886, are work permit holders in foreign worker dormitories, while 25 cases are foreign workers not living in dorms. Experts say it's too early to say the country has turned the corner, citing the need for sustained decline in local community cases and a week of zero transmissions in the first week of May.

site_title: Mermaid Maritime takes US$8 million loan; pandemic, oil price drop expected to hit customer demand
summary: Mermaid Maritime, a Thai-based offshore services provider, has taken a US$8 million loan from the Export-Import Bank of Thailand. The company warned that the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and low oil prices may impact customer demand, particularly in the Middle East market. A default event will occur if controlling shareholder Thoresen Thai Agencies' shareholding falls below 33%. Mermaid has invoked a force majeure claim on a customer contract due to virus-related restrictions and expects to release further announcements on its business operations.

site_title: Bank property sales, new retail complexes among Indonesia real estate market opportunities
summary: Indonesian banks may start selling off real estate in May due to distress in the pandemic-hit market. Property market analyst Steve Atherton of Colliers notes that bank-owned properties and loan portfolios will be available at discounted prices. Weaker rupiah is seen as a discount-buying opportunity for foreign capital. Additionally, "power centre retail concepts" are emerging as a market opportunity, with big box retailers potentially forming traditional retail centers despite lower demand for office and retail space.

images.alt_text: A public park in downtown Jakarta.

site_title: Tritech Group to take automatic extension and release full-year results by July 30
summary: Tritech Group, a Singapore-based engineering and environmental services provider, has agreed to release its full-year financial statements by July 30 after taking a two-month extension from the Singapore Exchange. The extension was sought due to the challenges in preparing the financial year-end report due to COVID-19 measures. The annual report will be issued by September 6, and the annual general meeting will be held by September 28. The company has withdrawn its earlier application for more time to release its unaudited full-year results.

site_title: OCBC Bank releases plan for virtual AGM on May 18
summary: OCBC Bank has announced that its annual general meeting (AGM) will be held virtually on May 18 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Shareholders must pre-register by May 15 for live audio-visual or audio-only broadcasts, providing their full names, addresses, and share details. The meeting will not allow in-person attendance, and shareholders can only vote by proxy. A final dividend of S$0.28 per share will be paid on June 5 if approved.

site_title: Nearly 21m workers face job losses as pandemic shreds Asean-6 economies
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is expected to cause a sharp spike in joblessness in Southeast Asia, with approximately 20.7 million jobs potentially lost in the Asean-6 economies. Indonesia, Vietnam, the Philippines, and Thailand are at high risk, with Indonesia facing 9.4 million job losses. The region's labor market is expected to be severely impacted, particularly in services sectors such as accommodation and retail trade. Governments in the region are rolling out fiscal support packages, but more targeted relief is needed to mitigate the economic impact.

site_title: 618 new Covid-19 cases, taking total to 12,693
summary: Singapore reported 618 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 12,693, with migrant workers in dormitories making up the majority of new cases. The daily number of cases has fallen below 1,000 for the first time in five days. 3% of migrant workers have tested positive, highlighting concerns over their living conditions. 952 patients have fully recovered and 12 have died of complications due to Covid-19, while four have died from other causes.

site_title: Mirach Energy granted AGM extension on hold-up in audit of Malaysian unit
summary: Mirach Energy has received an extension for its FY2019 annual report and annual general meeting due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company, which had initially planned to release its report by April 15 and hold its meeting by April 15, has now been granted a waiver by the bourse operator. The new deadlines for the annual report and meeting are May 15 and June 29, respectively. The extension was granted due to audit delays caused by the pandemic, which affected the company's principal subsidiary in Malaysia.

site_title: Some US companies will keep small business loans, defying backlash
summary: US companies receiving Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loans, worth hundreds of millions of dollars, plan to keep the funding despite Treasury Department updates and calls for repayment. The loans support small businesses with 500 or fewer employees. Some companies have already started returning the aid, but others, including those with hundreds of millions of dollars, claim they don't need the funds. The Treasury Department's updated eligibility criteria aims to target only those companies that truly need the aid.

site_title: Proxy advisers recommend Boeing shareholders vote against key board members
summary: Two proxy advisers, Glass Lewis and ISS, recommend Boeing shareholders vote against key board members due to the company's handling of the 737 Max crisis. Glass Lewis specifically recommends voting against Larry Kellner, the chairman of the board who oversaw the audit committee, citing the committee's failure to mitigate risk. The recommendations come ahead of Boeing's annual meeting on April 27.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange reported a dramatic decline in Capesize market voyage rates due to falling fuel costs. In contrast, the London Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event, while also expanding its robotaxi services to California and Arizona. FedEx partnered with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas. Delta Air Lines offered an upbeat outlook on travel demand, and Japan's carmakers reduced export prices to the US to offset tariff impacts.

site_title: Amazon asks workers staying at home to return or seek leave
summary: Amazon is asking warehouse employees who stayed away from work during the pandemic to return for scheduled shifts starting May 1, or request a leave of absence. The company had previously offered unpaid time off without penalty and $2-an-hour hazard pay for workers who report for duty. Amazon is extending its hazard pay through May 16 and providing flexibility with leave options, including Covid-19 circumstances, for part-time and full-time employees.

site_title: Oxley unit, former contractor in dispute over The Peak project
summary: Oxley Gem (Cambodia), a unit of Singapore's Oxley Holdings, has initiated legal proceedings against its former contractor, Sino Great Wall Engineering Co (SGW), over a dispute related to the The Peak project in Cambodia. Oxley Gem claims SGW breached its obligations, causing significant delays, and is seeking compensation. SGW, a unit of debt-ridden Sino Great Wall, is counter-suing for outstanding payment and compensation. The dispute involves two performance bonds and the termination of the contract in October 2019.

site_title: S&P downgrades Greece outlook on coronavirus fears
summary: Standard & Poor's downgraded Greece's outlook to stable due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on its economy, forecasting a 9% contraction in 2020. The agency maintained the country's credit rating, citing an expected rebound in 2021. This follows Moody's downgrade of Greece's banks to stable last week, and Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis' warning of a "deep" recession. The downgrade reflects Greece's vulnerability to economic crisis and its reliance on tourism and foreign investment.

site_title: OKP Holdings to keep an eye on share buybacks as Covid-19 delays construction works
summary: Construction group OKP Holdings has delayed project timelines and construction activities due to the coronavirus pandemic. The company expects to incur an adverse financial impact, but will continue to monitor its share price and exercise prudence when it comes to share buybacks. OKP has closed its showflat for The Essence and plans to launch Phoenix Heights in the second half of 2020, depending on market conditions. The company will explore alternative marketing strategies and prepare to recommence full business operations after the circuit-breaker measures are lifted.

site_title: Inactive Serial System unit to be sold for US$1 to joint-venture partner
summary: Serial System's inactive subsidiary, Serial Microelectronics (HK), will be sold to a joint-venture partner for US$1 in cash. The sale is a result of arm's-length negotiations that took into account the group's inactive status and financial position. The deal has a net loss of approximately US$2,000 for Serial System. The sale does not have a material impact on the group's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2020.

site_title: China orders TikTok owner ByteDance to remove office app
summary: Chinese regulators ordered ByteDance to temporarily suspend downloads of its office app Feishu from major domestic app stores for about a month due to content from banned sites like Facebook and Twitter. The decision comes as Feishu gained popularity during the pandemic as a work-from-home alternative and was intended to spearhead ByteDance's foray into the enterprise software market. The move deals a blow to ByteDance's ambitions and highlights the challenges of expanding into new markets.

site_title: Nam Cheong to hold AGM by June 29 after two-month deadline extension
summary: Malaysia-based shipbuilder Nam Cheong has secured a two-month extension for its annual report and annual general meeting, which will now be held by June 29. The company cited disruptions from the novel coronavirus pandemic and the impact of a prolonged movement control order on its operations. The annual report, originally due by April 15, will be released by April 29. Nam Cheong faces "immense challenges" in completing the report, including working from home and a global oil price rout. The company assures it will not be in contravention of laws and regulations.

site_title: Virus-hit Madame Tussauds owner raises 500m euros in bond sale
summary: Merlin Entertainments, the owner of Madame Tussauds and Legoland parks, raised 500 million euros (US$540 million) via a five-year bond with a 7% yield to secure funds during the coronavirus pandemic. The company, which has 130 venues, is currently operating only nine of them and faces a liquidity crisis. The bond sale, which was increased from an initial 400 million euros, has a higher yield than a similar bond sold by Merlin last October. Ratings agency S&P downgraded the company to junk territory, but investors still bought into the bonds, likely due to the risk premium on European junk bonds being at its highest since the eurozone debt crisis.

site_title: Getting into a twist over pump prices
summary: Petrol prices in the Asia-Pacific region remain volatile despite a decline in global crude oil prices. The benchmark Brent is currently between US$19 and US$26, down from US$68 in January. Consumers respond strongly to changes in fuel prices, with a call for pump prices to be adjusted downwards ringing out despite the price drop. Experts attribute this to the emotional connection consumers have with fuel prices, with the price fluctuations affecting daily lives and driving consumer angst.

site_title: US weighs taking equity stakes in US energy companies, says Mnuchin
summary: The US government is considering taking equity stakes in US energy companies to help the nation's oil and gas sector amid the coronavirus outbreak. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that the federal government is exploring alternatives, including buying fuel and purchasing airline tickets in advance. President Donald Trump expressed a desire to help the industry, and the move is seen as a response to the sector's struggles during the pandemic.

site_title: AT&T names John Stankey CEO as Randall Stephenson plans to retire
summary: AT&T names John Stankey as its new CEO, replacing Randall L. Stephenson who plans to retire. Stankey, 57, will take over on July 1, having previously led the company's operations and oversaw its media and entertainment divisions. Stephenson, 60, will remain executive chairman until the end of the year. Stankey's appointment was announced after Elliott Management, a major hedge fund, backed his leadership, following criticism of his strategy. The decision was made earlier than planned, with the board concluding its search for a new CEO.

site_title: Court approves record US$5b fine of Facebook over privacy
summary: US regulators have approved a record $5 billion fine for Facebook over data privacy, following a settlement with the US Federal Trade Commission. The deal requires Facebook to implement enhanced privacy protections, provide detailed quarterly reports, and establish an independent oversight board. The fine is the largest monetary penalty obtained by a consumer protection agency. Critics had argued the settlement was too lenient, but Facebook says it will "consider privacy at every stage of its operations" and prioritize transparency and accountability.

site_title: Li Ka-shing's CK Asset furloughs most staff at UK pub chain
summary: Billionaire Li Ka-shing's real-estate company, CK Asset Holdings, has furloughed over 95% of staff at UK pub operator Greene King due to the UK's pub closure order. Greene King, which has 38,000 employees across England, Scotland, and Wales, was acquired by CK Asset in 2019 for $3.3 billion. The closure was prompted by UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's order to close businesses like bars and restaurants.

site_title: Singapore private home prices to tumble, question is by how much?
summary: Singapore private home prices are expected to drop in the second half of the year, with larger price drops seen in more expensive homes. According to the Urban Redevelopment Authority, prices in the core central region fell 2.2% in Q1, while the rest of central region and outside central region saw smaller declines. While prices fell only 1% in Q1 overall, sharper price drops are anticipated for the rest of the year, with the magnitude varying depending on the location and property type.

site_title: More companies may need to cut dividends on Covid-19 uncertainty
summary: Companies may need to cut or suspend dividend payouts due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, as market-watchers predict a shift towards conserving cash. The current economic landscape, characterized by uncertainty, may force firms to prioritize cash reserves over dividend payments. As a result, some companies may need to reassess their dividend strategies to ensure financial stability. This trend is expected to continue as the pandemic continues to affect global markets.

site_title: Oil rises, but ends wild week lower as coronavirus slashes fuel demand
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday, ending a week of losses, as global production cuts struggled to keep pace with demand destruction caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Brent futures rose 0.5% to $21.44 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 2.7% to $16.94, despite a volatile week marked by negative pricing. Traders expect demand to remain short of supply for months, and producers may need to take further production cuts to support prices.

site_title: US SEC names former Goldman Sachs exec as adviser to coronavirus taskforce
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has appointed Sumit Rajpal, a former Goldman Sachs executive, as a senior adviser to its coronavirus taskforce. Rajpal, who retired from Goldman in February, will contribute his market knowledge and skills to the financial watchdog. The SEC's temporary Covid-19 Market Monitoring Group aims to direct agency actions and analysis related to the effects of the pandemic on markets, issuers, and investors. This move is seen as an effort to expand the agency's ongoing assessment and response to the market effects of the coronavirus.

site_title: 897 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, taking total to 12,075
summary: Singapore reported 897 new Covid-19 cases as of Friday, bringing the total to 12,075. The majority of the new cases are still unvaccinated individuals, with 13 new cases among Singaporeans and permanent residents.

site_title: Reits (April 25-26, 2020)
summary: Reits (April 25-26, 2020) reported high-yielding real estate investment trusts. This article is not related to the previous article but appears to be part of a larger publication.

site_title: Deal falls through for Hin Leong founder's GCB
summary: The sale of a good-class bungalow in Singapore belonging to Lim Oon Kuin, founder of failed oil trading giant Hin Leong Trading, has fallen through due to a caveat lodged for S$27 million. The bungalow, valued at S$1,352 per square foot, was aborted after Lim's lawyers confirmed the transaction was not carried out. This comes as Hin Leong Trading has withdrawn a debt moratorium application and intends to go into judicial management amid ongoing police investigations into the company.

site_title: Airbnb booking data from China offers glimpse of a rebound
summary: Airbnb's booking data from China shows a significant rebound in the first half of April, with domestic bookings increasing by over 200% compared to the same period in March. In 10 major Chinese cities, bookings rose by nearly 80% in the week of April 13 compared to the week of March 16. This trend is attributed to the recovery of China from the coronavirus outbreak, which is being closely watched as an indicator for other countries. The daily average rate in China from May onward is similar to 2019 levels, suggesting a strong demand for short-term rentals.

site_title: FCC may halt US ops of three state-controlled Chinese telco firms
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) may shut down operations of three state-controlled Chinese telecommunications companies, citing national security risks. The FCC issued show cause orders to China Telecom Americas, China Unicom Americas, Pacific Networks Corp, and ComNet (USA) LLC, directing them to explain why their US operations should not be revoked. The FCC granted approvals more than a decade ago, but national security risks have grown significantly due to the Chinese government's involvement in computer intrusions and attacks. The FCC's action is part of President Trump's administration's hard line toward China.

site_title: Business booming for smaller online grocers as virus drives demand
summary: Smaller online grocery providers in Singapore have seen a surge in demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with some platforms experiencing a 50% increase in business in recent weeks. Several platforms, including MarketFresh, OpenTaste, and Hao Essential Goods Store, have had to close off orders temporarily due to overwhelming demand. These platforms offer alternative options to traditional supermarket chains, which have struggled with delivery slot issues. The sudden boom in demand has allowed smaller players to capitalize on the situation and expand their services.

site_title: Found8 offers members 30% off fees for 3 months amid Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Found8, a co-working operator in Singapore, is offering 30% off fees for its members from May to July amid the Covid-19 outbreak. This move aims to support its 1,000 members, who are facing extended circuit-breaker measures. Found8 is taking on the bulk of the responsibility for providing relief, with co-founder Grace Sai stating that the company has only received rebates from some landlords. The decision tests the value system of co-working operators and their commitment to member-centricity.

site_title: Apple, Google say users to control virus 'tracing' tool
summary: Apple and Google have developed a coronavirus "contact tracing" technology that allows smartphone users to control their own data, including location and identities. Users can choose to turn on the technology and opt-in to sharing data with public health authorities. The system will be shut down after the pandemic ends, and data will be stored on individual devices, not on government servers. Public health authorities will have access to "beacons" provided by users confirmed as positive for the virus, only if they have opted in.

site_title: Tycoon running 500 hotels says virus crisis is worst he's seen
summary: Tycoon Bill Heinecke, founder of Minor International, describes the current pandemic as the worst crisis he's faced in his decades-long career in the hospitality industry. The group has furloughed thousands of workers and temporarily closed over 530 properties across the Asia-Pacific, Middle East, Africa, Europe, and the Americas. Many hotels have been repurposed as hospitals. Heinecke believes the travel industry will undergo significant changes but won't disappear, calling the current situation a "depression" rather than an economic recession.

site_title: We need great leadership now, and here's what it looks like
summary: Leadership is crucial now, with a global crisis testing leaders at all levels. Trust, values, and principles are essential for effective leadership, and those who prioritize these qualities will be remembered. Great leaders trust people with the truth and make hard decisions guided by values, not just politics or profits. Humility, hope, and transparency are also key, as leaders must navigate uncertainty and inspire collaboration. Those who pivot towards a more human-centered approach, prioritizing people and society, will earn enduring respect and support.

site_title: Google's real estate pause shows cracks in tech office demand
summary: Google has paused its real estate expansion plans, walking away from office leases and deals in Silicon Valley, San Francisco, and Seattle. This move signals a slowdown in tech office demand, prompting landlords and brokers to reassess their strategies. The pullback comes as the company slows its hiring amid the coronavirus pandemic, leaving the real estate world bracing for a broader retreat by technology companies. This shift may lead to a decrease in office leasing activity and redevelopment plans in major US cities.

images.alt_text: A plan to buy a Silicon Valley campus. An office lease on San Francisco's waterfront. Space at a building in the heart of Seattle's tech hub.

site_title: Pandemic could fuel demand for 'diaspora bonds', says World Bank
summary: The World Bank suggests that the COVID-19 pandemic could boost demand for "diaspora bonds," allowing migrants to invest in their home countries. This could generate $50 billion annually, offsetting a 37% decline in foreign direct investment. However, experts are skeptical, citing the economic downturn and job losses affecting many migrants. The World Bank has previously worked with countries like Nigeria and India on diaspora bond issues, and potential issuers include Ethiopia, Somalia, and Kenya. The success of diaspora bonds depends on careful structuring and allowing early withdrawal.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide as EU stimulus fails to impress
summary: European stock markets declined 1.1% on Friday, adding to weekly losses of 1.2%, due to investor disappointment over the lack of details in a trillion-euro emergency fund. EU leaders approved a 500 billion euro rescue package but left details for a summer. The Stoxx 600 index snapped a two-week winning streak.

site_title: China cuts medium-term lending facility rate by 20 basis points amid pandemic
summary: China's central bank cut the interest rate on its medium-term lending facility (TMLF) by 20 basis points to 2.95% to support the economy amid the pandemic. The move injects 56.1 billion yuan into the economy. Analysts expect additional easing measures in the coming months due to the struggling economy, which shrank 6.8% in January-March from the same period last year.

site_title: The lucrative takeovers that changed EPL history
summary: A Saudi-backed consortium is close to completing a £300 million takeover of Newcastle United, potentially turning the team into a major English Premier League powerhouse. This takeover follows the lucrative deals that transformed other EPL teams, such as Manchester City, Chelsea, and Blackburn, into dominant forces. These takeovers brought in significant investment, leading to the signing of top stars, appointment of renowned managers, and ultimately, multiple league titles and domestic trebles.

site_title: Trump signs huge new economic relief spending package
summary: President Donald Trump signed a nearly $483 billion economic relief package to combat the coronavirus shutdown's effects. The majority of the funds will go to small businesses, following a $2.2 trillion rescue fund enacted in March. The move comes as 4.4 million workers filed new jobless claims, bringing the total to 26.4 million since mid-March. The package aims to provide relief to the US economy, which has been severely impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Micro-Mechanics' Q3 net profit jumps 48.1% despite Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Micro-Mechanics reported a 48.1% jump in net profit to S$3.9 million for the third quarter ended March 31, 2020, driven by a 12.9% increase in revenue to S$16.2 million. Despite the Covid-19 outbreak, the company's high-precision tools and parts for the semiconductor industry saw a significant rise in sales. This increase was attributed to the company's resilience and adaptability in the face of the pandemic.

site_title: Dyson says UK government no longer requires its ventilators
summary: Dyson, the UK-based company founded by James Dyson, announced it will no longer supply the UK government with its ventilator prototype, CoVent, due to a lack of demand. The company had invested £20 million in the project and won't seek government funding. This decision comes amid shortages of medical equipment and logistical issues affecting the UK's response to the COVID-19 crisis, which is expected to surpass 20,000 fatalities this weekend. Dyson hopes the ventilator may still be useful in other countries.

site_title: Pharma boosts March factory output but economic impact may be limited: analysts
summary: Singapore's factory output rebounded 16.5% year-over-year in March, driven by a surge in pharmaceutical production, exceeding private-sector economists' expectations of a 4.9% contraction. Biomedical manufacturing grew 91.4% and pharmaceuticals 126.6% in March. However, excluding the volatile biomedical sector, total manufacturing output remained unchanged. The boost is seen as limited, with economists noting the biomedical cluster has weak inter-industry linkages and the main drag on the economy is services, which accounts for two-thirds of the economy.

site_title: S$20m package to help tourism sector prepare for recovery after virus hit
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has launched a S$20 million Marketing Partnership Programme to support the tourism industry's recovery after the COVID-19 pandemic. The programme will fund marketing costs for tourism businesses and provide training and digital tools to enhance their offerings. The initiative aims to encourage collaboration among tourism players to create unique experiences for visitors.

site_title: Facebook takes aim at Zoom with video chat upgrade
summary: Facebook has launched "Messenger Rooms," a new video chat service with virtual "rooms" that allow up to 50 friends to join and linger, targeting users turning to Zoom during the pandemic. The feature, available on Facebook Messenger, is designed for socializing with friends and family, with features like augmented-reality effects and immersive fake backgrounds. Unlike Zoom, Messenger Rooms doesn't require a Facebook account, and users can create rooms and invite friends without needing to download the app. The feature is expected to be available to Facebook's 2.5 billion users in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: Facebook on Friday unveiled a new video chat service with virtual "rooms" where people can pop in to visit friends, aiming at users turning to the popular Zoom platform during the pandemic.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality's hotel managers issue default notices to sponsor; FTI hired for restructuring
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has issued default notices to its master lessees for 16 of its 18 hotels due to insufficient working capital and failure to pay management fees and operating expenses. Wells Fargo has also issued a notice of default, demanding payment of a US$35m mortgage. The trust's sponsor, Urban Commons, has hired FTI for restructuring. The defaults are a result of the master lessees' inability to meet operational requirements, highlighting concerns over the trust's financial stability.

site_title: Bitcoin jumps to highest since March
summary: Bitcoin surged 9.1% to reach $7,556, its highest price since March 2020, driven by a shift in risk sentiment and retail interest. The token is nearing its recent trading range's top and could break above $8,000 with enough momentum. Analysts attribute the surge to the widening coronavirus pandemic's impact on financial markets and the growing use of cryptocurrencies as a hedge against currency wars. A break above $8,000 could signal a run higher, while a drop could take it to $6,500.

site_title: Does a paid research service constitute unfair dealing?
summary: A paid research service may not constitute unfair dealing if it provides fair opportunities to act for all clients, despite differences in service levels. The Fair Dealing Standard requires investment professionals to treat all clients fairly and objectively, even if some receive premium services for a fee. Companies must disclose differing service levels and ensure they do not disadvantage other clients. A case study illustrates that disseminating information in a fair manner, such as sending monthly reports to all clients, can satisfy the Fair Dealing Standard, even if some clients pay for additional services.

site_title: New-home sales in the US tumble in March
summary: US new-home sales plummeted 15.4% in March to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 627,000 units, the largest decline in over 6½ years. The drop was largely attributed to the novel coronavirus outbreak, which battered the economy and threw millions out of work. This decline follows February's sales pace revision down to 741,000 units, and new-home sales are expected to continue to decline due to historic unemployment and faltering consumer confidence.

site_title: Unions denounce Las Vegas mayor's call to reopen casinos
summary: Las Vegas Mayor Carolyn Goodman's call to reopen casinos despite the ongoing coronavirus risk has drawn criticism from unions, including the United Auto Workers and the Culinary Workers union. The unions argue that reopening casinos would put workers' lives at risk, particularly with nearly a dozen deaths already reported. The unions are urging politicians to denounce Goodman's remarks, which they deem "irresponsible" and "betray a profound level of ignorance" of the current situation. Goodman's city faces a possible $150 million budget deficit due to lost revenue from coronavirus-related closures.

images.alt_text: The powerful United Auto Workers union on Friday criticised Las Vegas Mayor Carolyn Goodman's call to reopen casinos despite the continued risk of coronavirus, the latest labour organisation to weigh in on her remarks.

site_title: S&P affirms UK credit rating, cites government's coronavirus response
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) has reaffirmed the UK's credit rating at AA, citing the government's swift response to the coronavirus outbreak. The rating remains unchanged despite a likely rise in the fiscal deficit to 14% of economic output. S&P praised the government's fiscal and monetary flexibility, as well as the country's ability to issue its own currency and long-term debt. The UK's economy is expected to contract by 6.5% this year, a slight downgrade from consensus estimates.

images.alt_text: Ratings agency Standard & Poor's left Britain's credit rating unchanged on Friday, citing a swift response from authorities in limiting the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: UK govt to void commercial landlords' eviction of tenants
summary: The UK government has announced it will void eviction attempts against small retailers and businesses due to non-payment of rent during the COVID-19 pandemic. This move comes as commercial landlords face a significant decline in rents, with the overall rent collection for the March quarter falling by 28.7% in the UK. Top retailers such as JD Sports and Primark have refused to pay their March quarter rents, prompting the government to intervene. The government aims to encourage landlords and tenants to work together and provide support to those struggling financially.

site_title: Biggest oil ETF 'almost unanalysable' after ditching disclosures
summary: The US Oil Fund (USO), the largest exchange-traded fund tracking oil, has become increasingly complex due to its suspended share issuance and changes in its holdings, making it difficult to predict its performance. Despite this, retail investors continue to buy into the fund, attracted by its potential to profit from oil's recovery. The fund's premium has widened to over 36% due to disrupted arbitrage trades, and short sellers face high borrowing costs, making it a risky proposition. USO's holdings are subject to frequent changes, making it challenging to analyze its direction.

site_title: An investor guide to spotting 'greenwashers'
summary: Investors can spot "greenwashers" by looking for ambitious long-term goals, achievable interim targets, and a focus on real emissions reduction rather than relying on offsets. Companies with a low carbon footprint in emission-intensive industries, such as financial services or aluminium production, may have a competitive advantage. Investors should also analyze a company's research and development spending, board level commitment, and capital allocation decisions to assess their ability to manage emissions exposure and develop a true competitive advantage.

site_title: HC Surgical raised stake in surgeon's practice despite SMC complaint
summary: HC Surgical Specialists (HCSS) acquired an additional 19% stake in surgeon Julian Ong's private practice, Julian Ong Endoscopy & Surgery (JOES), for S$3.8 million despite a complaint filed by a woman alleging Dr Ong and another specialist had colluded with vulnerable female patients. The complaint was filed with the Singapore Medical Council (SMC) in 2018 and was later lost by Dr Ong in a defamation lawsuit. HCSS said it had safeguards in place, including the option to repurchase its shareholdings if Dr Ong's employment is terminated, and will allow due process to run its course.

site_title: Gold bars flying 17,700 km to New York to ease supply squeeze
summary: Australia's Perth Mint has increased production of one kilogram gold bars to ease the US supply squeeze, with 6,800kg produced weekly. The move comes as air travel disruptions and virus-related issues have tightened gold availability, causing a premium surge to over US$70 in March. The mint expects elevated demand to be short-term, and production is being supplemented by new contracts with North American and West African gold producers. The facility continues to see strong retail demand for precious metals products.

site_title: HDB resale, rental volumes down in Q1; prices stagnant
summary: HDB resale and rental volumes in Singapore declined in Q1 2020, with resale flat transactions falling 7% to 5,893 units, and rental applications dropping 4% to 11,591 cases. Despite this, resale flat prices remained stagnant, with median prices ranging from S$815,000 to S$852,500. Experts attribute the decline to the circuit breaker measures and economic uncertainties brought by the pandemic, but predict a potential rebound in the resale market after the outbreak subsides.

site_title: Gold turns higher as safe-haven buying returns
summary: Gold prices rose as safe-haven buying returned, driven by expectations of additional stimulus measures from central banks and governments. Despite a brief decline after US President Trump's reopening guidelines, gold futures rebounded to new weekly highs, boosted by European ministers' comments on stimulus measures and a Bank of America report predicting a $3,000 gold price next year. Geopolitical risk in the Middle East and ongoing COVID-19 cases also supported gold prices.

site_title: SPH provides operational updates amid Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has released an operational update amid the Covid-19 pandemic, as requested by the Singapore Exchange Regulation column. SPH CEO Ng Yat Chung stated that the company is providing updates to shareholders to keep them informed. This move comes as the company navigates the fluid situation, but no specific details on the updates or their impact are provided.

site_title: Japan tilts at self-sufficiency windmill
summary: Japan is taking steps towards self-sufficiency by offering subsidies to firms to relocate production from China, following the novel coronavirus and trade wars. Face mask-maker Iris Ohyama is set to become the first Japanese company to receive a government subsidy. However, the country's efforts may be hindered by its reliance on foreign direct investment in China, a lack of spare labor, and limited immigration laws. Other countries, including Germany, France, and Canada, also face similar challenges in achieving self-sufficiency, and companies can reduce dependence on a single country by diversifying their supply chains and holding more inventory.

site_title: SGX Q3 net profit jumps 38% to 13-year high on higher volatility
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 38% jump in its fiscal Q3 net profit to a 13-year high, reaching S$137.5 million, driven by higher volatility caused by the Covid-19 pandemic and geo-political tensions. Trading activity increased across its asset classes, with revenue rising 29% to a record S$295.8 million. The company's CEO, Loh Boon Chye, expects volatility to persist, citing uncertainty around the pandemic's economic impact.

site_title: Razer launches Singapore mask production; Frasers, JustCo pitch in on shipments
summary: Razer, a gaming hardware maker, has launched an automated mask manufacturing line in Singapore, producing five million masks monthly. The facility, operational within 24 days, has been supported by Frasers Property, JustCo, and PBA Group, with other potential sponsors also expressing interest. The company has also donated one million masks to various countries and launched a US$50 million Covid-19 relief fund. Razer's mask production is set to address the lack of high-quality face masks in the market and in South-east Asia, with the facility located in an ISO 13485 certified controlled room environment.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: IReit Global appoints Louis d'Estienne d'Orves as new CEO, replacing Aymeric Thibord, effective Thursday. Tikehau Capital and City Developments Limited increase their stakes in IReit to 29.2% and 20.87%, respectively. Singtel secures S$4.17 billion in credit facilities for general corporate purposes and refinancing. Sats issues S$100 million in notes due 2025 for general corporate purposes and value-creating investments.

site_title: Tech weapons to fight the coronavirus
summary: A personalized approach to managing COVID-19 outbreaks could have reduced the severity of the pandemic by confining high-risk individuals while deconfining low-risk individuals. This approach, leveraging advanced data technologies like machine learning and AI, could have enabled faster and more effective policy decisions. By classifying individuals into high or low clinical risk groups, governments could have mitigated the need for prolonged lockdowns and minimized economic disruption. However, data availability and privacy concerns have hindered the widespread adoption of this approach, and it remains unclear whether these challenges can be overcome to inform future pandemic management strategies.

images.alt_text: Samples taken from people tested for the novel coronavirus, at a laboratory recently dedicated for the processing of Covid-19 samples at The Lighthouse Lab in Cheshire, northern England, on Wednesday.

site_title: Q1 negative net office absorption sign of worse to come
summary: Singapore's office market saw a Q1 net office absorption shrink for the first time in 12 quarters due to the Covid-19 outbreak and unresolved US-China trade tensions. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's office rental index for the central region experienced its third consecutive quarter-on-quarter correction. Analysts predict a worsening trend, with the office rent correction and negative net demand in Q1 being a sign of things to come.

images.alt_text: Islandwide, the amount of occupied office space shrank by 7,000 sq m of net lettable area (NLA) in the first quarter of 2020, contrasting with an increase of 30,000 sq m in the previous quarter. This is the first time net demand turned negative since Q1 2017.

site_title: Google and UOB unveil training courses for retail, tourism and F&B SMEs hit by Covid-19
summary: Google and United Overseas Bank (UOB) have launched new training courses for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in retail, tourism, and food and beverage, aiming to help them tackle challenges from the Covid-19 crisis. The SME Leadership Academy, which was initially set to train 400 SMEs by the end of 2020, now aims to train 4,000 by the end of 2021. The free courses are designed to support SMEs in Singapore.

site_title: Fight the virus, not each other
summary: Online vigilantes in Singapore are accusing others of flouting COVID-19 rules, sparking concerns about their motivations. Experts say some may be driven by frustration and a desire for control, while others may be genuinely trying to raise awareness. However, some reports may be baseless or intended to cause harm, highlighting the need for caution and empathy. Authorities are encouraging responsible reporting, while also acknowledging the importance of kindness and compassion during this challenging time.

site_title: China securities regulator approves trading of hog futures
summary: China's securities regulator approved the Dalian Commodity Exchange to start trading hog futures, a move expected to help manage risk in the nearly 1 trillion yuan pork market. The new futures contract was over a decade in the making, with the DCE applying for regulatory approval three years ago. The approval is seen as a significant development for the sector, allowing players to manage risk and help the sector develop.

site_title: The best free online yoga classes: an addict's picks
summary: A seasoned yogi shares their top picks for free online yoga classes, prioritizing hatha, vinyasa, stretching, and handstands. They recommend teachers like Susie Vanessa, Josh Kramer, and Adell Bridges for their clear verbal instructions, emotional cues, and modifications for various levels. The yogi also highlights international teachers, such as Celest Pereira and Morgan Rose Moroney, and local studios like Jyan Yoga Studio, Platinum Yoga, and Pure Yoga, offering a range of classes and schedules.

site_title: Razer launches mask production line in Singapore
summary: Razer has launched a mask production line in Singapore, capable of producing 5 million masks monthly. The facility, operational within 24 days, exceeds the initial target of 2 million masks. The masks are manufactured in an ISO13485-certified controlled room environment, addressing the lack of high-quality masks in the market. Razer has already donated 1 million masks to several countries, and its fintech unit has launched a US$50 million Covid-19 relief fund.

site_title: Who's making Hong Kong's ubiquitous face masks? Prisoners, among others
summary: Hong Kong residents, fearing the deadly Sars outbreak, have relied heavily on face masks since the Covid-19 pandemic began. Despite the city's low death toll of four, millions of surgical masks are produced by prisoners, who work late nights for low pay. This practice highlights the often-overlooked labor force behind the pandemic's protective measures.

site_title: US dollar snaps four days of gains, but outlook bright
summary: The US dollar ended a four-day winning streak, but remains set for its biggest weekly rise since early April. The euro initially weakened 0.4% against the US dollar following a European Union meeting that failed to deliver a surprise positive outcome, despite agreeing to a trillion-euro emergency fund. The euro subsequently erased losses and edged into positive territory, with investors remaining cautious due to ongoing EU disagreements. Oil prices stabilized after a historic collapse, reducing the dollar's safe-haven appeal.

site_title: Indonesia puts capital relocation on hold, shifts spending to fight virus
summary: Indonesia's capital relocation project has been put on hold due to the coronavirus outbreak. The $33 billion project, which aims to move the capital from Java to Borneo, will not receive new funding this year. Instead, the government is reallocating funds to focus on healthcare and welfare. A tender for the new city's masterplan is still underway, with plans to begin construction in 2024. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati has shifted state spending to prioritize the pandemic response.

site_title: HDB resale and rental volumes down, prices stagnant amid Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Resale and rental volumes of HDB flats in Singapore declined 7% in the first quarter of 2020 due to the Covid-19 outbreak. Resale flat transactions fell from 6,339 to 5,893, while rental applications decreased by 4%. Prices remained stagnant, with median resale prices ranging from S$815,000 to S$852,500. Experts attribute the decline to the circuit breaker measures and economic uncertainties brought about by the pandemic, with some predicting a potential drop in resale volumes for the second quarter.

site_title: Singapore retail rents in central region down 2.3% in Q1: URA
summary: Singapore's central region retail rents declined 2.3% in Q1 2020, following two consecutive quarters of increases, amid the COVID-19 outbreak. The decline was the largest in six years, with a 43,000 sq m decrease in occupied retail space. Retailers faced reduced foot traffic and sales, leading to cash flow constraints. Online retailers benefited, while smaller retailers saw their sales halted. The vacancy rate rose to 8% and the URA's price index for retail space in the central region shrank 3.1%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 11.79 points to 1,369.85, due to a decline in trading volume. The market saw a slight imbalance with 445 gainers versus 400 losers.

site_title: SIA responds to Sias queries on S$15b cash call
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has proposed a S$15 billion debt and equity capital raising to strengthen its balance sheet amid the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the aviation industry. The airline attributes the need for this move to the difficult environment for tapping debt capital markets. The proposed capital raising will allow SIA to treat the raised capital as equity, improving its balance sheet. The move is set to be voted on by shareholders at an extraordinary general meeting on April 30.

site_title: UK apologises after website for home coronavirus tests runs out
summary: The UK government apologized after its new website for home coronavirus tests ran out of supply within minutes of opening, with 5,000 kits snapped up in two minutes. The website, launched as part of the government's plan to expand testing, was closed due to high demand. Despite this, the health department promised more tests would be available the next day. The surge in online applications highlights the government's challenge in meeting demand for virus tests, with officials scrambling to meet a pledge to increase testing tenfold to 100,000 a day.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide as pandemic jitters return
summary: European shares fell 1.1% on Friday as pandemic jitters returned, with London's FTSE 100 down 1.3%.
