A failed clinical trial of Gilead Sciences' Covid-19 treatment and a cut to Deutsche Bank's credit rating contributed to the decline. The Stoxx 600 index also fell, with banking and healthcare sectors leading the losses. The market downturn comes amid concerns about the pandemic's economic impact and the ongoing US-EU trade talks.

images.alt_text: European shares tumbled on Friday on fears of a severe and lasting economic hit from the coronavirus pandemic after a report raised doubts about progress in developing a treatment for Covid-19.

site_title: SPH to provide updates to shareholders amid Covid-19 situation
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has released an operational update to shareholders amid the COVID-19 situation, providing key business segment updates to improve investor understanding. Digital subscriptions rose 4% in March, while its student-accommodation business in the UK remains resilient. As a retail landlord, SPH granted rental rebates to affected tenants and is considering an extension of support. The company has also refinanced an outstanding loan and secured additional credit, resulting in over S$800 million in cash balances. Updates will be released regularly to keep shareholders informed.

site_title: SIA replies to Sias questions on S$15b cash call
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is raising S$15 billion in debt and equity capital to address its liquidity and operational requirements amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The proposal includes an S$8.8 billion renounceable rights issue and up to S$6.2 billion in additional mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs). SIA cited limited traditional funding opportunities and the need to strengthen its balance sheet for the future. The capital raised will be used for operating cash flow, capital expenditure, and debt servicing, with up to S$6.2 billion available for potential future use if the crisis is prolonged.

site_title: I, Robot
summary: Tan Tingxi, chief product officer of OhmniLabs, says the current global pandemic has surged interest in the firm's telepresence robots, which allow users to remotely interact with their surroundings. Launched in 2017, OhmniLabs has deployed over 2,000 units worldwide, with applications in telemedicine, remote education, and virtual tourism. The company is expanding its production to fulfill hospital orders and is also developing robotic tools for businesses. Despite predictions of the telepresence robotics market reaching $312.6 million by 2023, OhmniLabs' CEO believes the technology will become a common feature in other devices, such as vacuum robots, and will enhance experiences like concerts and museum tours.

site_title: US: Stocks turn mixed after positive opening
summary: US stocks opened mixed on Friday, with the Dow Jones up 0.1% to 23,547.61, while the S&P 500 nearly flat at 2,798.79 and the Nasdaq down 0.2% to 8,476.30. Oil prices surged 7.3% to $17.72 a barrel, driven by tensions between the US and Iran. However, analysts warn that gains are unsustainable due to a crude supply glut and filled storage facilities. New data also showed a 14.4% decline in durable manufactured goods orders in March, largely due to industry shutdowns.

site_title: Nam Cheong reviews options, considers restructuring
summary: Nam Cheong, a Malaysia-based offshore support vessel builder, is reviewing options to realign its businesses and balance sheet amid the global oil and gas downturn and Malaysia's extended Movement Control Order. The company is considering restructuring, including extending loan maturities or seeking advisors, to address significant debt maturities and preserve value for stakeholders. No definitive agreements have been reached, and the outcome is uncertain, with a potential going-concern issue if restructuring is not completed in a timely manner.

site_title: Trump's coronavirus disinfectant comments 'dangerous', doctors say
summary: US President Donald Trump suggested scientists investigate inserting disinfectant into the bodies of people infected with Covid-19 as a way to cure the disease, sparking widespread concern among doctors and health experts. The comments were described as "absolutely dangerous" and "unscientific" by experts, who warned people not to drink or inject disinfectants. Reckitt Benckiser, the manufacturer of household disinfectants Dettol and Lysol, also issued a statement warning against ingesting or injecting its products. Trump's comments have raised concerns about the spread of misinformation and the potential for harm to public health.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump suggested scientists should investigate inserting the cleaning agent into the body as a way to cure Covid-19.

site_title: World leaders to launch WHO Covid-19 plan, but US won't take part
summary: World Health Organization (WHO) plans to launch a global initiative to accelerate Covid-19 research, including the development of safe, effective drugs, tests, and vaccines, with French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel set to participate. However, the US will not take part, with a US spokesman stating that the country will not participate in the initiative. The move comes as more than 2.7 million people have been infected with Covid-19, with nearly 190,000 lives lost, and over 100 potential vaccines are being developed.

site_title: HSBC to push on with overhaul 'wherever possible' despite crisis
summary: HSBC will proceed with its planned overhaul, reallocating capital from underperforming businesses, cutting costs, and reducing management layers, despite the coronavirus pandemic. CEO Noel Quinn has re-committed to the February strategy, pausing most redundancies to avoid disruption. The bank will report first quarter earnings on April 28, with a sharp rise in provisions against bad loans expected. HSBC has apologized to shareholders for cancelling its dividend, citing the need to maintain stability during the crisis.

images.alt_text: HSBC will press ahead with plans to reallocate capital from under-performing businesses, cut costs and strip out layers of management, despite problems caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters defy social distancing rules, vow to resume movement
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy protesters staged a small demonstration at a luxury downtown mall, defying social distancing rules and government restrictions. Around 100 people gathered, wearing masks and face coverings, to voice opposition to Beijing's tightening grip on the city. The protesters vowed to resume their movement, despite concerns about police intervention and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The gathering marked a glimpse of potential unrest to come as local cases ease, with some expressing anger over Beijing's recent statements on Hong Kong's politics.

site_title: Sale of Hin Leong Trading founder's good class bungalow falls through
summary: The sale of Lim Oon Kuin's good-class bungalow in Singapore has fallen through due to the withdrawal of the caveat. The bungalow, valued at S$27 million, was set to be sold on a 19,989 sq ft freehold site. Lim Oon Kuin, founder of debt-hit oil trader Hin Leong Trading, had previously applied for a debt moratorium but withdrew the application. He now intends to go into judicial management. Several other bungalows owned by Lim and his family are also mentioned, including those in Third Avenue, Queen Astrid Park, and Tanglin Villas.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower with virus in focus
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday, down 0.9% or 167.44 points, amid a mixed close on Wall Street and news on an apparently failed coronavirus drug test. The Nikkei 225 index ended at 19,262.00, while the Topix index fell to 1,421.29. The mixed global market performance contributed to the decline in Tokyo's stock market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish week lower on persistent virus worries
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed the week lower, down 0.6% to 23,831.33, amid concerns over Covid-19 treatment progress and US economic damage. Corporate earnings were worse than expected, and investors are awaiting China's fiscal and monetary policies to boost domestic demand. China's central bank cut interest rates, and the government announced subsidies for electric vehicles and tax exemptions on purchases for two years. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record-low US business activity report.

site_title: S$20m marketing fund among new STB support schemes amid Covid-19
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has launched new support schemes to aid the tourism industry amid the Covid-19 pandemic. A $20 million Marketing Partnership Programme will fund marketing costs for tourism businesses, with increased support for collaborations and digital transformation. The STB also established a $2 million SG Stories Content Fund for local creators, and is developing digital tools, including a Tourism Transformation Index and a Singapore Tourism Analytics Network. Additionally, the STB has reduced regulatory compliance costs for travel agents and is offering training and innovation programs to support the industry's recovery.

site_title: Korean Air to get up to 1.2t won support from state-owned banks
summary: South Korea's state-owned banks will provide up to 1.2 trillion won (S$1.38 million) in liquidity to Korean Air Lines Co. amid the coronavirus crisis, which has severely impacted the aviation industry. This move follows the provision of 1.7 trillion won to Asiana Airlines and comes as the country's transport ministry and financial regulator announced a 300 billion won liquidity extension to domestic budget carriers in February. The support aims to help Korean Air overcome operational difficulties resulting from the pandemic.

site_title: STI closes 0.95% lower, down 3.69% for the week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.95% on Friday, closing at 2.518.16 points, and finished the week down 3.69% due to dimmed economic reopening prospects. Despite a surprise surge in Singapore's manufacturing sector, the impact of Covid-19 will be felt more keenly in April. Losers outnumbered gainers 259 to 158, with Hotel Royal being the top gainer and Jardine Matheson the top loser. Regional markets were also downbeat, with declines in the Hang Seng, KLSE, Nikkei, and Shanghai Composite.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher but posts first weekly loss in April
summary: Australia's benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.5% higher at 5,242.6 on Friday, despite posting its first weekly loss this month. The energy space led gains, rising 2% on a rebound in oil prices, while healthcare stocks rose 1.7%. The index fell 4.5% for the week, amid subdued volatility and volumes ahead of corporate earnings releases from supermarket operators and banks.

site_title: Philippines' coronavirus infections top 7,000
summary: The Philippines' Health Ministry reported 211 new coronavirus cases, 15 deaths, and 40 recoveries, bringing the total to 7,192 cases, 477 deaths, and 762 recoveries. President Rodrigo Duterte extended the strict lockdown in Manila until May 15 to contain infections. Restrictions will be eased in lower-risk regions.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end over 1% lower as recession fears mount on economic data
summary: South Korean shares fell 1.3% on Friday, marking the largest loss in over a week, due to recession fears fueled by bleak economic data from the US and Europe. The US reported 26.5 million Americans seeking unemployment benefits, wiping out the longest employment boom in US history. The won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield rose. This marks the end of a four-week winning streak for the Kospi index, which lost 1.3% for the week.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's factory output rebounded 16.5% in March due to a surge in pharmaceuticals amid the pandemic. Private home prices fell 1% in Q1, but sharper declines are expected for the rest of the year. The Singapore Tourism Board introduced new support schemes, including a $20m marketing fund. Razer launched a mask production line in Singapore. The STI fell 0.95% on Friday, down 3.69% for the week, amid dimming prospects for a world economy re-opening.

site_title: 897 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, taking total to 12,075
summary: Singapore reported 897 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 12,075. Migrant workers in dormitories account for the majority of new cases, with 982 linked to dormitories on Thursday. The number of unlinked cases in the community has decreased, with 25% of new cases on Thursday being unlinked. Globally, coronavirus cases stand at 2.7 million, with the US reporting the highest number of cases. Singapore's "circuit-breaker" measures have been extended to June 1.

site_title: Europe beats China in Q1 electric vehicle sales, study shows
summary: Europe surpassed China in Q1 electric vehicle sales, with 79,300 registrations in the first quarter of 2020, narrowly edging out China's 77,256. Europe's unit sales more than doubled compared to the first quarter of 2019, while China's sales fell by over half due to the coronavirus lockdown. However, China is expected to regain its lead as the top-selling market for electric vehicles once lockdown restrictions are lifted, with the government introducing incentives and tax breaks.

site_title: Singtel secures S$4.17b in credit facilities; SATS issues S$100m in 2.6% notes due 2025
summary: Singtel secured S$4.17 billion in credit facilities, including a S$2.5 billion revolving credit facility and S$950 million one-year facilities, for general corporate purposes and refinancing. In Australia, Optus secured A$800 million in 364-day committed facilities. The facilities are guaranteed by Singtel and Optus.

site_title: Work smart, travel alone, eat out fast: South Korea's prescription for coronavirus recovery
summary: South Korea has outlined guidelines for a post-coronavirus normality, including flexible working, public transport bookings, and quick restaurant meals. The country has seen a significant drop in cases, with just six new cases reported, the lowest since February. Authorities hope daily new cases will drop to zero in the coming days. With 10,708 recorded infections, the toll remains at 240, and the country has been a role model in containing the pandemic.

site_title: Coronavirus clouds Intel outlook, despite short-term bump from PC buying
summary: Intel Corp forecasted second-quarter earnings below Wall Street views due to costs of preparing new PC chip, Tiger Lake, and economic uncertainty caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Despite a short-term bump in demand, Intel's shares fell 6% as executives expressed uncertainty about the second half of the year. The company expects lower gross margins in the second quarter, but plans to sell the chips at high margins in the third quarter.

site_title: Biden predicts Trump will try to postpone US election
summary: US President Donald Trump is predicted by Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden to attempt to postpone the November election in an effort to win. Biden stated Trump is considering postponing the election due to the pandemic and job losses. The US Post Office emergency funding veto by Trump is seen as an attempt to make voting harder. Mail-in voting and absentee ballots could limit the spread of coronavirus, but Trump claims they create potential for fraud. The presidential election is six months away, and Biden believes Trump's path to victory will be harder than anticipated due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Micro-Mechanics Q3 net profit jumps 48.1% to S$3.9m on increased sales
summary: Micro-Mechanics, a semiconductor industry tool and parts manufacturer, reported a 48.1% increase in net profit to S$3.9 million for the third quarter of 2020, driven by robust revenue growth across its geographical markets. Revenue rose 12.9% to S$16.2 million, while earnings per share increased to 2.78 Singapore cents. No dividend was declared for the quarter. The company's balance sheet showed S$66.5 million in total assets and S$54.8 million in shareholders' equity as of March 31, 2020.

site_title: US Fed balance sheet increases to record US$6.62t
summary: The US Federal Reserve's balance sheet increased to a record $6.62 trillion, surpassing 30% of the US economy. The central bank has been using its buying power to stabilize markets amid the coronavirus pandemic, slashing interest rates and restarting bond purchases. The Fed's holdings of mortgage-backed securities rose to $1.62 trillion, while its use of liquidity swap lines and loan facilities also increased. The central bank has also taken on loans from participating banks in the Small Business Administration's "Payroll Protection Program."

site_title: Coronavirus prods Japan agencies, including data collectors, to embrace change
summary: Japan is adapting to the coronavirus pandemic by introducing changes in data collection and government agency meetings. The internal affairs ministry will rely more on phone calls to gather data, reducing human contact. This shift is similar to other economies, including the US, and aims to maintain data accuracy. Japan's government agencies have also started using technology, such as teleconferences and online briefings, to combat the pandemic. These changes reflect the country's efforts to balance social distancing measures with voluntary cooperation from citizens and businesses.

site_title: China's CCCC among firms awarded US$626m Mexican train contract
summary: The Mexican government has awarded a 15.5 billion peso (approximately $897.8 million) contract to a consortium led by China Communications Construction Company for the first phase of the "Mayan Train" project, a nearly $8 billion rail project connecting tourist hot spots in southern Mexico. The project, deemed essential infrastructure by authorities, is expected to begin construction in the next few days and will be built along an existing rail line. The winning bid was selected from 14 offers, and construction will help generate jobs in the country's poor south.

site_title: Eagle Hosp gets US$35m loan default notice; hotel managers may scrap sponsor's agreements
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has received a US$35 million loan default notice from Wells Fargo, citing non-payment of several sums due in March 2020. The lender also demanded payment in full. Meanwhile, 16 out of 18 EHT hotels have received notices of default from hotel managers due to insufficient working capital and failure to pay management fees. The EHT managers are working to preserve the value of properties and have appointed FTI Consulting to assist in the restructuring process. The stapled securities of EHT have been voluntarily suspended since March 24.

site_title: Blackstone's GSO distressed-debt bets post 30% quarterly loss
summary: Blackstone's GSO Capital Partners reported a 30.3% quarterly loss on distressed-debt investments, the company's worst performance in at least a decade. The losses were driven by the energy sector, which was a drag on returns. Despite the losses, GSO's chief operating officer, Jonathan Gray, said the firm is seeing opportunities emerging from market dislocation and is looking for businesses that are cyclically, not secularly, under pressure. The firm deployed $3 billion during the first quarter, with assets specific to distressed-debt investing totaling $7.8 billion.

site_title: Brokers are trying to keep some traders away from volatile oil futures
summary: Four brokerages are restricting traders from entering new oil futures contracts, citing unprecedented volatility and the risk of losses after oil prices plummeted to negative territory. The move aims to curb losses, particularly for smaller clients, amid concerns over crude storage capacity. The restrictions, effective for accounts under $5 million, are part of efforts to reduce risk and mitigate market volatility.

site_title: Investors flock to South Korea as wins in coronavirus battle earn reward
summary: South Korea's economy is rebounding faster than other major markets amid its successful handling of the coronavirus pandemic. The country's benchmark Kospi stock index has soared 31% from March lows, with investors betting on its ability to recover sooner and stronger than others. South Korean bonds have also seen significant inflows, attracting $3.6 billion in March, as investors seek reliable yields. Authorities' testing, contact tracing, and tracking apps have helped keep confirmed cases low, with a 1.56% yield on 10-year government debt making it an attractive trade. Despite risks, ratings agencies say South Korea is well-positioned to weather the storm.

site_title: PSA International unit prices US$650m 10-year notes at 2.25%; to be issued below par
summary: PSA International's subsidiary, PSA Treasury, will issue US$650 million worth of 10-year guaranteed notes at 99.822% below par, carrying a 2.25% annual coupon. The notes are expected to be issued on April 30, 2020, under the US$3.5 billion global medium-term note programme.

site_title: Distressed US energy debt jumped by US$11b amid oil collapse
summary: US energy debt surged to $190 billion, a $11 billion increase in less than a week, as oil prices plummeted below zero. This represents the highest level since 2008. Energy sector distressed debt includes bonds yielding at least 10 percentage points over Treasuries and loans trading for less than 80 cents on the dollar. Experts warn that if oil prices remain low, energy debt could retest recent highs, and bailouts for individual companies may not solve the underlying oversupply issue.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 12.09 points lower, or 0.88%, to 1,369.55 on Friday. The index saw 505.8 million lots traded worth RM189.44 million. Gainers beat losers 193 to 183.

site_title: Singapore factory output rebounds 16.5% in March due to surge in pharmaceuticals
summary: Singapore's factory output rebounded 16.5% in March due to a surge in biomedical manufacturing amid the COVID-19 pandemic, according to the Economic Development Board. Excluding biomedical manufacturing, output remained unchanged. Biomedical manufacturing grew 91.4% in March, driven by a 126.6% increase in pharmaceutical production, while other clusters like precision engineering, transport engineering, and chemicals also saw growth. Electronics output contracted by 9.2% year on year, while general manufacturing declined by 7.9%.

site_title: Sharper falls in Singapore private home prices a given; the question is: by how much?
summary: Singapore's private home prices fell 1% in Q1, with larger price reductions seen in the core central region. Prices in this area dropped 2.2% compared to -0.5% and -0.4% in the rest of central region and outside central region, respectively. Despite a deep recession forecasted, consultants expect a fair correction in prices this year, but not to the magnitude of the 24.9% plunge during the Global Financial Crisis. Total transaction volume in 2020 may decline by 40-50% due to the 'circuit breaker' period.

site_title: US meat giant shutters beef plant for coronavirus testing
summary: US meatpacking giant Tyson Foods has temporarily closed its massive beef slaughterhouse in Washington state to test its employees for coronavirus. The closure affects a facility that produces enough beef to feed four million people daily. Workers will receive pay while self-isolating, and the plant's reopening will depend on test results. This move comes amid concerns about the spread of the disease in slaughterhouses, with several other US plants already closed due to coronavirus outbreaks.

site_title: Tesla adds former CIO of world's largest pension fund to board
summary: Tesla has added Hiromichi Mizuno, former chief investment officer of Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund, to its board of directors. Mizuno joins as an independent director and will serve on the audit committee. His appointment aligns with Elon Musk's preferences, given his experience in Silicon Valley and environmentalism, as well as his criticism of short selling.

site_title: Mexico's Pemex declares force majeure on fuel imports from trading arm: sources
summary: Mexico's state oil company Pemex has declared force majeure on fuel imports from its trading arm PMI Comercio Internacional due to a bottleneck of tankers waiting to discharge gasoline and other refined product imports. This move comes as demand for motor fuels has declined due to coronavirus-related restrictions, and available storage is filling up. A declaration of force majeure allows Pemex to avoid liability for nonperformance, but it's unclear how this will impact fuel supplies.

site_title: Apple aims to sell Macs with its own chips starting 2021
summary: Apple plans to start selling Macs with its own main processors, codenamed Kalamata, by next year. The company is developing three systems-on-a-chip based on the A14 processor, which will be faster than Intel processors. Apple's partner, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, will build the new chips using a 5-nanometer production technique. The move aims to gain control over performance, unify its apps ecosystem, and reduce reliance on Intel. The first Mac processors will have eight high-performance cores and at least four energy-efficient cores, and may double or quadruple the number of cores provided by Intel.

site_title: Expedia names new CEO, shores up US$3.2b to fight slump
summary: Expedia Group has named new CEO Peter Kern and CFO Eric Hart, and raised approximately US$3.2 billion to shore up its finances amid the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the travel industry. The company withdrew its full-year forecast and eliminated 3,000 jobs earlier this year. Expedia shares rose 3.5% to US$63.58 following the announcement, giving the company a market value of US$8.9 billion. The company plans a US$1.2 billion private stock placement and US$2 billion in new debt financing, with Apollo Global Management and Silver Lake providing the equity investment.

site_title: Virgin Australia owes A$6.9b to creditors, to seek waiver on aircraft leases: administrator
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings owes A$6.9 billion to over 10,000 creditors, including A$1.9 billion in aircraft leases, A$2.3 billion of secured debt, and A$2 billion of unsecured bonds. The airline's administrators are seeking a three-month payment waiver from aircraft lessors due to an initial review. The waiver is needed to avoid paying leases on aircraft starting April 28, as administrators are required to inform lessors within five business days. The airline's restructuring could lead to a sale.

site_title: Google and UOB unveil training courses for retail, tourism and F&B SMEs hit by Covid-19
summary: Google and United Overseas Bank (UOB) have launched training courses for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in retail, tourism, and food and beverage sectors affected by the Covid-19 crisis. The SME Leadership Academy, which aims to train 4,000 SME business leaders by 2021, offers free training to help them accelerate digital adoption and move online. The initiative was announced as businesses face significant disruptions due to the pandemic, with Google Singapore director Ben King stating that supporting SMEs is crucial for their survival.

site_title: J&J strikes deal with Emergent BioSolutions on coronavirus vaccine manufacturing
summary: Johnson & Johnson (J&J) has struck a deal with Emergent BioSolutions to manufacture over 1 billion doses of its experimental Covid-19 vaccine candidate. The deal, valued at $135 million, is part of a global partnership to accelerate vaccine production. J&J plans to start human testing by September and aims to have the vaccine ready for emergency use authorization in early 2021. The US government and J&J are investing $1 billion to create manufacturing capacity for the vaccine.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree Logistics Trust, SGX, Sats, HC Surgical, Oxley
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported a 6.2% increase in distributable income to S$77.8 million for its fourth quarter. Singapore Exchange (SGX) saw a 38% rise in net profit to S$137.5 million. HC Surgical Specialists closed up 4% after explaining its decision not to further investigate a surgeon amid the Singapore Medical Council's findings. Oxley Holdings' subsidiary commenced formal legal proceedings against a former contractor for damages suffered due to contractual breaches. IReit Global appointed a new CEO, and Mary Chia Holdings announced a new continuing sponsor.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index losing 18.73 points or 0.7% to 2,523.64. Losers outnumbered gainers 81 to 66, with Genting Singapore and healthcare-related counters Biolidics, Clearbridge, and Medtecs International seeing significant gains. US markets closed almost flat overnight, and Tokyo stocks also opened lower.

site_title: Singapore retail rents ease 2.3% q-o-q in Q1 2020: URA
summary: Singapore's retail rents eased 2.3% quarter-over-quarter in Q1 2020, contrasting with a 2.3% increase in the previous quarter. Central region retail space prices fell 3.1%, while islandwide, occupied retail space decreased by 43,000 sq m and vacancy rates rose to 8% from 7.5% in Q4 2019. The total supply of retail space increased to 358,000 sq m, but the stock of retail space fell by 15,000 sq m.

site_title: SGX Q3 net profit rises 38% on higher revenue from all three businesses
summary: SGX posted a 38% rise in net profit to S$137.5 million for its Q3, driven by revenue increases across equities, fixed income, and data businesses. Earnings per share rose to 12.8 Singapore cents, up from 9.3 cents a year ago. The increase is attributed to higher revenue from all three businesses.

site_title: US lawmakers urge Fed to keep energy industry out of lending programme
summary: US lawmakers Senator Edward Markey and Representative Nanette Diaz Barragán have urged the Federal Reserve to reject the energy industry's request to use a $600 billion emergency lending facility to pay off debts. The lawmakers argue that it would be a "short-sighted misuse of taxpayer resources" and would only increase the financial toll of climate change. The energy industry has requested to be allowed to use the funding to repay other loan balances, but the Fed may tweak the program terms if necessary.

site_title: Singapore office rents fall 0.8% q-o-q in Q1 2020: URA
summary: Singapore office rentals fell 0.8% quarter-over-quarter in Q1 2020, a smaller decline compared to the 3.2% drop in Q4 2019. Office prices in the central region also contracted by 4% in Q1 2020, a larger drop than the 0.5% decline in the previous quarter. The total islandwide office space supply decreased to 682,000 square meters at the end of Q1 2020, lower than the previous quarter's 753,000 square meters.

site_title: Winemakers turn to Zoom tastings to survive lockdown upheaval
summary: Winemakers worldwide are adapting to the COVID-19 pandemic by turning to digital platforms like Zoom for tastings and sales. Many wineries, such as Montes Wines in Chile, are connecting with clients remotely, discussing wine flavors and performance. However, the industry faces significant challenges, including reduced consumption, job losses, and disruptions to logistics and exports. The European Union forecasts a 8% decline in wine consumption this season, and some producers may not survive the upheaval. Despite these challenges, some wineries are finding innovative ways to stay afloat, such as building direct-to-consumer sales and using social media to reach customers.

site_title: IReit Global names new CEO from unitholder Tikehau Capital
summary: IReit Global has appointed Louis d'Estienne d'Orves as its new CEO, effective Thursday. He joins from Tikehau Capital's real estate team, where he will oversee IReit's investment strategy and leverage local expertise. The appointment comes after Tikehau raised its stake in IReit to 29.2% and City Developments Limited increased its stake to 20.87%. This brings their combined stake over 50%. The previous CEO, Aymeric Thibord, quit in February to pursue other opportunities.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower with virus remaining in focus
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.5% on Friday, following a mixed close on Wall Street, amid concerns over the coronavirus and economic data. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped to 19,336.20, while the Topix index fell to 1,418.38. Authorities are closely watching the upcoming Golden Week holidays, which may lead to increased infections despite government policies. The Bank of Japan is set to announce additional monetary easing, including unlimited bond-buying, which may weigh on the market.

site_title: Clearbridge says unaware of reason for share price surge, notes Biolidics announcement
summary: Clearbridge Health's share price surged 49% to 38 Singapore cents on Thursday, before paring most gains to close at 22.5 cents. The company attributed the price movement to the announcement of Biolidics' US distributor, Aytu Bioscience, for its Covid-19 rapid test kit. Clearbridge has a 24.8% stake in Biolidics and had issued adjusted conversion shares to a convertible bond holder. The share price decline on Friday was attributed to a 8.9% drop, with shares trading at 20.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: HC Surgical says 'impractical' to further probe doctor named in SMC complaint
summary: HC Surgical Specialists (HCSS) stated that investigating surgeon Julian Ong further would be "impractical" after a complaint was filed against him in early 2019. The complaint alleged Ong and another specialist had sex with vulnerable female patients. HCSS's shares dropped after Ong lost a defamation lawsuit in April. The company will not pursue further investigation into Ong, despite a request from the Singapore Medical Council (SMC) to review the case.

images.alt_text: About 17 per cent of HC Surgical's group revenue in the half year ended Nov 30, 2019, came from Dr Ong's private practice.

site_title: MLT declares higher Q4 DPU of 2.048 Singapore cents
summary: MAPLETREE Logistics Trust (MLT) has declared a 2.048 Singapore cents DPU for Q4, up 1.2% from the previous year, with distributable income rising 6.2% to S$77.8 million. Net property income rose 9.3% to S$114.7 million, while gross revenue grew 5.5% to S$128.1 million. The Reit's assets under management increased to S$8.9 billion, with net asset value per unit rising 3.4% to S$1.21.

site_title: Snap eyes US$750m convertible bond offering in 'strategic move'
summary: Snap Inc. has launched a US$750 million convertible bond offering, dubbed a "strategic move" by CEO Evan Spiegel, to fund long-term goals, including talent acquisition and augmented reality development. The offering, led by Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase, comes after a successful earnings beat and accelerating app usage. The bonds, set to mature in May 2025, feature a hedging tool to mitigate dilution, suggesting management's bullish stance on shares. This marks the company's second convertible offering in the past year.

site_title: US Treasury mulls coronavirus loan to force Postal Service rate changes: Washington Post
summary: The US Treasury Department is considering a $10 billion emergency loan to the US Postal Service to force changes in how it operates, including package delivery fees. The loan, part of a $2 trillion stimulus package, would be used to urge changes in the Postal Service's finances. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin must approve the loan, which would be used to help the Postal Service continue service past September. The move comes after President Donald Trump accused the post office of charging too little for packages.

site_title: Insurtech startup Axinan closes Series A+ round, takes on new name
summary: Insurtech startup Axinan (now rebranded as Igloo) has raised an undisclosed sum in its Series A+ funding round led by InVent, Intouch Holdings' corporate venture capital arm. The $16 million funding brings Igloo's total funding to date. The company plans to expand into Vietnam, strengthen its presence in the Philippines and Thailand, and double its business development and engineering teams. Igloo will focus on customer acquisition, dynamic risk assessment, and expedited claims management, offering products through its insurance partners in six key markets, including South-east Asia.

site_title: UK PM Boris Johnson plans return to work as soon as Monday: Telegraph
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson plans to return to work as early as Monday to take control of the coronavirus crisis, following his discharge from a London hospital. He faces criticism for reacting too slowly to the outbreak, which has resulted in a national death toll of 18,738 and at least 184,900 global deaths. Johnson will schedule meetings with cabinet ministers to get up to speed on the crisis, as the government works to roll out a mass testing and tracking programme to reduce transmission and ease economic restrictions.

site_title: Oil rallies on faster output cuts to offset virus-induced fall-off in demand
summary: Oil prices surged on Thursday as major oil-producing nations accelerated planned production cuts to combat the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on demand. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 19.7% to $16.50, while global benchmark Brent crude rose 4.7% to $21.33. The move aims to offset the 30% decline in fuel demand worldwide in April, but analysts remain cautious, citing weak demand forecasts and the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: EU lays out trillion euro escape route from coronavirus pandemic
summary: European Union leaders agreed to create a trillion euro emergency fund to aid in post-pandemic recovery. The decision was made during a four-hour video conference, with a focus on expanding the EU's 2021-27 common budget to around 1% of the EU's economic output. The move was seen as a step towards unity amidst the pandemic, but details will be left for summer negotiations. Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte described the progress as "great."

site_title: Sculpted Blooms
summary: Florists offer online blooms despite non-essential status, with stores like Wonderland Botanicals and Far East Flora providing options. A decorative vase, the Muuto Ridge Vase, can double as a sculpted objet d'art, featuring a dent for flowers to stand upright and serving as a handle. Available from S$200, it's made of terracotta or earthenware. This design combines Nordic aesthetics with a functional purpose, enhancing any space with flowers.

site_title: Credit Suisse boosted by exceptional first quarter gains
summary: Credit Suisse recorded a 75% jump in first-quarter profits to 1.3 billion Swiss francs, its highest quarterly result in five years, thanks to exceptional gains from the transfer of a funds platform. The bank built up reserves of 1 billion francs to cope with the economic upheavals of the coronavirus crisis. CEO Thomas Gottstein attributed the success to the bank's wealth management-focused business model and its ability to leverage investment banking capabilities. The bank has granted about 14,000 loans worth 2.4 billion francs to businesses through Switzerland's bridging loan plan.

site_title: A world of spice and more
summary: Thevar and Tiffin Room offer a culinary tour of India through their delivery and takeaway menus. Thevar, a mod-Indian eatery, serves dishes inspired by its chef's family cooking and travels to India, with a focus on quirky mashups and bold flavors. Tiffin Room, a Northern Indian specialty, offers comforting curries, biryanis, and desserts. Both restaurants cater to hearty appetites and offer set menus and a la carte options, with prices ranging from S$40 to S$158.

site_title: ST Engineering's US$750m, 5-year bond a hit with investors
summary: ST Engineering's US$750 million, 5-year bond was met with strong demand from investors, receiving an order book of over US$4 billion. The bond, priced at 1.5% coupon, was oversubscribed, with funds accounting for 45% of the issue. The bond market in Asia reopened after the COVID-19 pandemic, with investors from Asia and Europe, Middle East, and Africa participating. The deal was arranged by DBS and JP Morgan, marking only the second bond deal for the company.

site_title: US: Wall Street stocks end little changed as oil prices gain
summary: US stocks ended almost flat Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 shedding 0.2% and 0.1% respectively, despite oil prices gaining 20% amid heightened US-Iran tensions. The jobless claims total rose to 26.4 million, while a closely-watched coronavirus drug developed by Gilead Sciences failed in its first clinical trial. Petroleum-linked companies rallied, while Expedia jumped 3.2% after a $3.2 billion investment.

site_title: We should get our priorities right as shareholders
summary: A letter to The Business Times questioned the timing of annual general meetings (AGMs) in Singapore, suggesting it may be a conspiracy to avoid shareholder scrutiny. However, the actual reason is likely due to the busy management schedules of companies in the four months leading up to the AGM. The writer's letter failed to acknowledge this, instead attributing the issue to a conspiracy. This highlights the need for better understanding of the complexities involved in company operations and AGM scheduling.

site_title: Oxley unit starts legal proceedings against ex-contractor of Cambodia project
summary: Oxley Holdings' subsidiary, Oxley Gem (Cambodia), initiated legal proceedings against Sino Great Wall Engineering (SGW) in Singapore on April 1. SGW, the main contractor for The Peak project in Cambodia, is being sued for damages due to repeated breaches of its contractual obligations. Oxley Holdings is seeking compensation from SGW for the damages suffered. The case is related to a 55-storey mixed hotel development project in Cambodia, and the outcome will determine the extent of Oxley Holdings' losses.

site_title: Singapore private home prices fall 1% in Q1 q-o-q: URA
summary: Singapore private home prices fell 1% in Q1 2020 compared to the previous quarter, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA). This contrasts with a 0.5% increase in Q4 2019 and a 2.4% year-over-year rise. Non-landed property prices declined 1% in Q1, while landed properties fell 0.9%. Rentals of private residential properties edged up 1.1% in Q1. Developers launched 2,093 uncompleted units for sale in Q1, but sold 2,149 units.

site_title: Gilead disputes report that its drug flopped in leaked coronavirus trial
summary: Gilead Sciences' experimental antiviral drug remdesivir failed to show improvement in patients with severe Covid-19 in a Chinese clinical trial, contrary to reports of its effectiveness. The trial was terminated early due to low enrollment, and Gilead disputes the findings, stating they are inconclusive. Despite this, the company's shares dropped 4.3% after the data was leaked. The trial's results do not provide robust evidence of remdesivir's effectiveness, and more clinical studies are needed to confirm its potential benefits.

site_title: FCT's Q2 DPU down 49% on bigger base, retained earnings
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a Q2 DPU of 1.61 Singapore cents, down 48.7% from last year, due to an enlarged unitholders base and reduced payout ratios amid the pandemic. The trust's decision to preserve distributable income for financial flexibility will impact revenue for the rest of FY20. The trust's manager cited the need for financial flexibility in uncertain times, with the market adjusting to lower payout ratios for Singapore Reits.

site_title: Fans dive for pearls in food and hawker stalls that also sell bubble tea
summary: In response to Singapore's partial lockdown, bubble tea stalls were deemed non-essential services, but food stalls allowed to operate saw a surge in demand for bubble tea, with orders increasing by 50% on Wednesday. To cope, many shops had to reject orders and suspend operations temporarily, affecting their stock and staff. Despite the challenges, some business owners saw an opportunity to increase sales and expand their market share. The sudden demand also highlighted the resilience of the global bubble tea market, valued at US$3.21 billion by 2023.

site_title: Treat workers fairly or lose Covid-19 support help: MOM
summary: The Manpower Ministry of Singapore has warned companies that cutting salaries or putting staff on no-pay leave during the circuit breaker period will result in lower wage subsidies under the Jobs Support Scheme. Companies found to treat workers "irresponsibly or unfairly" may lose future support and face penalties, including curtailed work-pass privileges. Employers must acknowledge their intentions to support employees via an online form to receive wage subsidies and foreign worker levy rebates. Those found guilty will face investigations and potential suspensions or denials of future support.

site_title: Europe: Oil stocks, banks drive gains; EU stimulus decision awaited
summary: European stock markets rose 0.9% on Thursday, driven by gains in oil stocks and banks, as investors await an EU stimulus decision to revive the economy. The Stoxx 600 energy index jumped 3% with Total, BP, and Royal Dutch Shell leading the charge. Despite the rally, investors remain cautious due to the ongoing coronavirus lockdowns. The EU's stimulus decision is expected to be announced soon, with markets watching closely for further signs of economic support.

images.alt_text: A rally in energy and bank shares lifted European stock markets on Thursday, while investors counted on more stimulus to revive the bloc's economy as the coronavirus-induced lockdowns brought activity to a halt in April.

site_title: The post-pandemic new order
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a significant shift in how businesses, individuals, and societies operate, with profound effects on the global economy. New trends are emerging, including increased corporate action on climate change, the rise of online vigilantism, and changes in how we work, play, and seek healthcare. These shifts will have lasting impacts on the world and economies, with companies like Ernst & Young adapting to changing client expectations and investors needing to distinguish between genuine sustainability efforts and "greenwashing".

site_title: Seniors taking to online banking; challenge is to keep them hooked post-pandemic
summary: Singaporean banks have seen a surge in online banking adoption among seniors, with OCBC recording a 20% year-on-year growth of digital users aged 60-80 in March. To maintain this shift, financial institutions must make digital banking a sustainable change, as many seniors are initially driven by short-term necessity or comfort. OCBC has rolled out initiatives such as a Chinese-language mobile app and tele-advisory services to encourage seniors to bank online. However, experts note that changing habits takes time, and rewards and incentives may not be enough to keep seniors hooked.

site_title: Q&M to invest S$3m to build Covid-19 testing business
summary: Q&M Dental Group is investing S$3 million to build a Covid-19 testing business via a joint venture with local scientist Ong Siew Hwa, founder of Acumen Research Laboratories. The joint venture, called Acumen Diagnostics, will be used to manufacture, sell, and distribute Covid-19 test kits. Q&M has already purchased 20,000 test kits and plans to work with agencies to deploy dentists to assist in testing. The company believes there is a market demand for diagnostic test kits and vaccine trials due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Expedia raising US$3.2b to weather pandemic hit
summary: Expedia Group is raising US$3.2 billion to weather the pandemic-hit travel industry. The online travel booking service will furlough workers and its top executives will forgo cash pay for the rest of the year. Senior executives will take a 25% pay cut. The company also appointed a new chief executive. These measures aim to help the company navigate the devastating slump in the travel industry linked to the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: The online travel booking service will also furlough workers, and its board and top executive will forgo cash pay for the rest of the year, Expedia Group chairman Barry Diller said in a release.

site_title: Wild swings in Biolidics' shares after news of Covid-19 test kit deal
summary: Biolidics' shares rapidly lost gains after announcing a deal with Aytu Bioscience to be the exclusive distributor of its Covid-19 rapid test kit in the US. Trading halted and resumed with a circuit breaker on the Singapore Exchange. The decision led to a significant swing in the company's shares, reversing gains accumulated in recent days.

site_title: Food supplies in cold storage causing worries about shortages
summary: US meat facilities have shut down, causing concerns about meat shortages. Seven major facilities have halted operations in a few weeks, including Tyson Foods and JBS SA, the world's top meat producer. The US government's monthly figures show that combined pork, beef, and poultry supplies in cold storage now equal two weeks of total American meat production, raising the potential for deficits. Meat prices are surging due to the disruptions, and farmers are facing reduced payment for their animals, potentially leading to euthanized pigs.

site_title: Vonovia makes second attempt to acquire rival Deutsche Wohnen
summary: Vonovia, a German residential property heavyweight, is considering its second attempt to acquire rival Deutsche Wohnen in a deal valued at approximately 37 billion euros. The potential transaction would create a real estate giant and overcome political scrutiny. Vonovia is working with advisers to explore the feasibility of the friendly acquisition, which faces several hurdles.

site_title: A New World
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a temporary reduction in air pollution, carbon emissions, and human activity in cities worldwide. However, experts warn that this temporary improvement may not be sustainable once the pandemic is over, and the pre-pandemic status quo may return. The crisis has also highlighted issues with urban planning, housing, and waste management. Industry players suggest that the pandemic could encourage a push towards designing buildings that are more people and environmentally-friendly, with a focus on sustainable materials, energy efficiency, and reducing waste. Individuals can also make eco-friendly choices, such as using reusable containers, working from home, and supporting businesses with sustainable practices.

site_title: Energy giants Vitol, Sinopec eye Hin Leong's oil storage terminal
summary: Energy giants Vitol and Sinopec are eyeing Hin Leong's oil storage terminal, Universal Terminal, in Jurong, Singapore, amid the company's debt fallout and police probe. The terminal, valued at nearly US$4 billion, is 41% owned by the Lim family and has a first right of refusal for non-selling shareholders PetroChina and Macquarie Asia Infrastructure Fund. Vitol joins other industry titans in exploring a stake purchase, seeking to bring value to the asset. The terminal's appeal lies in its "outside the tree" status, shielding it from Hin Leong's financial troubles.

images.alt_text: The Hin Leong empire spans oil trading, the chartering oil tankers and a bunkering services firm that last year was Singapore's third largest.

site_title: 1,037 new coronavirus cases, bringing Singapore's total to 11,178
summary: Singapore reported 1,037 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 11,178. Migrant workers living in dormitories account for the majority of the increase, with only 22 cases among Singaporeans and permanent residents. A construction worker died from his injuries at Khoo Teck Puat Hospital, with police investigating the cause of death and confirming he was a COVID-19 patient. The Ministry of Manpower expressed sadness and offered support to the worker's family.

site_title: Jason Pomeroy, founder of Pomeroy Studio and Pomeroy Academy
summary: Architect Jason Pomeroy, founder of Pomeroy Studio and Pomeroy Academy, has found a silver lining in the COVID-19 pandemic. Being grounded has allowed him to reduce his carbon footprint and focus on sustainable design. Pomeroy, who typically travels three times a week, has realized that much of his work can be done remotely. This newfound flexibility has enabled him to create online courses and host a TV series on sustainable design, furthering his mission to raise awareness about climate change and its impact on the environment.

site_title: Fresh backing could decide if WeWork Singapore will be 'WeLive' or 'WeDead'
summary: WeWork Singapore, the dominant co-working operator in Singapore, faces an uncertain future after SoftBank's decision to abandon its parent company. The unit may need new investors or a buyer due to Covid-19's impact on the industry. With a rudderless parent company, WeWork Singapore's survival is now dependent on securing fresh backing. The company's South-east Asian business may be at risk if it cannot secure the necessary funds. WeWork Singapore's fate remains uncertain, with the outcome potentially being "WeLive" or "WeDead".

site_title: Pandemic to dent demand, prices of Singapore industrial space after Q1
summary: Singapore's industrial space prices and rents declined in Q1 2020, falling 0.4% and 0.1% quarter-over-quarter, respectively, due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Occupancy rates remained flat at 89.2%, but the pandemic is expected to weaken demand for industrial space in the coming quarters. Delays in construction activity and project completion timelines are also anticipated. Despite this, warehouses are expected to fare better, driven by e-commerce demand, while factory rents are likely to decline, with some segments potentially increasing by 0.5-1% year-on-year.

site_title: Marketing and pricing on leaving lockdown
summary: As businesses emerge from lockdown, maintaining competitive pricing and adapting to changing consumer needs is crucial. With consumers having more time to explore alternative suppliers, companies must prioritize agility to remain competitive. The shift towards more flexible and adaptive business models is necessary to meet the evolving demands of the market. By being responsive to customer needs and continually assessing the market, businesses can minimize the risk of losing customers and stay ahead in the competitive landscape.

site_title: The Cooking Connection
summary: Singaporean chefs are responding to the Covid-19 crisis by starting small-scale, home-style cooking operations, dubbed a "cottage industry." Chefs such as Alastiar Tan, Gan Ming Kiat, and Joseph Yeo are creating personalized meals with an emphasis on comfort and nostalgia, often using family recipes and ingredients from local markets. The initiative aims to provide a sense of authenticity and intimacy to the cooking process, as people seek comfort in familiar flavors during the pandemic. These small-scale operations have been successful, with many chefs reporting high demand and positive feedback from customers.

site_title: UV disinfecting robots to be deployed at Singapore malls
summary: Singapore will deploy over 200 locally-made UV disinfecting robots, known as Sunburst UV Bots, in malls and healthcare sectors by the end of the year to combat Covid-19. The robots, made by PBA Group, use UV-C light to decontaminate surfaces, killing 99% of bacteria and viruses. The robots will be deployed in 14 malls, including Northpoint City, and will be used only after closing hours. PBA plans to roll out robots in Malaysia, Thailand, and Hong Kong, with an estimated 500 robots in the region.

site_title: Boeing to lay off 10% of workers in civil aviation: sources
summary: Boeing plans to reduce its workforce in its civil aviation unit by 10% due to the novel coronavirus crisis, affecting up to 7,000 workers. The layoffs will impact the 737 MAX, 787, and 777 aircraft manufacturing. The move comes as the company resumes production at its Puget Sound facility with new health measures. Boeing has sought $60 billion in public aid but is under pressure to agree to non-layoff conditions as part of the aid package.

site_title: World Bank's pandemic bond too little too late; needs to rethink structure
summary: The World Bank's first pandemic bond, issued in 2017, was deemed too little too late as the COVID-19 pandemic triggered its payout last week. The bond, which transferred pandemic risk to capital markets, was oversubscribed but ultimately provided only $195 million to the World Bank's Pandemic Emergency Financing Facility, which would distribute funds to 76 poorest countries. Critics argue the structure prioritized investor profits over poor countries' needs, and the World Bank is reportedly working on a new iteration with a more generous payout structure.

site_title: Australia says all WHO members should back coronavirus inquiry
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison urges all World Health Organization (WHO) members to support an independent review into the coronavirus pandemic, citing concerns over China's handling of the outbreak. The proposal comes as diplomatic ties between Australia and China have frayed over allegations of cyber attacks and interference in domestic affairs. China has rejected the call, while the US has withdrawn funding from the WHO, citing "mismanagement" of the crisis. Australia's push for an inquiry is expected to gain support from the White House, but European countries such as France and Britain have expressed reluctance to blame China.

site_title: Record number of firms in 'crossover zone' in Q1, says Moody's
summary: Moody's reports a record high of 96 non-financial companies have entered the "crossover zone" - the credit ratings closest to the line between speculative grade and investment grade - by the end of Q1 2020. This is an increase of 26 firms compared to 2019, driven by deteriorating global economic conditions, sharp commodity price declines, and financial market volatility due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The number of potential fallen angels soared to 76, while potential rising stars shrunk to 20, with 21 companies crossing over to speculative grade.

site_title: Why custodians must adapt with technology, not reinvent themselves
summary: The US$245 billion digital asset industry is driving modern custodian banks to leverage technology to safeguard both traditional and digital assets. However, custodians face a challenge in using technology to enhance their existing services without completely reinventing themselves. To thrive in the current Covid-19 economic crisis, custodians must adapt by investing in technologies such as blockchain-backed platforms and cryptographic techniques to provide efficient customer transactions. They must also maintain their core custodial principles, including relationship-driven services and fiduciary duties, while evolving into "one-stop-shops" for digital asset investors.

site_title: US business activity hits fresh record lows amid coronavirus lockdowns
summary: US business activity reached record lows in April due to coronavirus lockdowns, with the manufacturing and services sectors experiencing significant contractions. The IHS Markit US Composite Output Index fell to 27.4, the lowest since 2009, and services sector activity plummeted to an all-time low. Over 22 million people have filed for unemployment benefits since March 21, and economists believe the economy slipped into recession in March. Economists warn that manufacturing production could continue to decline through the second quarter, with many firms expressing pessimism about the outlook for output over the coming year.

site_title: Digital investments up as banks explore virtual wealth conversations
summary: Singapore banks have seen a surge in digital investment applications and transactions as the country's "circuit breaker" period has encouraged more people to move their wealth management conversations online. UOB reported a 20-fold increase in online gold purchases and a record high in unit trust applications, while OCBC saw a 240% jump in sales of its robo-advisor service and a 20% hike in sales of blue-chip investment plans. Other banks, such as HSBC and DBS, are also expanding their online services, including video-conferencing for investment consultations and self-directed investing activities.

site_title: SMEs offer their know-how to help in fight against pandemic
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are contributing to the country's fight against the COVID-19 pandemic by offering their innovations and capabilities. PBA Group has developed UV-disinfecting robots, while 1929 Mask has created reusable face masks. Other firms, such as Razer and Racer Technology, are producing surgical masks and epidemic-related supplies. Esri Singapore is using geographic information system (GIS) software to manage COVID-19 information. These innovations aim to reduce the workload of cleaning staff, minimize exposure to harmful chemicals, and provide essential services during the pandemic.

site_title: CapitaLand donates S$1m to elderly affected by Covid-19
summary: CapitaLand has donated S$1 million to support elderly residents in Singapore affected by Covid-19 through its philanthropic arm, CapitaLand Hope Foundation. The donation, part of a near S$6 million contribution, will provide meals and essentials to those at AWWA Senior Community Home and Apex Harmony Lodge. The initiative aims to address the lack of volunteer support and supplies at the homes due to heightened precautions. The donation is part of CapitaLand's efforts to support vulnerable groups, including migrant workers, and protect them from the pandemic.

site_title: EHT's sponsor dogged by payment disputes
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has faced payment disputes with its master lessee and Reit sponsor, Urban Commons (UC). Original investors, a hotel management firm, and the City of Pasadena claim to be owed money for hotels acquired by UC. EHT's prospectus stated that the hotels were sold to the trust by US Hospitality Investments, an entity owned by UC's founders, but UC has declined to comment on the matter. UC has also been trying to find a buyer for a $89 million subordinated loan, which has been delayed due to market instability.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Classic Fine Foods, a high-end food supplier, has launched a next-day delivery service for European and Australian chilled and frozen meat, seafood, dairy, and grocery items. The service offers a range of products, including beef, seafood, and dairy products. To celebrate, Classic Fine Foods is offering a 15% discount to BTWeekend magazine readers from April 24 to May 3. The discount can be redeemed by using the promo code BUSINESSTIMES15 when ordering from classicdeli.market/sg/.

images.alt_text: If you're looking to do some gourmet cooking at home, it's a lot easier to get ingredients delivered straight to your house now that high end food suppliers like Classic Fine Foods have moved into online retail.

site_title: This corporate reporting season will provide a reality check on stock rally
summary: Singapore's corporate reporting season will provide insight into the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on companies' financial performances. Despite the market's optimism, the sector is expected to face challenges, particularly in the aviation, retail, and tourism sectors. Key companies such as Singapore Airlines, Reits, and local banks will share their quarterly results, which may unveil vulnerabilities and resilience. Investors will be looking for detailed sharing on the impact of the pandemic, recovery prospects, and dividend payouts. The mid-year reporting season will provide a more comprehensive picture of the sector's performance.

site_title: Lufthansa reports Q1 operating loss of 1.2b euros
summary: Lufthansa reported a Q1 operating loss of 1.2 billion euros, significantly higher than the 336 million euro loss in the same period last year. The airline attributed the increase to crisis-related asset impairments and a decline in fuel hedge values. The company expects a higher loss in the current quarter. More detailed results will be published in May.

site_title: Drama Queen At Home
summary: Kelly Wearstler, a renowned interior designer, has launched a 17-episode Masterclass.com series on creating drama for your home. Wearstler emphasizes the importance of being perpetually curious and collecting items that inspire her, then bringing them together on a mood board. She advocates for combining "tension" and "symmetry" to create drama and enlarging a room. Wearstler's approach thrives on creating whimsical solutions to awkward problems, but acknowledges that her experiments sometimes fail. The series is a great primer for those looking to refresh their surroundings, and Wearstler's tips are available on Masterclass.com for $90.

images.alt_text: (Left) Kelly Wearstler poses at a property featuring her contrarian style of interior design. (Right) When a client wanted a bar for a small room, Wearstler put in a robot sculpture to do the job.
She creates drama through connections and contrasts.
Another example of her mix-and-match sensibilities.
Wearstler's class is useful for novices.
A tiny artwork over a fireplace uncannily draws your eye to the entire room.

site_title: Pricing the benefits of cheap oil in a world of economic lockdowns
summary: The COVID-19 lockdowns may have a silver lining in the form of cheap oil, which has eased financial conditions and boosted liquidity indexes. The 60-70% fall in oil prices has equated to twice the stimulus from the US Federal Reserve, according to consultancy CrossBorder Capital. While cheap oil can have negative effects, such as tightening financial conditions, it also frees up resources for financial asset investing and can benefit consumers. Experts predict a V-shaped rebound in the economy when lockdowns end, with a 50% equity price/earnings re-rating in six months predicted by Pictet Asset Management.

site_title: Circuit-breaker hit to inflation raises risk of more monetary easing
summary: Singapore's circuit-breaker measures to curb the coronavirus are expected to keep consumer prices in check this year, with inflation remaining subdued due to falling services demand. Despite this, economists warn of a rising risk of another monetary easing by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) due to a potential deeper recession and larger output gap. The MAS has reaffirmed its forecast for core inflation to fall between -1% and 0%, but some analysts believe that a second easing in a year is becoming increasingly likely, particularly in October.

site_title: Prepping Singapore firms for life after Covid-19
summary: Singapore firms are preparing for life after Covid-19, with three possible scenarios emerging: a temporary recession (Thunderstorm), prolonged economic impact with minimal changes (Muddling Through), and a deep and extended recession with fundamental business model changes (Metamorphosis). Companies should examine each scenario's implications and be proactive in adapting to the changing environment, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises, which should tap into government financial support. Prudence requires flexibility and collaboration with the government to navigate the post-Covid-19 future.

site_title: Government sets aside S$100m for 8,000 traineeships for fresh grads
summary: The Singapore government has set aside S$100 million to support fresh graduates through a traineeship programme, offering up to 8,000 opportunities to graduates from 2019 and 2020 batches. The programme, SGUnited Traineeship Programme, includes partnerships with over 280 private sector organisations, providing trainees with a training allowance of S$1,100 to S$2,500 per month. The programme aims to support graduates in various fields, including life sciences, engineering, and the arts, and is expected to last up to 12 months.

images.alt_text: The Singapore government has set aside S$100 million to support fresh graduates through a traineeship programme that now offers them more than 4,000 such opportunities.

site_title: 26.5m Americans seek unemployment benefits in 5 weeks
summary: The US labor market has experienced a significant downturn, with 26.5 million Americans seeking unemployment benefits over the last five weeks. This marks a reversal of the longest employment boom in US history, wiping out the 22 million jobs created since 2010. The economy has entered recession, with collapsing oil prices, retail sales, and manufacturing production. President Trump has been eager to restart the economy, despite warnings from health experts about a potential surge in infections.

site_title: France defines natural wine, but is that enough?
summary: France has officially defined natural wine, a label that will be voluntary and only available to producers in France. The "Vin Méthode Nature" charter requires members to use organic grapes, spontaneous fermentation, and minimal use of sulfur dioxide. Critics argue that the definition may lead to co-optation and stifling creativity, while proponents see it as a necessary step to protect the natural wine movement from industrial practices. The label will not be enforceable, and some argue that it may only provide an illusion of discernment, allowing consumers to make their own judgment about what constitutes a natural wine.

site_title: Extended lockdown nudges Singapore towards record slump
summary: Singapore's extended lockdown measures have led economists to predict a record slump in the country's economy, with a 6-10% contraction in gross domestic product (GDP) from last year. The extended "circuit breaker" period is expected to inflict significant economic pain, with Q2 GDP growth possibly contracting by over 20% and the manufacturing, services, and construction sectors experiencing sharp double-digit contractions. Economists have downgraded their forecasts, with UOB predicting a -4% GDP growth for 2020 and Citi estimating an 8.5% contraction.

images.alt_text: With tightened lockdown measures that have been extended through to June 1, economists have pencilled in more sobering numbers that would cement the deepest recession that the Republic will ever print in its history.

site_title: Euro sinks to one-month low amid economic stall
summary: The euro has fallen to its lowest level in a month, dropping 0.6% against the US dollar after data showed economic activity in the euro zone halted by government-imposed lockdowns. The single currency is now at US$1.07795, with investors awaiting a meeting of EU leaders to discuss a proposed recovery fund to help the bloc recover from a forecast deep recession caused by the pandemic. The outcome of the summit remains uncertain, with EU governments' willingness to share the burden of debt mutualization still unclear.

site_title: UK economy crumbles under Covid-19 strain
summary: The UK economy is experiencing its second consecutive month of contraction due to the strain of the coronavirus lockdown, further exacerbating the economic downturn. Government borrowing has reached the highest levels in peacetime history, increasing pressure on the government to set an exit strategy. Prime Minister Boris Johnson is facing criticism for his handling of the outbreak, with some epidemiologists arguing he reacted too slowly. The economic contraction adds to the challenges faced by Labour leader Keir Starmer, who is seeking to capitalize on the government's mismanagement of the crisis.

site_title: Sats' S$1.6m share buybacks beg question of prudence
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based ground handler and inflight caterer, spent nearly S$1.6 million on share buybacks in April, prompting questions about the prudence of the move during the COVID-19 pandemic. The company repurchased 535,000 shares to fulfill its annual obligation to issue shares to managers and senior management. Market-watchers have raised concerns about Sats' cash flow position and the timing of the buybacks, as the company is cutting costs and receiving subsidies to ride out the pandemic.

site_title: STI falls for third straight day on bleak macro data despite oil rebound
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 2,542.37 for the third straight day, as investors remained cautious amid bleak macro data, including a rise in US jobless claims. Oil markets rebounded from a two-decade low, but regional markets were mixed, with the Hang Seng rising 0.35% and the Nikkei increasing 1.52%. Losers outnumbered gainers 217 to 190, with top losers including Clearbridge Health and ESR Reit, while Jardine Cycle & Carriage was the top gainer, rising 3.05%.

site_title: Green Oasis
summary: A Singaporean home in Bukit Timah features a garden on each of its three levels, a unique design concept by Wallflower Architects. Initially, the client, the Lim family, was hesitant due to cost and maintenance concerns. However, after seeing the gardens' design and automatic watering systems, they trusted the architect's proposal. The result is a cool and tranquil space, with the designated gardener able to water plants on upper floors automatically. The project showcases innovative design solutions for unusual home layouts, blending nature and functionality.

site_title: Pandemic digital disputes underline why firms need a foreign policy
summary: French digital minister Cédric O has called for Google and Apple to weaken privacy protections in their coronavirus digital contact tracing system, citing a need for a sovereign European health solution. The move comes as other countries, such as Singapore, have developed their own contact tracing apps despite similar restrictions. The debate highlights the balance between user privacy and contact tracing efficacy, with Paris believing it should be a public policy issue, not corporate. The French government wants the restrictions lifted by May 11, while Apple and Google are set to release their technology in mid-May, sparking a potential battle of wills.

site_title: Adaptive challenges and the language of leadership
summary: Leaders need to evolve and develop a new mindset to build a complex way of thinking and behaving to face adaptive challenges, such as the COVID-19 pandemic. A study by Harvard professors Robert Kegan and Lisa Lahey found that leaders who operate with a socialized mind, lacking internal control, often succumb to external pressures and assign blame. In contrast, leaders who can objectively analyze circumstances and find alternatives to conventional responses can effectively navigate adaptive challenges. To succeed, leaders must model the way, prioritize people's intangibles, and demonstrate mindful, selfless, and compassionate behavior.

site_title: The future of oil demand is being reshaped by virus lockdowns
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a significant shift in global oil demand, with over 30% of demand wiped out due to lockdowns. The impact is expected to be permanent, with some analysts predicting a slower recovery and others expecting a rebound by next year. Experts point to changes in transportation habits, with more people opting for private cars and reduced public transport usage, as key factors in shaping the future of the oil market. The shift towards remote work and online commerce is also expected to have a lasting impact on oil demand.

site_title: Mary Chia changes Catalist sponsor 'for commercial reasons'
summary: Mary Chia Holdings announced that SAC Capital Private Limited will be its new continuing sponsor, replacing PrimePartners Corporate Finance, due to commercial reasons. The last day of sponsorship for PPCF will be Friday. Mary Chia Holdings expressed gratitude to PPCF for its 10-year sponsorship services. The company's shares closed unchanged at 9.5 Singapore cents on Thursday before the announcement.

site_title: Google to verify all advertisers, and their location
summary: Google is expanding its verification program for advertisers on its platform to combat fraud and "bad actors." The company will start verifying US advertisers first, then expand globally, requiring advertisers to submit personal and business documents to prove their identity and location. Users will be able to click on links to view information about specific advertisers, promoting transparency and informed decision-making. The process is expected to take a few years to complete, aiming to detect and limit the activities of misrepresenting advertisers.

images.alt_text: Google said Thursday it would expand its programme of verification of advertisers on its platform as part of an effort to weed out fraud and "bad actors."

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.25 points to 1,381.64. Volume reached 5.035 billion lots worth RM2.571 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 462 to 376.

site_title: US new home sales fall sharply in March
summary: US new home sales plummeted 15.4% in March to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 627,000 units, the largest decline since July 2013. This marks a significant drop from February's revised 741,000 units. Economists had forecast a 15% decline, and further declines are expected due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and job losses.

images.alt_text: Sales of new US single-family homes dropped by the most in more than 6-1/2 years in March and further declines are likely as the novel coronavirus outbreak batters the economy and throws millions of Americans out of work.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Manpower Ministry warned companies treating workers unfairly during the circuit breaker may lose support and work pass privileges. The Jobs Support Scheme wage subsidies will be reduced for companies reducing employee salaries or putting them on no-pay leave. The circuit breaker extension is expected to cause significant economic hardship, with a potential 6-10% GDP contraction. Industrial prices and rents fell in the first quarter, but occupancy remained flat. The STI fell 0.30% as investors waited cautiously for Q1 earnings season.

site_title: Lagarde tells EU leaders GDP may fall up to 15% on Coronavirus
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde warned EU leaders that the euro area's GDP could fall by as much as 15% due to the pandemic, with a 9% cut in output being her baseline estimate. The warning comes as the region faces a severe economic crisis, with strict lockdowns and travel halts causing widespread devastation. The EU is discussing a proposed $2.2 trillion economic recovery plan, but disagreement remains over who will share the costs and how the funds will be disbursed. Lagarde expressed concern that the EU may be doing too little, too late to mitigate the economic fallout.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day higher, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.35% to 23,977.32, following gains in Asia and on Wall Street. Oil prices continued their rally, despite concerns over the economic outlook. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes fell 0.19% and 0.50% respectively.
