Investor sentiment remains cautious, with the economic outlook still clouding investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks closed higher Thursday, in line with gains across Asia and on Wall Street as oil prices extended their rally, though concerns over the economic outlook continue to cloud investor sentiment.

site_title: Negative oil prices are not a new phenomenon
summary: Negative oil prices, previously seen as a rare phenomenon, are not a new occurrence. In various sectors, such as power generation and banking, negative prices have existed for years due to imbalances between supply and demand, and marginal costs of zero. This can be triggered by new production conditions and the Internet. The concept challenges traditional market dynamics, where marginal costs are typically greater than zero, and prices of zero or below are rare. In the case of oil, it has now happened for the first time, with a barrel of West Texas Intermediate falling to minus-US$40.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher despite jump in jobless claims
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, despite a jump in jobless claims, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.4% to 23,561.52. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively. The latest spike in unemployment claims did not seem to deter investors, who are focused on the US economy's recovery from the coronavirus shutdowns. The market is expected to continue its rally, with traders brushing off new US threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Japan takes dimmest view on economy since financial crisis
summary: Japan's economy is in an "extremely severe situation" and "getting worse rapidly" due to the coronavirus pandemic, according to the Cabinet Office. It downgraded its view of consumer spending, production, corporate earnings, and the jobs market for the second month. The economy is expected to continue in a severe condition, with some analysts predicting a 20% shrinkage this quarter. The grim assessment comes as the number of known virus cases in Japan exceeds 11,000 and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe widened a state of emergency to cover the whole country.

site_title: Australia: Shares close little changed on grim business activity survey
summary: Australian shares closed nearly unchanged on Thursday, despite a survey showing grim business activity data, as a surge in exports was offset by losses in healthcare and financial stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.1% to 5,217.10, following a 1.2% rise earlier in the day on hopes of a US relief package. The country's overall activity index plummeted to a record low of 22.4 in April, indicating a contraction due to virus-driven lockdowns and social distancing measures.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets extend gains at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Thursday, building on the previous session's strong gains, as oil prices recover from historical lows. London, Frankfurt, Paris, and Milan climbed 0.1-1.0% in value, while Madrid advanced 0.8%. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Keppel FELS delivers sixth of 11 jack-up rigs to Borr Drilling
summary: Keppel FELS, a subsidiary of Keppel Corp's offshore and marine business, has delivered the sixth jack-up rig, named Hild, to Borr Drilling. The Hild is built to Keppel's proprietary KFELS Super B Class design, capable of operating in 400 feet water depth and drilling to 35,000 feet. This delivery marks the sixth of 11 jack-up rigs ordered by Borr Drilling, with the remaining five rigs expected to be delivered in the coming years.

site_title: 1,037 new coronavirus cases, bringing Singapore's total to 11,178
summary: Singapore reported 1,037 new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 11,178. Foreign workers in dormitories account for 982 of the new cases, while 30 cases were among non-dorm residents. No imported cases were reported, and three-quarters of the new cases were linked to known clusters. The number of new cases in the general community has decreased, and 36 patients were discharged, bringing the total discharged to 924.

site_title: CapitaLand donates S$1m to elderly affected by Covid-19 in Singapore
summary: CapitaLand is donating S$1 million to support elderly affected by Covid-19 in Singapore through its philanthropic arm CapitaLand Hope Foundation. The donation will provide meals, daily necessities, smart communication devices, and personal protection equipment to elderly care homes. The company has pledged close to S$6 million to support communities in Singapore impacted by the pandemic, with a focus on vulnerable groups such as the elderly and migrant workers.

site_title: US jobless claims at 4.43 million in labour rout's fifth week
summary: The US labour market experienced its fifth consecutive week of decline, with 4.43 million Americans filing for unemployment benefits last week. This brings the total to 26.5 million, the steepest downturn since the Great Depression. The unemployment rate is estimated to be around 20%, double the 10% peak in 2009, assuming all who filed for benefits are counted as unemployed.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end 1% higher on oil rebound, US stimulus hopes
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.98% to 1,914.73, driven by a rebound in oil prices and hopes of a US stimulus package. Despite grim economic data, investor sentiment was boosted. Foreigners sold US$28.66 million worth of shares, while the US House of Representatives is set to pass a nearly US$500 billion coronavirus relief bill. Oil extended gains amid signs of reduced production to cope with the pandemic.

site_title: How living and working will change in a post-COVID world
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly altered how people live and work, with remote working becoming the norm. As social distancing measures lift, people will likely prioritize flexibility in their living and work arrangements, with 47% of employees believing team productivity is higher when working from home. This shift may lead to changes in the real estate market, with businesses potentially downsizing and adopting digital platforms to provide greater efficiency and value to tenants. The pandemic has also highlighted the importance of community, with people seeking housing options that offer flexibility and social connections.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up more than 1.5%
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 1.52% to close at 19,429.44, driven by rallies on Wall Street and a recovery in oil prices. This follows recent declines, with investors buying back shares. The broader Topix index also gained 1.36% to 1,425.98.

site_title: Malaysia to extend virus curbs by two weeks to May 12
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced the extension of the movement control order (MCO) by two weeks to May 12, the third time the government has done so. The decision comes as Covid-19 cases show a reduction, with 63.2% of patients recovered. The government plans to ease curbs in stages if cases decrease further, and is studying methods to revive the economy in stages, including a short- and medium-term economic recovery plan. The MCO can still be extended further.

images.alt_text: Curbs on movement may be eased in stages in several sectors, including the social sector, if the number of Covid-19 cases reduce.

site_title: WFH is great... even if things go wrong!
summary: A company, aAdvantage Consulting Group, successfully transitioned to work-from-home (WFH) arrangements during the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite initial technical issues, distractions from family members, and challenges in virtual communication, the team adapted and achieved significant milestones, including company-wide townhalls, online product development, and leadership conversations. The company's culture of trust, ownership, and collaboration played a crucial role in its success, with employees learning and adapting together.

site_title: A deeper recession in Singapore as 'circuit breaker' stretches to June: economists
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to experience a deeper recession in 2020 due to the prolonged "circuit breaker" measures, with economists projecting a 6-10% GDP contraction. The extension of the lockdown is expected to inflict significant economic pain, with Q2 GDP growth possibly contracting by over 20% from a year ago. Economists have downgraded their 2020 GDP growth forecasts, with UOB projecting -4%, Citi -8.5%, and Barclays -4.5%. The prolonged lockdown is likely to delay a recovery, with some experts warning of another wave of infections and potential further easing of containment measures.

site_title: Singapore's food and hawker stalls hold hidden pearls of bubble tea
summary: Singapore's partial lockdown has led to a surge in demand for bubble tea, with many food stalls and hawker centers experiencing a significant increase in orders. Brands like Gong Cha and Koi have been forced to meet the demand by operating outside of their usual standalone stores. The sudden change has created opportunities for smaller players with Taiwanese branding, with some owners expressing hope that customers will return in the future. The demand for bubble tea has also led to the launch of DIY kits, with companies like Woobbee planning to sell bubble tea-making kits online.

site_title: Malaysia to extend virus curbs by two weeks to May 12
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced the extension of virus curbs by two weeks to May 12, amid slowing daily increases in COVID-19 cases. The country has reported 5,603 infections and 95 deaths. To ease curbs, the government may allow more sectors to resume operations, including the social sector, with detailed guidelines to be provided to investors and corporate sectors. The government is also studying methods to revive the economy in stages, with a focus on domestic spending and economic recovery.

site_title: Hermes weathers coronavirus storm better than luxury rivals
summary: Hermes reported a 7.7% decline in first-quarter comparable sales, outperforming luxury rivals such as LVMH, Kering, and Moncler, which reported declines of 15% or more. Despite the global coronavirus crisis, Hermes saw a strong rebound in sales in China after shops reopened in March, with double-digit growth. The company's shares rose 2.6% to 689.8 euros, driven by the resilient performance. Hermes attributed its success to careful production and stock management, which has helped maintain its luxury exclusivity.

site_title: STI closes 7.67 points or 0.30% lower on cusp of Q1 earnings season
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 7.67 points, or 0.30%, to 2,542.37, marking its third consecutive day of losses, ahead of Q1 earnings season. Trading volume reached 2.2 billion securities worth S$1.23 billion. Top losers included Clearbridge Health and ESR Reit, while Jardine Cycle & Carriage was the top gainer. Regional markets showed mixed results, with the Hang Seng rising 0.35% and the Nikkei rising 1.52%.

site_title: Downward pressure on industrial prices, rentals in coming quarters owing to virus outbreak: JTC
summary: Singapore's industrial prices and rents fell 0.4% and 0.1% respectively in Q1 2020, with occupancy remaining flat at 89.2%. The decline is attributed to the Covid-19 outbreak, with JTC warning of downward pressure on prices and rentals in the coming quarters. Project delays are also expected due to construction halt until June 1, with about 2.1 million sq m of industrial space originally slated for completion, now likely to be delayed. Transaction volumes fell 29% quarter on quarter and 38% from a year ago.

site_title: Singapore headline inflation falls to zero in March
summary: Singapore's headline inflation remained flat in March, narrowly avoiding a negative turn, with the all-items consumer price index (CPI) unchanged year on year. Core inflation, which is used as a guide for monetary policy, fell to -0.2% from -0.1% in February. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) attributed the decline to safe-distancing measures and weaker domestic labour market conditions, which are expected to cap price increases for discretionary goods and services.

site_title: China's Didi looks short on engine power
summary: China's Didi Chuxing, the country's largest ride-hailing company, has unveiled a new three-year strategic plan with ambitious targets, including 100 million daily trips and 800 million monthly active users globally by 2022. However, the plan lacks specific details and seems out of touch with the changing post-Covid-19 landscape, where technology investors prioritize profitability and governance over growth. Didi's US$53 billion valuation may be at risk without a stronger drive, following a two-year slump after high-profile safety scandals.

site_title: SK Hynix warns of volatile chip demand after Q1 profit beats forecast
summary: SK Hynix, a major chipmaker, warned of volatile chip demand due to the ongoing pandemic. The company reported a 41% drop in quarterly profit, beating estimates, but cited uncertainties about server demand in the second half. Despite a weaker South Korean currency boosting exports, SK Hynix expects flat shipments of DRAM chips and a bigger impact from the coronavirus on mobile phones. The company's shares dipped 0.95% after the announcement.

site_title: China's Sinopec in talks to buy stake in Hin Leong's Singapore terminal: sources
summary: Chinese state energy company Sinopec is in talks to buy a stake in Hin Leong's Singapore terminal, valued at over US$1.5 billion, as the company seeks to provide much-needed cash. Hin Leong owes US$3.85 billion to 23 banks and has applied to delay debt repayments. Sinopec, Asia's largest refiner, is evaluating the quality and cost of the asset, but will be cautious given growing internal scrutiny over spending. The terminal has its own integrated marine infrastructure, making it an attractive investment opportunity for potential investors.

site_title: Record US jobless claims wipe out post-Great Recession employment gains
summary: The US economy has seen record 26 million Americans likely seek unemployment benefits over the last five weeks, wiping out the 22 million jobs created during the longest employment boom in US history. The data confirms the novel coronavirus has savaged the economy, surpassing the natural disaster-like job losses seen during the Great Recession. Economists warn that the unemployment rate is expected to shatter the post-World War Two record of 10.8%, with continuing claims forecast to reach a record 16.476 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Thursday's session with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the open on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.38% to 23,983.65, following positive leads from Wall Street and oil markets. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. This rally comes ahead of US-EU trade talks and despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Thailand plans to sell up to 133b baht of govt bonds in April-June
summary: Thailand plans to sell up to 113 billion baht (S$5 billion) of government bonds in April to June as part of a debt-restructuring effort. The domestic bonds, with maturities ranging from four to 47 years, will be sold to help reduce the country's debt. The move is part of the government's efforts to manage its debt and improve its financial stability.

site_title: Venture firm Benchmark raises new fund without early Uber investor: source
summary: Benchmark, a Silicon Valley venture capital firm, is raising a new $425 million fund without early Uber investor Bill Gurley. Gurley, who led Benchmark's early investment in Uber, will not be part of the new fund but will remain on the boards of Benchmark's portfolio companies. The reasons for his exclusion are unclear, but he will continue to work with the firm and startups for "many, many years." Benchmark has a long track record of backing major tech firms like eBay and Twitter.

site_title: Record number of firms in 'crossover zone' due to Covid-19, oil price shock: Moody's
summary: A record 96 non-financial companies have entered the "crossover zone" - the credit ratings closest to the line between speculative grade and investment grade - by the end of the first quarter this year, up 26 from 2019. The surge was driven by global economic deterioration, sharp commodity price declines, and financial market volatility due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This led to a significant increase in potential fallen angels, with 76 companies in the zone, holding $593 billion in debt, and a decrease in potential rising stars to 20.

site_title: For SoftBank's Son, coronavirus turns vision to illusion
summary: SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son's vision for a global tech empire is unraveling due to the coronavirus crisis. The Vision Fund, a $100 billion investment vehicle, is suffering losses, with over half of its capital invested in startups impacted by the virus. Ride-hailing usage has plummeted, and several startups have pushed back IPO plans. SoftBank has reported a 1.8 trillion yen loss at the fund, and critics argue that Son's strategy of investing in unproven businesses has been too risky. Despite some bright spots, such as growth in short video app TikTok, the fund's performance is under pressure, and Son's plans to raise a second mega-fund are in jeopardy.

site_title: Singapore's Biolidics inks US distribution deal for its Covid-19 test kits
summary: Singapore-based Biolidics has inked a one-year distribution deal with US-listed Aytu Bioscience to distribute its Covid-19 test kits in the US. Aytu will handle logistics, sales, and marketing, and Biolidics will retain the right to sell directly to clinical partners. As part of the deal, Aytu must purchase 1.25 million test kits within the first three months to maintain exclusivity. Biolidics expects the deal to contribute positively to its revenue for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Aytu must purchase from Biolidics an initial 500,000 Covid-19 test kits within one business day from the date of the agreement.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust declares higher DPU of 2.048 Singapore cts
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust has declared a higher distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.048 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter, up 1.2% from the previous year. The Reit's net property income rose 9.3% to S$114.7 million and gross revenue increased 5.5% to S$128.1 million. The improved performance was driven by higher revenue from existing properties and accretive acquisitions in Malaysia, Vietnam, South Korea, and Japan. The Reit's assets under management totalled S$8.9 billion, and net asset value per unit rose 3.4% to S$1.21.

site_title: Asia: Equities, crude cautiously higher but capped by virus uncertainty
summary: Asian markets showed tentative gains on Thursday, driven by oil market stabilization, but investors remained cautious due to the uncertain economic outlook and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Despite signs of slowing disease transmission, the World Health Organization's head warned that the end of the crisis is still far off. Global markets are now focusing on exit strategies, with governments considering easing lockdowns and stimulus packages, but concerns about the road to recovery persist, particularly in China and the European Union.

site_title: Oil rises for second day as producers trim output to respond to demand loss
summary: Oil prices rose for a second day as producers cut output to cope with collapsing demand due to the coronavirus outbreak. Brent crude rose 1.6% to $20.70 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate futures rose 2% to $14.06 a barrel. Opec, Russia, and other producers are set to cut supply by 9.7 million barrels per day starting May 1, which may need to be extended to match the demand shortfall. Crude inventories in the US rose 15 million barrels to 518.6 million barrels, and Japan's services sector shrank at a record low amid the pandemic.

site_title: North Korean capital sees 'panic buying' of food: NK News
summary: North Korea's capital, Pyongyang, is experiencing "panic buying" of food staples, causing store shelves to empty, amid stricter coronavirus measures. The purchases are not related to reports of leader Kim Jong Un's health, according to people living in Pyongyang. Food shortages are common in North Korea, which is one of the world's poorest states, and the virus could exacerbate the issue. The World Food Program has warned of potential starvation in the developing world, citing 40% of the population as undernourished.

site_title: Australian goods exports jump 29% in March: ABS
summary: Australian goods exports rose 29% in March to A$36.1 billion, driven by increased iron ore shipments to China and non-monetary gold exports to Hong Kong and the UK. Imports rose 10% to A$23.8 billion, with capital goods and intermediate goods also seeing increases. The data follows declines in January and February, suggesting a rebound in the country's trade sector.

site_title: Thai March domestic car sales tumble 41.74% y-o-y: industries federation
summary: Thai domestic car sales plummeted 41.74% in March, reaching 60,105 vehicles, due to the coronavirus outbreak. This marks the 10th consecutive month of decline, following a 17.1% drop in February. The Federation of Thai Industries may lower its 2020 sales forecast, citing a 50,000-unit reduction from last month's estimate of 950,000 units. This contraction is attributed to the pandemic's impact on the automotive industry in Thailand, a significant regional vehicle production and export base.

site_title: Gojek acquires payments startup Moka for US$130m: sources
summary: Gojek, Indonesia's ride-hailing giant, has acquired mobile point-of-sale startup Moka for approximately US$130 million. The deal was completed about a month ago and marks Gojek's move to strengthen its position in the country's digital payments industry, amid the COVID-19 pandemic accelerating the shift away from cash.

site_title: Australia says all WHO members should participate in a coronavirus inquiry
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison urges all World Health Organization (WHO) members to participate in an independent review into the spread of coronavirus. Morrison believes there should be responsibilities and obligations attached to being a WHO member. He aims to make the world safer from viruses and hopes other nations, including China, will share this objective. The review is proposed in response to the coronavirus outbreak in China late last year.

site_title: US calls on China to permanently close wildlife wet markets
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has called on China to permanently close its wildlife wet markets, citing links between those markets and zoonotic diseases. The markets are believed to be the origin of the COVID-19 virus, which has killed over 180,000 people worldwide. Pompeo stated that the US wants China to close all markets that sell illegal wildlife, in an effort to prevent future pandemics.

site_title: Thailand's March foreign tourist arrivals tumble 76.4% y-o-y amid virus crisis
summary: Thailand's foreign tourist arrivals plummeted 76.4% in March from a year ago due to the coronavirus outbreak, with 0.82 million visitors spending 39.5 billion baht. This represents a 77.6% decline from the previous year. Tourists from China, Thailand's largest source, dropped 94.2%. The tourism sector accounts for 11% of Thailand's GDP.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as oil rebound stirs risk appetite; Lynas soars
summary: Australian shares rose 1% to 5,274.7, driven by a 21% surge in rare earths miner Lynas and a 3% gain in energy stocks, amid a rebound in oil prices and hopes for global stimulus. The US military is set to fund Lynas' Texas facility, and a $500 billion US coronavirus aid bill is expected to pass. However, analysts warn the relief in equity markets may be short-lived due to limited central bank resources and uncertain long-term recovery.

site_title: Singapore FinTech Association, Razer offer fintech firms up to US$1.5m financing amid Covid-19
summary: The Singapore FinTech Association and Razer Fintech have partnered to provide bridge financing to fintech companies in Singapore, offering up to US$1.5 million in funding. The financial assistance is aimed at addressing challenges faced by local fintech players due to the Covid-19 crisis, including business continuity concerns and funding issues. The partnership also includes cash flow and marketing support, as well as evaluation and due diligence processes. This move is part of Razer's US$50 million Covid-19 support fund, which focuses on investments in companies fighting Covid-19 or supporting people through the pandemic.

site_title: Bankruptcy looms over US energy industry, from oil fields to pipelines
summary: The US energy industry, including oil fields, pipelines, and refineries, is facing a severe crisis due to heavy debt loads and a dual supply/demand shock caused by the coronavirus pandemic and a price war between Russia and Saudi Arabia. Oil prices have plummeted, with US prices reaching negative territory, and about half of the top 60 independent US oil producers are likely to need to review options for securing more liquidity. Many midstream companies, backed by private equity, are in danger of bankruptcy, and large banks are preparing to become owners of oil and gas fields. The crisis is expected to be a multi-year process, with restructuring efforts and potential bankruptcies affecting the industry.

site_title: Hong Kong political crisis deepens despite protest lull during virus
summary: A political crisis in Hong Kong deepens despite a recent lull in protests due to the coronavirus pandemic. Prominent activists were arrested on charges linked to last year's demonstrations, fueling tensions over Beijing's increasing control. A row over the powers of the Liaison Office, which represents China's central government, has sparked accusations of Beijing's attempts to erode Hong Kong's autonomy. The situation has raised concerns that future unrest is near inevitable, with expectations of a return to large-scale protests, particularly ahead of the September legislative elections.

site_title: Unnerved by new virus cases in navy, Taiwan debates lockdowns
summary: Taiwan is debating a potential lockdown amid a sharp increase in coronavirus cases in the navy, with 28 new infections reported on a ship that was part of a friendly mission to Palau. The country has seen 426 confirmed cases, with 236 recovered and 6 deaths. Despite low infection rates, the government is considering a lockdown, with Taipei Mayor Ko Wen-je planning a "tabletop exercise" to simulate closing down the capital. The central government has ruled out lockdowns for now, citing the lack of widespread community transmission and the need to maintain economic activity.

site_title: Pimco steps up distressed bet with another US$3b fund
summary: Pacific Investment Management Co (Pimco) is raising another US$3 billion for its Distressed Credit Opportunities Fund III, targeting leveraged loans, high-yield bonds, and collateralized loan obligations. This is the second distressed bet by Pimco this year, as the company seeks to capitalize on dislocations in the fixed-income market. The fund will also invest in stressed and distressed debt and companies that cannot access traditional markets, marking a growing trend in the industry.

site_title: Singapore shares post modest gains at open, tracking Wall St rally; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 2,554.84, driven by a US Wall Street rally. Banking stocks, including DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank, advanced. ESR-Reit's share price declined 0.5% despite its manager halving the distribution per unit to manage cash flow amid the pandemic. The STI has now notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: US sees 1,738 new coronavirus deaths in 24 hours: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US recorded 1,738 new coronavirus deaths in the past 24 hours, bringing the total number of fatalities to 46,583, according to Johns Hopkins University. This is a lower toll than the previous day. The US has the highest number of Covid-19 fatalities among all countries affected by the pandemic.

site_title: Japan's coronavirus shutdowns pummel service, factory sectors: PMIs
summary: Japan's services sector shrank at a record pace in April, while factories also fell quiet due to the coronavirus pandemic. The au Jibun Bank Flash Japan Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) slumped to 43.7, its lowest since 2009, and the services PMI index plunged to 22.8, marking the lowest since 2007. The government's economic stimulus package was raised to $1.1 trillion, amid a projected annual rate of over 10% contraction in the second quarter.

site_title: Q&M to invest S$3m to build Covid-19 testing business
summary: Q&M Dental Group is investing S$3 million in a joint venture with scientist Dr Ong Siew Hwa to build a Covid-19 testing business via Acumen Diagnostics, a local biotech company. The venture, conditional on regulatory approvals, aims to develop rapid diagnostic tests and vaccine trials for infectious diseases. Dr Ong will hold a 30.7% stake in Acumen Diagnostics, while Q&M holds 51%. The investment is seen as a response to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and market demand for diagnostic test kits and vaccine trials.

site_title: Mukesh Ambani tops Jack Ma as Asia's richest after deal with Facebook
summary: Mukesh Ambani has surpassed Jack Ma as Asia's richest person after a deal with Facebook, with his fortune increasing to $49.2 billion. Reliance Industries' stock surged 10% following the $5.7 billion investment in Jio Platforms, a digital apps and wireless platform. The deal marks Facebook's largest investment in a global market and puts Ambani $3.2 billion ahead of Ma on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 8.27 points, or 0.60%, to 1,390.16. Volume was 161.58 million lots worth RM44.04 million. Gainers outpaced losers 262 to 17.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust malls see 42.5% fall in sales, 37.6% drop in footfall for Q1
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 42.5% drop in sales and a 37.6% decline in footfall for Q1, mainly due to the COVID-19 outbreak in China. Despite this, the Reit's manager is "cautiously optimistic" about the second half of the year, citing pro-business government stimulus measures and a "healthy flow" of shoppers returning to its malls. Occupancy rate remains high at 95.4%, and the Reit has implemented cost-containment measures to mitigate losses.

site_title: China bank BoCom halts open positions for crude oil trading products
summary: China's Bank of Communications (BoCom) has halted open positions for crude oil trading products, citing "current pricing and liquidity risks" in the market. This decision follows similar restrictions announced by Bank of China, amid a supply glut and low oil prices. The US WTI futures fell below $0 a barrel in April due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on demand. The move is part of a broader trend of caution in the oil market.

site_title: SensorFlow raises US$8.3m in Series A+ round led by Openspace, Gaw Capital Partners
summary: SensorFlow, a Singapore-based proptech company, has raised US$8.3 million in a Series A+ round led by Openspace Ventures and Gaw Capital Partners. The funding will be used to develop its smart building management solution for HVAC systems and expand globally. SensorFlow will also hire new talent in hardware and data science roles. The company aims to optimize energy and operational efficiency for hotels and commercial properties.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 1.02% and the Topix index gaining 0.73%. The gains were driven by buy-backs following a previous drop, but investors remain cautious due to the ongoing pandemic and its economic impact. Despite this, the market shows resilience, with other regional markets also experiencing gains.

site_title: South Korea posts biggest GDP fall since 2008 as pandemic cripples demand
summary: South Korea's economy contracted by 1.4% in the first quarter, its largest decline since 2008, due to the pandemic's impact on consumption and global trade. Self-isolation measures have crippled demand, with exports declining 2% and private consumption shrinking 6.4% on-quarter. The government is bracing for a bigger shock in the second quarter, with economists predicting a 0.1% or 1.2% contraction this year, depending on the severity of global demand and domestic demand.

site_title: Daimler first quarter operating profits plunge as virus bites
summary: Daimler, the German car giant, reported a 78% drop in preliminary first-quarter operating profits to 617 million euros due to the coronavirus pandemic. Worldwide sales slumped 15% year-on-year, with Mercedes-Benz cars experiencing a 20% drop in China and 16% in Europe. The company withdrew its 2020 financial targets, citing uncertain market conditions. Experts expect a 14% contraction in the global car market for 2020, with Daimler forecasting lower sales, turnover, and operating profit compared to 2019.

site_title: ST Engineering unit to issue US$750m 1.5% notes under new programme
summary: ST Engineering's wholly-owned subsidiary, STE RHQ, priced US$750 million in 5-year notes with a 1.5% fixed-rate coupon, expected to mature on April 29, 2025. The net proceeds will be used for new capital expenditure, acquisitions, and refinancing existing borrowings. The senior unsecured notes are priced at 1.5% and will be issued on April 29, 2020.

site_title: iFAST Q1 net profit jumps 126.8% to S$3.6m
summary: iFAST, a wealth management fintech firm, reported a 126.8% jump in net profit to S$3.6 million for its Q1 2020, driven by a 25.3% rise in net revenue and 41.5% increase in gross revenue. Gross revenue rose to S$38.5 million, with significant increases in transaction fees and service fees. The company declared an interim cash dividend of 0.75 Singapore cent per share. Despite the COVID-19 "circuit-breaker" period, iFAST's services remain operational, with 90% of its Singapore office working from home.

site_title: Facebook takes US$5.7b stake in India's Jio digital platforms
summary: Facebook has taken a $5.7 billion stake in Jio Platforms, a digital business of India's richest man Mukesh Ambani, giving it a 10% stake. The deal aims to link WhatsApp with Jio, expanding digital business in India, where Facebook has 400 million users. The move is expected to boost income for small businesses, farmers, and micro-traders, and aid India's national goals of improving ease of living and doing business. The deal marks one of the biggest foreign investments in the country.

site_title: UK virus measures could last for months, health official warns
summary: UK health officials warn that social distancing measures to combat coronavirus may last for months due to the low probability of a vaccine or effective treatments being available soon. England's chief medical officer, Chris Whitty, says it's "wholly unrealistic" to expect a sudden lift in lockdown measures, and deaths continue to rise, reaching 18,100 on Wednesday. The government faces growing criticism over its response to the crisis, with Labour leader Keir Starmer accusing ministers of being slow to act.

site_title: Harvard says won't accept virus aid money after all
summary: Harvard University announced it will not accept $8.6 million in COVID-19 relief funds allocated to it under the federal CARES Act, following President Donald Trump's criticism. Trump called on the university to pay back the funds, citing it was meant for workers, not a wealthy institution. Harvard instead plans to use the funds to support students facing urgent financial needs due to the pandemic, and will inform the Department of Education of its decision to reallocate resources.

site_title: Money FM podcast: New training scheme to help older workers enter the tech sector
summary: A new training scheme, the TechSkills Accelerator (TeSA) Mid-Career Advance, aims to help older workers in Singapore enter the tech sector and address manpower gaps. The program, led by the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA), will match jobs to mature workers and provide training to help them upskill. The initiative is part of Singapore's efforts to boost the tech industry and support workers in transitioning to new roles.

site_title: Ships, trains, caves: Oil traders chase storage space in world awash with fuel
summary: Oil traders are struggling to find storage space due to abundant supply and plummeting demand caused by the novel coronavirus crisis. Ships, trains, and caves are being used as floating storage, with dozens of oil tanker vessels booked to store 30 million barrels of fuel. Onshore storage facilities are full or booked, and oil producers are turning to unusual tactics like storing crude in railcars or unused pipelines. The world's total oil storage capacity is unclear, but rising sea storage and booked facilities indicate the limit is being reached.

site_title: New York cats become first US pets to contract coronavirus
summary: Two cats in New York have become the first US pets to test positive for the new coronavirus, according to officials. The cats, living in separate areas of New York state, had mild respiratory illness and are expected to recover. Their owners or household members may have transmitted the virus to the cats, with no evidence of pets playing a role in spreading the virus. Health officials recommend social isolation and indoor confinement for cats and leash-wearing for dogs to prevent transmission.

site_title: US: Dow ends 2.0% higher as stocks rally with oil prices
summary: US stocks rebounded on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 2.0% to 23,469.58, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gaining 2.3% and 2.8%, respectively. Oil prices rallied, with futures for West Texas Intermediate jumping 19% to $13.78 a barrel. Analysts attribute the gains to investor optimism on the economy's reopening and large technology companies' strong performances, despite concerns about the oil industry's vulnerability to further weakness.

site_title: Bank of Japan says to shorten policy meeting to one day on April 27
summary: The Bank of Japan announced it will shorten its upcoming monetary policy meeting to a single day on April 27 due to the spread of the novel coronavirus. The meeting, originally planned for two days, will begin at 9am and conclude around noon. The BOJ is expected to take further steps to ease funding strains for companies hit by the pandemic by boosting purchases of corporate bonds and commercial paper. This change follows a similar adjustment made in March, when the BOJ replaced a scheduled rate review with an emergency policy meeting.

site_title: Bloomberg to help New York build 'army' of Covid-19 tracers
summary: Billionaire Michael Bloomberg is contributing over $10 million to help New York build a "tracing army" to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The effort aims to test, trace, and isolate residents in New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut. Governor Andrew Cuomo announced the plan, citing a need for thousands of tracers to manage the state's outbreak, which has claimed over 15,300 lives. Bloomberg's contribution will support widespread testing, which is seen as key to lifting stay-at-home orders and reopening the economy without sparking a surge in infections.

site_title: UK unveils large-scale study to track coronavirus
summary: The UK government has announced a large-scale study to track coronavirus in the general population, with 300,000 people expected to take part within a year. The study will involve regular testing of 25,000 people using self-administered swabs and blood samples from 1,000 households. Initial findings are expected in early May, which could inform the government's decisions on easing a month-long nationwide lockdown. The study aims to establish the extent of transmission and infection, predict the virus's future trajectory, and inform the development of new tests and treatments.

images.alt_text: The British government announced plans Thursday for a major study to track coronavirus in the general population, with as many as 300,000 people expected to take part within a year.

site_title: Denied a bailout, Virgin Australia is a warning for other airlines
summary: Virgin Australia, a debt-laden airline, has collapsed after handing control to administrators following a brief fight, highlighting the global airline industry's vulnerability to the coronavirus. The carrier, which was 20% owned by Singapore Airlines, had been struggling with a near-halt in passenger revenue, leading to its demise. Industry groups, including the International Air Transport Association, have warned of a surge in bankruptcies without government aid, with 25 million jobs at risk. The airline's failure exposes the challenges of managing complex ownership structures and the urgent need for rescue funds.

site_title: Delta warns of need to 'resize' after big loss on virus shutdowns
summary: Delta Air Lines reported its first quarterly loss in nearly a decade, suffering a US$534 million loss due to the coronavirus crisis, which devastated the global travel business. The airline expects a slow and choppy recovery, with chief executive Ed Bastian predicting it could take up to three years for a sustainable recovery. To protect the business, Delta will need to "resize" its operations, which Bastian acknowledged would be "painful." The company has already taken drastic measures, including parking 650 aircraft and slashing expenses by 50%.

site_title: Draft virus resolution submitted to the UN Security Council
summary: The UN Security Council has begun working on a draft resolution co-authored by Tunisia and France, urging enhanced coordination and a general cessation of hostilities in conflicts amid the coronavirus pandemic. The three-page draft, which emphasizes the urgent need for coordination, demands a general and immediate cessation of hostilities and calls for a 30-day humanitarian pause. Discussions will begin after member comments, with a possible vote early next week, and a videoconference of the five permanent members may be held on Friday to push the text. This comes after UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres called for a global ceasefire last month.

site_title: Facebook adds location of posts to curb state-led manipulation
summary: Facebook is adding location information to posts from "high-reach" accounts to curb state-led manipulation efforts. This move follows a 2016 foreign influence campaign and builds on efforts to increase transparency and provide context about messages influencing politics. Facebook has been offering location information for page administrators since 2018. The new measure aims to further boost transparency and prevent state-sponsored election manipulation.

images.alt_text: Facebook said on Wednesday it would include the location of postings from some "high-reach" accounts in a stepped-up effort to boost transparency and curb state-sponsored election manipulation efforts.

site_title: Canada provinces seek military help to combat pandemic
summary: Canada's Ontario and Quebec provinces have requested military assistance to combat the coronavirus pandemic, particularly in elderly care homes. Ontario Premier Doug Ford asked for soldiers at five of the most affected care homes, while Quebec Premier Francois Legault requested 1,000 troops. The provinces face staffing shortages and overwhelmed facilities, with many long-term care homes reporting outbreaks. The military help is expected to assist with non-medical tasks and alleviate staff workload. Ottawa is expected to respond to the requests on Thursday.

site_title: Nation-backed hackers tune attacks to Covid-19 fears: Google
summary: Nation-backed hackers are exploiting the coronavirus pandemic to target health care organizations and those working to fight the pandemic. Google has detected over 18 million pandemic-themed malware or phishing messages per day, and 240 million Covid-linked spam messages. State-sponsored groups are using Covid-19 themes as bait in phishing and malware traps, including bogus charity solicitations and fake government websites. Google is tightening security at 50,000 accounts thought to be in the crosshairs of state-sponsored hackers, and has notified targeted users with a "government-backed attacker" warning.

site_title: US probes whether traders profited off tips on Russia at Opec+
summary: The US is investigating whether traders profited from inside information on Russia's Opec+ discussions, potentially breaching US laws. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) is scrutinizing transactions involving CME Group Inc West Texas Intermediate contracts, which may have leaked information to market participants. Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is also looking into the trades. The entities involved employ individuals with ties to the Kremlin, but the traders' names have not been identified. The probe aims to determine if the traders exploited the information for financial gain.

site_title: Brent crude rebounds from more-than 20-year low; US oil up 20% in wild trade
summary: Brent crude oil prices rebounded 5.4% to $20.37 a barrel, its highest level since June 1999, amid tentative Opec supply cuts and US inventory builds. US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures rose 19.1% to $13.78 a barrel. Despite a 65% drop in Brent prices since the start of the year, oil trading remains volatile due to a growing supply glut and cratering demand amid the coronavirus pandemic. Opec producers, including Saudi Arabia and Iraq, are expected to discuss further supply cuts in June.

site_title: Dubai welcomes unwanted cruise liners at sea amid virus fears
summary: Dubai has welcomed 13 foreign cruise ships carrying 29,000 passengers and 10,000 crew members that were at sea during the coronavirus pandemic. The ships, which were granted entry despite most countries' maritime borders being closed, underwent medical tests and had most passengers and crew flown home to Europe, with none testing positive for Covid-19. The now-empty cruise liners are docked in Dubai until October, when tourism season may resume. The move aims to minimize the economic impact of the pandemic on the emirate's tourism industry.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CRCT, MCT, ST Engg, Keppel Reit, FCT, ESR-Reit
summary: Stocks to watch on Thursday saw mixed performances amid the ongoing Covid-19 situation. CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) and ESR-Reit posted significant declines in distribution per unit (DPU) due to the pandemic's impact on sales. Meanwhile, Singtel's joint venture Hooq Digital faced a global workforce reduction, while Singapore banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB are set to take charges against their oil-linked sectors. ST Engineering priced US$750 million in five-year notes, while Keppel Reit and Frasers Centrepoint Trust reported relatively stable DPU.

site_title: Europe: Shares gain on oil rebound, hopes of stimulus
summary: European shares rose 1.8% on Wednesday, rebounding from a 3% drop the previous day, driven by a rebound in oil prices and hopes of more stimulus. The Stoxx 600 index has bounced 21% from its March low, with energy and mining stocks leading the gains. Despite cautious investors, analysts expect earnings to slide 37% in the second quarter and 27.6% in the third. The European Union is set to discuss a joint long-term budget to restart economic growth, while the US House of Representatives is expected to clear a $484 billion relief package.

site_title: Singapore hits its 2020 solar deployment target
summary: Singapore has achieved its 2020 solar deployment target of 350 megawatt-peak (MWp), surpassing the goal of powering 60,000 households for a year. The Energy Market Authority and JTC have set a new target of at least 2 gigawatt-peak by 2030, equivalent to powering 350,000 households. JTC will expand its SolarLand and SolarRoof initiatives to generate clean energy via solar panels on vacant land and rooftops, contributing to the national goal and reducing carbon emissions.

images.alt_text: Singtel's new 1.65 MWp solar-energy installation at Bedok Data Centre is its largest generator of clean energy to date. It comprises 4,292 solar panels spanning about 8,205 sq m.

site_title: Shares of medical suppliers soar with rise in virus cases
summary: Shares of medical suppliers in Singapore surged as the number of coronavirus cases continued to rise globally, despite the benchmark Straits Times Index falling 0.07%. Healthcare-related companies, including Medtecs International and Healthway Medical Group, saw significant gains. The rally follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Female-centric 'Star Wars' series in works: reports
summary: Disney is developing a new female-centric "Star Wars" television series for its Disney+ streaming platform, with Leslye Headland, co-creator of "Russian Doll," attached to the project. This follows the success of "The Mandalorian." Details on the show's plot and release date have not been announced.

site_title: JAL cuts profit forecast more than 40% as virus bites
summary: Japan Airlines (JAL) has cut its annual net profit forecast by 43% due to the coronavirus pandemic, citing declining demand and cancellations of domestic events. The airline now expects 53 billion yen in net profit, down from an earlier forecast of 93 billion yen. JAL also revised down its operating profit forecast to 100 billion yen from 140 billion yen, and sales are expected to fall to 1.41 trillion yen. This downward revision follows other airlines, including Virgin Australia and ANA, which have also reduced their forecasts due to the pandemic's impact on global tourism.

site_title: FCT posts 48.7% drop in Q2 DPU on enlarged base, retained earnings
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) posted a 48.7% drop in Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.61 Singapore cents, down from 3.137 cents last year, due to an enlarged unitholders base and higher retained earnings. Income available for distribution rose 25% to S$36 million, with 50% retained and S$18 million distributed. Gross revenue increased 0.9% to S$50.2 million, while net property income fell 1.3% to S$36 million. FCT's gearing level stood at 37.4% as of March 31, and the manager has adopted a "prudent approach" to navigate the Covid-19 situation.

site_title: North Korea state media silent on Kim's health or whereabouts
summary: North Korea's state media has remained silent on the health and whereabouts of leader Kim Jong-un, despite international speculation about his health following reports he was gravely ill after a cardiovascular procedure. The lack of information is unusual, as state media typically responds quickly to questions about the leader's status. South Korean and Chinese officials, as well as US intelligence sources, have cast doubt on the reports, with US President Donald Trump saying they had not been confirmed. Kim's absence from a major anniversary ceremony has fueled speculation about his health.

site_title: Keppel Reit declares near flat Q1 DPU of 1.4 Singapore cents
summary: Keppel Reit declared a first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.4 Singapore cents, a 0.7% increase from the previous year. Despite a 3.7% decline in net property income to S$30.2 million, distributable income remained steady at S$47.3 million. The Reit's manager attributed the steady DPU to capital gains distribution of S$5 million.

site_title: Boeing to lay off 10% of workers in civil aviation: sources
summary: Boeing plans to lay off 10% of its civil aviation workers, affecting up to 7,000 employees, in an effort to cut costs due to the coronavirus-induced crisis in the airline industry. The layoffs will impact workers in the 737 MAX, 787, and 777 aircraft manufacturing units, which have been grounded for over a year following deadly crashes.

site_title: Latest Miami fashion accessory: a branded condo
summary: Luxury condos in Miami are partnering with high-end brands like Armani, Diesel, Fendi, and Porsche to stand out in the market. The trend, which predates the Covid-19 crisis, aims to attract new consumers in a crowded field. Brands are involved in various aspects, including interior design, marketing, and even sales, with some units being delivered partly decorated. The partnership is seen as a way to tap into Miami's fashion-conscious population and provide a unique selling point. Prices range from $370,000 to $5.5 million, with some projects already sold out or nearing completion.

images.alt_text: Fendi collaborated with the interior designer Fanny Haim on the beachfront Fendi Chateau Residences in Surfside, Florida.

site_title: Covid-19: Building a digital bridge to the new normal
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is accelerating the shift to digital technology and analytics, with enterprises adopting digital tools to navigate the crisis and prepare for the new normal. Key areas for refinement include: (1) leveraging technology for transparency and responsiveness, (2) replacing traditional demand forecasts with scenario-planning techniques, (3) incorporating diverse data sets to build actionable plans, (4) prioritizing digital customer experiences, (5) investing in technology architecture to accelerate digital transformation, and (6) accelerating automation efforts. By taking proactive steps in these areas, businesses can increase resilience, deepen customer relationships, and emerge better-prepared for the future.

site_title: Travel startup Klook to cut staff; co-founders ditch pay
summary: Travel startup Klook to cut staff, implementing cost-cutting measures amid the pandemic. The Hong Kong-based firm will lay off employees, put others on temporary leave, and reduce the work week. Co-founders have stopped taking a salary since February, continuing to do so until the crisis is over. The company aims to reduce costs and navigate the challenging travel industry during the pandemic.

site_title: Energy transition: Coal as the canary
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic presents a unique opportunity for a clean and just energy transition, supporting workers and communities. As the US coal industry declines, other countries like China and Germany are grappling with the transition away from coal. A "just transition" policy is proposed to support workers, communities, and vulnerable populations. This includes income support, job retraining, and investment in clean-energy research and development. The US is urged to establish a long-term industrial strategy, invest in renewable energy, and avoid propping up the legacy energy economy.

site_title: 240 staff axed by Singtel's Hooq face uncertain future
summary: Singtel's streaming service Hooq Digital has entered liquidation, resulting in the termination of 240 staff worldwide, including 98 in Singapore. Former employees expressed disappointment over the sudden decision, citing a lack of notice period and inadequate severance pay. Despite Singtel's efforts to place staff in suitable roles, many were left feeling blindsided and undervalued. The company's financial struggles, including significant losses, are attributed to a challenging market and inability to grow sustainably.

site_title: Citi Singapore commits to job postings for summer interns
summary: Citi Singapore has committed to offering full-time analyst roles to its 76 summer 2020 interns after graduation, as long as they meet the minimum requirements, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The move aims to provide certainty for the interns, who are mostly penultimate-year students from local universities. The internship, originally set to start in June, will now begin in July and last five weeks, with parts of the program potentially delivered virtually. Interns will be fully paid for the original duration, which varies between 10-12 weeks.

site_title: Netflix posts explosive growth, but warns boom may not last
summary: Netflix posted record-breaking growth, adding 15.8 million paid subscribers in the first quarter, nearly double Wall Street's forecast. The surge in subscribers is attributed to the global novel coronavirus pandemic, but executives warn that the boom may not last, expecting a decline in growth in the months ahead. Despite this, Netflix's financial results showed strong growth globally, with a record 7.5 million new subscribers forecast for the second quarter, and a first quarter of positive free cash flow since 2014.

site_title: In Canada's oil capital, a real estate glut compounds the misery
summary: Canada's oil capital, Calgary, is struggling with a real estate glut, compounded by the COVID-19 pandemic and the oil crash. Over 20% of office space is vacant, with 33% expected to be empty by early 2021, leading to falling rents, declining values, and a "huge crater" in local government finances. The city's downtown office market has expanded by millions of square feet, but now faces an epic glut, with net asking rents at less than C$15 per square foot. Unemployment is expected to rise, with Alberta Premier Jason Kenney warning of 25% unemployment.

site_title: China's banks hit by bad loans despite 1.5t yuan relief
summary: China's banks reported a slight increase in bad loans, despite a 1.5 trillion yuan relief package, due to a more lenient definition of bad debt. The non-performing loan ratio rose 0.06 percentage point to 2.04% at end March. This comes as the country's economy struggles after the coronavirus outbreak, with regulators allowing banks to defer payments and roll over loans. The move aims to mitigate the impact of the pandemic on the financial sector.

site_title: Listcos with FY-ends in Feb, March, April get extension for results release
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has granted extensions for listed firms with financial years ending in February, March, or April 2020 to release their full-year unaudited results. Those with February or March year-ends will receive a two-month extension, while those with April year-ends will get a one-month extension. The extensions were granted in consultation with the Monetary Authority of Singapore, citing practical difficulties posed by Covid-19 measures. Issuers must notify SGX RegCo by email and make announcements via SGXNet by the new due dates.

site_title: Changi Airport turns to cargo as passenger flights take a hit amid Covid-19
summary: Changi Airport Group is shifting focus to air cargo due to a 70% decline in passenger numbers in March compared to the previous year, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The airport is redirecting resources to cargo operations as passenger flights continue to be severely impacted by travel restrictions. This move aims to capitalize on the growing demand for air cargo and maintain the airport's revenue streams.

site_title: ComfortDelGro Taxi extends full rental waiver for cabbies till June 1
summary: ComfortDelGro Taxi has extended its full taxi rental waiver for drivers until June 1, following Singapore's extended circuit breaker period. This one-month extension is expected to cost the company an additional S$17 million, totaling S$116 million in relief. The move aims to support cabbies who are struggling financially during the extended circuit breaker period. Over 680 cabbies have been deployed to alternative jobs, including delivery services for major food chains.

site_title: Trump allies organise and promote anti-lockdown protests
summary: US President Donald Trump's allies are organizing and promoting anti-lockdown protests across key electoral battleground states, despite the White House's cautious guidance on relaxing restrictions. Republican politicians and Trump allies have encouraged social media followers to join the protests, which contradict the administration's recommendations for a slow and phased reopening. Many Trump supporters see the protests as endorsing the cause, despite the Trump campaign's lack of direct involvement. A Reuters/Ipsos poll shows a bipartisan majority of Americans want to continue sheltering in place, amid the US's highest number of coronavirus cases and deaths.

images.alt_text: In Michigan, the organisers of last week's rally against Democratic Governor Gretchen Whitmer's stay-at-home order aimed at combating the coronavirus pandemic are said to be involved in the Republican president's re-election effort.

site_title: Hin Leong files for JM; SCI acts to safeguard gasoil at HL unit
summary: Hin Leong Trading, a Singapore-based oil trader, has filed for judicial management instead of a debt moratorium after being pressed for time due to a US$4 billion debt pile. PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) LLP will be appointed as interim judicial manager to help fix its financials and protect its assets. This move has surprised market watchers, who say judicial management is a blunt instrument that can be value-destructive. Sembcorp Industries has also scrapped a decade-old gasoil supply and storage deal with Hin Leong to safeguard its interest.

site_title: Keppel-led group bags S$1.5b deal to develop integrated waste management plant
summary: A Keppel-led consortium has secured an S$1.5 billion engineering, procurement, and construction contract from Singapore's National Environment Agency to develop the Tuas Nexus Integrated Waste Management Facility, including a waste-to-energy plant and materials recovery facility. The project aims to improve waste management in Singapore.

site_title: Market strategists see slow economic recovery amid prolonged Covid-19 lockdowns
summary: Market strategists predict a slow economic recovery amid prolonged Covid-19 lockdowns, with a U-shaped recovery expected in the second half of the year. Countries in Asia are expected to be cautious, and easing lockdown measures too soon could lead to a second wave of infection. China is being used as an example of a recovering economy, but services sectors have yet to bounce back due to fear factors. Healthcare and quality cyclical industries like semiconductors and consumer discretionary are seen as winners, while travel, entertainment, and commercial real estate are expected to be losers.

site_title: Singapore food manufacturers scramble to comply with fresh rules
summary: Singapore's food manufacturers face a crisis amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with reduced demand, supply-chain disruptions, and cash flow issues. The government's circuit-breaker measures have halted operations for some manufacturers, while others have reduced staff strength and production. The industry is struggling to cope with a 50-80% decline in demand from the hospitality and food-services industries, and supply-chain issues are further exacerbating the problem. Manufacturers are seeking government support, including the enhanced Jobs Support Scheme, to mitigate the impact, and some are exploring alternative sales channels and product development.

images.alt_text: Singapore's food manufacturers may be facing a rare test in the form of the Covid-19 crisis, as extensive shutdowns, supply chain and cash flow issues assail them from various quarters.

site_title: Emerging Stronger taskforce will have its work cut out in a bellicose world
summary: Singapore's Emerging Stronger taskforce, co-chaired by Desmond Lee and Tan Chong Meng, aims to review the country's economic resilience and build new sources of dynamism post-Covid-19. As the pandemic's impact is felt globally, tensions between major economies, particularly the US and China, are rising. Singapore must navigate these challenges while considering reshoring manufacturing and maintaining its attractiveness as a hub for value-added services. The task force's tasks will be formidable, requiring both top-down and ground-up efforts from Singaporeans to address the threats emerging from the pandemic.

site_title: Negative oil prices breaking traders' risk models
summary: Oil prices have broken through to negative for the first time in history, causing a scramble for Wall Street banks to recalculate the value and riskiness of their trading books. The shift has exposed significant losses and triggered wild swings in the markets, with some traders facing potentially substantial losses. To address this, major exchanges such as the CME Group and ICE Brent are switching to models that can accommodate negative prices. This has led to a surge in interest in options contracts with negative strikes, with some traders already working on the assumption that oil prices could turn negative.

site_title: Tianjin Eco-City plot sells for 1.17b yuan
summary: A 10.86-hectare residential plot in the Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City was sold to Sunac China Holdings for 1.17 billion yuan (S$236.4 million), a 3.62% premium over the starting price. The plot will be developed as an ecological and liveable project with low-rise and mid-high-rise buildings, located near the China-Singapore Friendship Garden and waterfront leisure spaces. The sale is comparable to another land plot sold in 2019, and SSTEC expects high-quality residences and a transformation of the Central District into a green, smart, and liveable district.

site_title: 34 crew members on cruise ship in Japan test positive for virus
summary: At least 34 crew members on the Costa Atlantica cruise ship docked in Japan's Nagasaki city have tested positive for coronavirus. The ship, carrying around 600 crew members, underwent repairs in January. Japanese officials have not boarded the ship yet, citing concerns about safety, but are providing support and supplies. The outbreak comes months after Japan dealt with a massive outbreak on the Diamond Princess, and local officials are seeking help from neighboring regions if many crew members become severely ill.

site_title: Oil hits lowest since 1999 as coronavirus crisis hammers demand
summary: Oil prices plummeted to their lowest since 1999, with Brent crude hitting $15.98 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate falling to $10.97, amid a surge in global supply and a sharp decline in demand due to the coronavirus pandemic. Opec+ agreed to reduce output by 9.7 million barrels, but lockdowns and excess storage have led to a glut in the market. Experts warn the oil market is in deep trouble and unlikely to recover soon, with supply expected to outstrip demand for months to come.

site_title: Lagarde draws the line on how far ECB can help virus-stricken euro zone countries
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde has drawn a line on how far the ECB can help virus-stricken euro zone countries, stating that lending directly to governments would be illegal and handing out cash to citizens would be difficult. The ECB plans to buy 1.1 trillion euros in sovereign bonds this year, but Lagarde ruled out direct financing of governments and dismissed the idea of "helicopter money" drops for households. The ECB will continue to buy bonds on the secondary market, even if it comes close to owning a third of the debt of countries such as Germany and Portugal.

site_title: Hong Kong reshuffles govt as debate rages over Beijing's role
summary: Hong Kong's government has reshuffled its top officials, with Director of Immigration Erick Tsang replacing Patrick Nip as head of the Constitutional and Mainland Affairs Bureau. The move aims to revive the city's economy, which is struggling amid the pandemic and recession. However, the reshuffle has sparked concerns that Beijing is exerting more control over Hong Kong, with some lawmakers describing it as a "show of power." The changes come amid escalating tensions over Beijing's role in the city's affairs and fears of encroachment on Hong Kong's freedoms.

site_title: STI claws back early losses to end above day's low at 2,550.04
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) opened lower due to Singapore's extension of the partial lockdown period by four weeks but rebounded to close at 2,550.04, 1.88 points or 0.07% lower. Trading volume was 2.34 billion securities worth S$1.53 billion. Analysts predict a year-end target of 2,050 for the STI, citing uncertainty in sectors like banks and small caps.

site_title: Could fintech firms have the solutions governments need to tackle Covid-19?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has brought the global economy to a halt, causing widespread unemployment and disrupting supply chains. Governments are struggling to provide financial support to firms in need, but traditional banking solutions are not effective. Financial technology firms (fintechs) offer a potential solution, providing quick access to capital, transparency, and data-driven insights. Fintechs can fill the gaps left by banks and provide governments with a top-down approach to support small and medium-sized enterprises, helping to stabilize the economy and mitigate the effects of the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Global supply chains have been disrupted as countries go into lockdown. Goods are simply not flowing in the same way they used to.

site_title: US home sales post biggest monthly decline since 2015
summary: US home sales plummeted 8.5% in March, the largest monthly decline since 2015, with existing homes selling at a seasonally-adjusted annual rate of 5.27 million. The drop-off was most pronounced in the west, where sales fell 13.6%, and is attributed to lockdowns and growing job losses. Despite this, home prices rose 8% to a median of $280,600. Economists warn that April may see further declines, with unemployment rising to 22 million jobs lost in the first month of the pandemic.

site_title: Suntec Reit posts 27.7% fall in DPU for Q1; retains 10% of distributable income as virus crisis deepens in Q2
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 27.7% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.76 Singapore cents for Q1 2020, due to lower distributable income from operations and retention of distribution. The Reit's distributable income fell 6.5% to S$55.1 million, and net property income fell 7.2% to S$54 million. The company retained 10% of distributable income and waived rent for retail tenants in April 2020. Despite this, the Reit's Singapore office portfolio is expected to remain resilient, with a committed occupancy of 98.8% as of March 31.

site_title: Bagful of opportunities
summary: Vivien Ang, a 48-year-old woman with cerebral palsy, has overcome her shyness and self-doubt after finding employment at Wise Enterprise, a Singaporean fashion brand that hires people with disabilities. The company, founded by KT Soon, creates leather handbags and provides gainful employment for socially disadvantaged individuals, including those with muscular dystrophy. Noraini Bte Adnan, a pioneer batch member, has learned to converse with customers and differentiate real from fake leather. Despite challenges, Wise Enterprise aims to make the business self-sustainable within 10 years and provide opportunities for working-class women to own a bag from the brand.

site_title: Businesses offload stock, fear loss of crucial manpower
summary: Businesses in Singapore, including food and beverage companies, are scrambling to meet tightened COVID-19 measures that require them to shutter or modify operations until May 4. Excess stock and potential loss of crucial manpower are major concerns, with some exploring alternative channels to continue operations. Some companies are donating prepared food to charities, while others are offering online sales and virtual sessions to continue serving customers. The uncertainty may lead to job losses, particularly among Malaysians who may want to return home.

site_title: Trickle of bad UK property loans set to turn into a flood
summary: The UK is bracing for a surge in soured commercial property loans due to the coronavirus outbreak. A survey by Cass Business School estimates £10 billion in losses and write-offs on loans tied to UK stores and malls, with the value of bad loans increasing by over a third to £2.9 billion. Retail property has plummeted in value, leading to foreclosures and fire sales, and the pandemic's economic lockdown is further exacerbating the issue. With £43 billion of commercial property loans due to be refinanced this year and in 2021, the stakes have risen substantially.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit's DPU up 1.4% in Q1
summary: Parkway Life Reit's distribution per unit rose 1.4% to 3.32 Singapore cents in Q1, driven by additional revenue from Japan properties, rental growth, and financing cost savings. Gross revenue grew 5.2% to S$29.9 million, with net property income rising 4.5% to S$27.7 million. The Reit retained S$850,000 for Covid-19 relief measures, resulting in a S$20.1 million distributable income to unitholders. Despite ongoing uncertainties, Parkway Life Reit remains in a "stable financial position."

site_title: Beethoven the avant-gardist: A pianist makes his case
summary: French pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard planned to pair Beethoven's Opus 10 sonata with Schoenberg's serialist work and juxtapose it with Stockhausen's Klavierstück IX, as part of a recital series that would put Beethoven in the context of other avant-gardists. The event was scheduled to feature Beethoven's Opus 101 sonata alongside Sweelinck's Fantasia Chromatica and George Benjamin's canonic preludes. The planned recitals were canceled due to the coronavirus outbreak, but Aimard's innovative approach aimed to reevaluate Beethoven's relevance for modern audiences.

site_title: Singapore banks put to another major test on O&G exposure
summary: Singapore banks, including OCBC, UOB, and DBS, are likely to see an increase in non-performing loans and credit charges due to the volatility in the oil-and-gas (O&G) sector, particularly with the collapse of oil trading giant Hin Leong. The banks have significant exposure to Hin Leong, with total exposure of around US$600 million. However, analysts say they are better-positioned to weather the storm due to prudent measures taken since the 2017 shock, including provisioning and diversification of their loan portfolios.

images.alt_text: With oil trading giant Hin Leong making headlines amid the recent collapse of oil prices, the Singapore banks are set to take charges against their broader exposure to the oil-linked sectors but in a more measured way given more prudence today, analysts said.

site_title: Isec's profit fall may portend earnings weakness across healthcare sector
summary: ISEC Healthcare, a Singapore-listed medical eyecare services provider, reported a 37% drop in net profit to S$1.39 million in its first quarter, attributed to nationwide movement restrictions to curb COVID-19. The decline may signal weakness for locally listed healthcare players, including Raffles Medical Group and IHH Healthcare. Revenue fell 7% to S$9.27 million, while cost of sales increased 4% due to higher staff-related expenses. Analysts predict earnings decline for healthcare players, but expect a possible rebound in the second half of the year if the situation normalizes.

site_title: Safe havens still in demand despite markets stabilising
summary: The US dollar fell slightly against a basket of comparable currencies, but safe-haven currencies like the Japanese yen remained in demand amid market turmoil. Oil prices dropped to their lowest since 1999, despite a recent recovery, due to the coronavirus outbreak and lockdown measures. Investors sought safety, with the Canadian dollar up 0.5% against the US dollar, while the Norwegian crown remained steady. The euro remained range-bound ahead of an EU meeting to discuss financial aid, and the Australian dollar rose 0.8% after a record surge in retail sales.

site_title: North Korea media silent on Kim's whereabouts as speculation on health rages
summary: North Korea's state media has remained silent about the health and whereabouts of leader Kim Jong Un, sparking international speculation about his condition after reports he underwent a cardiovascular procedure. Despite US President Donald Trump and South Korean officials casting doubt on the reports, a US government source hinted that the possibility of Kim's health being a concern was being closely monitored. North Korea's official media continued to report on routine activities and achievements, fueling speculation that something may be amiss.

site_title: Surge in PayNow Corp sign-ups as firms seek fast support payouts
summary: Singapore businesses are rapidly adopting PayNow Corporate, a digital funds transfer service, amid the Covid-19 crisis. The service saw a 140% increase in new users between March 17 and April 17, with banks including Citi, HSBC, and Standard Chartered reporting significant jumps in registrations. The surge is driven by the government's rebate of S$750 for each work permit or S Pass holder, which can be received instantly through PayNow. This shift towards digital payments is expected to be sustainable, with experts believing it will accelerate digitalization in businesses.

site_title: SoftBank-backed travel startup Klook to cut staff; co-founders ditch pay
summary: Travel startup Klook, backed by SoftBank, is cutting staff and implementing a reduced work week to cut costs amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The company will lay off 10-20% of its workforce and reduce salaries by 20% for three months. Co-founders Ethan Lin and others will not take a salary until the crisis is over. The move is part of Klook's efforts to reduce cash burn and ensure the company's financial stability.

site_title: Doctors accused of having sex with patients agree not to contact female patients outside of work
summary: Doctors accused of having sex with patients, psychiatrist Chan Herng Nieng and surgeon Julian Ong, have agreed not to contact female patients outside of work, pending disciplinary action. The Singapore Medical Council (SMC) secured signed undertakings from both doctors after a woman complained of immoral desires. Dr Ong's accreditation was withdrawn by Parkway, and he can no longer use four hospitals, but he will continue practicing at HC Surgical's heartland centres. The SMC is investigating the complaint and has taken precautionary measures to protect patients.

images.alt_text: A woman had complained that surgeon Julian Ong (left) and psychiatrist Chan Herng Nieng had taken advantage of vulnerable female patients and colleagues "to satisfy their immoral desires".

site_title: Hong Kong pro-democracy tycoon pleads for help for his newspaper
summary: Hong Kong pro-democracy media mogul Jimmy Lai pleaded for help for his newspaper Apple Daily, citing significant losses due to advertising income slump and declining subscriptions. The paper's subscriber base has dropped to below 600,000 from 800,000, and Lai has personally invested about HK$550 million to keep the publication going. The newspaper, which has championed Hong Kong's protests against Beijing's tightening grip, faces substantial losses and political retaliation.

site_title: Be creative and get paid
summary: A new content channel, Cr8studiosg, aims to create opportunities for content creators during the COVID-19 circuit-breaker period.
