Launched on April 20, the channel partners with the National Youth Council and Creative Nation Singapore to hire people to create engaging content from their homes. The channel features themed videos on various topics, including health and wellness, dance tutorials, and entertainment, and pays content producers a sum for each video produced. Interested producers can sign up on creativenation.typeform.com/to/v7fphn.

images.alt_text: Cr8studiosg is working with a group of freelancers to produce the videos but is also running an open call for applications.

site_title: Zoom raises encryption level with upgraded meeting app
summary: Zoom Video Communications is upgrading its video conferencing app to enhance encryption features and protect meeting data. The new version, Zoom 5.0, will be released within the week. The company has faced criticism for security vulnerabilities and failing to disclose its service's encryption status. This upgrade aims to address user concerns and provide better safeguarding against tampering.

site_title: EU antitrust regulators resume probe into Boeing, Embraer deal
summary: EU antitrust regulators have resumed their investigation into Boeing's $4.2 billion bid to buy Embraer's jetmaking arm, with a decision due by August 7. The probe was halted in February while waiting for information, but the European Commission has received millions of documents since then. Concerns were raised about the deal removing Embraer as a global competitor in the commercial aircraft industry, particularly in single-aisle planes. The Brazilian competition watchdog has already approved the deal, which has backing from major aircraft buyers.

site_title: Debt-hit Hin Leong Trading files for JM
summary: Hin Leong Trading, a Singapore-based oil trader, has decided to pursue a judicial management path instead of filing for a debt moratorium, despite being pressured by its lenders over a US$4 billion debt pile. The company has hired PricewaterhouseCoopers as interim judicial manager, which has raised concerns among market watchers due to the potential for asset destruction and disruption to management. This move comes after Hin Leong revealed a significant loss of US$800 million in its financial statements and has further deepened its crisis amid a probe by Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department.

site_title: 1,016 new coronavirus cases here; Singaporean woman 12th person to die
summary: Singapore reported 1,016 new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 10,141. An 84-year-old woman, the 12th person to die from the virus, passed away on Tuesday. Foreign workers living in dormitories accounted for 967 of the new cases, with 17 being Singaporeans. The number of new cases in the community decreased, and 57 patients were discharged, leaving 896 recovered. Globally, at least 178,574 people have died from Covid-19 and 2,571,023 have been infected.

site_title: Now's an opportune time to ramp up efforts to improve BCP
summary: A robust Business Continuity Plan (BCP) is crucial for companies to survive the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak. Companies with a well-thought-out BCP are more likely to ride out the storm, while those without one may face significant challenges. Key elements of a good BCP include defined teams, detailed plans, frequent testing, effective communication, and uninterrupted IT operations. With many countries under lockdown, it's not too late to identify gaps in the BCP and transform the business to meet customer and workforce demands, potentially defining the future outcome of a company.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise as global stimulus efforts outweigh oil price plunge
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.89% on Wednesday, snapping a two-day losing streak, as global stimulus efforts outweighed concerns over plummeting oil prices. The KOSPI index closed at 1,896.15, despite foreigners selling US$30.02 million worth of shares. Meanwhile, South Korea prepares for a third supplementary budget and increased subsidies to support businesses and jobs amid the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Tyson Foods to indefinitely stop production at largest pork plant
summary: Tyson Foods has indefinitely halted production at its largest pork plant in the US, citing concerns over the rapid spread of the coronavirus. The Waterloo, Iowa, plant, which employs 2,800 workers, had already been operating at reduced capacity. The closure is the latest disruption to the US food supply chain, threatening to tighten meat supplies amid rising demand at grocery stores. The move is expected to impact farmers and contribute to the disruption of the nation's pork supply.

site_title: Coworking clients up in arms over continued fees charged by some operators
summary: Co-working operators in Singapore are facing criticism for continuing to charge membership fees despite the circuit breaker measures, which have forced them to suspend services for yet another month. Major operators including JustCo and WeWork have been accused of prioritizing their own financial interests over those of their members. Only The Working Capitol has waived fees for April, while others have announced rebates or are reviewing their policies. Members are considering refusing to pay fees due to the impossibility of using the space, and some lawyers believe they may have a case to dispute the contracts.

images.alt_text: The Business Times understands from coworking members that major operators including JustCo and WeWork continued to charge membership fees in April, even though most members were not able to use the space once circuit breaker measures were in effect.

site_title: Investors focused on value could miss out on new growth plays
summary: Retail investors in Singapore are buying into blue-chip stocks, but may be missing out on potential returns by neglecting mid-cap stocks. The Straits Times Index has declined 21% this year, while mid-cap stocks have outperformed, with some gaining over 20%. Investors seeking value in bear markets may be overlooking growth opportunities in emerging sectors, such as technology and healthcare. Local companies like Venture Corporation and Keppel DC Reit are among those benefiting from sustained demand for their products and services. Investors may consider seeking exposure to these companies for long-term growth potential.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after oil-led selloff
summary: US stock markets opened higher on Wednesday after a two-day selloff, driven by upbeat quarterly earnings reports and a record crash in oil prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.82%, the S&P 500 gained 1.88%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 2.07%. Despite companies warning of more pain in the coming months, the market sentiment lifted.

site_title: Saudi Arabia may re-route tankers if US imposes crude import ban
summary: Saudi Arabia is considering re-routing millions of barrels of oil onboard tankers sailing to the US if the US imposes a crude import ban, amid concerns over a glut of stocks and dwindling storage options. The kingdom has 40 million barrels of oil on its way to the US, with some sources suggesting it could divert the cargoes to Europe or Asia if the ban is implemented. US officials have hinted at blocking Saudi shipments or imposing tariffs, which would add significant costs for the kingdom.

site_title: Bank Indonesia makes first direct government bond buys
summary: Bank Indonesia made its first direct purchases of sovereign debt in primary auctions, buying 4.65 trillion rupiah (S$428.5 million) of government bonds to finance its ballooning fiscal deficit amid the coronavirus crisis. This move follows relaxed rules to keep yields steady. The purchases were made to stabilize the market and support the government's spending efforts.

site_title: New online channel for Thailand's food wholesalers to access region
summary: Thailand's Department of International Trade Promotion has launched a new online channel, Thaitrade.com, to facilitate food wholesalers to access regional markets. Partnering with OctoRocket, a Singapore-based business-to-business wholesale food platform, the channel aims to help Thai food manufacturers export their products and source products from South-east Asia for Thai consumers. This move is expected to encourage Thai food manufacturers to establish an online presence and source a wider variety of products to cater to the increasingly international palate of Thai consumers.

site_title: Keppel Reit declares marginally higher DPU of 1.4 Singapore cents for Q1
summary: Keppel Reit has declared a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.4 Singapore cents for the first quarter, a 0.7% increase from the previous year. Despite a 5.2% decline in net property income, the reit maintained distributable income due to capital gains distribution and lower borrowing costs. The reit's portfolio occupancy remained at 98.9%, and the weighted average lease expiry is 4.7 years. The company has taken precautions against the Covid-19 outbreak, including extending support to tenants.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index marginally up 0.16 points to 1,381.89. Volume reached 5.053 billion lots worth RM2.832 billion, with 458 gainers and 378 losers.

site_title: Listed firms with FY-ends in Feb, March and April to get reprieve for release of full-year results
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has granted a waiver to listed firms with financial years ending in February, March, or April 2020, allowing them to delay the release of their full-year unaudited results by one to two months due to the challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic. The waiver is in consultation with the Monetary Authority of Singapore and applies to firms with financial year-ends of Feb 29, March 31, and April 30, with revised release dates of June 29, July 30, and July 29, respectively.

site_title: US renews criticism of China's early handling of coronavirus outbreak
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo criticized China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, stating the ruling communist party failed to report the outbreak to the World Health Organisation in a timely manner. Beijing was accused of not reporting human-to-human transmission for a month, until it was widespread across the country. The US has previously criticized China's response, which has resulted in a global pandemic that has killed nearly 180,000 people, including over 45,000 in the US. The Trump administration's criticism continues to pressure China's policymakers.

site_title: Living in a brave new world when all this is over
summary: The COVID-19 crisis has brought about a temporary environmental improvement, with reduced air pollution and wildlife returning to areas previously affected. However, experts warn that old habits will likely return unless governments prioritize environmental sustainability in their recovery plans. This may involve changes in agricultural practices, building construction, and infrastructure development. Climate-conscious architect Jason Pomeroy suggests that the pandemic will drive shifts in architectural practices, but long-term sustainability will depend on government leadership and a fundamental shift in human relationships with the environment.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on oil, virus fears
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday due to concerns over the oil market and the coronavirus crisis, which has reduced global energy demand. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.74% and the Topix index declined 0.63%. The decline was attributed to ongoing worries over the oil market, with the benchmark index ending at 19,137.95.

site_title: Singapore hits 2020 solar deployment target, JTC to extend industrial initiatives
summary: Singapore has met its 2020 solar deployment target of 350 megawatt-peak (MWp), powering about 60,000 households a year. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) and JTC have announced plans to extend industrial initiatives, including the SolarLand and SolarRoof programmes, to increase solar energy adoption and contribute to the country's goal of at least 2 gigawatt-peak of solar deployment by 2030.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust declares lower Q4 DPU to 'exercise prudence'
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust has declared a lower quarterly distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.91 Singapore cents for Q4 2020, down from 2.31 Singapore cents in the previous year, due to exercising prudence amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite a 10.5% rise in distributable income, the trust retained S$43.7 million of the original distributable amount, leaving S$30.1 million available for distribution. The trust's CEO cited uncertainty over normalcy's return and measures taken to combat Covid-19 as reasons for the lower DPU.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day with a 0.42% gain, closing at 23,893.36. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.60%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 1.05%. Investors remain uncertain due to the coronavirus outbreak and oil market rout.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index added 0.42 per cent, or 99.81 points, to 23,893.36.

site_title: Changi Airport Group eyes cargo as passenger flights impacted by Covid-19
summary: Changi Airport Group is shifting focus to air cargo due to a 70% decline in passenger numbers in March, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. To maintain global supply distribution, freighter carriers operate round the clock and passenger airlines deploy aircraft for cargo-only flights. This move aims to narrow the capacity gap and ensure the delivery of vital supplies worldwide.

site_title: Australia to spend US$59m buying oil to store in US reserve
summary: Australia has agreed to spend $59 million to buy crude oil from the US Strategic Petroleum Reserve, taking advantage of historically low oil prices. The move aims to increase Australia's emergency oil stockpile to meet International Energy Agency fuel security rules. The deal will allow Australia to store over 5 million barrels of crude, helping US producers affected by the coronavirus pandemic. The agreement, announced in March, will see Australia lease space in the SPR for 10 years, with the goal of building a local fuel reserve to meet its IEA obligation.

site_title: Keppel-led group bags S$1.5b contract to develop integrated waste management plant
summary: A Keppel-led consortium, comprising Keppel Seghers Engineering Singapore, China Harbour (Singapore) Engineering Company, and ST Engineering Marine, has been awarded a S$1.5 billion contract to develop a waste-to-energy facility and a materials recovery facility at Singapore's Tuas Nexus Integrated Waste Management Facility. The project, valued at 2,900 tonnes per day, is expected to be completed in 2024 and will be one of the largest facilities in Singapore upon completion.

site_title: Ships, trains, caves: Oil traders chase storage space in world awash with fuel
summary: Oil traders face a global storage shortage amid the coronavirus crisis, with dozens of ships booked to store 30 million barrels of fuel at sea. This adds to 130 million barrels of crude already in floating storage, as on-land tanks fill up or are booked. The abundance of supply and plummeting demand have led to this unusual storage solution, with oil tanker vessels and railcars used as alternatives.

site_title: Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City land plot sold for S$236.4m
summary: Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City's 10.86-hectare residential land plot was sold for S$236.4 million (1.17 billion yuan) in a land tender on April 22, 2020. The winning bid was made by Sunac China Holdings' unit, Tianjin Sunac Real Estate Co, marking its first foray into the Eco-City. The plot will be developed into an ecological and liveable project comprising low-rise and mid-high-rise buildings, with SSTEC's CEO Tay Lim Heng expressing confidence in Sunac's ability to deliver high-quality residences.

site_title: Fight Covid-19's fallout from the communications frontlines
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, businesses are being forced to adapt to an online-only environment, with a thoughtful approach to communications crucial for success. Key considerations include having a clear online presence, ensuring consumers are informed about offerings, and being transparent about potential obstacles. Fact-checking information is also essential, especially in an "infodemic" environment, where fake news can spread quickly. Furthermore, leveraging community engagement and social media can help bring industry peers together and build credibility. By taking a strategic approach to online communications, businesses can navigate the challenges of the pandemic and emerge stronger.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded at the open on Wednesday, with London gaining 0.8%, Frankfurt 0.9%, and Paris 0.3%. The rebound followed a decline of 3-4% on Tuesday. Oil prices continued to slide, but mining and healthcare shares supported gains.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore banks are set to face a test on their oil and gas exposure amid the current oil price collapse. Analysts expect a more measured approach, given increased prudence. Meanwhile, Changi Airport Group is operating round-the-clock to maintain global supply distribution, and passenger airlines are deploying aircraft for cargo-only flights. Singapore has achieved its 2020 solar deployment target, and Citi Singapore is offering full-time analyst jobs to its summer interns. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 1.88 points lower, or 0.07%, following the extension of the partial lockdown period.

images.alt_text: With oil trading giant Hin Leong making headlines amid the current collapse of oil prices, the Singapore banks are set to take charges against their broader exposure to the oil-linked sectors but in a more measured way given more prudence today, analysts said.

site_title: Epic Games is fundraising at above US$15b value: sources
summary: Epic Games, the maker of Fortnite and Houseparty, is fundraising at a valuation above $15 billion, according to sources. The company has hired a financial adviser to handle the fundraising, which could raise between $500 million and $1 billion. This move comes as the company's popularity has surged during the pandemic. The exact amount and timing of the fundraising are still private, but the valuation suggests a significant increase in the company's worth.

site_title: Oil plunges again as virus ravages energy markets
summary: Oil prices plummeted, with Brent crude dropping 12.31% to $16.98 a barrel and US WTI falling around 5% to $11 a barrel, due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic's impact on energy markets. Storage facilities are approaching full capacity, and the crisis has been worsened by a price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia. Analysts predict prices will remain suppressed in the near-term until the pandemic is brought under control.

site_title: Coronavirus second wave may be even worse: US health chief
summary: US health chief Robert Redfield warns a second wave of the novel coronavirus could be even more destructive due to its collision with the beginning of flu season. The US has over 800,000 confirmed Covid-19 cases and 44,845 deaths. Redfield advises Americans to prepare and get flu shots to mitigate the impact of the two epidemics. The overlapping of the two diseases could strain healthcare systems and lead to a more challenging situation.

site_title: Plane-leasing firm BOC Aviation tests bond markets with travel halted
summary: BOC Aviation, a Singapore-based aircraft leasing company, is testing bond markets during the coronavirus pandemic, which has severely impacted the global aviation industry. The company is offering five-year notes at a premium of 330 basis points over US Treasuries, significantly wider than similar debt sold in January. This move diversifies bond investors as BOC Aviation counts several airline companies as clients, and its strong balance sheet is expected to benefit from depressed aircraft prices and increased demand for sale-and-leasebacks. The company's business offers a silver lining in the challenging times for the airline industry.

site_title: STI opens lower and closes still down 1.88 points
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 1.88 points lower, or 0.07% at 2,550.04, after Singapore extended its partial lockdown period by four weeks. Trading volume was 2.34 billion securities worth S$1.53 billion. Analysts at CGS-CIMB predict a decline in market earnings per share in 2020 and 2021 due to recessionary environment, and expect more downside to 2021 forecasts. The Hang Seng rose 0.42%, while the Nikkei fell 0.74%.

site_title: 84-year-old S'porean woman is 12th person to die from Covid-19; 1,016 new cases
summary: An 84-year-old Singaporean woman has become the 12th person to die from Covid-19 complications in the country, with a total of 10,141 cases reported. 1,016 new cases were announced, with 967 being foreign workers in dormitories and 17 Singaporeans and permanent residents. The number of new cases in the community has decreased, and 57 patients have been discharged, leaving 4,999 patients in community isolation.

site_title: Dutch staffing group Randstad sees tougher Q2 as coronavirus bites
summary: Randstad, a Netherlands-based staffing company, reported a 29% decline in core earnings to 162 million euros in the first quarter due to the impact of the coronavirus. Sales also dropped 5% to 5.4 billion euros, missing analyst expectations. The company forecast a "more challenging" second quarter, citing ongoing business disruptions from the pandemic.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat as record retail sales spur recovery
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Wednesday, rebounding from a 2.3% drop earlier in the session, as record retail sales data boosted the market. Retail sales surged in March due to virus-led panic buying, potentially staving off a contraction in the economy. However, analysts expect broader consumption to fall sharply in the first half of 2020. Energy stocks recovered, but still ended 1.1% lower due to oversupply fears and low oil prices.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS downgrades Koufu to 'hold', sees reduced footfall hurting earnings
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded Koufu to "hold" due to reduced footfall at foodcourts affecting earnings. The analysts cut their 12-month target price to S$0.68 from S$0.84, citing a 5-19% earnings forecast cut. The extended circuit-breaker period and lower tourist arrivals are impacting earnings, particularly at Macau and Marina Bay Sands outlets. DBS notes potential catalysts include a Covid-19 recovery, economies of scale, and special dividends, but highlights earnings risks such as lease renewals, new outlet acquisitions, and competition.

site_title: Citi Singapore to offer summer interns full-time analyst jobs amid 'challenging times'
summary: Citi Singapore will offer 76 summer 2020 interns full-time analyst jobs after graduation, providing a measure of stability during the COVID-19 pandemic. The move applies to interns who meet the minimum programme requirements, and the analyst role is the new name for the management associate programme. Due to the pandemic, the internship start date has been delayed to July and its duration shortened to five weeks. Interns will still receive full pay for the original duration of the programme.

site_title: Citi says Singapore GDP to shrink 8.5% as restrictions extended
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to contract by 8.5% in 2020 due to the extended partial lockdown, according to Citigroup. The circuit-breaker measures, extended until June 1, will cause 25-30% of GDP to stand still, resulting in a deeper recession. The revised forecast is wider than the earlier estimate of a 6% fall.

images.alt_text: Singapore will witness a deeper recession this year after the nation extended and tightened its partial lockdown, Citigroup warned, widening its forecast for an economic contraction.

site_title: Scarred by 2017, Singapore banks to face test on O&G exposure again
summary: Singapore banks are set to face another test of their oil and gas (O&G) exposure amid the current collapse of oil prices, but analysts say they are better positioned to weather the storm. The banks have significant provisions made since the 2017 shock, with DBS' O&G exposure making up 5% of customer loans and OCBC's NPL ratio for O&G loans at 0.8%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has reminded banks not to de-risk indiscriminately from the bunkering and oil trading sectors, but analysts expect the banks to take prudent measures to manage their exposure.

site_title: Facebook, STB, Enterprise Singapore offer free online training for firms in virus-hit sectors
summary: Facebook, Singapore Tourism Board, and Enterprise Singapore have launched a free online training program for businesses in virus-hit sectors such as travel, hospitality, and retail in Singapore. The program, starting April 30, offers webinars to help firms upskill their workforce, adapt business models, and stay connected with customers during the pandemic. The training is available at digitalupskillingsg.splashthat.com, and Facebook has also launched a business resource hub with tools and guidance to aid businesses in managing and building resilience during the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: In China, when small businesses get loans they buy property
summary: China's subsidized small business loans have been used by entrepreneurs to buy property, rather than invest in salaries or working capital, despite government efforts to support the economy. The central bank established 1.8 trillion yuan in re-lending facilities, but instead of being used for intended purposes, these funds have fueled a real estate frenzy in Shenzhen, with home prices rising 9.7% in March. This has raised concerns about the effectiveness of the stimulus and the role of property ownership in Chinese businesses.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 20.99 points, or 1.52%, to 1,360.74, with volume reaching 142.27 million lots worth RM34.20 million. Losers outpaced gainers 344 to 30 on Wednesday.

site_title: Virus-hit news industry needs tech giant aid: UK union
summary: The UK's main journalists' union is calling on the government to triple a tax on global tech giants to support the struggling news industry. The National Union of Journalists warns that up to 5,000 jobs could be lost due to declining print sales and advertising revenue amid the coronavirus outbreak. The union proposes a "news recovery plan" funded by increased taxes on tech companies, urging the government to act urgently to prevent widespread job losses.

images.alt_text: The main union representing journalists in Britain is calling on the government to triple a tax on global tech giants to support the industry, as it faces fresh shocks from the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Australia retail sales surge in March, might avert Q1 GDP contraction
summary: Australian retail sales surged by 8.2% seasonally adjusted in March, the largest on record, driven by panic buying of food and other staples during the coronavirus lockdown. This boost lifted sales to an all-time high of A$30 billion, adding 0.5 percentage point to the country's GDP. Despite economists' predictions of a Q1 contraction, the unexpected windfall may keep growth positive, albeit temporarily.

site_title: SoFi acquires Hong Kong startup 8 Securities in first global push
summary: SoFi, a US-based financial services company, has acquired Hong Kong startup 8 Securities, marking its first global expansion. The acquisition, valued at an undisclosed price, will allow SoFi to offer fee-free stock trading on over 15,000 US and Hong Kong stocks. SoFi's CEO, Anthony Noto, stated that Hong Kong is a "financial capital of Asia ripe for innovation." The move follows SoFi's recent buyout of Galileo Financial Technologies and valuation of US$4.3 billion.

site_title: Malaysia's March CPI falls 0.2% y-o-y, slightly faster than forecast
summary: Malaysia's consumer prices fell 0.2% in March, the first decline in over a year, driven by lower transport costs, particularly retail fuel prices. The drop was offset by higher prices in food, communication, and housing. This marks a slight acceleration from the forecasted 0.1% drop. The central bank expects headline inflation to average between -1.5% and 0.5% this year, lower than 0.7% last year, due to coronavirus curbs.

site_title: Hong Kong reshuffles government as war of words intensifies with Beijing
summary: Hong Kong's government has been reshuffled as tensions with Beijing escalate, with Erick Tsang replacing Patrick Nip as head of the Constitutional and Mainland Affairs Bureau. The move comes after Beijing reaffirmed its authority over the city, raising concerns of a potential revival of anti-government protests. Carrie Lam's administration has rejected calls to step down despite admitting to causing "unforgivable havoc" last year. Beijing's increasing influence has sparked debate over the city's autonomy, with the government's conflicting statements over the Liaison Office fueling tensions.

site_title: Oxley's The Addition condo in Potong Pasir obtains TOP
summary: Oxley Holdings' freehold residential project The Addition in Potong Pasir has obtained the temporary occupation permit (TOP). The eight-storey condominium, with 26 apartments, is fully sold and valued at S$36.8 million. Located near Potong Pasir MRT station, it marks the first of Oxley's 10 ongoing projects to achieve TOP. The developer had previously purchased the site for S$21.53 million.

site_title: Australian dollar saved by data surprise, but oil a drag
summary: The Australian dollar rebounded 0.4% to US$0.6314 after strong retail sales data in March, offsetting global risk aversion and a slump in oil prices. The data, which showed a 8.2% surge in sales, surprised bears and analysts, who emphasized that sales likely declined in April. Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe warned of a 10% economic contraction, but the RBA has been able to keep yields low through private demand for Australian debt.

site_title: Japan's coronavirus mask handout tainted by gripes over mould, stains, insects
summary: Japan's government has faced criticism over its coronavirus mask distribution program, with complaints of mould, stains, and insects on the masks. The Health Ministry has received nearly 2,000 complaints, mostly from pregnant women, and has asked manufacturers to replace defective products. The issue has fueled concerns over the government's handling of the pandemic, with some calling for a lockdown and better testing and medical equipment. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government is under pressure to ensure public confidence in the safety of the masks, which were distributed to every household at a cost of $430 million.

site_title: Hot stock: Covid-19 test maker Biolidics sees 54.6% jump in share price
summary: Biolidics, a cancer diagnostics firm, saw a 54.6% jump in its share price due to negotiations with a potential US distributor for its Covid-19 rapid test kits. The company also pursued regulatory authorisation for the test kits in the European Union, the Philippines, and Singapore. Biolidics reported its substantial shareholder Clearbridge Health's share price surged 69.6% as the company's wholly-owned subsidiary Clearbridge BSA held a 24.8% stake in Biolidics. The company's market cap reached $139.3 million.

site_title: Hong Kong's central bank sells HK$2.79b after HK dollar rises to trading limit
summary: Hong Kong's central bank, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, sold HK$2.79 billion of Hong Kong dollars after the currency hit its trading band limit of 7.85 per US dollar for the first time since December 2015. The move came after the currency rose on Tuesday. The Hong Kong dollar is pegged to the US dollar at a fixed rate.

site_title: More than 2,700 dead in US from coronavirus in last 24 hours
summary: The US coronavirus death toll has risen by 2,751 in the past 24 hours, bringing the total to 44,845 deaths, according to Johns Hopkins University. The country has also reported over 800,000 confirmed cases of Covid-19.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open on Wednesday on back foot
summary: Hong Kong shares opened on Wednesday with a 1.06% drop, or 253.01 points, to 23,540.54, following a sell-off on Wall Street and a rout on oil markets. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.46% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.77%. The losses come amid investor concerns over global market volatility.

site_title: US starts contact tracing the old-fashioned way, but 'it's late'
summary: The US has begun contact tracing efforts, but it's considered "late" due to the country's emphasis on personal privacy and decentralized system of government, unlike Taiwan and South Korea, which have led the world in digital contact tracing. Thousands of public health workers will manually phone individuals who came into close contact with confirmed COVID-19 cases, requiring significant resources and time. Experts estimate the US would need 100,000 contact tracers to effectively manage the outbreak, but recruiting efforts are expected to start in two to four weeks.

site_title: Equinix, Singapore fund GIC to invest in cloud data centres in Japan
summary: Equinix, a data centre firm, has signed a joint venture worth over $1 billion with Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC to build three data centres in Japan for the cloud computing market. The three centres, located in Tokyo and Osaka, will target large operators and house 12-18 customers each. Equinix will run the operations, with GIC owning 80% equity. The joint venture is expected to close in the second half of 2020, with Equinix funding a portion with debt.

site_title: South Korea prepares third supplementary budget, aims to protect jobs
summary: South Korea's President Moon Jae In announced plans to prepare a third supplementary budget, worth 100 trillion won, to protect jobs during the coronavirus outbreak. The 40 trillion won fund will help businesses keep jobs, and a 500,000 won subsidy will be provided to those who lost temporary or freelance work. The government will also increase its rescue package to 135 trillion won and establish a "key sector stabilisation fund" to protect key sectors from failing. The measures aim to keep jobs and support businesses struggling due to low credit ratings.

images.alt_text: South Korea President Moon Jae In said on Wednesday the government will prepare a third supplementary budget and sharply increase subsidies to keep more Koreans in jobs through the course of the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop nearly 2% as overnight oil crash curbs risk appetite
summary: Australian shares fell nearly 2% on Wednesday as energy stocks plummeted due to a 2% surge in Brent oil prices, which underscored fears of a severe economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic. The S&P/ASX 200 index hit its lowest level in over two weeks, with energy stocks dropping 3.5% and the benchmark index shedding 7% for the week. Analysts warn of "exceptionally high short-term price volatility" and "global markets teetering on the edge of a second leg down."

site_title: Facebook to invest US$5.7b in India's Jio Platforms
summary: Facebook is investing US$5.7 billion in India's Jio Platforms, becoming the largest minority shareholder with a 10% stake. The deal values Jio Platforms at US$66 billion, expanding Facebook's foothold in India's rapidly growing online market. The investment will also enable JioMart, an e-commerce venture, and WhatsApp to connect with businesses, aligning with Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg's expansion plans in the country.

site_title: US oil prices jump after massive rout
summary: US oil prices surged on Wednesday, with West Texas Intermediate rising 18.93% to $13.76 a barrel, after plummeting to a record low of minus $40.32 the previous night. European benchmark Brent crude also increased 0.98% to $19.52 a barrel. The price jump comes as traders scrambled to sell oil before contracts expired and storage capacity filled up. The price collapse was triggered by a coronavirus-induced demand shock, which has been exacerbated by the US-China trade tensions and the recent OPEC decision to trim oil demand for the next four years.

site_title: Coffee is one routine New Yorkers won't give up
summary: In New York, coffee shops remain open as "essential retail" during the pandemic, serving as a symbol of local support and routine. Many owners risk their staff's safety to maintain business, while customers appreciate the human interaction and sense of normalcy. Regulars like Lesley Berson and Noelle Quanci visit cafes for takeout or delivery, cherishing the opportunity to socialize and maintain a connection to their community. Despite financial challenges, coffee shop employees find meaning in their work, with many describing it as a source of comfort and emotional support.

images.alt_text: For many New Yorkers, the ritual of grabbing a daily coffee is one of the last luxuries they are holding on to while social distancing.

site_title: No last goodbye for Gulf migrant workers lost to pandemic
summary: A funeral for a deceased Indian migrant worker in Dubai took place without a last goodbye due to the pandemic. The worker's body was cremated without any family members or friends in attendance, and the ashes were placed in a silver box. The incident highlights the challenges faced by migrant workers during the pandemic, who often struggle to receive proper burials and farewells. The situation underscores the need for greater support and respect for these workers, who make significant contributions to the global economy.

site_title: Coronavirus takes mental toll on New York's medical staff
summary: New York City's medical staff, particularly those in the ICU, are facing a significant mental toll due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Long hours, fear of contagion, and the high risk of death are taking a toll on their mental health, with many experiencing anxiety, depression, and PTSD. The hospital has implemented measures to support staff, including mental health hotlines, virtual support groups, and meditation classes, but the situation remains dire, with at least 26 hospital employees having died from the virus.

site_title: Netflix profits soar as pandemic shut-ins sign up
summary: Netflix reported soaring profits, with a profit of US$709 million on revenue of US$5.8 billion in the first three months of 2020, driven by a surge in paid subscriptions, which grew by 15.7 million to nearly 183 million. The increase in subscribers was largely due to lockdowns during the pandemic.

site_title: IMF, regional financing arrangements agree to co-finance pandemic responses
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and regional financing arrangements have agreed to co-finance pandemic responses, working together to mitigate the economic and financial impacts of the coronavirus pandemic. The institutions will facilitate co-financing operations and coordinate assistance across different regions. This effort aims to support vulnerable countries and is modeled on previous collaborations, such as the IMF's work with the European Union and European Central Bank during the Greek debt crisis.

site_title: Kering cautious on China rebound after coronavirus hits Gucci sales
summary: Kering, the parent company of Gucci, reported a 15.4% decline in sales to 3.2 billion euros in the first quarter, mainly due to store closures and production shutdowns in Europe. Gucci's sales, which account for 37% of its Asia excluding Japan revenue, fell 23.2% like-for-like. However, financial chief Jean-Marc Duplaix noted an improvement in sales for mainland China as shops reopen, but cautioned it's too early to draw conclusions about the rebound.

site_title: Covid-19: Only 44 startups in Silicon Valley funded last month
summary: Tech investors in Silicon Valley are becoming more cautious due to the economic downturn caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Compared to this time last year, funding rounds are now resulting in a 46% increase in startup valuations, down from 117% in January. This suggests that investors are handing out fewer checks and are being more selective, with only 44 startups receiving funding last month, a significant decrease from the previous period.

site_title: STI slides as market braces for bad news from PM Lee's virus update
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed down 1.77% at 2,551.92 on Tuesday, with 341 losers outnumbering 111 gainers. The market was bearish after May futures contracts for US crude oil grade WTI turned negative for the first time. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced a four-week extension to June 1 of the partial lockdown measures, causing investors to brace for bad news. Regional markets, including the Hang Seng and KLSE, also fell 2.22%.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower after govt extends circuit breaker; STI down 0.9%
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on April 22, 2020, after the government extended the circuit breaker period by a month to combat the coronavirus. The Straits Times Index fell 0.9% to 2,529.03, with healthcare-related counters seeing gains. Biolidics rose 17.8% after announcing the distribution of Covid-19 rapid test kits in the US. The Dow Jones tumbled 2.7% on Wall Street, overshadowing progress on small business relief.

site_title: Harvard says to keep stimulus grant after Trump vows it will be returned
summary: Harvard University plans to keep an $8.6 million stimulus grant despite US President Donald Trump's vow to return it, citing the university's large endowment. Trump claimed Harvard should pay back the money, but the university stated it will direct 100% of the funds to financial assistance for students, not institutional costs. This decision comes as the US stimulus package has been marred by controversy over large companies receiving bailout funds while small businesses struggle.

site_title: Europe: Shares tumble on oil crash, pandemic worries
summary: European stocks plummeted 3.4% on Tuesday, snapping a three-session winning streak, due to a historic plunge in US crude prices and disappointing quarterly earnings reports. The Stoxx 600 index fell, with basic materials stocks declining 6% and energy stocks losing 4.3%. Investors are worried about the impact of the pandemic on the global economy and oil demand, with many energy companies cutting capital spending and delaying projects. The decline in oil prices has also raised concerns about dividend payments for oil companies.

site_title: Europe's banks brace for bad debt build up from coronavirus crisis
summary: Europe's banks are bracing for potential loan losses due to the coronavirus crisis, with analysts expecting billions of dollars in provisions for bad debt. The crisis has already led to a revision of loan loss provisions by 130% for Europe's most important banks, while full-year profit forecasts have been cut by 40%. European banks face pressure to be realistic about the looming downturn, with regulators set to be lenient on accounting rules. The vulnerability of European banks was highlighted by a credit rating agency, which took 116 rating actions on Western European banks, mainly revising their outlook to negative.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on continued risk sentiment
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, extending falls on Wall Street due to continued concerns over the oil market amid the coronavirus crisis. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.03% and the Topix index dropped 0.84%. This follows a decline on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade uncertainty and tariff concerns.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, extending falls on Wall Street amid continued worries over the oil market as the coronavirus crisis cripples global energy demand.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q1 DPU falls 27.7% to 1.76 S cents
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 27.7% decline in distribution per unit to 1.76 Singapore cents for the first quarter ended March 31, 2020, due to lower distributable income from operations and an enlarged unit base. Distributable income fell 6.5% to S$55.1 million. Operational performance declined after the implementation of COVID-19 measures, impacting events and advertising income. The Reit's Singapore office portfolio is expected to remain resilient, while Suntec City Mall is expected to experience a substantial decline in shopper traffic in Q2.

site_title: South African president unveils 500b rand virus relief plan
summary: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa announced a 500 billion rand (S$37.7 billion) relief package to support the economy and vulnerable citizens during the coronavirus pandemic. The package, approximately 10% of the country's GDP, includes grants, food parcels, and job protection measures. The plan aims to stabilize the economy, address supply and demand decline, and protect jobs, particularly for the 30% of South Africans who were unemployed before the virus struck.

site_title: Boeing names CFO to manage new group overseeing key operations
summary: Boeing has named CFO Greg Smith to oversee a newly formed group managing key operations, including enterprise operations, finance, and manufacturing, effective May 1. Smith aims to restore production and supply chain health as the aerospace industry recovers from the Covid-19 pandemic. Boeing has delivered 50 planes in the first quarter, the lowest since 1984, due to the pandemic and regulatory issues. The company is restarting commercial airplane operations in Washington and seeks $60 billion in government assistance. Boeing's 737 MAX is expected to return to service in late May after addressing software issues.

site_title: Trump says immigration suspension to last 60 days
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a 60-day suspension of immigration for green-card seekers, citing the need to protect US jobs. The move aims to put unemployed Americans first in line for jobs as the country reopens. Trump made the announcement during a pandemic briefing, amid the US having over 43,000 coronavirus-related deaths. The decision is seen as a key move to appease his conservative base, but its impact on the economy is uncertain.

site_title: Lord & Taylor explores bankruptcy: sources
summary: Lord & Taylor is exploring bankruptcy protection after temporarily shutting its 38 US department stores due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. The retailer, owned by Le Tote, is considering options such as negotiating with creditors and finding additional financing. Le Tote acquired Lord & Taylor last year from Hudson's Bay Company for $100 million, with Hudson's Bay keeping ownership of some real estate and rent payments. Neiman Marcus Group and JC Penney Company are also considering bankruptcy.

site_title: US: Stocks end sharply down for second straight day, Dow -2.7%
summary: US stocks plummeted for the second consecutive day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 2.7% to 23,018.88. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also dropped 3.1% and 3.5%, respectively. The decline was driven by concerns over the oil market's supply glut, the uncertainty of the coronavirus's impact on the economy, and companies withdrawing their profit forecasts. Additionally, sales of existing homes dropped 8.5% in March, and a US$480 billion emergency package for small businesses failed to boost the market.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks tumbled for a second straight session on Tuesday as worries about chaos in the oil market overshadowed progress in Washington on additional relief for small businesses.

site_title: Mexico to shut some oil wells, refine more as prices crater
summary: Mexico's state-owned oil company Pemex will shut production at newly drilled oilfields and refine more oil as oil prices plummet into negative territory due to low global demand. President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador announced the plan to ride out the crisis, citing the company's investment in new wells as a reason for the move. Mature fields will be harder to close due to artificially created pressure. The move aims to boost national refining and increase domestic production of petrol, but may not increase petrol output. Pemex faces a record loss this year and relies on hedging programs to mitigate the impact of low oil prices.

site_title: New Zealand's NZX faces technical issues as trading volumes soar
summary: New Zealand's NZX faced technical issues due to a surge in trading volumes since early 2020, mainly affecting its clearing and settlement system. The exchange has appointed Ernst & Young for an independent review and potential remediation actions, including hardware and software upgrades. The issues occurred amid global market volatility caused by the coronavirus outbreak and historic oil price crash. NZX attributed the surge in trading volumes to unprecedented demand in the New Zealand share market.

site_title: Money FM podcast: circuit breaker and our mental health
summary: Claressa Monteiro on Money FM 89.3 discusses mental health during the Singapore circuit breaker. She speaks with Dr. Morrison Loh, clinical director of Raffles Health Insurance Group, about strategies to protect mental well-being and coping mechanisms for healthcare workers. The conversation also touches on the #StayAtHome photography competition by Raffles Group.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Keppel DC Reit, Suntec Reit, Parkway Life Reit, Oxley
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singapore stocks are under scrutiny due to new developments. United Overseas Bank (UOB) plans to offer pre-approved loans to ease liquidity woes of small businesses. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is expected to report a 30% quarter-on-quarter jump in net profit. Keppel DC Reit's demand for services is expected to hold up despite the pandemic. Suntec Reit's distribution per unit dropped 27.7% in the first quarter. Parkway Life Reit's distribution per unit rose 1.4%. Oxley Holdings received a temporary occupation permit for a residential project. ISEC Healthcare posted a 37% drop in net profit.

site_title: No benefit, higher death rate for malaria drug in coronavirus study
summary: A US government-funded study found that hydroxychloroquine, a malaria drug touted as a potential Covid-19 cure, showed no benefit and was associated with more deaths compared to standard care. The study, conducted on American military veterans, has significant limitations but adds to growing doubt about the medicine's efficacy. The results contradict President Donald Trump's support for the drug, which was also backed by Fox News. The study's findings highlight the need for further research and caution against the use of unproven treatments.

site_title: US dollar surges, oil-linked currencies fall
summary: The US dollar surged against most major currencies on Tuesday as investors sought a safe haven amid a plunge in oil prices. Oil-linked currencies, such as the Norwegian krone and Canadian dollar, fell sharply, while the Swedish krona also declined due to concerns about a deeper and longer oil supply glut. The Norwegian krone hit a near one-month low, and the Canadian dollar fell to a three-week low. Meanwhile, the British pound declined due to investors offloading assets to raise cash, and the euro remained steady despite a survey showing improved mood among German investors.

site_title: SPH reports higher y-o-y bookings for UK student dorms
summary: SPH reports higher-than-expected bookings for 60% of its UK student accommodation properties, with 65% of target revenue achieved for the 2020/2021 academic year. This is a higher percentage than at the same time last year. The group also disclosed a £4.5 million (S$8 million) reduction in revenue due to the Covid-19 crisis, with 20% of this amount in the form of credits for students returning to their existing housing. The company remains positive on the UK student accommodation sector's long-term fundamentals.

site_title: Deal reached to fund virus-hit US small businesses: top Republican
summary: US lawmakers and the White House have reached a bipartisan agreement on a $480 billion emergency package to help small businesses devastated by the coronavirus crisis. The deal includes $320 billion for the Paycheck Protection Programme, $75 billion for hospitals, $25 billion for coronavirus testing, and $60 billion for economic injury disaster loans. The Senate is expected to pass the package on Tuesday before it heads to the House of Representatives, providing relief to small businesses hit hard by the pandemic.

images.alt_text: "I welcome this bipartisan agreement and hope the Senate will quickly pass it once members have reviewed the final text," Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said in a statement.

site_title: Google to make online shopping service free to merchants
summary: Google is opening its online shopping service, Google Shopping, to merchants free of charge in the US by the end of April, with plans to expand globally by the end of the year. The move aims to compete with Amazon in e-commerce and digital ads. Previously, only retailers who paid to promote products were featured. Google will display paid ads alongside free listings, and is working with PayPal to facilitate financial transactions. The move aims to provide relief for struggling businesses during the pandemic and lay the groundwork for a healthier retail ecosystem.

site_title: A passion for robotics and sports medicine
summary: Dr. Alan Cheung, a consultant orthopaedic surgeon, has established International Orthopaedic Clinic (IOC) as a leading orthopaedic and sports medicine clinic in the region. With a passion for robotics and sports medicine, Cheung aims to provide optimal treatment for patients with osteoarthritis and sports injuries. His clinic has supported numerous international sporting events, including SuperRugby, the Rugby World Cup, and One Championship. Cheung's expertise is rooted in his global experience, including training in the US, Australia, and England, and his ability to empathize with patients from diverse backgrounds.

site_title: ISEC Healthcare Q1 net profit slumps 37% due to Covid-19 movement curbs
summary: ISEC Healthcare reported a 37% drop in Q1 net profit to S$1.39 million due to nationwide movement restrictions in Malaysia and Singapore to curb Covid-19. Revenue fell 7% to S$9.27 million, mainly due to decreased business activities from its health services segment. The company's cost of sales increased 4% due to higher staff-related expenses, including hiring specialist doctors. Shares traded flat at S$0.30. The company's board expects its financial performance to be adversely affected for the remainder of the financial year.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit's DPU up 1.4% in Q1
summary: PARKWAY Life Real Estate Investment Trust (PLife Reit) reported a 1.4% increase in distribution per unit to 3.32 Singapore cents for its Q1 ended March 31. The increase was driven by revenue from three newly acquired Japan nursing rehabilitation facilities and rental growth of existing properties. Gross revenue grew 5.2% to S$29.9 million, while net property income rose 4.5% to S$27.7 million. The company retains S$850,000 for Covid-19 related relief measures, leaving S$20.1 million for distribution to unitholders.

site_title: A mission to get patients back on their feet
summary: Dr. Gowreeson Thevendran, a leading orthopaedic foot and ankle surgeon, has dedicated his career to helping patients recover from foot and ankle injuries. With a passion for sport and hands-on practice, he specializes in the rapidly growing field of orthopaedic foot and ankle surgery. The specialty has seen significant advancements in new conditions, surgical techniques, and non-surgical treatments, enabling surgeons to improve patients' quality of life. Thevendran's work is part of a growing trend in orthopaedic surgery, which is increasingly focused on innovative treatments and patient-centered care.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit expects demand to hold up amid pandemic
summary: Keppel DC Reit expects demand for its data centre services to hold up amid the Covid-19 pandemic, driven by an accelerated pace of cloud and technological adoption. The Reit expects higher data traffic and 27% annual growth in mobile data traffic from 2019 to 2025. With 70% of leases expiring in 2025 and beyond, the Reit's returns remain stable, and its low aggregate leverage of 32.2% provides financial flexibility for growth.

site_title: Crude futures plunge presages more oil woes in Singapore
summary: US crude futures plummeted into negative territory, signaling more oil woes in Singapore. Despite this, experts believe it won't worsen the outlook for Singapore's oil exports and petrochemical sectors. The market is already strained by low prices and plummeting demand for oil.

site_title: Centurion offers early lease termination for UK students
summary: Centurion Corp, a UK housing operator, is offering early lease termination for students due to lower occupancies caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The move applies to students in the UK academic year 2019-2020 until August 31. The company expects up to £5m revenue loss as a result.

site_title: Overheads limit majors' ability to extend lower petrol prices
summary: Singapore consumers are frustrated with petrol prices remaining unchanged despite global oil prices falling. Overhead costs, including land, shipping, and taxes, limit oil majors' ability to pass on lower crude oil prices to consumers. According to IHS Markit, land premiums and taxes account for 60% of the overall petrol retail price, while the actual cost of ex-refinery oil makes up less than 20%. Analysts suggest that global oil price movements take time to trickle down to consumers, and companies adjust prices based on various factors.

site_title: Lendlease reaches out to communities affected by Covid-19
summary: Lendlease is providing targeted support packages to communities affected by Covid-19 in Singapore, China, Japan, and Malaysia. The company is partnering with local community associations to offer relief measures, capacity building support, and community resilience enhancement. Lendlease's CEO, Tony Lombardo, emphasized the company's commitment to community care and resilience during the pandemic. The initiative aims to expedite the return to normal life for vulnerable groups, with the mayor of South East Community Development Council expressing appreciation for the business partner's efforts to aid the community.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: NetLink NBN Trust has received permission from the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) to resume fibre services to homes and offices after suspending them due to Covid-19 cases among its contractors. The IMDA had ordered the suspension last week, but NetLink has now been given the green light to resume services.

site_title: BOJ warns of potential financial system risks if pandemic extends
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has warned that a prolonged pandemic could trigger a negative feedback loop, destabilizing Japan's financial system. Financial institutions have increased lending to high-risk borrowers, making their balance sheets vulnerable to global market volatility. If the economy suffers a deep slump, a banking-sector correction could occur, worsening the economic downturn. The BOJ is closely monitoring the situation and may take further steps to ease corporate funding strains at its next rate review.

site_title: Plunge of US crude prices into negative territory unlikely to be the new normal
summary: US crude prices plummeted to minus-$37.63 a barrel in May futures contracts due to weak demand from the Covid-19 outbreak, but experts say this is unlikely to become the new normal. The historic crash was triggered by a technical quirk in the futures market ahead of the contract's expiry. Despite the shock, Brent crude prices remain stable at around $23 a barrel, and US President Donald Trump's remarks on blocking Saudi Arabian oil shipments offer support to crude prices. The global energy market remains volatile, with concerns over supply cuts and potential negative prices in June.

site_title: US state sues China's leaders over virus
summary: The US state of Missouri filed a lawsuit against China's leadership, seeking damages over alleged deliberate deception and insufficient action to stop the Covid-19 pandemic. The lawsuit, filed in a federal court, claims China hoarded protective equipment and seeks an unspecified amount in damages and an injunction on further actions. The move comes amid calls in Congress to punish China and criticism of President Trump's handling of the crisis. This is the first-of-a-kind state lawsuit against China's leaders.

images.alt_text: The US state of Missouri on Tuesday sued China's leadership over the Covid-19 coronavirus, seeking damages over what it described as deliberate deception and insufficient action to stop the pandemic.

site_title: Ahead of Singapore Airlines EGM, Sias raises questions about cash call
summary: Singapore Airlines is set to hold an EGM on April 30 to approve a S$15 billion debt and equity capital raising. The airline has proposed a S$8.8 billion renounceable rights issue and up to S$6.2 billion in additional MCBs. The Securities Investors Association (Sias) has raised questions about the proposed capital raising, including the use of funds for capital expenditure, the discount on the rights issue price, and the conduct of the EGM. Sias has also asked why the airline chose to raise cash from shareholders and whether it explored other funding options.

site_title: The market grapples with fear and the timing of a recovery
summary: The market has experienced a rapid recovery from its 35% decline in the first quarter, with the S&P 500 rising over 25% from its March low to April 14. Investment strategists believe a clearer picture of the future can be seen when looking three years ahead, with many expecting the world to return to normalcy by then. Advisers recommend maintaining a normal portfolio approach, rebalancing, and staying the course despite the current uncertainty. Some experts identify silver linings, such as government stimulus packages and the Federal Reserve's actions, and anticipate a 10% annual long-term return for stocks.

site_title: Adyen Q1 profit up 34%; hires more staff
summary: Adyen NV posted a 34% year-over-year increase in net revenue to 135.5 million euros in Q1, driven by a 38% growth in payment processing volumes to 67 billion euros. Despite a hit in fees from the travel and accommodation sector, the company made 169 new hires, boosting its workforce by 14%. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization margin declined to 47% due to new hires and marketing campaigns. The company warned that a deep economic recession could hurt earnings, citing uncertainty over the pandemic's duration.

site_title: Asia should contribute to reforming the global oil market
summary: Asia must contribute to reforming the global oil market to stabilize the oil price, which has plummeted to its lowest level in 18 years due to the coronavirus pandemic and Opec-plus agreement failure. The oil market's price mechanism has not adjusted supply to demand, and Asia's oil-consuming countries must cooperate with Opec-plus to address the issue. A new Asian Energy Agency (AEA) is proposed to stabilize energy policies in cooperation with Opec-plus countries, representing the interests of non-OECD countries and promoting cooperation between oil-consuming and producing nations.

site_title: Circuit breaker extension to hurt construction sector, shipyards
summary: Singapore's circuit breaker extension until June 1 will significantly impact the construction sector, with estimated 15% contraction in the second quarter and negative 6% growth for the full year. Construction companies will continue to face expenses despite lost revenue, and the government's assistance measures, such as waiving foreign worker levies and providing wage subsidies, are not enough to offset these costs. Shipyards have also been forced to stop work due to the tightened list of essential services, affecting industries like marine and offshore engineering.

site_title: A leader in treating haematological cancers
summary: Parkway Cancer Centre (PCC) in Singapore is a leading provider of comprehensive treatment services for haematological cancers, including leukaemia, lymphoma, and blood disorders. With a multidisciplinary team of haematologists, transplant physicians, and allied health professionals, PCC offers a holistic approach to care, resulting in better healthcare outcomes. The centre is also a pioneer in bone marrow transplantation, having performed the first transplant in a private hospital setting in Singapore over two decades ago. PCC aims to continue developing its expertise and services to stay ahead of medical advancements, including CAR T-cell therapies.

site_title: BreadTalk suspends trading after close of privatisation offer
summary: BreadTalk, a Singapore-listed food and beverage company, has suspended trading after its offeror, BTG Holding, acquired 98.03% of the company's shares at S$0.77 apiece. The offer was made to buy back all shares, with the remaining 1.97% of shares to be compulsorily acquired at the same price. The move comes after BreadTalk's founder and chairman, George Quek, requested a trading suspension, citing the company's loss of free float and the offeror's control over the majority of shares.

site_title: Businesses say big banks flouted 'first come, first served' for aid
summary: US small-business owners have accused three major banks - Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase, and Wells Fargo - of unfairly favoring applications from wealthy clients under the Paycheck Protection Program. The banks allegedly prioritized larger loans, collecting higher fees, and delayed processing smaller loan requests. The accusations come as the programme ran out of money, leaving many small businesses uncertain about their survival. Lawsuits have been filed in federal court, seeking class-action status, and lawmakers are working on a deal to add $300 billion to the programme.

site_title: Britain's high street seeks government rent support
summary: Britain's high street is seeking government rent support due to thousands of retailers unable to pay rents due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Trade bodies British Retail Consortium and British Property Federation proposed a Furloughed Space Grant Scheme, which would support fixed costs of businesses with dramatic falls in turnover. Many retailers are at risk of administration, with some, like Debenhams and Oasis, already facing financial difficulties. The government has already passed a law to prevent landlords from evicting tenants who cannot pay rents, but further support is needed to prevent widespread business failures.

site_title: Indonesia hires tankers to store fuel at sea while seeking bargains
summary: Indonesia's state-owned oil company, PT Pertamina, is hiring tankers to store refined fuels at sea, taking advantage of low oil prices. The company has chartered at least three long-range tankers to store clean fuels, with an option for floating storage near Singapore or Malaysia. This move comes as Indonesia, a major refined fuel importer, weighs the benefits of processing its own crude or buying fuels from abroad, which has become more cost-effective amid a global glut. The company plans to add external storage as its internal capacity fills up and will slash crude processing by 43% in May.

site_title: Donations on Giving.sg reach record high
summary: Singaporeans have shown remarkable generosity by donating a record S$13.6 million to charities on Giving.sg between April 1 and 19, exceeding expectations. The surge in traffic to the platform peaked on April 17, with over 67,000 visitors, and is part of a larger trend of increased online giving during the Covid-19 crisis. The donations are expected to go towards addressing immediate needs related to the pandemic, while also supporting vulnerable communities that require ongoing attention.

site_title: UOB to offer pre-approved loans of up to S$200,000 to small businesses impacted by Covid-19
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) announced it will offer pre-approved loans of up to S$200,000 to small businesses in Singapore impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Eligible customers with a good repayment track record will be contacted for the loans, which can be received in two business days by authenticating company information or submitting required details. This move aims to provide liquidity to small businesses, particularly those in hard-hit sectors, to help them stay afloat amidst the prolonged economic shock caused by the pandemic.

site_title: Generic disclosures ascribed to Covid-19 not good enough: SGX RegCo
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) chief executive Tan Boon Gin emphasizes the importance of issuers providing timely and detailed disclosures to investors, particularly regarding the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on their operations. Generic statements are deemed inadequate and may lead to investor shocks. Tan advises issuers to disclose specific data on suspended or curtailed operations, such as mall retail units and plant capacity. Immediate disclosure is required for material changes to earnings prospects caused by Covid-19, and issuers should provide regular business updates to manage investor expectations and demonstrate sound governance.

site_title: Extended circuit breaker deals fresh blow to reeling businesses
summary: Singapore's circuit breaker measures have taken a fresh blow to reeling businesses, particularly food and beverage establishments. Non-essential businesses, including standalone F&B outlets, hairdressing and barber shops, pet supply stores, and retail laundry services, were forced to shut by 11:59pm. The government has also restricted manufacturing facilities and optician shops, with some businesses already reducing staff and applying for financing aggressively. Despite government support, many businesses are bracing themselves for further challenges, with some predicting severe financial impacts over the coming months.

site_title: Australia's GDP to fall 10%, jobless rate to hit 10% in first half: RBA
summary: Australia's economy is expected to contract by 10% in the first half of 2020, with a jobless rate projected to reach 10% by June, according to Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) governor Philip Lowe. The nation is facing its first recession since 1991 due to coronavirus restrictions, but Lowe is hopeful that businesses can retain employees on lower hours. A massive fiscal-monetary injection worth 16.4% of GDP has been assembled to aid households and firms, and the economy could bounce back in the September quarter, with GDP growth of 6-7% expected in 2021.

site_title: Job security in Japan being put to the test
summary: Japan's unemployment rate is expected to rise to 2.8% in the second quarter of 2020, a 0.5 percentage point increase from six months earlier. Despite an unspoken expectation that labor cuts would be a last resort, three challenges threaten job security: freelancers and self-employed individuals lack a corporate shield, the government struggles to establish a system for prompt cash transfers, and corporate strength is gradually declining. Utilizing digital technology, including the My Number system, could help Japan respond to the crisis by quickly identifying those in need and providing benefits.

site_title: Piracy and robbery are still real dangers
summary: Piracy and armed robbery continue to be significant threats to merchant ships worldwide, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. According to the ICC International Maritime Bureau, 47 attacks occurred in the first three months of 2020, with 37 ships boarded by pirates. The ReCAAP Information Sharing Centre reported a three-fold increase in incidents in Asia, with 29 reported incidents of armed robbery against ships in January-March 2020. The Gulf of Guinea remains the world's piracy hotspot, with 17 crew kidnapped in three incidents in Q1 2020. The industry is urged to remain vigilant and take preventive measures to address these crimes.

site_title: Circuit breaker has seen some progress, but needs to be extended to June 1: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's circuit breaker period has been extended to June 1, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announcing the four-week extension due to a surge in COVID-19 cases, particularly among foreign workers in dormitories. The government has tightened measures, closing more workplaces and restricting entry to popular wet markets. The number of new cases has leveled off in the local community, but the total numbers have soared due to infections among foreign workers. The government urges Singaporeans to stay at home and cooperate with the circuit breaker rules to protect themselves and others.

site_title: Saudi Real Estate Refinance expects only temporary mortgage slowdown
summary: Saudi Real Estate Refinance Co expects a temporary slowdown in the mortgage market due to the coronavirus, CEO Fabrice Susini stated. The slowdown is expected to be temporary, with the market still supported by demographic trends. SRC aims to refinance 20% of Saudi Arabia's primary home loans market, with authorities aiming to expand the market to 500 billion riyals by 2020 and 800 billion riyals by 2028. The slowdown is attributed to curfews limiting property visits, but SRC does not expect it to fundamentally change the market's growth rate.

site_title: As oil gets beaten down, analysts find reason to look up
summary: Oil prices are expected to recover by the end of the year, with analysts projecting year-end targets of US$40 per barrel for West Texas Intermediate and US$43 per barrel for Brent crude. Despite weak demand, sharp production cuts by OPEC and companies are expected to lead the pick-up in oil prices. However, storage spaces are scarce, posing a challenge, and negative prices could return if demand does not recover. Analysts warn that accumulated storage must be unwound and spare capacity must come back online before oil prices can rise.

site_title: Homeless taste 'luxury' at Geneva hotel during pandemic
summary: Geneva's three-star Bel Esperance Hotel has temporarily converted to house homeless women and unaccompanied minors during the COVID-19 pandemic. The hotel, which normally offers luxury accommodations, has provided 20 rooms to homeless women and 11 to minors, offering meals, personal bathrooms, and Wi-Fi. The initiative, which began after the hotel's cancellation of bookings due to the pandemic, aims to help the estimated 1,000 homeless people in Geneva. The hotel's director, Alain Meuwly, believes the arrangement could be an asset to the business once the crisis ends, and residents, including 16-year-old Sofiane Rahmani, are enjoying the luxury accommodations.

images.alt_text: Hafida Marsli, a 42-year-old woman who made her way from Morocco to Switzerland a decade ago in search of a better life only to eventually find herself homeless, posing on April 16, 2020 in her room at the three-star Bel Esperance Hotel in Geneva, amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Could DBS Trustee have done more for EHT unitholders?
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) directed DBS Trustee to outline actions to protect EHT unitholders' interests, following a loan default at the Reit. DBS Trustee's responses to an inquiry raised concerns about negligence, contradicting its IPO covenant to exercise due diligence and vigilance. The MAS and SGX RegCo's directive comes after a loan default at EHT, which may have been preventable. The trustee's actions will be scrutinized to ensure compliance with its fiduciary duties.

images.alt_text: In what sounded like a reprimand, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) on Monday directed DBS Trustee to set out the actions it will take to protect the interests of unitholders in Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT).

site_title: N Korea's Kim in critical condition after cardiac surgery, says US official but S Korean accounts differ
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's health status remains uncertain after undergoing cardiovascular surgery, with US officials stating he's in critical condition but South Korean accounts differing. The Trump administration declined to comment on his current health, while South Korean officials have not publicly disclosed his condition. The differing accounts have raised questions about the accuracy of information on Kim's health, with the US citing a "turn for the worse" after surgery and South Korea remaining tight-lipped.

site_title: US: Stocks open sharply lower amid pressure on oil market
summary: US stocks opened sharply lower on Tuesday amid pressure on the oil market, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 2.2% to 23,129.42. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also fell, shedding 1.8% and 1.2% respectively. The decline comes as more large companies withdrew their earnings forecasts due to the uncertain economic outlook.

site_title: Qatar Airways defers half of some employees' wages for three months
summary: Qatar Airways has temporarily halved the salaries of mid-level employees and above for at least three months due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The unpaid portions of salaries will be back paid when the airline can afford it. CEO Akbar al-Baker has already forfeited his salary until the airline returns to full operations. The airline expects to seek government support due to the pandemic's impact. This measure is aimed at reducing costs and is expected to last until the economic situation improves.

site_title: SGX could see more than 30% jump in Q3 net profit
summary: SGX is expected to report a record quarterly net profit of over S$131 million, a 30% jump from the previous quarter, driven by increased securities and derivatives trading revenue. Analysts attribute this growth to the bourse's diversified business model, strategic priorities, and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Market data revenue is also expected to rise, with a 63% year-on-year growth. The stock is projected to continue outperforming, with a bull case valuation of S$12.30 and a target price of S$11.

site_title: Hin Leong collapse: No serious sectoral impact; firm faces police probe
summary: Hin Leong Trading, a Singapore-based oil trading giant, is facing a police probe amid its debt woes, with debts of US$4 billion. However, government agencies including Enterprise Singapore, Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, and Monetary Authority of Singapore have stated that the debt will have "no serious impact" on Singapore's oil trading and bunkering sectors. The banking system remains sound, and the agencies are closely monitoring developments related to HLT and the broader oil trading and bunkering sectors. The firm is seeking a standstill from creditors to restructure its debts.
