site_title: US: Stocks open higher on hopes for faster economic rebound
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by positive preliminary testing for a coronavirus treatment and the release of White House guidelines for re-opening the US economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 2.3%, the S&P 500 gained 2%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index added 1.3%. The positive news lifted market sentiment, with stocks closing at fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and divided Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Ads for S$5,500 temp jobs at Expo isolation facility are fake: Mindef, MOH
summary: Fake job ads offering up to S$5,500 for temporary roles at the Singapore Expo community isolation facility have surfaced, claiming to be for positions such as "healthcare associates" and "operations support staff". However, the Ministry of Health (MOH) and Ministry of Defence (Mindef) have confirmed that these ads are fake and not affiliated with the government. Mindef stated that genuine job openings for former SAF regulars will not ask for personal details, and applicants should only contact official channels. The ads were posted on job portals and social media pages between April 10 and April 13.

site_title: Premier League clubs committed to finishing season, but no deadline set
summary: Premier League clubs agreed to finish the 2019/20 season, but no June 30 deadline was set. The meeting, held due to the coronavirus, aimed to discuss models for a potential return to action. Despite lockdown measures in Britain, the league is working on scenarios for a safe restart. The health and wellbeing of players and staff remain the priority, with the league aiming to complete the season when medical guidance allows. A tentative schedule remains, as the impact of Covid-19 continues to develop.

site_title: UK property agent Foxtons taps markets for additional cash, furloughs employees
summary: UK property agency Foxtons issued new shares worth 20% of its existing capital to raise up to £22 million amid the coronavirus crisis, which has severely impacted the housing market. The company furloughed about 750 employees and implemented a 20% pay reduction for executives. Foxtons' share price surged 15.9% following the announcement, as the company seeks to maintain liquidity in a worst-case scenario. The company reported a 5% fall in lettings revenue in January-March, with commissions down 47% in the first three weeks of the UK lockdown.

site_title: European Tour cancels French Open, BMW International Open
summary: The European Tour has canceled the French Open and BMW International Open in Munich due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with the Scottish Open postponed. The British Open was previously scrapped, and the tour's last completed event was the Qatar Masters on March 8. The French government extended the ban on mass gatherings until mid-July, leading to the cancellation of the French Open. The tour's chief, Keith Pelley, expressed sympathy for those affected and promised to discuss rescheduling the Scottish Open when the global situation becomes clearer.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 20.81 points to 1,407.34. Gainers outnumbered losers 764 to 211, with volume reaching 6.312 billion lots worth RM3.022 billion.

site_title: Amazon's deal for Deliveroo gets initial green light from UK
summary: Amazon's proposed £1.7 billion investment in UK food delivery firm Deliveroo has received initial approval from the UK's merger watchdog. The Competition and Markets Authority cited the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on Deliveroo's business, stating it would fail financially without the investment. The deal could hurt competition by discouraging Amazon from starting its own operation, but the regulator has been seeking concessions, including relinquishing a board seat or lowering Amazon's stake. A final report is expected in late May.

site_title: Nasdaq proposes easing listing rules during coronavirus crisis
summary: Nasdaq proposes temporary relief to companies listed on its exchange due to the coronavirus crisis, suspending minimum requirement rules until June 30. The move aims to allow companies to focus on running their businesses rather than meeting listing requirements. As of Monday, 154 securities were out of compliance with the US$1 price requirement, and 117 securities had closing bid prices between US$1 and US$1.50. This proposal follows a similar request from the New York Stock Exchange, and investors can still view non-compliant companies on Nasdaq's website.

site_title: Coronavirus: Experts say big jump in infections is stretching the healthcare system
summary: Singapore's healthcare system is under strain due to a recent surge in Covid-19 infections, with experts warning of a high chance of hospital overcrowding. Experts estimate that 10,000 to 20,000 cases may be reported by the end of the month if safe distancing measures are not implemented. To mitigate the situation, experts recommend isolating and monitoring patients with mild symptoms outside of hospitals, and triaging cases to prioritize those at higher risk of complications.

site_title: StanChart donates S$1m to support Singapore's needy students, social service agencies
summary: Standard Chartered Bank is donating S$1 million to support needy students and social service agencies in Singapore amid the coronavirus pandemic. The bank will provide computers and broadband access to students and partner with the National Council of Social Service to support vulnerable groups. This donation is part of StanChart's US$50 million Covid-19 Global Charitable Fund, with half allocated to emergency relief and the other half to community restoration.

site_title: US airlines sitting on US$10b in travel vouchers, lawmakers say
summary: US airlines are estimated to hold over $10 billion in travel vouchers, instead of cash refunds, from cancelled flights. Senators Ed Markey, Elizabeth Warren, and Richard Blumenthal claim that airlines are "obfuscating" passengers' right to full refunds by offering vouchers as the default option. Most airlines did not disclose the total value of their travel vouchers and credits issued during the pandemic. The lawmakers are urging airlines to provide more information and are concerned about the potential for airlines to keep the vouchers instead of issuing refunds.

site_title: First Reit says a resident at one of its nursing homes has tested positive for the virus
summary: First Reit, a Singaporean nursing home operator, reported a COVID-19 case at one of its facilities involving an 89-year-old resident. The resident tested positive on April 15 and is in isolation at a hospital. The company has suspended visits, increased cleaning and disinfection, and is working with the Ministry of Health and Agency for Integrated Care to conduct contact tracing. This is the first COVID-19 case reported at First Reit's nursing homes. The company's units closed flat at S$0.80 on the same day.

site_title: Verizon snaps up Zoom rival BlueJeans for less than US$500m
summary: Verizon Communications has agreed to acquire BlueJeans Network, a rival of Zoom Video Communications, for less than $500 million. The deal comes as video-conferencing apps have gained popularity due to the pandemic. BlueJeans has around 15,000 enterprise clients, including Facebook and Standard Chartered. The acquisition is expected to close in the second quarter and will integrate BlueJeans into Verizon's 5G product plan to tap into areas like telemedicine and distance learning.

site_title: Credit Suisse gets approval to take majority stake in China JV
summary: Credit Suisse has received regulatory approval to increase its stake in its Chinese investment banking joint venture, Credit Suisse Founder Securities, from 33.3% to 51%. The Swiss bank will make the investment via a capital injection, allowing for better use of its global network to win market share in China. This move follows other international investment banks such as UBS, Nomura Holdings, JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs, and Morgan Stanley, which have also received approval for majority stakes in China operations under eased rules in 2018.

site_title: Sim Leisure inks theme-park deal with Guangzhou Daxin
summary: Sim Leisure Group has signed a cooperation agreement with Guangzhou Daxin Water Park Equipment, allowing Guangzhou Daxin to use the "Sim Leisure" name in securing theme-park design and building contracts in China and the Asean region. The agreement grants Guangzhou Daxin a 5% royalty payment to Sim Leisure's 60% owned subsidiary, Sim Leisure Creative, in exchange for the right to use the name. This partnership aims to capitalize on the growing theme park market in China, with Sim Leisure founder Sim Choo Kheng stating it is the "right moment" for the company to enter the Chinese market.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank may start buying new government bonds in two weeks: report
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, may start buying new government bonds in two weeks, Governor Perry Warjiyo announced, as the government prepares for a higher fiscal deficit amid the coronavirus response. The central bank will only buy 25% of the targeted amount in each auction and will hold weekly auctions for rupiah debt sales. This move aims to smooth out technicalities and is seen as a last resort.

site_title: STI posts subdued gains amid Asian optimism over US recovery plans
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the day up 2.35 points, or 0.1%, at 2,614.60, driven by optimism over US recovery plans and slightly better-than-expected China GDP data. Reits, including CapitaLand and Mapletree Commercial Trusts, were among the top performers. Local banks fell, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB losing 0.5%, 0.1%, and 0.6% respectively.

site_title: Netflix streams some educational films on YouTube for free
summary: Netflix has made some documentary features and series, including "Our Planet" and "Explained," available for free on its YouTube channel at the request of teachers due to the coronavirus outbreak. This move is a rare exception to Netflix's marketing strategy, which typically charges a monthly subscription fee. The decision aims to support teachers in keeping classes running virtually, as schools and colleges are forced to close. This move is part of the company's efforts to adapt to the pandemic-driven internet boom.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: NetLink Trust suspended service orders for homes and offices until April 19 after four workers under a contractor tested positive for Covid-19. The Singapore Exchange will close its CDP customer service centre on April 18. ARA H-Trust temporarily closed two-thirds of hotels, reduced workforce, and implemented pay cuts amid the pandemic. Meanwhile, a Yangzijiang subsidiary agreed to provide a credit facility to a chairman's unit, and Sheng Siong's Lim family joined the ranks of supermarket billionaires during the pandemic, with 61 supermarkets across Singapore.

site_title: Europe: Shares gain as Trump plans to reopen US economy
summary: European shares rose 2.5% on Friday, rebounding from weekly declines, amid US President Donald Trump's plans to gradually reopen the US economy and reports of a potential Covid-19 treatment. The Stoxx 600 index has recovered 24% since its March low, driven by global stimulus and tentative signs of the pandemic's peak. A positive report on Gilead Sciences' experimental drug remdesivir and Nokia's defensive takeover bid also boosted markets.

site_title: Australia: Shares finish week on a high note as US lays out recovery plan
summary: Australian shares finished the week on a high note, closing 1.3% higher, as US President Donald Trump outlined a plan to revive the US economy, boosting investor sentiment. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached its fourth consecutive weekly gain. Despite data showing China's first-ever economic contraction, hopes for a global economic recovery and reports on a potential Covid-19 treatment lifted risk appetite.

site_title: AirAsia, Malaysia Airlines merger an option as virus hits industry: minister
summary: Malaysia's second-most senior minister, Mohamed Azmin Ali, has mentioned merging money-losing Malaysia Airlines with budget airline AirAsia as an option to "save" the industry amidst the Covid-19 crisis. The pandemic has led to lockdowns, halted air travel, and left airlines struggling for survival. Deliberations on various options to support the industry are expected to take place soon.

site_title: Ads for S$5,500 temp jobs at Expo isolation facility are fake: Mindef, MOH
summary: The Singapore government has warned of fake job ads seeking individuals to work at the Singapore Expo community isolation facility and foreign worker dormitories during the COVID-19 pandemic. Recruitment agency PrimeStaff Management Services has been linked to the fake ads, despite the Ministry of Health stating they have not engaged the agency. The ads claim to offer S$4,000 to S$5,500 per month for temporary roles, but the Ministry of Defence has clarified that genuine job openings will not require personal details. The fake ads have been removed from online platforms, and the government urges individuals to be cautious of such scams.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher on China GDP data
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.6% on Friday, following China's GDP data, which showed the pandemic had a lesser impact on economic growth than expected. The Hang Seng Index closed at 24,380.00, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose. The positive data led investors to brush off concerns about the US-China trade tensions and extended the rally in Asian markets.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks finished higher on Friday after official data in China showed the coronavirus pandemic had not hit economic growth as badly as some had feared.

site_title: P&G beats profit estimates as consumers stock up on toilet rolls, detergents
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) reported a 5% increase in quarterly net sales to $17.21 billion, beating Wall Street estimates. Sales growth was driven by its health care, fabric, home care, and baby products units, with toilet rolls, detergents, and diapers being in high demand amid COVID-19 lockdowns. The company also raised its dividend and share repurchase plans. Despite a 3% cut in full-year sales growth target due to currency fluctuations, P&G's shares rose 1.3% in early trading.

images.alt_text: Procter & Gamble Co beat expectations for quarterly profit on Friday as consumers stocked up on everything from diapers and detergents to toilet rolls amid sweeping lockdowns around the world to curb the spread of the coronavirus.

site_title: Kitchen Culture signs MOU to acquire Chinese AI firm
summary: Kitchen Culture Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, signed a non-binding MOU with Chinese firm Ooway Technology to acquire Ooway's subsidiary, which uses machine learning and AI to provide credit-rating services for Chinese importers and exporters. The acquisition aims to expand Kitchen Culture's presence in the Chinese market and leverage Ooway's technology. The MOU outlines key areas of understanding for the proposed acquisition, marking a significant step towards the deal's completion.

site_title: Sheng Siong's Lim family join ranks of supermarket billionaires in pandemic's wake
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a Singaporean supermarket chain, has joined the ranks of billionaire families after its combined fortune surged to US$1.1 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. The company's shares rose 30% since the pandemic began, with founder Lim Hock Chee and his brothers operating 61 supermarkets across Singapore. The family's wealth was built on their ability to capitalize on the pandemic's surge in grocery spending, with analysts predicting continued robust sales even after social-distancing restrictions ease.

site_title: UK's sterling holds steady after government extends lockdown, risks remain
summary: The UK's sterling holds steady against the euro and dollar after the government extends its coronavirus lockdown for at least three more weeks, citing the need to prevent progress in fighting the outbreak. The pound has recovered by nearly 7% against the euro since the lockdown began, and is unchanged at 87.05 pence. The UK has also extended its furlough scheme for workers hit by the outbreak until the end of June. Despite the extension, currency analysts predict the pound's recovery to remain muted and warn of potential risks due to the looming Brexit deadline.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise on China GDP data
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday after China's GDP data showed the pandemic's impact was less severe than expected. China's quarantine measures have allowed the world's second-largest economy to gradually return to normal. The data boosted investor confidence, leading to gains in markets such as Singapore. The rally comes ahead of the release of Singapore's GDP data, which may provide further insight into the region's economic performance.

site_title: China-backed AIIB to double funds under coronavirus crisis facility to $10b
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), backed by China, has doubled its Covid-19 crisis recovery facility funds to $10 billion, exceeding initial $5 billion allocations due to high client demand. This move aims to support countries affected by the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore mulls placing workers who recover from Covid-19 on cruise ships
summary: Singapore is considering placing migrant workers who have recovered from Covid-19 on cruise ships as an alternative to dormitories, which have become infection hotbeds. The city-state has seen a surge in cases in dormitories, with 60% of infected workers residing there. To address the issue, Singapore is looking for new accommodation solutions for hundreds of workers. This proposal comes as the country struggles to control outbreaks on cruise ships, despite problems encountered elsewhere.

site_title: SGX to close CDP customer service centre from April 18
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will close its Central Depository (CDP) customer service centre at The Metropolis starting April 18, amid the novel coronavirus pandemic. All CDP services will be provided online, by phone, or through mail to ensure public health and safety. Shareholders are encouraged to use online methods for accessing services or making payments, and banks have temporarily closed branches for some services. SGX will also refine its processes to minimize face-to-face interaction and increase online services, while reviewing member firms' business continuity plans to minimize disruptions.

site_title: LTA awards S$639.5m contract for train testing centre to S Korea's GS Engineering
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded a S$639.5 million contract to GS Engineering and Construction for the design and construction of an integrated train testing centre (ITTC) in Singapore. The centre, to be built on a 50-hectare site, will perform integrated systems testing for new and existing MRT lines, freeing up engineering hours for maintenance and renewal works. The ITTC will be modelled after similar testing centres in other countries and is expected to become fully operational by end-2024, serving as a hub for LTA and the local rail industry to deepen competencies in systems integration and operations.

site_title: NetLink suspends service orders after 4 workers under contractor diagnosed with Covid-19
summary: NetLink Trust, a fibre broadband operator, has suspended all service orders for homes and offices until April 19 after four workers under a contractor tested positive for Covid-19. The workers visited 34 homes between April 1 and April 14, but none had contact with company staff in the last 14 days. NetLink is reviewing its Covid-19 precautions and will lift the suspension once enhanced measures are implemented. Affected parties will be notified, and rescheduled appointments will be made for next week.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end higher amid optimism over US plans to reopen economy
summary: South Korea's stock market closed 3.1% higher, its largest gain in over a week, driven by optimism over the US economy's potential reopening and a new coronavirus treatment. Despite China's GDP data showing a historic contraction, investors cheered the news. The won strengthened, and bond yields rose, while foreigners bought 398.2 billion won worth of shares. The Kospi index rose 2.9% for the week, its fourth straight gain, but remains down 12.9% for the year.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares closed more than 3 per cent higher on Friday, its sharpest gain in over a week, as optimism over reopening of the American economy outweighed worries over Chinese GDP data that showed a historic contraction.

site_title: LVMH, L'Oreal recovery in China fuels optimism for outlook
summary: French consumer giants LVMH and L'Oreal reported a potential recovery in China, with Louis Vuitton sales up 50% in the past three weeks and L'Oreal CEO Jean-Paul Agon stating sales in China turned positive in March and are on track for a 5-10% gain this month. This optimism fuels hope for a recovery in the outlook, despite the companies' comparable sales declines of 17% and 4.8% respectively.

site_title: Changi Airport sees more than 70% drop in passengers during March
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore reported a 70.7% drop in passenger numbers in March 2020 compared to the same period last year, with 1.65 million passengers handled. Aircraft movements declined by 49.9% and airfreight throughput fell by 19.1%. The airport's passenger traffic is expected to remain significantly impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, with a prolonged trough predicted. Analysts predict a gradual U-shaped recovery, with domestic travel coming back faster than the international market, and up to 25 million jobs in aviation and related sectors worldwide at risk.

site_title: China expects Q2 economic performance to be much better than Q1
summary: China's economic performance in Q2 is expected to be better than in Q1, with foreign trade improving and consumption rebounding due to pent-up demand. The employment situation remains stable, despite the coronavirus outbreak. This contrasts with the Q1 shrinkage of China's economy for the first time since 1992. The improvement in economic performance is seen as a positive sign for policymakers, who are under pressure to address mounting job losses and slow down the country's GDP growth.

site_title: Wuhan raises virus death toll by 1,290, up 50%
summary: Wuhan, China's coronavirus ground-zero city, raised its death toll by 50% to 3,869, citing "mistakenly reported" or missed cases due to overwhelmed medical staff, insufficient testing and treatment facilities, and patients dying at home. This brings the nationwide death toll up by nearly 39% to 4,632. The change has fueled global doubts about Chinese transparency amid growing pressure from Western powers, including the US, which is probing the virus's origin.

site_title: Singapore disinfecting robot trialled in virus fight
summary: Singapore researchers have developed a disinfecting robot, the "XDBOT," with a dexterous robotic limb to aid in virus-fighting efforts during the pandemic. The robot can reach awkward locations and spray disinfectant, reducing the risk of infection to cleaners. Trialled on the NTU campus, the XDBOT aims to provide deep-cleaning and disinfection services in public areas and hospitals. The robot is the latest in a growing trend of using robots to combat the coronavirus, seen as fast, efficient, and contagion-proof.

site_title: Investment scheme, S$20,000 grant to support Asean fintechs during pandemic
summary: A S$50 million fund has been established by AMTD Group and the Asean Financial Innovation Network to support Asean fintech firms during the pandemic. The AMTD Asean-Solidarity Fund offers a grant of up to S$20,000 to SFA-certified fintechs in Singapore for proof-of-concept exercises with Asean financial institutions on the API Exchange Platform. The fund aims to support regional fintech innovation and collaboration, providing a boost to the sector during the challenging Covid-19 period.

site_title: China property tycoon stung by cinema shutdown amid Covid-19
summary: China is slowly returning to normal life, with people heading to work and shopping at wet markets, but cinema closures remain. Movie theatres are ill-suited for social distancing, and US box-office sales are expected to plummet 96% in the second quarter, following a 23% decline in receipts in the first three months of 2020. This early sign of the cinema industry's difficulties suggests a prolonged recovery.

site_title: 28 employers fined S$1k each for breaching safe distancing rules in lorries
summary: Twenty-eight employers in Singapore have been fined S$1,000 each for breaching safe distancing rules for workers in lorries. The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) and other agencies conducted an island-wide enforcement operation, resulting in the fines. Employers who contravene the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act 2020 can face fines of up to S$10,000 or a six-month jail term. The penalties are doubled for repeat offenders, and more companies are being urged to implement safe distancing measures for workers.

site_title: ARA H-Trust temporarily shuts two-thirds of hotels, slashes workforce amid pandemic
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust temporarily shut 28 of its 41 upscale hotels due to low occupancy rates, resulting in a 70% workforce reduction and pay cuts for senior managers. The trust also cut costs by eliminating contract labor, slashing working hours, and deferring non-essential capital expenditures. With the US reporting 670,353 confirmed coronavirus cases, ARA H-Trust expects market conditions to worsen before improving.

site_title: New Zealand cites new deaths in case against lifting coronavirus lockdown
summary: New Zealand has cited two new deaths in coronavirus cases to justify its tough lockdown policies, despite a significant drop in cases. The country reported just eight fresh cases, taking the total to 1,409, and two new deaths, raising the death toll to 11. Finance Minister Grant Robertson warned that lifting restrictions too soon could lead to a return to lockdown, citing the risk of transmission and the need for continued social distancing measures. The government is set to make a decision on Monday regarding the lockdown's extension or easing.

site_title: Keppel Capital secures additional US$210m for its infrastructure fund
summary: Keppel Capital, the asset management arm of Keppel Corp, secured an additional US$210 million for its Keppel Asia Infrastructure Fund, bringing the total capital commitments to US$570 million. The fund had previously closed with US$360 million and has also secured a US$100 million commitment from the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank. The fund's second closing and co-investment vehicles have acquired a 30% interest in the Gimi floating liquefied natural gas facility. The fund's CEO, Christina Tan, attributes the fund's success to the Covid-19 crisis creating opportunities for high-growth investments.

site_title: HDB, URA extend parking grace period to aid delivery persons
summary: The Housing Development Board (HDB) and Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) have extended the parking grace period for delivery persons in HDB and URA car parks from 10 minutes to 20 minutes until May 31, to aid in the delivery of food, groceries, and other essential goods amid Singapore's COVID-19 safe-distancing measures.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, OCBC, UOB, ComfortDelGro, Yangzijiang, Perennial
summary: Singapore's three major banks - DBS, OCBC, and UOB - have a combined exposure of at least US$600 million to troubled oil trader Hin Leong Trading. This development may affect their trading on Friday. Meanwhile, some Straits Times Index constituents, such as ComfortDelGro Corp, are expected to follow suit in slashing or cancelling dividends amid the pandemic's impact. The Straits Times Index has seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: China home-buying curbs set to stay despite nascent rally
summary: China's residential property market appears to be on the road to recovery, but local authorities are sticking to policies that discourage speculation, as dictated by President Xi Jinping. Despite recent policy easings, such as exemptions for green buildings, these measures have been quickly reversed. Local governments in Shandong province have proposed and then withdrawn policies to relax curbs on home buying, suggesting authorities will maintain a cautious stance to prevent speculation. This approach may hinder the market's full recovery.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks higher ahead of China GDP data
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.88% at the open on Friday, driven by anticipation of China's GDP figures later in the day. The Hang Seng Index rose to 24,457.83, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. Investors are awaiting the GDP data, which may impact global markets.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up over 3.1% on US recovery hopes
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 3.1% on Friday, closing at 19,897.26, as investors welcomed US President Donald Trump's plans for a phased reopening of the US economy. Japanese shares were supported by US stock rises, despite China's economy contracting for the first time in decades. The impact of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's decision to extend a nationwide state of emergency was limited. Market analysts attributed the rally to "Trump's vow to press ahead with reopening the economy."

images.alt_text: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index rallied more than 3.1 per cent on Friday as investors welcomed plans by President Donald Trump for a phased reopening of the US economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, extending Wall Street rallies, as investors await China's GDP figures. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.87% to 19,651.07, while the Topix index increased 1.16% to 1,438.79. This follows US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Minimise visits to banks, insurers during 'circuit-breaker' period: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) urges individuals to minimize visits to banks and insurers during the 'circuit-breaker' period, citing guidance from the Ministry of Health to reduce movement. Customers are advised to use digital channels, such as online banking, email, and phone, to meet their banking and financial needs. Banks like OCBC are also adjusting operations, with some branches closing temporarily and customers advised to use digital platforms or phone for certain services.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 16.88 points to 1,403.41 on Friday, driven by a 379-41 gainers-to-losers ratio. The index opened higher with 402.726 million lots traded worth RM131.1 million.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher tracking US market gains; STI up 2.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 54.72 points or 2.1% to 2,666.97 as US markets closed higher, tracking gains. The local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also advanced. Globally, US stocks finished higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.1%, the S&P 500 gaining 0.6%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1.7%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 1.9%.

site_title: China GDP shrank 6.8% in Q1, first contraction in decades: government
summary: China's economy contracted 6.8% in Q1, its first contraction in nearly three decades, due to measures to contain the coronavirus pandemic. This is according to the National Bureau of Statistics. The contraction was the first negative growth reported by the world's second-largest economy since it began logging quarterly data in the early 1990s. The drastic measures brought activity to a standstill, leading to the economic decline.

site_title: Prince Harry and Meghan hand out meals in Los Angeles
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, volunteered in Los Angeles, delivering meals to sick people, their first public activity since moving to California during the coronavirus lockdown. They partnered with Project Angel Food, a non-profit organization, on Easter Sunday and Wednesday. The royal couple, who have stepped down as senior members of the British royal family, aimed to give back to the community through their volunteer work.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Kashkari says Trump's 'staged approach' to reopen economy makes sense
summary: Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari stated that President Donald Trump's plan to reopen the US economy following the novel coronavirus pandemic "makes sense" and aligns with health experts' advice. Kashkari praised the three-stage approach, saying it would slowly revive the economy while avoiding the virus's resurgence. He noted the US economy is not grinding to a halt, despite being the deepest and quickest shutdown on record, but emphasized the need for grants, not loans, for small and medium-sized businesses. Kashkari also highlighted the challenge of providing aid through Congress.

site_title: Singapore reports 728 new Covid-19 cases to cross 4,000 mark
summary: Singapore reported 728 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 4,427, with 654 cases linked to foreign workers in dormitories. No imported cases were reported for the seventh day. Five new clusters were announced, and 19% of new cases remain unlinked. Globally, at least 138,482 people have died from Covid-19, and 2,078,071 are infected.

site_title: China reports new coronavirus cases drop to 2-week low
summary: Mainland China reported 26 new confirmed coronavirus cases on Thursday, the lowest daily total in two weeks, with 15 imported infections and 11 locally transmitted cases. The total number of confirmed cases stands at 82,367. No new deaths were reported. The number of new asymptomatic cases increased to 66 from 64 a day earlier. This marks a decline in infections involving travelers and locally transmitted cases.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares climb as US announces plan to reopen
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.9% to its highest level in over a month, while New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index gained 2.4% for a fourth consecutive session, driven by US President Donald Trump's plan to reopen the US economy and Boeing's plan to restart operations. Shares of Rio Tinto advanced 3% after reporting higher iron ore shipments, while Coca-Cola Amatil fell 3% after withdrawing its dividend payout forecast. The US jobless claims dropped, but economists warn Australia's economy may enter recession due to virus-induced shutdowns.

site_title: Hong Kong co-working providers thrive amid Covid-19 lockdown
summary: Hong Kong's co-working providers are thriving despite the Covid-19 lockdown, with TheDesk and The Executive Centre reporting significant increases in membership and desk space leased. Companies prefer co-working for flexibility and cash conservation, as they avoid long-term office leases and potential disruptions at home. In contrast, Singapore's co-working spaces have been forced to close due to the government-ordered shutdown, with operators like JustCo facing financial challenges. As the world adapts to remote work, co-working providers will need to prioritize health and safety to attract multinational clients.

site_title: China urges World Bank to suspend debt payments for poorest countries
summary: China urged the World Bank to suspend debt payments for its poorest borrowers while dealing with the coronavirus pandemic, saying it would be "net present value-neutral" and maintain its credit rating. The request comes as the Group of 20 countries agreed to suspend bilateral official debt service payments for the world's poorest countries through the end of the year. China also supports a general allocation of new Special Drawing Rights, but US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin opposes the idea, saying it would not benefit the poorest countries.

site_title: Japanese airlines keep most domestic flights despite few takers for seats
summary: Japan's top airlines, ANA Holdings Inc and Japan Airlines, are operating most of their domestic flights despite a significant decline in demand due to the coronavirus outbreak. The airlines are currently flying around two-thirds of capacity with 10% of usual demand, with some flights carrying fewer than 10 passengers. The government has not restricted domestic travel, but authorities are requesting people to stay in and close non-essential businesses. The airlines are burning through cash and are seeking financial aid, with estimated losses of 500 billion yen by the end of May and potentially up to 2 trillion yen over the year.

site_title: Two private groups considering bid for Virgin Australia: report
summary: Two private groups, a private equity investor and a strategic airline investor, are considering bids for Virgin Australia Holdings, the second-biggest airline in Australia. The airline has suspended trading to discuss financial aid and restructuring options amid the coronavirus crisis. Virgin Australia has been unsuccessful in its request for A$1.4 billion in loans from the Australian government. The airline is also exploring debt restructuring options, including a debt-for-equity swap, and has hired advisers to help navigate the process.

site_title: Australia may keep coronavirus restrictions for a year, schools may work on roster
summary: Australia may keep coronavirus restrictions in place for another year, with Prime Minister Scott Morrison warning that social distancing measures could remain for several months. The country has avoided high coronavirus casualties by closing borders and imposing strict measures, resulting in 6,500 infections and 63 deaths. Schools in New South Wales are considering a rostering system, with some students returning to school in shifts, as parents and teachers express concerns about exposure to the virus.

site_title: Chefs On Lockdown
summary: Four Singaporean chefs are adapting to life at home during the COVID-19 pandemic by cooking family-style meals, stripping away their formal attire, and sharing their recipes for comfort food. After being away from their restaurants due to dining-in restrictions, the chefs are finding solace in cooking for themselves and their families, often incorporating new recipes and ingredients into their meals. This unconventional approach allows them to maintain their culinary expertise while also embracing the comforts of home cooking.

site_title: UK extends lockdown for 3 weeks, with no clear exit strategy
summary: The UK has extended its lockdown for at least three weeks to combat the spread of coronavirus, with no clear exit strategy in place. The decision was made by Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab, who stated that lifting the lockdown would risk a second outbreak and damage the economy. To ease restrictions, the government has set five prerequisites, including a sustained decline in daily death rates and increased testing capacity. However, Britain's testing record has been criticized, and experts say the government needs to implement an aggressive testing and contact tracing program for the general population.

images.alt_text: Britain confirmed on Thursday that it would prolong its lockdown for at least three more weeks as part of efforts to keep smothering the spread of the coronavirus. But the government was far less clear about the steps it is taking that would allow it to relax restrictions later without causing another outbreak.

site_title: Indonesian clothing maker pivots from Prada, Adidas to hazmat suits
summary: An Indonesian clothing maker, PT Pan Brothers, is pivoting from producing garments for luxury brands like Prada and Adidas to manufacturing hazmat suits and face masks in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The company is producing millions of masks and jumpsuits per week, with a focus on domestic distribution but also fielding calls from potential buyers in the US, Australia, and Europe. PT Pan Brothers aims to supply 80% of its production to Indonesia and 20% to the world, with a goal of producing 100 million masks and 10 million jumpsuits.

site_title: Trump was too slow in virus response: poll
summary: A recent Pew Research Centre poll found that nearly two-thirds of Americans, or 65%, believe President Donald Trump was too slow in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic. The poll also showed that 52% think Trump's public comments are making the situation seem better than it really is. Meanwhile, a gradual reopening of the economy is being discussed, despite a recent surge in US deaths. The survey found that 73% of US adults believe the worst is still to come, with concerns about states lifting restrictions too quickly.

images.alt_text: Nearly two-thirds of Americans say President Donald Trump was too slow in taking major steps to address the threat to the United States from the coronavirus, a poll published on Thursday said.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports in March jump 17.6% partially due to 'low base'
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports rose 17.6% in March, exceeding economists' expectations of a 8% contraction due to the Covid-19 pandemic. This follows a 3.1% gain in February, which also surprised economists. The strong performance is attributed to a 'low base', with the previous year's March exports having declined due to the pandemic. The data suggests a resilient economy despite the ongoing pandemic, with Singapore's exports continuing to grow despite weak global outlook.

site_title: US coronavirus death toll passes 32,000: tracker
summary: The US coronavirus death toll has surpassed 32,917, according to a Johns Hopkins University tracker, with a record 4,491 deaths reported in the past 24 hours. This figure likely includes "probable" deaths related to Covid-19, which were not previously included. The US has the highest death toll in the world, followed by Italy, with over 667,800 coronavirus cases recorded in the US. President Trump unveiled plans to reopen the US economy, allowing each state's governor to take a phased approach.

site_title: Toyota-backed Pony.ai to offer autonomous delivery service in California
summary: Toyota-backed Pony.ai to launch an autonomous delivery service in Irvine, California, amid the coronavirus lockdown, which has surged demand for online orders. The service will use electric vehicles to deliver packages from local e-commerce platform Yamibuy, marking Pony.ai's first attempt at delivering goods. The company has received regulatory approval from California's DMV and raised $462 million in funding, led by Toyota, to support its expansion.

site_title: Shell greenlights A$10b Australia natural gas project
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has taken a final investment decision to develop the Surat Gas Project in Queensland, Australia, a $10 billion natural gas project expected to produce up to 90 billion cubic feet per year. Construction will start this year, with first gas sales anticipated in 2021. The project is seen as a timely injection of cash for Australia's economy, which is facing recession due to the coronavirus pandemic, and will bring 200 jobs to the state. Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk welcomed the decision, calling it a "shot in the arm" for the state's economy.

images.alt_text: Royal Dutch Shell said on Friday it had taken a final investment decision to develop the first phase of Australia's biggest coal seam gas resource in Queensland state.

site_title: Yangzijiang subsidiary to provide credit facility to chairman's unit
summary: A Yangzijiang Shipbuilding subsidiary, Jiangsu New Yangzi Shipbuilding, has agreed to provide a 1.56 billion yuan credit facility to Jiangyin Xinyangchuan Enterprise Management Center, a company led by Yangzijiang executive chairman Ren Yuanlin and his son Ren Letian, who hold a 41% stake. The credit facility follows a master facility agreement signed on April 16.

site_title: China's virus-hit economy set to post first decline since at least 1992
summary: China's economy is expected to post its first decline since at least 1992, with analysts forecasting a 6.5% shrinkage in gross domestic product (GDP) from January to March. The coronavirus pandemic has ravaged demand at home and abroad, and policymakers face pressure to revive growth amid mounting job losses and growing debt. A stimulus package is expected to be delivered, with most new credit going towards financial relief to help enterprises, banks, and households survive the crisis.

site_title: South Korea workforce participation rate posts fastest drop since 2009
summary: South Korea's workforce participation rate dropped to 62.2% in March, the fastest decline since 2009, due to the coronavirus pandemic. The unemployment rate rose to 3.8%, while the number of new jobs decreased by 195,000, marking the first on-year decline since 2010. Analysts predict further shrinkage in the workforce, with exports expected to decline, potentially leading to an economic contraction this year.

site_title: US: Stocks finish higher despite weak economic data
summary: US stocks rose despite weak economic data, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.1%, the S&P 500 increasing 0.6%, and the Nasdaq Composite jumping 1.7%. President Donald Trump vowed to reopen the economy, despite bleak data. The gains were driven by positive investor sentiment, with traders brushing off new Trump threats. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records, while the Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) also rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Britain's Princess Beatrice cancels wedding amid coronavirus: media reports
summary: Britain's Princess Beatrice and her fiancé Edoardo Mapelli Mozzi have canceled their royal wedding due to the UK's lockdown amid the coronavirus pandemic. The couple had previously scaled back plans and canceled a Buckingham Palace reception. There are no plans to reschedule the wedding, with a spokesperson stating that the couple is not thinking about their wedding at this time.

site_title: Paper towels may remove virus missed by poor hand washing: study
summary: A study by experts from the University of Leeds and Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust found that using paper towels to dry hands after washing is more effective at removing microbes than jet dryers, which can spread pathogens. The study, conducted on four volunteers with contaminated hands, found that microbes were 10 times more likely to be present on surfaces touched after using a jet dryer. The researchers recommend using paper towels to dry hands after washing to reduce the risk of virus contamination and spread, particularly in hospital settings.

site_title: Upcoming earnings season will determine if new quarterly reporting regime is sufficient
summary: The effectiveness of Singapore's new quarterly reporting regime will be tested during the upcoming earnings season, which coincides with the global COVID-19 pandemic. Many STI constituents have shifted to semi-annual reporting, with some providing voluntary Q1 and Q3 updates. Market watchers express anxiety among stakeholders seeking answers, making the new approach's success uncertain. The first earnings season since the quarterly reporting regime was dropped will provide crucial insight into the new system's efficacy.

site_title: IMF approves US$1.4b in coronavirus aid to Pakistan
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) approved nearly $1.4 billion in emergency aid to Pakistan to help the country weather the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The near-term economic impact of Covid-19 is expected to be significant, giving rise to large fiscal and external financing needs.

site_title: Uber expects up to US$2.2b impairment charge, drop in quarterly revenue due to pandemic
summary: Uber expects an impairment charge of up to $2.2 billion due to the coronavirus outbreak, which will reduce its revenue by $17-$22 million in the first quarter and $60-$80 million in the second quarter. The company withdrew its 2020 forecast and will account for financial assistance to drivers and delivery people in its revenue. Uber's shares rose 6.6% in extended trading, and the company is set to report first-quarter results on May 7.

site_title: Australian companies race to raise capital, share placements top A$10b
summary: Australian companies have raised over A$10 billion in new shares this year, the second highest on record, as they seek funds amid the economic downturn triggered by the new coronavirus. The move makes Australia the most active capital market in the Asian region, excluding China. Analysts predict the country is on course for its first recession in three decades, but demand for equity deals from investors is expected to be sustained. Several companies, including QBE, Oil Search, and Cochlear, have raised billions of dollars in the past few weeks.

site_title: Carnival CEO defends company's safety record as cruise industry remains grounded
summary: Carnival CEO Arnold Donald defended the company's safety record during a media call, stating that the company followed international protocols while handling coronavirus outbreaks on two ships. The Diamond Princess and Grand Princess ships were quarantined, with 712 and 21 passengers infected, respectively, after exhibiting flu-like symptoms. Donald said the company cooperated with authorities, including the CDC, and implemented enhanced sanitization and health safety protocols. Carnival's shares remain down 77% since January due to the pandemic, and the company has no plans to re-incorporate in the US.

site_title: Apple launches new budget iPhone
summary: Apple has launched a new budget iPhone, the iPhone SE, priced starting at S$649 in Singapore. The device is available in 64GB, 128GB, and 256GB models, targeting consumers facing economic uncertainty. The iPhone SE will be available for order in over 40 markets, starting from this Friday.

site_title: Safe Scents
summary: Maison 21G, a Parisian perfumery, launches a new collection of scented hand sanitizers with 75% alcohol content to kill germs and bacteria. The hand sanitizers come in four scented combinations, elegantly presented in 15ml glass bottles, and are priced at S$15. This refined hand sanitizer is an alternative to soap and water when they are not available.

site_title: Will SGX look into problems of virtual AGMs and bunching?
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) listed companies face issues with virtual Annual General Meetings (AGMs) and bunching, which can prevent investors from attending due to conflicting schedules. The lack of detailed minutes and limited interactive Q&A sessions also hinders important information flow. To address these concerns, the SGX should encourage companies to hold AGMs at different times and use digital applications like Zoom to facilitate live meetings.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher on hopes of pandemic plateauing
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Thursday as daily coronavirus death tolls in Spain and Italy eased, signaling the pandemic may be plateauing. The STOXX 600 index climbed for the sixth time in seven days, driven by gains in technology, autos, and financial stocks. Analysts expect a corporate recession to deepen in 2020, with earnings for STOXX 600 companies falling 22% in the first quarter. US jobless claims fell slightly, and President Trump is expected to announce new guidelines for re-opening the economy.

site_title: Quest Ventures looks to bridge S-E Asia and Central Asia with second fund
summary: Quest Ventures has secured US$26 million in its first close for its US$50 million second fund, aiming to bridge startup collaborations between Central Asia and South-east Asia. The fund, which will target post-seed and Series A-stage startups, includes investments from Pavilion Capital and QazTech Ventures, a venture capital firm under Kazakhstan's sovereign wealth fund. Quest plans to deploy the capital into five deals, with an accelerator launch in Kazakhstan to "jumpstart the region's digital economy."

site_title: Trump says US reopening to be done 'one careful step at a time'
summary: President Donald Trump announced a gradual reopening of the US economy from the coronavirus shutdown, recommending a cautious approach with three phases. State governors will take the lead, and the plan allows for different states to reopen at varying times. Trump emphasized the focus on safety and preventing a resurgence, departing from his previous calls for a rapid reopening. The plan does not provide a specific timetable, but aims to gradually restore the economic life of the country "one careful step at a time".

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump on Thursday said the reopening of the US economy will take place gradually, with states that saw little of the pandemic starting first.

site_title: Oil little changed, US ties 18-year low after Opec cuts demand forecast
summary: Oil prices remained largely unchanged on Thursday, with Brent crude rising 0.5% to $27.82 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude ending at an 18-year-low of $19.87. Despite Opec's forecast of a 6.9% contraction in global oil demand for 2020, some European countries' plans to relax coronavirus restrictions may support a rebound in fuel demand, according to traders.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were mixed on Thursday, as Brent crude rose modestly while US futures ended unchanged at an 18-year-low after some European countries said they would relax coronavirus restrictions even though Opec lowered its global oil demand forecast.

site_title: Commercial, industrial properties still draw interest
summary: Despite the COVID-19 outbreak, Singapore's commercial and industrial properties continue to draw interest from business owners and investors. Recent deals include a freehold shophouse in Holland Village sold for S$15.2 million, and a six-storey International Press Building sold for S$26 million to the StorHub Group. Additionally, nine units at People's Park Centre in Chinatown were sold for S$22.2 million, while a freehold strata retail unit at 1 St Martin's Drive was sold for S$43 million. These transactions demonstrate the ongoing demand for commercial and industrial properties in Singapore.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit Q1 DPU down 26% to 0.883 Singapore cent
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit reported a 26.3% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.883 cents in Q1 FY2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The Reit's gross revenue rose 3.6% to S$23.5 million, but net property income fell 5.1% to S$17.4 million. The Reit's portfolio occupancy rate rose to 84.7% and about 11% of leases will expire in FY2020. The manager has adopted a more cautious approach by deferring certain capital distributions to conserve capital.

site_title: Sushi showdown
summary: Three upscale Japanese restaurants - Aoki, Ki-sho, and Sushi Kimura - compare their takeaway sushi options, known as chirashizushi. Aoki's Maze Chirashi (S$45) is a standout with a fun-to-eat combination of cubed sashimi and salad greens. Ki-sho's Luxurious Chirashi Don (S$98) eclipses Aoki's in quality, with premium seafood and sweet uni. Sushi Kimura's All-Kinds Chirashi (S$95) offers a variety of tuna cuts and perfectly textured sushi rice. The takeaway experience varies between the three restaurants, with Aoki offering a more convenient service and Sushi Kimura providing a contactless payment option.

site_title: International cooperation is crucial in solving Covid-19
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for international cooperation to address global shortages of medical supplies, such as masks, gowns, and ventilators. History shows that cooperation, not competition, can save lives, as seen during World War I when the Allies created institutions to pool and allocate scarce goods. The US and European countries' current export controls and competition for these supplies threaten to raise prices to dangerous levels. To solve this, empowering international bodies with resources to ensure every country has the necessary supplies is crucial, requiring a form of global redistribution.

site_title: DBS, OCBC, UOB faced with over US$600m total exposure to Hin Leong
summary: Singapore's three local banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, have a combined exposure of at least US$600 million to troubled oil trader Hin Leong Trading. DBS has the highest exposure at around US$290 million, while OCBC Bank is owed about US$220 million. United Overseas Bank (UOB) had a drawdown of over US$100 million as of early April. This exposure is part of more than 20 banks worldwide with a combined total of at least US$3 billion.

site_title: S-Reits get lifeline on cash flow, fund-raising
summary: Singapore's S-Reits will benefit from new measures to manage cash flows and raise funds amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The Ministry of Finance and Monetary Authority of Singapore have extended the deadline for distribution of taxable income and raised the leverage limit from 45% to 50%. Additionally, the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore will provide further details by early May. These measures aim to provide S-Reits with more flexibility to manage their cash flows and access different funding channels, including debt and equity fundraising.

images.alt_text: Real estate investment trusts listed on the Singapore Exchange (S-Reits) will soon benefit from new measures that will give them more flexibility to manage their cash flows and raise funds amid the operating environment made challenging by Covid-19.

site_title: UBS's billionaire clients keen on turnaround opportunities
summary: UBS's private credit business has seen a surge in interest from sophisticated wealth investors seeking turnaround opportunities amid the novel coronavirus-induced market dislocation. The O'Connor Capital Solutions unit has closed seven transactions in seven weeks, providing liquidity to companies, funds, and ultra-high-net-worth individuals. Wealthy clients are seeking refinancing of margin loans and exploring relative value investing opportunities in distressed credit markets. UBS is working on financing for middle-market companies, medical-device companies, and acquiring less-resilient peers, with a focus on providing liquidity and growth opportunities.

site_title: Lazard boosts restructuring team as virus-hit firms struggle
summary: Lazard Ltd has strengthened its restructuring team in response to the global economic downturn caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The US investment bank has hired former Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom partner Chris Mallon as a senior adviser to its global restructuring practice. The International Monetary Fund predicts a 3% global economic contraction in 2020, prompting companies to seek emergency aid. Lazard is in high demand, along with other independent advisory firms, as boardrooms scramble to mitigate the damage.

site_title: Cash-strapped Thais rush to sell gold as Covid-19 hits economy
summary: Thais rush to sell gold in Bangkok's Chinatown amid the COVID-19 recession, taking advantage of a surge in prices to US$1,722 an ounce, a seven-year high. Many Thais keep gold as savings and sell it during economic hardship. Thousands of people queued at shops, with some selling 120,000 baht worth of gold. Experts warn that gold prices may still rise, but advise against selling gold at once. Thailand's economy is expected to contract 5.3% this year, the worst contraction since 1998.

site_title: Boeing to restart commercial plane manufacturing
summary: Boeing plans to restart commercial plane manufacturing at its Washington state facility, with approximately 27,000 workers returning to work in a phased ramp-up starting next week. The facility, which was closed in late March due to the coronavirus, will resume building several commercial aircraft models, including the 777 and 737. This move comes after the company announced its intention to resume operations, marking the first time the facility has been operational since the shutdown.

site_title: PE firm Chartered Group to raise US$500m for Japan-Israel deep tech fund
summary: Chartered Group, a Singapore-based private equity firm, is raising a US$500 million fund to invest in deep tech firms from Israel or with Israeli founders and incubate them in Japan. The fund, in collaboration with Israel's Ministry of Defence, aims to facilitate investments in areas such as brain-machine interfaces, energy solutions, and autonomous systems. The partnership seeks to attract Japanese conglomerates and nurture deep tech firms, potentially leading to larger-scale government projects and collaborations between Japan and Israel.

site_title: STI ekes out small gain as Covid-19 continues to sour investor sentiment
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) ended Thursday up 6.69 points or 0.3% at 2,612.25 points, rebounding from overnight losses. The risk-off atmosphere amid growing Covid-19 cases and weak economic data weighed on investor sentiment. Despite this, the blue-chip index saw gains from advancers, with Yangzijiang Shipbuilding being the top performer. Banking stocks DBS, UOB, and OCBC fell, while agri-food company Japfa jumped 9.8% following an announcement of a China dairy business sale.

site_title: Perennial sells remaining 30% stake in 111 Somerset to Stanley Ho's Shun Tak for S$155m
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings sold its 30% stake in 111 Somerset to Shun Tak Holdings for S$155.1 million in cash. The development, located in Orchard Road, Singapore, comprises office towers and a retail podium. Perennial aims to rebalance its portfolio and maximize returns to shareholders with the deal, which is part of its active capital recycling strategy. The transaction is expected to be completed on May 31, with Perennial retaining property and project management rights.

images.alt_text: Perennial Real Estate Holdings is divesting its entire 30 per cent stake in 111 Somerset, known locally as TripleOne Somerset, to gambling mogul Stanley Ho's Shun Tak Holdings for S$155.1 million in cash.

site_title: Consequences to ponder if the US Fed indulges in 'QE Infinity'
summary: The US Federal Reserve is considering unlimited quantitative easing, dubbed "QE Infinity," to prevent a financial system collapse amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The Fed's massive bailout could inject up to $6 trillion into markets, buying various financial products, including stocks. While markets have welcomed the move, concerns remain over the long-term impact on the global economy and the potential consequences of such massive money injections, which could have inflationary effects or exacerbate existing economic imbalances. The VIX Index, measuring market volatility, has reached all-time highs, indicating market fears and the need for swift action.

site_title: China's March home prices may signal slow recovery
summary: China's new home prices in March grew 5.3% annually, the slowest pace since June 2018, but showed a tentative recovery after the COVID-19 pandemic. Prices rose for the 10th consecutive month, with 70 cities reporting monthly price increases. Despite a rebound in mortgages and consumer loans, analysts warn that the impact of the pandemic on jobs and consumer confidence may continue to crimp sales for months.

site_title: Japan makes Covid-19 emergency nationwide
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has expanded the country's COVID-19 emergency nationwide, affecting over 44% of the population. The state of emergency, which runs until May 6, aims to reduce traffic and prevent the spread of the virus during the Golden Week holiday season. The government is considering cash payouts of 100,000 yen (S$1,329) for everyone, and has set aside funds for households whose incomes have been hit by the virus. The move follows growing calls for bolder steps to combat the pandemic and cushion the economic downturn.

site_title: Shell vows to become carbon neutral by 2050
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has pledged to become a carbon-neutral energy business by 2050, matching rival BP's commitment. The company aims to reduce its net carbon footprint by 65% by 2050 and 30% by 2035. To achieve this, Shell plans to pivot towards serving businesses and sectors that also aim for net-zero emissions by 2050. The pledge comes as the energy sector faces severe strain from collapsing oil prices and the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Fed warns of worsening US economy as retail, factories hit
summary: The US economy has worsened due to the novel coronavirus pandemic, with key retail sales and manufacturing sectors contracting sharply. The Federal Reserve warns that the near-term outlook is for more job cuts, with about 17 million people losing their jobs since mid-March. Retail sales plummeted 8.7% from February, while manufacturing declined 5.4% in March, its largest drop since 1946. The Fed expects conditions to worsen in the next several months, with global GDP potentially shrinking by up to $9 trillion.

site_title: Design on Film
summary: Designers share their favorite films to watch during the Covid-19 pandemic, citing titles such as "The Human Scale," "Yellow is Forbidden," and "Her" for their insights into design and human experience. These films, including documentaries and fashion films, offer perspectives on design, functionality, and aesthetics, and are accessible for free on streaming platforms like Amazon Prime Video.

site_title: Ocean Tankers distances itself from Hin Leong Trading
summary: Ocean Tankers, a unit of Hin Leong Group, has sought to distance itself from the financial woes of Hin Leong Trading, citing "news in the public domain" about debt restructuring. Ocean Tankers' CEO Evan Lim Chee Meng assured partners and customers that the company is a separate entity and has not guaranteed Hin Leong's debts. The move comes amid reports that Hin Leong Trading owes US$3 billion to over 20 banks and is in talks with lenders to raise funds.

site_title: BT Budding Artists kids keep performing and painting online
summary: During Singapore's circuit breaker period, The RICE Company Limited, a not-for-profit organization, has adapted its arts programs to provide online classes for approximately 500 kids and trainers. The initiative, supported by The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, aims to bring arts education to low-income households. With 36 schools now participating, around 300 students from Ministry of Education schools are benefiting from the #Engage initiative, which includes self-shot classes and live video conferencing. The company plans to send "surprise packs" to all students at the end of the circuit breaker period.

site_title: Singapore coronavirus cases cross 4,000 with 728 cases in new daily record
summary: Singapore reported a new daily high of 728 coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 4,427 cases, surpassing 4,000 for the second consecutive day. The majority of new cases, 654, are foreign workers living in dormitories, with five new clusters announced, including two large dormitories linked to 31 and 21 cases. No imported cases were reported for the seventh consecutive day, with 683 patients recovered and 10 deaths.

site_title: American wine producers facing fear, uncertainty and hope
summary: US wine producers face uncertainty as the COVID-19 pandemic disrupts their business, with many relying on direct shipping to stay afloat. Small family-owned wineries, in particular, are struggling to survive, with some having to furlough staff and lay off employees. Despite the challenges, some producers are finding solace in the vineyard's natural rhythms, and a few are even seeing increased sales. However, the industry's reliance on the hospitality sector means that the long-term impact of the pandemic remains uncertain, with many fearing an existential crisis for some businesses.

site_title: China's fledgling car rebound faces risks of parts shortage
summary: China's auto industry is facing a new challenge as parts shortages threaten to disrupt the recovery from the coronavirus outbreak. The pandemic is causing production disruptions in Europe, North America, and Japan, which supply crucial components to Chinese automakers. The potential shortage of imported parts, particularly electronic components, could affect the production of higher-end vehicles that rely on software and computers. While some carmakers in China rely on local supplies, many still import components, making them vulnerable to supply shocks.

site_title: Corporates' bad actions speak much louder than good words
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, many corporations, including Marriott International and Amazon, have pledged to prioritize workers and communities, but their actions contradict these statements. Despite furloughing employees and paying dividends to shareholders, companies are not adequately protecting workers from danger. Examples include Marriott International, which has begun furloughing most of its American workers, while paying out more than $160 million in quarterly dividends, and Amazon, where workers have protested outside warehouses due to the company's failure to provide protective gear. The Business Roundtable's pledge appears to be a public relations move, as executive pay remains tied to stock prices.

site_title: A Creative Awakening
summary: The creative industry in Singapore is adapting to the Covid-19 pandemic by finding new ways to express themselves and provide aid to those in need. Companies like NoonTalk Media are using digital streaming to host events and shows, while artists and freelancers are sharing their work online to raise funds and provide entertainment. The government's S$55 million Arts and Culture Resilience Package is supporting digital projects, and various initiatives are being launched to support creatives, such as the Pasar Glamour Art Aid and the Singapore Association of Motion Picture Professionals' Covid-19 Relief Fund. Despite the challenges, many are embracing the opportunity to innovate and connect with their audiences online.

site_title: STI blue chips expected to cut dividends as pandemic slashes profits
summary: STI blue chips are expected to cut dividends as the COVID-19 pandemic slashes profits. SPH Reit, Singapore Press Holdings, and ComfortDelGro Corp have already cut their dividend payouts. Analysts predict other companies, including Singapore Airlines, Sats, and Singtel, to follow suit due to reduced revenue and cash preservation. Genting Singapore and Singapore Exchange (SGX) are potential exceptions, with Genting maintaining its dividend payout despite reduced forecasts and SGX having a net cash position. Dividend cuts are expected to persist for some time, making it harder to restore payouts.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: StarHub apologized for home broadband service disruptions and is offering a 20% rebate to affected customers. The company attributes the issue to an internal network change management process and is reviewing processes to prevent recurrence. Meanwhile, Darco Water Technologies is conducting an internal review of transactions entered into by its former CEO, Thye Kim Meng, amid allegations of misconduct. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, and Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Coronavirus and the coming green financial revolution
summary: A global pandemic is leading to a significant shift in capital reallocation, with trillions of dollars being poured into the renewable energy sector to address climate change. The economic crisis has made it clear that the current neoliberal economic trajectory has reached its limits, and a new generation of investors, innovators, and scientists are working to create a more sustainable future. Companies like Facedrive, Google, Facebook, Apple, and Amazon are leading the charge in adopting green technologies, with many committing to be carbon neutral or making significant investments in renewable energy. The COVID-19 pandemic has paved the way for a green financial revolution, with the environment, sustainability, and governance (ESG) investment niche already worth over $30 trillion.

site_title: US homebuilder confidence sees record plunge on hit from virus
summary: US homebuilder confidence plummeted to 30 in April, the lowest level in over seven years, due to the novel coronavirus pandemic. This is the largest monthly decline in the 30-year history of the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index. The unprecedented drop is attributed to the pandemic's impact on unemployment and construction activities. Before the pandemic, the market showed signs of strength, but with stay-at-home orders, builders have seen significant declines in buyer traffic and face various business challenges.

site_title: Hyflux gets Court's approval to postpone scheme meetings, moratorium deadline
summary: Hyflux, a water-treatment company, received the High Court's approval to postpone scheme meetings and extend a moratorium deadline due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The meetings, initially scheduled for April 22-23, have been postponed to a later date, while the moratorium has been extended until July 30. A case management conference has been scheduled for May 14 to issue further directions.

site_title: City In Red
summary: British photographer Finbarr Fallon's "Flora Phantasmagoria" series captures Singapore through infrared photography, revealing the city's lush greenery in shades of scarlet. The 14 photographs showcase the city's green spaces, such as the Padang and Bishan Park, and highlight the tension between urban development and nature. Fallon's unique approach uses a special glass filter to capture the vibrant hues of plants in infrared light, creating striking images that draw viewers in. The series aims to present the city in a different way, emphasizing the importance of biophilic planning and design.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims top 5.2m in latest week
summary: US jobless claims reached 5.2 million in the latest week, lifting total filings over the past month to 20 million, highlighting the deepening economic slump caused by the novel coronavirus outbreak. Economists predict a recession and estimate the economy contracted in the first quarter at its sharpest pace since World War II. Initial claims are expected to remain elevated in coming weeks as states struggle to clear backlogs and companies lay off workers in response to the shutdown.

site_title: China's risky wealth products gain new appeal
summary: China's low-interest rates are creating a lucrative trade for companies, as they issue debt to buy high-yielding asset management products. The yield gap between short-term corporate debt and banks' wealth contracts is at its widest since 2016, with some firms issuing debt to buy junk debt and maintain high returns. This trend is a result of the People's Bank of China's efforts to stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Building a European Reconstruction Fund to invest in recovery
summary: The Eurogroup has agreed to a 500 billion euro package to mitigate the economic fallout of the Covid-19 crisis, including 25 billion euros for the European Investment Bank, 250 billion euros for the European Stability Mechanism, and 100 billion euros for a new instrument to help manage unemployment crises. The deal provides substantial liquidity support to member states, but does not address the issue of mounting debt, which threatens to hamper growth. A new European Reconstruction Fund, backed by the European Commission, is proposed to finance a 1 trillion euro economic reconstruction package through consolidated annuities, which would be a safe investment in the EU's future and avoid mutualizing existing debt.

site_title: Moon's win shows public support for Seoul's big spending to fight Covid-19
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in's party won a landslide election, demonstrating public support for the government's big spending to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. The government's stimulus package, which includes emergency cash handouts, was already outlined before the election and received widespread backing. This victory shows the effectiveness of the government's economic measures, which have included a record-breaking annual budget and an additional extra budget. The outcome suggests that the public is willing to tolerate increased government spending to mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Business As Usual
summary: Singaporean executives share tips on maintaining a positive mindset while working from home during the Circuit Breaker period. Charles Yap, Vice President of Marketing Communications at ONYX Hospitality Group, stays positive by recreating hotel experiences at home, chatting with restaurant managers, and ordering food from his favorite restaurants. Casey Teh, Managing Director of Simmons, keeps his life normal by working out, reading, and spending time with his dog. Angelene Chan, CEO of DP Architects, finds calm through meditation, running, and family time. Anna Haotanto, CEO of The New Savvy, prioritizes self-care, learning, and relationships to maintain a positive attitude during the pandemic.

site_title: BreadTalk offeror meets compulsory acquisition threshold
summary: BreadTalk Group announced Thursday that its offeror has met the compulsory acquisition threshold, with acceptances representing about 97.77% of the company's total shares. The offeror, BTG Holding, is owned by BreadTalk founder George Quek and his wife, and intends to buy back all remaining shares at 77 cents per piece. The compulsory acquisition will allow BTG Holding to acquire all unaccepted shares under the same offer terms.

site_title: Darco Water reviewing transactions entered into by former CEO
summary: DARCO Water Technologies is conducting an internal review of transactions entered into by former CEO Thye Kim Meng, including those related to the Con Dao solar project and Darco Engineering Taiwan. The review focuses on terms, due diligence, and potential conflict of interests. The company has sought further information from Thye, who was the main driver of transactions for various projects. The review's preliminary findings have not been made public.

site_title: Swiber in talks with potential investor for restructuring plan
summary: Swiber Holdings, a debt-laden offshore and marine group, is in talks with a Middle East-based oil and gas conglomerate for a potential restructuring deal. The deal includes a US$200 million investment and a bond issuance, with the suitor aiming to acquire at least 80% of a new Swiber subsidiary, New Swiber, which will own some assets and contracts. The move comes as Swiber is currently under judicial management.

site_title: US: Wall St up on hopes of lockdown easing, jobless claims
summary: US stock markets rose on Thursday as weekly jobless claims fell slightly and investors remained hopeful about potential lockdown easing. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite opened higher, with the Dow up 0.17%, the S&P 500 up 0.57%, and the Nasdaq up 1.02%. The slight drop in jobless claims and President Trump's potential push for relaxed lockdowns contributed to the market's optimism.
