site_title: P2P lender Validus sees 50-75% spike in applications for unsecured SME loans
summary: Validus Capital, a Singapore-based peer-to-peer lender, saw a 50-75% surge in applications for unsecured loans to small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in March, driven by cash-strapped businesses hit by the virus outbreak. The firm plans to partner with more large corporates to provide loan facilities to their supply chains, aiming to bring down default risks. Validus' niche focus on SMEs has a high approval rate, and the firm has already tied up with 10 corporates and has a dozen more in the pipeline.

site_title: Trump to push for reopening US as millions more seek unemployment aid
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to announce new guidelines to reopen the economy despite concerns from health experts and business leaders about a resurgence in cases. The US unemployment rate has reached 8.2%, with over 20 million Americans seeking unemployment benefits, and the nation's economy has been severely impacted by the coronavirus outbreak. Trump will hold a call with governors and announce his plan at a news conference, despite warnings from union leaders and CEOs about the need for more testing and worker safety measures.

site_title: At home with staying at home
summary: The article discusses the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the workplace, exploring potential changes to work arrangements and office spaces. Experts weigh in on the shift to remote work, its effects on authenticity and consumer behavior, and the evolution of the office. Additionally, the article touches on various lifestyle topics, including dining, travel, and leisure options, as well as health issues such as throat cancer.

site_title: Greenback at 1-week high before US jobless data
summary: The US dollar reached a one-week high against a basket of major currencies, rising 0.2% to 99.808, before US jobless data was released. Economists forecast 5.1 million jobless claims, which would lift total filings above 20 million. The greenback has gained during the crisis due to its safe-haven status, but is expected to underperform in the medium term as economies recover. The euro dropped 0.3% against the US dollar, while oil prices remained at 18-year lows, further strengthening the dollar.

site_title: Preferred stock will help big firms recover from Covid-19
summary: Congress and President Donald Trump have enacted the Coronavirus Aid, Relief and Economic Security (Cares) Act in response to the Covid-19 crisis, but it's becoming clear that measures won't be sufficient. Lawmakers are discussing a potential second stimulus package, and some are advocating for alternative approaches to supporting large corporations, such as preferred stock, to avoid the risks associated with large-scale lending and potential misuse of funds.

site_title: Japan expands virus emergency nationwide
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has expanded a state of emergency nationwide to combat the growing coronavirus outbreak, covering all prefectures despite no punitive measures or legal force. The declaration, which will remain in effect until May 6, urges citizens to form a "united front" and aims to reduce transmission. To support the economy, Abe announced a plan to distribute 100,000 yen to every citizen. The country has seen around 8,500 infections and 136 deaths, with medical facilities warning of a potential collapse.

site_title: Covid-19 pandemic to bring Asia's economic growth to a halt for first time in 60 years: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) predicts Asia's economic growth will grind to a halt this year for the first time in 60 years due to the coronavirus crisis. The service sector and major export destinations are severely impacted, with the region expected to suffer zero growth. China's economy is forecast to grow 1.2% this year, down from 6% previously, while the world's second-largest economy is expected to rebound to 9.2% next year. Policymakers are urged to offer targeted support to households and firms, and to provide ample liquidity to markets to mitigate the economic impact.

site_title: Online Presentation
summary: Working from home on Zoom meetings requires a balance of professionalism and comfort. To appear presentable, position yourself in front of a clean and well-lit background, and sit at an angle to the camera. Wear neutral colors and avoid patterns, opting for cool blues, natural tones, and pastels instead. Add a pop of color with accessories or a blazer, and consider a turtleneck or tailored blazer to frame your face. Finally, keep your hair neat and apply makeup to enhance your features, making a good impression in online meetings.

site_title: Facebook steps up fight against fake news about Covid-19
summary: Facebook has introduced tailored warnings to users highlighting facts about the Covid-19 pandemic, following criticism of the platform's handling of misinformation. The company will show messages in News Feed to users who previously engaged with harmful misinformation, pointing them to accurate information from the World Health Organization. This move comes after 95% of users who saw warning labels about virus-related posts did not view the original content. Facebook has also launched a dedicated coronavirus information centre with over 350 million clicks, and limited message forwarding on WhatsApp to curb disinformation.

site_title: Manufacturing Integration's units obtain 'essential services' green light
summary: Manufacturing Integration Technology's subsidiaries, Casem (Asia) and Automated Manufacturing Solutions, have received approvals to operate as essential services during Singapore's circuit-breaker measures. They will assemble micro-positioners for the semiconductor industry and healthcare products equipment. The group's other staff will work from home. The move comes as workplaces are required to temporarily suspend operations from April 7 to May 4, 2020, to break the chain of local Covid-19 transmission.

site_title: Federal Reserve giving banks a break to keep markets calm
summary: The Federal Reserve is allowing banks to continue paying dividends despite the COVID-19 pandemic, which is causing severe strain across various markets. This decision has raised concerns that the Fed is ignoring the costly lessons of the 2008 financial crisis. Banks have voluntarily suspended stock buybacks, but are loath to halt dividends, which could signal financial weakness. The Fed has made changes to allow banks to continue making dividends, including relaxing borrowing caps and offering cheap funding programs. Some former Fed officials, including Janet Yellen, believe the central bank should consider constraining payouts to prevent banks from weakening in the face of uncertainty.

site_title: Linda Collins, Author of Loss Adjustment
summary: Linda Collins, author of "Loss Adjustment," shares her personal experience of profound grief after the loss of her 17-year-old daughter and a devastating earthquake that destroyed their home. Collins notes that the COVID-19 crisis has led to widespread grief, including the loss of identity, job security, and personal freedoms. She advises seeking emotional support from trusted individuals, such as family members, friends, or online communities, and prioritizing mental health. Collins also emphasizes the importance of finding comfort in nature, accepting uncertainty, and sharing gratitude. Her book, "Loss Adjustment," has resonated with readers and continues to provide a platform for those to share their stories of grief and loss.

site_title: Opec says oil market undergoing 'historic shock'
summary: Opec says the global oil market is experiencing an unprecedented "historic shock" due to coronavirus mitigation measures, resulting in a 6.8 million barrels per day drop in average daily demand for 2020. The cartel attributes this decline to reduced consumption, particularly in Asia and Europe. This forecast marks a significant adjustment to their previous estimates, indicating a substantial shift in the market dynamics.

site_title: StarHub says sorry with 20% rebate on home broadband fee for affected customers
summary: StarHub apologized for intermittent disruptions to its home broadband services in Singapore, caused by two separate incidents: an isolated fault in network equipment and a DNS issue. The telco offered 20% rebate on monthly home broadband fees to affected customers, equivalent to six days of free WiFi service. StarHub's CEO stated that the root cause was identified as an internal network change management process and measures are being taken to prevent recurrence. The company is cooperating with the Infocomm Media Development Authority in investigations and reviewing processes.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Panerai launches #OwnYourTime interactive content series on Instagram and Facebook, featuring ambassadors sharing how they make the most of each moment. Premium Korean strawberries, Jukhyang and Merryqueen, are now available at Culina, priced at S$28 and S$27 respectively. The #MyTreat initiative allows users to buy meals for friends and healthcare workers, with proceeds supporting frontline staff. Nine Lives Theatre releases video recordings of its productions, while the 1887 Virtual Bar offers digital cocktails on Zoom. Lady Gaga and the World Health Organisation host One World: Together At Home, a star-studded concert to be streamed live across multiple platforms on April 19.

site_title: China says has not seen large-scale exodus of foreign capital amid coronavirus outbreak
summary: China's commerce ministry stated that despite the coronavirus outbreak, the country has not experienced a large-scale exodus of foreign capital. Foreign direct investment into China fell 10.8% in the January to March period due to the pandemic. However, ministry spokesman Gao Feng noted that many Japanese firms are willing to boost investment in China, indicating that globalization trends will continue despite challenges.

site_title: AEM maintains FY2020 sales guidance despite Covid-19 situation
summary: AEM Holdings maintains its FY2020 sales guidance of S$360 million to S$380 million despite the Covid-19 situation. The company continues to operate worldwide without material adverse impact, with its China operations resuming on Feb 12, 2020, and its Singapore operations receiving approval to continue workplace activities. AEM's Penang plant operates with a leaner workforce, and the company expects to meet its full-year sales target.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rallied in opening deals on Thursday, driven by optimism over plans to ease coronavirus lockdown restrictions in several nations. The FTSE 100, DAX, and CAC 40 indices all rose, with the FTSE Mib and IBEX 35 indices also gaining. Analysts attribute the gains to investors focusing on positive developments, despite near-decade low oil prices and ongoing selling pressure in the energy sector.

site_title: Australia: Shares skid on likely rise in unemployment, bleak US data; NZ gains
summary: Australian shares fell 0.9% to 5,416.30, their worst session since April 3, due to a likely rise in unemployment and bleak US economic data. Analysts warned of up to 900,000 job losses in April, and energy stocks declined 1.6% as oil prices rebounded. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.6%, with gains from milk producer A2 Milk and transport firm Mainfreight.

site_title: Biofourmis acquires Gaido Health, expands into oncology
summary: Biofourmis has acquired oncology-focused patient monitoring platform Gaido Health, expanding its portfolio in the oncology space. The acquisition aims to provide a digital-therapeutics solution for oncology, enabling early intervention and preventing medical crises. Gaido Health's AI-based algorithms can detect signs of complications, and its platform will be combined with Biofourmis' Biovitals platform to manage toxicities in patients undergoing CAR T-Cell Therapy. The deal seeks to address high hospital readmission rates for immuno-compromised patients on chemotherapy and support Singapore's goal of increasing cancer survival rates by 20% by 2030.

site_title: Apple chipmaker TSMC's profit soars on iPhone demand
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) reported a 91% rise in earnings for the first quarter, driven by steady demand for advanced silicon in smartphones and data centers. The company's revenue rose 42% to NT$310.6 billion, despite Apple withdrawing its revenue outlook due to work slowdowns and lower demand in China. iPhone shipments in China jumped 19% in March, suggesting demand is bouncing back. TSMC is likely to cut its 2020 sales outlook due to competition and stricter US licensing requirements.

site_title: Perennial sells stake in 111 Somerset to Stanley Ho's Shun Tak for S$155m
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings is selling its 30% stake in 111 Somerset to Shun Tak Holdings for S$155.1 million. The sale is part of a larger transaction where Shun Tak already owns 70% of the development. The integrated complex, located in Orchard Road, features two office towers and a retail podium. The sale price is significantly lower than the S$1.26 billion property value it was purchased for in 2017. The deal marks a divestment for Perennial and a strategic move for Shun Tak.

site_title: BofA slashes regional growth forecast to 0.3% due to virus
summary: Bank of America has slashed its regional growth forecast to 0.3% due to the COVID-19 pandemic, citing delayed policy responses. Small open economies, such as Singapore, Thailand, and Hong Kong, are expected to contract more than large continental economies. Countries with fresh lockdowns and social distancing measures, like Malaysia and the Philippines, will likely see sharper slowdowns. Indonesia's recovery is expected to be more U-shaped, with a 1% growth forecast. The bank notes that policy responses vary, with some countries, like Singapore, moving quickly, while others, like Indonesia and Vietnam, lag behind.

site_title: UK will reject any EU request to extend Brexit transition
summary: The UK government has stated it will reject any EU request to extend the Brexit transition period, citing the need for business certainty. The transition period is set to end on December 31, and extending it would prolong uncertainty. The coronavirus has hindered trade negotiations, prompting calls for an extension. However, the UK government believes it's better to be clear about future trading arrangements now, rather than delaying them. The EU would need mutual agreement to extend the transition period, which both sides have until June to propose.

images.alt_text: The UK government said it will reject any request from the European Union to delay the final stage of Brexit even as coronavirus hampers negotiations over their future economic relationship.

site_title: Asean green bond issuance doubles to US$7.8b in 2019
summary: Asean green bond issuance doubled to US$7.8 billion in 2019, with Singapore contributing 55% of the total, according to a Climate Bonds Initiative report. Global issuance surged 50% to US$258 billion. Two-thirds of proceeds went to Buildings and Energy sectors, with green buildings and renewable energy being the top recipients. Significant transactions included the first perpetual green bond in Asean and the first green bond under Thai Securities and Exchange Commission notification. Regional initiatives, such as the Asian Development Bank's technical assistance program, supported the growth of Asean's green bond market.

site_title: Europe coronavirus cases reach almost a million, coming weeks 'critical' says WHO
summary: Europe's coronavirus cases have reached nearly 1 million, with the World Health Organization's European director, Hans Kluge, warning that the situation is "critical." The region accounts for about 50% of the global Covid-19 burden, with over 84,000 deaths. Kluge urges caution when considering easing lockdowns, emphasizing the need for controlled transmission, minimized outbreak risks, and sufficient health systems. He advises that any easing of restrictions must meet these criteria, and there is no "fast track back to normal."

site_title: Australia's top casinos flag big layoffs, new debt funding to combat virus
summary: Australia's top casino operators, Crown Resorts and Star Entertainment Group, have laid off approximately 20,000 staff due to the coronavirus crisis. Crown secured A$1.01 billion in debt funding and 95% of its employees are now laid off, while Star Entertainment Group has added an A$200 million credit line and laid off around 8,500 staff. The moves are aimed at helping the industry survive the pandemic.

site_title: Asean grocery retailers gain as Covid-19 shifts dining to the home: DBS
summary: Asean grocery retailers are expected to benefit from the COVID-19 pandemic as people shift dining to their homes, boosting sales at supermarkets and hypermarkets. Despite declining sales in discretionary items, online grocery sales remain small, accounting for only 5% of the market. Singapore and Thailand-listed supermarkets are among the top picks, while convenience stores are expected to see weak sales due to reduced foot traffic. Authorities' discouragement of going out is expected to last for a few weeks, with traditional stores likely to dominate Indonesia's grocery sector in the future.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down 1.3% on weak US data
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index dropped 1.3% to 19,290.20 on Thursday, following weak US economic data and earnings reports. Investors were discouraged by the US economic slowdown, with the Nikkei 225 falling 259.89 points. The broader Topix index also declined 0.8%. Market sentiment was negatively impacted by the US economic figures, according to Daiwa Securities chief technical analyst Eiji Kinouchi.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end flat as China stimulus measures offset recession fears
summary: South Korean shares ended flat on Thursday, despite China's stimulus measures offsetting recession fears. The KOSPI index fell 0.01 points to 1,857.07, marking a 15.50% decline so far this year. Foreigners sold US$305.94 million worth of shares, extending a 30th straight session of selloff. In response, South Korea's central bank announced a new loan program for brokerages to calm liquidity nerves. The country also proposed a second supplementary budget worth US$6.19 billion to fund cash payments to low- and middle-income families.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims top 5.2 million in latest week
summary: US weekly jobless claims reached 5.2 million in the latest week, bringing the total to over 20 million since March 21, as the economy struggles with the COVID-19 pandemic. Economists predict a deepening economic slump, with some estimating an additional 20 million initial jobless claims through May. The Labour Department's data also follows dismal retail sales and factory output data, and economists warn of a potential recession, with some predicting job losses could be 10 to 20 times larger than those in March.

site_title: Qatar flies to the rescue, winning plaudits as virus halts aviation
summary: Qatar Airways has been praised for its efforts in repatriating thousands of stranded travelers during the coronavirus pandemic, with the airline operating 35% of its normal services to carry 17,000 people on special charter flights. The Gulf state's actions have scored diplomatic points, with governments such as Germany, France, and Britain praising Qatar for its role in connecting countries. Qatar's efforts have also helped to offset lost ticket revenues, with the airline beginning to load more cargo into passenger baggage holds. The airline's actions are seen as a strategic move to maintain its image as a connector and go-between, despite a long-standing blockade by neighboring countries.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close slightly lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed slightly lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.26 points to 1,386.53. The index saw a volume of 4.811 billion lots worth RM2.660 billion, with 624 gainers outnumbering 254 losers.

site_title: Measures unveiled to help Reits through 'challenging' Covid-19 period
summary: Singapore's government has unveiled measures to support Reits (Real Estate Investment Trusts) during the challenging Covid-19 period. The Ministry of Finance and Monetary Authority of Singapore have extended the deadline for distribution of taxable income to 12 months, raised the leverage limit to 50% and deferred the implementation of a new minimum interest coverage ratio requirement. These measures aim to give Reits greater flexibility to manage their cash flows and raise funds.

site_title: Crunch time for world's supply chains to deliver masks and meat
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is putting the global trading system under intense stress, with supply chains for essential goods like masks, meat, and medical equipment facing critical phases. Shipping companies are operating with crews stuck on vessels longer than usual, and truckers are encountering snarls at borders. Governments are imposing trade barriers, and the lack of infrastructure and worker fatigue are threatening the backbone of global trade. The situation is expected to worsen in May unless action is taken to secure supplies and protect the food chain.

site_title: New Zealand mulls plan to ease Covid-19 lockdown
summary: New Zealand is set to start easing its nationwide lockdown, which has been in place since March 25, next week. The country has seen a significant decline in new cases, with just six confirmed on Thursday, and a total of over 1,000 cases and nine deaths. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern warned that any easing of the lockdown would need to ensure public safety, with restrictions on businesses and gatherings remaining in place. Schools may reopen, but attendance would be voluntary, and funerals and weddings would be limited to 10 people.

site_title: Prosecution seeks 6-8 weeks' jail for man who allegedly breached SHN to deliver newspapers
summary: A 48-year-old Singaporean, Palanivelu Ramasamy, is accused of breaching his stay-home notice to deliver newspapers on March 30. He is one of two Singaporeans charged with violating their SHN amid the coronavirus outbreak. The prosecution is seeking a 6-8 week jail term for Ramasamy, who is registered with Singapore Press Holdings as a news vendor.

site_title: STI up 0.3%, Covid-19 continues to dent investor sentiment
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 0.3% to 2,612.25 points, rebounding from a lower opening on Wall Street and Europe. The rebound was attributed to a risk-off atmosphere amidst the global coronavirus pandemic. Investor sentiment remains cautious despite a 5-day rally, with the US stock market hitting fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The Singapore government's GDP data and other market events will be closely watched for further market movements.

site_title: DBS donating S$10.5m to help communities in Asia hard hit by Covid-19
summary: DBS Bank announced a S$10.5 million donation to help communities in Asia affected by Covid-19 through its DBS Stronger Together Fund. The donation will provide 4.5 million meals and care packs to affected individuals across six markets, including funding for medical supplies in India and Indonesia. In Singapore, DBS will partner with The Food Bank Singapore and ItsRainingRaincoats to provide 300,000 meals to the elderly, low-income, and migrant workers.

site_title: Top Asian LNG buyer seeks to delay shipments deep into 2020
summary: Korea Gas, a top Asian LNG buyer, is seeking to delay shipments of liquefied natural gas (LNG) deep into 2020 due to the coronavirus outbreak and brimming inventories. The company is in talks with suppliers Qatargas and Petronas to delay cargoes originally scheduled for October, potentially pushing deliveries into 2021. The move could worsen a glut of natural gas and oil, impacting energy consumption and prices. South Korea's high LNG inventories and weak economic growth forecast this year also contribute to the decision.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit defers capital distributions; Q1 DPU down 26%
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit reported a 26.3% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.883 cents in Q1 FY2020, due to deferring capital distributions to conserve capital amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Gross revenue rose 3.6% to S$23.5 million, but net property income fell 5.1% to S$17.4 million. The Reit's portfolio occupancy rate rose marginally to 84.7%, and about 11% of leases will expire in FY2020. Units fell 1.3% to S$0.37 on the stock market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Swiber, an offshore support vessel owner, is in talks for a possible $200m cash investment and bond issuance from a Middle East-based oil and gas conglomerate. Construction tech startup Novade completed its Series B funding with $11m in funding from lead investors SIG and Vulcan Capital. Perennial Real Estate Holdings sold its 30% stake in 111 Somerset to Shun Tak Holdings for $155.1m. Revolut, PolicyPal, and Stashaway teamed up to offer cashback and Covid-19 insurance to Singapore medical personnel. DBS donated $10.5m to help communities in Asia affected by Covid-19, translating to 4.5 million meals and care packs.

images.alt_text: Debt-laden offshore and marine group Swiber Holdings, currently in judicial management, has started discussions with a third party with a view to set out the broad terms of a possible restructuring deal in a term sheet.

site_title: IMF head says UK should seek longer Brexit transition
summary: IMF head Kristalina Georgieva advises the UK to seek an extension to its post-Brexit transition period due to economic uncertainty caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The transition period is set to end on December 31, and a new trade agreement is needed to avoid barriers to exports and imports. Georgieva praises the UK's emergency measures, but notes that the country's sizeable role in the global economy means these measures will have a broader impact. The IMF managing director urges the UK to reduce uncertainty for the benefit of everyone involved.

site_title: Oil giant Shell vows to become carbon neutral by 2050
summary: Royal Dutch Shell, a major oil giant, has pledged to become carbon neutral by 2050, matching BP's commitment. The company aims to be a net-zero emissions energy business by 2050 or sooner, driven by shifting societal expectations and customer demands. CEO Ben van Beurden stated that Shell must "go further" to meet these expectations, marking a significant step in the energy sector's response to climate change.

site_title: Sony plans limited PlayStation 5 output in first year: sources
summary: Sony plans to produce 5-6 million PlayStation 5 units in its first year, a significantly lower output than the 7.5 million units sold in the first two quarters of the PlayStation 4's launch. The company expects high demand to be deterred by the console's ambitious specs and potentially high price tag, which could reach $499-$549. To mitigate this, Sony will rely on existing PlayStation 4 models as a bridge, and may cut prices around the launch to stimulate new subscribers.

site_title: Covid-19: Carousell to donate up to S$2m in ad inventory to non-profits
summary: Carousell, an online marketplace operator, will donate up to S$2 million in ad inventory to non-profit organizations in Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong, and the Philippines to support communities impacted by COVID-19. Partnered non-profits will be able to advertise on the platform, gaining visibility to replenish food and essential health products, recruit volunteers, and aid families-at-risk and seniors in need. Interested organizations can apply at caro.sl/freeadsforcharity.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at Thursday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day lower, following a negative overnight cue from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index slid 0.5% to 24,025.45, while Mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also opened down 0.45% and 0.57%, respectively. The decline was attributed to a trove of bad economic data spooking investors.

site_title: US probe unable to rule out White House influence on contract awarded to Microsoft, not Amazon
summary: The Pentagon's inspector general found it unable to determine if the White House influenced the $10 billion cloud computing contract awarded to Microsoft, despite several officials claiming their conversations were privileged "presidential communications." The report did not rule out White House influence, leaving open the question of whether President Trump improperly pressured the Pentagon. The Defense Department said the report should close the door on media and corporate attacks, while Amazon and its allies criticized the White House's refusal to cooperate with the investigation.

site_title: Malaysia to delay nationwide rollout of B20 biodiesel mandate due to coronavirus curbs
summary: Malaysia is delaying the nationwide rollout of its B20 biodiesel mandate due to the coronavirus outbreak. The country aims to pause the implementation in regions that have yet to adopt it, with plans to review the rollout after the movement control order is lifted. The mandate, which aims to increase the use of palm oil in biodiesel, was initially set to be fully implemented by mid-June 2021. The decision was made by the Plantation Industries and Commodities Ministry, which will hold a meeting with petroleum companies to decide on a new implementation date.

site_title: South Korea reshuffles central bank board, may shed light on government's focus on stability risks
summary: South Korea's Bank of Korea reshuffled its central bank board, replacing seven members, amid speculation about government focus on stability risks and unconventional monetary policy to combat the coronavirus pandemic. President Moon Jae In's focus on financial market stability and tackling runaway property prices in Seoul may be reflected in the new appointments, which could tip the balance to a more neutral-hawkish stance. The changes do not necessarily impact monetary policies this year, as the BOK is set to maintain looser policies until the pandemic eases.

site_title: Man GLG hires Asia equities head from rival BlackRock
summary: Man GLG has hired Andrew Swan, former head of Asia and global emerging market fundamental equities at BlackRock, to lead its Asia ex-Japan equities business in Sydney. Swan will report directly to Man GLG's CEO Teun Johnston and join in the third quarter. This move comes as a result of a shift in Man GLG's strategy, with Swan's appointment aimed at strengthening the firm's presence in the Asia market.

site_title: Wuhan's 'wet markets' struggle after virus lockdown
summary: China's "wet markets," where live animals and exotic wildlife are sold, face criticism and struggle after the COVID-19 pandemic lockdown in Wuhan. The markets were initially blamed for the virus's emergence, but the Chinese government has banned the sale of wildlife for food. Despite this, the reopening of markets has drawn international criticism, with some experts calling for their closure. Sales have plummeted, with vendors citing unaffordable rents and the lingering effects of the citywide shutdown as main concerns.

site_title: Reefknot, Mastercard co-lead US$11m funding round for UK fintech Previse
summary: Reefknot Investments and Mastercard co-led a US$11 million funding round for London-based fintech Previse, with existing investors Bessemer Venture Partners, Hambro Perks, and Augmentum Fintech also participating. The funding will support Previse's global roll-out of its InstantPay technology, marking a significant milestone for the company.

site_title: Japan business mood slumps to decade low on coronavirus hit: poll
summary: Japan's business confidence has plummeted to a decade low in April due to the coronavirus pandemic, with manufacturers and service-sector firms expecting further deterioration in the coming months. The poll showed 93% of companies expecting the virus's impact on supply and demand to last for months, with no industry categories optimistic about business mood except for real estate and information/communications sectors. This weak business confidence could deal a hard blow to capital spending, prompting calls for more supportive measures from the government.

site_title: Australia jobs rise in March, unemployment ticks up
summary: Australia's unemployment rate inched up to 5.2% in March, contrary to expectations of a larger spike, as the data covered the period before major mobility restrictions kicked in to fight the coronavirus. The country added 5,900 net new jobs, with part-time work increasing 6,400. The Reserve Bank of Australia has cut rates to a record low, and the government has pledged spending worth over 10% of GDP to combat the economic damage.

site_title: Asia: Markets down on virus impact fears
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday due to US economic data, with Tokyo down 1.2%, Hong Kong losing 0.8%, and Sydney dropping 1.4%. The US reported a sharp decline in retail sales and industrial production, fueling concerns about the pandemic's impact. The IMF warned of a century-long global downturn, while the World Health Organization cautioned against lifting lockdowns too early, fearing a possible second wave of infections. Oil markets also experienced volatility, with Brent Crude up 1.9% after hitting multi-year lows.

site_title: Gold eases on stronger dollar, dire economic outlook caps losses
summary: Gold prices eased 0.1% to $1,714.55 per ounce due to a stronger US dollar, but losses were capped by fears of a global recession amid weak retail sales and manufacturing data. US retail sales plummeted, and factory production declined, raising concerns of a sharp economic contraction. Despite profit-taking, investors remain optimistic about gold's upward trend, with central banks expected to keep interest rates low. Gold holdings of the SPDR Gold Trust rose 0.4% to 1,021.69 tonnes.

images.alt_text: Gold prices edged lower on Thursday as the US dollar firmed and investors booked profits, but losses were capped as dour retail sales and manufacturing data out of the United States heightened fears of a steep global recession due to the new coronavirus.

site_title: United cuts May flights by 90%, tells employees to brace for job cuts
summary: United Airlines has cut its flight schedule by 90% in May due to the coronavirus pandemic and expects similar cuts for June. The airline warned that travel demand remains "essentially at zero" and job cuts are likely. The move follows a similar trend among US airlines, with most states ordering residents to stay at home to contain the spread of the virus. The airline's Chief Executive Oscar Munoz and President Scott Kirby publicly released the memo outlining the reduced schedule and travel demand outlook.

images.alt_text: United Airlines said on Wednesday that it has cut its flight schedule by 90 per cent in May and expects similar cuts for June as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, and warned that travel demand that is now "essentially at zero shows no sign of improving in the near term," making job cuts likely.

site_title: Hot stock: Japfa climbs 10.8% after proposing dairy unit's stake sale
summary: Japfa, a Singapore-based agri-food company, saw its shares climb 10.8% after announcing the sale of a 25% stake in its China dairy business to Japanese conglomerate Meiji for US$254.4 million. The proposed stake sale is viewed positively by analysts. Japfa's shares traded at 56.5 Singapore cents, up from 56 cents, with 4.5 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on worries over economy
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on April 16, 2020, due to concerns over the US economy. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.46% and the Topix index dropped 1.38%. The declines followed weak economic data and earnings reports in the US.

site_title: Swiber in talks for possible US$200m cash investment, bond issuance
summary: Swiber Holdings, a debt-laden offshore and marine group, is in talks for a possible US$200 million cash investment and bond issuance with a Middle East-based oil and gas conglomerate. The proposed deal includes a restructuring component, where the conglomerate will invest in a new subsidiary and issue redeemable convertible bonds to address Swiber's liabilities. The deal, if signed, will form the basis for negotiations of definitive transaction agreements.

site_title: Amazon says it may temporarily halt operations in France
summary: Amazon temporarily halted operations in France after a court ruled the company had failed to protect warehouse workers against the coronavirus. The ruling, handed down Tuesday, ordered Amazon to restrict deliveries to only essential products and imposed a fine of 1 million euros per day. Amazon contested the decision, stating it was "perplexed" by the ruling, and will appeal. The company suspended activities in its distribution centers, citing the threatened fine as the reason for the halt.

site_title: China's March home prices up 0.1% m-o-m after stalling in Feb
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.1% in March after stalling in February, according to Reuters calculation. This marks a hopeful sign of a property market recovery after the coronavirus health crisis. On a year-on-year basis, home prices grew 5.3% in March, compared to a 5.8% increase in February. The growth indicates a possible pick-up in the property market, but it remains to be seen how sustainable the trend will be.

images.alt_text: New home prices in China returned to growth in March after stalling in February, according to Reuters calculation, in a hopeful sign of a pick-up in the property market after the coronavirus health crisis halted economic activity.

site_title: Google to slow hiring for rest of 2020, CEO tells staff
summary: Google parent Alphabet is slowing hiring for the remainder of 2020, citing the economic downturn triggered by the coronavirus pandemic. CEO Sundar Pichai announced the decision in an email to staff, stating the company will maintain hiring momentum in strategic areas while reducing hiring in other areas. Alphabet employs 118,899 people full-time, and the company has already onboarded over 4,000 new hires this year. The move is part of a broader effort to cut costs, including reducing investments in non-business essential marketing and travel.

site_title: Australia: Shares tumble 2% as US economic data paints bleak picture
summary: Australian shares dropped 2% on Thursday as US economic data showed a bleak picture of the coronavirus crisis. US retail sales plummeted to a record low, manufacturing output dropped by 74 years, and major Wall Street banks issued gloomy forecasts. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1.5% to 5,387.6 points, with miners and financials shedding 2.4% and 2.8% respectively. The decline came ahead of consumer inflation and employment figures later in the day, painting a grim picture of the pandemic's economic impact.

site_title: Robots ride to rescue as delivery risks rise
summary: Delivery risks rise due to the COVID-19 pandemic, prompting the use of robots to deliver essential items. In suburban Washington, a delivery robot navigates through the streets to deliver groceries to customers, allowing people to stay at home. This service is seen as a convenient alternative to traditional shopping. The use of robots in delivery is expected to become more widespread, providing a safer and more efficient way to transport goods during the pandemic.

site_title: New Zealand central bank governor says not ruling out negative interest rates
summary: New Zealand central bank governor Adrian Orr says negative interest rates are not ruled out in response to the economic fallout from the coronavirus crisis. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) has already cut its official cash rate to 0.25% and pledged to keep it at that level for at least 12 months. Orr stated that the bank is considering additional stimulus steps, indicating that negative interest rates may be a possible option in the future.

images.alt_text: The governor of the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) said on Thursday that negative interest rates are not off the table in its response to the economic fallout of the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Oil bounces back as rising stockpiles seen pointing to lower output amid coronavirus
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday as US crude rebounded from near-20-year lows due to concerns over rising stockpiles, which may prompt producers to deepen output cuts amid the coronavirus pandemic. Brent crude rose 2.5% to $28.38 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate climbed 2.8% to $20.43. The International Energy Agency forecast a 29 million barrel per day drop in oil demand in April, surpassing production cuts agreed upon by Opec and allied producers. Further cuts are needed to avoid another collapse in oil prices.

site_title: Construction tech startup Novade completes Series B funding
summary: Construction tech startup Novade has completed its Series B funding with lead investors SIG and Vulcan Capital, totaling an undisclosed amount. The funds will be used to accelerate global expansion, enhance technology, and increase investments in artificial intelligence capabilities. Founded in 2014, Novade offers smart field management software for the building and construction industry, focusing on improving quality, productivity, and safety. The company aims to expand in Europe, China, and Japan, particularly in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Once safer than gold, Canada property braces for reckoning
summary: Canada's housing market is facing a reckoning due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with nearly one-third of workers applying for income support and households heavily indebted. The country's economy is driven by real estate, which is now in a state of paralysis. Policymakers are offering mortgage holidays, but experts warn that this may not be enough to prop up the market. With households owing C$1.76 for every dollar in disposable income, a recession is a likely outcome if the housing market collapses. The government is preparing to purchase billions of dollars worth of mortgages to backstop the market, but concerns remain about the long-term sustainability of Canada's housing market.

site_title: Trump says US likely 'passed the peak' on coronavirus cases
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that the country has passed the peak of coronavirus cases, citing an aggressive strategy as the cause. He plans to announce guidelines for reopening the economy on Thursday. This comes as the US continues to battle the pandemic. Trump's announcement suggests a shift towards easing restrictions, but the timing and specifics remain unclear.

site_title: Virgin Australia stock suspended as restructuring talks extend
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings stock was suspended in Sydney as discussions on a potential financial restructuring continue. The airline, which has halted services due to the coronavirus outbreak, is exploring options for securing capital. It has asked the government for a A$1.4 billion loan and has been in talks with shareholders, with Australian Treasurer Josh Frydenberg urging the airline to prioritize its shareholders. The shares will be suspended for up to seven days as talks on financial help and alternative structures continue.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Thursday's open tracking Wall St losses; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.7% on Thursday, tracking overnight losses on Wall Street and Europe, where firms reported lacklustre earnings and weak US economic data. Banking stocks were in the red, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC falling 1.6%, 1.8%, and 1.4% respectively. Other heavily traded securities included Thomson Medical, which rose 1.7%, and ESR-Reit, which fell 4.5%. The Nikkei 225 index in Tokyo also fell 1.5%, while European shares closed in the red, ending a five-day rally.

site_title: Royal Caribbean sheds 26% of US workforce as coronavirus hits travel
summary: Royal Caribbean is laying off or furloughing about 26% of its US workforce, affecting nearly 1,300 employees, due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on international travel. The company has extended its "no sail order" for all cruise ships by the US CDC to curb the spread of the virus. Most of the reductions are permanent layoffs, although some employees will receive 90-day furloughs with paid benefits.

site_title: Revolut, PolicyPal, Stashaway team up to offer medical personnel cashback, Covid-19 insurance
summary: Fintech companies Revolut, PolicyPal, and StashAway are teaming up to offer medical personnel in Singapore cashback, Covid-19 insurance, and free investing services. Revolut is providing 3% cashback on debit card transactions, PolicyPal is offering free Covid-19 insurance, and StashAway is offering six months of free investing. Medical personnel can sign up by emailing employment proof to the respective companies. The partnerships aim to support medical personnel during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Kim Jong Un tribute absence sparks speculation
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's absence from commemorations for his grandfather Kim Il Sung's birth anniversary has sparked speculation that he may be emphasizing his own authority over his family's legacy. The Day of the Sun, a key North Korean celebration, is marked by reverence for the country's founder and his family members. Analysts believe Kim Jong Un's conspicuous absence could be a deliberate move to solidify his own position and separate himself from his predecessors. The significance of the event lies in its annual political calendar, highlighting Kim Jong Un's efforts to redefine his family's legacy.

site_title: Pandemic to halt Asia's 2020 growth for first time in 60 years: IMF
summary: Asia's economic growth is expected to grind to a halt this year for the first time in 60 years due to the coronavirus crisis, according to the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The pandemic is taking a severe toll on the region's service sector and major export destinations. Policymakers must offer targeted support to households and firms hardest-hit by the crisis, and Asian countries need to use all policy instruments to mitigate the impact. The IMF expects zero growth this year, but predicts a 7.6% expansion in Asian economic growth next year under the assumption that containment policies succeed.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Singapore Airlines, StarHub, CDL, Mapletree Industrial Trust
summary: Singapore's Big Three banks, DBS, UOB, and OCBC, saw a surge in enterprise loan applications from micro and small businesses amid the pandemic. DBS Group will pay its final dividend of 33 Singapore cents per share on May 26. Singapore Airlines reported a 65% year-on-year decline in passenger numbers to 1.1 million in March. StarHub is under investigation for disruptions to its internet services, and CDL acquired a 51% stake in Chinese real estate developer Sincere Property Group for S$880 million. Mapletree Industrial Trust will set aside up to S$13.7 million to support tenants.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Covid-19 Solidarity Budget: How to access support for your SME
summary: A Money FM podcast discusses how SMEs can access support during the Covid-19 pandemic. Ivan Chang, co-opted councilor at SGTech, joins the hosts to share tools and resources available to SMEs, including webinars and financial assistance. The conversation highlights the importance of digital adoption and seeking help from trade associations and government initiatives.

site_title: March's private home sales slump may be signal for full-year rout
summary: Singapore's private home sales slumped 32.4% in March, with 660 units sold, due to the COVID-19 pandemic and global recession. Experts expect full-year sales to plummet, with forecasts ranging from 4,000 to 5,000 units, a 20-30% decline from 2019. The circuit breaker and stricter safe-distancing measures have slowed down sales, with some buyers opting to wait and others diversifying their investment portfolios. Despite this, some remain optimistic about the market's long-term fundamentals and the appeal of homes as safe haven assets.

site_title: Singapore industrial rents to moderate as manufacturing suffers
summary: Singapore industrial rents are expected to moderate in 2020 due to shrinking global demand and the local manufacturing sector's decline. New lease volumes will fall as firms shelve relocation plans and renew current leases, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Factory rents and better-quality industrial buildings will be more affected, while warehouse rents are expected to experience lower moderation due to increased e-commerce activity.

site_title: Only a Covid-19 vaccine will allow return to 'normalcy': UN chief
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said a Covid-19 vaccine may be the only way to return to "normalcy" by the end of 2020, emphasizing its need for accelerated development and accessibility to all. He called for a harmonized approach to maximize the speed and scale of vaccine deployment, citing a 20% funding goal for a UN humanitarian response. Guterres praised efforts by several African governments to mitigate pandemic consequences, including tax relief and food aid, and urged international stakeholders to work together to control the pandemic.

site_title: South Korea ruling party wins parliamentary majority
summary: South Korea's left-leaning ruling Democratic Party, led by President Moon Jae In, won a landslide victory in the general election, securing an absolute majority of 163 seats in the 300-member National Assembly. The party's sister party is expected to win additional seats, giving them a total of 180 seats. This victory is seen as a result of the coronavirus pandemic turning the political tide in President Moon's favour.

site_title: Trump to announce 'guidelines' on reopening US economy on Thursday
summary: US President Donald Trump announced "new guidelines" for reopening the US economy on Thursday, citing data that suggests the country has passed the peak on new coronavirus infections. The US coronavirus death toll surged past 30,000, with millions losing jobs during the lockdown. Trump has been pushing to reopen businesses and end stay-at-home orders, despite the ongoing crisis. The announcement comes amid a struggling US economy and pressure on policymakers.

site_title: China may have conducted low-level nuclear test blasts, US says
summary: The US State Department has reported that China may have conducted low-level nuclear test blasts despite claiming to observe a "zero yield" standard, according to a report. The findings, first reported by the Wall Street Journal, raise concerns about China's adherence to the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. China has been operating its Lop Nur nuclear test site year-round and has been secretive about its nuclear testing activities. The report may worsen already strained US-China relations, with US President Donald Trump pushing for China to join an arms control accord.

site_title: Some issues to consider ahead of a technology acquisition
summary: Companies can overcome the disruptions of the Covid-19 pandemic by leveraging technology, but hasty acquisitions can be costly. To avoid such pitfalls, companies should carefully stage their technology procurement process by identifying their specific needs, selecting suitable suppliers, and crafting detailed solution specifications. This includes right-sizing technical requirements, furnishing suppliers with necessary information, and evaluating the financial, legal, technical, and project management aspects of proposed solutions. A well-informed decision will ensure a successful technology procurement that positions the company to stay ahead digitally after the crisis.

site_title: Macron vows to rebuild Notre Dame by 2024 despite virus
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has reaffirmed his goal to rebuild Notre Dame Cathedral by 2024, despite the COVID-19 pandemic, as the country faces a "gigantic sanitary, economic and social crisis." Construction halted due to the pandemic, but officials say the emotional intensity of the fire remains strong and interest in the project has not waned. A 200-foot crane still towers over the cathedral, and renovation work is expected to resume in 2021, with a focus on reopening the cathedral for religious services by 2024.

images.alt_text: President Emmanuel Macron, beamed to television sets around the world, vowed to rebuild by 2024, when Paris will host the Summer Olympic Games.

site_title: World's top pork producer closes more plants in a domino effect
summary: Smithfield Foods, the world's top pork producer, is closing two more US plants due to a COVID-19 outbreak among workers. The company shut down its Sioux Falls slaughterhouse in South Dakota on April 18 and will now close its Cudahy plant in Wisconsin and Martin City facility in Missouri, citing the interconnectedness of the food supply chain. The closures highlight the vulnerability of the industry amid the pandemic, with staff at the affected plants tested positive for the virus. The closures are part of a domino effect in the industry, with the Martin City plant dependent on the Sioux Falls slaughterhouse to resume operations.

site_title: Fitch cuts Mexico rating to one notch above 'junk'
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded Mexico's sovereign rating to BBB- with a stable outlook, citing concerns over the economic shock caused by the novel coronavirus, which will likely lead to a "severe recession" in the country. The downgrade forecasts a contraction of at least 4% in Mexico's economy this year and a widening general government deficit. The rating cut also highlights the contingent liability represented by the debt of national oil company Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex), totaling $105.2 billion.

site_title: CapitaLand bags 2 green loans worth S$400m
summary: CapitaLand secured two green loans totaling S$400 million from DBS Bank and HSBC to finance and acquire certified green buildings by 2030. The loans will be used to power renewable energy, reduce carbon emissions, and meet energy efficiency standards. The company aims to achieve 20% energy consumption from renewable energy by 2025 and has already implemented various initiatives, including powering its corporate offices with renewable energy and purchasing Renewable Energy Certificates.

site_title: Apple, Google must show contact tracing will not violate privacy, US senator says
summary: US Senator Richard Blumenthal says Apple and Google must convince the public their contact tracing technology won't violate privacy. The tech companies are developing a joint tracing effort to help public health officials identify those exposed to the coronavirus. They claim the technology won't track locations but interactions, will be anonymized, and won't be monetized. Dr. Anthony Fauci believes private contact tracing apps will be more accepted by the public, while advocacy group Public Knowledge suggests additional controls are needed to protect privacy.

site_title: Airbus puts off planned ramp-up of A220 jet
summary: Airbus is delaying the planned ramp-up of its A220 jet production by a year due to the coronavirus outbreak's impact on airline demand for aircraft. The company had initially planned to increase production from four per month to 10 by mid-2021 at its Mirabel facility in Canada. Production remains paused until at least May 4. The delay is part of broader production cuts, including a 40% reduction in wide-body production, as airlines preserve cash amid plummeting air travel demand.

site_title: Alibaba, Tencent, Softbank pour cash into India's gambling loopholes
summary: Asian tech giants Alibaba, Tencent, and Softbank are investing hundreds of millions of dollars in Indian apps that exploit loopholes in anti-gambling laws to offer cash prizes and other incentives. The apps, popular among 300 million players, offer fantasy cricket and rummy games, with industry sales forecast to reach $3.3 billion by 2024. This is expected to surpass the combined revenue of the music, movies, and TV show industries, according to India's richest man, Mukesh Ambani.

site_title: Construction work on HS2 rail project can begin, says Britain
summary: Britain has given the green light for construction work on the HS2 high-speed rail project to begin, despite the national lockdown. Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced in February that the line, connecting London to northern England, would go ahead. Companies involved in the project, including Skanska Construction UK and Vinci, can now start work following formal notification from the government. Construction workers and businesses will need to follow coronavirus safety guidelines, including social distancing at construction sites. The project aims to slash journey times and add capacity to Britain's crowded rail network.

site_title: US stalling massive IMF liquidity boost over Iran, China: sources
summary: US opposition to a massive IMF liquidity boost for Iran and China is preventing the IMF from deploying a powerful tool to fight the economic impact of the coronavirus. The liquidity injection, in the form of Special Drawing Rights, has backing from finance ministers, economists, and non-profit groups. It could provide hundreds of billions of dollars in foreign exchange reserves for all 189 IMF member countries, but US opposition is stalling the move.

site_title: Jump in demand for rental condos, HDB flats in March
summary: Demand for rental condos and HDB flats in Singapore surged in March, with private rentals jumping 10.9% to 5,244 units and HDB rentals rising 15.4% to 2,157 flats. The surge is attributed to the novel coronavirus pandemic, with existing tenants renewing contracts and others seeking temporary housing. Despite a 0.2% increase in private condo rents, year-on-year rents remain down 15% from their peak in January 2013. HDB rents, however, remain stable, with a 1.5% year-on-year increase.

site_title: Singapore voter rolls updated, open for online inspection
summary: Singapore's revised voter rolls, with 2,653,942 electors, are now open for public inspection. Eligible voters can check their particulars online or through the SingPass Mobile app. Those whose names were removed due to not voting can apply to have their names restored. Overseas citizens can also check and vote in future elections by registering at Singapore missions or applying as overseas electors if they've resided in Singapore for at least 30 days between 2017 and 2020.

site_title: Obama roars back into presidential political scene, endorsing Biden
summary: Former US President Barack Obama endorsed Joe Biden, the presumptive Democratic nominee, in a 12-minute video, aiming to unify the party ahead of the general election against President Donald Trump. Obama's endorsement, weeks after Biden's last opponent Bernie Sanders dropped out, highlights the party's need for a unifying figure. Obama's popularity remains high, with 91% of Democrats surveyed rating his presidency as "good" or "excellent." The endorsement is seen as a strategic move to appeal to persuadable voters and bring the party together, with Obama set to continue a virtual role in the campaign.

site_title: Greenback set to snap losing streak on virus fallout
summary: The US dollar rebounded on Wednesday, snapping a four-day losing streak amid concerns over the global economy's prolonged impact from the novel coronavirus pandemic. Oil prices fell, weakening riskier currencies, and investors braced for negative economic data from the US. The IMF predicted a 3% global economic shrinkage in 2020, its steepest fall since the Great Depression. The US dollar rose 0.8% against a basket of rivals, particularly against currencies seen as riskier bets, as investors sought safe-haven assets.

site_title: Pharma firms must stay healthy to win vaccine race
summary: Indian pharmaceutical companies are racing to develop a vaccine against COVID-19, with five companies and two research institutes aiming to deliver vaccines at lower prices. The Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation has relaxed regulations to fast-track the approval process. Companies such as Zydus Cadila and Bharat Biotech are collaborating with international researchers. Despite having a slim chance of success without government or donor funding, Indian pharma companies' surge in stock prices indicates their efforts to find a cure for the pandemic.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore Airlines' shareholders will vote on its S$15 billion debt and equity capital raising at an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on April 30. Shareholders can watch the proceedings via a live webcast or listen in via a live audio feed, and submit questions in advance.

site_title: First tranche of S$7b in wage subsidies being paid out
summary: Singapore is starting to distribute the first tranche of wage subsidies from its S$18 billion Jobs Support Scheme, with over S$7 billion being handed out. This move aims to keep workers employed during the Covid-19 downturn. The subsidies are being provided to employers, and the distribution is expected to support the country's efforts to mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic.

site_title: US: Dow ends 1.9% lower after terrible economic data
summary: US stocks fell 1.9% on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping to 23,504.35, amid weak economic data, including a 2.2% drop in the S&P 500 and a 1.4% decline in the Nasdaq Composite Index. Economic reports showed US retail sales plummeted in March and industrial production suffered its steepest drop since 1946. Major banks, including Wells Fargo and Bank of America, fell 5% or more due to increased reserves for potential loan defaults.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks tumbled Wednesday following a trove of weak economic data and bank earnings reports that pointed to a severe US economic slowdown.

site_title: China cuts borrowing costs to record low in fight against pandemic
summary: China's central bank cut a key borrowing rate to a record low to combat the pandemic, injecting US$43 billion into the financial system. The move also reduced reserve requirements for banks by around US$28 billion. The GDP report, released Friday, is expected to show a 6.5% contraction, the first quarterly decline in over 30 years, amid the coronavirus crisis. The policy support aims to stabilize the economy ahead of the report's release.

site_title: DBS to pay final dividend on May 26 after approval at AGM
summary: DBS Group will pay its shareholders a final dividend of 33 Singapore cents per share on May 26, pending approval from a virtual annual general meeting (AGM) scheduled for April 30. The AGM was rescheduled due to tightened safe-distancing measures in Singapore, which resulted in a partial lockdown.

site_title: J C Penney considers bankruptcy filing as recovery hopes fade
summary: J C Penney, a US department store chain, is considering filing for bankruptcy protection due to the coronavirus pandemic forcing store closures and reducing revenue. Despite having enough cash to survive, the company is exploring options to rework its unsustainable finances and save on looming debt payments. J C Penney has access to enough cash to survive in the months ahead, but concerns about prolonged store closures and sparse customer traffic have factored into its deliberations. The company has not made final decisions, but is considering asking creditors for breathing room through transactions outside of bankruptcy court.

site_title: Virus-battered smaller businesses flood banks with loan applications
summary: Singapore's Big Three banks experienced a surge in enterprise loan applications from micro and small businesses, mainly affected by the pandemic. The majority of these requests came from qualifying small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) who received interest rates as low as 3% for government-assisted SME loans, down from 6-9% previously. Despite the favorable conditions, some businesses remain uncertain due to loan rejection or unmet conditions.

site_title: Oxley boss in legal tussle with Italian contractor over Venetian hotel
summary: Singapore businessman Ching Chiat Kwong is involved in a legal dispute with an Italian contractor, Sama Global, over a luxury hotel in Venice and another hospitality project in Italy. The dispute centers on a remaining sum of 230,000 euros (S$357,406) owed to Sama Global despite the termination of its contract in 2018. Ching's company, Grandeur Oxley, is disputing the amount, citing issues with quality and quantity of work, as well as unpaid fees to employees, suppliers, and subcontractors. The case is pending, with a hearing set for May 28.

site_title: Oil sinks after record 19m barrel US crude build
summary: US crude oil prices plummeted to an 18-year low after the US reported its largest weekly inventory build on record, with crude stocks surging by 19 million barrels. Global demand is expected to fall to quarter-century lows due to the coronavirus pandemic, and despite a record output cut agreement by Opec+ and other producers, supply reductions are unlikely to prevent storage from filling. Brent crude dropped 6.45% and WTI fell 1.19% to settle at US$27.69 and US$19.87, respectively.

site_title: Gates Foundation ups pandemic funds to US$250m, says Trump WHO move makes 'no sense'
summary: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation has increased its pandemic funding to $250 million, with an additional $150 million, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Melinda Gates criticized US President Trump's decision to pull funding from the World Health Organization, calling it a "dangerous and nonsensical move" that makes no sense during a global health crisis. Gates emphasized the need for a global coordinated response, citing the WHO as the ideal organization to deal with the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Pulling funding from the World Health Organization (WHO) is a dangerous and nonsensical move when the world is facing the health crisis brought by the Covid-19 disease pandemic, Melinda Gates said on Wednesday.

site_title: Airbnb secures US$1 billion loan
summary: Airbnb secured a US$1 billion loan from private equity firms Silver Lake, Apollo Global Management, and others, just days after closing a US$1 billion debt deal. The five-year loan has an interest rate of 750 basis points over Libor, earning investors around 12% at a slight discount to par value. This comes as the company's home rental business suffers due to the novel coronavirus pandemic, which has frozen global travel. The loan terms indicate that creditors would be paid first in case of default, and Airbnb has not commented on its plans to list shares this year.

site_title: US industrial output falls 5.4 per cent in March as virus strikes: Fed
summary: US industrial production fell 5.4% in March due to the coronavirus pandemic, the largest decline since 1946. Manufacturing output dropped 6.3%, with motor vehicles and parts plummeting 28%. The pandemic has caused businesses to shed 17 million jobs and paralyzed the US economy. Total industrial output is 5.5% below March 2019, with further declines expected. Analysts predict "bleak" outlook for industrial sectors, citing supply chain disruptions and tighter financial conditions.

site_title: Q&M reclassifies final dividend as 'interim' to facilitate payout
summary: Q&M Dental Group has reclassified its proposed FY2019 dividends as interim dividends due to the COVID-19 pandemic, allowing for quicker payout. The dental services company initially proposed a special dividend of 2 cents and a final dividend of 0.42 cents per share. Bumitama Agri reduced its proposed final dividend by 60% to 0.5 cents per share, citing the need for strong cash flow reserves. TIH also withdrew its final dividend and proposed an interim dividend for FY2020 instead.

site_title: Japan's 'net cafe refugees' seek shelter
summary: Thousands of "net cafe refugees" in Japan are at risk of being homeless as the coronavirus pandemic forces the closure of their 24/7 comic book havens. These cafes, which offer internet, comics, and amenities for a nightly stay, have become homes for approximately 4,000 people in Tokyo. Activists warn that shutting down the cafes could lead to increased suicides and rough sleepers. The sudden closures have left the net cafe refugees without a place to stay, sparking concerns about their well-being and future.

site_title: Australia sells record A$13b in bonds
summary: Australia sold a record A$13 billion in bonds, exceeding its previous record of A$11 billion in 2017. The bonds were sold at a yield-to-maturity of 0.47% and received A$25.8 billion of bids. The sale is part of the government's efforts to combat the economic slowdown caused by the coronavirus pandemic, with the central bank pledging to buy debt and control borrowing costs. Australia aims to raise over A$250 billion in bonds in the next 15 months to fund its virus-combating measures.

site_title: Paltry dividends? Reits may go out of favour among investors
summary: Reit investors are facing a tumultuous time due to the Covid-19 crisis, with tenants demanding rental moratoriums, rebates, and waivers. Reit managers have cut dividends, with SPH Reit reducing its Q1 earnings by 77% without explanation. This move is seen as a precedent, with investors warning that Reits may go out of favour if they continue to cut dividends. Reit managers are criticized for lacking personal stakes and failing to show leadership, and experts argue that they should consider cutting management fees or setting aside acquisition and divestment fees to tide over the lean period.

site_title: STI fails to sustain early gains despite Wall Street rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.1% to 2,605.56 on Wednesday, despite an overnight Wall Street rally. The rally was driven by signs of slowing US Covid-19 cases. Analysts say a V-shaped recovery is still far from sight, citing ongoing concerns about lockdowns. Jardine Strategic Holdings was the best performer, while City Developments and SATS were among the worst losers.

site_title: Trump cuts WHO funding, draws world criticism as virus toll mounts
summary: US President Donald Trump halted funding to the World Health Organization (WHO) amid criticism for its handling of the coronavirus pandemic. The US, the largest donor, had contributed over $400 million in 2019. Trump accused the WHO of promoting China's disinformation and failing to investigate credible reports about the virus. The move drew criticism from other countries, medical experts, and the UN secretary-general, who emphasized the need for unity and cooperation to stop the pandemic. The WHO reported a decline in new cases in some areas, but warned of growing outbreaks in others.

site_title: Laws passed to save SMEs; now cut the red tape, as execution is key
summary: Singapore has expedited laws and measures to help small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) survive the Covid-19 pandemic. The government has increased its risk share of loans to 90% for SMEs and granted one-month rental waivers for government agency tenants. However, the execution of these measures is crucial, as SMEs face significant challenges in accessing financing and navigating the application process. With a significant portion of the economy dependent on SMEs, timely action is necessary to prevent their survival from being at stake.

site_title: Record 447 new cases in Singapore; G20 backs debt moratorium
summary: Singapore reported 447 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 3,699, with 41 more cases discharged, making the total recovered 652. The G20 backed debt moratorium, a key development in the global response to the pandemic.

site_title: Moscow apartment sales surge as rouble crashes
summary: Moscow apartment sales surged by 31% in March to 14,801, as Russians sought to protect their funds amid the rouble's four-year low due to the global oil deal collapse and coronavirus spread. This increase is attributed to the secondary market, where apartments are already built, providing more security for investors. The primary market saw a 13% rise in deals, with buyers fearing the rouble's fall would trigger higher mortgage rates. Experts expect a sharp drop in real estate deals this month due to the lockdown.

site_title: IMDA starts probe into StarHub broadband disruptions
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has launched an investigation into StarHub's broadband disruptions that affected over 500,000 residential customers in Singapore, with outages reported in the morning and afternoon. StarHub attributed the issues to network equipment faults and confirmed that there is no evidence of a cyber attack. The telco apologized and assured customers that traffic on its network is well below its available capacity, with ample redundancy built into the network to ensure service stability. IMDA vows to take "strong enforcement action" if necessary.

site_title: Bach in my heart, and my heart in his hands
summary: A New York Times critic reflects on the consoling music of composer Johann Sebastian Bach during the COVID-19 pandemic, drawing parallels to a surgeon's experience helping him. The critic notes that Bach's music, with its intelligence, inventiveness, and understated emotion, can offer solace and elevate the human spirit. In contrast, a surgeon, Craig R. Smith, writes daily updates about the crisis, emphasizing the importance of gratitude and respect for healthcare workers. The critic sees Smith's writings as a powerful expression of the human side of the pandemic, and hopes that Bach's music can bring solace to those affected.

site_title: ByteDance hunts for Singapore tech talent in global hiring spree
summary: ByteDance, the Chinese tech giant behind TikTok, is on a global hiring spree, with 79 job openings listed in Singapore. The company aims to create 40,000 new jobs this year, including 10,000 globally, with a focus on coding, engineering, and research roles. Singapore is considered an "extremely important regional hub" for ByteDance's South-east Asian operations, and the company has partnered with the Singapore Economic Development Board. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, ByteDance continues to grow, with many tech firms downsizing, and its strong engineering culture is attracting Singapore's tech talent pool.

site_title: Covid-19 pandemic may cause another stormy decade
summary: The World Bank and IMF are warning of a potential new wave of political unrest and social unrest in the 2020s, triggered by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The global economy is expected to deteriorate, with 200 million jobs lost worldwide and 1.25 billion people facing reduced income. The World Bank has slashed its growth forecast for South Asia to 1.8-2.8% due to the pandemic, with many countries at risk of deep recession. Social media is also seen as a key driver of political instability, and growing economic inequality and youth unemployment may fuel further social unrest.

site_title: CDL pays 4.39b yuan for 51% stake in Sincere Prop
summary: CDL, a Singapore-based developer, has acquired a 51.01% stake in Chinese real estate developer Sincere Property Group for 4.39 billion yuan, valuing Sincere at 8.60 billion yuan. This deal will transform CDL into a major property player in China, with a joint controlling interest in Sincere through an offshore investment vehicle. The acquisition will also broaden CDL's capabilities across property segments and increase its presence in China to 18 cities.

site_title: EMA, Keppel O&M start S$10 million partnership for innovative energy solutions in marine sector
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) and Singapore's Energy Market Authority (EMA) have launched a S$10 million partnership to develop innovative energy solutions for the marine sector. The partnership aims to encourage cleaner energy and greater environmental sustainability. The collaboration will focus on promoting the adoption of cleaner energy sources, such as renewable energy, and reducing the sector's carbon footprint. The partnership is expected to drive growth and development in the marine energy sector, contributing to Singapore's goal of becoming a leader in sustainable energy solutions.

site_title: Activist hedge fund Starboard pounces on US companies in turmoil
summary: Activist hedge fund Starboard Value is pursuing proxy contests against five US companies, including eBay, Commvault Systems, GCP Applied Technologies, Mednax, and Merit Medical, despite the economic fallout from the coronavirus outbreak. Starboard aims to secure roughly two dozen board seats, a record number for the firm. Its aggressive approach contrasts with other activist investors, who are holding back and reaching settlements. Starboard's track record includes securing 118 board seats since 2013, mostly through settlements, and boasts a significant return on investment for its investors.

site_title: Actors, dancers, musicians get creative online
summary: Singapore's creative sector adapts to the Covid-19 pandemic by offering online entertainment options, including theatre companies, actors, and musicians. Theatres like the Singapore Dance Theatre conduct dance classes on Instagram, while actors perform on video and festivals go online. Meanwhile, experts share tips on coping with the pandemic, including style suggestions for Zoom meetings and recipes for circuit breaker-friendly meals. The shift to online content may shape the future of consuming arts in Singapore.

site_title: A new iPhone could be coming as locked-down consumers seek bargains
summary: Apple is reportedly set to release a new, lower-priced iPhone, potentially called iPhone SE or iPhone 9, with a starting price under $400. This move aims to fill a gap in its line-up and appeal to budget-conscious consumers. Samsung has already introduced new devices priced under $500, and Google may follow suit with a Pixel 4A. The new iPhones will likely be sold online with limited retail presence due to the pandemic-induced economic crisis, and analysts predict sales of 20-25 million units before the release of a new flagship iPhone.

site_title: Japan firm offers spouses time-out apartments to avoid 'coronavirus divorce'
summary: A Tokyo-based short-term rental firm, Kasoku, is offering "time-out" apartments to couples struggling during the COVID-19 lockdown, helping them temporarily separate. The company aims to prevent "coronavirus divorce" by providing a safe space for couples to recharge and reconnect. Kasoku encourages customers to consult with them before making a decision, suggesting that the arrangement can be a temporary solution to maintain relationships.

site_title: Why can't America make enough masks or ventilators?
summary: The US is struggling to meet its immediate need for critical medical supplies and personal protective equipment due to inadequate domestic production capacity and reliance on global supply chains. Amid the Covid-19 pandemic, companies are stepping up to produce essential items like masks, ventilators, and hand sanitizers, but policymakers are slow to address the issue.
