summary: A federal appeals court revived nationwide litigation against Facebook, accusing the company of violating users' privacy rights by tracking their internet activity even after logging out. The 9th US Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco said users could pursue claims under federal and California privacy laws. Facebook had accused the lawsuit of being without merit, but the court ruled that users had a reasonable expectation of privacy and had sufficiently alleged a clear invasion of their right to privacy.

site_title: Trump says airline rescue plan coming soon
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to present a rescue package for the struggling airline industry this weekend, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The proposed plan, which may include direct conversations with individual airlines, aims to save the industry from reduced business. The US government has set aside $50 billion in the stimulus bill, but airlines are hesitant to accept conditions, fearing a potential equity stake from the government. The four major US carriers, including Delta and American Airlines, are considering the proposal, which could provide much-needed cash to sustain hundreds of thousands of jobs.

site_title: TikTok pledges US$250m for Covid-19 relief
summary: TikTok has pledged US$250 million to support coronavirus relief efforts globally. The funds will be allocated for medical staffing, supplies, hardship relief for healthcare workers, and support for diverse user communities, including musicians and educators. This move follows similar announcements from other technology firms and leaders, including Google, Facebook, and Microsoft. TikTok's president, Alex Zhu, emphasized the company's commitment to providing relief to those most affected by the crisis, stating that the funds will "magnify" the community's efforts.

site_title: Oil prices fall sharply as top producers hold key talks
summary: Top oil producers held key talks to finalize output cuts, leading to a sharp fall in oil prices. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropped 9.3% to $22.76 a barrel, while Brent slipped 4.1% to $31.48 a barrel. The move aims to counter the collapse in prices due to the coronavirus pandemic. The agreement's impact on the oil market remains to be seen, but the price drop indicates a positive step towards stabilizing the market.

site_title: March HDB resale prices fall 0.3% on higher volumes amid virus outbreak
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore fell 0.3% in March due to the coronavirus outbreak, but a total of 1,948 flats changed hands, a 16.8% increase from February. Higher volumes of transactions offset the price decrease, indicating resilience in the market.

site_title: Virtual showflats, marketing on the rise; but not all potential buyers sold on them
summary: Singapore's real estate market adapts to Covid-19 restrictions by increasing virtual showflats and online marketing tools. ERA Realty Network has produced virtual tours for 68 projects, including 360-degree photo shots, 3D floor plans, and Advanced Google Maps. However, some buyers prefer in-person viewings, citing a desire to touch and feel finishes. The Urban Redevelopment Authority facilitates electronic payments for booking fees and progress payments, but lawyers note that wet ink signatures are still required for OTP and SP&A documents.

site_title: Relief measures reprieve for builders, but month-long shutdown a dampener
summary: Singapore's construction industry faces a month-long shutdown due to the circuit breaker measures, affecting builders and potentially impacting FY2020 results. The government has introduced relief measures, including a S$5.1 billion Solidarity Budget and enhanced Jobs Support Scheme, to cushion the impact. However, construction firms face cash flow pressures, and some expect their financial performance to be negatively affected. Companies with large fixed costs and weaker profitability in the sector are particularly vulnerable to the prolonged shutdown.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Google News Lab
summary: Glenn van Zutphen spoke to Irene Jay Liu, Google News Lab Lead, APAC, about Google's efforts to help users and journalists access accurate news. Google is working to improve news discovery and generation, aiming to provide users with the right news. The conversation focused on Google's initiatives, but no specific conclusions or key events were discussed in the provided article.

site_title: Indonesia leans on healthtech startups to cope with virus surge
summary: Indonesia is relying on healthtech startups to cope with the surge in coronavirus cases. Doctors are working with apps like Alodokter to provide consultations and treatment for Covid-19 patients, especially in areas with limited healthcare facilities. The approach is becoming part of the national healthcare system, with many hospitals designating "red zones" for virus patients and utilizing healthtech startups to supplement their services.

site_title: STI closes 1.26% higher, clawing back some losses from Wednesday's fall
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 1.26% higher on Thursday, recouping some losses from the previous day, at 2,571.32. Seven of the 30 STI constituents finished in the red. Market sentiment will continue to depend on global Covid-19 infection rates, with investors watching US jobless claims figures and Opec output decisions. Asian benchmarks were mostly up, with Jardine C&C and Singtel being top performers.

site_title: Boris Johnson out of Covid-19 intensive care
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has left intensive care after three days of treatment for Covid-19 and will receive close monitoring during his recovery. He was transferred from intensive care to a ward at London's St Thomas's hospital on Thursday evening. The government has extended a lockdown, with 881 deaths reported, and senior ministers warned that the measures may not be lifted until the end of next week. Johnson's recovery comes as the UK struggles with the pandemic, with concerns over the numbers of people infected and the impact on the healthcare system.

site_title: Europe: Shares post best week since 2011, focus on EU stimulus
summary: European stock markets posted their best week since 2011, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index rising 7.4% after the US Federal Reserve rolled out a $2.3 trillion stimulus package. The US jobless claims data showed another week with over six million new claims, but Wall Street indexes jumped in response to the Fed's actions. The Stoxx 600 index closed up 1.6% to end the holiday-shortened week, with major sectors including travel, leisure, and energy gaining ground.

site_title: China developers already weak before pandemic
summary: China's large real estate firms reported declining margins and weakened liquidity buffers in 2020, exacerbating the challenges posed by the coronavirus pandemic. Average profit margins sank to the lowest in three years due to surging land costs and home-price caps. Many developers face a cash crunch, with cash reserves averaging 1.3 times short-term debt, and must offer deep discounts to meet sales targets. The nation's new-home market may slump 15% this year, and shares of major developers are trading at record lows.

site_title: EU finance ministers agree coronavirus rescue deal
summary: EU finance ministers have agreed on a 500 billion euro ($550-billion) rescue package for European countries hit by the coronavirus epidemic, with the funds specifically earmarked for COVID-19 crisis costs. The package includes 240 billion euros from the European Stability Mechanism and 200 billion euros in guarantees from the European Investment Bank. A proposal for a joint borrowing instrument, or "coronabond," was put on hold due to Germany's refusal to participate. The deal aims to restart the European economy, but observers believe it may not be enough to address the continent's economic meltdown.

site_title: Singapore considers solar energy imports to cut greenhouse emissions
summary: Singapore considers importing solar energy to diversify its energy supply and meet its goal of cutting net greenhouse emissions to zero by 2030. The country, one of the sunniest cities, generates 95% of its power from imported natural gas. Solar energy is its most viable renewable energy option, with a target of 2 GW of peak power by 2030. Singapore is also exploring regional power grids and low-carbon alternatives like hydrogen and carbon capture. The country aims to balance cleaner energy access with higher costs and energy security risks.

images.alt_text: The country generates about 95 per cent of its power from imported natural gas, with solar energy being its most viable renewable energy option.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropped 12.1 points or 0.9% to 1,357.7 as trading began on Friday. The decline was attributed to lower opening prices. In contrast, Singapore's STI rose 0.4% on Thursday despite US tariff uncertainty. Meanwhile, eSIM platform Airalo raised US$220 million in funding, valuing the company above US$1 billion.

site_title: Uber to distribute 'tens of millions' of masks in virus safety move
summary: Uber plans to distribute "tens of millions" of masks to drivers worldwide amid the coronavirus pandemic. The company has shipped masks to drivers in New York City and expects another half-million to be delivered to other US cities. The move follows health authorities' guidance to use face coverings as an added protection against the virus. Supplies are limited, and healthcare needs will take priority, with all N95 respirator masks being donated to hospitals. Uber obtained the masks from outside the traditional healthcare supply chains, including a company that normally produces electronics.

site_title: Living Bold
summary: A family of three, the Ongs, opted for a functional, yet unconventional, apartment design in Singapore. The apartment features dark interiors, a missing kitchen, and a wet kitchen that was initially deemed impractical by the developer. The couple and their son redesigned the space to create a more efficient and cozy living area, with a focus on minimalist design. The apartment's dark theme is balanced by natural light and unique design elements, such as a marble island and a floor-to-ceiling marble piece. The Ongs report feeling like they're living in a "big hotel suite" due to the apartment's spacious layout.

site_title: Asia's tycoons seeking cheap assets after virus rout
summary: Asian tycoons, including Victor Li and Guo Guangchang, are seeking cheap assets amid the coronavirus pandemic, but face hurdles from governments trying to deter foreign takeovers of local firms. Cash-rich conglomerates like Li's CK group are in a position to invest, with Li's CK Hutchison Holdings having HK$145 billion in cash and liquid investments. However, governments are introducing stricter rules to shield strategically important domestic companies, making acquisitions harder. This poses a challenge for companies that rely on acquisitions to grow, such as Li's CK group.

site_title: US economy purged 17m jobs amid pandemic
summary: The US economy has lost 17 million jobs since mid-March due to the coronavirus pandemic, with the unemployment rate expected to surge into double digits in April. The Federal Reserve has launched new lending programs to pump $2.3 trillion into the economy, and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin predicts businesses can restart as soon as May. Analysts expect the jobless rate to persist for months, with the International Monetary Fund warning of the worst global emergency since the Great Depression, and a projected unemployment rate of 14% in April and 16% in May.

images.alt_text: US unemployment is rising at a jarring rate, with data released Thursday showing 17 million people have lost their jobs since mid-March as officials scramble to apply a tourniquet to stem the damage from the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: As delivery workers become essential, India govt warms to e-commerce
summary: India's government has warmed up to e-commerce, recognizing its importance in the country's fight against the COVID-19 pandemic. Delivery workers, like Devender Singh, have become essential frontline soldiers, and their services are now being accepted despite initial concerns over police brutality. E-commerce companies, including Amazon and Flipkart, are slowly resuming operations, albeit with delayed deliveries and limited product catalogues. The government has also acknowledged the sector's value, with Trade Minister Piyush Goyal holding a video conference with e-commerce executives to understand their challenges.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens higher on massive US stimulus
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 0.5% to 19,442.69, following the US Federal Reserve's announcement of massive new stimulus, which boosted Wall Street rallies. This encouraged Japanese shares to rise, despite the broader Topix index slipping 0.2%. Market analysts attribute the increase to the positive impact of US stimulus on global markets.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's key Nikkei index opened higher on Friday, extending rallies on Wall Street after the US Federal Reserve unveiled massive new stimulus.

site_title: Clearing landmines after the war
summary: The world is facing a critical economic and financial crisis, exacerbated by the pandemic. To address this, governments must clear "landmines" from the economic system, including unsustainable debt and the need for structural reforms. The article warns that unlimited money creation will not solve the problem and that a return to traditional liberal capitalism or an active state with a decisive role in industrial strategy is necessary. Key measures include finalizing the EU budget, issuing corona bonds, and establishing a banking union with a real resolution system to prevent future economic shocks.

site_title: Culture for your quarantine
summary: Arts companies are releasing their works online to combat the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. This week, several notable productions are available to watch for free. These include "Those Who Can't, Teach" by The Necessary Stage, a drama about teachers and students, "Montreal Jazz Festival" archives, Pina Bausch's "Kontakthof" dance, "Einstein On The Beach" by Robert Wilson and Philip Glass, "Cosi Fan Tutte" by Royal Opera House, "Oklahoma!" by National Theatre, a tribute to Jerome Robbins by Paris Opera Ballet, and "Treasure Island" by National Theatre.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Huationg Global, a Catalist-listed civil engineering firm, has implemented a 20% pay cut for its chairman and two executive directors to cope with the COVID-19 pandemic's impact. The company will suspend construction works for its ongoing projects for a month and expects significant disruptions to its business, potentially affecting revenue and financial performance.

site_title: Airbnb to restrict bookings on its platform in Britain
summary: Airbnb will restrict bookings on its platform in Britain until at least April 18, allowing only key workers to stay in properties during the COVID-19 pandemic. The move comes after criticism of hosts advertising "isolation retreats." Key workers, exempt from government curbs, can book stays, while the government reviews lockdown measures next week. The policy will be reviewed in line with guidance if restrictions are extended.

site_title: ABS gives cash incentive to SMEs that sign up for PayNow to minimise virus spread
summary: The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) is offering a S$500,000 cash incentive to small businesses that sign up for PayNow, a peer-to-peer fund-transfer service, to encourage digital payments and minimize the spread of Covid-19. The first 20,000 businesses to sign up by July 31 will receive S$25 each, with additional S$25 for those receiving more than 10 payments. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is working to increase e-payment adoption among businesses and individuals, urging them to use digital services to minimize physical visits to financial institutions.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises on latest Fed rescue program
summary: US stocks surged on Thursday, with the S&P 500 index posting its best weekly gain since 1974, as the US Federal Reserve unveiled a $2.3 trillion package to support local governments and businesses affected by the coronavirus outbreak. The Fed's program includes four-year loans for companies with up to 10,000 employees and direct bond purchases. Early signs of the outbreak's peak and aggressive global stimulus also contributed to the market's rally. The benchmark index closed out the trading week on a high note, bolstered by the Fed's efforts to stabilize the economy.

site_title: Getting ready for the rebound
summary: As the coronavirus pandemic wanes, businesses can capitalize on the downtime to prepare for a potential rebound. Key strategies include acquiring new skills, leveraging technology, and nurturing employees. A small team of representatives from various age groups should be assembled to prioritize management decisions and guide the return to work. Long supply chains will be the most difficult to restart, requiring proactive measures to identify weak links and support suppliers. Reorganizing the business to prioritize strong leadership, flexibility, and human interaction is also crucial. Finally, getting finances in order, including loans, grants, and cash management, will be essential for a successful recovery.

site_title: Blackstone raises 9.8b euros for European property fund
summary: Blackstone has raised 9.8 billion euros for its European property fund, Blackstone Real Estate Partners Europe VI. The fund is the largest private equity capital raising since the pandemic's outbreak, swelling the firm's uninvested capital to about $30 billion. The fund's completion comes as the coronavirus continues to disrupt markets, with many investors viewing the current market as unappealing. Blackstone's head of Real Estate Europe, James Seppala, attributed the significant demand for the fund to the firm's ability to deploy strategic long-term capital.

site_title: Singapore-based investors value confidence, financial comfort: survey
summary: A study by Standard Chartered Bank found that Singapore-based investors prioritize confidence, financial comfort, and risk tolerance over other factors, making them less impulsive and more likely to make reasonable decisions during turbulent times. The study categorized investors into three groups: comfortable, conservative, and enthusiastic, with Singapore-based investors being most likely to fall into the comfortable category. This contrasts with investors in Hong Kong and Taiwan, who exhibit higher levels of speculation and impulsive behavior.

site_title: All Star Dining
summary: Odette, a three-Michelin-starred restaurant at National Gallery Singapore, has been named No. 1 on Asia's 50 Best Restaurants list for the second consecutive year. Chef Julien Royer's commitment to using seasonality, terroir, and artisanal produce is reflected in his dishes, such as the Oita Egg paired with Pertuis asparagus and French morels. The restaurant's respect for these principles helped it temporarily forget its concerns during the coronavirus outbreak in late March.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: The 2020 Asia's 50 Best Bars will be announced online on May 14. Manhattan at Regent Singapore, a temporary favorite, will be available to buy its bottled cocktails, including the Chocolate Negroni, from the hotel's deli. The cocktails retail for S$118 each and can be purchased from shop.regentsingapore.com.sg.

site_title: Bank of Korea's governor warns of heavy Covid-19 impact on country's economy
summary: Bank of Korea Governor Lee Ju-yeol warned that the country's economy will be heavily impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, surpassing the global financial crisis. Despite this, the central bank held its policy rate at 0.75% to avoid making further major moves, suggesting a cautious approach to economic stimulus. The decision was in line with forecasts by nine out of 17 analysts surveyed by Bloomberg.

site_title: Millions of Indonesians get ready to travel out of outbreak centre
summary: Millions of Indonesians are preparing to travel out of Jakarta, the epicenter of the country's coronavirus outbreak, as the city implements new social distancing guidelines and a commercial shutdown. An estimated 2.5 million migrant workers are expected to leave the city for their hometowns and villages, ahead of the Eid al-Fitr festival, which could exacerbate the outbreak. Experts warn that this mass migration could overwhelm local resources, particularly in areas that were previously unscathed, and lead to a surge in cases.

site_title: A stay-at-home whiskey project - the infinity bottle
summary: Whiskey enthusiasts have adopted a home blending method called the "infinity bottle," where leftover whiskey is poured into another bottle and aged. The process mimics traditional sherry production, with new whiskey added at regular intervals to mature wine. Enthusiasts worldwide share photos of their "infinity bottles" on Instagram, showcasing the unique blending process. Josh Peters, a whiskey blogger, popularized the term and technique, which has gained popularity among whiskey enthusiasts.

site_title: S-Reits themselves in need of some lifelines
summary: Singapore-listed Reits (S-Reits) are facing challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to a decline in tenant payments. The government has introduced measures to support tenants, but this may impact S-Reits' ability to pay out 90% of their annual distributable income for tax exemption. With no clear end to the pandemic, S-Reits may need to reconsider their financial strategies, potentially leading to a re-evaluation of their business model and ability to maintain high yields. The industry's reputation as a global Reit hub is also at risk.

site_title: Third week of big US jobless claims sees 6.61m filings
summary: The US saw a record 6.61 million jobless claims filed in the week ended April 4, bringing the total to about 16.8 million during the coronavirus pandemic's economic shutdown. This surpasses the median forecast of 5.5 million and the previous week's upwardly revised 6.87 million. The US Federal Reserve rolled out a $2.3 trillion effort to bolster local governments and small businesses, with Fed Chairman Jerome Powell stating the country's priority is addressing the public health crisis. The jobless claims figure implies an unemployment rate of around 13-14%, surpassing the 10% peak reached in the last recession.

images.alt_text: As wide swathes of the US economy shut down, workers have been laid off across industries with unprecedented speed.

site_title: Citi Singapore doles out S$1,200 cash to lower-paid staff as Covid-19 aid
summary: Citi Singapore is providing a one-off S$1,200 cash compensation to approximately 1,600 lower-paid staff members as a COVID-19 aid, costing the bank around S$2 million. The compensation is for employees with an annual base salary of S$70,000 or less, with additional benefits such as complimentary insurance coverage and preferred corporate rates for medical teleconsultation services. The deadline for using carry-over leave is extended to Dec 31, 2020, but overseas vacations are not allowed due to travel restrictions.

site_title: Coronavirus brings UK housing market to near standstill: chartered surveyors
summary: The UK housing market has come to a near standstill due to measures to slow the spread of coronavirus, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. Property viewings have been halted, and estate agents' offices are closed. Despite some initial improvement in house prices and activity, the trend has reversed sharply. Sales expectations for the next three months are the weakest on record, and price expectations for the coming months are the lowest since the financial crisis. Experts predict a larger fall in output than the 2008-09 financial crisis, with some expecting a year-long recovery.

site_title: Volatility drives SDAV, ETF value higher on Singapore Exchange in March
summary: Trading activity on the Singapore Exchange surged in March, driven by heightened volatility amid the coronavirus pandemic. The Securities Daily Average Value (SDAV) rose 114% year-over-year to S$2.2 billion, and total securities market turnover jumped 124% to S$48.2 billion. The increase in volatility led to a 9.8 times oversubscription of NTT DC Reit's public offer, and Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: WeWork skips paying some April rent in US locations, seeks landlord relief
summary: WeWork has stopped paying rent for some US locations in April, seeking landlord relief through rent abatements, revenue-sharing agreements, and lease amendments. The company aims to trim liabilities of up to $47 billion, or 30%, and has reached out to over 600 global landlord partners. WeWork has paid rent for other locations and is pitching solutions such as revenue-sharing agreements, but landlords are reportedly reluctant. The company is also offering discounts to tenants to minimize cancellations amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Grim times for fresh grads as pandemic hits job opportunities
summary: Singapore's job market faces challenges amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with economists predicting a decline in hiring opportunities for fresh graduates. Despite government efforts to support the workforce, including online career fairs and training subsidies, job postings have fallen by 14.9% year-on-year. Unemployment is expected to rise to 5% or more, from 2.3% in 2019. Some universities have shifted career fairs online and are offering alternative job opportunities, but experts warn that premature career setbacks may occur, and graduates may struggle to find suitable employment.

images.alt_text: SMU is doing career coaching online, while NUS and NTU will train students for virtual - rather than face-to-face - job interviews.

site_title: Can technology save the senior worker?
summary: The article discusses how technology is transforming the job market, particularly for middle-aged and older workers in the professional, manager, executive, and technician (PMET) demographic. As the economy faces an impending recession, older workers may struggle to adapt to new skills required by tech. However, technology can potentially help save displaced older workers by providing training and upskilling opportunities. Experts warn of a looming data storage crisis, while investors send mixed signals.

site_title: Greenback steadies ahead of US jobs data
summary: The US dollar steadied ahead of US jobs data, which is expected to show 5.25 million jobless claims. Economists forecast a major global downturn, with annualized US GDP contraction ranging from 9.5% to 42%. Markets have largely priced in the effects of the lockdown, making the jobless figures a non-game-changer. The greenback edged down 0.1% against major currencies, while currencies seen as riskier bets consolidated recent gains.

site_title: Large firms still hiring graduate trainees amid virus-fuelled uncertainty
summary: Large firms in Singapore are still hiring graduate trainees despite the pandemic-fuelled uncertainty. Companies such as Temasek's Mapletree, CapitaLand, and DBS are expanding their in-house management associate programs, with plans to bring on 20-30 fresh graduates this year. IT and healthcare positions remain in demand, and companies are investing in young talent for the long term. Despite concerns about job offers being yanked, organizations are honouring their arrangements with graduating students.

site_title: Robots may emerge as heroes in Covid-19 war
summary: Robots are being increasingly relied upon in the fight against the Covid-19 pandemic due to their speed, efficiency, and ability to minimize human contact. Robots have been used in hospitals to care for patients, deliver medication and meals, and even perform medical procedures. Some robots can scan for the presence of the virus and disinfect rooms, reducing the risk of transmission. The use of robots in healthcare has accelerated innovation, with companies like Xenex and Shark Robotics seeing a surge in demand for their disinfection and decontamination units.

site_title: We are all survivors
summary: Human beings have consistently demonstrated resilience in the face of devastating diseases throughout history, with examples including the Black Death, plague in China, and the 1918 influenza epidemic. Cities, which were initially unhealthy due to poor sanitation and overcrowding, became hubs for disease spread, but also facilitated survival through cooperation and adaptation. The development of vaccines, better living environments, and scientific understanding of diseases have greatly improved human survival rates. Despite the current COVID-19 pandemic, humans have a history of pulling through crises, thanks to their intelligence, cooperation, and consideration for others, making them a "survivor" species.

site_title: Ventilator orders breathe life into Chinese copper demand
summary: Chinese copper demand has received a boost from orders for ventilators in the fight against the coronavirus, with traders reporting 20,000-set orders from major US and European countries. The demand is expected to lift copper premiums, which have reached their highest since November 2019, due to logistics issues and a potential value-added tax cut in China. However, analysts note that the increased demand from ventilator production is unlikely to have a long-term impact on copper demand, which remains subdued due to the global economic slowdown.

site_title: Pandemic creates India, China rivalry
summary: India and China are engaging in a medical diplomacy rivalry to win the hearts and minds of South Asian countries affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. India has pledged $10 million to create a Covid-19 emergency fund and deployed medical teams, while China has provided emergency aid, including medical supplies and personnel. Pakistan, heavily reliant on Chinese loans, has prioritized its relations with China over its citizens' health. In contrast, countries like Nepal and Bhutan have contributed to the emergency fund and accepted Indian aid. As the pandemic continues, the competition between India and China is likely to deepen, with potential implications for the region's economic and security dynamics.

site_title: Engage workforce, reassert trust in firm's leadership
summary: Business leaders must rebalance priorities to manage the immediate and future during the Covid-19 crisis, stabilizing and consolidating culture to ensure the organization's resilience. Nine key focal points include prioritizing purpose and wellbeing, communicating clearly, understanding multiples, and fostering collaborative problem-solving. Organizations must also create sharable experiences, build sustainable support programs, and articulate a vision for a positive future. Effective communication, transparency, and trust are crucial to minimizing collateral culture damage and reasserting trust in leadership, ultimately enabling the business to return to optimal performance.

site_title: World economy faces US$5t hit that's like losing Japan
summary: The global economy is projected to lose over $5 trillion in growth over the next two years due to the coronavirus pandemic, equivalent to Japan's annual output. The downturn, the deepest since the 1930s, will take time to recover from, with GDP unlikely to return to pre-crisis levels until at least 2022. Policymakers face a delicate balance in delivering stimulus without reopening economies too soon and allowing the virus to return, with the risk of a second wave of cases and a prolonged recovery in emerging markets.

site_title: Linus Lim appointed as CEO of Phillip Capital Management
summary: Linus Lim has been appointed as the CEO of Phillip Capital Management (PCM) effective April 5, replacing an unspecified predecessor. Lim, who has been with the company since 2001, previously held the roles of director and co-CIO. He brings extensive experience in equity research and corporate finance from his time at Citibank Asia-Pacific and holds an MBA from UCLA. Jeffrey Lee will continue as director and CIO of PCM.

site_title: Global pandemic is as much a test of leadership as it is of businesses
summary: A global pandemic has transformed Covid-19 from a local outbreak to a global pandemic, with businesses needing to adapt quickly to an economic slowdown. Companies are implementing cost containment measures, including pay cuts, voluntary leave, and reduced bonuses. To balance affordability with fairness, organisations are considering alternative approaches to variable pay components, such as revising targets or making discretionary adjustments. Boards and remuneration committees are also taking a long-term approach to variable pay, ensuring executives' behaviours are aligned with the company's long-term success. Effective leadership is crucial in navigating this crisis.

site_title: SAP cuts 2020 earnings guidance as virus puts orders on hold
summary: SAP has cut its 2020 earnings guidance due to the coronavirus pandemic, now expecting a single-digit decline in operating profit after initially forecasting 10% growth. The company now sees operating profit in a range of 8.1-8.7 billion euros, a 1-6% fall at constant currencies. SAP stands by its mid-term growth forecasts, focusing on shifting to cloud subscriptions and away from software licenses. The company's adjusted operating profit edged 1% higher to 1.48 billion euros in the first quarter, with cloud revenue growing 29% on an adjusted basis.

site_title: Record 287 new Covid-19 cases here, most linked to foreign workers
summary: Singapore reported a record 287 new Covid-19 cases, mostly linked to foreign workers. Over 200 cases involved foreign workers, with Health Minister Gan Kim Yong predicting the number will continue to rise in the coming days and weeks. This surge comes as the daily number of cases among locals stabilizes.

site_title: US Fed moves beyond markets with US$2.3t package to aid SMEs
summary: The US Federal Reserve unveiled a $2.3 trillion package to aid small and mid-sized businesses and local governments amid the coronavirus pandemic. The package includes four-year loans to companies with up to 10,000 employees and direct lending to state governments and populous counties. Fed Chair Jerome Powell emphasized the central bank's expanded role in supporting the US economy during the crisis. The program aims to provide relief and stability, with a focus on ensuring a robust recovery.

site_title: President approves use of reserves for support measures
summary: Singaporean President Halimah Yacob has given her assent to the Resilience and Solidarity Budgets, authorizing a draw of up to S$21 billion from the country's past reserves to support measures amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The budget aims to cushion the impact on Singaporeans, with S$59.9 billion in support measures, including a S$44.3 billion budget deficit. The move is unprecedented in Singapore's history, following discussions with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat since February.

site_title: Oil prices rise on hopes Opec+ will agree to supply cuts
summary: Saudi Arabia and Russia agree on a deal to cut oil production by 15% as part of the Opec+ coalition's efforts to lift the market from a pandemic-driven collapse. The two nations have put aside differences, with Saudi Arabia pushing for a baseline of its April production and Russia favouring an average of the first quarter. Oil prices surged 11% as the deal was announced, with the US also expected to cut output to support the agreement. The deal is seen as crucial for the fate of oil-dependent economies and millions of oil industry jobs.

site_title: Indonesian barber cuts few corners with safety during these coronavirus times
summary: A 40-year-old Indonesian barber, Herman Maulanasyah, is taking safety precautions during the coronavirus pandemic by wearing makeshift protective gear, including a plastic sheet, gas mask, and gloves, to minimize the risk of exposure to the virus. Despite the risks, his income has significantly decreased, from $44.90 to $100,000 per day. Maulanasyah's salon now operates with limited capacity and strict distancing measures to protect himself and customers. This unusual approach highlights the challenges faced by Indonesian health workers and the need for increased safety measures in the country.

images.alt_text: Clad in a taped plastic sheet, a ski goggles, a gas mask and latex gloves, Mr Maulanasyah welcomes customers at his salon.

site_title: US February wholesale inventories revised down
summary: US wholesale inventories fell 0.7% in February, revised from the initial 0.5% decline, due to the novel coronavirus outbreak depressing imports. Goods imports dropped to a near 2.5-year low, with merchandise from China at its lowest since 2009. This decline could offset any contribution to GDP from a smaller trade deficit. The revised inventory decline is the third consecutive month of falls, with inventories slicing off almost a full percentage point from GDP growth in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Coronavirus woes force famous HK snake restaurant to shut
summary: A famous Hong Kong snake meat restaurant, She Wong Yee, will shut its doors in April 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic, which has kept customers away. The restaurant, known for its long-simmered snake soup, had seen a 70% drop in business after the Chinese New Year holidays and was now losing up to HK$200,000 per month. Hong Kong's economy, already weakened by the US-China trade war and anti-government protests, has been further impacted by the virus, with nearly 1,000 cases and four deaths reported.

site_title: Let Everyone Eat Cake
summary: Local bakers in Singapore are creating edible treats to bring cheer to those stuck at home during the COVID-19 pandemic. Various bakeries, such as Flofond, Ten Butter Fingers, and Drips Bakery Cafe, are offering customized brownies, cupcakes, and cakes with uplifting messages to help brighten people's days. Some bakeries are also donating a portion of their proceeds to charity organizations, promoting positivity and community support during this challenging time.

site_title: Lendlease Global Reit withdraws profit and distribution forecasts for FY20 and FY21
summary: Lendlease Global Reit has withdrawn its profit and distribution forecasts for FY20 and FY21 due to the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak on its portfolio. The manager cited the Singapore government's measures, including the impact on 313@somerset's contribution to the Reit's distributable income, as the reason. The Reit initially forecasted a loss of S$15.6 million and a distribution per unit of 3.82 cents for FY2020, and a profit of S$45.1 million and DPU of 5.29 cents for FY2021.

site_title: Special Feature - Home Dining Treats
summary: Pollen restaurant is offering special home dining treats, including gourmet meals such as roast lamb, beef wellington, and osso bucco, prepared by Michelin-starred chef Michael Wilson. The first 50 readers to order will receive a complimentary bottle of wine. Jumbo's Zui Yu Xuan Teochew Cuisine is also offering 20% off takeaway orders, while Indocafe is providing Peranakan takeaway with 20% off for phone orders.

site_title: Vehicle makers push to reopen plants with testing and lots of masks
summary: Global automakers are accelerating efforts to restart factories amid the COVID-19 pandemic, using safety protocols developed for China and US ventilator production. Key measures include temperature screening, daily health questionnaires, and social distancing. Manufacturers such as Ferrari and General Motors (GM) are implementing these measures, while unions, including the United Auto Workers, are working to ensure the safety of workers. Several automakers, including Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, Honda Motor, and Toyota Motor, aim to restart production in the US and Europe in mid-to-late April.

site_title: Hi-P gets approval to continue manufacturing operations
summary: HI-P International has received approval from Singapore authorities to continue manufacturing operations at its Jurong facility during the circuit-breaker period, which ends on May 4. Its subsidiary, South East Asia Moulding Company, has ceased production and awaits approval for an exemption from the business suspension. The company's shares rose 0.5 Singapore cent or 0.53% to close at 94.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Takeaway is the new fine dining
summary: Singapore's government has implemented a directive for restaurants to only offer takeaway or home delivery services from April 7 to May 4 to curb the spread of Covid-19. Michelin-starred chefs such as Julien Royer of Odette and Rishi Naleendra of Cloudstreet are adapting to the new model by creating comfort food menus, while others like Sun Kim of Meta are focusing on home-style Korean cuisine. To enhance the takeaway experience, chefs are providing tips on plating and presentation, and some restaurants are launching new concepts, such as drive-thru services and digital restaurants.

site_title: Gojek gives drivers up to 100% rebate in commission during circuit-breaker
summary: Gojek is offering drivers up to 100% rebate in commission fees during the circuit-breaker period in Singapore. From April 10 to May 4, drivers will receive a rebate of 60-100% depending on their tier status, replacing the current driver incentives scheme. All drivers will receive a 100% commission fee rebate. The move aims to provide competitive and sustainable earnings during a period of reduced demand for ride-hailing services.

site_title: Self-reflection in a time of pandemic
summary: Jenny Odell's book "How To Do Nothing: Resisting The Attention Economy" has gained relevance as countries implement nationwide stay-home orders due to the pandemic. The book encourages readers to refocus their attention on the present and their surroundings, rather than being distracted by technology and societal pressures. Odell argues that embracing solitude, observation, and simple conviviality can be a form of resistance against the "attention economy," which prioritizes constant productivity and consumption. By "doing nothing," readers can rediscover the joys of active listening, observation, and contemplation, leading to greater contentment and calm.

images.alt_text: Images of once bustling streets around the world now left empty as people stay home.

site_title: 85 more businesses told to close for flouting 'circuit breaker' rules; one fined S$1,000
summary: 85 businesses in Singapore have been ordered to close for flouting "circuit breaker" rules, with one fined S$1,000 for violating safe-distancing measures. The businesses, including wellness shops, travel agencies, and phone accessory retailers, were found to have remained open despite providing non-essential services or failed to enforce safe-distancing measures properly. The actions are part of a joint effort by Enterprise Singapore and the Singapore Tourism Board to enforce elevated safe-distancing measures, with more checks to be conducted over the long weekend.

site_title: Enterprise Singapore to partly fund food delivery fulfilled by logistics players amid virus outbreak
summary: Enterprise Singapore will fund 20% of delivery costs for food delivery orders fulfilled by logistics players between April 7 and May 4, amid the COVID-19 outbreak. This is part of the Food Delivery Booster Package, which aims to support the food and beverage sector. The agency also offers an aid package worth over S$1,500 and up to 90% support for eligible costs through the Enterprise Development Grant.

images.alt_text: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) said on Thursday that it will fund part of the costs incurred by food and beverage (F&B) players when they fulfil delivery orders through third-party logistics partners.

site_title: Airbus cuts output by a third amid virus woes
summary: Airbus reduced its aircraft output by a third due to the coronavirus pandemic, now aiming to produce 48 planes per month across its A320, A330, and A350 programs. This represents a significant decline from its initial goal of 880 planes or 73 per month. The company is also deferring handovers and seeking bailouts from cash-strapped airlines, with production targets to be reassessed on a monthly basis.

site_title: Saudi, Russia agree on contours of historic deal to tackle slump
summary: Saudi Arabia and Russia have agreed on the outline of a deal to cut oil production in an effort to lift the market from a pandemic-driven collapse. The two nations appear to have buried differences, with Saudi Arabia pushing for a higher baseline and Russia insisting on US output cuts. Russia is willing to reduce output by 1.6 million barrels a day, while Saudi Arabia is discussing a cut of 15-17%. The deal could impact entire oil-dependent economies, thousands of companies, and millions of oil industry jobs.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia and Russia have agreed on the outline of a deal to cut oil production in an effort to lift the market from a pandemic-driven collapse.

site_title: Downtown eats head to the suburbs
summary: CBD restaurants are now delivering to the suburbs, offering comfort food options previously unavailable due to the 3km radius restriction. With the latest no-dine-in policy, island-wide delivery has opened up a new continent of options, allowing people to dine on downtown pizza and designer hamburgers. This development is seen as a positive change for those living outside the CBD area, providing them with access to a wider range of food options.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 8.37 points to 1,369.76. Volume was 4.693 billion lots worth RM2.246 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 634 to 252.

site_title: Delay of digibank results due to Covid-19 not a dial back in commitment
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has delayed the results of its digital banking license applications until the second half of 2020, citing the need to allow applicants to navigate the COVID-19 situation. Industry players welcome the move, seeing it as a prudent decision to ensure the new banks can launch at the right time. The delay does not affect Singapore's digital banking ambitions, and some players view it as an opportunity to hire talented individuals in technology and data analytics. The MAS remains committed to its digital bank strategy, with successful applicants expected to be informed in the second half of 2020.

site_title: New York City's construction freeze is adding to industry's debt risk
summary: New York City's construction freeze, caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, is causing significant financial risk to the city's $66 billion construction industry. Over $8 billion in construction debt has been issued in the past two years, with lenders Wells Fargo and Deutsche Bank among the top originators. Many projects, including luxury condos and office buildings, are at risk of losing financing due to delays. Lenders are struggling to assess financial viability, and some are considering forcing borrowers to make capital calls or providing grace periods. The uncertainty surrounding the pandemic's duration and economic impact is exacerbating the crisis.

site_title: Enterprise Singapore to partly fund food delivery fulfilled by logistics players
summary: Enterprise Singapore will fund 20% of delivery costs for food and beverage orders fulfilled by logistics players through third-party partners like Lalamove and Zeek, from April 7 to May 4. The move aims to support businesses during the COVID-19 pandemic. Additionally, ESG will fund an aid package worth over S$1,500 to help businesses optimize their online presence and improve sales through digital marketing and manpower costs.

site_title: US: Wall St jumps at open after Fed's massive stimulus, jobless claims data
summary: Wall Street jumped at the open on Thursday, driven by the Federal Reserve's $2.3 trillion stimulus program for local governments and businesses. Jobless claims fell to 6.6 million, down from 6.87 million the prior week. The Dow rose 1.10%, the S&P 500 gained 0.98%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.97%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended with a 1.38% rally, reaching 24,300.33, driven by signs that coronavirus infections are slowing. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index also gained 0.37%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.85%. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close in the US S&P 500. Investors remain positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: What do recent SG Budgets mean for SMEs?
summary: The Singapore Government has announced a $59.9 billion support package, known as the Solidarity Budget, to help businesses and individuals affected by COVID-19. The package includes enhanced measures for SMEs, such as increased loan quantum, interest rate caps, and deferral of principal repayment. The maximum loan quantum under the Enterprise Financing Scheme has been raised from SGD 600,000 to SGD 1 million, and the interest rate cap has been capped at 5% p.a. The government has also increased the risk share of loans from 80% to 90%.

site_title: US fed launches US$2.3t financing to support economy
summary: The US Federal Reserve launched a $2.3 trillion financing package to support the US economy amid the coronavirus pandemic. The measures include new and increased facilities, such as the Main Street Lending Programme to provide loans to small and mid-sized businesses, and the Municipal Liquidity Facility to help state and local governments manage cash flow stresses. The programmes aim to provide relief and stability during the economic downturn, with Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stating that the goal is to ensure a vigorous recovery. The measures are expected to benefit 40,000 medium-sized businesses and 35 million Americans.

site_title: Lendlease Global Reit withdraws profit and distribution forecasts for FY20 and FY21
summary: Lendlease Global Reit withdraws profit and distribution forecasts for FY20 and FY21 due to the impact of the Covid-19 outbreak on its portfolio. The Reit had initially forecast a loss of S$15.6 million and a distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.82 Singapore cents for FY2020, and a profit of S$45.1 million and DPU of 5.29 Singapore cents for FY2021. Other property trusts, CDL Hospitality Trusts and Ascott Residence Trust, also face challenges due to the pandemic, with CDLHT extending its hotel operations and ART temporarily closing 15 of its properties.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims top 6 million for second straight week
summary: US jobless claims top 6 million for second straight week, totaling 16 million Americans seeking unemployment benefits over the last three weeks. Weekly new claims of 6.6 million were down from the previous week's revised 6.87 million. Economists had predicted 5.25 million new claims.

site_title: Interview - Karen Cheng, restaurateur
summary: Restaurant owner Karen Cheng reflects on her entrepreneurial journey, from her luxury goods industry background to launching food trucks in Singapore. She co-founded The Travelling C.O.W (Chef on Wheels) in 2012, which has since evolved into an events and catering company. With the COVID-19 pandemic affecting her business, Cheng faces challenges such as logistical issues, cancellations, and enforcing social distancing measures. Despite these difficulties, she remains optimistic, crediting the government's support and her team's spirit for helping the business survive. Cheng emphasizes the importance of adapting to the new normal and finding ways to bring affordable food to underserved communities.

site_title: Seoul: Shares gain on oil output cut, pandemic slowdown hopes
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.61% on Thursday, recovering from a near 1% loss in the previous session, as investors hoped for oil output cuts and a slowdown in the coronavirus pandemic. The Kospi index closed at 1,836.21, while the won strengthened and the benchmark bond yield fell. The central bank held its interest rate at a record low and signaled further cuts, and reported 39 new coronavirus cases, bringing the national tally to 10,423.

site_title: PM Johnson 'getting better' in intensive care as UK extends overdraft
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is improving in intensive care after being admitted with Covid-19, with his culture minister Oliver Dowden saying he's stable and improving. The UK government extended its overdraft facility with the Bank of England to finance a vast increase in state spending to support the shuttered economy. The government is reviewing lockdown measures, with no final decision expected, and the number of coronavirus infections and hospital admissions in Britain is beginning to show signs of flattening.

site_title: Fast Retailing cuts outlook on stores caught in shutdown
summary: Fast Retailing, owner of Uniqlo, lowered its full-year operating profit outlook by 41% due to the COVID-19 pandemic, citing store shutdowns in Asia and Japan. The company now forecasts 145 billion yen in profit, down from 245 billion yen. Over 408 Uniqlo stores worldwide have been closed, with more expected to shut down in Japan due to a state of emergency declaration. The retailer's overseas revenue may decline by over 20% in the second half.

site_title: ECB's Lagarde says large-scale debt cancellation 'unthinkable'
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) president Christine Lagarde has dismissed the possibility of a large-scale debt cancellation during the coronavirus crisis, calling it "unthinkable" at this time. Lagarde emphasized the need to keep the economy going and focus on managing public finances efficiently. In contrast, former ECB chief Mario Draghi has advocated for corporate debt cancellations.

site_title: ABS gives cash incentive to small businesses that sign up for PayNow
summary: The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) is offering a S$500,000 cash incentive to encourage small businesses to sign up for PayNow, a digital payments service. The first 20,000 small businesses to sign up between April 9 and July 31 will receive S$25 each, with additional payments of S$25 offered to those receiving more than 10 payments. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is promoting digital payments to minimize the spread of Covid-19 and increase the use of e-payments among businesses and individuals.

site_title: STI recovers previous session's losses to close 1.3% higher on Thursday
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore closed 1.3% higher on Thursday, recovering from previous losses, to 2,571.32. Seven out of 30 counters finished in the red, while the market's sentiment will depend on US jobless claims figures and Opec's output cut deal. Benchmark indexes in Asia, including China and Hong Kong, posted gains, while the Nikkei 225 Index edged down. Jardine C&C and Singtel were the top performers, with DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank also outperforming the benchmark.

site_title: Navigating loan obligations amidst the Singapore Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act 2020
summary: The Singapore Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act 2020 provides moratorium protection for scheduled contracts entered into or renewed before March 25, 2020, shielding borrowers from legal action. Scheduled contracts include loans secured against commercial or industrial properties, or plant and machinery used for manufacturing or business purposes. The moratorium, which can last up to one year, prohibits lenders from commencing or continuing legal actions, but allows for defaults and interest charges. The Act also modifies insolvency regimes, extending time to satisfy statutory demands and increasing threshold amounts for insolvency actions.

site_title: CFM Holdings gets go-ahead to continue operations
summary: CFM Holdings has received verbal approval from authorities to continue operating during the circuit-breaker period in Singapore. Its Singapore subsidiaries have been exempted from the suspension of business activities until May 4. The company expects the Covid-19 pandemic to impair its earnings capacity and profitability, potentially affecting earnings per share and net asset value. Revenue from Singapore accounts for 22% of total revenue.

site_title: Millions of Indonesians get ready to travel from outbreak centre
summary: Millions of Indonesians are preparing to leave Jakarta, the epicenter of the country's coronavirus outbreak, as a commercial shutdown and social distancing guidelines take effect. An estimated 2.5 million migrant workers are expected to return to their hometowns and villages, following new guidelines. This mass migration is part of Indonesia's efforts to control the spread of the virus, amidst severe travel restrictions worldwide.

site_title: Volatility drives SDAV, ETF value higher on Singapore bourse in March
summary: Singapore's securities and derivatives market surged in March, driven by global market volatility amid the coronavirus pandemic. The Singapore bourse's securities daily average value (SDAV) rose 114% to S$2.2 billion, while total securities market turnover jumped 124% year-over-year to S$48.2 billion. Exchange-traded funds (ETF) value increased by over eight times to S$1.2 billion. Total equity and debt fundraising reached S$11 billion during the month, with new listings including United Hampshire US Reit and Memiontec Holdings.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei edges down as virus fears offset stimulus hope
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index fell 0.04% to 19,345.77, as concerns over the coronavirus pandemic outweighed hopes for a positive impact from a massive Japanese economic package. The broader Topix index also declined 0.60%. The market's reaction to the stimulus package was offset by worries over the pandemic's ongoing impact.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MAS delays digital bank licence results to H2 2020 to allow applicants to focus on the Covid-19 pandemic. DBS ties up with Haier to offer digital distributor financing to support businesses. Prudential issues US$1b in 10-year notes. The Association of Banks in Singapore gives S$500,000 to small businesses that sign up for PayNow. Citi Singapore provides S$1,200 cash to lower-paid staff and additional benefits. The STI recovers losses, closing 1.3% higher.

site_title: Singapore considers solar energy imports to cut emissions
summary: Singapore is considering importing solar electricity to diversify its energy supply and meet its goal of cutting net greenhouse emissions to net zero by mid-century. The Energy Market Authority aims to increase solar power to 2 gigawatts by 2030, which could meet 4% of the country's electricity demand. The country is also exploring regional power grids and other low-carbon alternatives, including hydrogen and carbon capture. Importing solar electricity could help overcome land constraints and balance higher electricity costs with energy security risks.

site_title: Dyna-Mac's independent auditor flags cash flow, going concern issues
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings' independent auditor has raised concerns over the company's ability to generate sufficient cash flows and continue as a going concern due to uncertain billing milestones and new contract awards. Despite a net loss of S$24 million in 2019, the company believes it can repay its debt obligations within the next 12 months due to secured new orders and available credit facilities. The auditor's report remains unqualified, but the company's management and directors are monitoring the situation closely.

site_title: Record 287 new Covid-19 cases in S'pore
summary: Singapore reported a record 287 new Covid-19 cases on April 9, with most linked to foreign worker dormitories. The total number of cases now stands at 1,910. The government is advising a multi-ministry task force on handling the situation in foreign worker dormitories, with the police and Singapore Armed Forces involved. This surge brings the global number of cases to over 1.5 million.

site_title: Pokka settles lawsuit with ex-CEO Alain Ong
summary: Pokka, a beverage giant, has settled a lawsuit with its former CEO Alain Ong, resolving damages totaling S$10 million. The company alleged Ong was part of a conspiracy causing huge losses. Ong countered with allegations against Pokka. The parties reached an amicable settlement, ending the dispute.

site_title: Japan firms to join the world of online shareholder meetings
summary: Japanese companies are set to join the global trend of holding online shareholder meetings to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Mizuho Financial Group Inc. has started offering virtual annual general meetings (AGMs) ahead of this season's gatherings in June. This move comes as Japanese law allows companies to conduct AGMs without shareholders present, and many individual shareholders are elderly and unable to attend in-person meetings. Amazon.com and Starbucks have also scrapped in-person gatherings due to the pandemic, and the government has encouraged companies to let shareholders participate remotely.

site_title: DBS ties up with China's Haier Group to offer digital distributor financing
summary: DBS Bank has partnered with China's Haier Group to offer digital distributor financing, allowing Haier's downstream distributors to access financing within 24 hours. This is DBS's first digital distributor financing linked to an anchor's digital supply chain platform and supports liquidity needs of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) during the Covid-19 pandemic. The facility, launched in April, has seen nearly 30 distributors onboarded, with the ability to shorten cash conversion cycles and optimize working capital. DBS is the only non-Chinese bank appointed for this digital financing facility.

site_title: Singapore-based investors value confidence, financial comfort: survey
summary: Singapore-based investors prioritize confidence, financial comfort, and risk tolerance when making investment decisions, with 47% classified as "comfortable" investors who tend to be more cautious and reasonable. In contrast, Hong Kong has the highest concentration of "enthusiastic" investors who are impulsive and speculative, while Taiwan's "conservative" investors have a lower risk tolerance. The study, conducted by Standard Chartered Bank, suggests that investors in Asia have a greater appetite for speculative investments, differing from European investors who exhibit low speculation.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rally in early trade
summary: European stock markets rallied in early trade on Thursday, driven by gains in Asia and a surge on Wall Street. The rally was attributed to optimism that the coronavirus outbreak is nearing its peak and governments will roll out more stimulus. Frankfurt jumped 2.4%, Paris gained 1.9%, and London advanced 2.2%. The rally was also influenced by a potential cut in oil output by Opec, which could support crude prices at two-decade lows.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on hopes pandemic is peaking
summary: Australian shares rose 3.5% on Thursday, their best week since December 2011, amid hopes the US coronavirus outbreak was peaking. The Reserve Bank of Australia said Australian banks were well-positioned to withstand the economic slump, while New York Governor Andrew Cuomo reported reduced hospitalizations. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,387.3, driven by positive comments about the strength of Australian lenders. This follows overnight gains on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: UK may need government to step in as housing market flatlines
summary: The UK housing market is expected to remain flat due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) reported the weakest level of near-term sales in over two decades, with buyer demand and price expectations plummeting in March. The RICS chief economist Simon Rubinsohn warned that a return to normalcy may take time, and the government may need to intervene with measures such as suspending stamp duty to encourage buyers. The lockdown has forced agents to close offices and halt property viewings, leading to a significant decline in demand.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda warns corporate funding strains worsening
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda warned of "extremely high" uncertainty over Japan's economic outlook due to worsening corporate funding strains. The coronavirus pandemic is affecting Japan's economy through declining exports, output, and private consumption. Kuroda stated that the situation is severe and urged caution.

site_title: Top UK tech startups can't access virus relief, Chancellor told
summary: UK tech startups, including Deliveroo and Citymapper, have warned Chancellor Rishi Sunak that they are at risk due to the government's coronavirus stimulus package. The startups, which are too big for small business relief but also don't qualify for corporate finance loans, are urging the government to change the package. The startups claim they fall through the cracks of the £330 billion rescue package, highlighting a potential gap in support for the sector.

site_title: Prudential to issue US$1b in 10-year notes
summary: Prudential plc, a British life insurance and financial services company, priced US$1 billion in 10-year senior unsecured notes at 3.125% per annum, with expected completion on April 14, 2020. The net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes. The notes will be listed on the New York Stock Exchange, following a filing with the US Securities and Exchange Commission. The joint book-running managers are Barclays, BofA Securities, Citigroup, Credit Agricole CIB, and MUFG.

site_title: Sungei Tengah Lodge declared 4th isolation area after rise in coronavirus cases
summary: Sungei Tengah Lodge in Singapore has been declared its fourth isolation area due to a rise in coronavirus cases, with 11 new cases reported on Wednesday, bringing the total to 29. Workers at the dormitory are required to quarantine in their rooms for 14 days. This follows the declaration of three other isolation areas: Toh Guan Dormitory, S11 Dormitory @ Punggol, and Westlite Toh Guan. The surge in cases involving foreign employee dormitories has led to active clusters at nine dormitories in Singapore.

site_title: Nearly 2,000 US coronavirus deaths for second day in a row: Johns Hopkins tally
summary: The US recorded nearly 2,000 novel coronavirus deaths for a second consecutive day, with a total of 14,695 fatalities, according to a Johns Hopkins University tally. This surpasses Spain's death toll of 14,555 but not Italy's 17,669.

site_title: MAS delays digital bank licence results to H2 2020
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has delayed the announcement of digital bank licence results to the second half of 2020 due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Initially set for June 2020, the extension will allow applicants to focus on managing the pandemic's impact on their businesses. The decision aims to ensure monetary and financial stability, and enable successful applicants to offer banking services, including retail deposits and wholesale banking for small and medium-sized enterprises. The delay affects 21 applicants, including Grab-Singtel and Razer, who were expecting to receive news in June.

site_title: Takeaway.com says orders had only temporarily decline in March
summary: Takeaway.com, Europe's largest online food ordering and delivery company, reported a temporary decline in orders in March due to restaurant closures amid the coronavirus pandemic. However, order volumes recovered strongly by the end of the month, with around 2,000 new restaurants signing up in the Netherlands. Average order volumes have since increased, but are expected to return to normal levels after the crisis.

site_title: WHO urges virus unity after Trump attack
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) urged global unity in fighting the coronavirus pandemic after US President Donald Trump attacked its handling of the outbreak. Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus defended the WHO's management, saying the US and China should work together to combat the disease. Trump had accused the WHO of being too close to Beijing and making faulty recommendations. French President Emmanuel Macron expressed support for the WHO, while UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres emphasized the need for international unity to stop the virus.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Thursday, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.88%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.37% and 0.53% respectively. The gains were driven by signs of a potential deal among top oil producers to reduce output and alleviate a supply glut.

site_title: Hong Kong tourism chief pins hopes on recovery starting by July
summary: Hong Kong's tourism chief, Dane Cheng, hopes the industry will start recovering by July, with a focus on boosting local spending, attracting mainland visitors, and promoting the city to new markets such as India and Vietnam. The sector, accounting for 4.5% of Hong Kong's GDP, has been severely impacted by the coronavirus pandemic, with tourist arrivals plummeting 96.4% in February. The government has announced relief measures worth HK$137.5 billion, and Cheng believes that when the border reopens and air services resume, the tourism sector can start its recovery plan.

site_title: Citi Singapore doles out S$1,200 cash to lower-paid staff as Covid-19 aid
summary: Citi Singapore is providing a one-off special compensation award of S$1,200 to around 1,600 lower-paid employees, valued at S$2 million, to ease the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The award is for staff with an annual base salary of S$70,000 or less, and will be credited into their accounts in April. Additionally, the bank is offering complimentary insurance coverage, preferred corporate rates for medical teleconsultation services, and extended carry-over leave.

site_title: Huationg Global's chairman, executive directors take 20% pay cut amid Covid-19
summary: Huationg Global, a civil engineering firm, has implemented a 20% pay cut for its chairman and two executive directors amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The pay cut took effect on April 1, 2020, and will be reviewed as necessary. The company has also suspended most construction works and implemented work-from-home arrangements to minimize disruptions. Despite this, the company expects "significant disruptions" to its business and operations, which may impact revenue and financial performance. The company will closely monitor the coronavirus situation and provide updates to shareholders.

site_title: Oil producers intend to cut 10-15 million barrels: Kuwait
summary: Oil producers, including Opec and non-Opec countries, plan to cut production by 10-15 million barrels per day to restore balance to the market and prevent further price drops. The move comes amid a price war between Russia and Saudi Arabia, compounded by the coronavirus pandemic. Kuwait's Oil Minister Khaled al-Fadhel said negotiations are ongoing to secure participation from major producers, including the US, Brazil, and Canada. The cuts aim to counter a sharp drop in demand, estimated at 25 million bpd, and are seen as a step to shore up prices.

images.alt_text: Top oil producers meeting later Thursday intend to cut production by between 10 and 15 million barrels per day, Kuwait's Oil Minister Khaled al-Fadhel reportedly said.

site_title: Asia: Equities mostly rise as dealers eye slowing infection rate
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday as investors became optimistic about the slowing rate of COVID-19 infections and potential easing of lockdown restrictions. Despite thousands of new deaths, the slowdown in infections provided a boost to equities. US lawmakers discussed a potential $500 billion stimulus package, while stocks on Wall Street reached fresh records. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Exposure to coronavirus disruption low for majority of APAC infrastructure companies
summary: Moody's Investors Service found that 68% of Asia-Pacific infrastructure companies have low exposure to coronavirus disruption, while 23% have moderate exposure and 9% have high exposure. Highly exposed sectors include regional airports and toll roads in China, which face uncertain recovery and revenue strain. In contrast, 68% of issuers in essential goods and services, project finance, and public-private partnership structures have low exposure and are not completely immune to disruption. A gradual recovery is expected in the second half of 2020, but at a lower volume than before the outbreak.

site_title: NBA legend Michael Jordan wins long-running China trademark dispute
summary: China's Supreme Court has ruled in favor of basketball legend Michael Jordan, ending an eight-year trademark dispute with a Chinese sportswear firm. The court prohibited Fujian-based Qiaodan Sports from using the Chinese translation of Jordan's name, Qiao Dan. This ruling upholds intellectual property rights and marks a significant victory for Jordan. The decision comes after China pledged to improve protections of intellectual property as part of a phase one deal with the US in January.

site_title: UBS, Credit Suisse to delay half of dividend payments amid virus
summary: Switzerland's two largest banks, Credit Suisse and UBS, have proposed delaying half of their dividend payments due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. Credit Suisse plans to pay half of its 2019 dividend this year and the rest in the fall. UBS has also proposed paying its 2019 dividend in two instalments. The move comes as Switzerland's financial regulator Finma pressures banks to reconsider their dividend proposals, citing concerns about capital relief. The decision aims to ensure banks continue lending to businesses and households affected by the pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.32 points or 0.46% to 1,367.71 on Thursday, with a high trading volume of 181.28 million lots worth RM49.80 million. The market opened higher, with 320 gainers outpacing 32 losers.

site_title: Catering group Sodexo says H2 sales may plunge 26% on coronavirus, income to take big hit
summary: French catering and food services group Sodexo reported a potential 26% decline in second-half revenue due to coronavirus measures, which could hit underlying operating income by up to 700 million euros. The group's revenue for the six months to February was 11.7 billion euros, up 3.2% from the previous year. CEO Denis Machuel said the company is using government measures to protect employment and reduce costs, with a 30 million euro support program for employees facing lay-offs.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened slightly lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.07% and the Topix index down 0.18%. The decline was attributed to concerns over the impact of the virus pandemic, despite expectations for a massive Japanese economic package.

site_title: Singapore shares advance at Thursday's open; STI up 1.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.3% to 2,572.42 on Thursday, tracking a Wall Street rally amid optimism over slowing US coronavirus infections. Gainers outnumbered losers 119 to 13, with ESR-Reit and Genting Singapore among the top gainers. Banking stocks were initially down, but the three local banks pledged no retrenchments amid the outbreak. The rally follows a US market surge, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 3.4% and the S&P 500 reaching a fresh record.

site_title: Rich Asians face billions in losses on popular structured notes
summary: Wealthy Rich Asians face billions in losses on structured notes, a popular investment product during rock-bottom interest rates. The notes, tied to assets like stocks, offered regular coupons but carried a risk of steep losses during market declines. An estimated US$80 billion of Asian private banking assets is tied to such notes, with losses estimated in the billions. Investors who held leveraged positions have been forced into selling early, while those who remain invested hope for a market rebound. New rules and improved disclosure have tightened the regulatory environment, but the products remain popular due to their high yields.

site_title: British bank bosses take pay cuts amid coronavirus fallout
summary: British bank executives from HSBC, Standard Chartered, and NatWest have taken salary cuts amid the coronavirus crisis, showing solidarity with customers struggling financially. HSBC's CEO and CFO will donate 25% of their salary to charity, while the bank has paused most planned redundancies. Standard Chartered's CEO and CFO have also waived their bonuses, with the CEO donating £825,000. NatWest's CEO and chairman have taken a 25% salary cut, with the bank continuing to press ahead with investment bank redundancies.

site_title: France to extend virus lockdown, Macron will address nation: presidency
summary: France is extending its lockdown beyond April 15 in an effort to slow the spread of the coronavirus. President Emmanuel Macron will address the nation next week to present the new decisions. The lockdown extension aims to further slow the virus's spread, although no specific date has been set. Macron's address is expected to provide more details on the new measures.

site_title: New US jobless data to add to skyrocketing unemployment
summary: The US is expected to release new weekly jobless benefit claim data on Thursday, likely showing another jump in job losses amid the coronavirus pandemic. Analysts predict 5-6 million new claims, with some expecting a total of 10 million job losses. The data is expected to further pressure lawmakers to take action, amid a recession forecasted to be deep. The US economy has already shed 701,000 jobs and the unemployment rate has risen by 4.4%, with a monthly jobs report expected to show nearly 13 million jobs lost and a 15% unemployment rate.

site_title: Disney+ streaming service hits 50 million users
summary: Disney+ has reached 50 million paid subscribers just five months after its US launch, with 8 million in India and 42 million in Western Europe. The service, which offers Disney, Pixar, Marvel, and National Geographic content, aims to compete with Netflix, Apple, and Amazon. Disney+ is available in 11 countries, including Austria, Britain, France, and Spain, with a subscription rate of $10.80 per month. The service's success is attributed to the coronavirus pandemic, which has kept millions of people at home and providing a captive audience.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on oil, hopes of pandemic peaking in US
