summary: Australian shares rose 2.2% on Thursday, driven by gains on Wall Street and a jump in crude oil prices, lifting energy stocks 3.8%. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose over 4% for the week, with healthcare stocks also gaining 3.3%. Hopes that the US pandemic is peaking in the US bolstered sentiment, with new hospitalizations falling in New York. Energy stocks were boosted by US crude futures rising nearly 6% ahead of a production cut meeting.

site_title: Virus-stricken Australian liner to dock in Montevideo
summary: The Australian cruise ship Greg Mortimer, carrying over 200 passengers, will dock in Montevideo, Uruguay, on Friday after being anchored offshore due to the COVID-19 outbreak. Over 128 passengers have tested positive, and 8 have been hospitalized. A medical plane will evacuate Australian and New Zealand passengers, with those who test negative to be repatriated via Sao Paulo, Brazil. Passengers will be flown home and required to stay in isolation for two weeks upon arrival in Melbourne.

site_title: Google offers free Stadia game access during pandemic
summary: Google is offering free access to its Stadia online gaming service for two months to provide an escape for those staying home due to the coronavirus pandemic. The service, launched last year, allows users to access console-quality games on various devices. Stadia vice-president Phil Harrison said video games can be a way to socialize with friends and family while staying at home. The free access is available in 14 countries and includes nine playable games, with the option to buy other titles.

site_title: Bank of Korea keeps rates unchanged, awaits effects of last easing
summary: The Bank of Korea maintained its interest rate at record lows of 0.75% on Thursday, as expected, following a 50 basis point cut in March. The decision comes amid South Korea's struggling economy, which is heading for a contraction in the first half of the year due to the coronavirus pandemic. Despite the Bank's efforts to ease policies, economists predict a further rate cut in the current quarter, citing the ongoing global spread of the disease and weakness in overseas demand for Korean goods.

site_title: Air Canada to rehire 16,500 workers laid off due to pandemic
summary: Air Canada will rehire 16,500 employees who were laid off due to the COVID-19 pandemic under a government relief package. The airline will bring back workers who were furloughed in March after business dropped by 90% due to travel restrictions. The Canadian government's emergency wage subsidy plan, which is retroactive to March 15, will pay 75% of hard-hit companies' payrolls through June 6. The move is part of a broader effort to support businesses and workers affected by the pandemic.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, OCBC, UOB, Keppel, SGReit, Huationg, AMTD International
summary: Singapore's DBS, OCBC, and UOB banks pledged no retrenchments amid the coronavirus outbreak. DBS maintained its 1.4% fixed deposit rate despite peers cutting theirs. Keppel Corp's property arm, Keppel Land, may redevelop its Hoe Chiang Road office asset into a full-commercial project. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Sheltering consumers shut out of Snapchat for hours
summary: Snapchat's application went offline for several hours on April 8, 2020, due to an unspecified cause, leaving its users unable to access the service. The outage occurred as people worldwide relied on social media for information and entertainment during the coronavirus pandemic. Snapchat later restored the service and apologized for the inconvenience. The incident occurred just a week after the company reported a surge in engagement with its app, with real-time communication up 50% in March.

site_title: Trump says would like to reopen US economy with a 'big bang'
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed a desire to reopen the US economy with a "big bang" once the death toll from the coronavirus is on the decline. His chief economic adviser, Larry Kudlow, suggested this could happen in four to eight weeks. However, medical advisers caution against early reopening due to concerns of a renewed outbreak. Trump's administration has seen a decline in death toll projections, with the number of Americans dying from the virus falling short of initial estimates of 100,000 to 240,000.

site_title: Major Indian cities make mask-wearing compulsory amid virus fears
summary: India's major cities, including New Delhi and Mumbai, have made mask-wearing compulsory amid a nationwide lockdown to combat the spread of COVID-19. Residents in these cities, which have a combined population of over 40 million, are required to cover their faces in public spaces. The move comes as India's official number of cases rises above 5,200, including 149 deaths. Authorities have also released instructions on how to make homemade reusable face covers, and numerous neighborhoods and hotspots are set to be sealed off.

site_title: Bank of Japan to project economic contraction as pandemic damage deepens: sources
summary: The Bank of Japan is expected to project a full-year economic contraction for the first time since 2014 due to the coronavirus pandemic's damage. The BOJ will forecast a severe downturn this quarter, but predicts a gradual rebound towards the end of the year. This move comes as the pandemic threatens to push Japan's economy into recession, highlighting the challenges faced by the country's economy.

site_title: Million-dollar HDB resale flats facing downtrend
summary: A record S$1.232 million resale price was achieved in March for a 5-room HDB flat in The Pinnacle@Duxton, but data shows a downtrend in million-dollar HDB resale transactions as more supply comes on the market. According to Christine Sun, head of research & consultancy, the number of million-dollar flat transactions has dipped from 72 units in 2018 to 64 units in 2019. Increased housing supply and competition are attributed to the lower number of million-dollar transactions, with many alternatives available in the similar price range.

site_title: Cats can catch coronavirus, study finds, prompting WHO investigation
summary: A study published in the journal Science has found that cats can become infected with the new coronavirus, SARS-CoV-2, while dogs appear not to be vulnerable. Ferrets can also become infected, but dogs, chickens, pigs, and ducks are not likely to catch the virus. The World Health Organization (WHO) has announced an investigation into the transmission of the virus between humans and pets, citing the potential for cats and ferrets to be used to test experimental vaccines.

site_title: Oil futures rise on hopes of production cuts
summary: Oil futures rose on Wednesday, driven by hopes that Opec and its allies will agree to production cuts. Brent crude surged 3% to $32.84 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate rose 6.2% to $25.09 a barrel. The expected deal comes after a failed meeting in March and amid a collapse in demand due to the coronavirus pandemic. Russia is reportedly ready to cut its oil output by 1.6 million barrels per day, and Algerian Energy Minister Mohamed Arkab described the upcoming meeting as "fruitful."

site_title: MAS rolls out S$125m package for financial institutions and fintechs
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a S$125 million support package for financial institutions and fintech firms to aid them through the current economic slump. The package includes a Training Allowance Grant (TAG) to provide allowances for courses and increased course fee subsidies for Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents. Additionally, MAS will double salary support to S$2,000 a month for financial institutions to hire fresh graduates or workers from other sectors, and set up a Digital Acceleration Grant to support digitalisation initiatives in smaller financial institutions and fintechs.

site_title: World's biggest oil producers at odds ahead of talks on major cuts
summary: Top oil producers Saudi Arabia, Russia, and the US remain at odds over cutting global crude prices, with the US refusing to cooperate without Saudi Arabia and Russia making concessions. Russia is ready to cut its oil output by 1.6 million barrels per day, but no deal has been reached yet. The US has threatened Saudi Arabia with legislation that could pull economic and military support if it doesn't stabilize oil prices. The Opec+ meeting, scheduled for Thursday, may not yield a lasting agreement, and oil prices remain at historic lows.

site_title: US: Dow ends 3.4% higher after latest US coronavirus updates
summary: US stocks ended the day 3.4% higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 780 points to 23,433.57, as New York reported a new record 779 coronavirus fatalities but a decreasing hospitalization rate. The market is buoyed by hopes that the US economy may recover before May, but uncertainty over social distancing measures and potential prolonged lockdowns weighs on growth outlook.

site_title: Asian tycoons hunt for cheap assets after market rout
summary: Asian tycoons are seeking to acquire assets at discounted prices due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on markets. Major stock indices in the US, Europe, and Asia-Pacific plummeted 20% in the first quarter, making retail chains, hotels, and property developers attractive targets. Cash-rich conglomerates like Victor Li's CK group are well-positioned to invest in these sectors, while governments are also seeking to deter foreign takeovers of local firms. This shift could lead to a surge in acquisitions as Asian tycoons capitalize on bargain prices.

site_title: US approves Google request to use segment of US-Asia undersea cable
summary: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has approved Google's request to use a segment of the Pacific Light Cable Network System, a US-Asia undersea telecommunications cable, after the company warned it would face higher prices to carry traffic by other means. Google will operate the segment for the next six months to meet its internal demand for capacity between the US and Taiwan. The Justice Department had expressed concerns about the potential national security and law enforcement risks of granting direct access to Hong Kong, a special administrative region of China.

site_title: Hong Kong unveils unprecedented HK$137b coronavirus relief package
summary: Hong Kong has unveiled a HK$137.5 billion coronavirus relief package to support businesses and individuals affected by the pandemic. The package includes a 10% pay cut for the leader, Carrie Lam, and a 50% government subsidy for workers' salaries for six months, capped at HK$9,000. The measures aim to cushion the impact of the pandemic globally.

site_title: DBS keeps its FD rates attractive as peers cut theirs
summary: DBS Bank has maintained its fixed deposit (FD) rate at 1.4% per annum for placements of S$20,000 for 12 months, despite peers cutting their rates by as much as 1.02 percentage points. This decision is attributed to prevailing macroeconomic uncertainty and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. DBS' larger market share of low-cost current account and savings account (CASA) deposits also contributes to its competitive rate. The bank has adjusted its rates only for principal sums above S$100,000 and for tenors longer than 12 months.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars up sharply for week, markets absorb bond flood
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars saw significant gains for the week, with the Aussie rising 3.8% to US$0.6223 and the kiwi increasing 2.4% to US$0.6002. This surge was driven by market expectations that the COVID-19 pandemic may soon be on the horizon, leading to potential economic lockdowns and a boost in commodity prices. Despite a downgrade of Australia's economic outlook, the Australian government's bond sales remained strong, and the Reserve Bank of Australia kept yields in line with its target.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars were holding hefty gains for the week on Thursday as markets wagered a peak for the Covid-19 pandemic could be on the horizon, even as the death toll mounted across the globe.

site_title: Australian police seize black box in raid on virus-hit cruise ship
summary: Australian police raided the Ruby Princess cruise ship, seizing its black box, as part of a criminal investigation into the COVID-19 outbreak after thousands of passengers disembarked in Sydney and 15 later died. The seizure came after the ship was allowed to dock despite numerous passengers testing positive for the virus. NSW Police Commissioner Mick Fuller stated that the black box, similar to those found in planes, was part of the evidence gathered. The investigation is ongoing.

site_title: US pharmacies authorised to test for coronavirus
summary: The US has authorised pharmacies to carry out tests for the coronavirus, including antibody tests for those who have recovered from the illness. Health Secretary Alex Azar announced the move to ramp up testing efforts, allowing pharmacists to play a bigger role in the Covid-19 response. This expansion aims to increase testing capacity and support the country's efforts to combat the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Health secretary Alex Azar, announced that all tests approved by regulators could be carried out by pharmacies as the country seeks to ramp up its testing efforts.

site_title: Coronavirus uncertainty causes 'major downside risks': Federal Reserve minutes
summary: The Federal Reserve warned that the coronavirus pandemic's uncertainty poses "major downside risks" to the US economy, citing nearly 10 million unemployment benefits filed in the final two weeks of March. Despite the severity of the crisis, officials believe the economy and banking system are on solid footing, and a "forceful" response is needed to support businesses and low-income households. The Fed has taken measures to pump liquidity into the financial system, and growth is expected to resume based on the effectiveness of containment measures and policy responses.

site_title: Local farms can draw on S$30m grant to lift eggs, vegetables and fish output
summary: A S$30-million grant, the 30x30 Express, has been launched to support local farms in increasing egg, leafy vegetable, and fish production. The goal is to produce 30% of Singapore's nutritional needs by 2030. The grant will help farms defray upfront costs, including technology systems, to boost productivity and production capacity within 6-24 months. This is part of the government's efforts to strengthen food security and supply chain resilience, following the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: IMF should promote global view on tackling crisis
summary: The International Monetary Fund's (IMFC) International Monetary and Financial Committee (IMFC) is discussing the global economic outlook and financial stability amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Key global central banks and fiscal authorities have implemented massive crisis responses, but emerging markets and low-income countries face significant fiscal resource constraints. The IMF's World Economic Outlook (WEO) discussion aims to provide insights into the nature of the recovery, which is expected to be deep but short-lived. However, the recovery path is uncertain, with various scenarios possible, including a "V"-, "U"-, or "L"-shaped recovery, and potential long-term scarring of the economy.

site_title: Recognising and appreciating senior volunteerism
summary: A Singapore-based non-profit organisation, RSVP Singapore, is promoting senior volunteerism to tap into the untapped resources of the country's ageing population. Partnering with Standard Chartered Bank since 2019, the organisation aims to empower seniors as active volunteers serving the community. Examples of senior volunteers include Martha Ee, who visits elderly clients, and Evelyn Tan, who volunteers at various organisations, including the Indian Heritage Centre and Willing Hearts. Kumar Udaya, a 65-year-old retired engineer, leads an active lifestyle by volunteering at the Institute of Mental Health's Mentally Disadvantaged Outreach Programme. The organisation's efforts aim to dispel the myth that volunteering is only for the young and promote a positive mindset among seniors.

site_title: 10 businesses warned for operating even though they were non-essential
summary: Singapore authorities issued verbal warnings to 10 businesses for operating despite being non-essential during the month-long "circuit breaker" measures. The businesses, including TCM retail shops, wellness centers, and mobile phone retailers, were ordered to cease operations. Failure to comply may result in fines up to S$20,000 or imprisonment of up to 12 months. Enforcement efforts will continue to curb the spread of Covid-19, with a focus on safe distancing measures.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch up, all eyes on euro zone fiscal package
summary: European stock markets rose for a third consecutive day, driven by a rally on Wall Street and hopes that the COVID-19 outbreak is nearing its peak in the US. The Stoxx 600 index gained 0.02%, while defensive real estate stocks rose 1.4% and travel and leisure stocks surged 3.3%. However, euro zone finance ministers remain divided on an economic rescue package, with talks suspended until Thursday. Analysts warn that a lack of coordination could slow Europe's response to the pandemic.

site_title: Wuhan lockdown lifted; new imported cases in Heilongjiang
summary: China lifted its lockdown in Wuhan, a city of 11 million, after over two months, amid concerns about a potential second wave of infections. Meanwhile, Heilongjiang reported new imported cases of the new coronavirus. The Wuhan lockdown, which began on January 23, was a drastic measure to manage the virus, and its lifting marks a significant step in China's efforts to reopen.

site_title: Cell towers, warehouses look like safe plays in US real estate
summary: US fund managers are increasing stakes in cell towers and warehouses, seen as benefiting from an eventual economic recovery. Despite the lockdown's impact on the US economy, real estate investment trust (Reit) values have been hit hard. These sectors are considered defensive, but the fund managers believe they will perform well once the economy recovers. This shift in investment strategy is a cautious move towards diversifying portfolios amidst the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore's digital networks to be beefed up in next two weeks
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has announced initiatives to beef up digital networks capacity and access in the next two weeks. This move aims to support the growing number of Singaporeans working and learning from home due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The regulator and telecom operators will work together to enhance internet connectivity and access, ensuring sufficient bandwidth for the country's digital needs.

site_title: STI snaps 2-session rally to fall 1.25% as Covid-19 fears persist
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended a two-session rally 1.25% lower to 2,539.44 on Wednesday, with 22 of its 30 counters finishing in the red. Investors were cautious over global Covid-19 infections and potential oil output cuts. China's lifting of a Wuhan lockdown was seen as a positive, but the road to recovery is expected to be long-drawn. Genting Singapore remained the most actively traded stock, and AMTD International debuted on the Singapore Exchange with a 14.7% gain.

site_title: US$100b Reit rout pulverises family fortunes across Asia
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted the real estate investment trust (Reit) market in Asia, with the value of Reits plummeting by over $100 billion. The pandemic has disrupted cash flows, putting pressure on rental income, and affecting wealthy families' fortunes, including the Tangs, who have lost over $300 million in Reit investments. Reits, considered a safe haven, have posted an average decline of 25% this year, with the Tangs' SingHaiyi Group being one of the hardest hit.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Should identifying the immune population be on the cards in the battle against Covid-19?
summary: A Money FM podcast discusses whether identifying the immune population should be a strategy in the battle against COVID-19. Lily Fang, an INSEAD professor, shares her insights on the topic. Fang suggests that identifying the immune population could help policymakers tailor interventions to maximize their effectiveness. However, she also notes that the concept is still in its infancy and requires further research. The discussion highlights the complexity of understanding immunity in the context of COVID-19.

site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn to start making ventilators in US
summary: Foxconn, a major Apple supplier, will start manufacturing ventilators in the US at its Wisconsin plant. The partnership with Medtronic aims to address the global ventilator shortage, particularly for severe COVID-19 cases. Production is expected to begin within four to six weeks, with the company's subsidiary Sharp Corp also producing face masks in Japan. This collaboration follows Foxconn's efforts to aid in the pandemic, including making face masks in China since February.

site_title: A look at how Covid-19 has changed our lives ...
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted the food and dining industry, forcing restaurants to switch to takeaway or home delivery menus. Eateries, including Michelin-starred establishments, have been repurposing their creations into elegant takeaway boxes, offering diners a fine dining experience at home. Restaurant owner Karen Cheng shares her rollercoaster ride since the outbreak, highlighting the difficulties faced by the industry. Despite the challenges, Cheng remains passionate about her work, and the trend of upscale takeaway food continues to grow, providing an alternative to dining out during the pandemic.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SP Corporation will hold its annual general meeting via live webcast on April 16, exempted from the suspension of non-essential workplace activities. Broadway Industrial Group received a fresh query from the Singapore Exchange over trading activity, its third in nine months. Sunningdale Tech received approval to continue its Singapore operations during the circuit-breaker period, citing its essential services in the healthcare industry.

site_title: Citi replaces Credit Suisse on WeDoctor IPO top role
summary: Citi has replaced Credit Suisse as the top role on WeDoctor's Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO), working alongside JPMorgan Chase & Co and CMB International Securities. WeDoctor, backed by Tencent Holdings, aims to raise between $500 million and $1 billion. The IPO is expected to happen before the end of the year, with shares of Ping An Healthcare, a similar healthcare startup, surging 52% in Hong Kong this year. This move follows a lawsuit against Credit Suisse involving Luckin Coffee's US share sale.

site_title: Takeaway from dabao group: food delivery apps must step up for hawkers
summary: A Facebook group, "Hawkers United - Dabao 2020," has been established to support Singaporean hawkers struggling to survive during the Covid-19 pandemic. With dining-in banned, many hawkers are losing significant sales, while those on food delivery apps are facing steep commissions of 30-40%. The group aims to connect hawkers with customers and promote their takeaway services. Some startups, like WhyQ, are developing alternative models that don't charge hawkers commissions, offering a potential solution to the crisis. The group's founder, Melvin Chew, hopes that a more sustainable digital solution will be found to support hawkers in the long term.

site_title: EU fails to agree on mitigation as divisions persist
summary: European Union finance ministers failed to agree on a mitigation strategy for the economic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, prolonging a paralysis that casts doubt on the bloc's ability to recover. The divisions between southern and northern countries over sharing costs of the looming recession persisted, despite an emergency teleconference lasting over 16 hours. A new call is scheduled, but it's unclear what could push countries to compromise, as the European Central Bank's massive intervention has reduced market pressure. The EU's inability to agree on a strategy raises concerns about its ability to weather the crisis.

site_title: Covid-19: Record 142 new cases; man, 32, dies
summary: Singapore reported a record 142 new Covid-19 cases, including a 32-year-old Indian national who died after testing positive, according to the Ministry of Health. The total number of cases in Singapore is now 1,623. All returning travelers must now serve a 14-day stay-home notice at dedicated facilities, with 406 cases fully recovered and 542 still isolated. The ministry has also extended the rule to all Singaporeans, permanent residents, and long-term pass holders, regardless of their country of origin.

site_title: Sunningdale Tech to continue Singapore operations
summary: Sunningdale Tech has obtained approval to continue its Singapore operations during the circuit-breaker period, citing its essential services in the global healthcare industry. The company's manufacturing facilities in Singapore are considered critical to healthcare systems worldwide. Operations in China, Malaysia, and Mexico are also continuing with reduced workforce levels. Shares closed flat at 87.5 Singapore cents on the news.

site_title: Women fight for a place at the table as sushi chefs in Japan
summary: In Japan, women are challenging traditional stereotypes that claim they are unsuitable for sushi chefs due to physical and hormonal limitations. Despite these claims, a growing number of women are training and working as sushi chefs in top-ranked restaurants, with Mizuho Iwai, a 33-year-old apprentice, breaking the mold at the Onodera restaurant in Tokyo. Women make up less than 10% of the industry, with some estimating resistance to female chefs remains strong, particularly among older customers.

site_title: Zoom sued for fraud over privacy, security flaws
summary: Zoom Video Communications Inc is being sued for alleged fraud over privacy and security flaws in its video-conferencing app. A shareholder claims the company concealed the truth about software encryption vulnerabilities, including hacking risks and unauthorized data disclosure to third parties. The lawsuit comes as governments worldwide, including Taiwan, have banned or restricted Zoom usage due to security concerns. Zoom CEO Eric Yuan has apologized for the lapses, acknowledging the company had fallen short of expectations on privacy and security, and is working to add end-to-end encryption.

site_title: Is KepLand ditching residences in Hoe Chiang Rd project?
summary: Keppel Land may be redeveloping its office asset in Hoe Chiang Road, dropping the residential component. The decision could be due to potential development charges and competition for home buyers. Despite not taking advantage of the CBD Incentive Scheme, Keppel Land can still develop a predominantly office project, utilizing the site's existing 58,600 sq m GFA. This move could benefit Keppel Reit, allowing it to participate in the project's development with a lower entry cost and higher yield.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit proposes rent deferrals, monthly payments for tenants
summary: Cromwell E-Reit, a Singapore-based European real estate investment trust, proposes offering rent deferrals and monthly payments to tenants amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The trust has agreed to rent rebates for one tenant, a cinema operator in Italy, and is considering rent-free leases for tenants in exceptional cases. The trust's manager believes the pandemic has had a minimal impact on its income from properties, and occupancy rates remain high at 93.2%. The trust plans to hold its annual general meeting in June and has over 200 million euros in cash reserves to tide it through the crisis.

site_title: SGX Regco suspends new entries to watch list; expedites fund raising
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has suspended new entries to its financial watch-list and expedited fund-raising efforts by mainboard issuers amid the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on the market. The measures aim to ease financial strain on companies, which have seen significant losses in revenue and profitability. Companies on the watch-list will have their reviews suspended, while mainboard issuers can now seek a general mandate for a pro-rata share issue of up to 100% of their share capital.

site_title: UK PM Johnson stable after second night in intensive care
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson spent a second night in intensive care for Covid-19 complications, but remains stable after receiving oxygen support. His condition is improving, and Deputy PM Dominic Raab said Johnson would return to leadership soon. The UK is navigating the deadliest phase of the outbreak and considering lockdown lift options.

site_title: Dollar firms on rising novel coronavirus crisis worries
summary: The US dollar rose against the euro and other currencies as investors became increasingly concerned about the economic impact of the novel coronavirus crisis. The euro fell 0.2% to $1.0875 due to disagreements among European Union finance ministers over virus support measures. Despite a limited impact on the dollar's value, analysts warn that the crisis could lead to a weaker dollar in the long term if stimulus measures are not addressed by the end of the year.

site_title: MAS & SGX: Current rules for short-selling activities are already transparent
summary: SGX and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) already require transparency for short-selling activities. MAS and SGX publish information on short-sell trades and outstanding short positions, respectively, with no exemption for small orders. The "Percentage Threshold Exemption" allows for reporting of aggregate short positions above 0.2% of total issued shares or S$2 million in value, but not for smaller positions. Weekly aggregated short position reports are published by MAS, available on their website.

site_title: All countries fighting same enemy and need to cooperate closely: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for global cooperation in combating the Covid-19 pandemic, stating that despite differing circumstances, countries are fighting a common enemy. He introduced enhanced safe distancing measures, including a circuit breaker, to control the outbreak. Lee stressed the importance of learning from one another's experiences and working together to bring the pandemic under control, citing the World Health Organization's role in mobilizing a global response.

site_title: Driving critical mass in green financing within Singapore
summary: Singapore can reach critical mass in green financing by adopting a green taxonomy, standardizing environmental objectives and criteria across the ecosystem. Banks should factor green into their risk management frameworks, and the country's preeminent institutions should lead the way in green financing. To increase accessibility, green finance solutions should be made more widely available to smaller corporate players and retail investors. With Singapore's existing depth of liquidity and incentives, it can play a significant role in driving global green finance adoption, ultimately contributing to the US$6-8 trillion needed annually to combat climate change.

site_title: China's central bank to step up easing: sources
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), plans to increase monetary policy easing to support the economy amid the novel coronavirus pandemic. The PBOC will boost credit and lower funding costs for small firms, accommodate increased fiscal spending, and use a mix of liquidity and price-based tools to support the economy. Unlike the US Federal Reserve, the PBOC will not follow steep rate cuts or quantitative easing moves, instead opting for a more measured approach to avoid fueling property speculation and social problems.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher, Dow and Nasdaq both up 1.1%
summary: US stocks rose early Wednesday, with the Dow and Nasdaq both up 1.1%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached 22,903.26, while the S&P 500 gained 1.0% to 2,686.75 and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 1.2% to 7,983.68. Market sentiment was influenced by the latest coronavirus figures and prospects for economic support measures.

site_title: Collapse of Eagle Hospitality Trust warrants probe, regulatory reviews
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) has collapsed, losing over 80% of its market value since its initial public offering in May 2020. The trust has not distributed a single cent to investors, and trading in its units has been suspended. The company is trying to repay a $341 million loan, nearly three times its market value. An investigation into the collapse is warranted, focusing on the Yuans' large stake in EHT during the IPO, as well as the due diligence work on the master lessee, Urban Commons (UC). The regulators and UC's ability to meet its obligations as master lessee also need scrutiny.

site_title: Khazanah sceptical about GSV's US$2.5b offer for MAS
summary: Malaysia's Khazanah sovereign wealth fund is skeptical about a US$2.5 billion proposal by Golden Skies Ventures (GSV) to acquire Malaysia Airlines, citing concerns about GSV's financial backing amid the coronavirus pandemic. GSV claims to have secured funding from a European bank and a Japanese private equity firm, but Khazanah is cautious about the proposal's structure, which relies heavily on borrowings. The fund is evaluating proposals from various parties, emphasizing financial sustainability and risk of failure. A decision on the proposal is pending, with Morgan Stanley managing the airline's search for a strategic partner.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Oyo furloughs thousands of workers
summary: Oyo Hotels & Homes, a budget lodging service backed by SoftBank Group Corp, has furloughed thousands of employees globally due to the coronavirus pandemic. The company, which has over $1 billion in cash, is exploring options to remain viable over the next 36 months. Founder Ritesh Agarwal has assured employees that no job cuts will be made despite significant economic pressures. This move is part of a series of actions, including management pay cuts and a freeze on marketing spending, aimed at helping the company survive the pandemic.

site_title: Indonesia car sales to halve due to coronavirus pandemic, says ministry
summary: Indonesia's car sales are expected to halve this year due to the coronavirus pandemic, with domestic sales down 2.4% and exports down 21.5% in January and February. The country's automotive sector contributes 4% to GDP, and the industry ministry has requested tax breaks to help automakers weather the impact. Indonesia has reported 2,738 COVID-19 cases and 221 deaths, and the global pandemic has disrupted supply chains and demand across various sectors, including autos. The industry ministry says the auto sector's disruption will affect the national economy.

site_title: Bernie Sanders suspends 2020 presidential campaign
summary: US Senator Bernie Sanders has suspended his 2020 presidential campaign, clearing the way for Joe Biden to become the Democratic nominee. Sanders announced the suspension after a staff conference call, stating the path to victory was "virtually impossible." The decision comes as the US grapples with the coronavirus outbreak, which shifted public focus away from the campaign. Sanders' suspension clears the way for Biden to challenge Republican incumbent Donald Trump in November's presidential election.

site_title: Hong Kong-based BDx acquires Singapore data centre
summary: Hong Kong-based BDx has acquired a data centre in Singapore, its first outside of the greater China area. The facility, previously owned by Telstra, houses 1,800 racks with a 7.3-megawatt power capacity. BDx plans to upgrade the centre to increase power usage effectiveness and drive higher efficiency, providing critical connectivity into the South-east Asian market. This acquisition marks the platform's seventh data centre across Hong Kong, mainland China, and Singapore, according to Chief Operating Officer David Kim.

site_title: DBS, OCBC and UOB pledge no job cuts due to Covid-19
summary: Singapore's DBS, OCBC, and UOB banks have pledged no job cuts due to the Covid-19 pandemic, citing strong capital and liquidity positions and a focus on supporting employees, customers, and the community. CEO Piyush Gupta of DBS, CEO Samuel Tsien of OCBC, and CEO Wee Ee Cheong of UOB stated their commitment to retaining jobs, with UOB also implementing flexible work arrangements and providing additional leave. The banks join global financial institutions in vowing to keep jobs despite the economic downturn.

site_title: UOB CEO records S$10.75m total salary for 2019, up 1.8%
summary: UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong recorded a 1.8% increase in 2019 total salary to S$10.75 million, with base salary unchanged at S$1.2 million. The bank has also deferred its annual general meeting and adoption of a revised directors' fee structure due to the COVID-19 outbreak. Chairman Wong Kan Seng was paid S$907,000, while DBS chairman Peter Seah received S$1.97 million. Wee expressed confidence in the bank's ability to navigate the challenging environment, stating "storms will pass. We will stay the course."

site_title: Prudent nudges may encourage charitable giving
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a one-off cash payment of S$600 to all adult Singaporeans amid the Covid-19 crisis. The government also encouraged charitable giving, citing the importance of private donations to voluntary welfare organisations. This move may utilize "nudging" techniques, a form of choice architecture, to influence public behavior and increase charitable giving. The government's goal is to support the socio-economic fallout from Covid-19 while relying on public charitable efforts to supplement its own relief measures.

site_title: EU ministers fail to agree on coronavirus economic rescue
summary: European Union finance ministers failed to agree on a coronavirus economic rescue package worth half a trillion euros, with a persistent standoff between financially ailing southern European states and fiscally conservative northern states blocking progress. The European Central Bank warned that the bloc may need up to 1.5 trillion euros in fiscal measures to tackle the economic free-fall caused by the Covid-19 epidemic. A deal on the package is expected when ministers meet again on Thursday, but the issue of jointly issuing debt remains a major point of contention.

site_title: Light at the end of a long tunnel?
summary: The ongoing coronavirus pandemic has emerged as the dominant threat to the global economic landscape, with economists predicting a significant but transitory economic impact. Historical analysis of US inflation-adjusted GDP data suggests a typical average decline of 4-6% in GDP over the first two quarters of a recession, with a maximum drag of nearly 20%. A recession is likely to last more than two quarters, possibly a year, and a recovery of 9% is expected, resulting in a 10-point shortfall in growth.

site_title: HG Metal gets approval to continue on-site operations
summary: HG Metal's wholly-owned subsidiary HG Construction Steel has received approval from the Ministry of Trade and Industry to continue on-site operations until May 4. The company has implemented safe-distancing measures and reduced staff strength to comply with advisories. Staff will work from home for non-essential business functions. This exemption is part of the company's efforts to minimize disruption to operations.

site_title: Savings from pay cuts at Starhill Reit to be passed on to unitholders
summary: Starhill Global Reit's manager will implement pay cuts for its top executives, with a 20% reduction in directors' fees and 10% cuts for the CEO and CFO. The savings will be passed on to unitholders in the form of a 10% reduction in base management fees for the next three months. The company will also switch to semi-annual distributions and adopt a new financial reporting schedule, aiming to maintain financial flexibility during the pandemic. Total rental rebates, including those to tenants, total approximately S$13.6 million.

site_title: Zoom hires former Facebook security chief to beef up privacy, safety
summary: Zoom Video Communications has hired former Facebook security chief Alex Stamos as an adviser to improve the privacy and security of its video-conferencing app amid growing concerns. The company faces scrutiny over lack of end-to-end encryption, routing of traffic through China, and "zoombombing". In response, Zoom has set up a 90-day plan, formed a CISO Council, and established a board to advise CEO Eric Yuan on privacy issues. The company's stock has fallen 31% from its March high, but daily users have jumped to 200 million.

site_title: Virus to transform US presidential campaign
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly altered the 2020 US presidential election campaign, with former Vice President Joe Biden and Senator Bernie Sanders facing challenges in campaigning due to their age and health concerns. The Democratic National Committee has delayed the opening of its nominating convention to August 17, and some states have postponed their primaries to June. The pandemic has also given President Donald Trump an opportunity to dominate the media universe, with his public approval rating rising above 50%. The outcome of the election will depend on how American voters assess the performance of President Trump after the crisis ends, with some speculating that a virtual convention could be held if an open convention becomes difficult due to the pandemic.

site_title: Broadway Industrial gets third trading query in nine months
summary: Broadway Industrial Group, a precision manufacturer, received its third trading query in nine months from Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) over unusual trading activity. The group's shares rose 32.8% following the query, with the company stating it was unaware of any unannounced information and was still in talks with merger and acquisition prospects. This is the second query issued to the company in the past four months, following a previous one in December 2019.

site_title: Hong Kong unveils 'unprecedented' HK$137.5b virus relief
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam unveiled a HK$137.5 billion virus relief package, the largest in the city's history, to support the economy amid the coronavirus outbreak. The package includes an HK$80 billion job security program to subsidize 50% of wages for affected workers for six months. The government will also reduce its officials' salaries 10% for a year. The package is expected to cover many workers affected by the virus outbreak and prevent mass unemployment, but it will increase the projected budget deficit to HK$276.6 billion.

site_title: Hyflux asks for postponement of scheme meetings, extension of moratorium
summary: Hyflux has filed urgent applications in the High Court to postpone scheme meetings and extend its moratorium due to the enhanced measures against the Covid-19 outbreak. The company, which was scheduled to vote on proposed schemes of arrangement, claims it is "impossible" to convene meetings as planned. It is requesting a moratorium extension from April 30 to July 30, 2020, or until further order, citing the need for more time to prepare. Creditors had been set to vote on the proposed schemes based on Utico's rescue package for Hyflux and its subsidiaries.

site_title: Singapore banks pledge no job cuts due to Covid-19
summary: Singapore banks, including DBS, pledge not to cut jobs due to the Covid-19 pandemic. DBS CEO Piyush Gupta stated that the bank's strong capital and liquidity positions allow it to support employees, customers, and shareholders without retrenchments. This decision is seen as a positive move for the country's banking sector, which is a major employer. The move also reflects the banks' confidence in their resilience amidst the economic challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open as France falls into recession
summary: European stock markets declined at the open, with the Paris CAC 40 index falling 1.6% as France officially entered recession due to the coronavirus outbreak. Other major markets, including Frankfurt, Madrid, and Milan, also experienced losses. London dropped 1.3%. The economic data follows a broader global trend of declining markets amid ongoing trade tensions and recession fears.

site_title: Record 142 new Covid-19 cases in S'pore; 32-year-old man confirmed with virus after he dies
summary: Singapore reported a record 142 new COVID-19 cases on April 8, including a 32-year-old Indian national who died after testing positive. The cause of his death is being investigated. 40 cases are linked to dormitory clusters, with 115 cases at the S11 Dormitory @ Punggol. The Ministry of Health also announced the closure of a My First Skool center in Ang Mo Kio Avenue 10 after a teacher tested positive. 29 patients were discharged, bringing the total number of cases to 1,623.

images.alt_text: Singapore reported a record 142 new cases of Covid-19 on Wednesday (April 8), including a 32-year-old Indian national who was confirmed to have the virus after he died.

site_title: China Haida looking into the freezing of two bank accounts of its subsidiary after interim court order
summary: China Haida's subsidiary, Jiangyin Litai, has two bank accounts frozen and a third restricted following an interim court order issued by a Sichuan court. The order, made last November, was related to a pending legal dispute over lending/borrowing affairs. China Haida is trying to understand the circumstances and extent of the restrictions, with the company's finance team slow to respond due to the Covid-19 outbreak in China. The company is working with auditors to find out if other bank accounts have been affected.

site_title: MAS launches S$125m support package for financial institutions and fintech firms
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a S$125 million support package for financial institutions and fintech firms to help them navigate the current economic slump. The package includes a Training Allowance Grant (TAG) to support workforce training and a Digital Acceleration Grant (DAG) to aid digitalisation efforts. Additionally, MAS will provide six months of free access to API Exchange (APIX) for Singapore-based fintechs, and offer enhanced salary support and talent development programs to attract fresh graduates and workers from other sectors.

site_title: UK PM Johnson stable after second night in intensive care battling Covid-19
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson spent a second night in intensive care due to Covid-19 complications, but remains in a stable condition with oxygen support. He was transferred to St Thomas' hospital after his condition worsened on Monday. Johnson's deputy, Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab, stated that the prime minister will soon return to leading the country, which is facing one of the deadliest phases of the outbreak. The UK is grappling with the decision on lifting the lockdown amid the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall 1% as investors doubt pandemic slowdown, oil price recovery
summary: South Korean shares fell 1% on Wednesday, as investors doubted a pandemic slowdown and oil price recovery. The KOSPI index closed 0.90% lower at 1,807.14, extending a 25-session selloff. Foreigners sold US$110.01 million worth of shares, while medical teams struggled to save gravely ill patients. Despite levelling off hospitalizations in New York, the market remained pressured by economic fallout fears. Analysts expect continued price volatility due to uncertainty in the oil market and global economic recovery.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 8.53 points lower to 1,361.39 on Wednesday, with 617 losers outweighing 316 gainers. The index fell to RM2.658 billion in volume.

site_title: KrisEnergy sells 30% stake in Indonesia exploration block to BP for US$15m
summary: KrisEnergy sold a 30% stake in the Andaman II exploration block in Indonesia to BP's subsidiary for US$15 million. The block, covering 7,400 square kilometers in the North Sumatra Basin, was previously held by KrisEnergy under a production sharing contract. The sale price is subject to a retention sum of US$1.7 million. Proceeds will be held in a collection account secured by KrisEnergy's revolving credit facility.

site_title: Temasek's 2-week selling spree raises US$779m
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore state investment company, has sold stakes in several companies over the past two weeks, raising US$779 million. The sales include a US$186 million block trade in Thailand's Intouch Holdings and a US$507 million block trade in South Korea's Celltrion and Celltrion Healthcare. The move comes as the company re-evaluates new deals to pump funds into existing assets, which have declined by almost US$24 billion this year. Temasek's sales are part of a broader market rebound, with block trades reaching US$2 billion in the week of March 30.

site_title: Corporate-innovation firm RISE raises US$8m from Thai conglomerate Metro Co and others
summary: RISE, a corporate-innovation firm, has raised US$8 million from Thai conglomerate Metro Co, Japanese company D2C Inc, and Chanwanich Company Limited. The funds will be used to expand services to Singapore, Indonesia, and Malaysia. RISE, launched in 2016, works with corporates and government agencies to enhance innovation through its corporate accelerator and intrapreneur university. The company aims to disrupt the US$50 billion global corporate R&D and training landscape.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index up over 2% on weaker yen, stimulus
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 2.13% to 19,353.24, driven by a weaker yen and expectations of Japan's stimulus package. The broader Topic index gained 1.59%. The move comes after Japan's prime minister declared a state of emergency. A weaker yen also boosted other Asian markets, with Singapore's STI index up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: STI snaps 2-session rally, falls 1.3% on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.3% on Wednesday, ending a two-session rally, after investors expressed reservations over the sustainability of declining global Covid-19 cases and the potential for oil-producing countries to cut output. The benchmark closed at 2,539.44 points, with 22 of its 30 counters finishing in the red. The weaker performance followed a late-session dip in key Wall Street indices on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore telecom networks to be upgraded as more residents work, learn at home: IMDA
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) is upgrading its telecom networks to ensure consistent experiences at residential areas as residents work and learn from home due to pandemic-related measures. The agency is supporting telcos in upgrading their networks and boosting national capacity. The efforts will also provide subsidized broadband access and digital devices to low-income students and households. Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran stated that significant enhancements will be achieved over the next fortnight and the telecommunication infrastructure remains robust and stable.

site_title: Reit rout hurting family fortunes across Asia
summary: The Singapore power couple, Gordon and Celine Tang, have seen their family fortune decline by more than $300 million due to the pandemic's impact on their real estate investments. The Tangs' SingHaiyi Group has lost value in four Reits, including Suntec and OUE Commercial, with a total decline of 25% this year. The pandemic has disrupted cash flows, putting pressure on rental income, and has affected wealthy families globally, including Thailand's Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi and Singapore's Ng family. Despite this, Celine Tang believes real estate will remain a long-term trend.

site_title: SP Corp gets green light to hold virtual AGM
summary: SP Corporation has received approval from the Singapore Exchange to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) via a live webcast due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The virtual AGM will be held on April 16 and will be accessible to shareholders through a registration link. The company has also been exempted from suspending non-essential workplace activities. Shareholders can participate in the AGM by registering and receiving a unique link to access the webcast. The company will address substantial questions during the webcast, which will be posted on the SGXNet and company website afterwards.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's IMDA is upgrading telecom networks to support residents working and learning from home, with a S$125m support package for financial institutions and fintech firms. The MAS also launched the support package. The SGX suspended watch-list entry and raised share issue limits. Cromwell E-Reit proposed rent deferrals and monthly payments for tenants, while Frasers Property temporarily shut hospitality assets in Germany and UK. Singapore stocks experienced increased volatility in Q1 2020, with the STI falling 1.3% on Wednesday.

site_title: Savings from pay cuts at Starhill Global Reit to be passed on to unitholders
summary: Starhill Global Reit (SGReit) announced a 10-per-cent reduction in base management fees for the next three months, with savings from pay cuts by top executives to be passed on to unitholders. The board of directors will take a 20-per-cent cut in directors' fees, while the CEO and CFO will each take a 10-per-cent pay cut, and senior staff will have their salaries reduced by 5-per-cent. The move aims to maintain "financial flexibility" during the pandemic and will be reviewed at the end of the period.

site_title: France's central bank estimates first-quarter GDP shrunk 6% from previous quarter
summary: France's central bank estimates its economy contracted 6% in the first quarter from the previous quarter due to a nationwide lockdown caused by the coronavirus outbreak. This is the largest quarterly contraction since World War II, surpassing a previous record of -5.3% in 1968. The lockdown, which began on March 17, reduced economic activity by nearly a third and could extend beyond April 15 if deemed prudent. The Bank of France estimates annual economic activity could be reduced by 1.5 percentage points for every two weeks spent in lockdown.

site_title: 'Small number' of Covid-19 cases among staff, but no hit to BHP's operations
summary: BHP Group reported a "small number" of Covid-19 cases among its staff, but operations remained unaffected. The company stated that there was no broader transmission to other workers or any impact on sites. All confirmed cases are recovering well. BHP did not specify the number of cases.

site_title: Hong Kong to unveil fresh US$3.9b stimulus: SCMP
summary: The Hong Kong government is set to announce a fresh stimulus package worth over HK$30 billion (S$5.52 billion) to support businesses devastated by the coronavirus pandemic. The aid package will cover various industries, including schools, tourism, and entertainment sectors, and will also provide temporary discounts on public railway fares. The announcement is expected to be made on Wednesday, following discussions by the Executive Council. The move aims to support the economy, which had already slid into recession due to months of political unrest and the pandemic.

site_title: Volatility of Singapore stocks doubled in Q1 2020: SGX
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a 22% trailing 12-month volatility in Q1 2020, doubling from 10.7% in Q4 2019, according to the Singapore Exchange (SGX). Despite this, the FTSE Singapore Index was among the least volatile in the region. The index declined 21.5% in USD over the past year, with yields reaching 6% in March, significantly higher than the average 3.7% yield for other Asia-Pacific countries.

site_title: What small businesses need now
summary: Small businesses in Singapore need technology and human resource support to survive the COVID-19 pandemic and provide continued employment for Singaporeans. The government should consider reviving the Productivity and Innovation Grant (PIC) to help businesses acquire necessary technology and train staff. The SkillsFuture program can be streamlined and updated to provide more relevant courses and training packages. Additionally, the Productivity Solutions Grant (PSG) can adopt a simpler approval process to facilitate digitalization and productivity upgrading. Immediate help is needed to support small businesses, as the pandemic is expected to last for a year with possible economic recovery in 2021.

site_title: People allowed to leave China's Wuhan as coronavirus lockdown eases
summary: China's Wuhan city, locked down for 76 days to contain the coronavirus, began easing restrictions on Wednesday, allowing people to leave for the first time. About 55,000 people will depart by train, with the city's death toll reaching 2,571. Authorities are walking a fine line between economic activity and infection control, with concerns about a second wave of infection. Despite easing restrictions, Wuhan residents remain fearful of catching the disease, with 137 new asymptomatic cases reported on April 7.

site_title: Australia: Shares end marginally lower on country's bleak outlook
summary: Australian shares closed 0.9% lower on Wednesday, with the financial sector leading losses, amid concerns over the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 5,206.90. Standard & Poor's lowered its outlook on Australia's 'AAA' rating to "negative" due to the government's massive fiscal packages and expected sharp rise in debt. The unemployment rate is predicted to double to nearly 10%, with economists predicting the worst recession in Australia's history.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong shares closed lower on Wednesday, down 1.17% to 23,970.37, amid profit-taking after a two-day rally and concerns over the coronavirus spread. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.19% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.16%. The decline follows a recent rally in the region.

site_title: UOB CEO sees 1.8% lift in pay to S$10.8m; bank to defer April 30 AGM
summary: UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong's annual salary increased by 1.8% to S$10.75 million in 2019, with 60% of his variable pay to be deferred over three years. The bank has also deferred its annual general meeting and adoption of a revised directors' fee structure due to the COVID-19 outbreak. UOB shares closed at S$19.90, down 25 Singapore cents.

site_title: With Singapore lockdown underway, 'essential' chipmakers count on less disruption
summary: Singapore's strict lockdown is expected to cause fewer disruptions to chipmakers' factories compared to previous lockdowns in Malaysia and the Philippines, where unclear definitions of "essential" operations led to factory shutdowns and supply chain snags. Chipmakers like Micron Technology and Applied Materials are banking on Singapore's explicit declaration of semiconductors as an essential business, allowing them to operate with protections for workers. The lockdown's impact on shipments is still uncertain, but some companies, like Intel, have reported minimal production reductions.

images.alt_text: Computer chip makers are banking on less disruptions to their factories from this week's strict lockdown in Singapore than the havoc wreaked on their supply chains last month when Malaysia and the Philippines imposed vague restrictions about "essential" operations.

site_title: Supermarket tycoon's wealth surges amid India lockdown
summary: Indian supermarket tycoon Radhakishan Damani's net worth surged 11% to $10.7 billion this year, making him the richest Indian billionaire. His company, Avenue Supermarts, saw a 24% increase in shares due to panic buying of household essentials during India's lockdown. Damani's low-cost model and no-frills strategy helped the company thrive, while rival Future Group's shares plummeted 80% amid debt woes. Damani's stores are well-stocked, and his company's robust supply chain positions it for long-term success.

site_title: Bank of Japan says it will scale back operations amid coronavirus pandemic
summary: The Bank of Japan announced it will scale back operations amid the coronavirus pandemic, but will continue essential functions under close coordination with the government and financial institutions. This decision follows the Japanese government's declaration of a state of emergency. The central bank's actions aim to mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic.

site_title: SGX suspends watch-list entry, raises share issue limit
summary: SGX RegCo suspends entry into its financial watch-list, allowing companies to raise funds faster due to the economic downturn caused by the Covid-19 outbreak. The decision aims to alleviate liquidity crunch and facilitate recovery. The suspension comes after 3 years of losses and market capitalisation below S$40 million.

site_title: Citi replaces Credit Suisse on WeDoctor IPO role: sources
summary: Citigroup has replaced Credit Suisse on WeDoctor's Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) role, according to people with knowledge of the matter. Citi will work alongside JPMorgan Chase & Co and CMB International Securities to lead the share sale, which is expected to raise between $500 million and $1 billion. WeDoctor, backed by Tencent Holdings, aims to go public before the end of the year, and the IPO is seen as a potential success due to the growing demand for healthcare IPOs.

site_title: Apple partner Foxconn to start making ventilators in US
summary: Foxconn, the company that assembles most Apple iPhones, has partnered with Medtronic to develop and manufacture ventilators in the US. The Wisconsin plant will start production within 4-6 weeks, addressing a global shortage of ventilators needed for COVID-19 treatment. This collaboration aims to aid the fight against the pandemic, following Foxconn's previous efforts to produce face masks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 7.72 points lower, or 0.56%, at 1,362.20, on Wednesday. The index saw 226.85 million lots traded worth RM70.09 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 293 to 77.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open lower after rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Wednesday after a two-day rally, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.26% to 24,191.32. Investors remained cautious due to uncertainties caused by the coronavirus epidemic. The Shanghai Composite Index also eased 0.53% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.46%.

site_title: Saudi's biggest construction firm hires new CEO as it plans US$15b debt revamp
summary: Saudi Arabia's largest construction firm, Binladin International Holding Group, has appointed Khalid Al Gwaiz as its new CEO as it aims to restructure its $15 billion debt. Al Gwaiz previously managed Acwa Holding and Astra Industrial Group, and the company's top management has been overhauled several times since a crane collapse at the Grand Mosque in 2015. The restructuring plan is part of the company's efforts to recover after a government ban on new projects and a 36% stake purchase in 2018.

site_title: US set to pump more funds into small business loans
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin announced plans to ask Congress for an additional $250 billion in funding for the Paycheck Protection Programme (PPP), a small business loan program overwhelmed with applications due to the coronavirus pandemic. The initial $350 billion program has been criticized for its lack of clear guidelines and slow distribution of funds. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi have expressed support for the increased funding, but Pelosi emphasized the need for equitable distribution of funds to avoid solidifying inequality.

site_title: With supplies back, Hong Kong expats ship masks home to Covid-19 hot spots
summary: Expatriates in Hong Kong are stockpiling masks to send to family and friends in Covid-19 hotspots, as supplies return to shops. They are buying masks at lower prices in Hong Kong and shipping them to countries like Spain and France, where prices are up to 15 times higher. Some have already sent large quantities, with one expatriate sending 2,000 masks to France. The move is driven by the desperation of loved ones who are struggling to find masks due to shortages. Hong Kong has seen a spike in Covid-19 cases, with four deaths reported.

site_title: Frasers Property temporarily shuts Germany and UK assets, shortens staff hours
summary: Frasers Property temporarily shut its hotels in Germany and the UK, and reduced staff hours due to the novel coronavirus pandemic. The company closed all food and beverage outlets at two Australian hotels and limited restaurants to takeaways or deliveries in Singapore. To support employees, Frasers Property rolled out an employee assistance program and implemented cost-containment measures, including shortened work hours and unpaid leave. The company aims to mitigate the negative impact on its hospitality business while preserving staff employment.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower tracking losses on Wall St; STI down 2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 2% to 2,520.43, with 147 losers outweighing 39 gainers, following losses in a volatile US market session. ESR-Reit and SGX were among the few local stocks to gain, while Singtel, DBS, OCBC, and UOB lost ground. The losses followed a US market session where major indices finished in the red amid the latest coronavirus figures.

site_title: Boris Johnson spends second night in intensive care
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson spent his second night in intensive care due to coronavirus, with over 55,000 infected and nearly 6,200 killed in the UK. Deputising for Johnson, Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab expressed confidence in the prime minister's recovery, stating he's a "fighter" who will lead the country through the crisis. Raab also emphasized Johnson's determination to stay at work, with the Daily Express predicting he will "pull through."

site_title: CCCS invites feedback on LSEG's proposed acquisition of Refinitiv
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) is inviting public feedback on London Stock Exchange Group's (LSEG) proposed acquisition of Refinitiv Holdings, valued at US$27 billion. The US Committee on Foreign Investment has approved the deal without national security concerns. Refinitiv is 45% owned by Thomson Reuters, and LSEG claims the merger will not infringe on Singapore's Competition Act due to strong competition from other providers, including Bloomberg and JPMorgan. The public consultation runs from April 8 to April 22.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades MLT to 'buy', says it's 'safe harbour' amid virus outbreak
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) to "buy" amid the Covid-19 pandemic, citing its "safe harbour" status due to its pure logistics exposure and stable earnings. Analyst Derek Tan expects acquisitions to drive unit price growth, with DBS anticipating S$350 million in acquisitions by the end of FY2021. The Reit's stable gearing and financial capacity also support the upgrade. DBS adjusted its 12-month target price to S$1.85 from S$1.90, following a recent share price correction.

site_title: Women fight for a place at the table as sushi chefs in Japan
summary: Women in Japan are challenging traditional stereotypes that they are unsuitable for sushi chef roles due to physical characteristics and societal expectations. Despite being underrepresented, a growing number of women are training and working as sushi chefs in top restaurants, with some citing acceptance from colleagues and a focus on competence over gender. Industry experts estimate women make up less than 10% of sushi chefs, with resistance to female chefs remaining strong, particularly among older customers.

images.alt_text: Mizuho Iwai is a trainee at the upscale Onodera restaurant in Tokyo's Ginza, a ritzy neighbourhood home to some of the world's top-ranked sushi restaurants.

site_title: Australia's 'Big Four' banks see shares fall after regulator urges dividend deferral
summary: Australian "Big Four" banks, Commonwealth Bank, Westpac, National Australia Bank, and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, saw shares fall by 4.1-6.2% after regulator APRA urged banks to consider deferring dividend payouts or using buffers due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact. APRA asked banks to limit discretionary capital distribution to ensure sufficient capacity for lending and underwriting insurance. The regulator also suspended issuing new banking licenses for at least six months. The move follows earlier forecasts that the Big Four may cut dividends in coming weeks due to the pandemic.

site_title: Some self-employed unable to benefit from enhanced Sirs scheme
summary: Around 100,000 self-employed individuals in Singapore can now automatically benefit from the Self-Employed Person (SEP) Income Relief Scheme (Sirs) due to two enhancements made by the Ministry of Manpower. The enhancements include those earning up to $2,300 a month from employment and living in a property valued up to $21,000. However, some self-employed individuals who have suffered losses amid the pandemic claim they are still ineligible for aid, despite the expanded scheme.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit proposes rent deferrals, monthly payments for tenants
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) proposes offering tenants monthly rent payments and allowing deferrals of up to three months in special cases. The move comes after 139 tenants requested rent deferments for one to two months. The Reit's manager is also considering rent-free leases for exceptional cases and has not agreed to blanket rent relief or waivers. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the Reit's occupancy rate remains at 93.2% and it expects improved tenant retention rates this year.

site_title: US pushes back on call by Opec+ to join big oil output cuts
summary: The US has pushed back on Opec+'s call to join deep oil output cuts, citing that US output is already declining without government intervention. The US Department of Energy stated that US output is expected to fall by 30% over two years, in line with the White House's stance on private markets. Opec+ is seeking cuts to prop up prices, which have dropped 30% due to the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down as traders fret over coronavirus
summary: Asian markets retreated on Wednesday as investors fretted over the coronavirus crisis, despite signs that the rate of infections may be leveling out. The losses were widespread, with Hong Kong and Singapore down 0.5% and 2% respectively. Tokyo and Taipei, however, bucked the trend, rising 0.1% and 1% respectively. Oil prices rallied ahead of a producers' meeting, but uncertainty about the crisis's duration and impact on the global economy kept traders on edge.

images.alt_text: Foxconn, the company responsible for assembling most of the world's Apple iPhones, will aid the fight against the coronavirus pandemic by developing and making ventilators in the US.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher with investors' eyes on virus
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on April 8, 2020, as investors cautiously welcomed signs of an improvement in the coronavirus crisis. The Nikkei 225 index climbed 0.55% to 19,054.12, while the broader Topic index edged up 0.32%. The positive trend was attributed to tentative improvements in the crisis, but no specific details were mentioned.

site_title: Japan's Feb machinery orders rise in sign of business resilience
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 2.3% in February, beating economists' 2.7% decline prediction, indicating resilient business investment despite the coronavirus pandemic's impact. This follows a 2.9% gain in January, suggesting companies are bracing for a major demand shock. The data is seen as a positive sign for the country's economy.

site_title: USP substantial shareholder applies for company to be wound up
summary: A substantial shareholder, Oon Koon Cheng, director and sole shareholder of Sin Hong Hwa, has applied for USP Group to be wound up. USP stated it will resist the application, with Cheng holding 28.83% of USP shares. This move comes after Sin Hong Hwa sold Koon Cheng Development to USP Properties for S$32 million in 2016. The outcome of the application is uncertain.

site_title: Morgan Stanley among biggest lenders to embattled Luckin founder: source
summary: Morgan Stanley, Credit Suisse Group, and Haitong International Securities Group provided significant margin loans to Luckin Coffee's founder, Lu Zhengyao, before accounting fraud allegations led to a stock collapse. The banks lent around $300 million each, with Goldman Sachs handling the disposal of Luckin shares seized by lenders. The scandal has resulted in a $5.5 billion loss in Luckin's market value and has dealt a blow to banks that worked with the company, including arranging its initial public offering.

site_title: New York-listed AMTD International makes debut on SGX at S$13.95
summary: AMTD International, a Hong Kong-headquartered financial institution, made its debut on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) at S$13.95, becoming the first company to list via an online ceremony amidst Singapore's "circuit breaker" measures to curb the novel coronavirus. The listing marks AMTD's official entrance into the Singapore market and its strategic hub for expansion to Southeast Asia. The company's market cap is over US$2 billion on the New York Stock Exchange, following its US$200 million initial public offering in 2019.

site_title: Khazanah sceptical about GSV's US$2.5b offer for Malaysia Airlines: report
summary: Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional Bhd is skeptical about a proposed US$2.5 billion acquisition of Malaysia Airlines by Golden Skies Ventures (GSV). Khazanah's managing director Shahril Ridza Ridzuan expressed caution about GSV's financial backing given the risk aversion in the airline industry amid the coronavirus pandemic. GSV claims to have secured funding in excess of US$2.5 billion from a European bank and a Japanese private equity firm, but Khazanah prioritizes investment structures that avoid heavy borrowings to ensure financial sustainability.

images.alt_text: Malaysian sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional Bhd, the sole owner of Malaysia Airlines, is sceptical about a US$2.5 billion proposal by privately held Golden Skies Ventures (GSV) to acquire the national carrier, the New Straits Times daily reported.

site_title: Nearly 2,000 US coronavirus deaths in last 24 hours: Johns Hopkins tally
summary: US coronavirus deaths reached nearly 2,000 in the last 24 hours, according to a Johns Hopkins University tally, bringing the total US death toll to 12,722. This is approaching death tolls in Italy (17,127) and Spain (13,798). The US is experiencing a significant surge in coronavirus-related deaths, with the record daily figure surpassing previous totals.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop 2.5% as virus anxiety resurfaces, New Zealand slips
summary: Australian shares dropped 2.5% on Wednesday due to concerns over the economic slump caused by the coronavirus pandemic and an outlook downgrade on the local economy and banking sector. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1.9% to 5,152.5. The government's emergency A$130 billion stimulus package has been passed, but analysts predict a "very large" economic contraction and a spike in unemployment. The banking sector was the biggest loser, with top lenders Commonwealth Bank and Westpac losing 3.8% and 5.1% respectively.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust says review of proposed portfolio sale will take 2 more months
summary: Accordia Golf Trust's independent committee review of its potential sale to its parent, Accordia Golf Co, will be completed in June 2020, following a two-month extension due to the COVID-19 situation. The review will assess factors such as the price, terms, and valuation reports. The trust had received a non-binding proposal from Accordia Golf Co in November, which was later confirmed as the buyer. The review's completion will determine the fate of the proposed sale of the trust's 88 golf courses.

site_title: Trump threatens withholding funds from WHO
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to cut funding to the World Health Organization (WHO) during the coronavirus pandemic, accusing it of bias toward China. Trump said he would put a "very powerful hold on" US funding to the WHO, citing its perceived pro-China stance. The WHO had advised against curtailing international travel, which Trump had previously criticized for being "faulty." The move comes amid Trump's ongoing criticism of China's handling of the pandemic. The exact amount of funding to be withheld remains unclear.

site_title: WeWork sues Japan's SoftBank for backing out of deal
summary: WeWork sued Japan's SoftBank for backing out of a US$3 billion rescue plan, claiming a breach of contractual obligations. WeWork's board of directors alleged SoftBank yielded to activist investors and received most of the benefits under the deal, including control of WeWork's board. SoftBank cited pending investigations and terminated the agreement, citing WeWork's failure to meet obligations. WeWork is seeking damages or for SoftBank to fulfill the agreement.

site_title: Uruguay approves flight to evacuate Aussies, Kiwis from infected ship
summary: Uruguay has authorized a humanitarian flight to evacuate approximately 128 Australian and New Zealand passengers from the coronavirus-infected cruise ship Greg Mortimer. The flight, on an Airbus A340 plane, will transport passengers who test positive and negative for the virus, with the aim of repatriating around 100 Australians and some New Zealanders. Upon arrival, passengers will undergo a two-week quarantine in Melbourne. The flight is part of efforts to mitigate the global impact of the pandemic on the cruise industry, with other ships facing refusal of entry to ports and lockdowns.

site_title: Ecuador ex-president sentenced to 8 years for corruption: prosecutor
summary: Former Ecuador president Rafael Correa was sentenced in absentia to 8 years in prison for corruption during his 10-year term in office. Correa, who now lives in exile in Belgium, was one of 18 people convicted of bribery. The conviction marks a significant development in Ecuador's efforts to combat corruption.

site_title: Chinese refiners try out cheap, exotic oil from Europe: sources
summary: Chinese refiners have been purchasing cheap and exotic crude oil grades from Europe, taking advantage of the reduced demand caused by lockdowns related to the new coronavirus.
