In April, Chinese purchases of Brent-linked grades, including North Sea, Russian, and Caspian oil, surged. European oil traders stated that if there is a buyer in Europe now, it is China, highlighting the country's bargain-hunting nature in the market.

site_title: Airbnb's new US$1b investment comes at lower valuation: sources
summary: Airbnb has received a US$1 billion investment from private equity firms Silver Lake and Sixth Street Partners, valuing the company at US$18 billion, below its previous valuation of US$26 billion. The deal includes US$1 billion in five-year debt and warrants worth around 1% of Airbnb's total equity. The investment raises the company's cash reserves to around US$4 billion, amid a slowdown in global travel due to the coronavirus pandemic. This deal is seen as a sign of investor support and follows a previous discussion with lenders to extend a US$1 billion debt facility.

site_title: S&P downgrades outlook on Australia's AAA rating
summary: S&P has downgraded Australia's AAA rating outlook to "negative" due to a potential weakening in the government's debt position following a large fiscal stimulus package. The agency expects the economy to plunge into recession for the first time in nearly 30 years due to the COVID-19 pandemic. A downgrade to "CCC" rating is possible within the next two years if economic damage is more severe or prolonged than expected. This move signals increased risk of a downgrade to the country's AAA rating.

site_title: Covid-19: Big isn't necessarily better in handling a crisis
summary: Covid-19 has shown that size isn't a guarantee of success in handling a crisis. Countries like Denmark and Singapore, often smaller than their counterparts, have outperformed in economic and social areas during the pandemic. This trend is expected to continue, highlighting the importance of adaptability and effective management over size. Experts recommend that individuals prepare for future crises by future-proofing their careers, while organizations can benefit from support services like the Singapore Business Federation. A strong, agile response can lead to better outcomes, regardless of a country's size.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yangzijiang, SPH, Accordia Golf Trust, Fu Yu, USP Group
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's executive chairman Ren Yuanlin stepped down, allowing his son Ren Letian to take over as executive chairman. Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) posted a 5.5% rise in net profit for the quarter, but a 9.3% fall in the first-half period due to declining newspaper print advertisement revenue. Accordia Golf Trust's proposed disposal of its golf courses will be reviewed by an independent committee by June 2020. Fu Yu Corporation will continue operating in Singapore during the "circuit-breaker" period, while USP Group will resist a shareholder's application to be wound up and has commenced legal action against the shareholder.

site_title: Regulator test flight of Boeing 737 MAX delayed to May: sources
summary: A key test flight of the Boeing 737 MAX has been delayed to May due to the coronavirus crisis, according to sources. The certification flight, required to clear the jet to resume service, was initially targeted for April. Boeing faces financial pressure from the grounding, which has been in place since March 2019 following two fatal crashes. Despite the delay, a company spokesman confirmed that the company still expects regulatory approval in mid-2020. Other hurdles remain, including settling on pilot and crew training requirements for the upgraded MAX.

site_title: US: Wall Street rally fades as markets weigh latest on virus
summary: US stocks experienced a brief rally on Tuesday before fading as markets weighed the latest data on the coronavirus outbreak. Despite a decline, the Dow finished 0.1% lower, with investors encouraged by declining hospitalization rates in New York and improved data from Italy. Oil prices plummeted ahead of a key meeting between major oil producers. The US Treasury Secretary requested additional funding for a small business loan program, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: US stocks gyrated on Tuesday as markets grappled with the latest figures on the coronavirus outbreak, while oil prices tumbled in a volatile session ahead of key talks by petroleum producers.

site_title: More countries are embracing face masks after initial reluctance
summary: More countries are requiring face masks in public as the World Health Organization moderates its stance on their effectiveness in containing Covid-19. Indonesia, Vietnam, and the Philippines have implemented mask mandates, while Singapore has shifted its advice on face masks. The shift in mask policies comes after emerging evidence that asymptomatic carriers can spread the virus and that masks on sick people can prevent transmission. Experts emphasize that masks should be used in conjunction with other preventative measures like hand washing and social distancing.

images.alt_text: Indonesia, one of the world's most populous countries with 264 million people, on Monday ordered citizens to wear face masks when they leave the house after predicting as many as 95,000 people could be infected. President Joko Widodo said the authorities must ensure every household has face masks and that commuters won't be able to access public transportation without them.

site_title: US navy chief out over handling of ship virus outbreak
summary: US Acting Navy Secretary Thomas Modly resigned on Tuesday over his handling of the coronavirus outbreak on the USS Theodore Roosevelt aircraft carrier, amid criticism of his decision to remove the ship's captain, Brett Crozier. Modly's removal followed a leaked letter by Captain Crozier, who described the dire situation on the ship and alleged inadequate Pentagon attention. President Trump publicly questioned Crozier's treatment, but ultimately accepted Modly's resignation, citing the need to move forward for the Navy and sailors.

site_title: Internet overseers seek crackdown on coronavirus website scams
summary: The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) has urged internet registrars to prevent the misuse of website domain names during the coronavirus pandemic. With over 100,000 new website names registered using terms like "covid" and "corona," ICANN warns of phishing, spam, and malware campaigns targeting people desperate for protection. The agency, which oversees online addresses, cannot enforce content management but is concerned about the rise of cybercrime exploiting coronavirus fears. ICANN's security chief calls the situation a "new low" and urges registrars to thwart such scams.

site_title: Companies get more time to hold AGMs amid Covid-19 pandemic
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) and Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) have granted a 60-day extension to companies to hold their annual general meetings (AGMs) amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The extension applies to listed and non-listed companies with AGMs due between April 16 and July 31. Additionally, companies with annual return filing due dates between May 1 and August 31 will also receive a 60-day extension.

site_title: France coronavirus deaths exceed 10,000: official
summary: France has surpassed 10,000 coronavirus deaths, with 7,091 hospital fatalities and 3,237 in old age homes since March 1. Top health official Jerome Salomon warned the epidemic is still progressing, despite slowing. The country is treating over 30,000 people in hospitals, with 7,131 in intensive care. The death toll has increased by 597 in the last 24 hours.

site_title: Deprived of customers, UK farmers throw away milk
summary: UK dairy farmers are discarding thousands of litres of milk due to the coronavirus lockdown, which has reduced demand for milk from supermarkets, restaurants, and schools. The Royal Association of British Dairy Farmers is calling for government help with a short-term financial support scheme to aid affected farmers. About 300 dairy farmers, producing around one million litres daily, could be eligible for reimbursement. The industry faces concerns over a lack of workers for the next harvests, echoing concerns from asparagus producers in France and strawberry farmers in Spain.

site_title: 'Wuhan virus' no more: US and China in truce
summary: The US and China have reached a truce, with the US dropping its term "Chinese virus" and refraining from criticizing Beijing's response to the coronavirus pandemic. This comes after a telephone call between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping on March 26. The truce appears to be a tactical move, with both countries seeing mutual interests in calming tensions. The development marks a shift in the US-China feud over the pandemic.

site_title: Oil drops on growing crude glut, doubts over output cuts
summary: Oil prices plummeted 9.4% to $23.63 a barrel, with West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures settling at $2.45 lower, amid a growing crude glut and weak fuel demand due to the coronavirus pandemic. The US Department of Energy noted that production is already dropping without government involvement. Top global suppliers, including Saudi Arabia and Russia, plan to meet on Thursday to discuss output cuts, but US participation is uncertain.

site_title: Suppliers struggle to meet soaring demand for takeaway food packaging
summary: Singapore's takeaway food packaging demand surged 40% to 100% since the government's "circuit-breaker" period, with suppliers struggling to meet the increased demand due to lockdowns in Malaysia, a key manufacturing node. Companies are ramping up orders and exploring alternative suppliers, with some relying on domestic production and others sourcing products from neighboring countries like Indonesia. The Federation of Merchants' Association is monitoring the situation and prepared to help aggregate demands and negotiate with overseas manufacturers.

site_title: Showing solidarity to help businesses, individuals survive Covid-19 challenges
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a Solidarity Budget, a further S$4 billion drawdown from past reserves, to support businesses and individuals affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The budget includes measures to boost cash, cost, and credit support for enterprises, such as a 75% wage subsidy for local employees and a rebate for foreign workers. However, businesses may still struggle with remaining wage costs and job security, particularly for higher-income earners and non-Singaporean workers. The government's measures aim to cushion the impact of the pandemic and support the community's collective efforts to overcome the crisis.

site_title: Europe: Shares at 1-month high on hopes coronavirus crisis may be easing
summary: European shares reached a 1-month high on Tuesday, closing up 1.9% at their highest level in nearly a month, driven by early signs that the coronavirus pandemic may be easing. German shares led the charge, up 2.8%, while travel and leisure stocks outperformed. Economists expect a global recession but hold onto hopes of a swift rebound.

site_title: Twitter's Jack Dorsey pledges US$1b for Covid-19 relief effort
summary: Twitter co-founder and CEO Jack Dorsey pledged $1 billion to COVID-19 relief efforts through his philanthropic fund, transferring 28% of his wealth from his digital payments group Square. This move aims to support coronavirus relief and post-pandemic initiatives, including health and education for girls and universal basic income efforts. Dorsey's donation is the largest from a single individual for coronavirus relief, following other tech entrepreneurs' efforts, such as Amazon's $100 million pledge and Facebook's over $25 million donation.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chemotherapy, your immune system and Covid-19
summary: Dr. Choo Bok Ai, a radiation oncologist, discusses the impact of chemotherapy on the immune system during a COVID-19 pandemic. She advises patients to maintain a healthy immune system by eating well, exercising, and getting enough sleep. Dr. Choo emphasizes the importance of not skipping chemotherapy sessions, even if symptoms are mild, as this can lead to treatment failure. She also recommends staying hydrated and taking breaks to reduce fatigue. By prioritizing immune system health, patients can better cope with chemotherapy and COVID-19.

site_title: Dollar falls, riskier currencies rally on virus slowdown hopes
summary: The US dollar fell on Tuesday as riskier currencies rebounded on hopes that the novel coronavirus slowdown in some countries may be slowing the spread of the virus. Bets on oil price support from major crude producers also boosted market sentiment. The greenback has been volatile in recent weeks, but central bank easing helped calm markets. Riskier currencies such as the euro and yen rallied, while the dollar lost ground, marking a shift in market sentiment.

site_title: Risks of infection causing headaches over crew changes
summary: A managing director of Danica Crewing Services, Henrik Jensen, argues that crew changes should be halted due to the risks of infection from Covid-19. He believes that seafarers should stay longer on vessels to avoid traveling to and from postings, citing concerns about public transport networks and the lack of medical care on merchant vessels. Jensen suggests that vessel operators should extend contracts and provide support for seafarers to mitigate the impact of long postings, and that measures should be taken to adjust crew workload to prevent fatigue.

site_title: Chinese tycoon Tong Jinquan sells substantial stake in IReit Global to key unitholders Tikehau, CDL
summary: Chinese tycoon Tong Jinquan sold a substantial stake in IReit Global to key unitholders Tikehau and CDL for S$64 million. Tikehau raised its stake to 29.2% and CDL increased its stake to 20.87%, taking their aggregate shareholding to over 50%. Following the transaction, Tong's stake will be reduced to about 6%. The deal boosted IReit Global's unit price by 19.2% and CDL shares rose 11.3%.

site_title: Why Singapore is Asia's emerging hub for deep tech
summary: Singapore has outlined its vision for the country's tech ecosystem with a $300 million injection into the Startup SG Equity co-investment scheme to accelerate deep-tech innovation. As part of its Transformation and Growth Strategy, the government aims to develop Singapore's people and grow the country's deep tech ecosystem. This initiative gives Singapore a strong foothold in the deep tech race, but realising its potential requires a greater and more cooperative effort. The strategy is part of an $8.3 billion plan to enable stronger partnerships and deepen enterprise capabilities over the next three years.

site_title: MAS eases some capital requirements for banks, but says no share buybacks
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has eased capital and liquidity requirements for banks amid the COVID-19 pandemic, but warned against using released buffers for share buybacks. Banks can now fully recognize regulatory loss allowance reserves as Tier 2 Capital, and the net stable funding ratio will be halved to 25% until September 30, 2021. MAS prioritizes sustaining lending activities over discretionary distributions, and banks' dividend policies remain unchanged. The measures are aimed at supporting banks' ability to provide credit to households and businesses.

site_title: Editor's letter: Delivering with your support
summary: Singapore will require everyone to stay at home except essential services and key economic sectors, amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The Business Times will continue reporting on the pandemic's impact, but may experience delays in newspaper delivery due to worker shortages. To help, subscribers are asked to open their mailboxes to allow newspaper vendors to deposit papers, and an e-Paper service will be sent to direct subscribers via email until the situation improves.

site_title: Banks across Singapore will close some branches till May 4
summary: Banks in Singapore have announced plans to close some branches until May 4 to reduce footfall amid tighter social distancing measures to curb Covid-19. DBS, OCBC, and UOB will shut 29, 22, and 24 branches respectively, with some branches remaining open near essential services. The closures aim to balance staff welfare and minimize social interaction. ATM services will remain available, and vulnerable customers will have dedicated hours at remaining branches.

site_title: Next election shaping up to be a unique one in Singapore's history
summary: Singapore's next general election is expected to take place within the next 12 months, likely amidst the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. The government has proposed contingency measures to ensure a smooth and safe voting process, including allowing voters on stay orders to cast ballots outside their designated divisions and enabling candidates to nominate representatives during quarantine. The election will be the most unique in Singapore's history, and the government will need to carefully assess the evolving Covid-19 situation to determine the best timing for the poll.

site_title: The importance of focusing on the long term during a pandemic
summary: A global pandemic, COVID-19, has prompted severe social and economic concerns, with significant disruption to daily lives and businesses. While markets have survived past crises, the current downturn is expected to slow global economic growth, with a recession in the US and Europe possible. However, the US economy remains resilient, and governments have announced fiscal policies to support the economy. Investors should focus on long-term fundamentals rather than short-term market movements, and avoid getting caught up in volatility, as markets are likely to rebound in the long term.

site_title: China's commodities industry shows signs of recovery
summary: China's commodities industry is showing signs of recovery, with most of the country back to work at 90-95% capacity. Oil refineries and coal-fired power plants are nearing last year's operating rates, and metals stockpiles have shrunk from record levels. China has reported zero new Covid-19 deaths for the first time since January, marking a heartening milestone. Key indicators include rising oil refinery throughput, increased drivers on the roads, and a doubling of daily coal burn at select coastal plants.

site_title: Thailand unveils 1.9t baht plan to mitigate virus impact
summary: Thailand's Cabinet approved a 1.9 trillion baht ($82.6 billion) economic package to mitigate the impact of the coronavirus outbreak. The package includes borrowing 1 trillion baht for public health and relief measures, and 900 billion baht in soft loans and support for corporate bonds. The government expects to start borrowing in early May from domestic sources, aiming to alleviate the economic impact and recession. Thailand has confirmed 2,258 cases and 27 deaths since the outbreak began in January.

site_title: China's big developers shrug off short-term virus impact to splurge on land
summary: China's major property developers are investing heavily in land this year, despite the COVID-19 pandemic's short-term impact on the market. The country's top developers reported a 136% surge in sales in March, narrowing the first-quarter decline to 21% compared to last year. Many developers expect sales to normalize in April and plan to maintain or increase their land purchases, driven by government support measures and increased liquidity. However, analysts caution that the industry downtrend may persist, and a faster decline in home sales could lead to a drop in home prices.

site_title: Airbnb raises US$1b to stockpile cash in pandemic
summary: Airbnb has raised $1 billion in new funding, led by private equity giant Silver Lake and investment firm Sixth Street Partners, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The company lowered its internal valuation to $26 billion, citing a need to stockpile cash. Despite having $3 billion in cash reserves, Airbnb enacted a hiring freeze, cut its marketing budget, and reduced executive pay. The funding aims to support the company's long-term investments in its host community and adapt to the shift in travel patterns during the pandemic.

site_title: There's a silver lining to every crisis
summary: Global stock markets have crashed 30% from their peak to trough, but the odds of a financial crisis are now muted due to large global liquidity injections. Investors should focus on businesses that will thrive in the post-Covid-19 world, such as those in the digital economy, e-commerce, and healthcare. Companies with strong digital transformation, cloud computing, and technology hardware & equipment are potential winners. In contrast, interest rate-sensitive industries like financials, energy, and industrials may experience further downside risks. Investing in these sectors with a tactical approach or through funds managed by professionals may be a better option.

site_title: Airbus struggles to gauge size of scale-back to production
summary: Airbus struggles to determine the optimal scale-back in production due to the unprecedented civil aviation crisis caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The company faces a delicate balance between slowing output and avoiding suppliers being starved out of business. A significant reduction in production, such as on its A320 narrow-body workhorse, could risk losing its advantage over rival Boeing in the rebound period. Airbus has identified operational measures to minimize cash outflow, but the exact output plans remain uncertain, with the company's annual general meeting providing a possible update next week.

site_title: Has coronavirus tide turned in Asia and Europe?
summary: Asia and Europe have seen growing optimism that the coronavirus crisis may have passed its peak, with China lifting restrictions in Wuhan and countries like Italy and Spain reporting declining death rates. However, optimism is premature, as several countries, including Indonesia and the UK, are still experiencing high infection rates and potential second waves. Western Europe is also cautious, with restrictions still in place and concerns about a potential "emergency brake" if infections accelerate. The crisis is not yet over, and urgent international attention is needed for other key areas, including Africa and the Americas, where peaks are still some time away.

site_title: Singapore reports 106 new Covid-19 cases
summary: Singapore reported 106 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 1,481, with 103 local cases and 3 imported. Contact tracing is ongoing for 41 local cases, while 377 have recovered and 627 are still in hospital, with 29 in critical condition.

site_title: Gold falls from 1-month high
summary: Gold prices fell 0.5% to $1,654.26 per ounce, snapping a one-month high, as equities rose on signs of a Covid-19 slowdown. The metal had risen 2.8% on Monday. Investors expect gold to break through the $1,700 level due to low-interest rates and economic concerns. US gold futures rose 0.9% to $1,709.40, despite refinery closures and logistics constraints. A slowdown in new cases and reports of a state of emergency in Japan's Tokyo also supported gold prices.

site_title: Look beyond own interests at broader concerns, landlords told
summary: Singapore's Minister for Law and Home Affairs K Shanmugam has defended the government's plan to temporarily relieve commercial tenants of their rental obligations during the Covid-19 crisis, stating it's not "anti-landlord." The Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Bill proposes to allow tenants to defer rent payments for up to six months and offers protection from legal action. Shanmugam emphasized that landlords should consider broader concerns, rather than focusing solely on their interests, and that the move aims to give tenants breathing room to adjust for survival.

site_title: It's make-or-break time for Singapore
summary: Singapore has implemented measures to combat the COVID-19 pandemic, including shutting schools and curbing non-essential physical interaction, but compliance is crucial for its success. Residents must adhere to stay-home orders, social distancing, and only commuting for essential needs. The government has warned that failure to comply could lead to a more draconian lockdown, straining medical resources and contact tracing teams. With the next month being a make-or-break time, Singapore's residents must prioritize health concerns over fears of missing tuition lessons, as the virus can spread unknowingly among unsuspecting individuals.

site_title: TDSR waived for deferred mortgage payments
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has clarified scenarios where total debt servicing ratio (TDSR), mortgage servicing ratio (MSR), and loan-to-value (LTV) limits will not apply to deferred mortgage payments. Businesses and property owners with secured property loans, including mortgage equity withdrawal loans, are exempt from these limits if they defer payments for residential or non-residential properties. This relief applies to SMEs, individuals, and those refinancing mortgages for properties they reside in, with interest accruing only on the deferred principal amount.

site_title: NTUC First Campus preschools to offset fees following govt move
summary: NTUC First Campus preschools will provide a 50% offset of net fees for May 2020 for Singaporean children not attending due to the "circuit breaker" measures. This support will benefit approximately 19,500 children. The preschool has partnered with other anchor operators to offer interactive home-based learning resources and parent guides through a one-stop portal, Kidzmatters, to help families continue learning at home. This initiative aims to support working families and children's learning during the challenging period.

site_title: Fitch Ratings cuts LMIRT outlook to negative due to coronavirus impact
summary: Fitch Ratings has cut its outlook on Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) to negative due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on operating earnings. The negative outlook is based on an expected 50% drop in revenue and 60% decline in Ebita for 2020. LMIRT's cash flow will be pressured by the Indonesian rupiah's depreciation, and the company may defer interest payments and dividend distribution to conserve cash. The trust's long-term senior unsecured rating remains at BB.

site_title: The world's bank stocks price in 'Armageddon' as buyers flee
summary: Global bank stocks plummet to historic lows amidst the novel coronavirus pandemic, with developed bank equities falling to a record low versus the wider market. US lenders have sunk below 2008 levels, and eurozone institutions have traded at a 70% discount to book value. Investors are punishing the sector with intensity reminiscent of the global financial crisis, despite the sector's better shape.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Olam International, an agri-food giant, is keeping processing facilities operational in markets where local regulations allow, while implementing health and safety precautions and telecommuting measures amid the coronavirus spread. Fu Yu Corporation will continue its Singapore operations during the circuit-breaker period. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's executive chairman Ren Yuanlin stepped down and handed over to his son Ren Letian, who will take over as executive chairman. The company also announced the appointment of a new executive director and independent non-executive director.

site_title: A call for intellect and courage
summary: US leaders must demonstrate courage and intellectual commitment to effectively respond to the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the country's current state, characterized by widespread preference for believing over thinking and a lack of intellectual courage, hinders progress. This has led to numerous collective failures, including the spread of misinformation and the erosion of public trust. To rescue the nation, Americans must prioritize thinking over conforming, expand the sovereignty of a courageous and virtuous citizenry, and re-evaluate their priorities, shifting from engineered consumption to a more rational and truthful approach.

site_title: Singapore office rents to decline amid Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Office rents in Singapore are expected to decline amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with a 10% moderation in Grade A CBD rents in 2020 and a further decline in 2021, according to Cushman & Wakefield. The negative impact may become more evident in the second quarter of 2020 if demand for space falls further. Occupiers are delaying decision-making on new leases due to government closures and lockdowns in the US and Europe, but Chinese firms are showing renewed interest in Singapore's office market. Colliers expects a 4% rent decline in 2021.

site_title: Japan declares state of emergency; approves 1 trillion yen stimulus package
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared a state of emergency due to the new coronavirus, effective through May 6, in Tokyo and six other prefectures. The measure aims to reduce contact by 70-80% to slow infections. A 108 trillion yen stimulus package was also approved, equivalent to 20% of Japan's economy, making it one of the world's largest. The package includes direct fiscal spending and record bond issuance to support the economy.

site_title: Proposed law to facilitate voting and nominations if GE held amid Covid-19 restrictions
summary: Singapore is proposing a law to facilitate voting and nominations for a general election held amid Covid-19 restrictions. The bill, introduced by Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing, allows voters subject to stay-home orders to vote outside their electoral divisions and enables aspiring candidates to register on Nomination Day without being present in person due to illness. The law is meant to ensure public health and safety during polls and vote counting, with the next general election scheduled for April 14, 2021.

site_title: 1960s Bond girl Honor Blackman dies at 94
summary: Actress Honor Blackman, known for her iconic role as Pussy Galore in the 1964 James Bond film Goldfinger, has died at 94. Blackman's family announced her passing due to natural causes at home in Lewes, Sussex. A prolific actress, she also starred in the TV series The Avengers and appeared in various films and theatre productions. Blackman's legacy as a talented and independent actress has been celebrated by the film industry, with producers and directors paying tribute to her remarkable career.

images.alt_text: Blackman also became well-known in Britain for playing the character Cathy Gale in the popular 1960s TV spy series The Avengers alongside Patrick Macnee as the bowler-hatted John Steed.

site_title: SPH net profit up 5.5% in Q2, down 9.3% in H1
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported a 5.5% rise in net profit to S$31.3 million in Q2, driven by a 33% jump in property segment revenue. However, the media business declined 18.3% and 6.5% in advertisement and circulation revenue, respectively. The company slashed interim dividend to 1.5 cents per share, citing the challenging business environment due to the Covid-19 outbreak. SPH will continue with digital transformation initiatives and put investment activities on hold to conserve cash.

site_title: Thailand announces 1.9t baht plan to mitigate coronavirus impact
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved a 1.9 trillion baht economic package to mitigate the coronavirus impact, worth 82.6 billion SGD. The package includes borrowing 1 trillion baht, with 600 billion for public health and relief, and the rest for rebuilding and job creation.

site_title: WhatsApp tightens sharing limits to curb virus misinformation
summary: WhatsApp has introduced new limits on message forwarding to curb the spread of misinformation about the coronavirus pandemic. The platform now limits users to forwarding certain messages to one chat at a time, aiming to slow the propagation of provocative but false content. This move follows a significant increase in message forwarding that users have reported as overwhelming and contributing to misinformation. WhatsApp aims to keep the platform a place for personal conversation during the health crisis.

site_title: Oil higher as hopes build for output cut amid coronavirus crisis
summary: Oil prices rose 2.5% to $33.88 a barrel as hopes for a global production cut outweighed fears of a deeper recession due to the coronavirus crisis. Brent crude gained 83 US cents, while West Texas Intermediate rose 95 US cents. The world's main oil producers, including Saudi Arabia and Russia, are expected to agree to cut output at a meeting on Thursday, but the US participation is uncertain. Oil demand has dropped by 30% due to lockdowns and social distancing measures, with worldwide production at 30 million barrels per day.

site_title: Lufthansa grounds Germanwings in sweeping restructuring
summary: Lufthansa grounds Germanwings low-cost airline as part of a broader restructuring amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The airline will cut flight capacity at hubs in Frankfurt and Munich, reducing aircraft in service for Lufthansa and Eurowings. This move is part of a broader overhaul aimed at improving the group's financial stability. Global airlines warn that 25 million jobs could be at risk due to the travel downturn, and the European airline sector is ripe for consolidation.

site_title: For Singapore banks, a lesson on greater transparency from Jamie Dimon
summary: US bank JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon has released a 23-page shareholders' letter detailing how the bank is managing the COVID-19 crisis. The letter highlights the bank's efforts to support small businesses, with US$950 million in new loans extended in the past 60 days. Dimon also discussed the bank's capital position and potential dividend payouts. The letter emphasizes transparency and prudence in the face of uncertainty. Singapore banks can learn from JPMorgan's example and provide clearer information on their crisis management efforts, including credit extensions to needy customers and support for employees.

site_title: Japan declares coronavirus emergency, prepares ¥108t stimulus
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared a state of emergency to combat new coronavirus infections in major population centers, targeting Tokyo and six other prefectures. A stimulus package worth ¥108 trillion (S$1.41 trillion) was announced to cushion the economic blow, exceeding 20% of Japan's economic output. The package includes direct fiscal spending of ¥39 trillion, more than double the amount Japan spent after the 2008 Lehman Brothers collapse.

site_title: Bill passed to give temporary relief from contractual obligations
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Bill aims to provide temporary relief from contractual obligations caused by the coronavirus outbreak. Minister for Law K. Shanmugam emphasized that the principle of the sanctity of contracts remains important. The bill, which passed its second reading, offers relief only where the inability to discharge obligations is significantly impacted by Covid-19.

site_title: STI builds on strong start to the week to rise 4.1% to 2,571.89
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 4.1% to 2,571.89, its third-largest one-day gain in five years, driven by improved market sentiment and hopes of oil output cuts. The STI's 30 components saw gains, with City Developments and IREIT Global leading the charge. The improved mood is also bolstered by the Singapore government's Solidarity Budget and growing optimism over the West's slowing Covid-19 spread.

site_title: S$60b rescue package proof of optimal fiscal balance: Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat said Singapore's best response to the coronavirus pandemic is to build economic and social resilience through its S$60 billion rescue packages, which include S$48.4 billion in the Resilience Budget and S$5.1 billion in the Solidarity Budget. The packages aim to preserve viable companies' capabilities to recover and keep Singaporeans in their jobs. Heng emphasized the government's ability to maintain an optimal fiscal balance, with the support packages amounting to 12% of GDP, and vowed to continue efforts to position Singapore as a "global Asia node of technology, innovation and enterprise".

site_title: STI builds on strong start to the week, rises 4.1% on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 4.1% on Tuesday, finishing at 2,571.89 points, with all 30 benchmark counters gaining. The improved market sentiment is attributed to signs of slowing Covid-19 spread in the West and hopes of oil output cuts by major producers. The Singapore government's S$5.1 billion Solidarity Budget also boosted the mood, with Thailand's SET Index jumping 6.7% to close at 1,214.95.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) adjusts banks' capital requirements to ease requirements amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Minister K Shanmugam says the bill provides temporary relief to those affected by the virus. A proposed law allows special arrangements for voters and candidates affected by Covid-19 restrictions. Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rises 4.1% to 2,571.89.

site_title: US: Wall St jumps at open on coronavirus slowdown hopes
summary: US stocks surged at the opening bell on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 3.78% to 23,537.44, the S&P 500 gaining 2.81% to 2,738.65, and the Nasdaq Composite increasing 2.74% to 8,129.99. The jump was driven by early signs of a slowdown in coronavirus cases in US hot spots, raising hopes that lockdown measures are working.

site_title: Britain's supermarkets wrestle with coronavirus demand conundrum
summary: Britain's big supermarkets are struggling to meet the demand for food as the country remains under lockdown due to the coronavirus. With 60 million people to feed, they fear they cannot physically meet the demand without extending opening hours or relaxing social distancing rules. Despite efforts to increase online delivery capacity, supermarkets still need to serve 85% of the market through stores. Industry executives are considering radical measures, such as mandatory face masks, to get more shoppers in stores at any one time.

site_title: Fu Yu to continue Singapore operations during circuit-breaker period
summary: Fu Yu Corporation will continue its Singapore operations during the circuit-breaker period, receiving approval from the Ministry of Trade and Industry for an exemption. The company has implemented remote working arrangements and safe-distancing measures for employees. This decision allows Fu Yu to provide essential manufacturing services as part of the supply chain, enabling continued operations despite the government-imposed restrictions.

site_title: British PM condition deteriorates, moves to intensive care
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, 55, has been hospitalized in intensive care due to severe Covid-19 complications. He was admitted after suffering persistent symptoms for over 10 days, and his condition rapidly deteriorated, prompting Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab to take over the government. Johnson is receiving oxygen support and remains conscious, but the absence of the leader at a critical time has raised questions about who is in charge of the UK's economy. Johnson had asked Raab to deputize for him "where necessary" before his hospitalization.

site_title: Airlines cannot afford to refund cancelled tickets: IATA
summary: Global airlines cannot afford to refund cancelled flights due to the coronavirus crisis, according to IATA Director General Alexandre De Juniac. Airlines are instead issuing vouchers to conserve cash, with some facing criticism from consumer groups for not meeting refund deadlines. This decision is a financial necessity to avoid running out of cash, De Juniac stated, highlighting the industry's struggle to survive during the pandemic.

site_title: Samsung Q1 beats estimates; chips likely to prop up virus-hit Q2
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a slight rise in first-quarter operating profit, beating estimates, driven by solid chip sales amid the coronavirus pandemic's shift to working from home. Chip sales from laptop makers and data centers boosted revenue, while mobile and consumer electronics businesses suffered. Operating profit is expected to be 6.4 trillion won (S$7.5 billion), and revenue is forecast to rise 5% to 55 trillion won. Analysts expect the company's memory chip business to report better-than-expected results in the first half of the year, driven by rising demand from data centers.

site_title: 106 new Covid-19 cases, 39 linked to known clusters at foreign worker dormitories
summary: Singapore reported 106 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 1,481. Of the new cases, 39 are linked to known clusters at foreign worker dormitories, with 52 cases linked to existing clusters. Contact tracing is ongoing for the remaining 41 cases. 377 cases have fully recovered, and 33 patients were discharged. Most hospitalized cases (627) are stable or improving, with 29 in critical condition.

site_title: Pound rallies as risk appetite returns, traders await news on Johnson
summary: The British pound rallied on Tuesday as risk appetite returned, driven by a rebound in markets and traders awaiting news on Prime Minister Boris Johnson's condition. Johnson, 55, was moved into intensive care after his symptoms worsened, but analysts say his condition won't impact the pound's value. Sterling rose 1.2% against the dollar to US$1.2383, its highest since April 2. Government bonds attracted strong investor demand, with the UK aiming to sell a record US$55 billion this month.

images.alt_text: Sterling rallied on Tuesday with a broad rebound in risk markets encouraging some selling of the dollar, while traders awaited news on British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who is stable in intensive care as he battles Covid-19 symptoms.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 28.23 points to 1,369.92 on Tuesday, with a 900-134 gain-to-lose ratio. The index closed higher following a positive market trend.

site_title: US economy will eventually reopen but with big changes: Kudlow
summary: US economic adviser Larry Kudlow said the US economy will reopen when health experts give the go-ahead, but with significant changes. Americans will need to stay home when showing signs of sickness, undergo widespread testing, and submit to temperature checks. This new normal will be a permanent feature of American life, aiming to prevent future recurrences.

site_title: Europe: Shares climb as coronavirus cases slow
summary: European shares rose 2.7% on Tuesday, the second consecutive day of gains, as early signs of the coronavirus pandemic easing boosted investor confidence. The STOXX 600 index hit its highest level in almost a month, driven by tentative signs of slowing cases in Spain. Despite a long way to recover from the March low, the benchmark index has gained 22% since then.

site_title: UOB to shut 24 branches from April 11 to May 4
summary: UOB to close 24 branches in Singapore from April 11 to May 4 due to reduced customer footfall under stricter safe distancing measures. 38 branches will remain open, with most near essential services, and self-service machines and shared ATMs will remain operational. The bank's head of group channels and digitalisation assures customers that full banking services will continue during the "circuit-breaker" period. This move follows similar branch closures by DBS and OCBC.

site_title: SPH's H1 net profit down 9.3%, management warns of further disruption due to Covid-19
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported a 9.3% decline in net profit to S$77.6 million for the half-year ended Feb 29, 2020, due to a 20.4% drop in newspaper print advertisement revenue. The group's operating profit fell 15.3% to S$102.7 million, while the property segment recorded a 26.2% rise in revenue. SPH warned of further disruption due to the Covid-19 outbreak, citing lower footfall in retail malls and university closures in the UK. The group has reduced its interim dividend and will conserve cash to continue its digital transformation initiatives.

site_title: Olam's processing facilities to remain operational, staff on staggered shifts
summary: Olam International has announced it will keep processing facilities operational where local regulations allow, implementing health and safety precautions and staggered shift rotations to maintain business operations amid the coronavirus spread. The company is focusing on securing global supply chains and supporting smallholder farmers, communities, and customers. Olam has also raised S$1.3 million for Singapore's Courage Fund to provide relief for those affected by the crisis, with S$600,000 coming from employee donations. The company's shares rose 4.4% following the announcement.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up more than 2% on virus hopes
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index surged over 2% on Tuesday, following a strong rally on Wall Street, as countries with high coronavirus cases reported declining death rates. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 18,950.18, boosted by an unprecedented stimulus package worth 108 trillion yen. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is expected to confirm a state of emergency in seven regions, giving local authorities the power to request people stay at home.

site_title: Grow your own: Urban farming flourishes in coronavirus lockdowns
summary: Coronavirus lockdowns have spurred an increase in urban farming, with city dwellers growing their own fruit and vegetables at home. This trend is expected to provide a lasting boost to urban farming, addressing food security and nutrition concerns. Experts say urban farming can produce up to 10% of the global output of pulses and vegetables, and that cities have sufficient land for urban agriculture. The COVID-19 pandemic has also highlighted the importance of having a local food supply, with countries like Singapore aiming to produce 30% of their nutritional needs by 2030.

site_title: Yangzijiang's executive chairman steps down, CEO and son takes over
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's executive chairman Ren Yuanlin, 66, has stepped down to pursue other career opportunities. His son Ren Letian, 38, has taken over as executive chairman, succeeding his father since 2006. Yuanlin, who holds a 21.69% stake in the company, will cease to be an alternate director. His son has become the new CEO, marking a generational shift in the company's leadership.

site_title: The state of Chinese commodities shows recovery taking hold
summary: China's commodity industry is showing signs of recovery, with most of the country back to work and commodity demand increasing. Oil refineries and coal-fired power plants are nearing last year's operating rates, while metals stockpiles have shrunk. Construction activity and crude processing have also picked up, and China has reported zero new Covid-19 deaths for the first time since January. Key indicators include rising oil refinery throughput, increased coal burn, and declining metal stockpiles, signaling a return to normality in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Oil storage uneconomical despite hefty supplies as Brent futures strengthen
summary: Traders are putting plans to store oil on hold due to rising Brent crude futures, making storage uneconomical despite abundant supplies. The surge in front-month Brent crude prices, driven by expectations of a Saudi-Russia output deal, has created a disconnect between physical markets and physical supplies. The coronavirus pandemic has destroyed demand, leaving traders with unsold supplies from previous months.

site_title: DBS doubles SME digital business loan quantum to S$200,000
summary: DBS Bank has doubled the quantum of its digital business loan for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to S$200,000, providing more substantial working capital to weather the Covid-19 economic fall-out. The loan remains collateral-free and interest servicing for the first 12 months is waived. DBS also waives processing fees and offers a six-month principal repayment moratorium for existing SME property loans. The bank is onboarding over 70 food and beverage businesses for its DBS F&B Digital Relief Package and plans to introduce more targeted relief packages for different SME segments.

site_title: UK Foreign Minister in charge, will decide on lockdown measures
summary: UK Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab will run the country while Prime Minister Boris Johnson is in intensive care, making key decisions on lifting coronavirus lockdown restrictions. Raab will take the final decision collectively with the Cabinet, as planned by Johnson. No delay in the lockdown review decision is expected, according to Cabinet Office Minister Michael Gove.

site_title: UK housing market on hold due to coronavirus crisis: Halifax
summary: The UK housing market has come to a halt due to the coronavirus crisis, with Halifax reporting flat house prices in March after a 0.2% rise in February. Annual growth slowed to 3.0%, lower than forecast. The lockdown has led to reduced market activity, with most transactions paused, and economists expect a steep recession in the first half of 2020. While some predict a recovery once restrictions lift, others warn of a long-term impact on the market, citing reduced demand and increased unemployment.

site_title: Seoul: Shares extend gains on signs of coronavirus slowdown
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.77% on Tuesday, building on the previous day's 4% gain, as investors cautiously optimistic about the slowdown of the coronavirus pandemic in Europe. The KOSPI index closed at 1,823.60, despite being down 17% for the year. Foreign investors sold $126.09 million worth of shares, extending their sell-off to a 24th session.

site_title: Dubai extends closure of commercial activities until April 18
summary: Dubai has extended the closure of commercial activities until April 18 to contain the coronavirus. The two-week lockdown, initially set to end on April 4, was initially intended to run until April 18. Sectors exempt from the lockdown will operate as usual during this period.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks see another healthy rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 2.12% on Tuesday, following an Asia-wide advance and a rally on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 24,253.29, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose. Traders were optimistic about the slowing rate of coronavirus infections, driving the rally. This marks another healthy rally in Hong Kong stocks, following recent gains.

site_title: Saudi expects virus cases to spike up to 200,000
summary: Saudi Arabia's health minister warns of a potential surge in coronavirus cases to 200,000 within weeks, citing four studies predicting a range of 10,000 to 200,000 infections. The kingdom has already reported 2,795 cases and 41 deaths. To combat the spread, authorities have extended daily curfews in multiple cities, including Riyadh, and sealed off holy cities of Mecca and Medina. The kingdom is also scrambling to limit the economic impact of the virus, including suspending the umrah pilgrimage and halting flights.

images.alt_text: A general view shows almost empty streets, during the 24 hours lockdown to counter the coronavirus outbreak in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia .

site_title: Finnair's passenger numbers drop 56% in March
summary: Finnair reported a 56.4% drop in passenger numbers in March to 498,600 people, mainly due to the impact of the coronavirus. The airline attributed the decline to route and frequency cancellations, as well as travel restrictions.

images.alt_text: Finnair said on Tuesday its March passenger numbers fell 56.4 per cent year on year to 498,600 people due to the impact of the coronavirus.

site_title: StarHub channels $200,000 towards kids' online learning
summary: StarHub donates its $200,000 20th anniversary marketing budget to support needy individuals and families affected by Covid-19. The company will sponsor mobile broadband connectivity for 158 primary and secondary students from lower-income families, and the initiative will eventually benefit up to 550 students. This is part of StarHub's "StarHub Cares" Covid-19 Fund, which has a total of $750,000. The donation aims to bridge the digital divide and provide access to online learning for students during the pandemic.

site_title: South Africa's net foreign reserves fall to US$44.8b in March
summary: South Africa's net foreign reserves fell to US$44.77 billion in March, down from US$45.36 billion in February, according to Reserve Bank data. This decline is attributed to a decrease in gross reserves to US$52.458 billion. The central bank's forward position, representing unsettled or swap transactions, decreased to a balance of US$631 million. This move is likely due to economic pressures and currency fluctuations in the country.

site_title: Snapask, SPH offer students free online tutoring and news content
summary: Singapore-based education technology startup Snapask has partnered with media and property group Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) to provide primary and secondary school students with free online tutoring and news content. The partnership, launched ahead of a nationwide "circuit breaker" period, offers over 10,000 free subscriptions with online tutoring sessions and access to The Straits Times. The initiative aims to support home-based learning and cater to the increasing demand for digital, personalized educational solutions.

site_title: Cineworld closes all cinemas in 10 countries due to coronavirus
summary: Cineworld, the world's second-largest cinema operator, has closed all 787 cinemas across 10 countries due to the coronavirus pandemic. The company is in talks with lenders and other parties to mitigate the impact of the closures, including suspending dividend payments and negotiating with landlords and suppliers. This move comes as the pandemic continues to affect the global entertainment industry.

images.alt_text: British cinema operator Cineworld said on Tuesday all its 787 cinemas across 10 countries have been shut due to the coronavirus pandemic and that it was in talks with its lenders for ongoing liquidity requirements.

site_title: Adult PRs with Singaporean families get one-off cash payout of S$300
summary: Singapore's government has announced a one-off cash payout of S$300 to adult permanent residents with Singaporean parents, spouses, or children, as part of its economic support package amid the coronavirus crisis. The payout, along with other measures, aims to support Singaporean families and businesses, with a total budget of S$60 billion. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need to balance support for those in need with those who do not require immediate assistance, encouraging those who do not need the payout to consider donating or sharing with others.

site_title: Plus500 sees customer surge as lockdowns send financial traders home
summary: Online trading platform Plus500 Ltd nearly doubled its customer base in the first quarter of 2020, driven by a market sell-off and increased volatility, resulting in a 487% revenue rise to $316.6 million. The company's active customer base increased to 194,024 from 97,921. The surge in trading activity is attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic and investors scrambling to exit their positions, with many amateur traders drawn to the industry's mobile apps. Plus500 expects full-year results to be substantially ahead of current consensus.

site_title: Landlords should share pain, but tenants also shouldn't take advantage: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's Home Affairs and Law Minister K. Shanmugam has proposed a Bill to temporarily shield businesses from contractual obligations such as paying rent during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Bill will allow tenants to defer rental payments for up to six months and protect them from legal action or lease termination due to unpaid rent. However, landlords should not be unfairly burdened, and tenants should not take advantage of the situation, Shanmugam said. Tenants must show they are unable to pay rent due to a COVID-19 event, and landlords will benefit from government support packages and security deposits.

site_title: Taiwan bans government use of Zoom over cybersecurity concerns
summary: Taiwan has banned the use of video-conferencing app Zoom by its government due to cybersecurity concerns. The ban, which affects official agencies, comes amid growing security flaws and potential data routing through China, a country Taiwan disputes with over its sovereignty. The move is the latest blow to Zoom, which has seen an explosion in demand for its services during the pandemic. Google and Microsoft services have been deemed acceptable as alternatives. This ban follows similar actions by SpaceX and New York City's Department of Education.

site_title: Covid-19: DBS doubles SME digital business loan quantum to S$200,000
summary: DBS Bank has doubled the quantum of its digital business loan for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to S$200,000, making it collateral-free. The loan has a 12-month interest servicing period, and processing fees will be waived. This move aims to provide SMEs with more substantial working capital to weather the Covid-19 economic fall-out. DBS has also introduced other relief measures, including a six-month principal repayment moratorium and an extension of import facilities, to support SMEs during the pandemic.

site_title: Alaska to see lower revenue, weaker output on oil price slump: report
summary: Alaska's oil production and revenue are expected to decline due to the slump in oil prices, with the West Coast price for Alaska North Slope crude averaging $30 a barrel for the fiscal year ending June 30. This is a 19% drop from the earlier forecast and will result in a loss of over $1 billion in state revenues. North Slope production is expected to average 486,400 barrels per day in the current fiscal year and 486,500 barrels per day in the coming fiscal year, down from earlier forecasts.

site_title: Singapore enlists grounded air crew for virus prevention service
summary: Singapore Airlines and other aviation companies are teaming up with the government to deploy grounded pilots and staff as "ambassadors" to help prevent the spread of coronavirus. The pilots, who are making a salary, are handing out pamphlets and educating locals on safe distancing measures. This effort comes as Singapore enters a month-long partial lockdown to curb a sharp rise in cases. The government is also co-funding wages for workers in the hard-hit aviation sector and deploying staff to roles such as contact tracers and administrative jobs in hospitals.

site_title: 'Escape from Tokyo' hot topic in Japan as state of emergency looms
summary: Japan is set to impose a state of emergency in Tokyo and six other prefectures due to the steady rise of coronavirus cases, with over 1,000 new cases reported in the capital. The emergency, lasting until May 6, calls for people to stay home and businesses to close. The idea of "Escape from Tokyo" has gained traction on social media, with some residents fleeing to mountainous areas like Karuizawa, which has seen an increase in cars with Tokyo-area number plates.

site_title: France's Total sells assets in Brunei, Sierra Leone, Liberia
summary: Total, a French energy group, has sold assets in Brunei, Sierra Leone, and Liberia, valued at over $400 million. The company sold its Brunei subsidiary to Shell and its marketing and services businesses in Liberia and Sierra Leone to Conex Oil & Gas Holdings Ltd. These transactions support Total's action plan to weather the crisis amid low oil prices. Total's Chief Financial Officer, Jean-Pierre Sbraire, stated that the deals are part of the company's efforts to adapt to the current market conditions.

site_title: Hit by coronavirus, Fiat Chrysler, Peugeot seek to boost cash before merger
summary: Fiat Chrysler and Peugeot's owner PSA are seeking to boost cash reserves ahead of their planned merger due to the coronavirus outbreak's impact on car sales. The two companies have postponed shareholder meetings and are turning to banks for necessary cash, with Fiat Chrysler considering debt guarantees from the Italian government. The Italian government's scheme offers over 400 billion euros in liquidity and bank loans to companies affected by the pandemic. No decision has been made on the merger, but the companies are taking steps to secure their financial stability.

site_title: Need for temporary relief amid Covid-19 despite sanctity of contracts: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Bill aims to provide temporary relief from certain legal obligations amid the pandemic. The Bill, which applies to contracts entered into before March 25, 2020, provides relief for six months, with the possibility of extension. The relief applies where Covid-19 has had a material impact, but does not mandate immediate refunds or forgiveness. Instead, contracting parties are encouraged to come to fair agreements, with assessors appointed by the Ministry of Law making determinations in disputes. The Bill also provides additional safety nets for individuals and businesses.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend gains on glimmers of hope in virus fight
summary: Asian markets extended gains on Tuesday, driven by optimism over slowing coronavirus cases in key hotspots and plans to ease restrictions. Crude prices rose on hopes of output cuts by major producers. The rally followed a surge on Wall Street and was fueled by positive news from Spain, Germany, Italy, and France. The Singapore Stock Exchange notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Thailand says lockdown is slowing spread of novel coronavirus
summary: Thailand reported 38 new coronavirus cases, the smallest daily increase in about three weeks, with a total of 2,258 cases and 27 fatalities. Restrictions on daily life, including shutting down schools and bars, have slowed the spread of the disease, according to government officials. The country's benchmark stocks rose 5.3% as investors hope the virus crisis is easing. Thailand's prime minister said government measures have effectively slowed the spread, and there's less need for more stringent steps, citing cooperation from the public.

site_title: Britain's supermarkets wrestle with coronavirus demand conundrum
summary: Britain's big supermarkets, including Tesco, Sainsbury's, Asda, and Morrisons, are struggling to meet the demand for food due to the COVID-19 lockdown, with sales growth slowing as stores cut hours and restricted sales. Despite budgeting for a 15-20% rise in sales volumes, supermarkets fear they can't physically meet the demand under current social distancing rules, leading to concerns about extending opening hours or changing rules. The industry is recruiting staff and ramping up online delivery services to meet the demand, but supermarkets believe a more radical approach, such as mandatory face masks, may be needed.

site_title: Stock plunge gives South Korea business owners chance to save on succession costs
summary: South Korean business owners are taking advantage of the coronavirus-induced plunge in stock prices to transfer stakes to their children at minimal cost, reducing the burden of one of the world's highest rates of inheritance tax. The country's main stock price index, the Kospi, has fallen 35% since February, allowing owners to gift shares to the next generation without significant opposition. This move will lower inheritance tax bills, with some transfers saving up to 20 billion won in gift tax.

site_title: Australia: Shares finish lower on RBA outlook
summary: Australian shares fell 0.65% on Tuesday, led by financials and healthcare stocks, following the Reserve Bank of Australia's cautious outlook on the country's near-term economic fortunes. The central bank warned of a large economic contraction in the June quarter and a record-high unemployment rate. The S&P/ASX 200 index settled at 5,252.30, reversing early gains. Despite the RBA leaving its cash rate at a record low of 0.25%, the warning sent shares lower.

images.alt_text: Australian shares reversed course to end lower on Tuesday, with financials and healthcare stocks leading the decline after the central bank's cautious commentary on the country's near-term economic fortunes.

site_title: MMA promotion UFC close to securing private island for fights
summary: The UFC is close to securing a private island to stage international fights during the Covid-19 pandemic. UFC President Dana White has found a venue for UFC 249 on April 18 and plans to resume its calendar with weekly fights. To comply with travel restrictions, White will fly international fighters to the island for bouts. Fighters, support staff, and UFC crew will be tested regularly for the virus, and the organization aims to maintain its schedule despite the pandemic.

site_title: honestbee creditor Benjamin Lim applies to wind up company
summary: A court application has been filed by honestbee creditor Benjamin Lim to wind up the distressed startup, owing him US$3.8 million. The application will be heard on April 17. Honestbee's total debt stands at about US$230 million, with its sole secured creditor, Formation Group, holding all-monies charges for US$4 million. Employees will likely be paid ahead of creditors in a liquidation scenario. The startup's restructuring bid was dismissed by the court in March.

site_title: Swiss jobless rate rises in March, only small coronavirus impact so far
summary: Switzerland's unemployment rate rose to 2.9% in March, a 0.4 percentage point increase from February, despite the government's efforts to avoid coronavirus-related layoffs. The number of registered unemployed increased to 135,624. Meanwhile, around 1.3 million workers were put on shorter hours. Despite the increase, the impact of the coronavirus appears to be limited, with only 584 deaths and 22,000 positive cases reported in the country.

site_title: Proposed law to allow special arrangements for voters, candidates affected by Covid-19 restrictions
summary: Singapore is proposing a law to allow special arrangements for voters and candidates affected by Covid-19 restrictions, including voting outside their electoral divisions and registering as candidates without in-person presence. The Parliamentary Elections (Covid-19 Special Arrangements) Bill, introduced by Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing, aims to facilitate a safe general election while Covid-19 measures are in effect. The Bill will be debated in Parliament and take effect before the next general election, set to be held by April 14, 2021.

site_title: Toshiba should sell stake in ex-chip unit at IPO: Hong Kong activist fund
summary: A Hong Kong-based activist investor, Argyle Street Management, has urged Toshiba to sell its 40% stake in flash memory chip firm Kioxia Holdings, which could raise up to $32 billion in its IPO. The investor argues that selling the stake would benefit shareholders, as Toshiba has substantial headroom for share buybacks. Toshiba has not decided on the matter, but has a tacit understanding with the government not to sell down the stake until an IPO. The IPO is set to be Japan's biggest listing this year, despite market uncertainty due to the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Japan households gloomiest on outlook since 2008: BOJ survey
summary: Japanese households are the most pessimistic on their economic outlook since 2008, according to a Bank of Japan survey. The survey found an index of -42.2, down from -32.6 in December, indicating households expect prices to rise and their economic situation to worsen. This is the lowest level since December 2008, adding to concerns about the economy's resilience amidst the coronavirus pandemic.

images.alt_text: Japanese households were the gloomiest on the economic outlook since the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008, a quarterly central bank survey for March showed on Tuesday, adding to woes for an economy feeling the strain from the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: MAS to adjust banks' capital requirements amid Covid-19 pandemic
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced measures to adjust banks' capital and liquidity requirements to help them sustain lending activities amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The changes allow financial institutions to consider government fiscal assistance and relief measures when setting loan loss allowances. Implementation of new regulations, such as Basel III reforms, will also be deferred to ease operational burdens. The moves aim to enable banks to focus on supporting customers and responding to the virus outbreak.

site_title: China's big developers shrug off short-term virus impact to splurge on land
summary: China's top developers are increasing land purchases despite the ongoing coronavirus impact, citing a faster-than-expected sales recovery and abundant liquidity. Major property companies plan to ramp up spending, while others maintain purchasing levels similar to last year, as they remain confident in long-term demand for housing. Local governments are selling prime real estate to boost revenues, and smaller firms are offloading assets. This surge in spending is expected to test demand for housing in the market.

site_title: GSV bids US$2.5b for Malaysia Airlines, says funded by European bank
summary: Privately held Golden Skies Ventures (GSV) has made a US$2.5 billion offer to fully take over Malaysia Airlines' holding company. GSV secured financing from a European bank, with plans to finalize the deal within 3-4 months. The proposal comes as airlines worldwide face challenges due to the coronavirus pandemic. Former Malaysia Airlines officials and professionals with aviation experience established GSV, which aims to restructure the struggling carrier.

site_title: ACRA, SGX RegCo give companies more time to hold AGMs
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) and Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) are extending the time for companies to hold annual general meetings (AGMs) and file annual returns due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Listed and non-listed companies with AGMs due between April 16 and July 31 are given a 60-day extension, while those with annual return filing due dates between May 1 and August 31 will also receive an extension. The agencies will not impose penalties on companies holding AGMs within 60 days of their due dates.

site_title: S&P lowers Brazil outlook to 'stable,' but door still open to upgrade
summary: S&P Global Ratings lowered its outlook on Brazil's sovereign debt to "stable" due to huge government spending to combat the coronavirus, but still sees a higher chance of an upgrade than a downgrade. The fiscal deficit is expected to double to 12% of GDP, and the government's non-investment grade rating remains at BB-. The agency cites uncertainty surrounding Brazil's economic and fiscal road ahead, including political tensions, as a reason for its cautious stance. A credit rating upgrade is still possible, but a downgrade is less likely.

site_title: Airbus struggles to gauge how much scaling back is too much
summary: Airbus struggles to balance production cuts amid the coronavirus crisis, which has led to a historic contraction in civil aviation. The company warned of reduced earnings and production, citing a decline in demand and grounded airline fleets. Airbus must carefully gauge the impact of reduced output on suppliers and its own cash flow, as a too-aggressive cut could harm its advantage over Boeing. The company is exploring operational measures to minimize cash outflows and has built a 30 billion-euro liquidity buffer. Airbus's CEO, Guillaume Faury, has preached patience, but analysts predict a difficult recovery for the industry.

site_title: Sergio Rossi, Italian shoemaker and ready-to-wear ally, dies at 84
summary: Italian shoemaker Sergio Rossi, 84, has died from coronavirus in Cesena, Italy. Born into a bespoke shoemaker family, Rossi joined the business in the 1950s and introduced a namesake line in 1968, becoming a major figure in the Italian footwear industry. Rossi's eponymous brand continues to operate, with the company stating the cause of death was coronavirus. Rossi's legacy as a pioneering Italian shoemaker will be remembered.

site_title: 8 stores in Singapore warned for flouting safe-distancing rules
summary: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) has issued advisory letters to 8 businesses in Singapore for failing to comply with safe-distancing measures amid the coronavirus pandemic. The establishments, including 4 bubble tea shops and a retailer, were found not to be observing safe-distancing measures "adequately" despite repeated reminders. Errant operators face prosecution under the Infectious Diseases Act if non-compliance is repeated. ESG will deploy 200 "safe-distancing ambassadors" to monitor compliance with tightened measures, including closure of non-essential services and a ban on dining-in.

site_title: Hong Kong consumer lender PrimeCredit explores sale
summary: Hong Kong consumer lender PrimeCredit Ltd is exploring a potential sale, working with HSBC Holdings Plc, with a valuation of $500 million to $1 billion. The company, known for its advertising campaign, focuses on origination of personal loans and credit cards in Hong Kong and southern China. A formal auction may not occur until the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on the business is assessed. The sale comes after PrimeCredit was acquired by China Travel Financial Holdings Co, Pepper Group Pty, and York Capital Management Global Advisors LLC in 2015 for over $600 million.

site_title: Australia job ads dive most in decade, taste of pain to come
summary: Australian job advertisements plummeted 10.3% in March, the largest drop in over a decade, amid strict social distancing measures and business closures due to the coronavirus. This decline is forecast to lead to a spike in unemployment, potentially reaching 10%, the highest since the 1990s. However, a government "JobKeeper" subsidy is expected to mitigate the worst effects. The Reserve Bank of Australia has also lowered interest rates to 0.25% and launched a bond buying program to support the economy.

site_title: China Three Gorges eyes 25b yuan IPO with renewables listing
summary: China Three Gorges Renewables Group plans to raise 25 billion yuan (S$5.06 billion) through an initial public offering (IPO) in Shanghai, listing its 10 gigawatt renewable assets, including solar and wind farms. The IPO would be the second-largest in China this year, following Beijing-Shanghai High Speed Railway's US$4.3 billion debut. The company aims to boost its power capacity, improve profitability, and enhance competitiveness with the IPO funds, which will also be used for working capital and seven offshore wind farms.

site_title: Roku launches ad-funded streaming channel in 'stay-at-home' Britain
summary: Roku Inc launched its ad-funded streaming channel in Britain, offering over 10,000 free movies, TV episodes, and documentaries. The Roku Channel features British series and Hollywood hits, as well as children's content. The move aims to supplement subscription services like Netflix and Disney+, with ad-supported viewing growing rapidly on the platform. Roku's vice president, Rob Holmes, sees the trend as accelerating, presenting a long-term opportunity for advertisers to reach audiences shifting away from linear TV.

site_title: New Zealand's central bank adds local government debt to stimulus plan
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), announced it will purchase up to NZ$3 billion of local government debt to ease liquidity strains in the funding market amid the coronavirus pandemic. This move expands the Large Scale Asset Purchase (LSAP) programme, which has been buying government debt since 2019. The RBNZ aims to cushion the economy from the pandemic's fallout. The decision comes after observing signs of increasing illiquidity and dislocation in the Local Government Funding Agency (LGFA) market.

images.alt_text: New Zealand's central bank on Tuesday said it would buy up to NZ$3 billion (S$2.56 billion) of local government debt to ease liquidity strains in the funding market as it moves to cushion the economy from the fallout of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: UK restaurants find new recipes for success amid virus
summary: UK restaurants are adapting to the COVID-19 pandemic by reinventing themselves as delivery services and mobile greengrocers. Many have turned to delivering ingredients to local homes, while others offer fresh produce and meals to customers. Businesses like Mercato Metropolitano and Natoora are expanding their operations to meet the demand, with some maintaining up to 95% of their usual revenue. This shift is helping restaurants survive the economic impact of the virus, with some even turning into accidental greengrocers.

site_title: Gold rallies, spread balloons as investors charge into bullion
summary: Gold prices surged, reaching a 7-year high, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid the coronavirus pandemic's economic fallout. Futures rallied 2.9% to $1,742.60 an ounce, while spot gold rose 0.3% to $1,665.85 an ounce. The jump came despite signs of a potential slowdown in the outbreak, with JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon warning of a major downturn. Central banks' unprecedented stimulus efforts have fueled the rally, with a US$1 trillion stimulus bill expected in the US.

site_title: Major US banks aim to keep shareholders happy amid crisis
summary: Major US banks plan to continue paying dividends to shareholders despite an unprecedented economic crisis, citing their strong financial position. The banks argue they have built capital and liquidity since the 2008 financial crisis and can finance the economy while paying shareholders. The Federal Reserve has not objected to the plans, but some analysts warn of potential implications for the economy, including increased loan losses that could force dividend cuts.

site_title: US dollar is still king, even as coronavirus slams US
summary: The US dollar has maintained its value despite the COVID-19 pandemic, rising 6% from its lowest point in early March. The dollar's privileged position as the world's reserve currency, combined with the US Federal Reserve's injection of trillions of dollars into the financial system, has fueled its strength. Demand for safety and cash by companies and emerging markets has also driven the dollar's appeal, particularly against the euro, Russian ruble, Canadian dollar, and Norwegian krone. Experts warn that the pandemic may reshuffle the global economic landscape, but for now, the dollar remains the king.

site_title: Joys of (virtual) Spring: Cambridge University streams online garden tours
summary: Cambridge University Botanic Garden has started free virtual tours to showcase its 8,000-plus species during the UK's lockdown. The weekly "wellness wanders" are short videos featuring gardeners describing plants and their surroundings.
