The Penang factory resumed operations on April 6, adhering to strict measures, while the California factory reopened on the same day at a "limited level" to maintain US federal critical-infrastructure sector continuity. Shares rose 4.07% to S$0.64.

site_title: Grab halves commissions for drivers, lowers criteria for weekly payout scheme
summary: Grab is halving its commission rate for private-hire drivers from April 6 to May 4 in response to the Covid-19 circuit-breaker measures. Drivers who rent cars from Grab's vehicle rental arm will also receive an additional 50% commission reduction. These moves are seen as a way to support drivers amid reduced demand.

site_title: SEB's Swedish housing sentiment indicator plunges in April to -20 points
summary: SEB's Swedish housing sentiment indicator plummeted to -20 points in April, the lowest mark in a single month, due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on employment. This represents a significant drop from 47 points in March. The indicator measures the balance between those expecting rising prices and those seeing falling prices over the coming year. SEB economist Jens Magnusson attributed the drop to households' pessimistic expectations, which can be self-fulfilling.

site_title: Swedish airline BRA applies for court-administered reorganisation
summary: Swedish airline BRA has applied for a court-administered reorganisation due to a significant decline in demand caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The privately held airline, which operates mostly domestic flights, had temporarily discontinued flights from April 6 to May 31. Applying for reorganisation allows the court to appoint a trustee to restructure the company and avoid bankruptcy. This move comes as the airline faces financial difficulties due to reduced passenger traffic.

site_title: Solidarity Budget: Government's response to Covid-19 to cost S$59.9b
summary: The Singapore government has announced a Solidarity Budget to support businesses and households during the COVID-19 crisis, totaling S$59.9 billion. This includes S$6.4 billion from Budget 2020, S$48.4 billion from the Resilience Budget, and S$5.1 billion from the Solidarity Budget. The packages are equivalent to 12% of the country's GDP, increasing the overall budget deficit to S$44.3 billion or 8.9% of GDP for FY2020. The government plans to seek Parliament's approval for additional spending measures.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end nearly 4% higher as virus slows, oil recovers
summary: South Korean shares rose nearly 4% on Monday, their largest gain in over a week, as the coronavirus crisis showed signs of slowing down. The Kospi index ended up 66.44 points, or 3.85%, at 1,791.88. Oil prices recovered, boosting investor sentiment, while a slowdown in new cases and deaths in major European nations eased risk-averse sentiment. The won strengthened, while bond yields fell, with the benchmark 10-year yield dropping 1.3 basis points to 1.534%.

site_title: Changi Airport suspends operations at T2 for 18 months
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore is suspending operations at Terminal 2 for 18 months due to the coronavirus crisis. The suspension starts on May 1, with airlines relocating to the remaining terminals. This move aims to save costs and speed up upgrading works at T2, potentially shortening the project time by up to a year.

site_title: Dubai's Emaar suspends construction projects due to virus: sources
summary: Emaar Properties, a major developer in Dubai, has suspended construction projects due to the coronavirus pandemic, exacerbating the city's real-estate slowdown. The move follows Dubai's proposal to delay Expo, a major event set to take place from October. The city's property market has struggled in the past decade due to the global financial crisis and weak oil prices. The pandemic's impact on Dubai's economy is the latest blow to the already struggling real-estate sector.

site_title: NTUC to help administer applications, appeals for self-employed income relief
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) will help administer applications and appeals for the Self-Employed Person Income Relief Scheme (SIRS) starting April 20. Eligible self-employed Singaporeans will receive three quarterly cash payouts of S$3,000 each. The NTUC Secretary-General Ng Chee Meng announced the move in response to concerns from freelancers and self-employed individuals about the initial criteria. The eligibility criteria has also been broadened to include properties with annual value up to S$21,000.

site_title: Virus scrapped your marathon? In Japan, there's an app for that
summary: In response to the cancellation of marathons in Japan due to the coronavirus pandemic, event organizers have introduced two apps to allow runners to complete the marathons alone, tracked online. Registered participants can run anywhere, keeping a safe distance, and the apps measure and verify their performance. Two apps are available, one for a single run and another for completing the marathon over several days. Runners who complete the marathon through the app will receive a T-shirt and necklace, and organizers aim to respond to the spirit shown by those who trained for the now-cancelled races.

site_title: Philippines' Nickel Asia to resume ore shipments as coronavirus mining ban lifted
summary: Nickel Asia Corp, the Philippines' largest nickel ore miner and exporter, has announced the resumption of ore shipments from its two units in Surigao del Norte province after the local government lifted its suspension to curb the spread of the coronavirus. The resumption follows a ban on mining operations from April 1. The company will ensure that foreign vessels chartered to deliver ores adhere to quarantine guidelines. The move is expected to supply ore to Chinese nickel pig iron producers and smelters.

site_title: BMW Q1 sales slump as coronavirus hits all markets
summary: BMW's first-quarter car deliveries sank 21% to 477,111 due to the coronavirus pandemic, with the brand's sales down 20.1% and group sales down 20.6%. European carmakers have closed production lines, with BMW's scheduled to reopen on April 20th. The pandemic has significantly impacted the global automotive industry, with over 800,000 jobs dependent on the sector's economic engine.

site_title: Solidarity Budget: Third round of measures will not burden future generations, says DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat said Singapore has the plans and financial resources to implement the Solidarity Budget without burdening future generations. He emphasized the importance of trust and confidence in the government, urging citizens to support measures to combat the Covid-19 pandemic. The government has taken "bold and swift" actions, and Heng reminded everyone to be socially responsible, stay home, stay safe, and stay healthy to help stem the escalating infections.

site_title: Apple to ship 1m face shields a week for medical workers
summary: Apple plans to produce 1 million face shields a week for medical workers, with initial distribution focused on the US, to help address the global shortage caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The company has also sourced 20 million surgical masks worldwide. Apple's transparent protective face shield design is being mass-produced at US and Chinese factories, with shipments expected to begin by the end of this week. This move joins other global firms, such as Prada, in modifying production lines to meet demand for protective gear.

site_title: US blacklist hurt China AI giant's sales ahead of IPO attempt
summary: Megvii Technology, a Chinese AI giant, saw its revenue growth hindered by US sanctions in 2019, with sales increasing only 2.7% in the second half of the year after tripling in the first six months. The company, backed by Alibaba Group and Lenovo, had been among China's fastest-growing startups but was added to the US blacklist over alleged involvement in human rights violations. This led to a delay in orders and shipments, and ultimately forced Megvii to cancel its attempt to go public with a $1 billion IPO.

site_title: Norwegian Air's March traffic tumbles 60% amid virus lockdown
summary: Norwegian Air's passenger volume plummeted 60% in March due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with 85% of flights canceled and 90% of staff furloughed. The airline is heavily in debt and has seen its Oslo-listed shares plunge 78% this year. Norwegian is seeking financial aid from Norway's government and will postpone debt repayments to qualify for a rescue package. The company had previously set a goal of returning to profit this year, but has scrapped this goal amid the crisis. CEO Jacob Schram is seeking access to cash liquidity "within weeks, not months."

images.alt_text: Norwegian Air's passenger volume fell by 60 per cent year on year in March as the company gradually grounded its fleet amid global efforts to halt the spread of the novel coronavirus.

site_title: Emirates Airline seeks billions in loans after virus hit
summary: Emirates Airline is seeking billions of dollars in loans on top of a Dubai state bailout due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on air travel. The airline is discussing bilateral loans with local and international banks, aiming to secure additional funding beyond the undisclosed government aid. Emirates, the world's largest long-haul airline, is struggling with a collapse in air travel and potential revenue loss of over $250 billion. The airline's fleet operates over 500 flights daily, and state-owned carriers in the Middle East have an advantage in securing bailout packages.

site_title: Japan considering 6-month period for state of emergency: media
summary: Japan is considering a 6-month state of emergency due to the coronavirus pandemic, covering Tokyo and three neighboring prefectures, as well as Osaka. The government plans to announce the emergency as early as Tuesday, with prefectures deciding their individual measures within the six-month period.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rebounded on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 2.5% and the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices jumping 3.9% and 3.4%, respectively. This rebound comes as some of the world's worst-hit countries report falling death rates from the novel coronavirus. The gains are attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, which are seen as less affected by the pandemic. The positive momentum is expected to continue, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

images.alt_text: Price information displayed on a screen in the atrium of the London Stock Exchange. In initial deals, London's benchmark FTSE 100 index of major blue-chip companies was up 2.5 per cent to 5,552.32 points compared with Friday's closing level.

site_title: Solidarity Budget: More self-employed persons to get cash payouts under expanded criteria
summary: Singapore's Self-Employed Person Income Relief Scheme (SIRS) will automatically include self-employed persons who also earn a small income from employment work, with a ceiling of S$21,000. The current Annual Value threshold will also be raised. The expansion aims to support approximately 100,000 self-employed individuals, with the goal of helping them contribute to their networks and workers. The Ministry of Manpower will process appeals for SIRS as soon as possible.

site_title: MAS names Celine Sia as assistant MD to head new knowledge management department
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) appointed Celine Sia as assistant managing director (economics & knowledge management) on April 6, 2020, with effect. She will head the newly-formed enterprise knowledge department, overseeing the economic analysis and forecasting departments, to strengthen knowledge and data management in MAS.

site_title: Japan celebrity redesigns 'Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen' song as hand washing melody
summary: Japanese social media celebrity Pikotaro has created a hand washing melody based on his 2016 viral song 'Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen'. The new song, titled 'Pray-for-People-and-Peace', was released as a way to promote proper hand hygiene during the coronavirus pandemic. The video, featuring Pikotaro wearing the same gold animal print outfit as his original song, became a leading Twitter trend in Japan. The move aims to reuse his popular song in a meaningful way during a time of global health crisis.

images.alt_text: Japanese social media celebrity Pikotaro returned as a leading twitter trend in Japan with a coronavirus hand washing song that repurposes his signature Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen (PPAP) to Pray-for-People-and-Peace.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up over 4% on slowing virus death toll
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 4.24% to 18,576.30, driven by reports of a slowing daily death toll from coronavirus in Europe. The Topix index also jumped 3.86% to 1,376.30. The positive reaction was attributed to investors' optimism about the decline in virus-related deaths, which could ease restrictions and boost economic growth.

site_title: Samsung will offer clues on how Covid-19 is roiling global tech
summary: Samsung Electronics is expected to release its preliminary earnings, revealing the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the global tech industry in the first three months of 2020. The company's semiconductor unit, which accounts for more than half of its operating profits, is forecast to miss its revenue projections by a double-digit percentage if the pandemic persists. Despite initial growth in demand for memory chips, chip demand is expected to be reduced due to negative economic impact, particularly in smartphone sales. Analysts project a 12.3% decline in Samsung's revenue in the June quarter, with some predicting the company may miss its 2020 revenue projections.

site_title: CapitaLand reopens all China malls, posts rise in residential sales
summary: CapitaLand has reopened all its malls in China after previously shutting them due to the coronavirus lockdown. About 80% of stores were operational by end-March, and residential sales for the month exceeded 1.3 billion yuan (S$263.6 million). The company reported healthy figures since reopening sales offices, indicating sustained underlying demand for new homes. CapitaLand's shares rose 5.7% after the announcement, with its China portfolio showing improvements in business activity and footfall in March.

site_title: Solidarity Budget: S$5.1b package to be funded by S$4b of past reserves
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a S$5.1 billion Solidarity Budget to support households and businesses during the four-week circuit breaker period due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The budget includes wage offsets, self-employed income relief, foreign worker levy waivers, rental waivers, and a S$600 cash payout for all adult Singaporeans. The additional support for businesses and workers will cost S$4 billion, with S$1.1 billion coming from past reserves.

site_title: Short-form streaming platform Quibi goes live as consumers stay at home
summary: Quibi, a short-form streaming platform backed by major studios, launched on April 6, 2020, amidst the coronavirus pandemic. The service offers short comedies, dramas, and entertainment for on-the-go smartphone users, with 50 shows available at launch and 175 originals in the works. Quibi aims to appeal to audiences with time to watch content at home, with a monthly subscription of $5 with ads or $8 ad-free. Despite the pandemic's disruption, Quibi's founders believe the service can still find strong appeal with young audiences.

site_title: Solidarity Budget: Further S$4b draw on reserves to fund third package
summary: Singapore's third round of COVID-19 measures, the Solidarity Budget, will cost S$5.1 billion, with S$4 billion for business support and S$1.1 billion for the Solidarity Payment. The government will draw on S$4 billion from past reserves to fund the bulk of the budget, with the remaining S$1.1 billion funded from fiscal space. This is the third round of measures introduced to help the country tide over the pandemic, following the Resilience Budget and previous rounds.

site_title: Indian rice exports suspended on supply chain disruption -industry
summary: Indian rice exports have been suspended due to supply chain disruptions caused by the nationwide lockdown to combat coronavirus. Labour shortages and logistics issues have hindered the delivery of existing contracts, allowing rival countries like Thailand to raise shipments and lift global prices, affecting millions of poor consumers in Africa. The halt in exports has also led to higher prices for rice in the global market.

site_title: Solidarity Budget: April's foreign worker levy waived
summary: Singapore's government will waive the April foreign worker levy, aiming to ease labor costs during the circuit breaker period to slow coronavirus transmission. The Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister, Heng Swee Keat, announced the move as part of the third economic relief package. Employers will receive a rebate of S$750 for each foreign worker, to be paid as early as April 21. The measure is intended to support firms in resuming operations quickly after the circuit breaker period ends.

site_title: Indonesia's RaRa Delivery raises S$1.2m in seed round led by 500 Startups
summary: Indonesia-based same-day delivery provider RaRa Delivery has raised S$1.2 million in a seed round led by 500 Startups and a syndicate from AngelCentral. The funds will be used to expand the company's operations and become the market leader in the same-day delivery space. This investment aims to enhance talent acquisition in business development, operations, and technology.

site_title: Asia: Markets lifted by hopes on virus but oil in retreat
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday as some countries reported declining coronavirus cases, lifting spirits and hopes for a path out of lockdowns. Italy reported its lowest daily toll in two weeks, while Spain and France also saw declines. South Korea saw its fewest new cases in six weeks, and US President Trump said the country was stabilizing. However, oil prices retreated after a meeting of top producers was delayed, and investors remain cautious about the long tunnel ahead.

site_title: Stay home and karaoke: Tencent's JOOX sees usage spike in Southeast Asia
summary: Tencent's JOOX sees a 30-50% spike in karaoke usage in Southeast Asia due to lockdowns and travel restrictions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The platform's karaoke feature allows users to sing along with friends and receive virtual gifts, driving revenue. JOOX is competing with YouTube Music and Spotify for the top spot in music streaming services in the region. The platform's usage has also been boosted by the launch of cloud conferencing tool VooV Meeting and the growing demand for online education tools.

images.alt_text: Lockdowns and travel retrictions prompted by the new coronavirus have been a boon to JOOX, Chinese tech giant Tencent's international music streaming platform, driving traffic to its karaoke services up by as much as 50 per cent, an executive said.

site_title: Japan animal ventilator maker looks to boost output for human coronavirus patients
summary: A Japanese medical equipment maker, Metran Co, has been approached by Japan's government to mass produce its animal ventilators to treat people diagnosed with the new coronavirus. The company has expressed interest in producing 5,000 to 15,000 ventilators and is considering licensing the product for overseas firms to manufacture. Other countries, including the US, Britain, and India, have also shown interest. The move aims to address the global shortage of ventilators, which are in short supply in countries hardest hit by COVID-19.

site_title: Asian firms rush to meet US$69b in Q2 debt refinancing
summary: Asian companies are rushing to refinance their US$69.3 billion in Q2 debt, with some of China's largest state-owned enterprises, such as Sinopec Group and State Grid, seeking new funding. The region's capital markets remain turbulent due to the coronavirus pandemic, but debt markets are performing well globally. Lower-rated companies may face trouble refinancing, while corporates with diversified funding sources are more likely to succeed. The Asian market lags behind the US and Europe, with central banks' moves to allow increased credit purchases contributing to the disparity.

site_title: CIMB offers relief to Singapore retail customers amid virus outbreak
summary: CIMB Bank Singapore offers relief to retail customers amid the coronavirus outbreak, extending payment deferral for mortgage loans until Dec 31, 2020, and providing a relief loan option for unsecured debt. Eligible customers can also defer loan payments for renovation and education loans, with income loss of at least 25% after Feb 1. The bank also offers a GrabFood promotion for credit card holders. The measures are part of CIMB's Covid-19 Care Package, aiming to support customers with varying financial segments.

site_title: American joins United, others in suspending more NYC flights on coronavirus spike
summary: American Airlines suspended more flights in and out of NYC's three main airports until May 6 due to a spike in coronavirus cases. The airline now operates 13 daily flights from April 9, down from 271 in April 2019. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued a warning against non-essential travel to the area, contributing to declining demand.

site_title: Solidarity Budget: More rental support for govt's industrial, office, agri tenants
summary: Singapore's government has announced a new Solidarity Budget, increasing rental waivers for industrial, office, and agricultural tenants of government agencies to one month, up from half-month. Stallholders in hawker centres will continue to receive three months of waivers, while commercial tenants will receive two months. The government also introduced a 100% property tax rebate for non-residential properties for 2020, and a bill to defer contractual obligations, including rent payments, for businesses and individuals.

site_title: Solidarity Budget: All firms to get 75% wage subsidies under enhanced Jobs Support Scheme
summary: Singapore will provide a 75% wage subsidy of up to S$4,600 for local employees under the enhanced Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) for April 2020. The subsidy will be paid in two tranches, with the first payout in April and the second in July. The scheme aims to help workers retain their jobs and enable businesses to resume operations quickly. The wage cap of S$4,600 is based on the Republic's median wage level, and firms will receive the subsidy regardless of their employees' earnings.

site_title: Singapore firms' payment performance in Q1 worst since 2016: SCCB
summary: Singapore firms' payment performance in Q1 2020 hit its lowest since 2016, with prompt payments at 43.20% and slow payments at 45.80%, according to the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau. The services and manufacturing sectors saw the largest year-on-year increases in slow payment. Experts expect a continued downtrend in payment performance due to increased risk of payment delinquency.

site_title: Solidarity Budget: S$600 cash payout for all Singaporeans above 21
summary: Singapore will provide a one-off cash payout of S$600 to all adult citizens above 21 as part of a third economic rescue package to support businesses and households during the coronavirus pandemic. The payment, comprising S$300 from the Care and Support cash payout and an additional S$300, will be credited directly into bank accounts by April 14, 2020, provided account details have been submitted to the government.

site_title: 'We're not hungry, we need masks' says Australian doctor on coronavirus frontline
summary: Australian hospital workers on the coronavirus frontline are struggling to obtain proper respiratory face masks, despite the general public wearing them. Doctors and nurses are forced to use makeshift face shields, with some even using scuba gear, due to a global shortage of N95 masks. The healthcare workers union has sent a petition to Prime Minister Scott Morrison, demanding access to safe PPE, and a stockpile of 10 million masks has been released for healthcare workers. Authorities claim public hospitals have sufficient PPE, but the healthcare workers lack confidence in the distribution and availability of masks.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars inch up, bond sale draws strong demand
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose slightly on Monday, with the Aussie up 0.4% to US$0.6020, while the kiwi dollar held steady at US$0.5876. The moves were driven by slowing death rates in countries affected by the coronavirus, lifting share markets across Asia.

site_title: MAS to release data on forex intervention this month
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will release data on its foreign exchange intervention operations in April, three months ahead of schedule, to provide more timely information. The data, which includes the central bank's net purchase of forex from July 1, 2019 to December 31, 2019, will be published on its website this Thursday. MAS will subsequently release such data every six months, on the first business day of April and October, to align with its monetary policy cycle.

site_title: Trump open to big oil tariffs, but doesn't expect to need them
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed openness to imposing "very substantial tariffs" on oil imports if prices remain low, but does not expect to need them. The oil price war between Russia and Saudi Arabia has led to a two-thirds drop in oil prices this year. Trump believes Russia and Saudi Arabia would not benefit from continued low prices, which are their major sources of income. He reiterated support for the oil sector, but energy interests oppose tariffs, fearing increased costs for importing crude and materials.

site_title: Virus-hit Carnival cruise ship docks in Australia as country's death toll hits 39
summary: The Ruby Princess cruise ship, linked to Australia's highest number of COVID-19 cases, docked in Sydney, Australia, to provide medical treatment for crew members. Over 1,000 crew members remain on board after passengers disembarked without health checks. At least 360 cases and six deaths have been reported, with the ship under investigation by New South Wales' homicide squad. The Ruby Princess has been the source of a significant number of infections in Australia, with its crew and passengers requiring urgent medical attention.

images.alt_text: Carnival Corp's troubled Ruby Princess cruise liner, the biggest single source of coronavirus infections in Australia, docked south of Sydney on Monday to get help for sick crew members requiring urgent medical treatment.

site_title: Coronavirus sparks boom for local farmers in import-dependent Hong Kong
summary: Hong Kong residents are shifting towards local produce amid the COVID-19 pandemic, sparking a boom for local farmers. The city, reliant on 98% imports, saw a significant increase in demand for locally grown vegetables. The pandemic has prompted a reevaluation of Hong Kong's food production, with some advocating for a shift away from global imports and towards self-sufficiency. Local farmers are seeing increased business, with some reporting doubled takings since the outbreak. Experts see the pandemic as an opportunity for Hong Kong to rethink its reliance on external food sources and become more resilient to global crises.

site_title: Swiss face shortage of ethanol for disinfectant after abandoning stockpile
summary: Switzerland is facing a shortage of ethanol, a raw material needed for disinfectant, due to abandoning its 10,000-tonne emergency stockpile in 2018. The decision to privatize the country's alcohol market led to the depletion of the stockpile, prompting distilleries and breweries to produce ethanol for disinfectant. Swiss politicians are frustrated by the move, with some calling for investment in emergency reserves rather than a 6 billion Swiss franc purchase of fighter jets, which they say is a more pressing need during the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Singapore M&A activity down 22.4% to US$10.2b in Q1: Mergermarket
summary: Singapore's M&A activity fell 22.4% to US$10.2 billion in Q1 2020, with a 30% decline in deal count to 21 deals. This trend is consistent with regional and global M&A activity, which was impacted by the Covid-19 outbreak. The Asia-Pacific excluding Japan saw a 32% drop in deal value and 616 deals, the lowest quarterly value since Q1 2013. Private equity dealmaking declined 54.2% in deal value to US$9.4 billion, while global M&A activity fell 39.1% to US$563.7 billion.

site_title: Solidarity Budget: Government risk share of loans raised from 80% to 90%
summary: Singapore's government is raising its risk share of loans from 80% to 90% for three bridging loan programmes to support firms amid the coronavirus crisis. The change applies to loans initiated from April 8, 2020, to March 31, 2021. The measures aim to provide relief to Singaporean businesses affected by the pandemic. Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the Solidarity Budget in Parliament, aiming to support the country's economy during the crisis.

site_title: Fullerton Health fully redeems US$175m perps on first call date
summary: Fullerton Health Corp redeemed its US$175 million senior, unsecured perpetual capital securities in full on April 6, 2020, marking the company's "financial resilience and commitment to stakeholders amid economic uncertainty from the Covid-19 pandemic." The redemption was funded by internal and external resources, allowing the company to maintain its financial stability. The move also underscores Fullerton Health's diversification strategy across markets and services, enabling it to adapt to the pandemic's impact on the healthcare industry.

site_title: SIA, SIA Engg, Scoot and SATS to send 17,500 staff for skills upgrading
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA), SIA Engineering, Scoot, and SATS have committed to sending 17,500 staff members for skills upgrading due to widespread flight suspensions amid the Covid-19 pandemic. This translates to over 39,500 days of training for aviation workers. The decision was made after a closed-door dialogue session with NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Monday's session with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.39% on Monday, following an advance across Asia, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 23,558.83. The gains come after several countries reported fewer virus deaths over the weekend. Markets in China are closed for a public holiday. This upward trend is in line with other Asian markets and comes despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Mapletree syndicates US$1.8b pan US-European logistics fund
summary: Mapletree Investments has raised US$1.8 billion in equity for its pan US-European logistics fund, MUSEL Private Trust. The fund, comprising 262 logistics assets across 26 US states and 20 European cities, has a total investment value of US$4.3 billion. The syndication was supported by institutional, corporate, and high net worth investors, marking a significant milestone for the company.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened lower on Monday at 0.03% down to 17,814.30, amid ongoing coronavirus fears. The broader Topix index rose 0.22% to 1,328.08. This follows global market trends, where the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's key Nikkei index opened lower on Monday amid ongoing fears about the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on slowing coronavirus spread; New Zealand retreats
summary: Australian shares rose 3.2% on Monday, driven by financials and miners, as the coronavirus crisis in the US and Australia appears to be slowing. US President Donald Trump expressed hope for a "levelling off" of the virus crisis, boosting sentiment. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,227.5, while US stock futures climbed 1.5% ahead of the weekend. The positive trend was also seen in Singapore, where stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Oil prices fall as doubts grow over output cut deal
summary: Oil prices plummeted 8% in Asia, with West Texas Intermediate down 5.7% to $26.72 a barrel, and Brent crude down 4.3% to $32.64 a barrel, due to a delayed meeting between Opec and its allies to discuss output cuts. The meeting, expected to address the coronavirus-impacted energy market, was postponed to Thursday, fueling skepticism about a swift resolution. Analysts predict a deal will be insufficient to stem the oil supply glut, contributing to the lowest prices in years.

site_title: SingPost to continue nationwide deliveries; select post offices to remain open from April 7
summary: SingPost will continue nationwide mail deliveries, albeit operating 24 out of 56 post offices from April 7 to May 4, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The remaining open post offices include Ang Mo Kio Central, Bedok Central, and others, offering services such as postal services, bill payments, and banking.

site_title: Construction in New York limps forward despite shutdown order
summary: Construction in New York City has largely come to a halt due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but some projects have been deemed "essential" and allowed to continue. The New York state government has issued an order requiring most construction sites to shut down until at least the end of April, but exceptions include hospitals, homeless shelters, and affordable housing projects. Many developers are trying to find loopholes to continue their projects, with some arguing that they serve a vital interest and should be exempt from the shutdown. Despite the shutdown, some construction sites have continued to operate, albeit at a reduced pace, with developers taking precautions to ensure the health and safety of workers.

images.alt_text: Development has ground to a halt across New York City. Or has it?

site_title: Scots' medical chief resigns after flouting own coronavirus rules
summary: Scotland's Chief Medical Officer Catherine Calderwood resigned on Sunday after breaking her own coronavirus rules by visiting her second home. Calderwood had been warned by police and apologized for her actions, which she said were wrong. The move comes as Scotland has recorded 3,345 coronavirus cases and 218 deaths. Calderwood's resignation was seen as a blow to the government's efforts to maintain public trust, with First Minister Nicola Sturgeon stating that the chief medical officer's actions risked distracting from the country's pandemic response efforts.

site_title: Hong Kong faces delays in giving cash away with virus hitting economy
summary: Hong Kong's planned cash handout of nearly $1,300 to residents struggling with the economic impact of the coronavirus is delayed, potentially too late to support the economy. The payment was initially expected in the second quarter but may not arrive until the third quarter or later due to technical and legal work. The government has a fiscal reserve of over $1 trillion, but aid measures are moving slowly amid a recession forecast to struggle in growth of -1.5% to +0.5% this year.

site_title: Amid wild swings, Australian stock market trade volume doubles in March: ASX
summary: The Australian stock market experienced wild swings in March, with its worst month since 1987, posting a 21.5% decline. Despite this, trade volume and value doubled, with 67.5 million trades and A$264.2 billion in cash market trades, a 110% increase from the previous year. This surge in trades was driven by index options, which rose 51% to offset portfolio changes. Market volatility was high, with daily movements of 4.1% on the All-Ordinaries index.

site_title: MindChamps to set up JV fund which will acquire preschools in the GCC
summary: MindChamps PreSchool has entered into a joint venture with Foundation Corporation to establish a GCC PreSchool Fund, which will acquire preschools in GCC countries and operate them under the MindChamps brand. The fund aims to raise US$50-100 million and will be managed by a licensed fund manager. MindChamps will own 50% of the fund's share capital and receive management fees, profits, and royalties. The fund will also establish a master franchisee company to facilitate the operation and training of preschools in the GCC.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.84 points or 0.06% to 1,329.81. Trading volume was 312.82 million lots worth RM95.17 million. Gainers beat losers 213 to 78.

site_title: Australia's Flight Centre to raise A$700m to offset coronavirus hit
summary: Australia's Flight Centre Travel Group is raising about A$700 million to offset the coronavirus hit on the travel industry. The company plans to raise A$282 million through a share placement and A$419 million through an accelerated entitlement offer. Cost-cutting measures are expected to save roughly A$1.9 billion, with annualized operating expenses falling to A$65 million a month by the end of July. The company has also withdrawn its 2020 forecast and implemented pay cuts for executives.

site_title: Genting's RWS closes Singapore attractions in line with 'circuit-breaker' measures
summary: RESORTS World Sentosa (RWS) in Singapore has temporarily closed its attractions, including Universal Studios Singapore and SEA Aquarium, from April 6 to May 4 due to the government's "circuit-breaker" measures. The casino and only selected eateries will remain open for takeaway and deliveries. Guests with hotel bookings will continue their stays, while those with reservations from April 7 to May 4 will have their bookings cancelled and refunded. Staff will not be affected by the closure.

site_title: Oil product shipping rates in Asia at highest since 2008: Refinitiv
summary: Oil product shipping rates in Asia have reached a 12-year high, driven by a surge in demand for floating storage to combat oversupply, according to Refinitiv data. Freight rates for smaller vessels carrying naphtha and other clean oil products from the Middle East to Japan rose to near 12-year highs, with rates for larger vessels increasing to their highest since October 2019. The high rates are attributed to reduced demand from Europe and the US due to lockdowns, with at least 12 tankers booked for floating storage.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Genting, OUE C-Reit, Hong Leong Asia, ComfortDelGro
summary: Singapore stocks were affected by the government's "circuit-breaker" measures and the escalating Covid-19 situation. OCBC closed 22 branches and postponed its AGM, while Genting Singapore suspended its attractions. OUE C-Reit took a voluntary 10% fee cut, and Hong Leong Asia's CEO said the market may consolidate. ComfortDelGro waived rental for its drivers, and Chip Eng Seng sold 77 units of its condo project. Biolidics' Covid-19 test kit is now allowed for sale in the EU, and Perennial Real Estate Holdings obtained a S$250 million loan.

site_title: Singapore shares rise ahead of new Solidarity Budget; STI up 1.3% at open
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.3% on Monday ahead of the government's third major Solidarity Budget, which will contain support measures for workers, businesses, and households amid the novel coronavirus pandemic. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 29.8 points to 2,419.09, with local banks, such as DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also seeing gains. The new budget's details have not been released, but investors are optimistic about the support measures.

site_title: Singapore fintech aims to be payment bridge to UnionPay
summary: Aleta Planet, a Singapore fintech, has partnered UnionPay, China's largest card payment network, to enable digital payments for tourists and Singaporeans visiting China. Starting May 1, users can make payments with their mobile phones, eliminating the need for cash. The partnership is supported by the State Administration of Foreign Exchange of China and allows for secure, dynamic, and capital-controlled transactions. Aleta Planet aims to be a payment bridge in China, where digital payments are prevalent, and offers virtual commercial accounts for businesses and individuals to facilitate cross-border payments.

site_title: OUE C-Reit cuts directors' fees by 10% amid 'escalating' Covid-19 situation
summary: OUE C-Reit has agreed to a 10% fee cut for its directors amid the escalating Covid-19 situation. The move comes after the Singapore government introduced stricter social distancing measures, including the closure of non-essential workplaces. The fee cut applies to directors' fees accrued in the 2019 financial year, excluding two former directors who stepped down in 2019. The highest-paid director, Loh Lian Huat, will not be affected by the fee revision.

site_title: Biolidics' Covid-19 rapid test kit allowed to be sold in EU
summary: Singapore-based Biolidics' Covid-19 rapid test kit has been allowed for sale in the European Union after obtaining CE marking, a notification process confirming compliance with EU product safety directives. The test kit, described as "simple to use and portable," can be used as a point-of-care test in various healthcare settings. Results are not to be used for confirmatory testing or sole diagnosis, requiring interpretation with clinical presentation and supplementary testing. This approval follows previously received authorizations in the Philippines and Singapore.

site_title: City Development's retail tenants get full rental rebates in April, 50% in May
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) is providing full rental rebates of over S$17 million to its office and retail tenants in April and 50% in May to help them cope with the novel coronavirus outbreak. The rebates include the full quantum of the government's enhanced property tax rebates, announced last month under the Resilience Budget. This move aims to support CDL's tenants during the challenging economic period.

site_title: Bronx zoo tiger tests positive for coronavirus
summary: A 4-year-old Malayan tiger named Nadia at the Bronx Zoo in New York has tested positive for COVID-19, believed to have contracted the virus from an asymptomatic caretaker. Nadia and three other big cats developed dry coughs, but are expected to fully recover under veterinary care. The zoo has emphasized that there is no evidence animals transmit COVID-19 to humans, and preventative measures are in place for caretakers and all city zoos.

site_title: Best World eyes purchase of entire stake in British beauty firm Pedal Pulses
summary: Best World International, a Singapore-based skincare products firm, has agreed to acquire up to 100% of Pedal Pulses, a UK-based beauty brand specializing in foot, hand, and leg treatments. The acquisition, valued at £13.9 million, is part of Best World's growth strategy to expand its geographical reach and product offerings. The deal includes a put and call option agreement, allowing Pedal Pulses' shareholders to sell or buy shares over the next few years. The acquisition is expected to complement Best World's business and provide a premium beauty brand specialist in the UK and Europe.

site_title: Singapore retail investors load up on debt to buy shares in low-rate environment
summary: Singapore retail investors are taking on significant debt to buy shares amid low interest rates. Some are using their homes as collateral to borrow money, with one investor, Heng Kai Sheng, opening a share-financing account with a S$500,000 kitty and leveraging 3.5 times. This trend is partly due to the volatile markets caused by the coronavirus outbreak. The low interest rates are also encouraging investors to take on more risk, with some experts warning of potential financial instability.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The digital fight against Covid-19
summary: The Singapore government encourages businesses to digitalize operations and upgrade worker skills amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran discusses the government's efforts to promote digitalization and prepare for election management.

site_title: Landlords in peril as retail chains refuse to pay rent
summary: European retailers, including H&M and Adidas, are withholding rent payments due to the COVID-19 pandemic, putting pressure on landlords and the banking sector. Over €1 trillion of debt is secured against commercial real estate in Germany, France, and the UK. Landlords face steep shortfalls in income, making it harder for them to pay interest and avoid covenant breaches on loans. Several countries are legislating to temporarily halt interest payments, while property companies are urging for flexible rent payments and support for the distressed retail industry.

site_title: Boeing extends Washington state production shutdown indefinitely
summary: Boeing extends its production shutdown at its Washington state facilities indefinitely due to the coronavirus outbreak. The company halted production on March 23 and initially expected to resume early this week. Boeing cited ongoing health concerns, supply chain reliability, and government health authorities' recommendations for the extension. The shutdown affects approximately 30,000 production workers, who can use paid time off, vacation, and sick leave, and will continue to receive medical benefits.

site_title: France reports lowest daily virus toll in a week, total now 8,078
summary: France reported 357 coronavirus hospital deaths on Sunday, the lowest daily increase in a week, bringing the country's toll to 8,078. There are now 28,891 people with coronavirus in hospital, with 6,978 in intensive care. Despite a warm Easter holiday, officials urged continued lockdown adherence, warning against flouting restrictions. The government has evacuated over 550 severely ill patients from overwhelmed hospitals to other areas, and the interior ministry reiterated that confinement rules remain in place until a deadline is set.

site_title: Virus-hit US girds for 'Pearl Harbour moment' as death toll spikes
summary: The US is bracing for a "Pearl Harbour moment" as the death toll from COVID-19 surges, with governors appealing to the White House for a national strategy to combat the pandemic. The US death toll is nearing 10,000, with New York reporting a record 630 deaths in 24 hours. Health authorities warn of an escalation, with US Surgeon General Jerome Adams urging Americans to practice social distancing and stay home for at least 30 days. The lack of a unified national policy plan is creating a "porous situation" that may prolong the spread of the virus, with governors calling for the federal government to step up its efforts.

site_title: Rolls-Royce to ditch targets and suspend dividend: FT
summary: Rolls-Royce, a UK aero-engine maker, will abandon its profit and cash targets due to the coronavirus outbreak. The company will also suspend its dividend and announce new credit facilities exceeding £1 billion (S$1.76 billion) to bolster liquidity.

site_title: 20,000 foreign workers at two dorms to serve 14-day quarantine order
summary: Singapore has ordered 20,000 foreign workers at two dormitories to serve a 14-day quarantine order amid a surge in Covid-19 infections. The dormitories, Westlite Toh Guan and S11, have reported 62 and 28 cases, respectively. Workers will be housed separately and provided with essential services, including meals and medical support. The government also plans to implement safe distancing measures, including relocating unwell workers to isolated sick bays, and will ensure quarantined workers receive paid leave.

site_title: Dollar climbs on safe-haven bids
summary: The US dollar strengthened for a third consecutive day, driven by safe-haven bids amid worsening economic fallout from the coronavirus outbreak. Despite a weaker-than-expected non-farm payrolls report, the dollar largely shrugged off massive job losses of 701,000 last month. The euro fell 0.4% against the dollar, on pace for a 2.9% weekly loss, due to indecision among euro zone governments about a rescue package. The economic impact of the epidemic is becoming more marked, with purchasing managers' indexes showing a slump in business activity across the euro zone and Britain.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week of April 5, 2020, reveals improved sentiment in the Capesize market, with the Cape 5TC index closing at $5,949. South African loading options and Brazilian activity boosted the market, while Vale's iron ore output cuts countered the gains. The Panamax market saw strong demand, particularly in the North Pacific, while the Supramax and Ultramax markets were affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The Handysize market remained weak, with minimal activity in the Atlantic. The tanker market showed increased activity in the Middle East, with VLCC and Suezmax rates rising.

site_title: Boris Johnson in hospital as queen says joint effort will defeat virus
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, 55, was taken to hospital on Sunday after failing to shake off coronavirus symptoms, as Queen Elizabeth II urged a united effort to defeat the outbreak. Johnson had been due to re-emerge from self-isolation, a week after testing positive for Covid-19. The government announced his hospital admission as a precaution after the monarch's rare address to the country and Commonwealth nations. Johnson's hospitalization comes amid a growing concern over the UK's handling of the pandemic.

site_title: New York state virus toll tops 4,000 with 594 new deaths in 24 hours
summary: New York state's COVID-19 death toll has reached 4,159, with 594 new deaths reported in 24 hours, a slight decrease from the previous day's record of 630. The state has also seen 122,031 positive cases. Governor Andrew Cuomo warns that the peak of the pandemic could arrive over the next week, but notes that it's unclear if this will be a point or a plateau, with possible variations in the coming days.

site_title: Resilience of on-demand delivery startups tested amid Covid-19 crunch time
summary: Singapore's on-demand delivery startups face unprecedented demand and tougher operating conditions amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Authorities have rolled out support, including a package to help food and beverage players get on board GrabFood, foodpanda, and Deliveroo. However, industry watchers are concerned about the startups' ability to control costs and prove sustainability. Many are ramping up logistics capacities, but finding new gig riders on short notice may be challenging, with some considering hiring taxi and private-hire vehicle drivers. Government support and coordination may be necessary to match demand and supply, and last-mile logistics startups' performance will have implications for upstream e-commerce players.

site_title: Saudi Arabia delays setting May prices, looks to Opec meeting to settle price war
summary: Saudi Arabia has delayed setting May crude prices for the first time, looking to a meeting of OPEC to resolve a price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia. The price war, amid the pandemic, has cut crude prices to $34 a barrel from $65. OPEC members, led by Saudi Arabia, have stepped up efforts to resolve the dispute, but other major producers, including the US, have not been involved. The delay is seen as an attempt to halt the growing supply glut overwhelming markets.

site_title: Spanish hotel owner turns resort over to refugees during coronavirus crisis
summary: A Spanish hotel owner has turned his resort over to 12 families of Venezuelan refugees and homeless people due to the coronavirus crisis in Spain. The La Ciguena resort, usually hosting tourists and business meetings, now provides meals and shelter to the vulnerable families. The owner, Miguel Angel Carnero, has been helping the families voluntarily, saying it's a way to contribute during the pandemic. The complex is being managed by the staff who have been temporarily laid off.

site_title: Building materials turnaround marks new direction for Hong Leong Asia
summary: Hong Leong Asia (HLA) CEO Tan Eng Kwee expects a shift in the building materials supply business due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which could lead to consolidation and marginal players disappearing. The company is leveraging its size advantage to be the least-cost producer in the industry. HLA's building materials division swung back into profitability in 2019, with a 39% jump in net profit to S$34.4 million. The company plans to grow its business through acquisitions, with a focus on technology spin or environmental sustainability. Tan also hopes to balance the contributions from different business units at a profit after tax and minority interests (PATMI) level.

site_title: Five steps for legacy companies to drive disruptive innovation
summary: Legacy companies can drive disruptive innovation by establishing an independent innovation function, separate from their core businesses. To achieve this, they should consider the following steps: reframing the problem question from a customer's perspective, designing a consistent user experience across all channels, keeping implementation simple and flexible, using a dedicated marketing and sales organisation, and fostering a culture that supports innovation. By adopting these strategies, companies can successfully launch groundbreaking products in a bear market and stay competitive in volatile market forces.

site_title: Solidarity Budget to help tide through 'circuit-breaker' period: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat will announce the Solidarity Budget, Singapore's third round of support measures, in Parliament on Monday. The budget aims to help workers, businesses, and households navigate the four-week "circuit-breaker" period, when schools and workplaces will be closed. The measures include additional support for low-income workers, self-employed individuals, and the unemployed, as well as more help for the worst-hit sectors and property tax rebates. The budget is part of a larger effort to mitigate the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, which has been forecast to cause a full-year recession in 2020.

site_title: Director acquisitions continue in a less volatile market
summary: In a less volatile market, director and substantial shareholder transactions continued to be active, with 130 changes reported in five sessions. Key acquisitions include Olam International's substantial shareholder Kewalram Singapore buying 750,000 shares, increasing its stake to 7.06%, and Wee Investments (Pte) Ltd acquiring 101,000 shares of Haw Par Corporation, increasing Wee Chow Yaw's stake to 36.50%. Other notable transactions involve Centurion Corporation's non-executive director David Loh Kim Kang acquiring 1,476,200 shares, and Riverstone Holdings' founder Wong Teek Son buying 590,000 shares.

site_title: Oil price sanity may return on Saudi-Russia truce hopes
summary: Oil prices may stabilize on Thursday's Opec meeting, with hopes of a truce between Saudi Arabia and Russia. The commodity has more than halved since the start of the year due to the Covid-19 pandemic and price war. Analysts expect a mutually-agreeable deal on output cuts, but some experts warn of possible disappointment. A 10-15 million barrel per day cut has been proposed, which could reframe expectations, but the US has yet to commit to joining the effort, making a truce challenging.

site_title: Singapore market likely to keep sinking
summary: The Singapore market is expected to continue sinking due to the global economic downturn caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Straits Times Index (STI) has been in a state of "roller coaster" movement, with previous attempts at recovery being short-lived. Analysts predict a further decline to the 1,000 psychological level, potentially extending to the 887.69 level, as the market struggles to break above the 2,531.19 resistance level. A brief rebound to 2,673.50 or 2,815.70 may occur, but it is considered a "dead cat bounce" and not a sign of a strong recovery.

site_title: ESG to partly fund commission costs for F&B players on Deliveroo, foodpanda and GrabFood
summary: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) will partially fund commission costs for food and beverage (F&B) players on Deliveroo, foodpanda, and GrabFood from April 7 to May 4. The government agency will cover 5 percentage points of the commission cost, reducing it from 25% to 20%. This support aims to help F&B businesses manage costs during the month-long ban on dine-in sales due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: NUHS, startup Bot MD launch app for quick access to Covid-19 info
summary: NUHS and startup Bot MD launched an artificial intelligence-powered app for frontline medical staff to access hospital-specific Covid-19 information, including guidelines and protocols. The chatbot answers questions on various topics, including hospital protocols, drug dosage information, and on-call rosters. This partnership aims to provide quick and accurate information to medical staff during the pandemic.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng subsidiary sells 77 units at Kopar At Newton condo
summary: A subsidiary of Chip Eng Seng Corporation, CEL Development, sold 77 units at its Kopar At Newton condo project, which is a 99-year leasehold development off Newton Circus. The project's average price is S$2,350 per square foot. The sale marks the initial launch of the 378-unit project, with more details on the sale and the project's overall performance not provided.

site_title: At least I can be Wimbledon champion for two years: Halep
summary: Romanian tennis player Simona Halep will be referred to as the reigning Wimbledon champion for two years due to the suspension of the tennis season caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Halep won the title last year but will not be able to defend it this summer. She is currently in quarantine in her native Romania, where she has been locked down at home for 22 days.

site_title: Bleeding badly, F&B operators appeal to PM Lee for urgent help
summary: An informal group of over 500 Singaporean restaurants, led by well-known restaurateurs, has written an urgent letter to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, seeking immediate targeted measures to help the struggling food and beverage (F&B) industry. The industry, heavily impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, is calling for rental rebates, increased wage support, and pressure on landlords to waive base rents. Many restaurants are forced to close or significantly reduce operations due to the latest no-dine-in rule, with some estimating sales could drop by up to 85% and 50-75% for certain outlets.

site_title: Safeguarding our economic resilience
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) aims to strengthen the country's position as a financial hub, bolstering economic resilience in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic. Financial markets have been volatile, with intense price swings and benchmark stock indices falling into bear territory. In contrast, Singapore stocks have experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. SGX will focus on green and transition finance, deepening cooperation with the People's Bank of China (PBOC) to enhance its role as a global financial center.

site_title: Should investors participate in SIA's big rights issue?
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is tapping shareholders for S$8.8 billion, with S$5.3 billion raised through a 3-for-2 rights issue and S$3.5 billion through a 10-year mandatory convertible bond (MCB) issue. The rights issue is deeply discounted at S$3 each, and the MCBs have a zero coupon but are redeemable semi-annually. Despite SIA's poor investment fundamentals, Temasek Holdings, which owns nearly 55.5% of the airline, is backing the cash call, citing its strategic importance to Singapore's economy. SIA's shares have tumbled 15% since the announcement, and investors are advised to be cautious of the risks involved.

images.alt_text: Since 2000, Singapore Airlines has coped with the fallout of the 9/11 terrorist strike, the Global Financial Crisis, massive volatility in oil prices, and the rise of low-cost carriers.

site_title: Tesla cuts contractors from California, Nevada factories
summary: Tesla is cutting contractors from its US car and battery plants, affecting hundreds of workers. The cuts were reported to be due to the Covid-19 pandemic and the request from Tesla to end contract assignments. The move was made at the Fremont plant in California and the Gigafactory in Nevada. Tesla's production and delivery were largely unaffected by the coronavirus outbreak. The decision was made by Balance Staffing, a workforce management company, and contractors hired with other temp agencies also received similar notices.

site_title: Covid-19: 20,000 foreign workers at two dormitories to serve 14-day quarantine order
summary: Singapore has required around 20,000 foreign workers at two dormitories to serve a 14-day quarantine order amid rising Covid-19 cases. The S11 Dormitory @ Punggol and Westlite Toh Guan dormitories have seen additional 22 and 10 new cases, respectively. The two dormitories have been gazetted as "isolation areas" and foreign workers will stay in their existing rooms for 14 days, according to Manpower Minister Josephine Teo. This move aims to curb the spread of the virus.

site_title: Covid-19: Government to announce additional support measures for businesses and households
summary: The Singapore government will announce additional support measures for businesses and households on April 6, 2020, to help them cope with stricter safe-distancing measures amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The measures will be announced by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat in a ministerial statement. The statement will be published on the Singapore Budget website and broadcast live on various channels.

site_title: Covid-19: All public libraries to close from April 7
summary: Singapore's National Library Board announced the closure of all 25 public libraries from April 7 to May 4 due to the coronavirus pandemic. The National Archives of Singapore building and the Former Ford Factory will also be closed during this period. The move comes as the government imposes stricter measures to stem a spike in local cases, including shutting down non-essential workplaces and schools as part of a month-long "circuit breaker" until May 4.

site_title: Govt to enhance Jobs Support Scheme, waive foreign worker levy for April
summary: Singapore's Jobs Support Scheme will be enhanced and foreign worker levies waived for April to support businesses affected by the coronavirus outbreak. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the measures, following stricter measures to combat the outbreak, including a "circuit breaker" closure of schools and most workplaces. The moves aim to reduce disruption and costs for businesses, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong previously announcing the closures to curb local Covid-19 cases.

site_title: US stimulus package a start but more needed: analysts
summary: The US stimulus package and Federal Reserve monetary support have been deemed insufficient to address the severity of the Covid-19 pandemic and its economic impact. The pandemic has led to a record 6.6 million Americans filing for unemployment assistance and hundreds of deaths daily, with New York City reaching worst-case scenario proportions. Analysts warn that more "bazookas" of economic support are needed, and the stock market has tested bear-market lows due to concerns over the pandemic's duration and economic recovery prospects.

site_title: Catalyst for change
summary: Covid-19 is accelerating the adoption of large-scale work-from-home (WFH) arrangements, as organisations reassess their workforce strategies. Experts from various industries, including Ernst & Young, Bosch, Deloitte, Swiss Re, and Hewlett Packard Enterprise, share their views on the future of work. Many believe that WFH is here to stay, offering productivity, better work-life balance, and reduced carbon footprint. To make it successful, organisations need to invest in technology, soft skills, and flexible working models. The shift to WFH also highlights the need for organisations to rethink their HR policies, workspaces, and business continuity plans to support remote workers.

images.alt_text: Max Loh, Managing Partner, Singapore and Brunei, Ernst & Young LLP.

site_title: New Solidarity Budget will help Singapore tide through 'circuit-breaker' period: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the Solidarity Budget, the third round of measures to support workers, businesses, and households in Singapore, amidst the "circuit-breaker" period due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The budget aims to help the country tide through the four-week shutdown of schools and most workplaces. The Solidarity Budget will contain additional support measures, following the Unity Budget and Resilience Budget previously introduced. Heng emphasized the importance of unity and solidarity among Singaporeans during this challenging time.

site_title: 88-year-old man dies of Covid-19, 6th such death in Singapore
summary: A 6th patient, an 88-year-old Singapore permanent resident, has died from Covid-19 in Singapore. He had no recent travel history and was admitted to the National Centre for Infectious Diseases on March 30. The patient had underlying health conditions and was linked to the Singapore Cricket Club cluster. This marks Singapore's 6th death from Covid-19. The government has implemented measures to slow the spread, including closing most workplaces and moving schools to full home-based learning.

site_title: ComfortDelGro waives cab rental for a month with suspension of non-essential services
summary: ComfortDelGro, Singapore's largest taxi operator, has waived taxi rental for its drivers for a month due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The waiver, which covers one month, will help drivers during the period when non-essential services are suspended. The company expects the move to cost an additional S$19 million. This is part of a total relief package worth up to S$99 million, which will also kick in after May 5. The measure aims to support drivers who have seen their earnings plummet by 50-60% since the pandemic began.

site_title: LTA to cease ERP charges at all gantries from April 6 to May 4
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore will temporarily cease Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) charges at all gantries from April 6 to May 4, following the introduction of enhanced safe-distancing measures. The measures, including full home-based learning and closure of physical workplaces, aim to curb coronavirus infections. The LTA expects a significant reduction in traffic volume once the measures are implemented.

site_title: Thailand suspends all incoming passenger flights for 3 days
summary: Thailand has suspended all incoming passenger flights for three days starting April 4 to prevent the spread of novel coronavirus. Cargo flights and state aircraft are exempt. The ban comes after trouble at Suvarnabhumi international airport involving passengers from the US and Japan. The move aims to avoid importing more cases, with Thailand reporting 1,978 cases and 19 deaths.

site_title: Video app Zoom rockets to fame, with some hiccups amid pandemic
summary: Zoom, a videoconferencing app, has skyrocketed in popularity amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with 200 million daily users in March, up from 10 million at the end of last year. The company has faced scrutiny over privacy and security concerns, including "Zoombombing" incidents where virtual intruders disrupt meetings. Zoom's market value has reached $35 billion, and the company has vowed to step up data security measures. Prosecutors in several US states are investigating the company's practices, and experts warn that replicating Zoom's success will be challenging for competitors.

site_title: South Korea to extend intensive social distancing as coronavirus cases persist
summary: South Korea will extend its intensive social distancing campaign beyond its initial end date due to persistent concerns about imported coronavirus cases and new outbreaks. The campaign, which was set to end on Monday, will now continue to manage domestic transmissions and maintain social distancing measures. As of Saturday, South Korea reported 94 new cases, bringing the national total to 10,156, with a death toll of 177 and over 6,300 recoveries. Prime Minister Chung Sye Kyun described the situation as "grave" and emphasized the need to maintain social distancing for an extended period.

site_title: Covid-19: Restaurants appeal for immediate targeted measures
summary: A group of over 500 Singaporean restaurants, led by well-known restaurateurs, has urged Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong to implement targeted measures to support the struggling restaurant industry amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The group, #savefnbsg, is seeking immediate rental rebates, reduced base rent, increased Jobs Support Scheme, and support for restaurants forced to close due to dine-in restrictions. The industry, which employs 220,000 staff and contributes 0.8% to GDP, is facing significant losses, with sales expected to drop by up to 85% for some restaurants.

site_title: Oil surges more than 13% on hopes of output deal
summary: Oil prices surged over 13% on Friday, with Brent crude futures jumping 13.9% and US West Texas Intermediate rising 11.93%, due to hopes of a global deal to cut crude supply worldwide. A potential 10-15% cut in supply, equivalent to 10-15 million barrels per day, could be agreed upon at an Opec emergency meeting on Monday. Despite the rally, analysts warn that even a significant cut in supply may not reduce a glut in the market due to reduced demand during the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end lower as Covid-19 economic toll becomes clearer
summary: European stocks ended lower on Friday, closing the week down 0.6% as dismal business activity data highlighted a deep economic recession due to the coronavirus outbreak. The Stoxx 600 index fell 1% and insurers were hit hardest after EU regulators suspended dividends and share buybacks to shore up liquidity. Despite this, the index appeared to have regained stability after sharp daily movements over the past month.

site_title: 2 members of Kennedy family missing after canoe overturned
summary: Two members of the Kennedy family, Maeve Kennedy Townsend McKean, 40, and her 8-year-old son Gideon Joseph Kennedy McKean, are missing after their canoe overturned in the Chesapeake Bay due to strong winds. The family is seeking privacy and prayers for their safety. A preliminary investigation suggests the canoe was paddled into the bay to retrieve a ball, and a search involving multiple law enforcement agencies is ongoing.

site_title: China mourns thousands who died in country's coronavirus epidemic
summary: China is mourning thousands of deaths from the coronavirus epidemic, with more than 3,300 fatalities reported in mainland China. The country is observing a day of mourning, flying the national flag at half-mast and suspending entertainment. A three-minute silence will be observed at 10am, with cars, trains, and ships sounding their horns and air raid sirens wailing. The outbreak, which first surfaced in Hubei province late last year, has claimed 2,567 lives in Wuhan, accounting for over 75% of the country's coronavirus fatalities.

site_title: Opec+ debates biggest-ever oil cut, awaits US efforts
summary: Opec+ is working on a record-breaking 10% oil production cut, equivalent to 10-15 million barrels per day, in a global effort including the US, but the White House has not committed to such a cut. US President Donald Trump pledged help for the industry but did not agree to a domestic production cut. A global deal is needed to stabilize the markets, with Opec producers waiting for the US to commit. Russia has expressed frustration over supporting US shale producers, while Saudi Arabia's Energy Minister denies refusing to extend a production-cut deal.

site_title: French coronavirus cases jump above China's after including nursing home tally
summary: France reported 6,507 coronavirus deaths, a 61% increase, and 82,165 confirmed cases, a 44% jump, after including nursing home data. This surpasses China's case numbers, making France the fifth country to report more cases. Hospital cases rose by 9% to 64,338, while nursing home cases increased by 20% to 17,827.

site_title: Soaring unemployment increases odds US banks will cut dividends
summary: US banks face increasing pressure to cut dividends as a record number of Americans are unemployed due to the coronavirus crisis. Heavy exposure to credit cards makes banks more vulnerable, with Wall Street analysts considering the possibility. This could be a departure from European and non-financial companies that have already cut dividends. The situation highlights the economic challenges facing the US banking sector.

site_title: Disney delays Marvel blockbusters but hopes for summer 'Mulan' launch
summary: Disney delays over a dozen major films, including Marvel blockbusters, due to the coronavirus pandemic. The revised schedule includes a July 24 launch for live-action remake "Mulan" and pushes back Marvel movies like "Black Widow" and "The Eternals." The pandemic has also led to the release of "Artemis Fowl" on Disney+ instead of theaters. Despite theater closures, National Association of Theatre Owners officials suggest a potential reopening in late May or June with social distancing measures.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower after dreary March jobs data, Dow -1.7%
summary: US stocks ended lower on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 1.7%, as a gloomy jobs report showed a 701,000 job loss in March, a 4.4% jobless rate, and 10 million people filing for unemployment benefits. The report is seen as a harbinger of worse unemployment due to the coronavirus outbreak. Analysts expect 24 million job loss in April. The Trump administration launched a $350 billion small business program to limit the impact on employment.

site_title: US businesses swarm coronavirus bailout fund after days of confusion
summary: US businesses scrambled to apply for a $349 billion small business bailout fund after days of uncertainty over its terms. Despite the program's launch, lenders faced technical issues and unclear guidance, leaving many business owners frustrated. The loan program, part of a $2 trillion economic rescue package, aims to support businesses with fewer than 500 employees, but concerns remain about its ability to sustain businesses for the long term. Many business owners expressed worry that the loans would not be enough to cover essential expenses, and some feared they would be left with significant debt.

site_title: Developers told to suspend all showflat galleries for a month
summary: Developers in Singapore have been told to suspend all showflat galleries for a month starting April 7 to combat the Covid-19 outbreak. Stricter measures include closing show galleries for projects such as Chip Eng Seng's Kopar At Newton and Keppel Land's 19 Nassim. Developers are advised to use technology to showcase projects online instead. This move may delay some property launches, with CBRE predicting some may be pushed into 2H2020.

site_title: BT's Anita Gabriel bags journalism prize in SPH annual awards
summary: Senior correspondent Anita Gabriel of The Business Times (BT) won the "Excellence in Journalism" award at Singapore Press Holdings' annual EMTM Group media awards. Her scoop on switching to a cheaper electricity option by SP Group was recognized for highlighting the potential savings for households unaware of the differences in pricing between retailers and SP Group. The award honors the best work by journalists of the EMTM Group in the past year, with other notable winners including ST's Joyce Lim, Salma Khalik, and Tee Zhuo.

site_title: Decimated by virus, sporting world will rebound stronger
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has decimated the world's sporting events, with numerous tournaments and championships canceled or postponed. Notable events include the cancellation of Wimbledon and the postponement of the Tokyo Olympics and Euro 2020 championships. Many marathons and Formula One events have been delayed to later in the year. The National Basketball Association season has been suspended indefinitely. Despite the challenges, experts believe that the sporting world will rebound stronger once the pandemic is under control, with sports having the unique power to rally and inspire people.

site_title: Silicon is reaching its limit. What's next?
summary: Singapore can capitalize on the growing interest in gallium nitride (GaN) as a successor to silicon semiconductors, which could revolutionize the industry with its high-power, high-efficiency, and high-temperature electronics applications. GaN is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of 86% between 2018 and 2025, driven by its potential in fast chargers, wireless power, and electric vehicles. Local startups, such as IGSS GaN, are already working on GaN-on-silicon technology, which could make the material more affordable for mass production. The Singaporean government can support the development of GaN technology by investing in startups and collaborating with research institutions, ultimately enabling the country to become a key player in the GaN semiconductor hub.

site_title: Gold up on bleak US payrolls data; stronger dollar caps gains
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $1,619.40 per ounce after US nonfarm payrolls data showed a 701,000 job loss in March, confirming a recession. A stronger US dollar capped gains. Analysts say gold will eventually shine due to global fiscal and monetary stimulus. Meanwhile, other precious metals like palladium and platinum declined.

images.alt_text: Gold prices edged higher on Friday after gloomy US nonfarm payrolls data magnified the economic toll from the coronavirus, although a stronger US dollar capped bullion's advance.

site_title: New York in 'race against time' as death tolls jump in US virus hot spots
summary: New York City and Louisiana report record jumps in Covid-19 deaths, with New York's cumulative death toll comparable to the 9/11 attacks. The US is experiencing a surge in lethal coronavirus infections, overwhelming hospitals in affluent urban areas. Mayor Bill de Blasio calls for federal reinforcements of medical personnel and supplies, while Governor Andrew Cuomo warns that the city is in a "race against time." The US has seen over 275,000 cases and 7,077 deaths, with the economic consequences of the pandemic already being felt, including widespread job losses.

site_title: SembMarine safe from SGX watch-list despite 3 years of losses
summary: Sembcorp Marine, a Singapore-based rig builder, has avoided being placed on the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) watch-list despite recording three consecutive years of pre-tax losses. The company's six-monthly average daily market capitalization is S$2.46 billion, meeting the financial entry criteria. Sembcorp Marine's net loss for fiscal 2019 was S$137 million, mainly due to accelerated depreciation and low business volumes. The company's shares ended at 67.5 Singapore cents, down 1.5% on Friday.

site_title: What to do when world is in a coronacoma
