summary: The US is bracing for a massive wave of mortgage defaults, with up to 30% of Americans with home loans (around 15 million households) at risk of stopping payments due to the ongoing pandemic. The government has implemented a 180-day payment deferment program for federally backed mortgages, but lenders are uncertain about the scope and duration of the crisis. Experts warn that if the economic downturn persists, foreclosures could lead to a financial market crisis, prompting policymakers to consider debt forgiveness or other measures to prevent a catastrophic outcome.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.4 points or 0.2% to 1,333.3 at 9:18am on Friday, driven by a 334.8 million lots volume worth RM81.4 million. Losers beat gainers 243 to 27.

site_title: Hong Kong orders bars to close as it ramps up social distancing
summary: Hong Kong has ordered pubs and bars to close for two weeks due to the coronavirus pandemic. The move comes after 62 confirmed cases linked to bars, resulting in 14 new infections, including a baby. Anyone violating the law faces up to six months in jail and a fine of HK$50,000. The city has 802 cases and four deaths from the disease. Alcohol will still be available in supermarkets and convenience stores.

site_title: Americans urged to wear masks outside as coronavirus pandemic worsens
summary: The US is urging Americans to wear masks outside as the coronavirus pandemic worsens, with the US death toll rising by 1,000 in a single day for the first time. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) will soon add a mask recommendation to guidelines, but President Trump said only "if people want to wear them, they can." The US has seen over 243,000 cases and 5,887 deaths, with global cases surpassing 1 million and 52,000 deaths. The Trump administration and local officials have wavered on the issue of face masks since the pandemic broke out.

site_title: Singapore's richest man gains US$3.5b with ventilators
summary: Singapore's richest man, Li Xiting, has added $3.5 billion to his net worth this year due to the surge in demand for ventilators amid the COVID-19 pandemic. His company, Mindray Bio-Medical Electronics, has seen its shares climb 40% as the global health crisis exposes a shortage of ventilators. Meanwhile, Jeff Bezos is up $3.4 billion and Bill Gates is down $15.3 billion, as the pandemic continues to impact economies worldwide, with over 52,000 deaths and 1 million infections reported globally.

site_title: Australia: Shares give up early gains amid virus fears; energy stocks jump
summary: Australian shares rose 1.8% on Friday before trading flat, driven by a jump in energy stocks amid a record overnight rally in crude oil futures. The S&P/ASX 200 index is on track for its biggest weekly gain since 2011. Energy stocks surged 10% on the back of US President Donald Trump's comments on Saudi Arabia and Russia potentially announcing major oil production cuts. Meanwhile, fears of a global economic recession and record jobless claims in the US weighed on financials, with the "Big Four" banks trading lower.

site_title: China's services activity shrinks further in March, job cuts fastest on record
summary: China's services sector continued to contract in March, with the Caixin/Markit services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rebounding to 43 from a record low of 26.5 in February, but still in contraction territory. Job cuts accelerated to the fastest pace on record, with export orders slumping again due to virus containment measures. The sector, which accounts for 60% of China's economy, remains under pressure, with businesses cutting prices and pessimistic about the crisis duration.

site_title: US records 1,169 virus fatalities, new global daily high: Johns Hopkins University
summary: The US recorded 1,169 Covid-19 fatalities in a 24-hour period, surpassing Italy's previous record, according to Johns Hopkins University. This brings the US total to 5,926 deaths. Over 30,000 new cases were reported, with the country's total exceeding 243,000. Globally, Italy still holds the highest death toll, with Spain second. The US is nearing 50,000 positive cases in New York City, with over 1.3 million tests conducted nationwide.

site_title: Japan service sector activity slumps most in a decade as virus impact spreads
summary: Japan's services sector contracted at the fastest pace since the 2009 global financial crisis due to the coronavirus pandemic, with the final seasonally adjusted au Jibun Bank Japan Services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 33.8 in March from 46.8 in the previous month. The sector's business expectations and new business also plummeted, with the economy on the brink of recession and GDP expected to contract at an annual rate of around 8% in the first quarter. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has ordered a package of economic support measures amid the crisis.

site_title: Golden Energy raises stake in Stanmore Coal to 51% as part of takeover bid
summary: Golden Energy Resources (Gear) has raised its stake in Australian coal producer Stanmore Coal to 51% after purchasing approximately 50.3 million shares at A$1 apiece. This move makes Stanmore Coal a subsidiary of Gear and its subsidiaries. Gear's renewed takeover offer was announced the day before the share purchases, which represent about 19.7% of Stanmore Coal's shares.

site_title: Petrobras logistics unit mulls suspending some operations: memo
summary: Transpetro, the logistics unit of Petrobras, is considering suspending some operations and downsizing its real estate footprint as part of a cost-cutting plan to ensure short-term liquidity. The plan aims to save 507 million reais (S$137.9 million) through operational expenses, investments, and human resources costs. The move comes amid the coronavirus pandemic's impact on oil demand and prices, with Brent crude at US$25 per barrel. The plan also includes measures such as renegotiating contracts, optimising assets, and increasing remote work.

site_title: Airline industry braces for prolonged recovery from coronavirus crisis
summary: The airline industry is bracing for a prolonged recovery from the coronavirus crisis, with international seat capacity down 80% and half the world's airplanes in storage. Airlines, including United Airlines and Air New Zealand, warn of possible bankruptcies and a shift to uneconomic discounts to attract demand. Industry growth lost over several years is expected to take until 2022 or 2023 to recover, with planemakers considering drastic cuts in wide-body production.

site_title: US high-grade corporate bond issuance sets weekly record
summary: US corporate bond issuers set a record weekly issuance of $110.50 billion, surpassing the previous record of $109.10 billion. The surge in borrowing is driven by fears of the coronavirus pandemic limiting access to capital markets. The Federal Reserve and Treasury Department's stimulus measures have boosted the investment-grade debt market, but investors may lose appetite for corporate debt as default rates for riskier companies are expected to triple to 10% by December.

site_title: FairPrice to reopen Bedok Mall outlet on April 4 after virus-related deep clean
summary: FairPrice's FairPrice Finest outlet in Bedok Mall will reopen on April 4 after a three-day deep clean following a staff member testing positive for Covid-19. The store has been thoroughly disinfected and wiped down, with all staff on leave of absence. Non-packaged perishable food has been disposed of to prevent cross-contamination. The store will be staffed by volunteers from other stores, including those from FairPrice's headquarters, to minimize customer exposure.

site_title: UK plugs loan gap for firms teetering under coronavirus strain
summary: British Finance Minister Rishi Sunak is set to address a gap in government support for businesses struggling due to the coronavirus outbreak. Medium-sized companies with annual turnovers between £45m and £500m can apply for loans of up to £25m from banks with an 80% government guarantee. This move aims to prevent up to 18% of small and medium-sized enterprises from collapsing. The new loan scheme aims to provide crucial support for businesses teetering on the brink of collapse, amid a significant economic hit from the pandemic.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after US gains on oil price spike
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, following a four-day decline, driven by a cheaper yen and US gains on a spike in oil prices. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.22% to 18,036.77, while the Topix index gained 1.19% to 1,345.63.

site_title: Disney to furlough some US employees in wake of coronavirus
summary: Walt Disney will furlough non-essential US employees starting April 19, due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak affecting its media and theme park businesses. Despite previously committing to full pay and benefits through April 18, Disney made the decision to reduce staffing to conserve resources. Affected employees will remain Disney employees, receive full healthcare benefits, and have their healthcare premiums covered by the company. The exact number of employees to be furloughed is not specified.

site_title: Wuhan official preaches vigilance as China plans to mourn coronavirus 'martyrs'
summary: China's top official in Wuhan warns residents to maintain self-protection measures amid concerns of a potential second wave of coronavirus infections. The city is set to ease travel curbs on April 8, but officials remain vigilant. China will hold a national mourning on April 4 for "martyrs" who died in the fight against the epidemic, with three minutes of silence and air raid sirens. The country has reported 81,589 confirmed cases and 3,318 deaths, with a total of 1 million cases worldwide.

site_title: Singtel eyes sale of A$2b Australia tower portfolio: report
summary: Singtel is reportedly considering the sale of its Australian telecommunications tower portfolio worth over A$2 billion. The sale, which could take place in the first half of this year, would free up cash for Singtel to pay dividends or invest in growth markets. Analysts expect the deal to deleverage the balance sheet, with negligible impact on net profit and earnings per share. Interested buyers include Australian and offshore infrastructure funds, with asset manager Macquarie Infrastructure and Real Assets reportedly exploring a potential bid.

site_title: Trump negative for coronavirus again, orders military to New York
summary: US President Donald Trump underwent a second coronavirus test, which showed he is not infected. Trump, who had initially downplayed the virus, announced plans to deploy the US military and federal personnel to set up a makeshift hospital in New York to address the city's surge in cases. The city has over 47,000 confirmed cases, and the government will send N-95 masks to the public hospital system to aid medical workers. Trump also used the Defense Production Act to order companies to produce hospital ventilators and N-95 masks.

site_title: Brazil turns to China for help in coronavirus fight, eyes US cooperation
summary: Brazil is turning to China for help in its fight against the coronavirus, ordering 1.2 billion reais ($328.5 million) worth of medical and protective equipment, with deliveries expected in 30 days. The move comes as Brazil faces a low stock of supplies and clashes with President Jair Bolsonaro over the government's approach to the crisis. The country is also seeking cooperation with the US, with discussions underway for Brazilian firms to produce face masks for use in both countries.

site_title: Oil posts biggest one-day gains after Trump touts Saudi-Russia oil deal
summary: US crude prices surged 24.7% to $25.32 a barrel, while Brent futures rose 21.0% to $29.94, as President Trump announced a potential oil production cut deal between Saudi Arabia and Russia, aiming to stabilize the market. The deal, which could cut output by 10-15 million barrels, would require participation from other major producers. Despite the gains, oil prices have lost over half their value this year due to the coronavirus pandemic and low fuel demand.

site_title: US Navy relieves aircraft carrier commander who wrote letter urging coronavirus action
summary: The US Navy relieved Captain Brett Crozier, commander of the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt, after a letter he wrote to the Pentagon criticizing the Navy's handling of a coronavirus outbreak on the ship was leaked to the public. The letter called for stronger measures to control the outbreak, including isolating over 4,000 sailors. Acting US Navy Secretary Thomas Modly said Captain Crozier exercised poor judgment in sending the letter broadly, which raised alarm bells unnecessarily. The move has sparked criticism, with some saying it could have a chilling effect on others in the Navy who want to speak up about issues.

images.alt_text: The US Navy on Thursday relieved the commander of the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt, who wrote a scathing letter that leaked to the public asking for stronger measures to control a coronavirus outbreak onboard his warship.

site_title: Flower Power
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels has introduced new designs to its Frivole collection, inspired by flowers to mark Spring's arrival. The 7-flower bracelet in yellow gold and diamonds features seven corollas, adding elegance to any outfit. The collection includes earrings, necklaces, and rings, all adorned with heart-shaped petals and mirror-polished gold. Available from S$10,000, the Frivole collection is now available at Van Cleef & Arpels boutiques.

site_title: US: Oil jump lifts Wall St as jobless claims data surges
summary: US stocks rose 2.24% on Thursday, driven by a 24.7% gain in US crude futures and a 21.5% increase in Brent crude. The S&P 500 gained 2.28% and the Nasdaq Composite added 1.72%. Despite a surge in jobless claims data, with 6.65 million Americans filing claims last week, investors were lifted by hopes of a truce in the oil price war and a potential cut in oil output. Oil companies saw significant gains, with Occidental Petroleum surging 18.90%.

site_title: Edible Haute Couture
summary: Natsuko Shoji, a 30-year-old pastry chef from Tokyo, has been named Asia's Best Pastry Chef 2020 by the annual Asia's 50 Best Restaurants guide. Inspired by high fashion, Shoji's edible creations feature premium Japanese fruit and are priced from $150 to $2000. Her restaurant, én, has gained a cult following despite being small, and she aims to be a role model for female chefs in Japan, who are underrepresented in the industry. Shoji's success has come with sacrifices, including borrowing money from the bank and working hard to support her family.

images.alt_text: Natsuko Shoji's creations emulate designer handbags' iconic patterns
The interiors of été's dining salon and cake lab.
The interiors of été's dining salon and cake lab.

site_title: WeWork's troubles deepen as SoftBank pulls US$3b tender offer
summary: SoftBank has terminated a $3 billion tender offer for WeWork shares, citing criminal and civil probes, restructuring issues, and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. WeWork's board is considering legal action, and the decision plunges the company further into crisis. The withdrawal also means SoftBank is no longer obligated to provide an additional $1.1 billion in debt financing. WeWork is undergoing drastic restructuring, and its earnings are at risk due to the pandemic.

site_title: Keep calm and carry on shopping
summary: Singapore's fashion brands face challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic, including disrupted supply chains and reduced consumer spending. To adapt, many are shifting to online sales and local support. Local designers emphasize the importance of consumers promoting their brands on social media to maintain sales. Some brands, like Minor Miracles, are implementing unique marketing strategies, such as "try-before-you-buy" campaigns. Experts advise brands to focus on customer service and long-term solutions, rather than aggressive marketing and heavy discounting.

images.alt_text: The Missing Piece X Matter Prints.

site_title: EU announces work scheme to combat Covid-19 impact
summary: The European Commission proposed a package of measures to soften the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on the EU economy, including a short-time work scheme and easier access to funds for farmers and fishermen. The scheme, modeled after Germany's, would allow employers to cut working hours instead of jobs, with the government paying for the difference in salaries. The Commission would borrow 100 billion euros and lend it to member states, with some funds allocated to farmers and fishermen. The measures aim to prevent widespread job losses and support the economy during the pandemic.

site_title: US vehicle sales headed for crash after slowest pace in a decade
summary: US vehicle sales are projected to crash due to the prolonged factory shutdown, with sales at the slowest pace in a decade. The industry sold vehicles at a seasonally adjusted annualized rate of 11.4 million in the first quarter, with General Motors and Fiat Chrysler reporting 7.1% and 10% declines, respectively. Analysts predict a slow recovery as the global pandemic continues to impact consumer confidence and the US labor market.

site_title: Hong Kong business activity slumps further in March as virus pummels economy
summary: Hong Kong's business activity continued to decline in March, with the private sector experiencing its second-sharpest deterioration since 1998. The adjusted Hong Kong Purchasing Manager's Index (PMI) rose to 34.9, but still signaled severe contraction. Retail sales plummeted 44% in February, and new orders and production were severely impacted by the coronavirus pandemic. Business confidence fell to its second-lowest, with 59% predicting lower output over the next 12 months. The downturn is expected to worsen in the second quarter due to potential anti-virus measures.

images.alt_text: Business activity in Hong Kong deteriorated further in March, a private survey showed on Friday, as demand, output and confidence plunged amid the deepening coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: WeWork asks landlords to slash rent bill by up to 30%
summary: WeWork is in talks with major landlords to reduce rent liabilities by up to 30%. CEO Sandeep Mathrani is proposing revenue-sharing agreements to resolve the issue. The company is seeking solutions to its substantial rent burden, which has been a challenge since its bankruptcy in 2019. WeWork is seeking to restructure its agreements with landlords to make its operations more sustainable.

site_title: Gold dealers report big shortages of bars, coins
summary: Gold dealers are experiencing significant shortages of small gold bars and coins, mainly due to surging demand and disruptions caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. Retail investors are seeking kilobars, one-ounce bars, and coins, but supply is limited. Premiums in the retail market have skyrocketed, with prices 10-15% above spot prices, and some dealers are struggling to find sellers. The shortage has led to desperate attempts to contact clients, with many dealers offering high premiums to buyers.

site_title: Trump touts 'great' Saudi-Russia oil deal to halt price rout, but details unclear
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a deal with Saudi Arabia and Russia to cut 10-15 million barrels of oil per day, representing 10-15% of global supply, to halt the oil price rout amid the coronavirus pandemic. The deal, brokered by Trump, aims to stabilize oil markets and prevent further price drops, with global demand expected to fall by 30 million barrels per day in April. However, details of the deal, including the participation of US oil companies, are unclear, and the move faces opposition from some producers, including Canada.

site_title: Singapore reports 49 new Covid-19 cases, three new clusters
summary: Singapore reported 49 new Covid-19 cases, including 41 local and 8 imported cases, bringing the total confirmed cases to 1,049. Three new clusters were identified, including Mustafa Centre, Maxwell MRT station, and Keppel Shipyard. The country also reported its fourth death from the virus, a 68-year-old Indonesian man with underlying health conditions. A total of 266 cases have been discharged, with 464 remaining in hospital, mostly stable or improving.

site_title: US Fed balance sheet increases to record US$5.86t
summary: The US Federal Reserve's balance sheet has reached a record $5.86 trillion, increasing by $1.5 trillion in three weeks amid the coronavirus pandemic. The central bank has snapped up Treasury securities, mortgage bonds, and other assets, with holdings rising to $3.34 trillion and mortgage-backed securities to $1.46 trillion. Use of liquidity facilities also increased, with foreign central banks exchanging local currency for dollars and loan balances for the Fed's discount window dropping slightly. The Fed's efforts aim to keep markets functioning smoothly amidst heightened volatility.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve's balance sheet increased to a record US$5.86 trillion this week and the central bank reported greater use of some of its newly launched liquidity facilities, all part of its efforts to keep markets functioning smoothly amid heightened volatility related to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Towards a truly wireless future
summary: Researchers are developing gallium nitride, or GaN, a next-generation material that has the potential to revolutionize the semiconductor industry. GaN could enable exponential increases in power, making it a key component in a truly wireless future. This breakthrough could have significant implications for industries such as electronics, electric cars, and telecommunications. As the world moves towards a more wireless future, GaN could play a crucial role in driving innovation and growth.

site_title: Covid-19: New laws to compel landlords to pass on property tax rebate
summary: Singapore is set to introduce new laws requiring non-residential landlords to pass on full property tax rebates to tenants. The move aims to address concerns that landlords were not sharing the rebate with tenants. Businesses, including the Singapore Retailers Association, have welcomed the legislation, calling it "long overdue". Tenants, however, have expressed that the rebate amount is insufficient, and negotiations with landlords will continue. The new laws are seen as a positive step, but the effectiveness of the measure remains to be seen.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Sustainable hotels of the future
summary: A Money FM podcast discussed sustainable hotels of the future. The episode highlighted innovative hotels that prioritize environmental sustainability. Examples included hotels with green roofs, rainwater harvesting systems, and waste reduction programs. The conversation explored the role of hotels in promoting a zero-waste lifestyle and reducing carbon footprints. The podcast aimed to inspire a new generation of travelers and hoteliers to adopt sustainable practices. Key takeaways included the importance of corporate social responsibility and the potential for hotels to be leaders in environmental sustainability.

site_title: Trendlines sells ApiFix stake in its largest exit since IPO
summary: Trendlines Group, a Singapore-based startup incubator, sold its 18.62% stake in ApiFix, a scoliosis treatment company, to OrthoPediatrics for an undisclosed amount. This marks Trendlines' largest exit by value since its IPO in 2015, surpassing its second-largest exit in 2016. The deal is a significant milestone for Trendlines, demonstrating its ability to generate substantial returns on its investments.

site_title: Living in a Designer Space
summary: Two Singapore-based fashion labels, Minor Miracles and Adrian Furstenburg, showcase the benefits of combining work and home spaces. Minor Miracles founder Dawn Bey lives and works in a rented 1960s terrace house, where she shares a studio and retail space with her husband Jason Song. The space features eclectic decor, including a peg board for fabrics and curtains that double as a fitting room. Meanwhile, Adrian Furstenburg, a handbag designer, has designed his home to inspire creativity, incorporating elements of his heritage and European influences. Both entrepreneurs value the flexibility and energy that comes with working from home.

site_title: Greenback maintains gains after weeks of rally
summary: The US dollar maintained its gains after weeks of rally, but paused its upward momentum, as the Federal Reserve helped improve dollar liquidity in financial markets. The US now has over 200,000 confirmed Covid-19 cases, driving investors to safe-haven assets like the dollar. Analysts expect the dollar rally to continue but not further, following the Fed's liquidity injections. The euro and yen fell against the dollar, while the Norwegian crown advanced to a three-week high.

site_title: STI claws back early losses to end higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 12.76 points or 0.52% higher at 2,453.03, rebounding from early losses driven by higher oil prices and a strong European opening. The STI's blue-chip index was boosted by gains from telcos, including Singtel and Netlink NBN Trust, while real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) declined. The market awaits March manufacturing data from China, Japan, Australia, and Singapore on Friday.

site_title: UK lenders confront biggest mortgage test since 2008 crash
summary: UK lenders are facing their biggest mortgage test since the 2008 financial crisis due to the pandemic's impact on the housing market. With home prices forecast to fall by up to 10% this year, lenders' customers' creditworthiness is being questioned. The government's Help to Buy scheme, which provided £14.3 billion in loans to buyers with small down payments, may lead to losses if prices fall. The economic paralysis could cost up to 700,000 jobs, with the unemployment rate reaching 6% and affecting the most vulnerable regions, particularly the north of England.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims jump to record of over 6 million
summary: US jobless claims surge to record 6.648 million, surpassing 6 million for the first time, as more states enforce stay-at-home measures to curb the coronavirus pandemic. Economists predict the economy has entered a recession, with initial claims for state unemployment benefits jumping 3.341 million. The US Labor Department reported 10 million jobless claims in the last two weeks, with the unemployment rate forecast to rise to 3.8% in March.

site_title: Keeping vigilant against cyber scams and online lies
summary: Cyber-criminals and fake news peddlers are exploiting the coronavirus pandemic, launching malicious cyberattacks and spreading false information on social media. In Singapore, phishing calls and false news about government payments and safe distancing measures have been reported. Globally, 4,000 coronavirus-related domains have been registered, with 3% deemed malicious and 5% suspicious. Fake news has led to harm, such as Iranians ingesting toxic alcohol to prevent Covid-19. The government urges people to verify information, use common sense, and report suspicious messages to safeguard themselves and their families from online scams and falsehoods.

site_title: Oil price surges as Trump talks up potential Saudi-Russia truce
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed optimism about a potential Saudi-Russia truce, which led to an 8% surge in oil prices, with Brent rising 7.6% to $26.63 a barrel and US crude increasing 7.8% to $21.90. However, gains were limited by fears of a global recession due to the coronavirus. The price increase was also partly due to Trump's recent tariff announcements, including fresh tariffs on Canada and threats to others. Despite the oil price jump, markets remain volatile due to ongoing economic concerns.

site_title: Reits sold down as investors fret over challenges facing landlords
summary: Singaporean Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) fell on Thursday as investors fretted over challenges facing landlords. The government's plan to legislate property tax rebates for tenants has introduced uncertainty in the retail sector. REITs such as Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Mapletree Commercial Trust, and CapitaLand Mall Trust plummeted in value, with some experiencing declines of up to 13.3%. DBS Research warned of potential cuts in payout ratios and downgraded its calls on several REITs, citing the need for landlords to conserve cash amidst worsening operational outlooks.

site_title: Tee Int'l needs to step up corporate governance
summary: Tee International Limited (TIL) faces criticism for inadequate corporate governance following an investigation into questionable transactions involving its controlling shareholder and former CEO, Phua Chian Kin. The investigation, led by PricewaterhouseCoopers, uncovered unexplained remittances between 2018 and 2019. Despite the findings, key figures involved in the transactions remain in key posts, raising concerns over internal control and risk management.

site_title: Japan PM's latest coronavirus move riles social media
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe offered free cloth masks to households, two per household, amid growing frustration over his handling of the coronavirus crisis. Experts warned Japan was on the brink of a medical crisis as cases rose, especially in Tokyo. Abe's move was criticized on social media, with many calling for a state of emergency declaration. The prime minister claimed Japan was "barely holding the line" in its battle against the virus, but his handling of the crisis has sparked growing discontent.

site_title: Red hot demand forces RedMart to suspend new orders, Specialty Stores marketplace
summary: RedMart, a Singapore-based online grocer, has suspended new orders until Saturday due to high demand triggered by the Covid-19 outbreak. The company also suspended its RedMart Specialty Stores (RSS) online marketplace, which allows small businesses to sell grocery items, until further notice. RedMart will prioritize daily essentials, limit deliveries to specific days and times, and restrict order quantities to ensure timely delivery and minimize physical contact. The company aims to provide customers with access to daily necessities during this time.

site_title: Central banks' rate cuts cascade down to Singapore banks' key deposit accounts
summary: Singapore banks have cut interest rates on their flagship deposit accounts amid the global economic slowdown due to the COVID-19 pandemic. UOB reduced rates across the board on its UOB One Account starting May 1, with maximum effective interest rates falling to 1.8% per annum. DBS cut rates on its Multiplier account, while OCBC raised rates tied to salary crediting and lowered thresholds for other bonuses. The rate cuts reflect the weaker interest rate environment globally, with central banks including the US Federal Reserve and Singapore Interbank rates also falling.

site_title: Warm comfort at Summer Hill
summary: Summer Hill, a French bistro eatery in Singapore, offers hearty comfort food at affordable prices. The restaurant, run by ex-Cocotte chef Anthony Yeoh, serves a three-course set lunch and dinner for S$29, featuring dishes like roast chicken, seafood stew, and duck fat aglio olio. With a cozy patio and no-frills atmosphere, Summer Hill has become a neighborhood favorite, appealing to locals who appreciate its simple, no-frills comfort food and sense of community. Takeaway options are also available, with pre-cooked meals and DIY kits. Rating: 7.

site_title: Time to give Singapore's fair tenancy framework legislative bite
summary: The Singapore government is introducing new legislation to address the perceived imbalance of power between landlords and tenants, following five years of guidelines aimed at halting unfair leasing practices. The proposed provisions will address issues such as unfair clauses and rent-free months, and require property owners to pass on property tax rebates to their tenants. The move comes after Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat urged landlords to fully pass on the rebates, and comes as the government seeks to even the playing field after years of relying on voluntary compliance.

site_title: Countries must form a solidarity front to save the world
summary: Countries must form a unified front to mitigate the global impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, which has killed over 47,000 people and crippled the economy. The crisis requires wealthy nations to support the poor and economically insecure, young people to make sacrifices for the elderly, and rich countries to accept resource transfers to poor countries. If these conditions are met, the world can minimize the fallout. However, this outcome is uncertain, highlighting the need for global cooperation and solidarity in the face of the pandemic's devastating effects.

site_title: New Labour leader venturing into a landscape of change
summary: The UK's Labour Party is set to announce its new leader on Saturday, with Keir Starmer widely anticipated to win the contest. The new leader will face significant challenges, including a transformed political landscape due to the COVID-19 crisis and a struggling economy. Prime Minister Boris Johnson's popularity has surged in recent weeks, but his handling of the crisis has been criticized. The new Labour leader must navigate a party still recovering from its election defeat and a core fact that it has not won an election for nearly half a century. A looming recession and potential economic downturn may also create opportunities for Labour.

site_title: A history of beauty
summary: The Asian Civilisations Museum has opened two new galleries, one on fashion and jewellery, and another on Chinese dress from the late Qing to the mid-1970s. The galleries feature over 300 exquisite garments, accessories, and decorative art pieces, including a stunning peacock belt made of gold and diamonds and intricately designed Chinese qipao. The museum's director, Kennie Ting, describes the new galleries as "literally the crowning glory" of the museum, highlighting the significance of fashion and jewellery as markers of identity and communal and personal identity.

site_title: China's traders cash out as love for risky assets fades
summary: China's investors are cashing out of stocks, with borrowed money in stock accounts falling 3.5% month-on-month in March to 1.1 trillion yuan. Stock turnover has plummeted 60% from a February peak, as traders shift to bonds and cash-like instruments, predicting a slow recovery for stocks. The country's economy may be restarting, but external demand slumps and stimulus measures are deemed insufficient to boost domestic growth. Investors are seeking better liquidity and returns in alternative markets, such as the repo market and convertible bonds.

site_title: Deeper pay and fee cuts for SIAEC management, directors
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) has implemented deeper pay cuts for its management and directors, with CEO pay reduced to 25% from 12% and executive pay reduced to 20% from 10%. Directors have also volunteered a 25% fee cut. The company has also introduced additional measures to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, including varying days of compulsory no-pay leave, furlough for staff on re-employment contracts, and deferment of salary increments and promotions.

images.alt_text: The company has been working closely with its union on additional measures - such as varying days of compulsory no-pay leave, furlough for staff on re-employment contracts and deferment of salary increments and promotions.

site_title: Shorting on the SGX: Have full transparency on such trades, big or small
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has been criticized for not banning short selling, unlike many European and regional exchanges. The author, Tan Song Huat, argues that short selling should be allowed with full transparency to safeguard market participants. The current rules allow for exemptions, which can lead to opacity and abuse, and Tan calls for the removal of these exemptions and stricter reporting requirements for overnight short sell trades. He also advocates for heavy penalties for non-compliance and improved lending practices to ensure full transparency and fair market practice.

site_title: Keppel Land, Keppel Reit commit to fully pass on property tax rebate to office, retail tenants
summary: Keppel Land and Keppel Reit, a Singaporean real estate investment trust, have committed to fully passing on the property tax rebate to their office and retail tenants to support them during the Covid-19 outbreak. The companies will pass on the rebate savings to tenants, with office tenants receiving 100% of the rebate and retail tenants receiving an additional 30% of rental rebates. The move aims to support tenants during a challenging period, with Keppel Land's CEO Tan Swee Yiow stating the company is standing firmly behind its tenants.

site_title: Moody's cuts outlook for Australian banks
summary: Moody's downgraded Australia's banking system outlook to "negative" from "stable" due to expected increased loan losses and record low interest rates caused by the coronavirus. The "Big Four" banks, which generate most of their earnings from home loans, face intense pressure on margins. Strong capital positioning and asset quality will initially help ward off credit losses, but prolonged economic disruptions could erode capital levels and lead to more impairments.

site_title: Betting on the market's daily ups and downs
summary: Singapore traders are utilizing Daily Leverage Certificates (DLCs) to bet on market fluctuations amid COVID-19 uncertainties. DLCs, a Specified Investment Product, allow qualified investors to trade intraday or short-term moves. The certificates are available for retail investors who meet specific educational or professional requirements. As market volatility persists, DLCs have become a popular tool for traders seeking to capitalize on daily market fluctuations.

site_title: Golden Energy unit makes 2nd attempt to take over Stanmore Coal
summary: Golden Energy's unit, Golden Investments, is making a second attempt to acquire Australia-listed Stanmore Coal, offering A$1 per share. The offer, worth up to A$185.8 million, is a 22-27% premium to Stanmore Coal's closing price. The offer period starts on April 17 and ends on May 18. Stanmore Coal's board has recommended shareholders take no action, but analysts say long-term investors will likely hold on due to the intrinsic value of met coal.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singaporean property developers Hiap Hoe, Heeton Holdings, and Tee International will hold virtual annual general meetings due to COVID-19 restrictions. Hiap Hoe will cease leisure-business operations until April 30, while Heeton Holdings will limit shareholder participation to online proxy submissions. Tee International will allow online pre-registration for its extraordinary general meeting. The measures aim to minimize the spread of the virus.

site_title: India's emergency aid package a timely one
summary: India has launched a $22.5 billion emergency aid package to provide food and cash to millions of its poorest workers during the 21-day nationwide lockdown. The package aims to support 800 million people, but experts warn that the cumulative economic impact of the lockdown could be devastating, with estimated losses of $120 billion and a 4% decline in the country's GDP. The government must consider a backup package if the lockdown is extended beyond 21 days, with economists estimating that 136 million non-agricultural jobs are at immediate risk.

site_title: Singapore SMEs' business optimism hits lowest since 2009: Poll
summary: Singaporean SMEs are experiencing the lowest levels of business optimism since 2009, according to the SBF-Experian SME Index. The index recorded a historic low of 48.3 for the upcoming two quarters of this year, indicating that SMEs expect less business activity in the coming six months. Business services and construction are seen as the most resilient sectors, while the outlook for manufacturing and trade is less optimistic. This decline in business confidence is attributed to the ongoing impact of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Food, grocery delivery startups struggle with order deluge amid virus outbreak
summary: The COVID-19 outbreak has led to a surge in demand for grocery and food delivery services in Singapore, causing logistical strain on startups such as RedMart. To address the issue, RedMart has suspended new orders for two days and is updating its system to ensure delivery slots remain available. Industry watchers warn that the increased capacity may become excess capacity once the outbreak subsides, prompting players to reassess their systems and potentially leading to consolidation in the market.

site_title: Woman of Substance and Style: Prescription for Caring
summary: Fertility specialist Dr. Ann Tan, 57, is a compassionate and dedicated doctor who extends her care beyond babies to youths and women in need. Despite the COVID-19 crisis, she continues to work with patients, often deferring non-urgent treatments. Dr. Tan is a strong advocate for social egg freezing and increasing women's control over their fertility. Outside of her work, she supports disadvantaged youths through her involvement with the Halogen Foundation and other charitable organizations. She emphasizes the importance of kindness and self-care during the pandemic.

site_title: Spring Summer Accessories Report 2020
summary: The Spring Summer Accessories Report 2020 highlights key fashion trends. Oversized totes and cross-body bags dominate menswear, while women's styles feature pearly headbands, long necklaces, and chunky sunglasses. The trend also sees a resurgence of lug-soled boots, traditionally worn by women, and the revival of the James Brown and Diana Ross era's oversized sunglasses. To complete the look, accessories like chunky socks, tassels, and sequins add glamour. The report showcases the latest styles from top designers, including Bottega Veneta, Versace, and Salvatore Ferragamo.

site_title: Trump says Florida will evacuate stranded cruise ships
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to evacuate passengers from two stranded cruise ships, Zaandam and Rotterdam, due to dock in Florida, after being barred from several South American countries. Trump stated that the US will send medical teams on board and take people off, with foreigners sent home. About 1,200 non-ill passengers will be sent home on charter planes, while 45 people with mild symptoms will remain on board and 10 requiring critical care will be taken ashore for treatment.

site_title: Secretive shoe Instagrammers
summary: Men's shoe Instagrammers tend to be professional and discreet, often posting images of their shoes without faces or commercial intentions. They frequently discuss the traditional craft of cordwaining, a rare and exquisite method of hand-making shoes. These individuals, typically in their 30s and 40s, have large followings, with some reaching five or six figures, and often adopt distinctive poses to set themselves apart from others. Their posts focus on showcasing shoe and sock combinations, as well as their appreciation for the craftsmanship of cordwaining.

site_title: Semun Ho, CEO, Textile And Fashion Federation
summary: Semun Ho, CEO of the Textile and Fashion Federation, emphasizes the challenges faced by young fashion designers in Singapore, citing high overheads, low volumes, and tough competition. With limited venture capital, designers struggle to scale up and find stability. Ho's organization provides resources, networking, and capability development to help designers overcome these hurdles. However, scaling up internationally is particularly complex due to regulations, cultural barriers, and market demand. Ho identifies tenacity, grit, and the ability to make decisions as key qualities for Singapore designers to succeed in the industry.

site_title: India's property prices face steep falls as coronavirus freezes market
summary: India's real estate market is expected to see a significant price correction due to the coronavirus pandemic, with prices potentially falling 10-20% across geographies and 30% for land prices. This would be the first major correction since the global financial crisis. The market has been stagnant due to a liquidity crunch and discounts offered by developers. The situation is severe, with unsold inventory worth 6 trillion rupees, and banks worried about potential defaults. The impact will be felt across residential and commercial properties, with the "survival of the fittest" being the key factor.

site_title: Covid-19 likely to hit real estate, office loans: Fed
summary: The US economy is likely to face significant challenges from the COVID-19 pandemic, including a cut in home and office building prices, a permanent shift in demand for office space, and increased defaults among households and companies. Boston Fed Reserve President Eric Rosengren warned that small businesses may be particularly vulnerable despite promised federal aid. His remarks offer a more pessimistic view of the crisis than some of his colleagues, who expect a rapid economic rebound if the health challenge is managed quickly.

site_title: Index DLCs on SGX see higher activity in March
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) saw a 50% increase in active participants for its daily leverage certificates (DLCs) in March, with short-selling dominating activities. The top three traded DLCs were 7x Short Hang Seng Index, 5x Short MSCI Singapore Free Index, and 7x Short Hang Seng China Enterprises Index, with turnovers of S$38 million, S$16 million, and S$15 million, respectively. The DLCs offer flexibility to trade both rising and falling markets with up to 7x leverage.

site_title: Finding comfort in a bottle of familiar wine
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, people have turned to wine and other beverages for comfort. A survey of wine and food experts found that comfort is not necessarily tied to a specific style of wine, but rather to the emotions and memories associated with it. Syrah wines from the Northern Rhône Valley, such as Domaine de Pergaud St Julien-en-St Alban Vieille Sérine, are particularly comforting due to their complex flavors and associations with childhood memories. Other experts cited bubbles, chardonnay, and family wines as sources of comfort, often tied to social connections and personal experiences.

site_title: EasyJet founder escalates spending row with challenge to board
summary: EasyJet founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou is calling for a shareholder meeting to oust director Andreas Bierwirth, citing a £4.5 billion aircraft order dispute. Haji-Ioannou, who owns 34% of the airline, has threatened to remove the board one-by-one if his demands aren't met. Bierwirth, a board member since 2014, has been involved in the aircraft order decision. This move escalates a spending row between Haji-Ioannou and the airline's management.

site_title: European experts ready smartphone technology to help stop Covid-19
summary: European experts are launching a smartphone technology platform, called PEPP-PT, to help track individuals who have come into contact with those infected with Covid-19. The initiative aims to identify those at risk of infection, allowing for swift action to halt the spread of the virus. The platform uses low-energy Bluetooth technology and respects European data protection rules, aiming to launch by April 7. This technology could help ease country-wide lockdowns and contain future Covid-19 flare-ups, according to epidemiologists.

site_title: Almost all bets are off as casino capitals Macau, Las Vegas are slammed by virus
summary: Casinos in Macau and Las Vegas are severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with thousands of tables closed and revenue plummeting. Macau's gaming revenue fell 80% in March, while Las Vegas casinos have been forced to close, leading to mass layoffs and financial strain. The global gaming industry has lost 51% of its value this year, with many operators struggling to stay afloat. Macau's government has pledged support to small businesses and workers, but the future of the industry remains uncertain, particularly with operating licenses set to expire in 2022.

site_title: US: Stocks sink after massive jump in jobless claims
summary: US stocks plummeted on Thursday, dropping 0.8% in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, 0.4% in the S&P 500, and 0.5% in the Nasdaq Composite Index. The staggering 6.65 million new unemployment claims exceeded expectations, indicating the worsening impact of the coronavirus pandemic on the US economy. The sharp decline in stocks contradicts recent optimism about the market's resilience and raises concerns about the economy's prospects.

site_title: Global air passenger demand sees steepest decline since 9/11
summary: Global air passenger demand plummeted 14% in February, the steepest decline since the 9/11 attacks in 2001, according to the International Air Transport Association. The drop was mainly driven by a collapse in domestic travel in China and sharply falling international demand in the Asia-Pacific region due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Airlines worldwide reduced capacity by 8.7% and airlines in the Asia-Pacific region suffered a 41% drop in demand. The industry faces an unprecedented crisis, with estimated losses of $61 billion in the second quarter.

site_title: Retail unit facing Tanglin Road sold for S$43m
summary: A freehold commercial unit fronting Tanglin Road in Singapore has been sold for S$43 million, with a 42% share value in the development. The buyer, D'League Pte Ltd, holds the Asia distributorship for luxury watch brand Richard Mille, indicating plans to open another watch showroom at the property. The sale marks a return by the brand near a location where it once had a presence.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.24 points to 1,330.90, closing higher on Thursday. Volume reached 5.103 billion lots worth RM2.416 billion, with 671 gainers outnumbering 203 losers. The rally comes despite global market uncertainty, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq near fresh records despite tariff concerns.

site_title: Coronavirus: US agency seeks 100,000 body bags
summary: The US main disaster response agency, FEMA, has requested 100,000 body bags from the Defence Department as the coronavirus death toll continues to rise. White House experts predict US deaths from the disease could reach 100,000 to 240,000, even with mitigation efforts. The request comes amid a surge in infections and deaths, particularly in New York City. President Trump has warned Americans of a "painful two weeks" ahead, urging preparedness.

site_title: MICE players call for higher wage offsets
summary: Singapore's MICE (Meetings, Incentive Travel, Conventions, and Exhibitions) industry contractors are calling for higher wage offsets, seeking 75% support, not the 25% base support offered to operators of purpose-built venues. They argue that their exclusion will hinder the industry's survival and ability to recover. Industry leaders stress the importance of supporting SMEs, citing talent shortages and limited alternative revenue streams. The Singapore Tourism Board and CIMB economist Song Seng Wun support the contractors' request, highlighting the sector's strategic importance to the country's tourism industry.

site_title: EU court: Solving housing shortage has priority over allowing Airbnb-type rentals
summary: The EU Court of Justice has ruled that European cities can prioritize solving housing shortages over allowing short-term rentals like those on Airbnb. The Luxembourg-based court's advocate-general stated that a shortage of long-term housing constitutes an overriding reason of public interest, justifying national measures to regulate short-term rentals. The ruling applies to cities like Paris, where Airbnb has over 60,000 listings, and allows authorities to vet such rentals to tackle housing shortages. The court's decision is non-binding, but judges typically follow four out of five recommendations, paving the way for cities to crack down on short-term rentals.

site_title: Antler to invest up to US$500,000 in startups tackling Covid-19
summary: Antler, a startup generator and venture-capital firm, plans to invest up to US$500,000 in up to five companies addressing the Covid-19 pandemic through mitigation, medical equipment, remote health monitoring, and digital tools. The funding call is open until April 15 and will consider solutions that minimize the pandemic's impact and have post-pandemic relevance. Antler's founder and CEO, Magnus Grimeland, sees this as an opportunity for innovators to come together for the greater good.

site_title: US factory orders unchanged in February
summary: US factory orders remained unchanged in February, defying economists' expectations of a 0.2% increase. This follows a 0.5% decline in January. The Institute for Supply Management reported a factory activity index of 49.1 in March, indicating contraction in the manufacturing sector, which accounts for 11% of the US economy. The coronavirus outbreak continues to strain supply chains, potentially keeping factory orders weak.

site_title: 49 new coronavirus cases; three new clusters including Mustafa Centre
summary: Singapore reported 49 new coronavirus cases on April 2, bringing the total to 1049. Three new clusters were identified, including Mustafa Centre, a construction site, and Keppel Shipyard. Of the 49 cases, 41 are local and eight are imported. The number of recovered cases is now 266, with 21 discharged from hospitals and community isolation facilities. A fourth person in Singapore has died from the virus, a 68-year-old Indonesian man with a history of diabetes and hypertension.

site_title: Tee International to hold EGM through live webcast
summary: Tee International will hold its extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on April 9 via a live webcast due to COVID-19 restrictions. Shareholders must pre-register their interest by April 7 and verify their status before receiving an email with a unique link to access the webcast. As the company's Constitution does not allow online voting, shareholders must submit proxy forms in advance to cast votes. The company also allows shareholders to submit questions to be raised during the meeting by the same deadline.

site_title: EU announces work scheme, aid for farmers, fishermen amid coronavirus pandemic
summary: The European Commission proposed a package of measures to mitigate the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic, including a short-time work scheme and aid for farmers and fishermen. The scheme, modeled after Germany's, would allow employers to cut working hours and have the government cover the difference in salaries. The Commission also proposed increased funding for farmers and fishermen, with the EU lending up to 100 billion euros to member states. The measures, which need approval from the European Parliament and EU member states, aim to protect thousands of jobs and maintain food security.

site_title: Heeton Holdings to hold AGM through live webcast
summary: Heeton Holdings will hold its annual general meeting (AGM) through a live webcast due to COVID-19 restrictions. Shareholders must pre-register their interest by April 21 to participate. Those who wish to vote on resolutions must submit proxy forms in advance. Shareholders can also submit questions via email by April 21. The company will provide a link to access the webcast at a later date.

site_title: Keppel Land and Keppel Reit commit to fully pass on property tax rebate to office and retail tenants
summary: Keppel Land and Keppel Reit have committed to fully passing on the property tax rebate to their office and retail tenants in Singapore, supporting them during the Covid-19 outbreak. The rebate, announced in Budget 2020, allows up to 100% tax relief for non-residential properties. The companies will also provide an additional 30% rental rebate to eligible retail tenants. The moves aim to provide relief to tenants as the companies navigate the challenges brought about by the pandemic.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims hit 6.65 million, record once again
summary: US weekly jobless claims reached a record high of 6.65 million for the second consecutive week, surpassing economists' median estimate of 3.50 million. The surge in claims is attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the economy, with over 80% of Americans under lockdown. Economists predict jobless claims to continue escalating, citing the government's fiscal package and eased requirements for workers to seek benefits. The unemployment rate is expected to rise, with a potential payroll job loss of over 16 million jobs, boosting the rate to 12.5% from its current 3.5%.

site_title: Planemakers brace for sharp cuts in wide-body output
summary: Planemakers Boeing and Airbus are expected to cut wide-body production amid a slump in demand for large jetliners due to the COVID-19 crisis. Deliveries of long-range jets have been particularly affected, with airlines deferring progress payments. Industry sources estimate a possible cut of at least half in Boeing's production rate. Airbus is also likely to adjust its production, but no decision has been made. A consultancy forecasts a surplus of 5,000 commercial aircraft once the crisis settles. Planemakers will need to balance supply and demand as the industry recovers over the coming years.

site_title: Ellis Marsalis Jr, jazz pianist and music family patriarch, dies at 85
summary: Jazz pianist and music family patriarch Ellis Marsalis Jr. has died at 85 due to complications from Covid-19. Marsalis, who spent decades as a working musician and teacher in New Orleans, played a pivotal role in the resurgence of traditional jazz in the late 20th century. His four musician sons, including Wynton and Branford, went on to achieve prominent careers, earning the National Endowment for the Arts' highest honor as NEA Jazz Masters in 2011. Marsalis' legacy as a musician and educator continues to be celebrated, with his children and students continuing his advocacy of traditional jazz.

site_title: JustCo offers members up to 30% fee rebates amid virus outbreak
summary: Singapore-headquartered co-working space operator JustCo is offering fee rebates to its members amid the coronavirus outbreak. Members who have been with the company for two years or more will receive a 30% rebate, while those who joined before April 1 will get a 15% rebate. The move aims to benefit over 3,000 companies across the Asia-Pacific region. JustCo's CEO, Kong Wan Sing, emphasized the need for landlords and tenants to share the burden of the current economic situation.

site_title: Luckin Coffee shares sink after COO suspended for alleged financial misconduct
summary: Luckin Coffee shares plummet 81% after suspending its COO and several employees for alleged financial misconduct, including fabricating transactions totaling 2.2 billion yuan (S$444.3 million) from 2019 to 2020. The suspensions follow an investigation into consolidated financial statements, with the company citing initial recommendations from a special committee. The incident has raised concerns about the company's accounting practices and its future prospects.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close over 2% higher on stimulus plans, oil market recovery
summary: South Korean shares rose 2.34% to 1,724.90, the sharpest gain in over a week, amid hopes that the coronavirus outbreak's worst may have passed. Additional stimulus plans and a recovery in oil markets boosted investor confidence. The US Federal Reserve temporarily eased leverage rules for large banks, and US Treasury Secretary mentioned infrastructure projects to combat the economic slowdown. Foreigners sold US$422.80 million worth of shares, but overall market sentiment remained positive.

site_title: Novartis, Aurobindo call off Sandoz sale
summary: Novartis and Aurobindo Pharma have cancelled a deal to sell Sandoz's US generic oral solids and dermatology businesses, citing lack of US Federal Trade Commission approval within anticipated timelines. The deal, valued at $900 million, was intended to refocus Sandoz's US business on higher-added value activities. Sandoz will continue to operate its oral solids and dermatology business as part of the Sandoz US business.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish on upbeat note
summary: Hong Kong shares finished on an upbeat note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.84% to 23,280.06, boosted by energy firms due to a surge in oil prices. Despite this, concerns over the coronavirus outbreak kept traders cautious. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw significant gains, rising 1.69% and 2.26% respectively.

site_title: Thai rice prices hit 7-year high on anticipated sales as coronavirus troubles rivals
summary: Thailand's rice prices have reached a 7-year high due to exporters' anticipation of increased sales amid coronavirus-related disruptions to rival countries. The benchmark 5% broken white rice price jumped from under $500 per tonne to around $560-$570 per tonne, with the Thai Rice Exporters Association quoting $564 per tonne, a 12% increase from last week. The higher prices are driven by a better export outlook, as India faces a lockdown and Vietnam bans new rice export contracts. The Philippines has also expressed interest in importing 300,000 tonnes.

site_title: Trendlines makes largest exit since IPO with ApiFix deal
summary: Trendlines Group, a Catalist-listed startup incubator, has sold its 18.62% stake in ApiFix, a scoliosis treatment company, to Nasdaq-listed OrthoPediatrics for US$39 million, its largest exit since IPO in 2015. The deal includes US$2 million in cash and 934,783 new shares, with additional guaranteed milestone payments and earnout payments of at least US$30 million over the next four years. The sale contributed positively to Trendlines' consolidated earnings per share and net assets per share for the 2019 financial year.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close down for 4th straight session
summary: Tokyo stocks fell for a fourth consecutive session, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index losing 1.37% to close at 17,818.72. The decline was attributed to concerns about rising coronavirus cases in Japan. The broader Topix index also dropped 1.57%. The losses followed a rout on Wall Street.

site_title: Gold dealers report big shortages of bars and coins most in demand
summary: Gold dealers are experiencing a shortage of small gold bars and coins due to high demand and disruptions from the coronavirus pandemic. Prices are skyrocketing, with some dealers offering a premium of up to 15% over spot prices. The shortage is mainly caused by the preference for smaller bars and coins, which are in high demand but difficult to find due to supply constraints and refinery closures. Buyers are willing to pay significantly more than market prices, with some kilobars selling for over 6% above spot prices.

site_title: China's Shenzhen bans the eating of cats and dogs after coronavirus
summary: Shenzhen, China, has banned the eating of dogs and cats, effective May 1, in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The ban aims to curb the wildlife trade, which scientists suspect contributed to the emergence of the virus. The decision follows China's top legislature's ban on the trade and consumption of wild animals in late February. Animal welfare groups praise Shenzhen's move, calling it a model for governments worldwide to emulate, and citing the potential to prevent future pandemics.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound slightly at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded slightly in early trading on Thursday, recovering from the previous day's coronavirus-fueled losses. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.7%, while the eurozone's Frankfurt DAX and Paris CAC 40 also gained 0.5% and 0.6%, respectively. The rebound came after US President Donald Trump warned of a "very, very painful two weeks" and amid concerns about the nation's rising death count from the coronavirus.

images.alt_text: Frankfurt's DAX added 0.5 per cent to 9,593.53 points.

site_title: Hiap Hoe shutters leisure-business operations, expects virus to weaken H1 2020 performance
summary: Singapore property developer Hiap Hoe will cease leisure-business operations until April 30 due to the COVID-19 outbreak. The company expects its first-half 2020 financial performance to be adversely impacted, with occupancy rates and operating performances weakened. Hiap Hoe will implement cost-containment measures and conserve cash flow by postponing non-essential capital expenditures. The company attributes its weak performance to increased border restrictions and social-distancing measures. Its shares closed 1.43% lower to 69 Singapore cents.

site_title: 'Shoot them dead': Duterte says he won't tolerate lockdown violators
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte warned violators of coronavirus lockdown measures that they could be shot dead for causing trouble. He emphasized the importance of cooperation and following home quarantine measures to slow the contagion and protect the country's fragile health system. Duterte's comments follow reports of a disturbance and arrests in a poor area of Manila and outrage among the medical community about social stigma and physical abuse of hospital workers. The national police chief clarified that no one would be shot, but Duterte's rhetoric has sparked concerns about inviting violence and vigilantism.

site_title: STI overturns early losses to end 0.5% higher on Thursday
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.5% higher on Thursday, despite early losses, as investors found support in higher oil prices and hopes for a resolution in the Saudi-Russia price war. The local blue-chip index ended at 2,453.03, with 14 of its 30 constituents ending in the red. S-Reits declined, but DBS Research preferred picks, such as Mapletree Commercial Trust and Lendlease Reit, showed resilience. Telcos, including Singtel, outperformed the market, while Netlink NBN Trust added 2.3% to its value.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend Wall St losses as traders eye growing crisis
summary: Asian markets extended losses on Wall Street, falling 0.8-2% as the coronavirus crisis deepens, with the US potentially seeing 250,000 deaths and global economies hit hard. China's true extent of the virus remains uncertain, fueling market volatility. The US jobless claims figures are expected to be released, with estimates ranging from 6.5 million, and investors remain uncertain about the recovery path, with a "V"-shaped recovery unlikely.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore plans to introduce a new law requiring property owners to pass on government-granted property tax rebates to tenants. The SBF-Experian SME Index shows business optimism among SMEs at a historic low of 48.3. RedMart has suspended new orders due to a surge in demand amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Enterprise Singapore has launched an e-commerce help package for retail SMEs, covering 90% of costs. SIA Engineering has implemented deeper pay cuts for management to reduce the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The STI closed 0.5% higher, overcoming early losses.

images.alt_text: It may soon be compulsory for property owners to pass the government-granted property tax rebates on to tenants, under a new legislation to be introduced in Parliament next week.

site_title: Japan not yet ready to declare virus emergency
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has decided not to declare a virus emergency despite a rise in coronavirus infections, citing the country's relatively low number of confirmed cases (about 2,400) and the need to inform lawmakers beforehand. Abe will work with local governments to tackle the infection and consider granting them more powers to control the flow of materials and people. The decision comes as the US has reported over 217,000 infections, and Japan's government believes the medical system will be strained if infection numbers increase.

site_title: Covid-19: Singapore plans new law to ensure landlords pass property tax rebates on to tenants
summary: Singapore plans to introduce a new law requiring landlords to pass on the full amount of government-granted property tax rebates to tenants. The law aims to prevent landlords from withholding rebates, which were announced in Budget 2020 to help tenants cope with the Covid-19 pandemic. The legislation will also ensure timely payment of rebates and prohibit conditions on passing on the rebate. Property owners who fail to comply will be guilty of an offence. A valuation review panel will settle disputes between landlords and tenants.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS says Singapore retail Reits 'in for rough ride'
summary: DBS Group Research has downgraded its expectations for Singapore retail Reits, citing rising consumer risk aversion and government measures amid the Covid-19 outbreak. The research team has downgraded Frasers Centrepoint Trust and CapitaLand Mall Trust to "hold", while keeping SPH Reit at "fully valued". However, it has maintained a "buy" call on Mapletree Commercial Trust and Lendlease Global Commercial Reit, with target prices of S$1.90 and S$0.94 respectively, citing diversified exposure and a "bombed out valuation".

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as recession fears knock risk appetite, NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 1.98% to 5,154.30, dragged down by the financials sector amid recession fears. US President Donald Trump's warning of a "painful" two weeks in fighting the coronavirus took a toll on risk sentiment. The benchmark's 3.6% gain from Wednesday was wiped out, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing lower. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in US markets.

site_title: Deeper pay cuts for SIA Engineering management to reduce Covid-19 impact
summary: SIA Engineering Company has implemented deeper pay cuts for its management, with CEO pay reduced to 25% from 12%, and executive vice-president pay cut to 20% from 10%. The company's directors have also volunteered a 25% reduction in fees. These measures aim to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the business. Additionally, the company is deferring non-essential costs, deferring salary increments, and offering a voluntary no-pay leave scheme to staff.

site_title: ARA takes prudent approach to investments during Covid-19
summary: ARA Asset Management, one of Asia's largest real estate fund managers, has paused its investment activities amid the COVID-19 pandemic, citing prolonged economic uncertainty. CEO John Lim noted that the crisis is "extremely trying times" but the group is "sniffing for opportunities" and has implemented business continuity measures to ensure staff safety. ARA manages S$88 billion in gross assets across 28 countries and has taken precautions such as team splitting and frequent office cleaning. The group has also acquired a majority stake in European investment manager Venn Partners.

site_title: HDB shuts Bukit Merah branch again after 2nd staff diagnosed with coronavirus
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has closed its Bukit Merah branch for the second time due to a second employee testing positive for the novel coronavirus. The first employee, who works in an administrative role, was confirmed to have Covid-19 on March 27. The agency is working closely with the Ministry of Health to conduct contact tracing. Customers with appointments at the office will be rescheduled.

site_title: Boeing to offer voluntary layoffs to employees to tide over coronavirus fallout: sources
summary: Boeing is set to offer buyout and early retirement packages to employees as part of a voluntary layoff plan to mitigate financial fallout from the coronavirus pandemic. The company, which has 150,000 employees worldwide, aims to preserve cash by freezing hiring and overtime pay in certain areas. The plan, expected to be detailed by CEO Dave Calhoun in a memo to employees as early as Thursday, comes after Boeing halted 737 production in January and operations at its Seattle factory due to COVID-19 cases. The move aims to reduce cash outflow and address the crisis following fatal crashes of the 737 Max.

site_title: Social dis-dance: clubbing goes online as virus shuts nightspots
summary: Singapore clubbers adapt to pandemic by going online, as social distancing measures force nightspots to shut. Innovative DJs now live-stream performances from closed nightclubs, allowing fans to continue dancing from home. This trend reflects the virus's impact on daily life, with 3.6 billion people stuck at home under lockdowns. The shift highlights the creativity and resilience of the nightlife industry in the face of the pandemic.

site_title: Disney+ content to make exclusive Middle East debut on OSN
summary: Disney+ content will make its exclusive Middle East debut on OSN's regional pay television and online streaming services on April 9. The deal grants OSN long-term exclusive distribution rights to Disney+ original programming, including 'The Mandalorian', in 17 regional markets, including Egypt, Lebanon, and the UAE. The online streaming service costs US$9.50 a month.

site_title: Moody's downgrades outlook for Australian banks due to coronavirus
summary: Moody's downgraded its outlook for Australia's banking system to 'negative' due to the impact of the coronavirus. The downgrade, from 'stable' to 'negative', is driven by expected increased provisions for loan losses and record low interest rates. Despite strong capital positioning, prolonged economic disruptions could erode capital levels and lead to impairments of home loans. The Australian government's stimulus measures may mitigate risks of loan defaults, but Moody's warns that the banks' profitability will be squeezed.

site_title: China interbank market to expedite debt sales: sources
summary: China's interbank market regulator plans to ease short-term financing rules, allowing more companies to simplify their bond sales procedures. The National Association of Financial Market Institutional Investors (NAFMII) will relax rules for short-term bills and medium-term notes, enabling companies to issue debt with maturity of less than 12 months. The move aims to counter competition from the stock exchange and help companies struggling in a virus-hit economy. NAFMII also plans to expand the number of "quality" companies, increasing the number to about 300 from 110 currently.

site_title: RedMart temporarily suspends new orders amid Covid-19 demand surge
summary: RedMart, an online grocery platform, has temporarily suspended new orders until Saturday due to a surge in demand amid the Covid-19 outbreak. The company will prioritize daily essentials like rice, flour, and eggs, and limit delivery slots to specific days and times based on location. Existing deliveries will still be fulfilled, and the company will update its system to manage the increased demand. This change aims to ensure timely delivery of essentials to consumers.

site_title: Casino capitals Macau, Las Vegas slammed by virus
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has severely impacted the global gaming industry, with casinos in Macau, Las Vegas, Australia, South Korea, the Philippines, and Cambodia forced to close. Macau's gaming revenue has plummeted 80% in March, while Las Vegas' casinos have lost millions in revenue daily. The US government's $454 billion financial assistance package may help affected businesses, but the future remains uncertain. In Macau, the government is supporting small businesses and workers financially, but casino operators are facing significant financial pressure ahead of their operating licence expirations in 2022.

site_title: South Korea to allow absentee voting for coronavirus patients in parliamentary elections
summary: South Korea is allowing coronavirus patients to vote by mail or as an absentee in the upcoming parliamentary elections on April 15. Approximately 4,000 patients receiving treatment will be able to cast their ballots via mail or early absentee voting. The government is taking measures to prevent the spread of the virus at polling places, including mask-wearing, sanitizing, and social distancing. This is the first time South Korea has allowed absentee voting for coronavirus patients in a parliamentary election.

site_title: China's fruit farmers hurt by lockdown losses as harvests rot
summary: China's fruit farmers are struggling due to lost crops from coronavirus lockdowns and a slow recovery in demand. Many small farmers without access to cold storage or producing quick-spoiling fruits have suffered significant losses, with some forced to dump produce worth hundreds of thousands of yuan. To mitigate losses, farmers are reducing plantings, switching crops, or taking other jobs. Industry experts say supply has recovered faster than demand, leading to lower prices and increased consolidation in the industry. Analysts predict many smallholders will leave the farming sector due to credit constraints and lack of hedge against the crisis.

site_title: Singapore shares resume decline; STI down 1.5% at open
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 1.5% to 2,402.74 at open on Thursday, following a decline from the previous day, amidst ongoing global market volatility due to the Covid-19 outbreak. Losers outnumbered gainers 104 to 26, with 38.4 million securities changing hands.

site_title: Business optimism among Singapore SMEs lowest since 2009
summary: Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) have reported the lowest business optimism since 2009, with the SBF-Experian SME Index registering 48.3 for the upcoming two quarters. Expectations declined across six of the seven indicators tracked, with the exception of hiring in the transport/storage sector. The retail/F&B sector saw the largest decrease in sentiment due to travel restrictions and social distancing measures. SMEs are adopting a wait-and-see approach to address the economic fallout from the Covid-19 outbreak, with a deeper contraction in business sentiment expected in the coming weeks.

site_title: Taiwan hopes US$35b stimulus package will be enough against coronavirus
summary: Taiwan is hoping a $35 billion stimulus package will be sufficient to protect its economy from the coronavirus pandemic, with Premier Su Tseng-chang stating it's "hard to say for sure" as the virus spreads globally. The island has reported 329 infections and five deaths, and its export-reliant economy has been affected. Taiwan expects to spend a total of $49.71 billion in stimulus measures, with a special budget of $150 billion to be approved by parliament. The government has also cut interest rates and provided financing to support companies battling the virus fallout.

site_title: Masks are everywhere in Asia, but have they helped?
summary: In Asia, widespread mask-wearing during the COVID-19 pandemic has been more prevalent than in the West, with experts debating its effectiveness.
